brief:
APPROX 0040, 03FEB01, M/V SARA EXPRESS ALLIDED W/ THE NORTH SPAN OF THE NW 5TH ST BRIDGE ON THE MIAMI RIVER WHILE BEING TOWED DEADSHIP BY THE TUGS ANNELIESE & JOSEPH A. SARA EXPRESS INCURRED DAMAGE TO ITS SIDESHELL PLATING & FRAMING IWO THE STBD AFT CORNER OF THE POOP DECK & TO DECKING & FRAMING AT THE STBD AFT CORNER OF THE BOAT DECK. EASTERN MOST SUPPORT GIRDER OF NORTH SPAN OF BRIDGE & ITS TRUNNION WERE BENT. BRIDGE IS INOP. DAMAGE EST IS $3M. ETR IS 3-4 MONTHS.

Notify Date/Time= Feb  3 2001 @ 50        
                                
District Required? = N
HQ Required? = N
Last Updated in MSIS on Dec 11 2001

PA01000878 Incident Brief from MSIS
*********************************************
MARINER SUBMITTED TO POST CASUALTY DRUG TEST AND TESTED POSITIVE FOR COCAINE. MARINER OPTED TO ENTER INTO A SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT TO PROVE CURE.


 SUMMARY:
 
 Approximately 0040, 03FEB01, the M/V SARA EXPRESS (O.N. L8912118), while being towed outbound the Miami River stern-first and deadship by the tugs ANNELIESE (O.N.  D240646) and JOSEPH A (O.N. D275040) allided with the northeast corner of the NW 5th ST bridge abutment and the bridge's opened north span.  The bridge sustained major damage to the pedestrian sidewalk, the north span's eastern-most girder, and its trunnion.  The SARA EXPRESS sustained damage to the upper starboard corner of the transom including a 5 inch hole in the side shell plating just below the weather deck, buckled bulwarks, and bent handrails.  The SARA EXPRESS also sustained damage to a 2 feet wide by 1 foot deep section of deck, the deck-edge combing, and handrails on the starboard, after side of the boat deck.  There were no injuries as a result of the incident.  
 
 FINDINGS OF FACT:
 
 1. The SARA EXPRESS is a Panama flagged, 268 ft., 1597 GT, steel-hulled freighter built in 1989 (see encl 43).  The beam of the SARA EXPRESS is approximately 40 ft.  Her draft was 11 feet forward and 13 feet aft.
 
 2. The JOSEPH A is a U.S. flagged, 60.3 ft., 55 GT, steel-hulled tug rated at 900 horsepower (see encl 45).  The JOSEPH A is operated by P & L Towing and Transportation, Inc.
 
 3. The ANNELIESE is a U.S. flagged, 68 ft., 82 GT steel-hulled tug rated at 735 horsepower (see encl 44).  The ANNELIESE is also operated by P & L Towing and Transportation, Inc.
 
 4. Mr. Edward Nolan was the master of the JOSEPH A.  Mr. Nolan holds a vaild CG license #875833 authorizing him to serve as master of vessels of not more than 100 GT upon near coastal waters (see encl 34).  Mr. Nolan had been working for P & L Towing for several years as master of the trail tug.
 
 5. Mr. James Ratican was the master of the ANNELIESE.  Mr. Ratican holds a
 valid CG license #885620 authorizing him to serve as master of vessels of not more than 100 GT upon near coastal waters (see encl 33).  Mr. Ratican had been working for P & L Towing for several years.
 
 6. The SARA EXPRESS transits the Miami River on a weekly basis and normally departs Miami every Friday evening at 2100.  P&L tugs have provided towing services for the SARA EXPRESS for several years.  Both tug operators have significant experience towing this vessel and were very knowledgeable about the vessel's handling characteristics.
 
 7. The SARA EXPRESS was being towed stern-first and deadship out the Miami
 River in an easterly direction.  The ANNELIESE had two towing hawsers approximately 50 ft. long attached to the port stern and the starboard stern of the SARA EXPRESS and was responsible for towing the SARA EXPRESS down the
 river.  The JOSEPH A had two hawsers approximately 35 ft long attached to the port bow and the starboard bow of the SARA EXPRESS and was responsible for controlling the direction of movement of the SARA EXPRESS (see encl 6, diagram 1).  
 
 8. P & L's standard procedure to conduct a deadship tow on the Miami River is
 to use two tugs.  The lead tug stays in the middle of the channel while constantly pulling the leading end of the tow.  The control, or trail tug,
 pulls the trailing end of the tow to one side or the other which moves the
 stern in that direction much like the reaction caused by placing a vessel's rudder over hard.  "Pushing on the hawser" is the commonly used term used to describe the hawser leading aft from the control tug's bow while pulling the tow's trailing end to one side or the other (see encl 6, diagram 3).  The control tug can also back down to slow the forward movement of the tow or to pull the stern back to one side or the other in preparation for a turn if there is enough room astern of the tug (see encl 6, diagram 4).  The lead tug can also assist with turns by pulling the tow's leading end in the direction of the turn, but this action is taken less frequently (see encl 6, diagram 3).  The pivot point of the towed vessel will vary depending on the forces the lead and trail tugs exert and which towing hawsers the forces are being exerted on.
 
 9. Weather conditions at the time of the incident were clear, with good visibility.  The wind was light and variable.  The current was flooding at approx. one knot.  Low tide had occurred approx. 2300, 02FEB00.  Tides were noted to be 1-2 feet below the normally expected levels for that time of day.
 
 10. Outbound, approaching the NW 5TH ST bridge, the Miami River runs approximately 110 degrees true.  Approximately 150 feet before the NW 5TH ST bridge, the river makes a 10 degree bend to the right.  At the the bridge, the effective channel bends another 10 degrees to the right due to the orientation of the bridge across the river. The river then beds back 20 degrees to the left approximately 150 feet past the NW 5TH ST bridge (see encl 5).
 
 11. As noted on NOAA chart 11467, the controlling depth of the Miami River is 13 feet.  Depths in the Miami River are not marked on the chart (see encl 4). Vessels with drafts exceeding 13 feet commonly transit the lower portion of the Miami River.
 
 12. Approximately 150 feet to the west of the NW 5TH ST bridge, the Seybold Canal dumps into the Miami River from the north.  Although not shown on NOAA chart 11467, there is an area of shoaling in the Miami River at the mouth of
 the Seybold Canal.  The canal's depth is about 5 feet.  The depth of the river goes from 9 feet at the entrance to the canal and gradually increases to a
 depth of approximately 16 feet deep 50 feet from the north bank of the river. This shoaling was discovered 07MAR01 by USCG investigators onboard a USCG Aids to Navigation Team Miami boat which was equipped with a fathometer (see encl 13).  Neither Mr.  Nolan nor Mr. Ratican expressed any knowledge of this shoaling prior to alliding with the NW 5TH ST bridge on 03FEB01.
 
 13. The NW 5TH ST bridge crosses the Miami River approximately 1.7 NM from the mouth of the river.  The NW 5TH ST bridge is oriented on a line that runs
 almost exactly northeast to southwest.  The bridge is a bascule or lift bridge with a horizontal clearance of 75 ft as shown on NOAA chart 11467 (see encl 4). The fender system and concrete structure on the north side of the bridge show evidence of numerous, previous allisions.  The fender system was constructed against the bridge abutments and provides little or no protection if the flared bow or overhanging stern of a vessel with high freeboard impacts the fender system at an angle.  The fender system on the north bridge abutment tapers from a protective width of approx. 5 feet at the center of the abutment to a
 protective width of less than 2 feet at the eastern-most corner of the abutment where the majority of the damage to the bridge occurred (see encl 8 and encl
 9).  The north span was not able to be raised to the fully upright position due to modifications made to the structure over the years and the top of the opened span extended several feet past the protective edge of the fender system.
 
 14. The USACOE was the federal agency responsible for regulating the construction and operation of bridges at the time of the bridge's approval and construction.  The NW 5TH ST bridge was deemed an "illegal" structure by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACOE) in 1929 shortly after the bridge was completed (see encl 14.b, encl 14.c and encl 15).  The USACOE's report dated June 30, 1924 (see encl 14.a) approved construction of the bridge with a horizontal opening at right angles to the axis of the channel of at least 75 feet.  Due to the angle at which the bridge was positioned across the Miami River, the distance between the faces of the abutments needed to be 85 feet to achieve this horizontal opening of at least 75 feet.  As constructed, the distance between the faces of the abutments is approximately 73 feet and the horizontal opening at right angles to the axis of the channel is less than 65 feet (see encl 14.c, encl 16 and encl 18).  The Coast Guard is the federal agency now tasked with oversight and regulation of bridges.  The bridge's file is maintained at the Seventh Coast Guard District office. 
 
 15. Additionally, the bridge was designed and the USACOE approved it for construction with a 15 feet opening in the north abutment to provide current flow relief.  The bridge was constructed without this opening.  Lack of this opening is also cited as a reason by the USACE in making a determination that the bridge is an "illegal" structure (see encl 14.b).  The north bridge abutment extends approximately 25 feet into the channel past the harbor line (see encl 5) and south bridge abutment extends approximately 50 feet into the channel past the harbor line.  The entire flow of the 150 feet wide river is restricted at this point and is channeled through the 75 feet wide opening of the NW 5TH ST bridge.  The resulting currents in the vicinity of the bridge frequently change and are often unpredictable.  A large vessel passing through the bridge opening effectively dams the flow of the river and is subjected to a much-exaggerated force from the river's current. 
 
 16. The M/V SHASHA BOEKANIER was moored portside to the Ameritrade facility on the south bank of the river and immediately to the east of the south abutment
 of the NW 5TH ST bridge.  The SHASHA BOEKANIER is a 678 GT coastal freighter with a length of 163 feet and a beam of 30.8 feet.  The vessel's bow was approximately 20 feet from the bridge tender's house which is located on the east side of the south abutment (see encl 10).  The starboard half of the SHASHA BOEKANIER's bow was protruding past an imaginary plane formed by the face of the south bridge abutment.  This imaginary plane formed by the abutment face ran parallel to, and several feet to port of, the SHASHA BOEKANIER's centerline.  Additionally, as shown on the 1990 USACOE aerial survey, the Ameritrade facility's seawall has been extended approximately 20 feet into the channel beyond the harbor line.  Combined, these two factors place the outboard side of the SHASHA BOEKANIER's bow about 20 feet from the centerline of the normally 150 feet wide channel (see encl 6, diagrams 1-6).  The resulting effective channel width is approximately 65 feet which is the minimum required by 33 CFR 165.726(b)(4) (see encl 21). 
 
 17. At 2100, 02FEB01, the JOSEPH A and ANNELIESE arrived at the SARA EXPRESS' moorings and found her listing away from the pier, several degrees to port.
 The list was caused by the extreme low tide which had caused the SARA EXPRESS
 to ground while at her moorings.  The tugs placed lines on the vessel and attempted to pull her away from the pier, but were unsuccessful.  The tugs returned to their facility a short distance away and continued to watch the vessel's list.  They observed the SARA EXPRESS on an even keel just before midnight.  They then returned to the SARA EXPRESS and began to tow her down the river shortly after midnight.
 
 18. As typical, the tow was favoring the north bank as it approached the NW 5TH ST bridge.  The speed of the tow was approximately 1.9 knots or about 3.2 feet per second.  At the entrance to the Seybold Canal, the SARA EXPRESS unexpectedly and suddenly began to sheer toward the south bridge abutment (see encl 6, diagram 1).  Mr. Nolan and Mr.  Ratican both stated that it appeared that the SARA EXPRESS' stern had hit the bottom and was forced toward the south.  Mr. Paul Hill, a P&L observer onboard the SARA EXPRESS, stated that he felt an unusual sensation, much like the vessel bumping the bottom, just as the SARA EXPRESS began to sheer to the south.  Mr. Cilo Espinosa, master of the SARA EXPRESS, was unable to recall such a sensation at that point.  He attributed any sensations he felt to the forces exerted by the tugs on the SARA EXPRESS.  The sudden sheer to the south by the vessel is confirmed by the NW 5TH ST bridge tender, Ms. Tequita Crumpton.
 
 19. Mr. Nolan, master of the JOSEPH A, determined from his position trailing
 the SARA EXPRESS that the sudden sheer to the south and the vessel's forward momentum were going to result in the SARA EXPRESS alliding with the south abutment of the bridge.  He immediately told Mr. Ratican on the lead tug ANNELIESE to start pulling the stern of the SARA EXPRESS hard to the north.
 The ANNELIESE began pulling in a northerly direction.  At the same time, Mr. Nolan in the trail tug JOSEPH A began pushing the hawser attached to the bow of the SARA EXPRESS hard to the south in an effort to pivot the vessel and turn
 the SARA EXPRESS' stern to the left and away from the south abutment (see encl 6, diagram 3).  
 
 20. The combined efforts of the JOSEPH A and the ANNELIESE resulted in the
 stern turning to the left and narrowly clearing the south abutment.  The
 extreme forces required to be exerted by the tugs to prevent the allision with
 the south abutment now caused the SARA EXPRESS' stern to move north toward the north abutment at a fast rate.
 
 21. The JOSEPH A was now oriented with her bow to the south and her stern to
 the north (see encl 6, diagram 3).  Mr. Nolan, on the JOSEPH A, quickly determined the stern's sheering action to the north now had to be checked to keep the stern from alliding with the north abutment.  Due to the close proximity of the north bank, the JOSEPH A's rudders and screws would have struck bottom if Mr. Nolan had attempted to check the north movement of the SARA EXPRESS' stern by backing down toward the north bank to pull the SARA EXPRESS' bow to the north (see encl 6, diagram 4).  Instead, Mr. Nolan attempted to maneuver the JOSEPH A's bow from the south to the north so that he could push the SARA EXPRESS's bow hawser to the north, which would have pivoted the SARA EXPRESS and slowed or checked the stern's rapid movement to the north without the risk of disabling the JOSEPH A (see encl 6, diagram 5).
 
 22. The JOSEPH A was unable to reposition itself in time to complete the maneuver of pushing the SARA EXPRESS's bow hawser to the north and checking the stern's northward sheer.  The starboard quarter of the SARA EXPRESS' boat deck allided with the eastern-most girder of the north span.  The starboard corner
 of her transom hit the concrete sidewalk/maintenance platform on the east side of the north bridge abutment (see encl 6, diagram 6).  
 
 23. There were no injuries as a result of the incident.
 
 24. Once the allision occurred, the SARA EXPRESS was maneuvered through the NW 5TH ST bridge and the remainder of the Miami River without further incident.
 
 25. Mr. Nolan stated that the location of the SHASHA BOEKANIER was not a factor in the difficulties experienced in trying to prevent the allisions first with the south abutment and then with the north abutment on 03FEB01.  He did state, however, that vessels moored to the Ameritrade facility regularly pose a challenge during a typical transit through the NW 5TH ST bridge and was a
 factor in his decision to keep the tow so close to the north bank while approaching the NW 5TH ST bridge.
 
 26. The Coast Guard was properly notified of the bridge allision in accordance with 46 CFR 4.05-1.
 
 27. Following the bridge strike, the SARA EXPRESS, the JOSEPH A and the ANNELIESE were directed by the OCMI to moor at the south side of Dodge Island, Port of Miami, to facilitate investigation of the incident and inspection of
 the damages.  All vessels were moored at 0345.
 
 28. The SARA EXPRESS sustained relatively minor damage to the upper starboard corner of the transom, including a 5 inch hole in the side shell plating just below the weather deck, buckled bulwarks, and bent handrails.  The SARA EXPRESS also sustained damage to a 2 feet wide by 1 foot deep section of deck, the
 deck-edge combing, and handrails on the starboard, after side of the boat
 deck.
 
 29. Damage to the NW 5TH ST bridge was major, rendering the bridge inoperable and stuck in the upright position.  The eastern most girder buckled approx. 18 inches out of position.  In addition, the girder's trunnion pin was bent and
 the concrete sidewalk/maintenance platform was pushed over approx. 30 degrees (see encl 7).  Contractors hired by the Florida Department of Transportation estimated repair costs to be about $2,000,000.
 
 30. Alcohol breath tests were administered to Mr. Nolan and Mr. Ratican by 0420 and both tests were negative with 0.00 percent blood alcohol levels measured
 for both.  None of the crewmen exhibited any behavior which was indicative of being under the influence.  However, Mr. Ratican, master of the tug ANNELIESE, was observed to be drinking a large amount of fluids prior to investigators boarding his vessel.
 
 31. Crewmembers from both tugs were directed to undergo chemical testing for drug use and all were subsequently tested on the morning of 03FEB01.  All tests were negative with the exception of tests for Mr. Ratican, master of the ANNELIESE, and Mr. Giles Woods, crewman on the JOSEPH A (see encl 3).  Both individuals tested positive for cocaine use and both were immediately terminated as employees for P&L.  
 
 32. Mr. Woods does not hold a CG-issued Merchant Mariners Document or license.
 
 33. The NW 5TH ST bridge has been struck 12 times in 13 years according to a Miami River Commission report (see encl 24).  Towing companies operating on the Miami River have consistently complained about the obruction to navigation posed by the bridge (see encl 17, encl 19, encl 22, encl 23 and encl 24).  The vast majority of marine casualties occurring on the Miami River have involved allisions with the SE 2ND AVE bridge and the the NW 5TH ST bridge.  Replacement of the SE 2ND AVE bridge begins in September 2001.  The Miami River Commission and the Miami River Marine Group (an organization of ship and terminal owners on the river) have both recommended that the NW 5TH ST bridge be replaced (see encl 24).
 
 CONCLUSIONS:
 
 1. Florida state statutes 310.141 and 310.146(2) require vessels with a draft
 of 7 feet or more and operating in state waters to have a state pilot on board to direct their movements.  One exception is vessels transiting the Miami River which are being towed deadship by tugboats operated by federally licensed personnel.  Accordingly, the SARA EXPRESS was properly transiting the Miami River without a state pilot while being towed deadship by two tugboats operated by federally licensed personnel.
 
 2. Safely maneuvering relatively large vessels deadship up and down the Miami River is a very difficult and demanding task due to the river's narrowness, numerous bends, and the restrictions posed by bridges spanning the river and numerous vessels moored along the river.  The operators of these tugs must have considerable knowledge of the river and considerable experience unique to operating tugs in this environment.  The knowledge and experience required is typically beyond that which is required of most tugboats operators.  Mr. Nolan and Mr. Ratican both appear to have the experience and knowledge necessary to properly operate tugs engaged in deadship tows on the Miami River.
 
 3. As the stern of the SARA EXPRESS was approaching the NW 5TH ST bridge opening, it unexpectedly sheered to the south for unknown reasons.  Both tug masters recognized the vessel's unexpected action and took immediate corrective measures to prevent an allision with the south bridge abutment.
 
 4. The actions required to avert the allision with the southern bridge abutment were of such a forceful nature that the SARA EXPRESS' stern was diverted to the north at a rate which could not be stopped in time to prevent the SARA EXPRESS from striking the north bridge abutment.
 
 5. The primary factor in the JOSEPH A's inability to check this movement of the SARA EXPRESS' stern to the north by pulling or pushing the SARA EXPRESS' bow to the north and pivoting the vessel in a timely manner was the narrowness of the channel.  Mr. Nolan properly determined that he could not back down and pull the SARA EXPRESS's bow to the north due to the close proximity of the JOSEPH A's stern to the north bank and the substantial risk of disabling the JOSEPH A by running her rudders and screws aground.  Had there been adequate room astern of the JOSEPH A, Mr. Nolan most likely would have been able to properly check the swing of the SARA EXPRESS with a quick, hard pull on the bow hawser and prevented the allision with the north abutment.  Instead, Mr. Nolan properly determined that his only option was to quickly reposition the JOSEPH A's bow to the north and push the SARA EXPRESS' bow hawser to the north.  He attempted to do so, but was unable to complete the maneuver prior to the SARA EXPRESS alliding with the bridge.
 
 6. The bridge fender system provided little protection against damage to the bridge from the SARA EXPRESS.  The limited protection provided is due to the fender system's closeness to the bridge abutment, its relatively short height compared to the height of the SARA EXPRESS' overhanging stern, and the angle at which the SARA EXPRESS impacted the bridge.
 
 7. The reason for the SARA EXPRESS' sheer to the south is unknown, but could have been caused by several factors or a combination of factors.  It is reasonable to conclude that the stern of the SARA EXPRESS, which was favoring the north side of the channel, hit the uncharted area of shoaling at the entrance to the Seybold Canal (on the north side of the Miami River) and was deflected toward the south. 
 
 8. Another possible reason for the sheer is the phenomenon of a water cushion that develops as the river's water is compressed between a ship and the river 
 bank/deep draft channel edge when they converge.  Such a cushion may have
 formed at the area of shoaling and effectively pushed the SARA EXPRESS' stern
 to the south.  This scenario is less likely because the effect is normally more subtle, and SARA EXPRESS' sudden sheer was very pronounced.
 
 9. Additionally, the unpredictable currents present at the bridge opening
 which are caused by the restriction of the river's flow, could have pushed the stern to the south.  This possibility is even less likely because this effect
 is even more subtle than the effect of a water cushion and, as previously stated, the SARA EXPRESS' sheer was very pronounced.  
 
 10. The damming effect of a large vessel in the opening of the NW 5TH ST bridge could not be a factor since the sheer of the SARA EXPRESS' stern to the south occurred while the vessel was still 150 feet from the bridge opening. Additionally, this damming effect is normally most noticeable with an inbound vessel on an outgoing tide.
 
 11. In summary, the apparent cause of the incident appears to be the unintentional grounding of the SARA EXPRESS on the uncharted shoal at the mouth of the Seybold Canal, and the subsequent loss of positive control of the SARA EXPRESS by the tugs as it suddenly "bounced" off the shoal while approaching
 the bridge opening.
 
 12. A contributing factor appears to be the extremely low tide.  The area of shoaling at the mouth of the Seybold Canal had been passed over previously by the SARA EXPRESS and other vessels with similar drafts without incident.  The extreme low tide experienced just prior to the incident was unusual and
 resulted in the level of the river being 1 to 2 feet below normal at the time
 of the allision.  The shoaling at the mouth of the Seybold Canal became a
 factor due to this lower river level.
 
 13. The location of the SHASHA BOEKANIER was a contributing factor in this incident.  The tow was required to hug the north bank while approaching the bridge opening to minimize the potential for an allision with the SHASHA BOEKANIER's starboard bow which was jutting into the south side of the channel and was less than 20 feet from the centerline of the channel.  Had the SHASHA BOEKANIER posed less of an obstruction on the far side of the bridge opening, the tow probably would have made its approach at a greater distance from the north bank and probably would not have grounded on the area of shoaling.
 
 14. The extension of the seawall at the Ameritrade facility into the channel 20 feet past the harbor line contributes significantly to the obstruction that vessels moored at the facility pose at the southeast corner of the bridge opening.  The location of the seawall at the Ameritrade facility can also be considered a contributing factor.
 
 15. Attempting to move a vessel of the length, beam and draft of the SARA EXPRESS through a bridge such as the NW 5TH ST bridge is an obvious
 contributing factor to the grounding and subsequent allision with the bridge.
 It is reasonable to conclude that when the bridges spanning the Miami River
 were designed and built in the 1920's and 1930's, ships of this size were not expected to transit the river.  This is most likely the reason that no action was taken to address the USACOE's determination that the NW 5TH ST bridge was
 an "illegal" structure due to its less than 75 feet of horizontal clearance at right angles to the axis of the channel.  While there are obvious economic incentives for larger vessels of greater capacity to transit the Miami River, there are no regulations limiting the size of vessels transiting the river. Continued operation of large, medium-draft vessels on the Miami River with no improvement to the horizontal restrictions caused by this bridge will most likely result in similar incidents in the future.
 
 16. There is no evidence of negligence or misconduct on the part of either Mr. Nolan or Mr. Ratican with regard to their actions related to the maneuvering of the SARA EXPRESS through the NW 5TH ST bridge.
 
 17. Although Mr. Ratican tested positive for cocaine, there is no evidence
 that drug use by Mr. Ratican contributed to the incident or that he was under the influence or intoxicated at the time of the incident.
 
 RECOMMENDATION:
 
 1. Close case with no further action.
 
 W.L. WIGGINS, CWO4, USCG

 47. PSIX data for ANNELIESE This case was reopened due to a request made via PR01002077 on 05OCT01. It was approved by D. H. DICKEY.  Please see comments below made by D. H. DICKEY. To provide additional narrative information.

On 19MAR01, an 18.5'  flats boat driven by  a CG Licensed mariner, allided with a signpost at the foot of the 17th St Bridge in Vero Beach, FL.  At the time of the allision, the vessel was operated as an un-inspected passenger vessel with 2 passengers on board.  The force of the allision ejected the operator and one of his passengers.  The other passenger was not ejected but suffered fatal injuries.

Further information concerning this case is contained within the Narrative Supplement which was complied by the original Investigating Officers.  

IAW message P 051900Z OCT 01 CGDSEVEN MIAMI FL//ICP// para 3, (M) and G-MOA Policy Letter 2-02, the marine casualty investigation of the subject case has been conducted as a data collection investigation.




 CASUALTY SUMMARY:
 19MAR01, 18.5' flats boat operated as a 6-pack vessel with 2 passengers was being operated by John Jackson.  The vessel allided with a sign post at the
 foot of the 17th St Bridge Vero Beach, FL.  The allision ejected the operator & passengers into the water. One passenger and the operator were ejected into the water.  Both passenger sustained injuries due to the casualty with one
 passenger dying. The operator did not sustain any injuries.
 
 OPERATOR:
 John E. Jackson
 3030 PAR Drive
 Vero Beach, FL 32960
 561-567-6550
 CG License # 840133, " Master of Great Lakes and Inland Steam or Motor vessels of not more than 50 Gross Tons: also operator of Uninspected Passenger Vessels as defined in 46 USC 2101 (42) upon Near Coastal Waters." Issued 22 Sep97 out of MSO Miami.
 
 WEATHER:
 Daylight with approx 1/2 mile visibility due to rain (worsening), visibility considered poor.  Wind 25 mph from SSE.
 
 INJURIES:
 ED FRANCIS  -  sustained fractured/bruised ribs;
 David Peterson  -  Deceased, sustained blunt trama from the back of the head/neck to the lower back.  (See Police report)
 
 FACTS:
 Following is based on information gathered by USCG Investigation officers LT Lingaitis & MST1 Garcia during the 20MAR01 interview with John Jackson:
 - UPV operated by USCG licensed operator John E. Jackson.
 - UPV operation got underway approx 0700 on 19MAR01 for a half day charter with Ed Francis & David Peterson.  Confirmed with Ed Francis.
 - 1100: Wind & rain increasing.
 - 1130: Decision made to return to dock due to worsening weather.  Mr Peterson was seated to the left of the operator and Mr Francis was seated directly in front of the operator's station as per the operators instructions.  Confirmed
 w/ Mr. Francis.                                                  
 - VSL being operated at approx 23-25 mph on a NNW course, the wind was 25 mph from the SSE, with rain worsening thus decreasing the visibility to approx 0.5 mile.
 - 1145: Approx 50 yds frm the bridge the operator encountered increased wind driven waves & wakes frm other vessels.
 - 1145: Vsl allided with a sign post at the foot of the 17th Street Bridge. According to Vero Beach, Marine Investigator the sign post was exposed 5.5-6 feet.  The operator stated that Mr Francis was a distraction by the nature of him being seated at the center bow position in the operators field of view.
 - Vsl's port bow allided with the sign post & the operator was pushed or fell into the throttle resulting in the vessel being launched forward & alliding with the base of the bridge.  
 - the operator & Mr Peterson were ejected from the vessel. 
 - Mr Peterson was medically evacuated via helo to the hospital & Mr Francis was treated by EMS and transported to the hospital via ambulance. 
 - Jackson stated that he normally transits at a higher speed and his normal return route takes him through the center span of the bridge, the shortcut that he attempted to use was 2 spans to the east of normal transits.  He stated that he was attempting to reduce the transit time & the affects of the weather on
 his passengers.
 - The operator did not have a sufficient lookout due to positioning one passenger directly infront of his field of visibility.
 -The operator was operating at excessive speed in reduced/obstructed visibility.
 
 CONCLUSION:
 19Mar01:  Approx 0700 Mr. John Jackson; holder of USCG Lic #840133, Master 50
 GT also Operator Uninspected Passenger Vessel, got underway with two passengers onboard. He was operating a 18.5' flats boat with a 175 HP outboard motor.  
 Approx 1130 it was decided to cease fishing for the day. The weather was worsening to the following:  Increased rain, visibility reduced to 1/2 NM, wind from the SSE at 25 knt.  The operator place one passenger in the center of the cockpit facing aft (directly infornt of the operating station) and the other to the left of the operator.  The passenger facing aft was place there to prevent rain & wind from blowing in his face. While returning to the dock the wind was at their backs. The operator chose to take a shortcut passing under a different span of the 17th Street bridge (a different route than normally transitted) to save some time.  The operator was traveling at approx 23-24 mph.  During an interview he stated that this speed was less than his normal operating speed. Prior to passing under the bridge the operator stated that he encountered wave
 & waked created by boat traffic & wind. The operator struck an object in the water which was later determined to be a cement sign post (sign missing) which was exposed approx. 2.5 feet out of the water.  After hitting the post either a passenger or the operator fell into the throttle and the boat struck the 17th Street Bridge, ejecting one passenger & operator.  One passenger was severily injured and medivaced to the hospital where he later died.  The other passenger sustained brused/fractured ribs.  
 The casualty resulted due to failure to observe Rules of the Road's rule 5 (lookout) and rule 6 (safe speed).
 
 Recommendation:  
 MSO Miami initiate S&R action against the operator for neg ops w/ the spec. of Rules 5 & 6.

 It was determined that the Operator of the M/V REPENT, Timothy Matherne, was illicitly using a prescription drug that severely impaired his ability to navigate and maneuver the vessel causing him to negligently strike the Louisa Bridge.
 
 1) 17MAY01:  The Bridge Tender, Martha Comeaux, witnessed the M/V REPENT glance off the south bank three times as the M/V REPENT approached the Louisa Bridge just prior to the allision.  Ms. Comeaux stated that each time the M/V REPENT struck the bank she called the master of the M/V REPENT to inquire to the problem.  Each time the master, Timothy Matherne, replied that he was having steering problems.  It was the opinion of the Bridge tender that the master of the M/V REPENT was falling asleep because he sounded groggy on the radio.
 
 The M/V SONNY COOK was approximately 500 yards astern of the M/V REPENT at the time of the allision.  The master of M/V SONNY COOK, Lester Naquin, stated he heard the bridge tender's calls to the M/V REPENT, confirming the bridge tender's statement.
 
 The Marine Surveyor, (John Wiggins), inspected the M/V REPENT's steering system and verified that the entire system was operating correctly and stated that the allision was not due to mechanical error.
 
 During the onboard investigation immediately after the allision, Timothy Matherne appeared to fall asleep multiple times in the presence of the CG Investigator.  The first time was during an interview with the CG Investigator. Subsequently, Mr. Matherne appeared to
 fall asleep two more times during the investigation.  On one of these
 instances, the Marine Surveyor, John Wiggins, also witnessed Mr. Matherne appearing to fall asleep.
 
 2)  30MAY01:  At American Tugs' office in Harvey, LA,Timothy Matherne confessed to the Coast Guard in the presence of his boss, Autry Dufrene, that he had
 taken several Xanax, which is a depressant prescriptive drug.  He stated he did not have a prescription for Xanax.  Mr. Matherne also stated he received a
 urine sample from his deckhand and that he substituted that sample as his own during a required post casualty drug screen required by American Tugs.
 
 MSO MORGAN City initiated a Personnel action case.  A Settlement Agreement was signed for use of dangerous drug.  The Settlement Agreement included a
 thirteen-month suspension of Mr. Matherne's license for drug use and required drug rehabilitation and the clearance from a Medical Review Officer to prove cure.  The Administrative Law Judge also ordered a six-month suspension of Mr. Matherne's license for negligence.  For complete investigation details on the personnel action part of this case refer to Case PA01000989.

PA01001027 Incident Brief from MSIS
*********************************************
On 03May01, at 1745, SNM was piloting the M/V STONEWALL JACKSON S/B on the UMR approaching the Cairo Hwy Bridge center span at MM 0.5.  The Cairo gauge was at approx. 29' and the current in excess of 6 mph.  He misjudged the current and allided with the Illinois pier with the aft barge in port string.  The tow broke and, as a result of damages sustained during the allision, the barge that allided with the pier subsequently sank at MM 953.5 on the LMR.


 SUBJECT:
 M/V STONEWALL JACKSON, O.N. 647465, allision with the Cairo Highway Bridge on the Upper Mississippi River at Mile Marker 0.5 on May 3, 2001.
 
 SUMMARY:
 On May 3, 2001, at approximately 1745, the M/V STONEWALL JACKSON was southbound on the Upper Mississippi River approaching the center span of the Cairo Highway Bridge at Mile Marker 0.5.  The Cairo gauge was at approximately 29 feet and the current was in excess of 6 mph.  The weather was clear and sunny.  There were no other vessels in the area.
 
 As the Master approached the bridge he misjudged the drift caused by the swift current and allided with the Illinois pier in the center span with the aft most barge in the tow's port string.  The allision broke the tow loose with three barges adrift independently and the remaining 23 remaining intact as one unit. As a result of the damages it sustained during the allision, the barge that allided with the pier subsequently sank at Mile Marker  953.5 on the Lower Mississippi River.  After the allision the Master stated that in his 30+ years of piloting on the Mississippi he has never seen such swift conditions in the Cairo, IL area.
 
 CONCLUSIONS:
 The apparent cause of the casualty was the failure of the Master of the M/V STONEWALL JACKSON to accurately assess the river's current and drift.
 
 A contributing cause to this casualty was the high river conditions present at the time of the allision.  With the Cairo gauge at 29 feet and the Upper Mississippi River swollen with high water, the current flowing around the bend and approaching the bridge was in excess of 6 mph.
 
 RECOMMENDATIONS:
 It is recommended that a further investigation be initiated in the case of Alvia Edward Hester, operator of the M/V STONEWALL JACKSON, concerning his part in this casualty.
 
 With the above exceptions, there is no evidence of actionable misconduct, inattention to duty, or negligent or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of licensed or certificated personnel; nor any evidence of failure of inspected equipment or material; nor evidence that any personnel of the Coast Guard or of any other federal agency, or any other person contributed to this casualty.  Therefore, it is recommended that this casualty investigation be closed.
 
 B. J. HAWKINS

 II.  PARTICULARS OF THE SIDNEY SHERMAN/IH 610 BRIDGE: 
 
 1.  The construction of the Sidney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge, often referred to as the Houston Ship Channel Bridge, was commenced during the Summer of 1979 and completed in May 1982.  The bridge is of post-tensioned prestressed concrete box girder design, constructed by cast-in-place balance cantilever methods. The main span is 750 feet with the main piers of the bridge consisting of 38 ft x 20 ft hollow boxes with 2 ft thick walls.  They are of conventional reinforced concrete construction utilizing 5500 psi concrete.  Each pier is founded on 255 two foot diameter pipe piles with a 15 ft concrete pile cap that measures 75 ft x 81 ft. The top elevation of this pile cap is -10 ft, bottom - 25 ft.  The bridge is an important part of the City of Houston's transportation infrastructure, allowing commercial and non-commercial vehicular traffic to bypass the city's congested downtown area.  It has been previously struck by vessel traffic, most recently on 07 Sep 00 by the M/V MEDITERRANEAN and on 01 Dec 99 by the M/V AL RAYYAN.
 
 III.  FINDINGS OF FACT:
 
 1.  At approximately 1625, 21 Dec 00, the  time of the pilot's (ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR.) arrival aboard the vessel at sea, the No. 2 aft stulcken derrick which eventually struck the Sidney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge was rigged for sea at an inclination angle of approximately 6 degrees to the vertical (Verbal Statement IVAN KREGAR made to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio; Verbal Statement Chief Officer ANDREW BENITEZ made to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio).
 
 2.  At approximately 1640, 21 Dec 00 the pilot, ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR., during review of the vessel's particulars and air draft observed that the vessel's air draft exceeded 135 feet, the vertical clearance of the Sydney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge (Written Statement ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR.; Verbal Statement IVAN KREGAR to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio).
 
 3.  At approximately 1645, 21 Dec 00 the pilot, ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR., notified the vessel's master, IVAN KREGAR, that the vessel's air draft was too high and that to allow a safety factor the vessel's air draft must be under 132 feet.
 The master agreed to have the derricks lowered and air draft recalculated (Written Statement ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR.; Verbal Statement IVAN KREGAR to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio).
 
 4.  Prior to the vessel, which was proceeding inbound into the Port of Houston to  moor portside at City Dock 17 (a transit that would require the vessel to proceed past City Dock 17, under the Sydney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge to the
 turning basin where it would make a 180 degree turn and backtrack under the bridge again to City Dock 17), reaching Morgans Point the vessel's Chief Officer, ANDREWS BENITEZ, based upon his review of the ships plans and other
 relevant documents, calculated that the vessel's derricks would have to be lowered to an approximately 45 degree angle to achieve an air draft of 129
 feet.  He then supervised the lowering of the derricks, choosing to make use of his "mariner's eye" to judge the angle of the derricks in lieu of utilizing angle indicators affixed to the derricks (Written Statement ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR.; Verbal Satement IVAN KREGAR to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio; Verbal Statement ANDREWS BENITEZ to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio; Written Statements of M/V RICKMERS TIANJIN Crew).
 
 5.  Prior to the allision the pilot,  ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR., was notified
 that the vessel's air draft was 129 feet (Houston Pilots Vessel Transit Card signed by the vessel's master IVAN KREGAR; Pilot Card All Ships Columbia Ship Management LTD Form Code SNA.22-AX-0 Issue Date 7/95 signed by vessel's master on 21 Dec 00; Written Stament ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR.; Verbal Statement IVAN KREGAR to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio).
 
 6.  Prior to the allision the pilot, ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR., had available
 ship's manuevering information required under the provisions of 33 CFR 164.35 (g)(6) (Pilot Card All Ships Columbia Ship Management LTD Form Code SNA.22-AX-0 Issue Date 7/95 signed by vessel's master on 21 Dec 00; Maneuvering Characteristics [Posted on Bridge]).                
 
 7.  At approximately 2128, 21 Dec 01 the No. 2 aft Stulcken Crane of the M/V RICKMERS TIANJIN did allide with the Sydney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge causing the following damage:
 
 a.  M/V RICKMERS TIANJIN: Constructive loss of the No. 2 aft Stulcken Crane and adjacent protective guardrails.
 
 b.  Sydney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge: Road slabs (eastmost, above the channel) destroyed between girder 6 and girder 5, girder web 6 cracked, girder 6 stiffeners damaged, girder 5 web and flange damaged, 2 diafram and wind brace connections in way of girder 6 damaged, diafram connection in way of girder 5 damaged, and localized bridge lighting destroyed (Full engineering details available from the Texas Department of Transportation, PO Box 1386, Houston TX 77521  tel# (713) 802-5000).
 
 8.  At the time of the allision the vessel's chief officer, ANDREWS BENITEZ, possessed the technical knowledge necessary to calculate proper air draft for the vessel (21 Dec 00 demonstration by Chief Officer to USCG Investigators
 Bryan and D'Orazio; Chief Officer post-incident air draft calculations).
 
 9.  At the time of the vessel's allision with the bridge, the posted bridge clearances were substantally correct providing on average approximately 4
 inches more clearance than posted (Texas Department of Transportation 13 Dec 1999 Bridge Clearance Report contained within Texas Department of
 Transportation post incident documentation dated 11 Jan 2001; 15 Dec 1999 Texas Department of Transportation letter for Eighth Coast Guard District Bridge Administration Branch). 
 
 10.  At the time of the vessel's allision with the bridge winds were calm,
 skies were clear, visibility was unimpeded, and temperature was approximately
 45 degrees Fahrenheit (COGARD MSO Houston Galveston Galena Park TX SITREP One dtg 220952Z Dec 00) and no unusual currents in the vicinity of the bridge were present (Verbal Statement Pilot ROBERT ARTHUR to investigators Bryan and D'Orazio). 
 
 11.  Post incident drug and alcohol testing of the following M/V RICKMERS
 TIANJIN crewmemembers conducted by Marine Medical Inc. did not reveal the presence of alcohol or dangerous drug metabolites: A. ALVIAR (OS), L. DOLOTINA (1ST Engineer), I. Kregar (Master), A. MONZALES (2nd Enginer), and R. YNIESTRA (3rd Engineer) (Marine Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 04 Jan 01 for A. ALVIAR; Marine Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 04 Jan 01 for L. DOLONITA; Marine
 Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 04 Jan 01 for I. KREGAR; Marine Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 04 Jan 01 for A. MONZALES; Marine Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 04 Jan 01 for R. YNIESTRA; Marine Medical Inc. Alcohol Log dated 22 Dec 00). 
 
 12.  Post incident drug and alcohol testing of the pilot ROBERT V. ARTHUR JR.
 by Marine Medical Inc. did not reveal the presence of alcohol or dangerous drug metabolites (Marine Medical Inc. Drug Profile dated 26 Dec 00 for ROBERT
 ARTHUR; Marine Medical Inc. Alcohol Log dated 21 Dec 00 for ROBERT ARTHUR).
 
 13. Though no post incident drug and alcohol testing of the Chief Officer ANDREWS BENITEZ was conducted, direct observation of the Chief Officer by investigators Bryan and D'Orazio did not reveal specific, contemporaneous physical, behavioral, or performance indicators of probable use.
 
 14. During the investigation there was no evidence discovered to indicate
 vessel or crew non-adherence with the provisions of the International
 Convention on Standards, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers, 1978 as amended (STCW Convention) and the Seafarer's Training, Certification and Watchkeeping Code as amended (STCW Code).
 
 IV.    CONCLUSIONS:
 
 Based upon the investigation it is concluded that:
 
 1.  The proximate cause of the incident was the Chief Officer's (ANDREW BENITEZ) negligient failure to utilize the No. 2 stulcken derrick's angle indicator to ensure that the stulcken derrick was properly positioned to avoid allision with the bridge.
 
 2.  Contributing to incident was the Master's (IVAN KREGAR) negligient failure to properly verify that the Chief Officer had properly positioned the No. 2 stulcken derrick utilizing the derrick's angle indicator.
 
 3.  The positioning of the stulcken derrick at an inclination of 6 degrees to the vertical at the time of the pilot's arrival aboard the vessel was
 reasonable and in accordance with instructions from the vessel's builder (Kawasaki Heavy Industries LTD Instruction Book for 225 T Stulcken Derrick F2- W81 Finished Plan 26 Jul 79, Section V (Sea Lashing), page 14) 
 
 4.  Meteorological and/or current conditions were not contributary to the cause of the incident.       
 
 5.  Vessel equipment failure was not contributary to the cause of the incident.
 
 6.  The use or or addiction to dangerous drugs and/or alcohol was not contributary to the cause of the incident.
 
 7.  Personnel fatigue was not contributary to the cause of the incident. 
 8.  The level of personnel training and qualification, including the Chief Officer's (ANDREWS BENITEZ) was sufficient to have have prevented this incident.
 
 9.  The pilot, ROBERT K. ARTHUR JR., did not commit any act or ommision
 that directly or indirectly caused or contributed to the allision which
 occurred other than to reasonably rely upon the vessel's air draft calculation that was provided to him by the vessel's master, IVAN KREGAR, who had verified the Chief Officer's (ANDREW BENITEZ) calculations.  
 
 10.  The owner of the Sidney Sherman/IH 610 Bridge, the Texas Department of Transportation, did not commit any act or ommision that directly or indirectly caused or contributed to the allision which occurred.
 
 V.     RECOMMENDATIONS:
 
 1.  There are no recommendations associated with this case for changes to existing International treaties, conventions, or United States laws and regulations pertaining to any aspect of vessel operation, crew training, waterways management on the Houston Ship Channel or bridges over navigable waters of the United States.   
 
 2.  Pursuant to the provisions of the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea, 1974 as amended, Chapter 1 Regulation 11 (c), the recognized organization responsible for issuing relevant certificates on behalf of the flag administration, Det Norske Veritas, was notified of the accident.

On August 15th, 2001 the Tug TED WAXLER, pushing ahead four empty red flag barges southbound on the Atchafalaya River, allided with the Kansas City Southern railroad bridge while transiting under the bridge.  The apparent cause of the allision was failure of the pilot to adequately navigate course of transit under the bridge. Two barges sustained $20,987.63 in damage.  No other damage, pollution, or injuries occurred.  See narrative statement for details.

Notify Date/Time= Aug 15 2001 @ 657       
Investigator = N/A                                               
Unit Command = N/A                                               
District Required? = N
HQ Required? = N
Last Updated in MSIS on Dec  7 2001


 INTRODUCTION
 
 
 On August 15th, 2001 the 120 foot, 2560 hp, diesel-powered Tug TED WAXLER, pushing ahead four empty red flag barges southbound on the Atchafalaya River, allided with the KCS Railroad Bridge while transiting under the bridge.  The
 apparent cause of the allision was failure of the pilot to adequately navigate
 a course of transit under the bridge.  Two barges sustained $20,987.63 in damage.  No other damage, pollution, or injuries occurred.
 
 FACTS
 
 
 The Tug TED WAXLER is a 120 foot, 2560 hp, diesel-powered tug.  Vessel is owned by the Thomas Transportation Corporation and operated by the Waxler Towing
 Company, Inc..  The tug was pushing ahead four empty red flag barges
 southbound.  On the morning of the incident, there were seven people on board, including the captain, Mr. George A. Duncan, and the pilot, Mr. Harry G. Roe. 
 
 On 15 August 2001, at approx. 0100,(see enclosure #1) the weather was clear/no moon with a temperature of 78 degrees.  Visibility was good with a range of 12 miles.  Wind speed was calm, current speed was southbound at 1 - 1.5 mph.
 River stage was 10.75 ft., (see enclosure #2).
 
 Mr. Harry G. Roe was the pilot of the Tug TED WAXLER, on the morning of 15 August 2001.  Mr. Roe is a sixty-four year old male, who attained his pilot's license at the age of twenty-two, after two years as a deckhand.  Mr. Roe has been employed in the marine industry for 47 years.  Mr. Roe returned to
 piloting eight months prior to this incident after a three and a half-year
 lay-off due to bladder cancer.  At the time of incident, Mr. Roe was taking medication for his blood pressure and sugar diabetes, (See enclosure #7).
 During the eight months since his return, Mr. Roe has piloted three short
 trips, five to 10 days in duration and twice on long trips, normally 30 days in duration.  Mr. Roe was on duty for approx. one hour prior to the incident. 
 
 On 07 August 2001, the Tug TED WAXLER, got underway pushing ahead four empty
 red flag barges southbound, from Paducah, Kentucky to its destination in Krotz Springs, Louisiana.  The tow entered the Atchafalaya River on 15 August 2001, with Mr. Harry G. Roe piloting the vessel.  At approx. 0100, the tow approached a bend in the Atchafalaya River where the KCS Railroad Bridge crosses, located
 at MM4.5, (see enclosure #3).  On information received from Captain George A. Duncan, Mr. Roe decided to transit under the west-side span of the bridge
 rather than the normal route, the east-side span.  Captain Duncan informed Mr. Roe that a rock barge dumped rock under the east-side span, making a hazardous transit when the river gauge is at a low level.  Mr. Roe acknowledged piloting vessels under the bridge 100 - 150 times throughout his career, three times since his return eight months prior to this, but normally through the east-side span. The tow was positioned to transit straight through the west-side span, at a speed of 11 mph, but Mr. Roe acknowledged that the speed of the tow was too fast for the turn.  Halfway under the bridge, the tow came too close to the right descending pier and allided it's two starboard barges into the KCS Railroad Bridge.  Before the allision, Mr. Roe stated he felt like something was pushing the tow to starboard, so he counter-maneuvered by putting on a hard starboard rudder to swing the stern out, however this had no effect (see enclosure #8).  Mr. Roe noted that after the tow was between the bridge piers, the current had a tremendous set to the starboard side.  Mr. Roe stated that he felt the Tug TED WAXLER could make good speed for such a wide bridge span, but acknowledged that he should have reduced speed and flanked the tow around the bend and through the west-side bridge span.  Four wires, which held the barges together, broke upon the allision with the bridge pier, however, the tow did not break apart.  Two barges suffered damage in the allision (see enclosures #4,#5,#6). The WTC 115B sustained damage to the port stern corner, knuckle and cap plating.  The STC 125 sustained damage to the #5 starboard cargo tank, which began leaking water water into the void at a rate of 5" per/hour.  After the allision, Mr. Roe had the wires secured between the tow, then continued underway, leaving the scene.  A tankerman was manned to provide surveillance of the barges.  Mr. Roe informed no one of the allision until Mr. Duncan, Captain, awoke at approximately 0600.  Mr. Roe acknowledged that he was in some "state of shock" and "wasn't thinking right" when he failed to report the allision at the time of the incident.  Mr. Duncan, Captain, notified Waxler Towing Company, who in turn notified the United States Coast Guard.  
 
 APPARENT CAUSE
 
 
 The apparent cause of the casualty was failure of the vessel's pilot to
 navigate a course of transit under the KCS Railroad Bridge.
 
 ROOT CAUSE
 
 
 The root cause of the casualty is the Tug TED WAXLER was transiting too fast (Approx. 11 mph) in a southbound direction where there was a bend in the river with a railroad bridge crossing.  Mr. Roe stated that he felt the Tug TED
 WAXLER could make good speed for such a wide bridge span, however he also acknowledged the tow's speed was a little too fast when the allision occurred. Mr. Roe further acknowledged that if he could do it all over again, he would have reduced speed and flanked the tow to navigate around the bend and under
 the bridge.
 
 CONTRIBUTING FACTORS
 
 
 Time away from piloting was a contributing factor in the allision.  Mr. Roe
 was piloting vessels for only eight months following a three and a half-year layoff, due to medical problems.  This trip was only his second 30-day trip
 back since his return eight months prior.  Mr. Roe stated that he was in some state of shock and wasn't thinking right when he failed to report the incident and left the scene. 
 Area familiarization was a contributing factor in the allision. During the
 eight months prior to the incident, Mr. Roe transited the KCS Bridge three times and only under the east-side span, not the west-side where the incident occurred.  Taking into consideration the three and a half years Mr. Roe was out of the marine industry and eight months since his return, he has only transited under the bridge three times, with none of the transits under the west-span where the incident occurred.
 
 RECOMMENDATIONS
 
 
 This case has been forwarded to the personnel action team for review.

 5. Superior Boat Works Invoice #18664;
 6. Mississippi Marine Corporation Invoice #0011405-IN.
 7. Drugstore.com Medication Information.
 8. Mr. Harry George Roe, Witness Statement

19JUL01 SNM a license holder while acting as master of the M/V MR. BARRY negligently drove the MR. BARRY and LHG barge into the Louisa Bridge.


 Narrative Supplement for case #: MC01009280
 
 Fact Outline:
 
 19 July 2001, the following events occurred at the times indicated:
 
 1. Prior to 0221 The M/V MR. BARRY was u/w west bound, pushing a T/B fully loaded with a cargo of PPM (propane-propylene mix), and pushed up on the North bank of the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway (GIWW) mile marker 132.5, 1.5 miles east of the Louisa Bridge awaiting the arrival of their relief pilot.
 2. 0221 The M/V VICTORIA CENAC and the M/V DONALD E CLARK pushing westbound and the M/V RICOHOC pushing eastbound asked for an opening, received permission and transited through the Louisa Bridge.
 3. 0253 The Louisa Bridge closed.
 4. 0320 The M/V BAYOU VOYAGER pushing westbound, passed the MR BARRY, asked the Louisa Bridge Tender for an opening, received permission, the bridge opened and they transited the Louisa Bridge.
 5. 0333 The Louisa Bridge closed.
 6. 0330 The M/V MAGGIE RAE was u/w pushing westbound and the M/V LADY JEANETTE was light boat u/w west bound toward the Louisa Bridge.
 7. 0350 (approximate) The LADY JEANETTE overtook the MAGGIE RAE and they both passed the MR BARRY who was still pushed up on the bank.
 8. 0410 (approximate) The MR BARRY's relief Pilot arrived at and drove his vehicle across the Louisa Bridge to speak to the Bridge Tender.
 9. 0413 The LADY JEANETTE and the MAGGIE RAE u/w westbound asked the Louisa Bridge Tender for an opening, received permission, the bridge opened and they transited through the Louisa Bridge.
 10. 0415 (approximate) The Bridge Tender, Ruby Simon spoke to the pilot of the MR BARRY on VHF, giving them info that the MR BARRY's relief Pilot, Richard Harding, was at the bridge, and that the bridge was going to close to allow the relief to drive back across the bridge.
 11. 0420 (approximate) The MR BARRY got u/w without telling the Bridge.
 12. 0425 The Louisa Bridge closed and allowed the relief pilot to drive his vehicle to the north side of the channel to facilitate their relief process. The LADY JEANETTE continued westbound GIWW. The MAGGIE RAE pushed up against the bank mile to the west.
 13. 0435 (approximate) The Bridge Tender began opening of the bridge for the MR BARRY.
 14.  The MR BARRY struck the bridge with its barge while the bridge was only fifty- percent open breaking relief valves and cracking piping on the STBD
 Tank, allowing product to be released into the atmosphere.
 
 Narrative:
 19 July 2001, prior to 0221, the M/V MR. BARRY pushed up to the bank 1 1/2
 miles east of the Louisa Bridge, waiting for the relief Pilot, Richard Harding to arrive.  The M/V LADY JEANETTE overtook the M/V MAGGIE RAE and they both passed the MR BARRY and proceeded westbound toward the Louisa Bridge. The
 relief Pilot arrived and drove across to the south side of the bridge
 requesting the Bridge Tender Ruby Simon to contact the MR. BARRY and tell him that Richard Harding, the relief Pilot was ready for the crew change. At the same time, the operators of the M/V LADY JEANETTE, Robert Newcombe, and the M/V MAGGIE RAE, Randall Smith asked the Bridge Tender for an opening to pass.  The Bridge Tender acknowledged and opened the bridge to allow them to transit. The Bridge Tender then called the MR. BARRY and informed the Pilot, Mr. Hasley L. Prosperie, that the MR BARRY's relief Pilot, Richard Harding was waiting at the bridge. The Pilot of the MR.BARRY, Hasley Prosperie, requested a bridge opening, but the Bridge Tender, Ruby Simon told the Pilot of the MR. BARRY, Hasley Prosperie no, that she would close the bridge to marine traffic first and allow their relief Pilot, Richard Harding to drive to the north side of the channel. Both the relief Pilot for the Mr. BARRY and the Pilot of the MAGGIE RAE, Randall Smith, confirmed hearing the radio communication exchange, that the bridge would be closed to marine traffic. The LADY JEANNETTE and the MAGGIE RAE had passed through the Louisa Bridge opening, with the LADY JEANETTE continuing westbound and the MAGGIE RAE pushing up to the bank 1/2 mile west of the bridge to facilitate their crew change. The Bridge Tender closed the bridge to allow MR BARRY's relief Pilot, Richard Harding, to drive across to the north side of the bridge. Despite having been told that the bridge was closed to vessel traffic, the MR BARRY, under the command of Hasley Prosperie, got u/w without telling the Bridge Tender and proceeded westbound towards the Louisa Bridge. Once the relief Pilot, Richard Harding's vehicle drove across the bridge, the Bridge Tender began procedures to open the bridge. The Bridge Tender noticed that the MR BARRY was approaching and had passed the 1/2 mile checkpoint, but had not checked in with the bridge. The Bridge Tender stated that she blew a five-whistle blast, yet the relief Pilot, Richard Harding, who was standing on the north bank of the GIWW, west of the Bridge stated that he heard only three. The Bridge Tender then radioed the MR BARRY on VHF and told him to back down because the bridge was not open yet.  The Pilot of the MR BARRY, Hasley Prosperie radioed back that he was backing down and that he would follow the bridge through as it opened towards the west.  The Bridge Tender radioed that the bridge opened to the east, i.e., toward the MR. BARRY and that he needed to back down.  Hasley Prosperie, the Pilot of the MR BARRY radioed that he was backing down. MR BARRY's barge loaded with
 propane-propylene mix struck the bridge, shearing the port and center tank
 vents and cracking the starboard tank vent allowing product to escape into the air, pluming up through the grates in the bridge, forming an explosive vapor cloud. MR BARRY's deckhands, Patrick Carlos and Daniel Duet secured all electrical power. All of MR BARRY's personnel evacuated the vessel.  The main propulsion engines secured due to lack of oxygen when the propane-propylene mix vapor reached the air intakes. The Bridge tender, Ruby Simon dialed 911 and evacuated the bridge house.  
 
 Conclusions:  
 a. In conclusion, the Pilot operated the MR BARRY negligently, resulting in his tow's allision with the Louisa Bridge.
 b. The Pilot started his approach to the bridge despite having been told by the Bridge Tender that the bridge was closed.
 c. The Pilot did not check in with the Bridge Tender after getting u/w. 
 d. The Pilot was fatigued based upon the fatigue model worksheet, scoring a fatigue index of 53.67. As per the Fatigue Investigative Addendum, any score of 50 or higher is fatigued. 
 e. The pilot assumed that the bridge swung to the west, when in fact it opened towards the east. He had made numerous trips through the bridge in the past 3 years and should have known the direction the bridge swung when opening.
 f. The Bridge Tender deviated from the state-required routine for opening the bridge. The Bridge Tender's Notebook page 19 and LA DOT Engineering Directives and Standards, 3.A. states that, " Horn signals for openings and closings must be given without exception, even if communication is also being handled by marine radios." Bridge Tenders Notebook states, "Louisiana DTOD policy is to give sound signals and to request sound signals from vessels--without exception." The Bridge Tender only sounded the danger signal when she noticed the MR. BARRY was close to the bridge.

While transiting outbound through the Chelsea Street Bridge, the barge KTC-60 being pushed by the tug MARYLAND struck the fendering system.  The barge's #1 starboard cargo tank was punctured twice.  Both holes were approx 4 inches in diameter and 3-4 feet above the waterline.  No pollution. Tug and barge were allowed to transit to New York, NY for repairs after inspection by abs & USCG. Cause: Human error. Contributing: Gusty wind and empty condition of barge.

SUMMARY
 
 On September 5, 2001, at approximately 0145, the empty tank barge KTC-60 , VIN: D630272, allided with the Chelsea Street Bridge.  At the time of the casualty, the KTC-60 was being pushed ahead by the tug MARYLAND, VIN: D287444, making its making its transit outbound from the Global (Atlantic) Terminal in Chelsea Creek.  The KTC-60 was empty, with only residue in the cargo tanks.
 
 FINDINGS OF FACT
 
 1.  Vessel Particulars:
 
 MARYLAND                                                        KTC-60
 VIN/Flag:        D287444/US                               D630272/US
 Reg. Length:   94.8 Feet                                     308.2 Feet
 Tonnage:        281 Gross/191 Net                      3824 Gross/3824 Net
 Propulsion:      Twin Screw Diesel Reduction      None
 Horsepower:    2160 BHP (Total)                         N/A
 Cargo:              N/A                                             Empty
 
 2.  Crew Information:
 
 Master: 
 Mate: 
 Crew:  
 
 3.  At the time of the casualty, the mate was at the helm.  A deckhand was positioned on the port bow acting as a spotter to assist the mate in maneuvering through the bridge opening.  The barge tankerman was spotting on the starboard bow.  According to the mate, the tow was traveling at an approximate speed of 3.5 knots.
 
 4.  The empty condition of the KTC-60 presented a substantial amount of sail area for the 10-15 knot beam wind.  Slack water in Boston Harbor on September 5, 2001 occurred at 0056, approximately forty-nine (49) minutes before the casualty.  Although there is not a current measurement station in Chelsea Creek it is common local knowledge that under such circumstances the ebb current velocity is approximately one to two tenths (0.1 - 0.2) of a knot.  The mate did not indicate that the following current affected the maneuverability of his vessel.  The mate did state, however, that the wind was causing the vessel to be set to port as he was approaching the Chelsea Street Bridge.  As the vessel was proceeding through the opening, a gust of wind pushed the stern of the barge to port, causing it to rub the fendering on the south support structure for the bridge.
 
 4.  The mate knew that that there was an exposed steel beam protruding out of the bridge support structure on the south side of the opening.  In an effort to overcome the effect of the wind, and get away from the known obstruction, he turned the wheel to starboard.  The wind continued to hold the bow to the south side of the opening so the mate held the rudder over.  When the wind gust subsided, the bow swung quickly to starboard and struck the fendering on the north support structure.  The bow rake caught an exposed girder on the fendering.
 
 5.  After clearing the bridge opening, the mate moored the tug and barge at the TOSCO Terminal dock, East Boston, MA and notified the MSO Boston (BOSMS) watch desk.  The BOSMS Duty Marine Inspector (DMI) examined the damage and found that the impact had punctured the rake in way of the connection with the starboard side shell, leaving two (2) baseball-size holes in the steel plating approximately 2 1/2 to 3 feet above the waterline.  A temporary epoxy patch was applied to the damaged area, and with the concurrence of the DMI and the American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) surveyor, the vessel was allowed to sail to New York, NY for permanent repairs.  The KTC-60 was repaired in New York at a total cost of $8,000.
 
 6.  When the bridge fendering system was examined by the DMI, it was confirmed (by the presence of wood fragments on the barge) that it had sustained damage from this casualty.  However, some of the damage to the fendering appeared to have been there before the allision.  Therefore, the extent of new damage caused by this casualty could not be determined. 
 
 7.  Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was performed on all crewmembers.  
 
 CONCLUSIONS
 
 1.  The apparent cause of the casualty was that the mate made an error in judgment when he failed to anticipate the rapid swing of the bow to starboard when a strong gust of wind from the starboard beam subsided.
 
 2.  The prevailing wind conditions were a contributing factor to the casualty.
 
 3.  The empty condition of the barge was a contributing factor to the casualty. 
 
 4.  There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, negligence, inattention to duty or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of any seaman, owner or agent of such owner, licensed or documented persons, nor any evidence that any person of the United States Coast Guard, or any other government agency, contributed to this incident; nor evidence that the use of alcohol or drugs contributed to this casualty.
 
 RECOMMENDATIONS
 
 1.  It is recommended that this case be closed.

At approximately, 0410, as the subj vsl and tow were lining up for the Louisa Bridge westbound, the captain stated that he observed that the light marking the end of the northeast fender system was extinguished. At approximately 1630 on April 13, 2001, the M/V FROSTY'S SLEIGH was being moored at a dock in position N26-3.0, W80-9.0, in the Intercoastal Waterway in Hollywood, Florida.  The vessel's master maneuvered the vessel to about fifteen (15) feet away from the dock in a side-to-side and backward motion by using the main control and port engine.  The master then switched from the main control to the remote control and continued to maneuver the vessel to the dock.  When the master and crew were preparing to throw a line to the dock, the starboard engine engaged into full speed forward.  The handle on the remote and main controls were in the neutral position when the starboard engine engaged.  The master tried to regain control of the vessel by moving the remote back and forward, but the engine would not respond.  The master proceeded to the main control located on the flying wing of the vessel and tried to transfer the power of the starboard engine by matching the revolution per minute (rpm), but he was unable to match the engine's rpm.  

Traveling full speed forward and parallel to the dock, the M/V FROSTY'S SLEIGH collided against the stern of the unmanned M/V AMERICAN DREAM.  After striking and pushing the M/V AMERICAN DREAM off the dock, the master of the M/V FROSTY'S SLEIGH pressed the stop button for the starboard engine which was located on the main control panel at the flying bridge, successfully shutting the power to the engine.  

The forward momentum of both vessels produced by the engine and water current carried both vessels into the Intercoastal Waterway.  The M/V FROSTY'S SLEIGH port side struck the piling of the Dania Beach drawbridge and became unengaged from the M/V AMERICAN DREAM.  Crewmembers of the M/V FROSTY'S SLEIGH successfully secured the vessel with a rope to the dock.  The M/V AMERICAN DREAM drifted down the Intercoastal Waterway and sunk a few yards down the river.  Overall estimated damages exceed $1,000,000.   No injuries occurred as a result of the marine casualty.

Unit Command = N/A                                               
District Required? = N

Last Updated in MSIS on Nov 16 2001

FINDINGS:

1. The M/V Frosty's Sleigh, CG 06161, is a 122', 204 Gross Ton, British flagged, Passenger Vessel.
2. The Frosty's Sleigh is owned by Frosty Investment Company.
3. Weather at the time of the incident was clear with good visibility at day.  Wind was from the southeast at 10 to 15 kts, temperature was 90 degrees Fahrenheit.
4. The vessel was on a north course at 5 knots.
5. The vessel and crew departed Fort Lauderdale, FL on Friday, 13 April 2001 at 11:30 am. 
6. The Master was in the process of maneuvering the M/V Frosty's Sleigh to be docked to the Martha Restaurant Dania Beach Boulevard dock.    
7. The Master was using the remote control to maneuver the vessel into the Martha Restaurant Dania Beach Boulevard dock when the starboard engine engaged into full speed forward.  
8. The handle on the remote and main controls was in the neutral position when the starboard engine engaged in the full speed forward. 
9. The Master tried to regain control of the vessel by moving the remote back and forward, but the engine would not respond. 
10. The Master tried to transfer the power from the port engine to the starboard engine (a standard procedure for this vessel) by using the main control on the flying wing to accelerate and balance the rotations per minute (rpm) between the two engines, but was not successful.  
11. The Master was able to push the stop button for the starboard engine only after the vessel struck the M/V AMERICAN DREAM, dock, and pilings of the Dania Beach Boulevard Drawbridge.
12.  No injuries occurred as a result of the incident.  
13. The Master moored to the dock and contacted the US Coast Guard, Hollywood police department, Florida Marine Police, and Capam Powerboat Towing Company. 
14.  A representative from the Yacht Equipment & Parts examined the various controls and determined that the remote control head failed.  There were no emergency kill switches on the remote control handles to shut off the engine promptly.  Design circuitry does not have the capability of indicating there is a fault with the system.  Transfer of station to station is only possible by matching engine revolutions per minute with the running engine and an inherent delay of twenty-two (22) seconds to transfer from the remote station to the main control station is existent.

CONCLUSION:

1.  In accordance with XXXX, Head Marine Electrician for the Yacht Equipment and Parts Company; The cause of this incident was the result of an equipment malfunction with the remote control head.  Evidently, normal usage of the remote control head caused the wire to the controls of the starboard shift and throttle to become defective.  The defective wire intermittently caused the command circuitry to go into ahead and full throttle without the actual control head commanding this action.
2.  There is no evidence to suggest that drugs or alcohol was a contributing factor in this casualty.  
3.  There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, inattention to duty, negligence, or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of the licensed or certified personnel, which may have contributed to this casualty.

An uninspected towing vessel with a deck barge in an astern tow configuration allided with the Spuyten Duyvil Bridge's North draw fendering system.  The casualty occurred as the towing vessel was attempting to take a deck barge from the North River into the Harlem River via the Spuyten Duyvil Creek (Creek).  The barge was made up astern of the towing vessel with gate lines attached.  Assisting with this maneuver and made up to the barge's port quarter was a second  towing vessel whose job it was to pull the stern of the barge up to counteract the ebbing tide as the tow made the turn into the Creek.  After the turn was made the second towing vessel had to let go of the barge's port quarter due to a lack of safe maneuvering space.  The lead tug then had the barge alone and in an astern mode configuration abeam to an ebb tide.  Consequently, the tide set the barge down onto the fendering system.   As the lead towing vessel began to proceed forward in the Creek, the rake of the barge caught a 4"x8"x10' section of wood fendering cracking it.  The structural integrity of the bridge remained intact and the bridge was never closed.  There was no damage to the barge.

Apparent Cause:     Strong ebb tide set barge down onto fendering system.
Contributing Cause: Earlier delay moving another barge brought maneuver into ebb tide condition vice slack
                                water as desired.
Contributing Cause:  Environmental: As described in U.S. Coast Pilot 2,p. 266 the "currents (of the Spuyten 
                                 Duyvil Creek) are swift and erratic around the mouth of the creek."
Contributing Cause:  Use of the North vice South draw.  Using the South draw would have set the tow
                                 shoreward instead of towards any bridge infrastructure.
Contributing Cause:    Second towing vessel's inability to stay on the port quarter of the barge to assist lead                       tug.
