CASUALTY SUMMARY
On 06 Feb 02 at approximately 0624 EST, the M/V AGIOS NEKTARIOS, a 738 ft. bulk freighter, allided with the McArdle Bridge fender system in Chelsea, Massachusetts.  The vessel was loaded with salt and bound for Eastern Minerals, Chelsea.  Escorting and assisting AGIOS NEKTARIOS were the four tugs MOLLY, RUSSELL JR, ALEX C, and LITTLE JOE.  Immediately prior to the allision, AGIOS NEKTARIOS suffered a loss of propulsion control while attempting to maintain position in the channel waiting for the bridge to fully open.  Neither the bridge nor its supporting structures were damaged.  Damage to the fender system was estimated at $750,000.  AGIOS NEKTARIOS suffered minor scrapes along its stern.

FINDINGS OF FACT
1.	AGIOS NEKTARIOS began its transit from anchorage in Broad Sound at approximately 0330 on 06 Feb 02, bound for the Eastern Minerals Terminal, on the north side of the Chelsea River, immediately upriver from the Meridian Street (McArdle) Bridge (Evidence #6 and #8).
2.	All required equipment, including the vessel's propulsion plant, was tested and found satisfactory in accordance with US regulations 12 hours prior to transit (Evidence #3, #6).
3.	Weather for the transit was as anticipated; light and variable winds, clear visibility, rising tide with negligible tidal current.  Sunrise was at 0653 ET.
4.	AGIOS NEKTARIOS is a single screw, bulk freighter with a 106 ft beam.  It was carrying approximately 55,000 LT of road salt.  During the transit, the vessel's draft was 38.5 ft (Evidence #1, #8)
5.	Boston Harbor Pilot boarded the AGIOS NEKTARIOS at 0340 as it approached Boston Harbor.  After a brief discussion with the master, Captain assumed the watch and proceeded inbound, escorted by the four tugs MOLLY, RUSSELL JR, ALEX C, and LITTLE JOE (Evidence #6 and #8).
6.	Captain holds a valid, sixth issue, USCG Merchant Mariner License for a Master, Steam or Motor Vessel of any gross tons upon oceans, with endorsements for First Class Pilot that allows for pilotage of vessels of any gross tons for Boston Harbor, Mystic River, Chelsea River, Town River, Fore River, the Narrows and Nantasket Roads from the LNB to Braintree, Salem Harbor, and Salem Sound .  Due to the fact that the AGIOS NEKTARIOS is a foreign vessel on a foreign voyage, the services of a Federal First Class Pilot were not required by law or regulation (46 U.S.C 8502 and 46 CFR 15812).  Captain has held a Full Branch Pilot Commission, issued by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, since 1999.  On 06 Feb 02, while Captain was onboard the AGIOS NEKTARIOS he was acting under the authority of his state issued credentials.
7.	MOLLY, RUSSELL JR, ALEX C, and LITTLE JOE are owned and operated by Bay State Towing Company in East Boston, Massachusetts.  The tug particulars are as follows (Evidence #9):
	Length (ft)	Disp (GT)	Horsepower
	MOLLY:	99.5	196	2750
	RUSSELL JR:	104.1	195	1000
	ALEX C:	96.3	192	2450
	LITTLE JOE:	80.4	175	3600		
8.	At 0532 Docking Master Captain XXXXXXX XXXXXX arrived onboard the AGIOS NEKTARIOS (Evidence #6, #7).
9.	Captain XXXXXX is licensed to serve as the following:  Master of Ocean Steam or Motor Vessels of not more than 1600 gross tons; Radar Observer Unlimited; also, Chief Mate of Ocean Steam or Motor Vessels of any gross tons; First Class Pilot of vessels of any gross tons upon the waters of Boston Harbor from Deer Island Light to and including Chelsea and Mystic Rivers; Weymouth Fore River and Town River from Germantown Point to the Head of Navigation.  Captain XXXXXX was onboard the AGIOS NEKTARIOS and acting in the capacity of Docking Master to assist in the bridge transit and mooring evolution on 06 Feb 02.  His holding of a First Class Pilot license endorsement is a condition of his employment and a condition of his being contracted by Ilios Shipping.  Since 46 CFR 15.610 requires anyone controlling the movement of any uninspected towing vessel to hold an Operator Uninspected Towing Vessel license (or acceptable equivalent as defined by 46 CFR 15.910), Captain XXXXXX was operating under the authority of his Coast Guard Merchant Mariner License.
10.	At 0535 AGIOS NEKTARIOS proceeded inbound Boston Harbor with the RUSSELL JR. and the LITTLE JOE made fast forward, with the ALEX C. and the MOLLY trailing (Evidence #6).
11.	Captain XXXXXX relieved Captain XXXXXX when the AGIOS NEKTARIOS was approximately abreast of the U.S. Coast Guard facility at 455 Commercial Street.
12.	At 0600 AGIOS NEKTARIOS arrived at the turning basin off of the Chelsea Terminal Limited Partnership pier. The tug MOLLY was made fast to the stern of the vessel and the ALEX C was stationed off the port quarter. The vessel started its turn by bringing the bow toward the Tobin Bridge and using the ALEX C on the port quarter to push the stern around. After the vessel was in position to proceed astern, the ALEX C moved around to the starboard quarter to help stop the swing of the ship and the tug MOLLY was used to tow the AGIOS NEKTARIOS astern.
13.	At 0606 the engine order was slow ahead as the AGIOS NEKTARIOS moved toward the McArdle Bridge. The engine was responding normally at this time (Evidence #6).
14.	High tide for the morning was at 0609.  At the time of the allision, the height of the water was 9.99 ft above MLLW (Evidence #6).
15.	At 0610	the engine was ordered all stop. Captain XXXXXX made a call to the McArdle Bridge on VHF radio channel 13 to request an opening. The bridge operator acknowledged the request and made preparations for opening. At this time buoy no. 16 was off of the port quarter of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS and the vessel was proceeding towards the McArdle Bridge at approximately 1 knot. The tugs were in the same arrangement as before (Evidence #3, #6, #13).
16.	At 0615 the McArdle Bridge was not open or opening, according to Captain XXXXXX and Captain XXXXX XXXXXXXXX, master of the MOLLY. Dead slow ahead was ordered by Captain XXXXXX onboard the AGIOS NEKTARIOS. The vessel's engine did not respond. The Master of the vessel was investigating the cause of the failure and was in contact with the Chief Engineer (Evidence #3, #6).
17.	At 0617 the south leaf of the McArdle Bridge was open but the north leaf remained in the down position, as stated by Captain XXXXX and Captain XXXXXX. Captain XXXXXX ordered full ahead. There was still no response from the engine (Evidence #6).
18.	Shortly after the 0617 command for full ahead, Captain XXXXXX notified Captain XXXXXX that the engine was not responding.  Captain XXXXXX indicated that he was aware of the failure (Evidence #8).
19.	As AGIOS NEKTARIOS neared the bridge, the tug MOLLY cleared the stern of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS and moved off to the East Boston (south) side of the Chelsea River to avoid striking the McArdle Bridge.
20.	At approximately 0622, Captain XXXXXX contacted McArdle Bridge via channel 13 and advised personnel to clear the bridge (Evidence #8).  Bridge operators and workers stated that immediately following Captain XXXXXX's warning they left the bridge, which had been operating properly until their departure (Evidence #12).
21.	At 0623 Captain XXXXXXX determined the bow tugs were clear of the anchors, and then ordered both the port and starboard anchor to be let go (Evidence #6).
22.	At 0624 the stern of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS came in contact with the fender system of the Chelsea side of the McArdle Bridge and also ran aground in the mud on the Chelsea side of the Chelsea River. The stern of the vessel penetrated the fender system, bending the fender system into a V shape (Evidence #1, #2, #3, #12).
23.	After the vessel came to rest, the anchors were weighed and AGIOS NEKTARIOS was pulled from the fender system by the tugs. Once the McArdle Bridge was completely opened, the AGIOS NEKTARIOS proceeded as normal to the Eastern Mineral pier and docked without further incident.
24.	Following the incident, the chief engineer surveyed and cleaned the starting air pilot valve.  The starting air system was restored and operationally tested with the engine ahead and astern.  Both the starting air system and the engine operated satisfactorily (Evidence #15).
25.	After returning to the Bay State Towing dock (Pier 1, East Boston), Captain XXXXXX and each of the tug captains submitted to alcohol and drug testing.  The watchstanders on the AGIOS NEKTARIOS submitted to alcohol testing after mooring the vessel.  All results were XXXXXXXX for both alcohol and drugs (Evidence #5 and #17). Although the agent and owner's representative were reminded by the OCMI of their responsibility to determine the need and provide chemical testing (Evidence #16), the watchstanding crew of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS was not tested for drugs. 
26.	Coast Guard inspectors and ABS surveyors attended the vessel at the pier to determine the extent of damage.  Minor scrapes were noted along the vessel's stern, with no inset or structural damage reported (Evidence #15).  Northeast Diving Services of Newport, RI conducted an underwater survey of the hull and running gear and reported no apparent damage (Evidence #14).
27.	Damage to the McArdle Bridge fender system is estimated at $580,247.83 (Evidence #18).
28.           The McArdle Bridge just finished a 20 month refurbishment project. The project required a 4 hour notification for bridge opening. 05 FEB 02 was the first day of "normal" operation. In preparation, XXXXX XXXXX initiated a telephonic conversation with Captain XXXXXX on 04 FEB 02 to inform him of the bridge status that it would "open on demand" 24 hours a day, 7 days a week (Evidence #11).

CONCLUSIONS
1.	The apparent cause of this casualty was engine failure, most probably attributable to an unexpected failure of the starting air pilot valve (Facts 16-18, 24).
2.	Contributing causes include; (1) Human error on the part of Captain XXXXXX XXXXXX, (2) Accepted practice within the port of closely approaching bridges while awaiting opening, (3) Lack of formal policy and procedure for McArdle Bridge opening requests and responses (4) Poor communication between McArdle Bridge operators and Captain XXXXXX.
3.	There is evidence of error in judgment on the part of Captain XXXXX.  Although Captain XXXXX was aware that this was the first time the McArdle Bridge was available for immediate opening after extensive construction, having discussed the necessity for ample advance notice with the Superintendent of Bridges for the City of Boston, XXXXX XXXXX, and despite having repeated difficulty with the bridge in previous transits, he did not request an opening until 0610, 14 minutes prior to the allision.  Captain XXXXX also failed to confirm the status of the bridge with its operators at any point during his approach, assuming it would be open upon his arrival.  He relied solely on the ship's propulsion system as a means of checking his way in the event of encountering the bridge closed.   Finally, Captain XXXXX did not take sufficiently early and appropriate action to avoid allision with the bridge or its fenders.  The initial order to slow the vessel's sternway was given at 0615, with no response from the engine.  None of the four assist tugs present were used to stop the vessel, and the anchors were not let go until 0623, one minute prior to striking the fender system.  (Facts 10, 15-18, 21, 22)
4.	There is evidence of a violation of 46 CFR 4.06-1 on the part of the agent and owner's representative, Paralia Corporation in that the crew of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS was not tested for drugs following a serious marine incident.  (Fact 25)
5.	There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, negligence, inattention to duty or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of the Boston Harbor Pilot or on the part of any of the operators or crew of the assist tugs.
6.	There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, negligence, inattention to duty or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of any person of the United States Coast Guard, or any other government agency, contributing to this incident.  There is no evidence that the use of alcohol or drugs contributed to this casualty. 

RECOMMENDATIONS
1.	That the Officer in Charge, Marine Inspection, initiate a dialogue with the Boston Harbor Pilot's Association, local operators, the City of Boston, the Massachusetts Highway Department, and other interested parties to formalize deep draft vessel transit procedures for drawbridges in the Boston Zone and to review current assist tug practices, procedures, and contingencies. (Conclusions 2, 3)
2.	That the Officer in Charge, Marine Inspection initiate a Marine Violation investigation regarding the failure of the AGIOS NEKTARIOS owner's representative to provide drug testing for crewmembers directly involved in a Serious Marine Incident (Conclusion 4)	
3.	That this case be closed.

UTV SHEILA MORAN was undocking the barge SUMERSET from Lyon Shipyard in Norfolk, VA.  The SUMERSET is a 500 foot by 105 foot freight barge and was empty, resulting in siginificant freeboard and a shallow draft.  The barge was moored port side to the pier with the bow facing the left descending bank.   The barge was to be undocked and proceed west to the Perdue facility on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  

The SHEILA MORAN was in the notch of the barge and the UTV CAVALIER was assisting, made up port side to the barge's starboard side, with a bow line on the barge's #2 cleat and stern line to the #3 cleat.  The tide was flooding and winds were WNW at 20 knots.  

The barge was backed out by the SHEILA MORAN.  When the bow of the barge cleared obstructions along the river bank, the master of the SHEILA MORAN instructed the CAVALIER to let go the stern line and to back down, maintaining a 90 degree angle with the tow to swing the bow west into the channel.  The master split the throttles on the SHEILA MORAN, port forward and starboard reverse, planning to swing the bow of the barge west into the channel with the assistance of the CAVALIER.  

The barge swung to starboard until it was approximately at a 45 degree angle to the channel, with the bow facing southwest.  The tide and wind began to set the vessels east toward the nearby Campostella Bridge.  The CAVALIER and SHEILA MORAN were unable to complete turning the barge into the channel.  The master of the SHEILA MORAN ordered the barge's anchor dropped, but the anchor was unable to hold the tow against the flood tide and wind.  The tow continued to be set east until the port quarter of the SHEILA MORAN allided with the fendering system of the Campostella Bridge at 0440L.  The master of the SHEILA MORAN then requested an additional assist tug from Moran Twoing.  

At 0510L the UTV GREG TURECAMO arrived and made up to the starboard bow of the barge and began aligning it in the channel.  At 0515L, the tow was properly aligned in the channel and free from the bridge fendering system.  The barge was towed to the Perdue facility and was moored at 0815L.   The bridge sustained an estimated $95,000 in damage to the fendering system.  There was no damage to the bridge structure or any of the vessels involved.     

There were no mechanical or failures or equipment factors contributing to this casualty.  Drugs, alcohol and fatique were not factors.

The  cause of this allision was the failure of the master of the SHEILA MORAN to properly plan the undocking maneuver.  Specifically, he underestimated the difficulty of maneuvering the 500 foot barge in close proximity to the bridge, which was just upstream.  He also underestimated the effect of the wind and tide on the high freeboard and shallow draft of the barge.  

Contributing to this casualty was the failure to use a second assist tug.

SUMMARY:

BRIDGE ALLISION, T/V MEDICINE BOW PUSHING (2) EMPTY RED FLAG BARGES ALLIDED WITH GRAND LAKE PONTOON SWING BRIDGE AT MM 231 GICWW.
1. SITUATION:
012200R MSU LAKE CHARLES RECEIVED NOTIFICATION THAT THE T/V MEDICINE BOW WAS TRANSITING THE GICWW EAST BOUND PUSHING (2) EMPTY RED FLAG BARGES WHEN THE STBD BARGE (T/B GONSOLIN 203) ALLIDED WITH THE GRAND LAKE PONTOON BRIDGE AT MM 231.

NO INJURIES ON THE T/V OR BRIDGE WERE REPORTED.

THE MASTER REPORTED NO MECHANICAL PROBLEMS WITH THE TOWING VESSEL. THE CAUSE OF THE ALLISION, AS REPORTED BY THE MASTER, WERE STRONG WINDS IN THE VICINITY WHICH SET THE TOW INTO THE SWING BRIDGE.

ON SITE INVESTIGATION BY MARINE INSPECTOR CONFIRMED NO VISIBLE DAMAGE TO BARGE.  NO POLLUTION SIGHTED.

Passenger vessel SS INDEPENDENCE was being towed dead-ship from Pier-50, San Francisco, to Anchorage 26 (location for MARAD Reserve Fleet of ships).  Three tugs were assigned for towing, and a Pilot hired for the transit.  Weather conditions were nominal.  The transit was uneventful until approaching the Carquinez Bridge.  The ship Master initiated an inquiry to the pilot regarding the air draft clearance with the Bridge.  The pilot stated the maximum clearance was 135 feet, who then asked the master what the INDEPENDENCE air draft was.  The master didn't know the entire air draft, but said the height-of-eye pilot house level was 85 feet.  The transit continued.

At approximately 1045 the upper portion of the ship foremast allided with the Carquinez Bridge, breaking off about 20 feet; the broken section remained suspended amongst the rigging.  The MARAD Project Manager later estimated the actual strike took place 7 feet down from the mast top.  Upon recognizing the lessened air draft was still too great to safely clear the next bridge along the transit (Union Pacific Railroad Bridge), the ship was returned to Pier-50.  The Carquinez Bridge tidal conditions during the incident was approximately 2.5 feet above MLLW, thus even a transit conducted at low tide would have resulted in a similar incident.  January 9, 2003: Issued LOW to John Going.  February 4, 2003: Recieved signed LOW.

At 0715 on Monday, March 18, 2002 the M/V CHARLIE EVERHART, O.N. 534782 was underway at Mile 190.5 of the Cumberland River (CBR).  The "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" was pushing six total freight barges in a two wide and three long arrangement, down river with a very strong current on her stern. The weather was poor with wind and heavy rain but fair visibility. All barges were empty at the time of the incident. While attempting pass under the CSX railroad bridge also known as the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Bridge in the preferred channel (right descending side), the starboard lead barge, "ING 732" struck the right descending bank bridge pier. 

BM1 XXX XXXXXXX, CG MSD Nashville arrived onboard the then moored "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" at 0900 on the same day to conduct an initial investigation.  The vessel captain, and person in charge at the time of the incident was Mr. XXXXX XXXXX, CG License XXXXXX, issued 14 July 2000 at Memphis, Tennessee. During his interview with BM1 XXXXXXX and his submitted CG-2692, Report of Marine Accident, Injury or Death, Captain XXXXX reported his speed at 1.5 knots; his tow was 677' total length and 70' wide. The Cumberland River was flowing at an estimated 10 miles per hour. During his approach to the subject bridge, a deckhand was on the bow of the "ING 732" dewatering the bow void, which had some rainwater in it, and at the same time he was on a portable radio reporting distance to the bridge pier.  Captain XXXXX stated he was flanking, attempting pass under the bridge, and his last report from the deckhand was 150 feet to the bridge pier, and immediately after that report the "ING 732" struck the bridge pier. The current of the river immediately pushed the "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" with her tow intact to port. The entire tow pivoted on the bridge pier and came to rest against the three bridge piers, with the stern of the "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" against the left descending bank and her tow blocking the entire channel. Captain XXXXX immediately contacted his operations office that in turn dispatched the "M/V L.B. EDGIN" and  "M/V TRACY K" to assist and reported the incident to CG Group Ohio Valley who in turn reported it to this office.

The "M/V TRACY K" and "M/V L.B. EDGIN" arrived from the down river side (against the current) and tied off to the forward and stern barges on the port side of the tow at the same time the M/V CHARLIE EVERHART managed to maneuver to the starboard side of the center barge. The barges where then pushed off the bridge piers using all three barges, the pivoted to line back up with the right descending channel. The "M/V TRACY K" made fast to the bow of the tow and with the "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" made fast to the stern the tow was brought through the span and then moored to federal mooring cells on the down river side of the bridge. A damage survey was completed on all the barges with the only damage noted top the bow of the "ING 723". 

In a written statement Mr. XXXX X. XXXXXXXXX writes that he was onboard performing the duties of the senior deckhand. Mr. XXXXXXXXX was dewatering the bow void of the "ING 732" and at the same time giving the captain distances to the bridge. He moved from the lead starboard barge to the center barge and that is when he realized they where going to hit the span hard and he sought shelter by holding on to the combing of the cargo containment on the center starboard barge. After the allision he saw the downriver lead barge brake a facing wire, he ran and secured the barge with a mooring line and then was called by radio to return to the "M/V CHARLIE EVERHART" to replace another facing wire that had broken.

In a written statement Mr. XXXXXX X. XXXXXXXX, CG License #XXXXXX was onboard performing the duties of the pilot. He states that the Captain XXXXX was communicating with his senior deckhand with regard to distance to the bridge pier and the last report he heard on the radio was the barge still had 150' distance to the pier that was the last report before the barge struck the pier.

In a telephone conversation between Mr. XXXX XXXXX, Regional Engineer for Structures with CSX Railroad and CWO XXX XXXXXXXXXX on 27 March 2002, Mr. XXXXX stated that the damage to the number one bridge pier was minimal. Their office inspected the bridge on the day of the allision and at most a couple of stones on the pier structure will have to be replaced. He estimated damage to the bridge at approximately $2000.00.

CONCLUSIONS

1. The primary casual factor appears to stem from inaccurate reports from the senior deckhand bow-watch to the master of the vessel during the unusually high river current and flows.

2. Coast Guard Group Ohio Valley received immediate notification of the allision and the responsible party took immediate and decisive action to clear the channel and secure the tow.

3. In the opinion of this investigating officer the master is at fault for the allision. However, due to the river current and poor visibility during the event, this investigating officer recommends no administrative action against the vessel captain is warranted.

No evidence exists to suggest inattention to duty or actionable misconduct on the part of the licensed master. This Investigating Officer recommends case closed.

                                                        BM1  X. X.  XXXXXXX

M/V RIO MIAMI while inbound the Miami River and being towed deadship by the tugs HEIDI and JOSEPH A allided with the north side of the NW 5th St bridge.  Vessel sustained 2 insets to hull plating above the weather deck IWO the stbd fwd bulwarks.  Bridge sustained minor damage to concrete retaining wall, Florida DOT failed to provide estimate of damages.  Cause appears to be loss of control of tow due to excess current due in river caused by opening of flood gates upstream.  Tug masters were not aware of flood gates opening.  In addition, NW 5th St bridge was not constructed IAW ACOE regulations and has been deemed an "illegal structure" due to a completed horizontal opening (width) that is less than the required 75' and completion without any current relief opening(s) in abutment(s).  There is no evidence that act of negligence or misconduct on the part of the tug masters or crew contributed to this allision.  Close case.
While morring the vessel the master fouled the propeller with a submerged line, resulting in a loss of propulsion. No injuries. Minor damage to propeller.

A U.S. inspected tank barge under the direction and control of a U.S. uninspected towing vessel allided with a railroad bridge fendering system resulting in damage to the fenders but no structural damage to the bridge itself.  The transit through the bridge was being made during adverse weather conditions (snow squall with winds from the NW at 20 knots gusting to 35) and as they attempted tho pass throught the bridge's north draw the strong winds set the barge hard up against the fenders, damaging several wooden whales.  No damage was sustained by either the tug or barge.

UTV pushing ahead 1 loaded deck barge E/B through north side of Chef Menteur Highway 90 swing bridge allided with the bridge causing considerable damage to the upperdeck handrail and  pilothouse.  No reported damage to the bridge, minor cuts to deckhand reported, no pollution reported.  Chemical testing on pilot and deckhand were XXXXXXXX.  Chemical test was reported as performed on bridge tender, but results were not provided following several calls and remain unknown.  The bridge had opened for the vessel to pass eastbound.  The barge was already through and UTV partially through when the pilot thanked the bridge tender for the opening.  The bridge then started to swing closed.  The pilot called on the radio to the bridge tender with negative results.  The pilot was heard by the Chef Menteur railroad bridge tender.  The Highway 90 bridge struck the UTV at the upperdeck rail, then tore the roof flashing back as the vessel maneuvered around the closing bridge. In addition to damage to rail and flashing, electronic cables were severed, and pilothouse damaged.  The apparent cause was human error in that the bridge tender failed to wait for all clear signal from the vessel, failed to monitor the radio until the vessel was clear, or to visually verify the vessel was clear prior to closing the bridge.  Root cause was failure of the bridge tender to ensure safe operation of the bridge.  Contributing factor may have been a result of misunderstanding between the tender and pilot, with the tender interpreting the thanking for the opening as an all clear.  DCA per G-MOA ltr 01-00.

No injuries, no damage and no pollution was reported.  Drug & alcohol testing ordered by DIO.  Apparent Cause was loss of power in starboard engine at critical moment during approach to HPL bridge. On May 9,2002 the M/V Issaquena (D505721) was transiting up bound on the Ohio River at mile 858.2.  The Shawneetown Highway Bridge is located at mile 858.2 the M/V Issaquena was transiting through the center channel span of the bridge during this transit the vessel lost momentum due to the high water conditions and possible drift caught in rudder.  The vessel started to lose headway and began to drift down river.  While drifting down stream the starboard stern of the starboard string of barges struck the center bridge pier.  This caused the fifteen-barge tow to pivot to the port where the barges struck the RDB bridge pier.  When the first barge struck the bridge pier the tow broke apart and continued to drift down river.  Shawneetown Harbor Service had two harbor tugs working that morning and was able to assist in gaining control of all of the barges adrift.  All barges were recovered, inspected, and placed back into the tow.  All of the barges sustained some damage, with the most severe damage being two small cracks in the stern of the barge AGS 222.  The crack was shingled for temporary repairs.  All of the barges in the tow were damaged to some degree.  Two of the Shawneetown Highway bridge support piers were damaged when the barges drifted down and struck them.

While transiting the St. Joseph River enroute to the Consumers Asphalt Dock in Benton Harbor, due to the extremely strong current, vessel was set down on the CSX Railroad Bridge. Vessel rubbed along bridge fendering approx 100ft until clear of bridge. Vessel involved was the limestone barge McKeesons and the tug Invincible. No damage or pollution reported from the tug or barge.  CSX reports damage to bridge as missing 8-10 grouping of pilings, damage to the center span fendering system and the piling and fenders on the North side off the bridge offset by 1 foot.


07Jul04:
No CG-2692 available for scanning.  Case was inactive since last input on 2002.  Involved party was not completed and information was not available therefore, Joe Doe, was entered in order to close case.

While running the shore span of the Burlington Draw Bridge, the vsl stopped and Allided with the turntable. No damage to vsl or bridge reported.

DRUGS AND ALCOHOL ARE NOT CONSIDERED TO BE PART OF THIS CASE.

Received a report that a US flaged towing vessel pushing a US flagged tank barge allided with a bridge in the East River.  While trying to round up off the dock at Con Ed Ravenwood, the flood current caught the tug and barge sideways and pushed the unit under the Roosevelt Island lift bridge.  While under the bridge, the top of the barge's boom allided with the bridge's  I-beam, causing the barge's topping lift to part, which dropped the boom to the deck of the barge. Additionally,  while adrift under the bridge the barge also grounded  (rubbed bottom plate) in the vicinity of tanks 1 and 2. Cause: Current.  No damage to tug. Cargo hose boom position corrected.  Drug and alcohol testing was conducted which yielded negative results.

Data collection level of investigation conducted iaw msg dtg P 051545Z Oct 01 fm Comlantarea Cogard Portsmouth Va//Am//.

M/V Julie S was southbound with 15 loads in tow arranged 3x5.  While navigating bridge near mile 481 UMR current set tow to starboard and barge ML 527B in starboard string came in contact with BNSF Crescent R.R. bridge right descending sheer fence.  Damage to barge was estimated as a Total Constructive Loss - Unsalvagable (PHONCON w/ American Commercial Barge Line, Inc. @ 24 MAY 1300 repairs exceed value of barge $60,000).  BNSF was unavailable to provide estimate of damage and repairs at this time of 24MAY02.  No actionable negligence on part of pilot.

At approx 0048R 29MAY2002, the uninspected towing vessel M/V JOE BOBZIEN was underway southbound on the Lower Mississippi River at mile 531 pushing ahead 30 loaded barges arranged 5 long and 6 wide when it allided with the Hwy 82 Bridge at Greenville, MS. 

Three barges sank because of the allision, one barge sank in the vicinity of the bridge, one sank at MM 527.4 on the RDB below the bridge, and one sank in an unkown location but the ACOE deemed the barge to not be a hazard to navigation.  The ACOE was notified and marked sunken barges.  In addition to the sunk barges,  four barges were damaged and repairable.  No pollution ocurred from the casualty and there is no evidence that drugs or alcohol were contributing factors.  The LMR was closed from MM 510 to MM 535 prior to identifying the location of the three sunk barges.  A broadcast notice to mariners was released by Group LMR detailing the known location of the sunk barges.

American Comercial Barge Lines, LLC is developing a salvage plan for the sunk barges.  High water in the area is preventing prompt action from being taken.  ACBL has hired someone with Meryll Marine Services to positively identify all barges and determine whether any barges are recoverable and provide a salvage plan to the COTP.  ACBL estimates that salvage operations will proceed over the next 35 to 40 days while the LMR's water level drops.

Cause of casualty was error in judgment by pilot of the M/V JOE BOBZIEN. The Pilot failed to make proper approach to HWY 82 Bridge. Contributing factors, swift current due to high water.  It is recommended that the pilot receive a Letter of Warning for lack of judgement in approaching and passing through the HWY 82 bridge.  

Pending final results of drug/alcohol testing and submittal of a salvage plan, the investigation is complete.

LT, USCG                                                            CWO3, USCG
Lead Investigating Officer                                     Investigating Officer

At approx  0413 LCL 30MAY2002  the uninspected towing vessel M/V ELIZABETH HUGER was underway southbound on the Lower Mississippi River at mile 531 pushing ahead 21 loaded barges with military vehicles on them, when it allided with the HWY 82 Bridge, Greenville, MS. 

Barges were arranged 7 long and 3 wide. Two barges were damaged after the allision with a total of nine pieces of military equipment being lost in the river.  ACOE was notified and located the lost military equipment.  Five pieces of the equipment were located at:  33 degrees , 15 minutes, and 51.23 seconds North Latitude;  091 degrees, 08 minutes, and 10.606 seconds west longitude.  The remaining four pieces of equipment were determined to be and the river bottom below the Hwy 82 bridge in 125' of water.

Canal barge line hired Merrill Marine Services to develop a salvage plan to recover the lost equipment.  Merrill Marine is working closely with the Army National Guard to develop the Salvage plan.

United States Environmental Services, LLC was hired to conduct a pollution search of the area around the M/V Elizabeth Huger, its' barges, and the sunk equipment.  A small sheen was found approximately 100 to 300 yards below the salvage operation but dispersed rapidly.  It could not be determined if this sheen was a result of the incident.  USES surveyed ten miles of the right and left descending banks with no detection of any petroleum release.

Two CG- 2692s were submitted for this incident.  The first CG-2692 received was from Port Captain for Canal Barge Company.  The second CG-2692 was submitted by The Law Firm hired by Canal Barge Company.

Cause of the casualty was error in judgment by Pilot of the M/V ELIZABETH HUGER.  Failed to make proper approach to HWY 82 Greenville Bridge. No evidence that drugs or alcohol were contributing factors. This was the first reportable accident by the Pilot in 27 years on the river. Contributing factors swift current due to high water.

The pilot stated that several buoys were missing during his approach to the Hwy 82 bridge and did not know whether they were "diving" or not.  Channel buoys were moved to the tree line due to the high water.  The entire width of the river at/near the Hwy 82 bridge was safe for navigation at the time of the incident due to the high river stage.  Since no channel was necessary to be marked so buoys were moved until the river begins to recede.  Buoys are navigational aids for vessels transiting the Mississippi River.  Aids to navigation were not the determined to be the cause of this incident.  In the 12 hour period prior to this incident, at least ten vessel's with tows transited through the Hwy 82 bridge safely.  

It is recommended that the pilot receive a Letter of Warning for his error in judgment while transiting the Hwy 82 bridge which resulted in the casualty.

Pending results from the drug/alcohol testing and a salvage plan for the 9 pieces of military equipment, the investigation is complete.

Pilot was on board and was maneuvering the vessel up-bound on the Mississippi River.  The Captain advised the Pilot that the vessel was currently being ballasted to make certain she had enough air draft to clear the Huey P. Long Bridge.  Near 9 Mile Point, the Captain advised the ship had an air draft of 137.07'.  The Huey P. Long Bridge has a vertical clearance of 153.0' minus the Carrollton Gage, which at the time had a reading of 15.3', which provided for a clearance of 137.6', which should leave over 5" of clearance above the ship.

As the vessel passed under the Bridge, approximately 2" - 4" of the radio direction finder antenna scraped the bottom of the bridge, causing no damage to the bridge.  The RDF was no longer used by the ship and was inoperable prior to this incident.

The cause of this incident was Human Error / miscalculation of the vessel's air draft.

On 03 May 2002, at approximately 0100, the M/V BADGER was southbound on the Illinois River (MI 43) with fifteen loaded barges in tow.  The captain reported that as the tug and tow approached the Gateway Western Railroad Bridge (also known as Pearl RR Bridge), the lead barge on the port side (barge CC-7821) lightly bumped the bridge's starboard protection cell.  No damage was noted to the protection cell or the tug.  CC-7821 sustained minor damage to port bow and to the #1 wing tank, however, a subsequent survey showed that no repairs were warranted.

The company did not conduct drug or alcohol testing in conjunction with this incident.

The company does not recommend any additional corrective safety measures at this time.

On 28 October 2001, at approximately 0024, the M/V HERMAN POTT was northbound on the Illinois River (MI 61.2) with 16 barges in tow.  As the captain was aligning the tow for a turn just below the Norfolk Southern Bridge, the stern barge (T 3014) on the port side rubbed the bridge.  The allision caused the T 3014 to break free from the tow and float downriver until landing on the bank of the river.  The captain retrieved the loose barge, re-built the tow, and proceeded on the northbound voyage.

No damage was noted to the tug or any barges in the tow.  Two timbers were damaged on the bridge.  Estimated cost of replacing the timbers is $13,000.

The company states that, to the best of their knowledge, drugs or alcohol were not a factor in this incident.

Investigating Officer

On June 10, 2002, the TUG PETALUMA was engaged in her normal business of pushing a sand barge from Port Chicago towards the NorCal Building Materials industrial facility at Petaluma.  During the evening transit, the barge struck the Black Point Railroad Bridge while it was in its normally open position. The allision destroyed several pilings (designed as a fendering system) but did not appear to harm the bridge structure itself.  The PETALUMA's captain notified his employer and the Coast Guard of the incident shortly after clearing the bridge.  Drug testing was conducted.

On 02 June 2002, at approximately 0420, the M/V JACK FLAHAUT was southbound on the Missouri River (MI 448) with four barges in tow.  The pilot reported that as the tow was passing through the bridge, the lead starboard barge (MEM 5230) struck the protection cell of the St. Joseph Railroad Bridge.  In accordance with company policy, pilot was tested for drugs and alcohol.  Barge MEM 5230 sustained damage to the bow rake which caused water to leak into the cargo space.  The bow rake was reportedly caved in past the cargo box.  The company made arrangements for another barge to be brought in to offload the cargo from the MEM 5230.  There was no damage to the cargo, however, the cost of transferring the cargo to another barge was estimated at $36,000.  The company estimates the cost of repairs to the bow rake at $60,000.  Two other barges (MEM 94157 and MPC 32) sustained minor damage as a result of the incident.  Both barges were damaged after the MEM 5230 bounced off the protection cell and pushed into the other barges in the tow.  Both barges sustained the same damage; minor dents in the #2 wing tanks.  The estimated cost of repairs for both #2 wing tanks is $4000 ($2000 each).   Because the damage is considered minor and does not affect the structural integrity of the barges, the company may decided not to repair the damages on both the MEM 94157 and the MPC 32.

The tug MARK-C was pushing 4 barges (2 loaded & 2 empty) on the Industrial Canal headed to Algiers Fleet when it struck the concrete abutment of the Florida Ave railroad bridge at 1955 on 30 MAY 02. No pollution & no injuries resulted from this casualty.  The concrete abutment was chipped and the barge that made contact was damaged.  LA DOTD and Harbor Police inspected the damage shortly after the allision and allowed the bridge to continue operations.MARK-C and her tow were crossing under the bridge when foul weather came through and wind gusts (up to 44 mph) blew the MARK-C and her tow into the side of the dolphin adjacent to the bridge abutment.  The starboard side of the MARK-C made contact with the dolphin causing the head of the tow to come out and swing to port.  The port bow of the lead empty barge struck and chipped the concrete abutment of the bridge.

Captain of the MARK-C was tested for alcohol use by the DIO. The Florida Ave RR bridge is a combination car/RR bridge of the cantilever type.  There were intense periods of thunderstorm activity throughout the New Orleans metro area the night of the incident.  Apparent Cause: severe weather.

Vessel was proceeding upriver through open span of Crescent Rail Bridge approaching Lock and Dam 15 pushing 15 coal barges.    As the head of the tow cleared the bridge, deckhand  began to move aft on the tow when he heard tow wires part.  Wires parted at break coupling causing first nine barges to top around and come to rest on opposite side of bridge turntable with tow vessel and six barges resting on upbound side.  One tow wire on port side remained secured to forward and aft barge sections.  Vessel and barges blocked channel and prevented bridge from closing for appoximately 14 hours.  MSD investigators administerd alcohol breath test to pilot and deckhand.  Pilot submitted to chemical test.  Interviews with crewmembers and bridge tender indicated that the neither the two vessel nor the barges allided with the bridge prior to the parting of the tow wires.  Inspection of wires by MSD investigators revealed wires to be in serviceable condition.  High water and strong current may have contributed to casualty as vessel began starboard steer, coming across the current and putting strain on the tow wires.  Investigation complete.  No evidence of misconduct or negligence.

3MAY02 at approx. 1750 the M/V MARY KATHRYN was pushing a booster barge Southbound  in North Carolina on the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway. While transiting through the Figure Eight Island draw bridge the tow boat encountered a lateral current from the North East of bridge setting the stbd spud on the barge into fender wall on West entrance to draw bridge. One piling was cracked. The M/V MARY KATHRYN is a 66.5 foot towboat, built in 1950. The BOOSTER #1 is a 90 foot jack up spud barge. No damage to the barge or towboat.

3MAY01 Coast Guard Station Wrightsville boarding team members boarded MARY KATHRYN to conduct post accident inspection. Boarding report activity #1613096. No discrepancies noted.

The incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by paragraph (M) of COMDT Msg P 042025Z OCT 01. Empty oil barge NATHAN 114, towed by tug LELA JOY, allided with the Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad's Duwamish River RR bridge, while outbound. Tug ISLAND BREEZE was transiting the Lake Washington/Lake Union Ship Canal eastbound between Mats Mats quarry and Kenmore towing at less than two knots the gravel-loaded barge ITB230 at 1820 local time on Wednesday 10Jun02, when the last 1/3 of his loaded gravel barge "grazed" the University bridge's fendering with no apparent damage to the vessels or to the bridge. A Letter of Concern was issued to the vessel owner/operator.  05DEC02 Received response to LOC and scanned as Correspondence.

For the reasons detailed fully in the Investigating Officer's Narrative, which is attached to this activity as a supporting document to Correspondence # 15200, the purview of each respective agency, for the purposes of this casualty investigation, included the following:
Scope of National Transportation Safety Board Investigation (NTSB) - Determine the cause of the casualty and make recommendations to prevent reoccurrence. 
Scope of this U.S. Coast Guard Activity - Determine whether there was any violation of law or regulation associated with this casualty and prosecute enforcement activities accordingly.
Hence, the purpose of the factual narrative and the supporting evidence contained in this activity is simply to provide a factual basis to determine whether there was any violation of law or regulation and prosecute enforcement activities accordingly.
                                                                     
At approximately 0745 on May 26, 2002, the tow being pushed by the M/V ROBERT Y LOVE allided with the I-40 bridge at Webbers Falls, Arkansas. As reported on the Report of Marine Accident, Injury or Death (CG 2692) on June 24, 2002, the M/V RHETT PARKER pushing ahead six open hopper barges was transiting northbound on the on the Tombigbee River at mile 173.4.  It was reported that while setting up to transit under the Naheola Bridge, the vessel developed a little side motion toward the west bridge pillar. As reported on the Report of Marine Accident, Injury and Death (CG 2692), on June 22, 2002 the M/V CHARLES M pushing two red flag barges was transiting near mile 003 on the Tombigbee River setting up to transit under the Chickasaw Creek Railroad Bridge.  It was reported that as the vessel approached the bridge, the barges swung out of position.  Traveling at approximately .5 MPH, the lead barge allided with the protective fender system of the bridge bending the handrail on the bridge.  No damage was noted on the barges. This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M) of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.  6/25/02  @ 2100L - HMRMS CDO received notification from Baltimore Pilot, aboard the outbound M/V TAMESIS, reporting a loss of propulsion between trestles B and C of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel (CBBT).  At approximately 2000L, within one NM of the CBBT, pilot noticed a reduction of the main diesel engine (MDE) rpm's to dead slow ahead.  While abreast of trestles B and C the MDE shut down.  Two attempts to restart the MDE failed.  Pilot and the master decided to allow the vessel to drift with the wind and current back through the CBBT.  The 1,800 hp bow and stern thrusters and the steering gear were available to the pilot at all times.  Pilot stated that the wind and current safely carried the vessel back over the tunnel and the vessel remained parallel to the channel at all times.  Once clear of the CBBT the pilot spun the vessel using the thrusters and anchored the vessel in position 37-04.5N / 076-06.4W.  The vessel was issued a Captain of the Port (COTP)  Order to remain at anchor pending identification of the fault and corrective action.  6/25/02 @ 2250L - The crew shut down the automation system and were able to restart the MDE.  The crew cleaned and tested the fuel and air start systems and found no deficiencies.  6/26/02 - Det Norske Veritas (DNV) surveyor confirmed proper operation of the automation and propulsion system; however, due to the fact that the cause was not identified the vessel was released from the COTP Order contingent on a tug escort through the CBBT.

A small passenger vessel inspector from the Marine Safety Office in Miami, Florida was notified by a local mariner on June 25, 2002 that the PV CARROUSEL, O.N. 583015, was involved in an allision with the SE 3 rd Avenue drawbridge while traveling outbound (SE) on the New River at Fort Lauderdale, Florida on June 19, 2002.  Master of the PV CARROUSEL requested the SE 3rd Avenue bridge to be opened by the bridge tender.  The bridge tender acknowledged request and began opening the bridge.  The south span of the bridge began to close while the vessel was traveling underneath.  The master of the vessel blew the danger signal to notify the bridge tender of the emergency, but the bridge tender did not respond.  The master increased the vessel's speed to exit as quickly as possible and avoid the vessel from being struck.  The south span of the bridge struck the vertical support of the starboard side damaging the vessel's radar arch.  Estimated damage to the vessel does not exceed $25,000.  No damage to the bridge.  No injuries occurred as a result of the marine casulaty.  A U. S. Coast Guard form 2692 was filed on June 27, 2002.

No reported damage to the barge, no injuries or no pollution reported.  The apparent cause was human error in that the operator failed to maintain control of his tow while passing through the bridge.  Contributing factor was current and wind.  Allision was initially reported by the bridge tender 11 days following incident.  DCA per G-MOA ltr 01-00.

Report of the Grounding of the F/V FALLEN ANGEL


The following report has been obtained from COGARD STA PASCAGOULA MS 2010453Z AUG 02, Law Enforcement SITREP One and Final. On 20 August 02, the Pascagoula Police Dept. were enforcing the No-wake zone near construction operations being conducted at the Hwy 90 bridge in Pascagoula, MS.  The F/V FALLEN ANGEL was towing the F/V LUCKY L & V in excess of the speed/wake restrictions. The F/V FALLEN ANGEL was hailed by Pascagoula Police to slow down but did not reply. The Pascagoula Police boat was positioned in front of the oncoming vessels as a deterrent to force them to reduce their speed. When the vessels would not slow down the Police personnel drew their weapons. The Operator of the F/V FALLEN ANGEL, Operator immediately ran his vessel aground.

According to operator the bridge operator opened the bridge to allow both vessels to transit through. He stated that control of both vessels was minimized due to the size of both vessels and the current, preventing him from stopping. Once he saw the police officers draw their weapons he panicked and intentionally grounded the F/V FALLEN ANGEL. No damage was reported to either vessel as a result of the grounding. Coast Guard Station Pascagoula personnel assisted the vessels and the voyage continued without further incident.

After numerous attempts to reach operator via telephone, he reported to the Marine Safety Office in Mobile, AL to complete the CG-2692, Report of Marine Accident, Injury or Death form.  The CG-2692 form written by operator lacks detail due to his English writing skills. He was interviewed and found that the details matched the events listed above.

Environmental Conditions: Daytime, clear skies, Good visibility of 7 NM, Winds and seas calm.

//s//
Chief Warrant Officer, U.S. Coast Guard
Investigating Officer
Marine Safety Office, Mobile, AL

Tug Evergreen State hit Townsend’s Inlet bridge on 15 Aug and damaged fendering system.  No damage to bridge. CG Sta (sm) TI responded and conducted assessment, but no boarding.  During course of events between 15 Aug and 07 Oct bridge was struck several times by three tugs and barges, with different operators working on same dredging project.

This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M) of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.

8/29/02 - The UTV SARA KAITLIN was pushing two empty hopper barges northbound on the Elizabeth River.  At 2206L HMRMS' CDO received notification from captain,  reporting that the Jordan Lift Bridge operator lowered the bridge while his vessel was passing underneath, striking his vessel. 

At approximately 2145L, the SARA KAITLIN was following the UTV CAPTAIN RON L northbound at the Middle Reach of the Elizabeth River, approaching the Jordan Lift Bridge.  Captain of the CAPTAIN RON L contacted the bridge operator,  via channel 13 VHF, requesting an opening.  The SARA KAITLIN was 200 yards behind the CAPTAIN RON L as it approached and completed its transit through the bridge span.  

Captain commenced his approach to the open span.  He did not contact the bridge operator as required by regulation.  As the barges crossed under the open span of the Jordan Lift Bridge the bridge began to close.  Captain contacted the bridge via channel 13 VHF asking the bridge operator to keep the bridge open.  He responded and asked the tug to stop.  Bridge operator then reversed the bridge closing sequence.  These actions were too late and the bridge deck struck the mast and navigational equipment array atop the pilothouse of the SARA KAITLIN.

The vessel was issued a Captain of the Port (COTP)  Order to remain at the Vulcan Marine Yard pending an assessment of the vessel's navigational abilities and corrective action.

8/30/02 - W. R. Tye & Associates, marine surveyor, confirmed proper operation of the replaced navigational equipment and the vessel was released from the COTP Order.

The IO contacted  Risk Manager for the City of Chesapeake, VA to obtain information on the training of bridge operators and the written procedures they use for operation of the bridge.  On 9/10/02  Risk Manager provided a copy of the emergency operation procedures for the Jordan Lift Bridge, instead of the requested information.

10/30/02 - The IO and  Fifth Coast Guard District (Obr), met with Bridge Administrator for the City of Chesapeake.  The Bridge Administrator provided the previously requested Operating Procedures and discussed the training of the bridge operators. 

The cause of this allision was the failure of the bridge operator to follow the written procedures for the operation of the bridge, in that he failed to ensure river traffic in both directions was clear prior to initiating the closing sequence of the bridge.  Contributing to this allision was the failure of the master of the SARA KAITLIN to signal the Jordan Bridge for a required opening as required by 33 CFR 117.19.

On 23 July 2002, around 2050 hours the M/V St. Louis was transiting north bound with 6 loaded regulation barges, the port string in the tow made incidental contact with the bridge fender system.  Inspection by the crew revealed no damage to the barges or the bridge fender system.  Notifications were made to the proper authorities.

While heading southbound on the Barataria Waterway approaching the Bayou Barataria Bridge, towing vessel TYLER, pushing 4 barges, was being operated by an undocumented mariner.  The licensed Captain of the vessel was on board but was not on the bridge at the time of the incident.  The dimensions of the tow were 450 feet long x 75 feet wide.  According to Chart 11365, the horizontal clearance of the waterway beneath the bridge was 77 feet after the bridge is swung open.  The operator was in communication with the bridge attendant during the approach.  The attendant informed the operator that vessels over 70 feet wide cannot pass through, which he apparently did not understand; when the attendant informed him that the bridge was all the way open, he still attempted to pass through with his 75-foot wide tow.  When the tow was approximately 40 feet from the bridge, the attendant contacted the operator again and instructed him not to enter because the tow looked too wide.  As the operator of the tug backed the engines down, the tow struck the piling next to the bridge and they broke.  The tow subsequently struck a piling attached to a nearby private wharf, damaging that piling as well.  There were no injuries or pollution associated with this incident, and none of the barges or the tug were damaged.  Drug testing conducted on operator.  Property damage summary is estimated.

Contributing causes to this casualty:
1.  Unlicensed mariner operating the vessel, who was also apparently unfamiliar with navigation of the area.
2.  Human error - miscommunication between operator of tug and bridge attendant.  Operator did not heed bridge attendant's direction not to attempt to pass.
3.  Horizontal clearance when bridge is opened marked as 77 feet on the chart, but vessels greater than 70 feet in breadth are prohibited from passing.

At 2130LCL, received notification via MSO that the M/V Marinette, while down bound on the Menominee River,  under bow and stern tow, had allided with the Ogden Street Bridge.  By way of Station Sturgeon Bay small boat, MSD investigators responded to the vessel which was at anchor approximately 3 NM NE of the entrance to Menominee River.  Initial inspection of the vessel revealed only superficial damage including an inset of 24" by 6" to the bulwark of the port bow and paint scraping to the outboard overhead just below the starboard boat deck (see Evidence).

During an interview, the M/V Marinette's master stated that upon approaching the bridge, the M/V Marinette was lined up with the opening.  But as the M/V Marinette neared, a strong current set the vessel to the north of opening.  Both tow vessels were then ordered by the Pilot, to pull to the south.  The pilot then came ahead to avoid grounding at port quarter.  The vessel continued to be set north and at 2056LCL contacted the northwest section of the bridge.  Since the tugs were pulling strongly to the south, the vessel then headed south and at 2058LCL contacted the bridge tender house located on the southeast section of the bridge.  The M/V Marinette then continued down river and at 2101 was released from tow.  The master also stated that this was his first transit of this river during the night and that, as a result of this incident, he had no intention of conducting a night transit in the future.

Investigators then proceeded to the bridge to assess damage.  Initial inspection revealed moderate damage to a concrete structure on the northwest section of the bridge and damage to the roof overhang of the bridge tender's house on the southeast section of the bridge (see Evidence).  Wisconsin Department of Transportation damage assessments estimated approximately $60,000 of damage had occurred.  No injuries or pollution occurred.

During an interview of the operator of the forward tow Tug Carla Anne Selvick, he stated that he had noticed no problems with navigating his vessel down river.  He also stated he had noted no difficulties with communication with the other vessels and that all maneuvering orders were being given by the pilot on board the M/V Marinette.  Upon approaching the bridge, he stated, that he was ordered to proceed straight as the tow was then lined up with the bridge passage.  Upon entering the passage, he was ordered to pull south.  But, due to being within the passage, he was unable to pull south until his tug had cleared the bridge.  He further stated that he had only transited the river at night approximately twice before.

During an interview of the operator of the stern tow Tug Jacquelyn Nicole,  he stated he had made multiple routine maneuvers with his vessel throughout the tow to compensate for the disturbance created by the M/V Marinette's maneuvering.  He also stated that there had been no difficulties with the tow prior to the allision.  He further stated he believed current to be the reason the M/V Marinette had been set.

During an interview with the master, he stated that at approximately one boat length before reaching the bridge passage that the M/V Marinette was lined up for the passage.  He also stated that there had been no difficulties with communication with the other vessels and that there had been no difficulties with the tow prior to the M/V Marinette being set and alliding with the bridge.  He further stated that upon the vessel being set to the north, he brought the M/V Marinette ahead to avoid grounding at the port quarter and to use bridge fendering system to aid in turning the vessel.  But, due to the flare of the vessel's bow, the M/V Marinette also contacted a concrete structure on the northwest section of the bridge.  He also stated that upon the vessel being set to the north, he ordered the tow vessel to pull to the south.  He further stated that he had only one prior transit of this area during the night.

Cause of the casualty was determined to be unforeseen marine conditions, a northerly current in vicinity of the bridge, that all parties were unable to respond to in such time as to avoid the allision.  A loss of situational awareness, on the part of the pilot, with regards to the location of the tow vessels, and lack of experience with night transits of this area, were contributing factors.

Vessel allided w/ vertical lift railroad bridge @ Greens Bayou on the Houston Ship Channel, a navigable water of the United States.  Allision occurred on 31 Oct 02 @ approx 1045.  Encl (1).  Bridge owned/operated by Port Terminal Railroad Association.  D8 (cc) & D8 (ob) timely notified of bridge allision.  Encl (12).

No injuries or pollution associated w/ incident; however, wheelhouse of vessel sustained damage to hydraulic lift system, starboard search light & exterior visor overhanging wheelhouse.  Encl (11).  Wheelhouse damage estimated to be $15,250.  Encl (3).  No damage to bridge.  Encl (10).

Vessel was pushing one uninspected hopper barge (OR6238) loaded w/ steel pipe at time of incident.  No damage to barge.  Vessel was transiting inbound Greens Bayou from Megafleet to Walton's Terminal at time of allision.  Encl (1) & (5).  Person operating vessel at the time is currently on the 7th issue of his license & has never had any disciplinary action taken against his merchant mariner credentials (MMC) by the Coast Guard.  He has no record of any prior marine casualties or incidents in MISLE.  Encl (6) & (7).

Operator advised that the bridge tender raised the vertical lift railroad bridge all the way up a few minutes before the allision, which we verified w/ the bridge tender.  Encl (9).  As the bridge was being raised, he began jacking down the hydraulic lift wheelhouse, which was fully extended so that he could see over the barge he was pushing.  UTV MR VANCE was approx 1000' from the bridge at this time & was "drifting" w/ the tide/current towards the bridge (engines idling).  The current was approx 2 knots running north, i.e. towards the bridge, w/ winds blowing approx 5mph in the same direction.  The wheelhouse started to lower but then suddenly stopped.  Captain tried to go full astern but it was too late as the wheelhouse allided w/ the underside of the bridge.  Encl (1).  Captain explained that he did not lower the wheelhouse any sooner b/c he needed to maintain maximum range of vision over the barge he was pushing for as long a time as possible to ensure a safe transit under the bridge.  It is essentially a matter of timing to lower the wheelhouse at the last possible moment in order to safely complete this evolution, which the Captain had successfully completed many times before w/out incident over the past couple years he has been on the UTV MR VANCE.  

According to the Captain, there were never any problems w/the wheelhouse before this incident, so it surprised him that it failed so suddenly & at such an inopportune time.  In fact, the wheelhouse raised/lowered properly earlier in the day when UTV MR VANCE passed under the same bridge, pushing the same barge (except it was empty), outbound Greens Bayou @ approx 0900.  Encl (9).

Captain advised that, when fully extended, the wheelhouse is approx 28' above the deck of the UTV.  Based on measurements we took after the incident, large steel hopper covers were stacked 12.5' high above main deck of the barge, fore & aft.  Combined w/ freeboard above 8' draft of loaded barge, the covers were approx 20' above the water line at the time of the incident (20' estimate verified by crewmember on UTV who observed covers while they were pushing barge).  

These hopper covers created an obvious obstruction to UTV's line of sight, causing Captain to jack up wheelhouse as high as it could go in order to see above barge as he pushed it.  Captain advised that he prefers to maintain, if possible, at least 5' of clearance above barges he pushes in order to ensure a full range of vision.  

The steel pipe in the hopper of the barge was not loaded in such a manner as to prevent hopper covers from being secured in place prior to transit; however, the crew who loaded barge left the covers stacked on the deck instead of securing them in place.  This essentially resulted in an additional 12.5' of vertical obstruction for Captain.

While approaching the Rigolets CSX Railroad Bridge, tug ANNETTE pushing one barge ahead was forced into the guidewall by 25-30 knot southwest winds and approximately 6-knot current from west to east.  The barge was pushed into the east side of the guidewall and subsequently bounced off and hit the west side of the guidewall, resulting in significant damage to both sidewalls as well as damage to the barge.

After the incident, both operators were instructed by the operating company to stop and wait any time winds are above 10 knots and current is 5 to 6 knots.

The "Pilot" states that although he was on watch and steering at the time of the incident, he was not in direct control of the vessel.  He states that the Captain did not trust him and was therefore directing him in the operation of the vessel.  The Captain was, in fact, on the bridge, but states that he was not directing the movement of the vessel, and was simply giving advice when needed.  The Captain further states that the Pilot was lined up nicely, but that the vessel was simply overcome by the wind and current, and there was nothing that could have been done differently in the maneuver.  There was obviously a good deal of miscommunication on the bridge just prior to the allision (question as to speed of the vessel, which guide wall to line up on, and who was in command of the vessel's movement).

The Captain stated that this bridge is dangerous because of cross-currents and wind, and recommends that the guide walls be extended in order to make transit easier.

Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was done after this incident.

As stated in the CG2692, on 17OCT02 the M/V PASCAGOULA was underway with six barges on
the Tombigbee River. In the area of mile marker 173 the vessel approached the Naheola Bridge.
As the vessel passed through, it was set broadside onto the east pier of the bridge. No damage to
the vessel or bridge was detected at the time. The vessel proceeded to its next port of call without further incident.  The owners of the bridge were contacted and informed of the incident. Later the bridge owners contacted the C.G. and reported that the bridge was inspected and no damage was detected.

P.O.

On 10 November 2002 at approximately 2120, the tug BARBARA TAYLOR was transiting southbound at mile 57 of the Ouachita River pushing ahead two empty tank barges when they allided with the Harrisburg Highway Swing Bridge.  The tank barges were configured one in front of the other.  The port bow of the lead tank barge, GBL 430, allided with the support pillar located on the west span on the Harrisburg Highway Swing Bridge as it entered the west bridge span.  As a result of the allision, the tank barge GBL 430 sustained approximately 20K in damage to its port bow headlog and rake knuckle.  A CG-835 was issued requiring the GBL 430 to be repaired by 11 December 2002.   The second tank barge, GBL 330, and the tug BARBARA TAYLOR sustained no damage as a result of the allision.  A representative from the Louisiana State Highway Department inspected the bridge and found no damage.  No pollution, injuries or further damage occurred.   

   The operator, stated he transited this area over thirty times in the past year without incident.  

Apparent Cause:
   The apparent cause of the allision was high winds from a strong storm front which passed through the area at the time of the incident.  The high winds associated with the front set the stern of the vessel to starboard which in turn caused the bow of the lead barge to turn to port and strike the bridge support pillar.  The operator was unable to stop the vessels forward momentum or the vessels swing towards the support pillar in order to prevent the allision.

32/147/02

11/11/2002 - According to 2692:
At approximately 0030 on November 11, 2002 the M/V PAIGE GERTRUDE was pushing 4 empty hopper barges with the covers of the hoppers stacked on the decks of the barges.  The vessel was making an approach to the Louisa Bridge (Mile 134-GIWW).  The tow was lined up between the lights of the bridge until it reached the 300' mark from the bridge at which time the Master, lost sight of the light on the North fender wall.  Due to the height of the stacked covers, and the high winds in the area the tow appears to have veered to the North causing barge RM 87 to make contact with the guide wall and bridge itself.  Damage was sustained to the North fender wall, bridge and barge RM 87.  MSO Morgan City was notified and no injuries were reported.

Recommend LOW be issued to Master of vessel.

1. Received information on 11/26/2002 from LT, PCDO that two barges were cut away from a pier in Jamaica Bay and went aground on a sand beach. The UTV Harbor II was tasked with recovering the barges. While attempting to do so, the Harbor II went soft aground.
No damage waas sustained as a result of this incident.  

2. 2692 was requested as well as drug and alcohol testing.

3. 2692 received.

4. The Master of the Harbor II was operating when the Vsl went aground, he does not have a CG license for Master of Uninspected Towing Vessels.  This case is being refered for enforcement against him for operating outside the limitations of his OUPV license.
