LTJG

On 21 November 2002 at approximately 1000, the tug GINNY STONE was southbound in the vicinity of mile 167 on the Lower Mississippi River pushing ahead 35 barges when the dry-cargo barge, SG 637, allided with the Sunshine Bridge.  The apparent cause of the allision was the operator onboard the tug GINNY STONE.  Operator setting-up for his transit under the Sunshine Bridge too close to the center span.

See correspondence #9175 for details.

While being pushed northbound in the Inner Harbor Navigation Canal ("Industrial Canal") by the tug TYLER, the barge LEVIATHAN allided with the Judge Seeber Bridge ("Claiborne Ave Bridge").  As the vessels were traveling at approximately 5 knots, the operator was concentrating on maneuvering within the canal, monitoring traffic, the weather, transiting the locks, and the effect of his wake on smaller, docked vessels, etc.  Upon realizing that the vessel did not have the vertical clearance to pass beneath the bridge, the operator put the engines to full astern, but the barge was already approximately 200 feet from the bridge, and did not stop in time to avoid striking the bridge.  The starboard forward spud allided with the underside of the bridge, and was bent to an approximately 45-degree angle (see survey report for damage details).  The bridge did not show any obvious structural damage; only a few scrapes.  IO attempted to obtain copies of the bridge survey from the bridge maintenance office, but was unsuccessful.

The Master/operator of the vessel admitted (to the IO) his own failure to call the bridge tender to have them raise the bridge prior to the arrival of his vessel.

All vessel navigation and engineering systems were operational before, during, and after the casualty.

In addition to lack of communication between the tug operator and the bridge tender, a contributing factor to this allision was an apparent lack of communication between the tug operator and his crew on the bow.  For communication with his crew, the operator had been using VHF channel 10.  His crew attempted to remind him that he would have to call the bridge tender to ask them to raise the draw bridge prior to the barge transiting below.  However, in the moments leading up to the allision, the operator had switched to channels 13 and 14, and therefore did not hear the reminders from his crew.

On 11/05/02 at 1110 the tug SEAWIND, barge MARY P, and assist boat SALVAGE STAR were proceeding up the Annisquam river through the BLYNMAN Bridge to conduct dredging operations. During the transit through the bridge the MARY P's rub rail struck a navigational light that was attached to the fendering system on the bridge. As a result, the light was cracked at the base and was no longer operational. The master of the vessel immediately agreed to pay for the damage and the light was subsequently repaired.

On 11/06/02 at 0945 during high tide the barge struck a different navigational light attached to the fendering system snapping it at its base. The master of the vessel again paid for the light and it was subsequently repaired.

On 12/04/02 the barge struck the fendering system and damaged a sign. The sign marked a submerged cable 
and the sign was submerged at the time it was struck. The sign was attached to the outside portion of the fender system.

On 12/05/02 MSO Boston Investigator attended the bridge to check for damage. Photographs of the light placement were taken and the bridge operator was interviewed. The bridge operator stated that the barge was very wide with 6 inches of clearance on either side. The waterway is dramatically restricted at the BLYNMAN Bridge, producing a 3 kt current. While transiting the bridge, the barge was supported by two vessels, one fore and one aft. The bridge operator stated that the operators always transited slowly and were very concerned when they damaged the lights. MSO Boston received a fax from  Massachusetts Bridges and Highways division, detailing the allisions. Received CG-2692's for all allisions from the Fore River Dock & Dredge, Inc. The dredge work has since been completed and the barge MARY P will no longer be transiting the bridge.

Conclusions
The  placement of the lights and sign on the bridge appear to be the primary reason that any damage occurred. If the lights and sign were placed further back from the bridge the barge would never have touched them. The size of the barge (36.1ft w) combined with the width of the bridge (39ft) and the current made it almost impossible for the barge to get through the bridge without touching. The barge operator appeared to use all possible means to avoid the allision, including using a vessel on either end of the barge. The operator of the barge willingly admitted to the incidents and readily paid for the replacement of the lights.

Recommend that the Captain of the Port initiate an examination of the BLYNMAN Bridge in conjunction with the Massachusetts State Highway department; specifically to address the placement of the navigation lights, hazard markings, and the maximum width of vessels allowed through the bridge. MSO Boston Waterways division and the State Highway department are working on making changes.

Recommend this activity be closed, no further agency action required.

12/7/2002:  The uninspected towing vessel ANDREW CARGILL MACMILLAN was south bound on the Lower Mississippi River pushing ahead 46 loaded freight barges.  Capt. Joseph A. Dragon, Jr. was on watch in the pilothouse.  The MACMILLAN and tow was passing Memphis, TN on or about 1310 and approaching the 3 bridges located at Mile 734.7.  From north to south the bridges are the Harahan R/R Bridge, Burlington Northern R/R Bridge, and the I-55 Highway Bridge.  Note:  These three bridges are correctly identified in the USCG Light List; however, the USACoE Flood Control and Navigation Maps (Map No. 57) incorrectly identifies the Harahan and Burlington R/R Bridges.

At approximately 1315 the MACMILLAN was flanking the tow through the bridges.   Capt. Dragon, Jr. misjudged how fast the tow was flanking and the starboard string of barges grazed the Harahan R/R Bridge's right descending bank pier of the channel span.  The tow broke away from the MACMILLAN and several local fleeting towboats were deployed to round up the breakaway barges.  Four barges sustained damage.  The SG 569B flooded its box bow void; however, the barge was still seaworthy and placed back into the tow.  The AT 515B and AB 83 were both intentionally grounded to prevent them from sinking.  Both barges are located near the LDB at Mile 733.  The AT 689B sank near the LDB at Mile 730.

1640:  MSO Memphis Investigators LCDR N. Shoemaker, PO1 Dunfee arrived on scene.  It was determined that Capt. Dragon's Fatigue Index Score was 22.5;  Whereas, a score of 50 or above may indicate fatigue as a possible casual factor.

Budwine and Associates, Inc. were contracted to salvage the two grounded barges and raise the sunken barge.

On 20Oct02 at approx 1540 the UTV MONICA LEE was heading east through the Roosevelt railroad bridge and rubbed the north fendering system of the bridge.  The operator of the UTV stated that while passing through the bridge the cross current caused by eddies from the high-rise bridge suddenly caused the bow of the barge to sheer to port resulting in the barge rubbing the fendering system of the bridge .  The operator made attempts to avoid making contact with the bridge but rubbed the fendering system. The operator observe no damage to the bridge.  FEC later reported that a sensor for the RR bridge had been compromised and believed that the MONICA LEE was the cause of the sensor failure.  MSD IO responded and inspected the bridge and found no damage or evidence of an allision to the bridge.  

16Jan03:  Received notification from USCG D7 Bridge Section that their representatives went out and surveyed the bridge and found that all previous repairs have been completed in accordance with the approved plans and the maximum width between the fendering system is 50 feet.  Reps noted strong current passing through the bridge span.

Conclusion:  The span between the fendering system is only 50 feet.  There are strong currents, eddies caused by the high-rise bridge to the east and the old US 1 bridge to the west.  The three bridges are in close proximity (approx 250 yds apart) and aligned and in such a position that vessels must turn while passing through the three bridges.  The operator was proceeding at only 1 knot and took all precautions to avoid making contact with the fendering system but due to the weather and tidal condition rubbed the fendering system.    The operator was operating in a prudent manner and no further action is recommended.

On December 6, 2002 at approximately 1415, the M/V JOSEPH PATRICK ECKSTIEN (ON# 600552), a 140 foot line boat operated by Bluegrass Marine Inc, was transiting the UMR south bound at mile 169 just north of the Jefferson Barracks (JB) Bridge with 30 hopper barges in tow, when the lead port barge CC-7927 struck the LDB and grounded.  When the operator, XXXX attempted to straighten out his tow, he was unable to control the vessel and struck the RDB with barge CC95102 and the vessel.  The subsequent grounding broke away several mooring wires causing the first fifteen barges directly in front of the M/V JOSEPH PATRICK ECKSTIEN to break away.  The forward fifteen barges remained together at that time.  Mr. XXXX reported the breakaway over the radio to all vessels in the immediate area to assist.  Five tugs from Riverway arrived on-scene within minutes and started to gather the drifting barges.  The M/V JOSEPH PATRICK ECKSTIEN proceeded to push the remaining fifteen barges through the JB Bridge and attempted to tie them along side the dolphins directly below the bridge.  During the attempt to moor the remaining barges, the mooring wires started to break away and as a result the remaining fifteen barges were also set adrift.  Vessels in the area responded and were able to gather up all drifting barges without incident.

CWO XXXX and MK2 XXXX, MSO ST. Louis arrived on-scene approximately 1630 and started to assess the incident.  Most barges were already being made back in the tow.  Two barges CC-7927 and CC-95102 sustained damage in the incident.  There were no other barges damaged.  Upon investigation of the abutment to the JB Bridge, it was apparent that the bridge had been struck by one of the adrift barges.  There was little damage to the abutment, mostly cosmetic damage to the concrete facing to the abutment (photos attached to the case file).  The master of the M/V JOSEPH PATRICK ECKSTIEN stated that he did not see any barges hit the bridge, but acknowledged that he did not see every barge transit through the bridge.  The investigation to the barges damaged indicates the barge CC-7927 struck the abutment.  There was heavy damage to the port corner of the bow rake that is indicative to the damage that would have occurred by striking the bridge.

It is the opinion of this investigator that the cause of the grounding and subsequent break away is a result of low water conditions in the UMR and operator error on the part of Mr. XXXX  There are indication that the three buoys directly north of the JB Bridge are missing which could have been a factor to the grounding, however the fact that the river stage was at a negative 2.3 at the time of the grounding, the master of the M/V JOSEPH PATRICK ECKSTIEN should have exercised more caution when operating in an area with missing aids.

32/153/02

The M/V SHIRLEY P. SETTOON was pushing two (2) loaded barges abreast of each other, while transiting west bound on the Falgout Canal.  The current of the river was also moving west bound @ approximately 4 mph with a northerly wind @ 20 mph.  Due to these conditions, the Master was not able to get his tow straightened out when he tried to pass through the Falgout Bridge.  His port barge allided with the south finder on the bridge.  No Damage/Injuries reported.

12 DEC 02 - As per PHONCON with Company Rep., on the 2692, the statement that there is a "Description of accident on separate sheet" is misleading, because he could not locate any other sheet nor did he have any knowledge of one.

At approx. 2140 the Tug SAVANNAH pushing the Barge B-18, loaded with 15,000 Barrels of #6 Fuel Oil, departed Allied fuel Pier in Charleston, SC.  At approx. 2255 on the 1st of June, 2002, the Tug and barge were Southbound on the ICW in the vicinity of the Wappo Cut draw bridge when it allided with the North West fender system of the bridge. The Tug operator had lined the barge up on the North west side of the bridge and was slowly moving forward when he attempted to actuate the barge's bow thruster to push the barge away from the Northwest side but inadvertently energized the bow thruster in the wrong direction.  This pushed the barge to the starboard  into the fender system.  Once operator realized he had actuated the bow thruster in the wrong direction he shifted it to the port and put the tug in reverse in an attempt to minimize the impact to the fenders and bridge.  Due to the current and the velocity of the tug and barge he felt they were going to be put in a more precarious position if he continued to back out so he decided to power through. This resulted in the barge causing damage to the fender system but no impact/damage to the bridge structure and no personnel injured. Master notified Coast Guard, was directed to proceed to Stevens Towing were investigator met vessel.

Incident Brief:

On 28Jun02, a 12-barge fleet of barges was moored at the Upper River Services Dakota Barge Fleet located at MM 836.2 on the UMR.  The barges were tied together awaiting a towboat for transit south down the river.

At approximately 1315 local time, the UTV ITASCA received a call stating that the above referenced string of barges had broken away from its mooring and was drifting south toward the Pig's Eye Railroad Bridge (located at MM 835.7 on the UMR).  Also, around the same time the UTV KATHY ELLEN w/11-barge tow, was spotted transiting north through the section of the Mississippi River that runs adjacent to the downtown St. Paul Airport (approx UMR mile 838). 

In response to the breakaway call, Upper River Services (URS) dispatched all of their available towboats (6-total) to the scene for recovery operations.  The UTV ITASCA was the first to arrive on-scene.  The crew of the ITASCA reported that the fleet of barges bounced off the right descending bank and continued down river until landing broadside against the Pig's Eye Railroad Bridge's northern protection cell.  Six of the barges then broke off from the tow and came to rest against the left descending bank on the north side of the railroad bridge.  The remaining six barges remained perpendicular (blocking the entire river) with the Freight Barge AGS 943 (originally the port lead barge in the string) resting against the bridge's protection cell. 

USCG Group Upper Mississippi River issued an urgent notice to mariners informing boat traffic of the river blockage at 1715 local time.  Investigators from MSD St. Paul arrived on scene around that time and enacted an emergency river closure at the Pig's Eye RR Bridge.  Members from the CG Auxiliary arrived on-scene at 1750 and helped to enforce the closure, which affected numerous recreational vessels and a couple small passenger vessels.  The closure was in effect until approx 1830 (local).

URS personnel responded quickly and commenced barge recovery operations.  The AGS 943 sustained severe damage to the port side amidships shell plating and was taking on water.  Several pumps were installed and the barge was eventually dewatered to a point that allowed for recovery off of the bridge protection cell.  The 6-barges resting perpendicular in the channel were recovered first and the channel was cleared and reopened by 1830.  Recovery operations then shifted to the barges along the left descending bank and the scene was wrapped up at 2020.  

Post accident analysis revealed that a port deck fitting on the stern of the Freight Barge AGS 967 failed.  Prior to the incident, the fitting had been the point where the aft end of the 12-barge string was secured to the mooring lines.  The fitting subsequently ended up bent at a 90-degree angle after the plating beneath it broke away from the barge's main deck.   Total damage to the AGS 967 was estimated at $600.
 
The AGS 943 suffered major structural damage to the port side shell, main deck and bottom plating around amidships.  Overall the barge suffered $76,000 in damages and another $7,000 in lost/damaged cargo.

Lock & Dam 1 ACOE personnel reported that the river flow rate at the time of the incident was 24,305 CFS.  They also stated that the above flow rate is double the average June flow rate and was four times higher than the flow rate on 21 June 2002 (one week prior to the incident).  The sudden increase in flow was cause by heavy rains that swept through central MN on June 22nd (3.1") and 25th (1.6").  ACOE personnel estimated that the corresponding Mississippi River current in the vicinity of St. Paul would have been 5 to 6 knots.

Lock & Dam 2 ACOE personnel reported that only two tows locked through on 28 June 2002 and supplied the actual lockage records for the towboats.  The records indicate that the UTV KATHY ELLEN completed n-bound lockage at 0630 (local time) with a string of 11-barges and that the UTV NEIL N. DIEHL completed n-bound lockage at 1130 (local time) with a string of 12-barges. 

A review of the Mississippi River charts indicates that the distance from L&D 2 to the Dakota Barge Fleet is about 20.7 NM.

Opinions:

After considering interviews with URS personnel, reviewing ACOE lock records and projecting a northerly towboat speed made good of approximately 3-knots, it is probable that the UTV KATHY ELLEN was transiting  near the Dakota Barge Fleeting area when the incident occurred.  It is also likely that the KATHY ELLEN was generating a wake as it attempted to overcome a strong current with a large string of barges.  It is also possible that fleeting tugs and recreational vessels may have been in the area at the time of the incident.

URS mooring lines and methods in place at the time of the incident are considered adequate for the prevailing conditions.  URS has historically had numerous barge strings in place at several mooring locations throughout the navigation season.  This has been accomplished without any notable record of breakaways.  In this case, their standard mooring practices were adhered to.  However, the fact the barges were fleeted together put a lot of strain on the mooring lines and barge deck fittings since they were holding the entire string of barges as a composite unit.  

URS emergency response to the incident was very timely/effective and greatly minimized the overall disruption to vessel traffic and the potential for further damage.

The deck fitting on the AGS 967 should not have failed under the prevailing conditions.  The plating, securing the fitting to the main deck, was weakened in some manner prior to the incident.

Overall, the incident is considered an accident with no noteworthy negligence on behalf of the involved parties.  Thus, no civil penalty or suspension/revocation actions were initiated.

Conclusion:

The weakened deck fitting on the AGS 967 is a considered to be a major contributing factor to the incident in that it failed and allowed the barge string's stern mooring line to slip off.

The strong river current is considered a contributing factor in that it applied considerable force to the composite barge string and mooring lines.  The strong current also made it more difficult for northerly tows to transit without generating a wake.

A vessel wake (most likely from the UTV KATHY ELLEN) is considered to be a contributing factor in that it was the probable source of a dynamic shock force that broke the barge string away from its mooring.

On January 7, 2003, at approximately 1410, the Derrick Barge HAGAR allided with the eastern edge/underside of the Union Pacific Railroad (UPRR) Bridge between Benicia, California and Martinez, California.  The UPRR Bridge suffered minor structural damage and rail service was stopped for two hours and forty minutes pending the post-casualty safety inspection.  The HAGAR suffered significant damage throughout the derrick, its foundation and the barge's two spuds.  In recognition of the damage to the derrick and barge, the HAGAR was maneuvered out of the channel for post-casualty inspection and temporary bracing prior to being moved to Richmond, California for permanent repairs.  

The primary causal factor in this marine casualty was the mistaken belief by the Master of the towboat, the M/V BEARCAT, that the derrick would "clear" all bridges.   Statements taken from the tow operator, the deckhand (Deck-Engineer) and representatives from the HAGAR, indicated that the barge crew did tell the tow operator that the derrick would clear all bridges.  Unfortunately, it was never explicitly stated that in order to clear the UPRR Bridge, the lift section of that bridge would need to be in the raised position.  The air-draft of the HAGAR was calculated as 117 feet above the water and the clearance of the UPRR Bridge with the lift section in the down position was less than 70 feet.

There was no pollution or personal injuries as a result of this incident.  No Enforcement Action (EA) was taken against the crew of the BEARCAT.

On 12 January 2003 at 0010 the M/V NCC MEKKA, O.N. 9047752, a 176.9 meter Norwegian flagged tank ship was in the process of departing the Chemserve Facility on the west side of the Hilton Railroad Bridge on the Cape Fear River in Wilmington, NC. The NCC MEKKA was being towed at the stern by the towing vessel FORT BRAGG, O.N.  1074922.

The Cape Fear River above the Hilton Railroad Bridge has no turning basin, the only method for ships departing the Chemserve Facility is to be towed backwards by the stern until they are well clear of the Hilton Railroad Bridge before they can turn around.

The towboat FORT BRAGG was passing through the Hilton Railroad Bridge, towing the NCC MEKKA by the stern, the NCC MEKKA was using the bow thruster to keep her bow in line, when the pilot onboard the NCC MEKKA determined the bow thruster was not working.

The NCC MEKKA master and the pilot immediately ordered forward turns to keep from passing under the bridge, when the ship began to power back up river, she towed the towing vessel, FORT BRAGG. The FORT BRAGG now under tow, struck the north side fendering system as she was towed backwards causing damage to the wooden structure of the bridge pier fendering system.  The bridge piers and structure where not affected according to follow-up inspections performed by CSX railroad bridge engineers.

The cause of this casualty was the failure of the NCC MEKKA's bow thruster.

The allision was reported immediately and an on scene investigation followed. Neither the harbor pilot or the FORT BRAGG master have any history of Coast Guard violation.

No evidence exists to suggest actionable misconduct or inattention to duty of the part of the pilot, ships master or tow boat master. Recommend this investigation be closed.

On February 3, 2003 Tug Sun Merchant struck the navigational lights of the McCormick bridge, estimated time was 1225.  Master said he miss judged the height of the mast of the tug Sun Merchant.  The tugs Sun Merchant mast is higher than the mast of other tugs that he is use to.  There was damage to the tugs mast, estimated cost of damage is unknown.  The damage to the McCormick bridge navigational lights was one lights stanchion was bent and the other light had to be removed and replaced.

07 Feb 03 - At 0115 received a report from  that an empty hopper barge, the  B 255, being pushed northbound on the Hudson River by the towing vessel Sea Wolf had allided with the Spuyten Duyvil Railroad Bridge.   

The bridge was in the open position at the time of the allision and the impact of the vessel caused the bridge to spin 90 degrees breaking past the stop blocks.  Damage was sustained to both the structure of the bridge, operational control of the bridge, and its fendering.  The barge also sustained minor damage due to the impact.  

The vessel also reported that just prior to the allision that the STBD towing cable had parted.  The vessel was able to regained control of the barge following the allision at which time they continued up river to their final destination in Haverstraw, NY.  

At approximately 0730, the vessel was attempting to approached the pier and tie up.  As the vessel made for the dredged channel into the pier the vessel ran aground while towing the empty barge.  The master of the vessel began to work the vessel to free itself at which time the tow line parted sending the barge adrift.  The barge continued to drift down river coming to rest along the shore approximately 1 mile down river.  

The vessel was then able to free itself and proceed after the drifting barge.  While in route to regain control of the barge the tug ran aground in approximately the same location in which it had just freed itself from.  The vessel once again was able to maneuver itself free and proceed to tie up at the pier.

The vessel radioed for assistance from area tugs but due to the location and lack of water no tug was able to immediately retrieve the barge.  A small boat from one of the assisting tugs was deployed and able to retrieve the barge and tie it up to a mooring cell.

Drug and alcohol testing was conducted.
M/V GENIE CENAC SOUTHBOUND ON THE ILLINOIS RIVER STRUCK THE CSX R/R BRIDGE WHEN UNABLE TO LINE TO UP AFTER MAKING THE JEFFERSON STREET BRIDGE.  MINIMAL DAMAGE TO CTCO 3023. NO OTHER DAMAGE  REPORTED.

On 21 February 2003 at approximately 0036, the M/V ELLY LANE was heading southbound on the Lower Mississippi River at MM 530.8 with 10 barges in tow (9 empty, 1 loaded).  While transiting the Greenville Bridge, the port stern barge, CBC 226 (empty red flag) struck the left descending pier of the channel span causing extensive damage to the #2 Port Wing Void.  The tow remained together during the incident, but the starboard face wire broke.  Following the allision, the tow was landed on the right descending bank, south of the new bridge construction site where the broken face wire was replaced and the barges were surveyed by Mr. XXX XXXXXXXX.

The pilot on board the M/V ELLY LANE at the time of the incident was Mr. XXXXXX X. XXXXXXXX (CG Lic. # XXXXXX).

The vessel was boarded by the MSD Greenville Marine Investigator (LT) the Drug Testing Representative, and Mr. XXX XXXXX (Canal Barge Port Engineer) at 0910 on 21 February 2003.  

An interview of Mr. XXXXXXXX was conducted at 0930 by LT XXXXXXXX.  Mr. XXXXXXXX had been on watch for one hour prior to the incident.  A fatigue analysis using the Fatigue Investigation Worksheet was conducted on Mr. XXXXXXXX revealing no fatigue related issues.  During his approach to the Greenville Bridge, Mr. XXXXXXXX set the M/V ELLY LANE and its' tow on the range lights located on the center span of the Greenville Bridge.  As Mr. XXXXXXXX piloted the vessel and its' tow under the Greenville Bridge, the current pushed the tow onto the left descending pier (drafted tow sideways) damaging the CBC 226 on its' port side.  Following the allision, the tow "bounced" back into the channel permitting the M/V ELLY LANE and the remaining length of the tow to pass safely under the Greenville Bridge without further damage.

Cause of Incident:  Mr. XXXXXXXX was not expecting the tow to draft as much as it did while passing under the Greenville Bridge.  Due to a recent rise in the Lower Mississippi River, current conditions changed significantly within a week prior to the incident.  Mr. XXXXXXXX stated that if he had know that the draft in way of the Greenville Bridge was going to be as much as it was, he would have set the vessel and its' tow up more toward the Right Descending Bank during the bridge approach.

The weather condition at the time of the incident was rainy with a slight haze.  According to Mr. XXXXXXXX, the channel buoys, bridge piers, and bridge range lights could be seen despite the rain and haze.  Mr. XXXXXXXX stated that the weather was not a factor in this incident.

"International Drug Detection" conducted an alcohol breath test and obtained urine samples at approximately 1000 on 21 February, 2003.  All drug test results were XXXXXXXX for alcohol and drugs.  Alcohol/Drugs were not a factory in this incident.

Conclusion:  The pilot, Mr. XXXXXXXX, of the M/V ELLY LANE misjudged the current in way of the Greenville Bridge.  The incident occurred at night, making it very difficult for current conditions to be observed.  Mr. XXXXXXXX stated that he has been a towing vessel master for twenty years.  His experience with river navigation, river stages, and familiarity of the area should have provided him with the knowledge to make safe approach and transit of the Greenville Bridge.  Mr. XXXXXXXX received an LOW previously for alliding with the Hwy 41 bridge on the Ohio River on 28 July, 1998 causing several barges to be damaged.  

It is recommended that Mr. XXXXXXXX be given a Letter of Warning for negligent operation of a vessel.

No further action to be taken.

Issued Permit To Proceed for the CBC 226.  Vessel is to proceed to Baton Rouge to effect repairs.  COTP Baton Rouge notified of vessel's condition.  Repairs to be completed on CBC 226 prior to 21 March 2003 and/or prior to cargo operations.

Investigation Complete.

LT X. X. XXXXXXXXI
Supervisor, MSD Greenville

On 1 March 2003 it was reported via CG-2692 that the BROWN WATER V had allided with the Galveston Causeway Bridge.

BROWN WATER V was west bound at MM 357 GICWW with the wind and current off his starboard side.  As he made his approach to the Galveston Causeway Bridge the wind began to gust.  With the wind gusting he was unable to maintain his heading and recognized he was going to hit the bridge so he immediately placed the vessel all astern.  He was not able to prevent hitting the bridge however, his prompt action eliminate all damages that could have accrued to the vessel and/or the bridge.  

It should be noted that the Galveston Causeway Bridge has been determined to be an unreasonable obstruction to the free navigation of the GICWW.  

No further action is required.

On March 21, 2003 at approximately 1400 hours, the towing  vessel NIGHT HAWK was pushing the barge PATAPSCO outbound from Havre De Grace Quarry on Susquehanna River.  While attempting to maneuver under the AMTRAK Rail Bridge, the barge allided with the fendering system on the center footing of the bridge. The were no injuries but there was damage to the barge and bridge fendering system. 
 
The NIGHT HAWK is a 74 foot, 194 GRT, steel hulled tow vessel owned and operated by Salisbury Towing Company.  The barge PATAPSCO is a 350 foot, 60 foot wide, steel hulled barge used primarily to transport stone and rock.  At the time of the incident the vessel was operated by the Mate. The barge allided on the port side amidships and starboard bow. 

The main contributing factor to this incident was the speed of the current in the river at the time which was increased due to the number of flood gates open from the Conawingo Dam, upstream.  There were 14 gates open at the time of the incident.  

Damage to the barge was a breach in the hull on the starboard side amidships just below the water line.  There was also some damage to the bridge fendering system.

On March 22, 2003 at approximately 0750, while operating on the Susquehanna River near Havre De Grace, MD, the M/V SHARPS ISLAND, traveling approximately 3 knots was pushing ahead barge #215.  While attempting to maneuver under the Amtrak Railroad Bridge,  the barge allided with the center footing of the bridge.  The SHARPS ISLAND is a 81.5 foot, 196 GRT vessel and  barge #215 is a 315 foot 52 foot wide steel hulled barge used primarily to transport stones.  

The main contributing factor to this incident was the speed of the current in the river at the time which was increased due to the number of flood gates open from the Conawingo Dam, upstream.  There were 20 flood gates open at the time of the incident.  The opening of the gates caused the current in the Susquehanna to be unusually fast, 4.5 - 5 knots, which made maneuverability through the bridge opening difficult.  The damages to the barge consisted of a small breach in the hull above the water line on the starboard side bow.  There were damages to the bridge fendering system.

On April 20, 2003, the TUG PETALUMA was engaged in its usual business of pushing ahead BARGE 201, a sand barge, from Port Chicago towards the sand dock at the NorCal Building Materials industrial facility at Petaluma, California.  The route involves transiting the Petaluma River, a United States navigable waterway.  During the transit, the barge struck the Black Point Railroad Bridge while it was in its normal open position. The allision dislodged a piling from the fendering system, but did not harm the bridge structure itself.  The PETALUMA's operator notified his employer and the Coast Guard of the incident shortly after clearing the bridge.  The tug and barge proceeded undamaged to the sand dock.  Post-accident drug testing was conducted on the operator.

See IO Narrative in correspondence for additional details.

2APR03   1310
M/V NATALIE H was underway with 5 fully laden barges westbound on the ICW. Tug and tow attempted to cross under the West Port Arthur bridge while another vessel, the M/V ELLISSA, performing a crew change at the same location.  Captain of the M/V NATALIE H made arrangements to pass with the understanding the M/V ELLISSA would "flatten out" (change direction to make room for the M/V NATALIE H).  Captain reports the M/V ELLISSA did not do so, and a combination of current and the M/V ELLISSA's prop was pushed the AR 852, a barge under control of the M/V NATALIE H, into the south side of the West Port Arthur bridge.  Resultant damage to AR 852 was a 4' x 4' inset on the port bow knuckle.  The West Port Arthur Bridge abutment seems to have significant wood damage, possibly a concrete fendering piling was displaced as well.  A crewmember of the M/V NATALIE H, was asleep in his rack and the collision pushed him into the bulkhead.

According to 2692 submitted by owner of M/V PADDY CROSBY:
2/28/2003 - The M/V PADDY CROSBY was pushing a loaded rock barge southbound in Bayou Lafourche en route to Port Fourchon. the master, a licensed OUTV, was at the helm. 32/059/03 - MRP

The M/V BAILEY ANN was heading south bound and was waiting to pass through the Bayou Boeuf R.R. Bridge.  While waiting the northerly wind was blowing at 15 mph and the Master had some difficulty in keeping control of the vessel and tow (one empty barge).  The barge and tow ended up being pushed in to the bridge.  Some minor damage was caused to the bridge, but is still operational.

32/62/03 CNP
04/12/2003 - The barge U 784 was being towed by two vessels, the M/V SUSAN MARIE and the M/V MS MONIQUE southbound through Bayou Boeuf.  The M/V SUSAN MARIE was towing the U 784 astern and the M/V MS MONIQUE was pushing the barge.  A licensed 100 ton master, was at the controls of the M/V SUSAN MARIE.  An unlicensed mariner, was at the controls of the M/V MS MONIQUE.   As the vessels approached the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge, Master told Mariner via radio to hold his rudder at zero degrees and bring his engines back one quarter speed.  Master had a lookout posted on each side of the M/V SUSAN MARIE to check that they were making it through clearly.  As the M/V SUSAN MARIE began to clear the bridge, the port side of the barge U 784 struck the fender system and pushed the starboard side of the barge into the opposite fender system where it tore down the wooden fenders, bent up the steel casing around the supports and damaged a signal box.  The U 784 sustained a 3 foot dent in the starboard bow rake.  After the allision, the bridge tender attempted hailing the M/V SUSAN MARIE several times with negative results.  

The vessels continued through the bridge then the M/V SUSAN MARIE  pulled into the nearby  ASCO fuel dock where they proceeded to have a crew change which had been scheduled prior to the allision.  Master as well as 2 other crew members departed from the vessel and then 2 new crew members came aboard.  Master did not report the bridge allision to his company nor to the Coast Guard prior to leaving the vessel.  

The vessels continued on their voyage with Master number 2 at the controls of the M/V SUSAN MARIE.  The M/V SUSAN MARIE finally answered the calls from the bridge tender and was contacted by the OOD at MSO Morgan City.  The vessels were instructed by the OOD to stand by until an investigator arrived to speak to the crews.  At approximately 1330, I, ENS accompanied by a boarding team from MSO Morgan City, arrived onboard the M/V SUSAN MARIE.  Upon arrival I was informed that the crew of the M/V SUSAN MARIE had just changed and that the master at the controls during the allision, had left the vessel at approximately 1200.  I proceeded to interview the crew of the M/V SUSAN MARIE including second master, who was on lookout on the port side of the vessel during the allision.  He informed me that he told Master that they had hit the bridge, but He did not feel the need to report the allision to the Coast Guard because "the damage has to be more than $25,000".  I received verification from the crew as well as the port captain for Crosby Tugs that the crew change had been scheduled the day before.

I then proceeded onboard the M/V MS MONIQUE where I spoke to mariner, who had been at the controls during the allision with the bridge.  Also present in the pilot house was the pilot who is a supervisor for Settoon Construction, Inc. he had arrived via a small boat simultaneously with my arrival.  As I began to question supervisor he stopped me and said , "Before we get into anything else I just want you to know that I do not have a Coast Guard license, I lost it a few years back due to health reasons."  I then asked supversior if he knew that mariner did not have a valid license to which he replied, "I did not know anything about this until I got onto the boat a little while ago.  I assumed that he had a license because I had worked with him before when he had a license."  I continued with my questioning concerning the allision during which mariner confirmed that Master had told him to hold his boat at zero degree rudder and back 1/4 speed and that they had struck the bridge with the barge U 784.  

//S// 
Investigating Officer
MSO Morgan City


Recommend S&R action against Master of M/V SUSAN MARIE, 
Recommend Civil Penalty action against owner of M/V MS MONIQUE, Settoon Construction , Inc.
Recommend Civil Penalty action against owner of M/V SUSAN MARIE, Crosby Tugs, LLC.
Recommend Civil Penalty action against Settoon Construction, Inc. supervisor  
Recommend Civil Penalty action against Un-Licensed Master of M/V MS MONIQUE,

02 May 2003 - Rcvd 2692 from vsl owner.  Spoke with owner; claimed that they did not know they had to report an incident this minor.  The vessel being operated by XXXXXXXXX, did not sustain any damage and according to the owner, the reason for the outriggers striking the bridge was due to high water.

INCIDENT SUMMARY

ON 02MAY03 AT APPROXIMATELY 2150 THE M/V LAURA ELIZABETH, PUSHING 15 BARGES S/B, STRUCK THE JEFFERSON ST. BRIDGE IN JOLIET, IL. THE BRIDGE WAS FULLY OPEN AT THE TIME OF THE ALLISION.  GROUP UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  THE BRIDGE WAS LOWERED AT 2222, DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE WAS UNKNOWN.  M/V LAURA ELIZABETH CONTINUED SOUTHBOUND.  AT 2343 MSO CHICAGO WATCHSTANDER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  0830 MSO CHICAGO INVESTIGATORS ON SCENE AT JEFFERSON ST. BRIDGE.  IDENTIFIED AND PHOTOGRAPHED DAMAGE TO NORTHWEST CORNER OF BRIDGE.  INTERVIEWED BRIDGE OPERATOR ON DUTY AND CONFIRMED THAT BRIDGE WAS IN THE OPEN POSITION AND THAT IT WAS OUT OF OPERATION UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE (APPROX 4-6 MOS).  0900, INVESTIGATORS BOARDED M/V LAURA ELIZABETH AT ILR MILE 278.  INTERVIEWED CAPTAIN # 1  & PILOT # 1.  DETERMINED THAT CAPTAIN # 1 WAS SCHEDULED TO BE ON WATCH DURING THE TRANSIT OF THE JEFFERSON ST. BRIDGE, BUT PILOT # 1 TOOK THE WHEEL BECAUSE HE HAD MORE EXPERIENCE OPERATING IN THAT PARTICULARLY CONGESTED AREA OF THE CHANNEL.  PILOT # 1 HAD APPROXIMATELY ONE YEAR'S EXPERIENCE TRANSITING THE AREA.  

UPON NAVIGATING THE CASS ST. BRIDGE, WHICH IS APPROXIMATELY 1100' NORTH OF THE JEFFERSON ST. BRIDGE, THE STARBOARD AFT CORNER OF THE STARBOARD AFT BARGE (PIN 346) OF THE TOW BUMPED THE BRIDGE.  THE IMPACT OF THE ALLISION FORCED THE HEAD OF THE TOW TO SURGE TO STARBOARD, IN THE DIRECTION OF THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE JEFFERSON STREET BRIDGE.  PILOT # 1 WAS UNABLE TO CONTROL THE TOW AND ALLIDED WITH THE CASS STREET BRIDGE.  BARGE EFC 9225 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE STARBOARD BOW.  THE M/V LAURA ELIZABETH CONTINUED SOUTHBOUND, UNAWARE OF THE EXTENT OF THE DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE.

CONTRIBUTING CAUSES

1. EXCESSIVE CURRENT: THE RIVER FLOW AT THE TIME OF THE ALLISION WAS 5200 CFM AT LOCKPORT LOCK.  THE AVERAGE FLOW ON A NORMAL DAY IS 800-1200 CFM.  THE FLOW READING AT BRANDEN LOCK WAS 10500 CFM.  THE AVERAGE FLOW AT BRANDEN LOCK IS 1200-1500 CFM.

2. CLOSE PROXIMINTY OF BRIDGES & NARROW CHANNEL.  VSL CAPTAIN STATED THAT THERE WAS ONLY 20' BETWEEN THE HEAD OF THE TOW AND THE JEFFERSON ST. BRIDGE AT THE TIME THAT THE VESSEL ALLIDED WITH THE CASS ST. BRIDGE, ALLOWING MINIMAL TIME TO CORRECT.

RECOMMENDATIONS

CHARGE PILOT # 1 WITH NEGLIGENCE FOR ALLIDING WITH THE JEFFERSON STREET BRIDGE.

The pilot tried to recover but did not have enough time.  This caused the barge to strike the bridge and cause the barge wires to part.  No damage to the barge. $5000.00 to $10,000.00 damage to the bridge.

M/V BROTHER COLLINS W 15 LOADS.  VSL WAS S/B AT 158-ILR.  WHILE MAKING APPROACH TO THE LOCK WITH  ASSISTANCE TUG ON THE STBD STRING TOW,  PORT STRING BARGE PV 9921 CAME INTO CONTACT WITH BRIDGE PIER.  NO DAMAGE WAS REPORTED TO THE PIER.  BARGE PV 9921 SUSTAINED DAMAGE IN WAY OF #2 & 3 WING TANKS.

CG-2692 NOTIFICATION MADE ON 2JUN2003, AMERICAN COMMERCIAL BARGE LINE LLC.

INTRODUCTION:

On 15 Aug 03 @ approx 0855, T/B CHEM 303 (O.N. 511892), being pushed by the uninspected towing vessel (UTV) TED W. EWING (O.N. 637374) outbound on the Houston Ship Channel (HSC) along w/ 3 other barges, swung free from the tow & allided with the Fred Hartman (Highway 146) bridge.  UTV TED W. EWING subsequently backed over & destroyed flashing green light #103 (LLNR 23995) in the aftermath of the allision.  Encl (2), (3), (4), (8) & (12).

FACTS:

Captain of UTV TED W. EWING, picked up the 4 barges in the tow @ Carpenter's Bayou (off HSC) on 14 Aug 03.  The barges, all loaded w/ an even 9' draft, were to be pushed from Carpenter's Bayou to Baton Rouge, LA.  The CHEM 303, which is 2600 gross tons, 195' x 52', was loaded w/ styrene.

The tow configuration was 1x2x1, w/ the CHEM 303 being the single lead barge of the tow.  Her stern was made up centered to the bows of the barges ACL 00604 (O.N. 1093406) & ACL 02137 (O.N. 1139659).  The sterns of the barges ACL 00604 & ACL 02137 were made up centered to the bow of the T/B CHEM 3701 (O.N. 511892), whose stern was made up centered to the bow of the UTV TED W. EWING.  Encl (6), (7) & (8).

The UTV TED W. EWING is a 60' long, 1200 hp, twin screw towboat.  The total length of the tow, as configured by Captain , was 892'.  The width of the tow, at her widest point, was 70'.  Encl ( 5) & (7).

The CHEM 303 swung free from the tow when the outermost wire coupling (3/4" inch, double knit) connecting her port stern to the ACL 00604 snapped after the UTV TED W. EWING executed a starboard turn to make way for an approaching inbound deep draft vessel that she was meeting on one whistle (i.e. port to port) at the Fred Hartman bridge.  After the outermost coupling on the port stern of the CHEM 303 broke, the other two wire couplings on her port stern also snapped, followed by her center stern rope safety line (2.75", double twine).  None of the three wire couplings connecting her starboard stern to the ACL 02137 broke or even severed.

When the CHEM 303 swung free, she pivoted starboard towards the Fred Hartman bridge, pulling the entire tow w/ her.  Captain  tried to go hard astern on both screws, but the CHEM 303 struck the concrete footing on the west side of the bridge, chipping a concrete block & holing the barge near her starboard bow rake in way of a void, below the waterline.  The barge took on water, but no cargo was discharged.  The barge was subsequently dewatered w/ two portable pumps & towed by another UTV to Channel Shipyard for repairs.  See inspection activity # 1877597.  Encl (8).

Pilot of UTV TED W. EWING, took the wheel after the allision while Captain went out to secure the CHEM 303.  In the process of securing the barge, crewmember inadvertently backed over light # 103 just west of the bridge.  After the barge was secured, crewmember pushed the tow onto the west side bank of the HSC just below the Fred Hartman bridge near light # 101, and he notified VTS Houston-Galveston of the incident @ approx 0855.

MSO Houston-Galveston notified D8(ob) & the bridge owner as soon as the allision was reported to us by VTS.  VTS notified USCG Group Galveston of the ATON discrepancy after UTV TED W. EWING backed over light #103.  See message P 151818Z AUG 03.  Encl (12).

EVIDENCE:

When interviewed, Captain admitted that his chosen 1x2x1 tow configuration placed excessive stress on the couplings connecting the lead barge, causing the wires to snap.  Pilot Short confirmed this, as did the 2 deckhands that we interviewed.

Captain relayed that he made a one whistle meeting arrangement w/ an approaching inbound deep draft ship well before the Fred Hartman bridge, but when he started his starboard swing to "make room" for the ship, the CHEM 303 broke free from her port couplings.  Captain said that he was approx 1/4 mile away from the approaching ship when this happened.  He feels that the ship "had nothing to do" with the barge breaking free from her couplings.  Captain did not remember the name of the ship or the identification number of the Houston pilot onboard the ship (whom he previously spoke with on VHF FM channel 13).

Captain stated that both he & the approaching deep draft ship were riding "center channel" before meeting.  That is why Captain had to turn starboard to "make room" for the ship, i.e. he had to get over to the right.  

Since the charted depth of the entire HSC proper is 40', it is unclear why Captain was riding "center channel" w/ only a 9' draft.  Furthermore, since the charted width of the HSC proper is 400', it is unclear why Captain  was riding "center channel" w/ only a 70' wide tow.  For the sake of safety, he should have been further over on the green side / outbound lane of the HSC instead of riding "center channel" close to, or encroaching in, the red side / inbound lane of the HSC.  Encl (4).

All 4 witnesses that we interviewed, including Captain, corroborated that the 3/4" double knit wires used to make up the tow were in excellent condition, as were the wenches & chocks/bitts.  Our visual inspection confirmed the excellent condition of the towing gear, ruling out the possibility that equipment and/or material failure caused and/or contributed to this casualty.

Captain advised that a 2x2 box configuration would have been much more stable & safe, but he claimed that it would be "too slow" to go all the way to Baton Rouge w/ such a tow configuration.  Captain said that he would have actually preferred to string all the barges out, 1x1x1x1, but that such a configuration was too long for the fleeting area at Carpenter's Bayou.

There is no evidence that drugs, alcohol and/or fatigue played any role in this casualty.

Conclusion:

Captain knowingly chose an unsafe tow configuration.  He should have either used a 2x2 box, made arrangements w/ a different, larger fleeting area to string out the barges 1x1x1x1, or not have taken one or more of the barges to Baton Rouge.  His 1x2x1 configuration placed excessive stress on the lead barge couplings, especially when turning the tow.

Furthermore, given the tow's relatively shallow draft & limited width, he should not have been pushing the tow "center channel" in the HSC.  He should have been well on his side of the channel, eliminating the need to swing sharply to starboard to "make room" for approaching deep draft vessel traffic.

See MISLE enforcement activity # 1887508 for enforcement action against Captain's license for his role in casualty.

Case closed.

ON 19MAY03, THE M/V CINDY CELESTE PUSHING 25 LOADED BARGES SOUTHBOUND AT MM 979, OHIO RIVER, ALLIDED WITH THE CAIRO HIGHWAY BRIDGE.  VESSEL WAS ATTEMPTING TO TRANSIT THE CENTER SPAN WHEN THE PILOT UNDERESTIMATED THE SPEED AND SET OF THE CURRENT AND THE VESSEL/TOW WAS SET TO STARBOARD.  WHEN THE PILOT ATTEMPTED TO COMPENSATE BY STEERING TO PORT, THE RF624, LOCATED SECOND TO LAST BARGE ON THE STBD STRING, STRUCK THE BRIDGE PIER.  THE ALLISION BROKE APART THE TOW, AND CAUSED THE RF624 TO SINK.  THE REMAINING BARGES WERE GATHERED BY THE M/V RIVERCAT AND VARIOUS HARBOR TUGS FROM LOUISIANA DOCK CO. AND CGB WATERFRONT SERVICES INC.  BASED ON CURRENT EVIDENCE, NO FURTHER ACTION IS RECOMMENDED.

On August 15, 2003, the M/V DELAWARE BRIDGE was underway from Garden City Terminal (GCT) at 0030 hrs, maneuvering in the Kings Island Turning basin preparing to head outbound.  The main diesel engine (MDE) had just returned to stop from dead slow astern when the Pilot called for dead slow ahead, the engine failed to re-start.  A second attempt was made, again the engine did not start.  The chief engineer (CE) tried to start the MDE a third time from the local control (emergency mode, all electrical signals by-passed), and again the engine failed to start.  Two tugs were tethered to the vessel, one forward and one aft, the vessel was safely moored at GCT berth #3 at about 0136 hrs.  While mooring the MDE successfully responded to a dead slow astern command.  The master stated the vessel never lost astern propulsion.

The MDE is a 9-cylinder slow-speed Sulzer, the CE could not immediately identify any problems and the only alarm noted was the 10 second start time limit alarm.  If the engine fails to start after 10 seconds an alarm sounds in the control room.  

1200 hrs:  In company with Germanischer Lloyd (GL) class surveyor,  to conduct an incident investigation.  Met with the Master,, and the CE, to review the casualty and the corrective steps taken thus far.  The CE believes the problem was with the control air system, possibly contamination or debris in the system.  He had already inspected the starting air block valve, the control valve for the block valve and all control air and starting air connections for leaks noting no problems.  Since re-assembling the system, the MDE was started numerous times in both directions without any problems.  

Discussed the propulsion system and potential causes of the failure with the CE.  Also reviewed control air and starting air system drawing #RTA84C (enclosed in case file).  Concurred with the CE and the class surveyor that the failure was likely caused by a problem with the control air system.  The vessel never lost "astern" propulsion suggesting the problem was with the "ahead" signal.  Possibly control air valve #49HA (piston type valve) had stuck due to system contamination/debris.  Had this valve opened as designed an "ahead" signal would have been sent to the starting air distributor, thereby starting the "ahead" start sequence.  

Inspected control air filter noting good conditions.  Although valve #49HA was not opened and inspected, its operability was tested as the air lines to the distributor were disconnected to verify adequate air signals were sent.  Additionally, witnessed 8 start stops of the MDE from the bridge and control room.  We could not recreate the problem, the class surveyor believes that any contamination or debris was cleared from the system.  Cleared vessel for sailing w/two tug escort.

The vessel safely departed with no report of any problems.

On 19 August 2003, the M/V SUPERAMERICA was southbound at Ohio River mile 606.5 with 3 loaded barges, 2 of which were carrying gasoline, the third diesel.  The AI 531, with it's load of gasoline, was the starboard barge at the head of the tow.  At approximately 1100, the tow passed beneath the Clark Highway Bridge in downtown Louisville.  Construction activities could be seen taking place on the surface of the bridge, and while the vessel was passing under the bridge, one of the crew indicated he saw sparks falling.  At 1140, while in the Louisville and Portland Canal immediately above McAlpine Lock and Dam, the deck crew observed a small flame in the vicinity of the starboard number 1 cargo tank manhole.  The tow was immediately stopped and secured to the adjacent lock long wall, above the lock but now blocking entering and departing lock traffic.  The M/V SUPERAMERICA separated from the tow, maneuvered adjacent to the site of the fire, and extinguished the flame by 1150 using the vessel's fire main and foam system.  Not knowing the extent of the fire, and as a precaution against reflash, a water curtain was sprayed on the AI 531 by the vessel as well the USCGC OBION, which happened to be in the vicinity.  The M/V GAIL ANN was also on scene assisting in the response.  The water curtain was continued for approximately 3 hours, when Coast Guard and fire department officials determined in was safe to stop.  A preliminary assessment of the barge showed no damage, and there were no spills or injuries.  The M/V SUPERAMERICA locked through, and later that afternoon MAP and Coast Guard officials performed a closer inspection of the barge.  They found no fire damage other that a manhole gasket that needed to be replaced.  No vapor leaks were detected at any fitting, and the manhole cover's fastening devices were "tool tight" as required. 

There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, inattention to duty, negligence, incompetence or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of the USCG licensed mariner.
Rcvd report from M/V Invincible that it allided with the CSX RR bridge in St. Joseph River, St. Joseph, MI.  No damage to tug or bridge (under $25K threshold), no pollution or injuries.

At 0220 on 26 August 2003, the 55 ft, 87 GT, UTV DESIREE was westbound, pushing ahead a crane barge, KS-4509, at mile marker (MM) 12 on the West Intercoastal Waterway.  The Master of the tug had been on watch for 5 hours at the time of the incident.  Barge KS-4509 is a deck barge with a track crane strapped down to the deck of the barge.  The vessel and barge worked block 37 in Venice and were transiting back to Houma, LA.  The crane was boomed down on the 25th of August at 0100.  Chet Morrison Contracting Co. personnel, owner/operators of the crane barge, were on board to boom down the crane.  The crew of DESIREE noted that the crane operators were in a hurry to finish the job.  The attached digital photographs clearly show that the boom of the crane was sitting very high at the time of the allision and clearly the crane could have been boomed down much further on the 25th of August.  Neither the crew of the DESIREE, nor Chet Morrison personnel, knew the exact clearance of the crane barge.  Regardless, Tug DESIREE departed Venice with the crane barge.  During the transit on the night of the 25th and morning of the 26th the tug and crane barge successfully passed under the Algiers Bridge and Bell Chase bridge.  The Master,  Pitre,  closely watched the boom pass under both bridges and since he had made it under those bridges, he only assumed  the crane would pass under the Crowne Point Bridge.  Pitre did not consult the chart to confirm that the clearance for the Crowne Point Bridge is 20 feet less than the other bridges.  His negligence to confirm the clearance of the bridge and the clearance of the crane led to the allision.  At 0220 the boom of the crane hit the Crowne Point bridge.  When the crane hit, the boom rode upward on the side of the bridge face.  Then, the top of the crane crashed through the iron work and cement deck of the bridge, causing an approximate 1.5 sq ft hole on the tarmac.  The center span light on the bridge was also broken.  Damage to the barge included a split wire where a cable secured the boom and headache ball to the port/fwd corner of the barge.  Upon impact the base of the crane was shoved back 11 feet, splitting the port wire cable that previously secured the crane to the deck.  No further damages, pollution or injuries to report.  The owner/operator of UTV DESIREE, Central Gulf Towing, had drug testing conducted on all three crewmembers

On 9/30/2003 the M/V HARRIET ANN was pushing ahead 22 loaded hopper barges southbound on the Lower Mississippi River.  Twenty of the barges were arranged 4 across and 5 deep; whereas, the remaining 2 barges (Rw 174 and Rw 178) were made up along side the first and second barge up from the towing vessel on the starboard outboard string.  The M/V HARRIET ANN and her tow were in Linwood Bend just east (up bound) of the I-155 Highway Bridge located at MM 838.7.  According to the statement provided by the vessel’s master he out draft above the bridge caught the tow, pushing toward the bridge pier.  He tried to steer away from the pier.  At 0550, the starboard side of Rw 174 landed on the flat side of the RDB bridge pier.  The RW 174 and Rw 178 broke-away from the tow and drifted down bound until they were caught by assist vessels and pushed-in at MM 836 (Cottonwood Fleet) on the LDB.

Apparent cause:  The vessel's operator misjudged the current during the approach to the bridge.  No enforcement action is recommended.

No other damage, injuries, or pollution was observed by the USCG Boarding Team or reported by the vessel or bridge owner/operator.

*FULL INCIDENT NARRATIVE AVAILABLE IN CORRESPONDENCE.

At 2030 on 31 Jul 03 the M/V DRU LIRETTE was pushing a tow of 15 dry cargo barges.  While entering the Portland Canal at OHR mile 604.5 on of the barges in the tow made contact with a protection cell for the L & I Railroad bridge.  The Operator stated that he was not sure if it actually made contact or not and there was no damage to the barge in question.  The Operator later informed the CG that the barge (TA 118) immediately forward of the barge that was suspected of hitting the cell, was taking on water.  When MSO personnel arrived on scene they observed a slight rub mark on the side shell of the barge MEM 5064, that was thought to have hit the cell.  Investigators then moved to the TA 118 and observed that all of the wing voids were flooding.  Investigators observed what appeared to be preexisting shingles in one of the void that were dislodged.  The crew had five dewatering pumps running and the barge was still taking on water.  Eventually two additional pumps were added and the crew starting gaining on the flooding.  The following day the crew was able to pump off enough water for a Marine Surveyor to inspect the damage and temporary repairs were made, the Surveyor stated the barge was repaired well enough to proceed to its destination and then to a repair facility.  The repair estimate was $5000.  The investigators interviewed the operator and the deckhand that witnessed the allision.  Both accounts of the incident led the Investigator to believe that the barge MEM 5064 was the one that made contact with the cell.  The physical evidence of the rub marks on the side shell supported that conclusion.  The operator stated that his tow was set toward the cell by the draw from the cut out in the Vane Dyke.  He tried to avoid making contact with the cell and was not sure that he made contact or not until he observed the marks on the barge.  The deck hand stated that he was on a barge forward of the one that made contact and was watching as the tow passed.  He stated that he observed the background light between the cell and the barges as they passed.  He stated the light disappeared for a brief moment as the MEM 5064 was passing the cell and then came back.  When the surveyor was able to enter the stbd #1 wing tank on the TA 118,  he observed an area between the 2nd and 3rd lower longitudinal that was set in 0 - 3" and ran the entire length of the barge, the surveyor noted the damage appeared to be new.  The surveyor also observed a 14" x 2" at the #2 aft bulkhead, this hole was shingled.  Based on the surveyor's observations it is believed the TA 118 made contact with something below the surface that was part of or near the protection cell.  I. O. recommends that a OCMI Letter of Warning be issued to the Operator of the M/V DRU LIRETTE.

The captain of F/V LUCKY STRIKE wife called the Stephensville Bridge approx. 30 minutes prior to the arrival of the F/V Lucky Strike and announced the vessel would be approaching the bridge and needed to pass through.  

It's reported the bridge operator, arrived at the bridge approx. 25 minutes prior to the vessels arrival.  The bridge operator stated that he noticed the vessel coming from the North, and he proceed to open the swing bridge.  The swing bridge opens to the North.  The bridge operator stated that the vessel did not slow down as he was opening the bridge.  The bridge operator just started to open the span when the vessel struck the bridge at 0855 on 20OCT03.  

When the vessel was approx. 10 feet away from the bridge, The BO said he sounded the horn twice to let the mariner know that the bridge was not open. Captain of the F/V reportedly put the vessel in reverse but there was not enough time to avoid an allision.  Captain of the F/V stated that he thought the bridge was open as he proceeded toward the bridge.  He stated that he was, "daydreaming."  He also stated that the sun was in his eyes and that there was quite a bit of glare on the water. Captain of the F/V stated he then turned the vessel around and then tied the vessel up in the bayou across from his house at 1035 Dawn Drive, Stephensville, LA.  

Report approx. $40,000 - $50,000 damage to vessel.  The Captain's son stated that they were removing all of the fuel and was going to scrap the vessel. There were no injuries and no damage to bridge.

10/30/2003: Total loss of vessel. Bridge fully functional. Master at fault for allision. No remedial action being taken toward Master since Master has lost his vessel and any future earnings the vessel could provide.

On November 30, 2003 at approximately 2245 the uninspected towing vessel (UTV) DIANA T pushing 16 loaded lash barges allided with the Sunshine Bridge at mile marker (MM) 167.3 on the Lower Mississippi River.  
While transiting south through the Sunshine Bridge the UTV DIANA T broke its starboard facing wire causing it to lose control of its barges.  The operator of the UTV DIANA T, was attempting to regain control of the barges when they allided with the fendering system of the Sunshine bridge.  Damage to the Sunshine Bridge was estimated at 370,600 dollars.  Damage to the lash barges is estimated at $16000.   There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident.  Refer to correspondence for details.

On 3 Dec 03, at approximately 1900, the UTV CAPITAL STAR was transiting southbound on the Atchafalya River and allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge at mile marker 30.  The UTV CAPITAL STAR went under the fixed section of the bridge taking off the antenna's for the radar and the UTV CAPITAL STAR's radio.  Over the past week the water height of the river had risen 11 ft and the current had significantly increased.  The UTV CAPITAL STAR failed to answer radio calls for approximately 1 hr after the incident.  The operator of the UTV CAPITAL STAR stated he was set up to transit through the bridge and as he was coming ahead felt a vibration at the same time something obstructed his starboard wheel, causing his starboard engine to almost cut out.   Due to the obstruction in his starboard wheel he was not able to use the starboard engine while transiting through the bridge and as a result could not avoid an allision with the Melville Railroad Bridge.  The bridge tender stated the boat was south bound with the head of his tow at an angle toward the west bank and was not lined up correctly for passage.  The first barge struck the inside of the south pier, which caused all six barges to break free.   Bridge tender had a difficult time getting any information from the UTV CAPITAL STAR operator.  There is no evidence of damage to the UTV CAPITAL STAR to support operators claim something got stuck in his propeller at a critical time in the maneuver.  The Bridge tenders observations and the fact operator failed to answer communications until approximately 1 hour later lends me to the conclusion that the operator just failed to judge the conditions correctly.

10Dec03: MSO notified that UTV FAWN allided with the I-10 bridge at San Jacinto River.  Approx. 2 feet of mast was damaged as the vessel passed under the bridge.  TXDOT was notified and did a sight inspection for damages on 10Dec03.  None were observed.  Notified Kirby of CG-2692 requirement as a reportable marine casualty.  UTV FAWN indicated a report had been given to the Kirby Port Captain.

At about 0640 (all times Eastern Standard Time) on December 8th 2002 2003 the uninspected towing vessel SARA KAITLEN, O.N. 293828 was underway northbound in the AICW pushing three deck barges in a straight bow to stern arrangement.  As the vessel approached the bridge draw, the middle barge in the tow arrangement struck the pilings on the east side fender system causing damage to the fendering system. See photos in evidence for pictures and details of damage.

As of the date of this report a dollar amount has not been established, however, from my investigation and visit to the site on the morning of the incident the damage will not exceed $100,000 and will not meet the criteria for a serious marine incident.

On 28 November 2003 the tug M/V TRIG LIND was pushing 2 unladen work barges ahead down bound in the Petaluma River.  At approximately 0715 the lead barge of the tandem tow cleared the span of the Haystack Railroad Bridge and the 15 knot, southwesterly wind set the bow towards the left (east) bank of the Petaluma River.  As more of the tow continued to clear the span, the bow continued its swing to the point of touching the fender dolphin on the east side and brushing the abutment on the west side.  No damage was done to either the bridge or the vessel(s) from the collision.  The TRIG LIND adjusted its tow and proceeded on its way to Anchorage 9.  I recommend no action be taken against the master's mariner credentials.  Case closed IAW G-MOA letter 2-02.

At 08:00 on July 09, 2003 (ECN 1970692 #002 SML), the M/V LACEY NICOLE lost power to the fuel transfer pump after a circuit breaker tripped. This caused the day tank to run dry, the engines to shut down, and the vessel lost propulsion. (In addition to the tripped ciruit breaker, the sight glass on the day tank was broken inhibiting observation of the low fuel situation.) While drifting down river the the tow struck the Brown's Island Bridge. The M/V MOUNTAINEER (ECN 1970692 #001 SML and ECN 1970692 #002 SML) assisted the drifting tow, tying it up to a nearby cell at Ohio River MM 62.0. There was no damage or injury to the towboat, tow, crew, or bridge.  Johnson Towing did not submit a CG-2692 for this incident until July 29, 2003, fifteen (15) days after the marine casualty.  Due to the internal confusion over responsibilities and procedures for reporting requirements within Johnson Towing Corporation, it is likely that without Coast Guard prompting (ECN 1970692 #004 SML) no written report would have been submitted for this casualty.

10 January 2004 - The UTV ELIZABETH was underway east bound on the Eastern Branch of the 
Elizabeth River, pushing the BARGE WEEKS 320 on the port hip, bound for Lyon's Shipyard.

1715L - The mate was at the controls of the tug and the master was positioned on the port bow of the barge for the transit through the bridges on the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  XXXXX moved the ELIZABETH to the extreme southern side of the channel for the approach to Railroad Bridge 5.  [Railroad Bridge 5 is a bascule bridge.  When it is fully opened the lift span extends over the waterway at an angle.  The vertical clearance varies under the lift span depending on how far to the north a vessel passes under the lift span.]  

Because of the size/shape of the tug and barge, the visibility concerns and the bend in the river, XXXXX was concerned about allowing the vessels to get too far to the north.  XXXXX slowed to clutch speed only, approximately one knot, trying to keep the approach at a controllable speed but sacrificing maneuverability.  During the approach to the bridge, XXXXX did not have enough speed to adequately control the tug and barge.  As a result, he let the ELIZABETH get too far to the south and allided with the moored barge BILLY D at a very slow speed.

1720L - The starboard quarter of the ELIZABETH was the only portion of the vessel to allide with the BILLY D.  XXXXX and XXXXX used the spotlight to look for any damage to the BILLY D.  Since the allision occurred at less than one knot there was no damage to either vessel.  

XXXXX reoriented the ELIZABETH and barge WEEKS 320 toward Railroad Bridge 5 and realized the vessels were in good position for the approach to the bridge.  XXXXX was primarily concerned with the width of the tug and tow with the additional five foot pipe that protrudes from the port side of the barge.  XXXXX was also concerned with the air draft of the spuds on the WEEKS 320.  XXXXX decided the safest course of action to pass through the bridge would be to stay as far to the south as possible and to proceed at clutch speed.  Because the ELIZABETH had the WEEKS 320 made up on the hip, XXXXX knew that he was giving up  maneuverability in order to keep the speed slow.  

1725L - While transiting under Railroad Bridge 5 Basinski realized that the tug and barge were drifting to starboard towards the bridge.  XXXXX decided that his choices were to increase revolutions on the starboard propeller or to allow the vessel to lay against the bridge's fenders and use the fender to pivot back towards the center of the channel.  XXXXX decided that while increasing power to the starboard propeller would possibly avoid an allision, the damage created by any resulting allision would be greater than allowing the vessel to lay against the fender system at less than one knot.  XXXXX decided to disengage the engine and make a slow landing against the bridge fender.  

1728L - The starboard quarter of the ELIZABETH allided with the fender system of Railroad Bridge 5 at less than one knot.  XXXXX pivoted the vessel off the fendering system, reorienting the direction of the tug and tow toward the center of the channel and proceeded through the opening.  

1745L - XXXXX moored at Lyon's shipyard without further incident and contacted HMRMS to report the allisions.

2030L - HMRMS Investigating Officer arrived with HMRMS Inspectors XXXXX and XXXXX.  Alcohol tests were administered to XXXXX and XXXXX with negative results.  

2100L - XXXXX got the ELIZABETH underway with XXXXX to conduct a navigation safety check and examine the bridge and barge BILLY D.  No steering, navigation or propulsion problems were noted on the ELIZABETH.  All charts were corrected with recent Notice to Mariners retained on board.  XXXXX inspected the BILLY D and the ELIZABETH and noted that there was no visible damage.  No damage was noted on the fendering system of Railroad Bridge 5.

This was XXXXX first attempt to transit through Railroad Bridge 5 on the ELIZABETH in this configuration.  He had witnessed it once before during his break-in process.  He calculated the clearances in advance and planned the trip to coincide with slack current.  XXXXX had a reasonable plan to safely transit through the bridge but sacrificed too much maneuverability by going at clutch speed, and was unable to maintain control of the tug and barge.  Although XXXXX failed to provide a credible no fault explanation to overcome the presumption of negligence that arises whenever a vessel allides with a fixed object, this incident was deemed not actionable.  The mitigating factors such as the safety conscious approach, amount of damage and XXXXX actions once the vessel was in extremis outweigh the presumption of negligence.  This case was not referred for enforcement.

The tow allided with the North guide wall removing two timbers.  Incident was reported by Kirby. Taylor Bros. Inc faxed allision info with notification of possible financial responsibility of Kirby.

There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident.  See correspondence for further details.

M/V MALLARD, pushing 2 loads Northbound at mile 326.2 of the Chicago River, allided with the W. Chicago Ave. bridge while trying to avoid a southbound pleasurecraft, bending approx. 10 of railing on the vessel's stern.  No reported damage to the bridge.

M/V NORTHLAND, Southbound at Illinois River mile 320.4, lightboat, allided with the right descending bridge protection structure of the Western Ave. Bridge. The uninspected towing vessel (UTV) BELLE WATLING was underway northbound in the AICW pushing two deck barges in a straight bow to stern arrangement. 16DEC03 M/V EILEEN C ALLIDED WITH THE CHICAGO RAILROAD BRIDGE WITH THE NOTCH AT THE SECOND STRING COUPLING ON THE PORT STRING BARGE XL-713. CONFIRMED THRU BRIDGE THAT NO DAMAGE WAS REPORTED AND BRIDGE WAS STILL OPERATIONAL.
