The M/V HAZEL was transiting down bound w/4 loaded coal barges in high water and strong current when the operator began maneuvering tow to transit the Spottsville R/R bridge at mile 9 on the green river.  At this time the current set the tow toward the sheer fence on the bridge support, the operator was not able to correct for the set and the barge C317 contacted the sheer fence.  There was no damage to the barge or the sheer fence.  The Spottsville R/R bridge has not been used for R/R traffic for many years and has been the location of many allisions due to its location near a sharp bend in the river.  

There is no evidence of actionable misconduct, inattention to duty, negligence, incompetence or willful violation of law or regulation on the part of the USCG licensed mariner.

The commercial F/V PROVIDIAN was outbound in Cape May Harbor. As the vessel was proceeding under the Two Mile Bridge, a gust of wind forced the vessel's port quarter into the wood fendering system of the bridge. No damage was observed to the fendering system or the vessel and there were no injuries. Casualty was weather related, no negligence on the part of the captain.

INCIDENT:

On 07 Jan 04 at 0530, the M/V RIVER HAWK and tow consisting of 16 barges (14 loaded - 2 empties; 1138'  x 105') was north bound on the Ohio River at MM 246. The river stage was 44.7.  Immediately after the Captain,  came on watch, the boat's forward momentum stalled as they passed Sliding Hill Bend due to the river's excessive flow and currents.  The M/V River Hawk and her tow was forced into the bank on the Ohio side of the river.  The middle of the tow struck the river bank across from the Sliding Hill Bend Light, resulting in the nine lead barges breaking loose from the tow.  The boat and remaining barges struck the Pomeroy-Mason Highway Bridge pier.  Specifically, the crew indicated that barge "CBY 265" contacted the bridge.  

The Pomeroy-Mason bridge was immediately closed to traffic by local authorities and inspected by the Ohio Department of Transportation.  The bridge was later reopened after the inspection revealed no significant structural damage. The M\V A.A. Vestal, M/V Robert P. Tibolt, M/V William Robinson, M/V Fred R. Shedd, M/V Gale R. Rhodes, and M/V Lacey Nicole all came to the scene to assist with rounding up barges.  All barges were collected at approximately 0830.   There were numerous reports of property damage made to the Coast Guard COTP Huntington (from both commercial and private sources) that were passed to Excell Marine for settlement.  

Drug testing was ordered by the marine employer and conducted on 08 Jan 04.  One unlicensed crewmember  employment was terminated by Excell Marine.

There were no injuries, deaths, or reports of pollution. 

RECOMMENDATIONS:

All statements and correspondence received by the involved parties indicate that there were no engineering casualties that lead to the M/V RIVER HAWK loosing momentum.  Therefore, the cause of the grounding and subsequent barge break-away and allision with the Pomeroy-Mason Highway bridge was a result of the insufficient horsepower of the M/V RIVER HAWK given the river condition on 7 Jan 04.  

A letter of warning against Excel Marine has been submitted.  In a phone conversation between LTJG and representative for Excell Marine Corporation on 12 Feb 04, it was indicated that Excell would not dispute a letter of warning and they will reevaluate their current policy of 250 h.p. per barge.

CWO3, INVESTIGATING OFFICER

LTJG, INVESTIGATING OFFICER

09 MAR 04:  Excell representative advised LTJG  during a phone conversation, that Excell Marine increased their horsepower per barge policy to 400 shaft horsepower (from 250).  Justification for this change was that using the advertised shaft horsepower of a vessel was dangerous since the calculations are done when the vessel is new and not after the horsepower naturally degrades from normal mechanical wear.  The representative also mentioned that Excell's vessel captains were advised to immediately call the safety director if they feel that any operation is unsafe.   

LTJG, INVESTIGATING OFFICER

CDO Received call from Indian Creek bridge tender notifying that Tug George Eli & Barge MB604 had allided with bridge and damaged nav lights on bridge. 

Contacted Bunnell Foundation Inc. They explained that the tug & barge were uninspected, and that the company had been hired to work on the bridges. The tug & barge had finished the job at Indian Creek Bridge, and were transitting to their next job, which was further south (NFI.) Company  indicated the tug did not need a USCG licensed Master, since it was under 26'. 

Faxed 2692 to operating company for report.  Owner/operator failed to return 2692 activity referred for enforcement.

32/20/04 MMS

Incident Description:

The Parker Drilling Rig 56-B was engaged in a tow with the M/V Celia Ann and the M/V Miss Stacie.  The M/V Miss Stacie was the lead tug in the tow.  In preparation for a transit through the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge (SPRR Bridge)(29-40.1N,   090-06.0W). Deckhand #1 was posted on the bow of the Parker Rig to check clearance on either side of the rig.  Deckhand #1 was equipped with a handheld radio.  Because the M/V Celia Ann could not see around the rig to judge clearance, Deckhand #1's job was to direct the vessel on steering to safely navigate between the bridge trusses.  

Just prior to transiting through the bridge, Deckhand #1 checked clearance on the starboard side and radioed the Captain of the M/V Celia Ann, Crewmember #2, to come slightly to starboard. At this time, it is estimated that the tug and tow were traveling at about 2.5 knots.  Crewmember #2, the master, then came slightly to starboard.  While walking to the port side of the rig to check clearance, Deckhand #1 stepped on a manhole cover.  The manhole cover was dysfunctional in that the strong back was missing.  Deckhand #1 fell partially into the manhole, and had to be assisted by two rig deckhands to get out.  After being helped out of the manhole Mr. Lirette noticed the rig was not going to have enough clearance.  He radioed the M/V Celia Ann to stop.  Crewmember #2 of the Celia Ann put his engines in full reverse in order prevent an allision, but this was not successful.  The rig allided with the Railroad Bridge at its starboard bow, causing damage to the freeboard around the starboard bow cleat.  The allision also caused damage to the bridge itself by bending a truss.

Consequences of Damage to Railroad Bridge:

As a result of the bridge allision, the SPRR Bridge was closed for a period of four days in which no railway traffic was permitted to travel over it.  Subsequently, for the next week, separate inspections and closures caused delays in rail traffic.  The bridge has been repaired and is fully operational.

Enforcement/Recommendations:

An interview conducted with the captain of the M/V Miss Stacie showed that the captain had frequently transited through the bridge with no incident.  The captain has held a license for over 35 years. The Captain stated two factors contributed to the allision.  The first is the small clearance allowable for a vessel and tow to pass through.  The barge was 54' wide and the bridge opening was 56'. The second factor is the loss of help from the deckhand who was momentarily disrupted from his duties by falling into the manhole cover.  The Parker company has been notified of this safety hazard and the need to be more vigilant of hazards of the decks of their barges.  Although this the deckhand's fall did not directly cause the bridge allision, it can certainly be considered an contributing factor.  No enforcement action is recommended for any of the involved parties.

On or about 1540 on November 11, 2003, the M/V SEA LEADER, owned and operated by Ben-Tech Marine & Oil Services LTD., of Nigeria struck the Dularge Bridge in Houma, LA.

======================================================
ACCORDING TO THE CREW

  M/V SEA LEADER was eastbound on the ICW near MM 60 when it struck the Dularge Bridge in Houma, LA.

  M/V SEA LEADER Master XXXXX was at the helm and under operational control of the vessel at the time of the incident.  Captain XXXXX and his crew are in the U.S. for the first time from South Africa to take custody of the M/V SEA LEADER and deliver it to Nigeria. Captain XXXXX and his crew came onboard the M/V SEA LEADER for the first time on 9 Nov 03.  Captain XXXXX was in a hurry to move the subject vessel from a shipyard at Morgan City, LA to the Quality Shipyard in Houma, LA.    Captain XXXXX stated that he saw the Dularge Bridge but thought he could pass under it safely.   Captain XXXXX admitted he was unfamiliar with the M/V SEA LEADER's height of masts.

  Captain XXXXX attempted to stop his vessel prior to the allision but was unsuccessful.

  Captain XXXXX was the only crewmember in the wheelhouse at the time of the incident.

======================================================
ACCORDING TO THE BRIDGE TENDER

  Bridge tender stated that she saw the M/V SEA LEADER approaching the bridge but did not have time to call the vessel or raise the bridge.  After she heard the vessel strike the bridge she called the M/V SEA LEADER and told them they had hit the bridge.  The M/V SEA LEADER replied that "they thought they could have made it (under the bridge)."

The crew of the M/V SEA LEADER did not call to have the bridge raised.  

The bridge was operating normally.

The radios in the bridge control room were operating normally.  

=========================================================

APPARENT CAUSE

XXXXX failed to perform his duties to...
      a.     be thoroughly familiar with his vessels dimensions.
      b.     review the available charts on board for bridge heights.
      c.     error on the side of safety and request the bridge be raised.

  Equipment failure was not a factor in this casualty.

  Fatigue was not a factor in this casualty.

  Weather was not a factor in this casualty.

=========================================================

REMEDIAL ACTION

      1.    The M/V SEA LEADER has been sold to a non-US company and is now operating outside US waters.

      2.    The crew of the M/V SEA LEADER are South African and their licenses are not under US 
               jurisdiction.

It is reported the UTV ENDEAVOR while pushing three empty, uninspected barges (450ftx35ft) Northbound on Bayou Boeuf suffered a steering failure and allided with the East Guide wall of the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge.  Conducted telephone interview with the Pilot, who was at the wheel at the time of the accident and reports the lead barge had just entered the bridge span when the generator surged and then dropped the load. Thereby rendering the steering gear inoperable. Steering gear of the UTV is hydraulic and powered by an electric pump. Pilot stated to reduce the impact on the bridge he attempted to control the direction of the tug & tow with the use of the tugs engine throttles but was unable to keep the third barge, MI 97-2, from striking the fenders of the East and West guide walls. The Master of the tug, was asleep at the time but did confirm the tug's generator unexpectedly shutdown during the transit of the bridge span thereby disabling the vessel's steering. MI Drilling, operator of the tug, reported the failure of the generator was due to contaminated fuel. 

Failure of the generator was the root cause of the allision and corrective action has reportably been taken to protect the fuel system from further contaminates.

On 13FEB2004, Form 2692 was received reporting an equipment failure on board the M/V JAMES RIVER BRIDGE on 12FEB2004.  While the vessel was underway, it was observed that the boiler water level started dropping and that the feed water pump filling rate was less than the amount of steam generation.  Leakage in the boiler water system was suspected.  In order to investigate the cause, the boiler firing was stopped and the main engine was stopped.   The investigation revealed the feed water suction line was partially choked due to scale formation.  Therefore, the feed water pump was unable to supply the amount of water necessary for the boiler.  The feed water suction lines were cleaned.  After the system was tested, the main engine was restarted and the vessel resumed its voyage.

//S//
XXXXXX
Marine Investigator

32/35/04 KAK

On 19 February 2004, Captain # 1 was southbound on the GIWW as Master of the UTV ROSE D. (549301), which was pushing two hopper barges full of sugar.  Captain # 1 was headed from St. Mary Sugar in Bayou Teche to Baldwin.  As he neared the Charenton Canal (Baldwin) RR Bridge at 0750, Captain # 1 stated that he called the bridge tender, Person # 1, on the telephone to open the bridge.  As Captain # 1  rounded the bend, he said the bridge wasn't open and he started to slow down.  He stated that he again called the bridge tender via radio and telephone at 0800, to which the bridge tender replied that a shift change had just occurred and that he wasn't told the UTV ROSE D. was approaching.  The bridge tender then began opening the bridge, and Captain # 1 said that the current was pushing the barges at a 45 degree angle as he went through the opened bridge.  At 0810, the lead barge caught the current and laid sideways, midway of the barge, on a cinder block of the northeast fender system.

According to Person # 1, Captain # 1 did call before 0800 for the bridge to be opened, right at the time the tenders were switching shifts.  Person # 1 stated that the tug was approaching the bridge at an east-west angle and attempting to pass through the bridge before it completely opened.  The bridge tender began opening the bridge at 0758 and the accident occurred at 0800.  This bridge requires 8 min to fully open for marine traffic.

Person # 1 claimed that the fender system was damaged as a result of the allision, whereas Captain # 1 claims that the damage was pre-existing.  Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway bridge inspector Person # 2 confirmed that the damage occurred as a result of the allision.  This conclusion was based on records of previous Charenton Canal (Baldwin) RR Bridge inspections that indicated the bridge had not sustained this damage previously.  In addition, the area of the pilings where the barge allided showed markings of fresh wood rather than weathered.

Damage to the bridge included the protrusion of two fender boards 4' from the pier at the east end of the channel.  Wires connected to the lighting system also were pulled away.  Repairs to the bridge were estimated to be $5,200.00, to include pulling the protruding timbers back into place and bolting them in two places to the top timber.

A BNTM was issued on 20 February advising marine traffic of this navigational hazard at MM 123 on Charenton Canal.  A BNTM was issued later on 20 February notifying marine traffic of possible delays due to emergency repairs to the fender system.

When the Investigating Officer # 1interviewed Captain # 1, he stated that he regularly travels this area while operating the UTV ROSE D.  He also stated that this was the first time he had trouble transiting this particular bridge.  However, Person # 1 and Person # 2 reported that they've witnessed on several occasions over the years that Captain # 1 continuously attempts to pass through the Charenton Canal (Baldwin) RR Bridge before the bridge is opened completely.  Person # 1 and Person # 2 also reported that Captain # 1 often does not wait for the bridge tender to clear the traffic before he makes his approach in the tug.  A search of MISLE by the Investigating Officer # 1 revealed that Captain # 1 was involved in a similar incident 10 yrs prior, also while operating the UTV ROSE D. 

The weather was clear and visibility was good the morning of 19 February.  The wind was out of the east at 10 mph, and the current was running in a southerly direction at 3 mph.

No damage to the vessels occurred, and no injuries or pollution occurred.

Referred for enforcement.

32/36/04 KAK

On 22 February 2004, the UTV SARAH GRACE (503023) was traveling northbound on Bayou Boeuf, heading a towline composed of TETRA RIG 2, the deck barge JOSHUA (1050801), and the M/V CAPT JERRY HENRY (504705) (tailboat).  OOA 2015, TETRA RIG 2 allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge (Mile Post 73.3).

The UTV SARAH GRACE approached the open span on the east side passage of the bridge at approx 0.5 kt.  As the tow entered the fendering system of the bridge, a tire on the port side of TETRA RIG 2 allided with the guidewall, bouncing the rig toward the east.  Following this, the rig's starboard lead corner allided with the fendering system and pile cluster.  The M/V CAPT JERRY HENRY reversed the tow and backed out of the span.  The tow pulled over on the west bank of the south side of the bridge, where the crew disassembled the towline.  None of the vessels sustained any damage.

The captain of the UTV SARAH GRACE, went to the bridge tender who was trying to close the bridge.  However, the pilings were pushed into the channel to the point that the bridge could not close.  The bridge tender also discovered that the bridge's navigational lights were no longer functioning.  A Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway bridge inspector  was notified of the incident.  He said he would have a crew out there in the morning to remove the pilings from the waterway.

A BNTM was issued closing the channel to marine traffic, with the exception of small fishing vessels, until the pilings could be removed from the waterway.  The pilings were removed the next morning, 23 February, and the bridge was opened to marine traffic.  The contractor's estimate to repair the fendering system is $12,570.00.

The width of the channel with the bridge open is 57'.  The maximum width of the tow with towboats and tires was 55'.  The current on the night of 22 February was running in a southerly direction at 1-2 kt.  Wind was from the east at approx 25 mph., which the Captain attributed to the reason for the allision.  Visibility was clear.           

No injuries or pollution occurred.

32/37/04 KAK

On 23 February 2004 the UTV CAROLINE (904702) was pushing a straight line of five empty red-flag barges (4 lube oil and 1 benzene) westbound on the ICW from Baton Rouge to Houston.  The operator of the vessel was Captain # 1.  At MM 134, the UTV CAROLINE's tow allided with the north side of the fender system of the Louisa Bridge.  Bridge tender # 1, called Captain #1 after he heard the noise.  The bridge remained operational.  A bridge inspector came at daylight to inspect the Louisa Bridge and found no damage.  

About two minutes prior to the allision, the lookout on the barge radioed to Captain # 1that the vessel was close to hitting the bridge.  At that, Captain # 1began to reverse his engines and slow down, but the vessel allided with the fender system.  Captain # 1claimed that as he was proceeding through the bridge at 1.2 mph, strong winds started setting the tow to the starboard side of the bridge fender.  A coupling broke on the barge second from the stern port side of the UTV CAROLINE, and two deckhands were able to repair the coupling on-scene.  No other damage was sustained to either the vessel or the barges and all were fully maneuverable.

After the allision, Captain # 1 pulled the tug and barge over to await Coast Guard inspection.  The Coast Guard inspector confirmed no damage was sustained to the barges and tug, and the towline was allowed to continue its transit.  

The wind the morning of 23 February was gusting out of the south at 15-20 mph.  The weather was misty and raining.  The current was running 1.2 mph in a westerly direction, and the tide was rising.

Referred for enforcement.

On 26 February 2004 at approximately 0200, the tug PHIL MOSESSO was traveling up-bound on the Monongahela River at mile 6.2 when she experienced a steering loss.

As the vessel transited the Monongahela River, the online starboard steering pump motor failed.  The operator onboard the tug PHIL MOSESSO immediately sounded the general alarm to alert the crew.  The operator attempted to bring the port steering pump motor online but it too failed and would not operate properly.  The bearing in the starboard steering pump motor seized causing the motor coil and breaker box to overload.  As a result of the motor coil and breaker overloading, excessive heat was generated in the motor coils and the starboard steering pump motor caught on fire.  The fire was immediately extinguished by the vessel's crewmembers using portable fir extinguishers.  The fire was confined to the starboard steering pump motor.  The port steering pump failed to come online as a result of a seized bearing.

As a result of the starboard steering pump motor shutting down and the port not coming online, the vessel lost partial maneuverability and began drifting towards the CSX Transportation Railroad Bridge.  The operator made attempts to control the vessel using propulsion alone in order to minimize any potential damage in the event of an allision.  The barge T13528B landed on the center span of the CSX Transportation Railroad Bridge.

No damage, pollution, or injuries occurred as a result of this casualty.  This case is data collection IAW COGARD Washington DC (G-M) 042025Z OCT 01.

On 26 February 2004 at approximately 2300 the UTV JOHN C. TERRAL, pushing ahead one deck barge with a crane atop, allided into the west-side pier of the Krotz Springs railroad bridge, at mile 40 of the Atchafalaya River.  Upon it's southbound approach of the Krotz Springs railroad bridge, the operator of the UTV JOHN C. TERRAL claimed to have poor vision on the port side of the tow, due to a moored spud and hopper barge, causing difficulties in judging distances off the east span pier.  The operator, of the UTV JOHN C. TERRAL, acknowledged he misjudged the current speed and vessel course set thru the transit of the bridge supports.  

The UTV JOHN C. TERRAL and Krotz Springs railroad bridge sustained no reportable damage.  The deck barge, TRS #2, sustained a minor dent on the starboard stern, with no inset other than scratch marks.  There was no injuries or pollution as a result of the incident.

This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M)of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.

The CRYSTAL COAST is a 66.5 foot, 148 gross ton uninspected towing vessel built in 1983.  The SUSQUEHANNA is a 350 foot uninspected freight barge built in 1991.

5 MAR 04 - The UTV CRYSTAL COAST was transiting north along the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River pushing ahead the empty freight barge SUSQUEHANNA.   The weather was clear, visibility was good and winds were from the southwest at approximately 25 knots.  The current was an ebb tide flowing to the north at 0.5 knots.

1200L - The vessel was preparing to transit underneath the Norfolk Southern Rail Road Bridge 7, a single leaf bascule bridge.  

1210L - While maneuvering to pass underneath the bridge,  Captain positioned the vessels to the western side of the channel to compensate for the wind and tidal current.

1215L - While passing underneath the bridge, the SUSQUEHANNA allided with the west fender wall on the south side of the bridge.  The point of impact on the SUSQUEHANNA was the port bow rake, causing a small fracture in that area.  The bridge fendering system suffered numerous broken wooden boards and the catwalk was bent.  The vessels proceeded directly to a Newport News repair facility to effect repairs on the SUSQUEHANNA.  Salisbury Towing determined the fracture was minor and repaired it by welding at an estimated cost of $100.  

The damage report from Norfolk Southern filed by worker contains inaccuracies.  The worker's report states that the starboard side of the barge hit the bridge.  Questioning of the worker revealed that he did not actually witness the allision, but filled out his report based on information he received from the bridge operator.  He admits that he may have misinterpreted the information.

Captain retrieved weather and current reports prior to getting underway.  He stated that the weather conditions at the time of the incident were within his personal operating limits.  Captain admitted that this incident could have been prevented by using a lookout on the barge.  Although the Captain failed to provide a credible no fault explanation to overcome the presumption of negligence that arises whenever an allision occurs,  he was cooperative and forthcoming regarding this investigation and has no prior actions against his license in his 28 year career.  Captain promptly reported the casualty.  He has developed a plan to use lookouts when performing this type of maneuver in the future.  This incident was not referred for enforcement.

On March 9, 2004, the tug GEORGE BURROWS, official number 634141, was operating in the Sloop Channel on the Wantagh Parkway Bridge repair project.  As the tug was backing away from the bridge construction site, the current caught the tug resulting in the tug striking the bridge broadside.  The current was 4 knots, east flood.  The tug received damage to the hand rail and upper deck.  The bridge received damage to the catwalk, handrail, and part of a temporary bridge support structure.

XXXXX attempted to transit the Bayou Boeuf Rail Road Bridge between the center span and the East bank span.  XXXXX stated he was passing through the span and the wind caught the barge. Investigation complete. Remedial Action recommended.

On 14-Mar-04 at approximately 2010, the UTV MELISSA ANNA, was pushing ahead four loaded hopper barges of rock, when the tow allided with the Hwy 80 railroad bridge on the Lower Mississippi River, Mile 437. The uninspected hopper barge (AGS 944) sustained damage to it's #2 & #3 wing tanks, with a 0' to 3' insect running approximately 15' along the two tanks.  The vessel operator further stated that dense fog, limiting his vision as being a causal factor in the incident.  The Hwy 80 bridge halted rail traffic until inspection was completed 15Apr04, by the Vicksburg Bridge Commission.  There was not pollution or injuries as a result of the incident.  

Vessel Owner
The UTV MELISSA ANN is owned by Equipment Chartering Co. Inc., P.O. Box 3255, Bay St. Louis MS  39520, (228-216-5302 or 1-800-338-9270).  P.O.C.was notified and he ordered the drug test at request of our office.

27 Jan 2004, on the TomBigBee River the M/V Piachi was enroute to Mobile. AL with 6 hopper barges in a 2-long 3-wide configuration.  While the pilot was steering through the east span of the Naheola bridge the tow moved toward the East Channel Span Pier.  After trying to flank the tow back inline, the starboard head barge (WGN 9717) made contact with the East Channel Span Pier to the Nehola Bridge.  The pier supports the footing for the bridge's eastern span.  The barge sustained an 18" crease to the starboard bow corner headlog and was estimated at $3500. On the 17th of March, at 0730, the F/V ISABELLE TAYLOR struck the Bascule Bridge.  The bridge spans over the Middle Thorofare waterway in Cape May, NJ.  The vessel was going on an outbound route with an ebb tide when the accident occurred.   Weather on scene was unlimited visibility, 40 F, with winds at 15k out of the NW.  4 people were onboard with Mr. XXXX XXXX as the master.  After the allision, Mr. XXXX notified the bridge operator along with Coast Guard Station Cape May.  The bridge operator suspended road and waterway traffic and contacted bridge engineers to conduct a survey of the damage.  The bridge engineers arrived on scene and determined only one section of the bridge fender was damage (estimated at $30,000), with no structural damage to the bridge itself.  The bridge resumed normal operations a short time later.

The F/V ISABELLE TAYLOR was order to dock at the local Coast Guard Station in Cape May.  PO XXXX (from Station Cape May) led a boarding team onto the vessel.  The boarding team conducted a field sobriety test on all four crewmembers, which turn out to be XXXXX.  The boarding team also took digital photos of the damage along the hull and photos of the fenders at the bridge.

CWO XXX XXXX (Investigating Officer) interviewed Mr. XXXX XXXX.  Mr. XXXX stated he was not aware of the strong outgoing tide, until he was too close to the bridge.  Mr. XXXX further stated he overcorrected the steering, which forced the vessel to allide on the starboard side of the vessel with the bridge fender.  The bridge's width along the waterway is at 50 feet, with the vessel width at 30 feet, leaving very little room to maneuver under the bridge.  Mr. XXXX has been working on this vessel for over 3 months.  The vessel had been in port for the last 48 hours, with the crew conducting minimal work on the vessel.  Mr. XXXX had a restful evening the night before the accident.  

LTJG XXXX (Marine Inspector) conducted a hull examination of the vessel and only found minimal damage to the starboard hull. No repairs needed

Case closed.

4/4/04 0820L - The UTV ELIS got underway from West Point, VA pulling the empty freight barge 
SMURFIT STONE 25 astern on a short hawser.  NOAA issued a gale warning calling for 25 to 30 knot winds gusting to 40 knots.

0830L - The Captain decided to transit the Eltham Bridge with the SMURFIT STONE 25 on a short hawser astern and then pay out the tow after clearing the bridge to tow the vessel astern to Elizabeth City, NC.  Captain lined the ELIS up to transit the center of the bridge span.  He expected the wind at the barge's stern and to have approximately 25 feet of horizontal clearance on each side of the barge.

0845L - After the ELIS and most of the SMURFIT STONE 25 had safely cleared the bridge span a gust of cross wind, approximately 35 - 40 knots on the starboard quarter, pushed the port side of the barge into the fendering system of the Eltham Bridge.  

0900L - After clearing the bridge, Captain slowed the ELIS in the middle of the channel and sent the tug's engineer to see if there was any apparent damage to the barge or bridge.  The engineer reported that he could not see any evidence of damage to the barge.  The bridge tender contacted the ELIS via VHF radio and reported that he had checked the bridge and there was some damage to the pilings making up the end of the fendering system.  The bridge tender also reported that his wind gauges verified that a strong cross wind gust had caught the barge.

1110L - Captain contacted HMRMS to report the allision.  Captain stated that he didn't believe there was any damage to the barge and that he intended to continue to Elizabeth City.  He stated that there were no mechanical problems with the ELIS and that all steering, navigation and propulsion systems were working perfectly.  HMRMS authorized Traywick to continue the transit to Elizabeth City.

DISCUSSION:

When questioned by HMRMS investigators, the Captain stated that he felt the stern tow was safe considering the weather and the direction of the wind.  Since the wind was on the stern and he wasn't experiencing crosswind, Captain decided that he could transit under the bridge on a short hawser and then pay out line for the transit down the Chesapeake Bay.  This would allow the hawser to act as a shock absorber in the heavy weather.  This decision is generally in keeping with standard marine practice.  Captain stated that had he anticipated the cross winds or if he had it to do again, he would put the barge in pushing gear.  

NOAA issued a wind advisory and Gale Warning for that section of the Chesapeake Bay and the Captain was aware of the weather broadcast.  The existence of crosswinds and high wind gusts are something a prudent mariner should anticipate.  Although the Captain failed to provide a credible no fault explanation to overcome the presumption of negligence that arises whenever a vessel allides with a fixed object, this incident was not referred for enforcement.  The minimal damage that occurred in this allision, coupled with the Captain's safety record, action to report the casualty and efforts to learn from the event to improve the company's future operations were considered in this decision.

The T/V STOLT CAPABILITY was outbound and allided with the fender system of the Casco Bay Bridge.  The vessel sustained minimal damage and no damage was done to the bridge.

The Master of the tank ship became concerned with way the vessel was being handled by the Docking Pilot .   In the Master's opinion, too many commands were being given to the tugs causing counter steering, especially since this vessel had a bow thurster and a controlable pitch propeller.  The master also noted that the Pilot was not concerned with the handling characteristics of the vessel at the pre-brief and did not inquire until well into the evolution.  The Master tried to compensate for the counter steering by using the bow thruster.

When the vessel entered the bridge span it was out of position and glanced off the fender with the starboard side.

Visibility did decline but not significant enough to cause the incident.

The cause of the incident appears to be poor bridge management and communications with weather playing a minimal role.

On March 31, 2004, at approximately 0715 the UTV VICKIE, pushing 6 loaded hopper barges, allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge on mile 30 of the Atchafalaya River.  The UTV VICKIE was transiting southbound enroute to New Iberia, La.  While attempting to transit through the Melville Railroad Bridge the UTV VICKIE and its tow were set towards the pilings of the bridge.  The port side of the L-228 allided with the bridge piling.  Immediately after the incident the bridge tender inspected the bridge and found no damage.   The master of the UTV VICKIE, crewmember immediately pushed his tow up on the RDB to check for damage. Deckhand aboard the UTV VICKIE noted that the L-228 suffered damage to its port side during the Allision.  The L-228's port side had a 15-foot inset with a small fracture 9 inches long by ½ inch wide.  The seaworthiness of the barge was not affected. The UTV VICKIE resumed its southbound voyage at approximately 0700 on April 1, 2004. No injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.

A contributing factor to the incident is the lack of adequate lighting on the bridge.

06APR2004-  At approx. 1936 the tug REGINA T was outbound for sea, pushing ahead a 195'x35' barge.   Tug and barge originated at FT. Pierce, Fl with end destination being Naples, FL  Tide at a strong ebb being as it was a full moon as well.   During the outbound transit of the Sanibel Causeway Bridge "A" span draw the STBD side of the barge "rubbed" the west side fendering system.     

After Captain  transited through the bridge he notified the bride tender via VHF-FM of the allision.  the Sanibel Bridge tender in turn notified CG Sta Ft. Myers as well as his own internal notification contacts.  Sta FT. Myers Beach  sent an asset out to assess the bridge, no significant damage noted.  

The Sanibel Bridge has a Regulated Navigational Area (RNA) in force surrounding the "A" span (Federal Register Vol. 68) due to questionable structural safety issues.   Tug and barge traffic may only transit at slack tide while pushing ahead in tandem.  

At 0900 07 APR2004-  MSD FT. Myers contacted the Lee County DOT asking if his people had inspected the bridge for damage, this was the first he had heard of the allision.  He will send his people out this am to inspect.  1230/ Rcvd report from Lee County DOT that  nothing other than some minor splintering of a bridge fender had occurred.

07APR2004-  Spoke with Captain and requested he submit a CG-2692 within 5 days.  MSD awaiting return of form.  

Conclusions/recommendations:

The RNA in force for the "A" span has been in effect since November 2003.  It was being broadcast initially  by Group St. Petersburg for a duration of 14 days beginning in November.  Speaking with Local Notice to Mariners editor Bernie Dukes the RNA was never published.  

The bridge tender on duty  was aware of the RNA in place.  He is the "last line of defense" for the implementation of the RNA.  When he was asked for a bridge opening especially when the tide was a strong ebb, not slack water, he should have asked the Captain if he was aware of the RNA in place, and if in fact the Captain was not, he should have requested the he, the Captain, contact the CG via VHF 16.

The bridge tenders internal notification system is flawed seeing as the bridge tender was not aware of the incident until I had contacted him the following day.  

The above mentioned items have been corrected as a result of this investigation. As per D7 ATON, the RNA will be published in next weeks LNM Had this bridge not have such political and community scrutiny surrounding this it would have been just a "standard" allision.   Seeing as the RNA was not being broadcast,  not being published in the Local Notice to Mariners, or posted there would be no way for a transient mariner to be aware of the RNA in place, therefore there is not enough evidence to assess a civil penalty to Captain Masters as the RNA stipulates.  There is also no violation of the twelve hour rule suspected in this Marine Casualty.

Transiting outbound on Duwamish Waterway, Seattle, WA, tug JEFFREY FOSS allided with drawbridge fendering for the Burlington Northern/Sante Fe Railroad Bridge (BN/SFRR); the tug was unable to maintain control through the obstructing drawbridge's narrow opening.  The tug skimmed along bridge fendering; there was no damage to its tire fenders or their securing chains. The tug was made up to the stbd qtr of empty Canadian gravel barge SEASPAN 240.  The tug's allided w/facing boards on the center section of the bridge's east shearwall fendering; neither vs lwas damaged.  Damage: entire center fendering section was carried away, with vertical pilings and a bridge navigation light broken.  Divers reported  it on the bottom & still intact.  Tug's crew directed to undergo drug tests on 7Apr04, by CG I.O; due to delay, no alcohol testing was completed.  BN/SFRR Bridge Supervisor of Construction, provided a cost for repair exceeding all prior estimates.  

Based on current evidence, no enforcement activity is contemplated at this time.

On 04May04, at approximately 2330, the UTV FREEDOM was pushing ahead four loaded rock barges when the tow allided with an abandoned Union Pacific railroad bridge pier on the RDB of the Ouchita River.  Two bridge piers, LDB and RDB, were abandoned by Union Pacific at mile 114.1 on the Ouchita River when the railroad bridge was dismantled.  In the year 1942, a vertical lift railroad bridge (Ouchita Railroad Bridge, operated by Union Pacific RR) was built up bound at mile 114.2, to replace the dismantled bridge.  The UTV FREEDOM operator was steering the UTV's tow around Horseshoe Bend at mile 113.8 when he set a course to transit the channel span of the Ouchita Railroad bridge.  According to the master, he placed the UTV's spot lights to mark the position of the abandoned Union Pacific bridge pier (RDB) upon setting his course of transit.  However, he, set the head of the tow too close to the approaching Union Pacific bridge pier (RDB) and allided the tow's port lead barge, ING 1724, with the pier head-on.  Subsequent to the allision, the Union Pacific bridge pier (RDB) collapsed into the Ouchita River.  On 05May04, the Vicksburg Army Corp of Engineers conducted an underwater survey to determine the depth of the collapsed Union Pacific bridge pier (RDB) and found the pier laying on it's side on the bottom of the Ouchita River, along the channel with 22 feet of water over the top of the pier.  On 05May04, the Monroe gage indicated 23.8 foot and rising.  There were not further marine casualties, pollution, or injury as a result of the incident.

Reportable marine casualty per 46 CFR 4.05-1 (a)(7).  Serious marine incident per 46 CFR 4.03-2 (a)(3). Longboat Pass drawbridge, west side approaching ICW
On 2SEP03 the assist vessel "Daze Off", under the command of Captain was towing the disabled sailing vessel "Seaweed" from the Gulf of Mexico to Sarasota Bay for repairs.  The Seaweed had experienced engine failure and its main mast had been damage at sea (or, according to the owner, it was a prior condition before the voyage).  

According to Capt,  as the Daze Off with Seaweed in tow approached the Longboat Pass drawbridge at approximately the seas were running 3' to 4' and the wind was clocked at 8 to 12 MPH from the South West.  Incoming current at the bridge was approximately 3 MPH.  The Daze Off was able to make only 2.3 MPH due to problems with the tow.

Several radio contacts were made to the bridge tender, one 45 minutes prior to arrival at the bridge, to advise the tender that due to difficulty in towing and the incoming current the Daze Off would not be able to heave too if the bridge was not open at the time of arrival.  Twelve minutes prior to arrival, the bridge tender acknowledged further contact and as the vessels approached the tender began to open the draw span at 1800 hours.  The Daze Off turned to the north side of the bridge channel, which gave the greatest clearance below the span, and continued inbound.  For unexplained reasons, the bridge tender stopped the opening of the span too low to clear the mast height of the Seaweed which caused the already damaged mast to strike the westerly beam of the span about 2' from the top, further damaging the mast, and damaging the masthead light and VHF antenna.  The bridge immediately began to open further so that the broken mast would not hit any more of the bridge beams.  No damage was reported to the bridge.  

Causal Analysis:  
·	The operator of the towing vsl elected to tow the S/V under a drawbridge, in difficult towing arrangement and with inbound strong current.  Unadvisable.

·	Bridge operator informed tow vsl to continue in and stated they would open the bridge in time.  This is not good practice; the tow vsl should have stayed in position until bridge was completely up.

Recommend case closed. 
LT, SIO

On 01Jun04 at approximately 0330, the UTV JULIA WOODS was on a southbound transit, pushing ahead 35 loaded coal barges, when the vessels tow allided with the Kansas City Southern Railroad bridge at Mile 435 on the Lower Mississippi River.  The UTV JULIA WOODS allided it's starboard lead barge, MST 263, head-on into the channel span's right descending bridge pier.  Subsequent to the allision, the starboard lead barge, MST 263, immediately began taking on water after alliding with the bridge pier.  The barge, MST 263, dipped bow first, raising the stern and broke the breast wiring holding the starboard string together.  The MST 263 sunk in 64 feet of water, in the middle of the navigation channel, approximately 1/2 of a mile downstream from the railroad bridge.  Due to the MST 263's sinking and breaking of the breast wiring, the starboard string of barges, (MST 318, MST 359, MST 740, MST 413), became adrift.  The four barges were retrieved by the UTV MARITIME and UTV SYNERGY.  There was no injury, pollution or further marine casualty as a result of the incident.

Bridge Allsion involving Foss Tug PT Vicente underway with Barge 30 in side tow; top of boom on tug scrapped along bottom of Hiem bridge. 

SUMMARY: At time of incident tug and barge headed west bound in Cerritos Channel with boom approximately 3 ft above its cradle and off center. Fatigue was not a contributing factor.  Master had taken barge under Hiem bridge on prior occasions w/o incident.  Masters view of barge deck was obstructed by barge itself do to height of barge along side tug.  Tankerman normally secures boom after a job.  Boom was secured to a port-o-potty at the time b/c crew was planning on returning to Foss office to unload port-o-potty.  Master then decided to do another job before returning to Foss Offices.  All crew assumed since mast lights made it under bridge that boom would make it but because out of cradle it did not.  On final approach to Hiem lookout saw boom was out of cradle and warned master via radio but it was too late.
 
CONTRIBUTING CAUSES:
1. Boom on barge was unsecured
2.  Barge was in lightened load
3. It was High tide
4.  It was too dark to judge clearance under bridge.
5.  Off center angle of boom obscured perception of its height.

BARGE MM-3501, BEING PUSHED BY THE M/V LIMESTONE LADY S/B AY MM 941 OHR, ALLIDED WITH THE RIGHT DESCENDING PIER OF THE HIGH WATER SPAN OF THE I-24 BRIDGE.  ALLISION CAUSED EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO STBD SIDE WING VOIDS OVER A LENGTH OF APPROX 100FT. (SEE SURVEY REPORT FOR DETAILS).

THE PILOT ABOARD THE M/V LIMESTONE LADY, MISJUDGED THE HIGH WATER CURRENT WHILE ATTEMPTING TO TRANSIT UNDER THE I-24 BRIDGE LOCATED AT MM 940, OHIO RIVER.  THE HIGH WATER CURRENT SET THE TOW DOWN THE PIER ON THE RIGHT DESCENDING SIDE FASTER THAN EXPECTED, AND THE PILOT WAS UNABLE TO MAINTAIN HEADWAY.  THE MAJORITY OF THE TOW WAS ABLE TO PASS UNDER THE HIGH WATER SPAN BUT THE MM-3501, LOCATED 4TH BARGE BACK ON THE STBD STRING, ALLIDED WITH THE PIER.

COST OF DAMAGE REPAIR ESTIMATED TO EXCEED VALUE OF BARGE.  SURVEY CONDUCTED.

CHEMICAL TESTING CONDUCTED BY COMMONWEALTH INDUSTRIAL AND OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH.

On 03Jul04, at approximately 0315, the UTV DISCOVERY was pushing ahead two empty red flag barges when the tow allided with the Hwy 8 swing bridge.  The incident occurred at mile 57 on the Ouachita River.  Upon the tow's approach of the Hwy 8 swing bridge, UTV DISCOVERY vessel operator, allided the tow's starboard lead barge (COASTAL 2531) with the fendering system upstream the highway bridge.  Subsequent to alliding with the Hwy 8 swing bridge fendering system, the operator maneuvered the vessel off the fendering system and grounded the tow into the left descending bank.  While holding the tow on ground, the operator awoke the vessel's secondary pilot, to assist in maneuvering vessel off-ground and transit the tow through bridge span.  UTV DISCOVERY secondary pilot stated that upon the tow's second approach thru the bridge span, the current set the tow towards the east bank bridge pier.  The port lead barge (COASTAL 2528) allided with the left descending bank bridge pier.  Subsequent to alliding with the bridge pier, the secondary pilot stated he powered the tow forward to get thru the channel span and allided the two empty red flag barges head-on into the southbound fendering system of the bridge.  There was no injury or pollution associated with the incident.

The operator was unable to complete the turn without colliding with the Snake River Highway Bridge.  Once the operator realized the tow was going to make contact with the bridge, the operator maneuvered the tug to collide only with barge 57.  At 2050,  barge 57 allided with the Snake River Highway Bridge.  After maneuvering the barges to safety, the deckhands inspected barge 57 and heard air leaking from it.  Divers were called and temporary repairs were made.

1621 11JULY2004, the automobile carrier M/V PACIFIC HIGHWAY (ON# 26847/PANAMA) allided with the fendering system on the Western span of the Richmond San Rafael Bridge (RSRB) while enroute Benicia, CA with a pilot onboard.  The M/V steered hard to port to avoid colliding with the S/V DELLA BROWN who was incorrectly crossing the narrow channel in light winds under sail.  The HIGHWAY sounded danger signals but the S/V did not react.  S/V operator stated that his vessel was becalmed under the bridge while attempting to cross in the path of the HIGHWAY.  The M/V then steered hard to starboard to avoid striking the RSRB West span head-on.   Resulting damage to the HIGHWAY was isolated to a 150 ft long indentation on portside above the waterline; a hull penetration of 6 inches long pierced the sideshell at the indentation.  Estimates to replace damaged fendering system on the bridge are close to 1.5 million.  CG assets deployed to make positive contact with the sailing vessel and ascertain damages to bridge. Drug testing results obtained from crew and pilot aboard the HIGHWAY.  No resulting injuries or pollution.

On June 4, 2004 the M/V Invincible O.N. 610267 pushing the barge McKee Sons O.N. 247490 allided with the CSX railroad bridge in St. Joseph, MI.  After the allision the barge went aground causing the tug and barge to become stuck partially in the bridge opening and thus the bridge was unable to close.  The tug and barge could not free itself and required assistance from two tug boats.

On 04 July, 2004, the tug CAPT. GEORGE was transiting the Wappoo Cut with tow.  The towing bridle got caught under a fender of the tug, and came loose passing under the Wappoo Cut bridge allowing the barge to contact the bridge's fender system.  Approximately $10,000 of damage occurred to fender system, no damage to barge or tug.

On 14 July, 2004, the Capt. of the tug,  was summoned to MSO Charleston for an interview with MSO Personnel.  Capt. was questioned as to the nature of the incident, and also another allision approximately 14 months later.  Investigators determined misconduct or negligence was not a factor in this marine casualty.  The main causitive factor is that the bridle got caught, allowing the allision.

07 July 04 - While up bound on the Kanawha River, MM 0.6, the BELLE OF CINCINNATI's  stdb stack contacted the up bound, green, center range light of the Chessie Railroad Bridge (A.K.A. B&O RR Bridge as indicated on the ACOE charts). 

The Master contacted HUNMS and explained that the charted clearance of this bridge was 66.0' and he required 64'. The Master indicated that his decorative trim around the very top of his stbd stack contacted the range light, knocking the range light off it's mount but not causing any damage to his vessel. 

HUNMS instructed the Master to lower the stacks (thus lowering his required clearance to 52') and authorized him to proceeded on his voyage. HUNMS contacted GRP Ohio Valley and requested a BNM be issued for the extinguished range light and to contact the bridge owner. D8 Bridge Branch was also contacted by the Group watch stander.

08 July 04 - HUNMS investigator visited bridge to inspect damage to range light and confirm Master's report. Range light found hanging by wires. 

08 July 04 - During the BELLE OF CINCINNATI's transit through Huntington the HUNMS small boat confirmed that the vessel sustained no damage from this incident.

There was no indication of mariner negligence or misconduct that contributed to this casualty. No further action anticipated.

On 21Jul04, at approximately 0355, the UTV MARTIN NAVIGATOR was pushing ahead two empty red flags, when the tow allided with the Krotz Springs Railroad bridge.  The tow was transiting southbound at Mile 41 on the Atchafalaya River, when the incident occurred.  According to the operator of the UTV MARTIN NAVIGATOR, the vessel was transiting southbound thru the Krotz Springs Railroad bridge span when the current set the vessels tow westward, subsequently alliding with the turntable bridge pier.  Barge # MMLP 220 sustained a 6" hairline crack in the deck of the port stern corner of the barge.  Bridge pier was undamaged and operational.   USCG Marine Inspector issued barge # MMLP 220 a permit to proceed, repairs conducted to the satisfaction of the USCG at Bollinger Repair Yard in Morgan City, LA. Received a report that the Tug Consort while pushing EMI 1152 (loaded coal barge) up the Hackensack River, allided with the Witt Penn Bridge (Route 7).  The vessel allided with the span of the bridge in the down position causing significant damage to the pilot house and minimal damage to the bridge.  The barge did not impact the bridge and sustained no damage during the incident.

Drug and alcohol testing was completed on vessel's crew.
The M/V Mary Scheel was southbound and MEM2006 rubbed the left descending side of the Cass Street Bridge.  Barge received a small dent in the port corner.  No bridge damage.

Vsl, Seneca Queen, (new name, Ronald Dalhke) was pushing the barge, Candice Andrie, outbound St Joseph River on 02Oct03 when barge allided with the CSX RR bridge's center fender system causing damage to the timbers and rails.  Minor scrapes on barge, no damage to tug.  RR Bridge operational-minor damage.

Interviewed tug captain about the incident.  Seas in channel were 3' rolls, wind: NW at 22-25 kts.  The vsl captain stated that the wind and current pushed the barge into the bridge's fender system.  He stated that since he was in a push configuration, he was unable to control the barge movement when the wind gusted at 25 mph.  He stated that he wanted to wait until the channel swells/wind calmed down before departing the dock, but the owner/operator insisted that he leave.  

CSX correspondence lists the damage to be approximately $10,000.00 to the fender system and will be billing the owner/operator.

Also, the boarding team noted several dayboards that had been knocked down in the area where the tug and tow had transited, the master of the tug stated to boarding team members that he had probably knocked down the dayboards but was not sure since he didn't see it happen.

The vessel was making its approach upbound to the John Day locks in a strong current. M/V EILEEN C pushing 5 barges southbound on the Calumet River, allided with the 130th Street Bridge, Injuring the Pilot and damaging the vessel and the bridge.  Pilot stated that he was paying attention to the stern of the tow, when he looked forward and realized that he needed to lower the vessel's pilot house in order to clear the bridge.    The pilot house was not lowered in time.  As the vessel passed under the bridge, it damaged cross members on the underside of the bridge, and pushed the pilot house back approximately 6 feet. On 21-Apr-2004 at approximately 1500, the tug UTV MORGAN RAY pushing crane barge POULE D'EUA allided with a pile-on (bridge fender) before passing through the Almonaster Railroad Draw Bridge in New Orleans, LA.  The tow configuration consisted of a single string of two barges (a rock barge first, then a crane barge, POULE D'EUA, second).  The UTV MORGAN RAY master stated he had limited visibility on the port side due to the height of the crane barge superstructure and no lookout was posted on the crane barge at time of allision.  The POULE D'EAU, suffered a 1' x 4" wide dent and a small puncture to the port bow about 1.5' above the water line.  No injuries, no pollution, the bridge was not affected and remained fully operable.  Damage estimate of approximately $500 to barge.

UTV, traveling westbound in ICW, transitting through the Galveston Causeway Bridge, pushing one empty, three loaded barges, when wind and tide affected tow, resulting in tow landing on bridge fenders causing damage to timbers.  No damage to barge.  No release of chemical.

M/V GINNY STONE, PUSHING 36 LOADED NON-REGULATED BARGES S/B ON THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER, ALLIDED WITH THE THEBES RAILROAD BRIDGE LOCATED AT MM 43.1.

NO VISIBLE DAMAGE TO BRIDGE OR BARGES.

Received report from Coast Guard Group Ohio Valley that M/V ANNAPOLIS, pushing (2) loaded barges (P-Xylene), allided with New Johnsonville Railroad Bridge.  I/O assigned and responded on-scene to conduct investigation.  

No pollution, no injuries, no waterway closures.

More details available in correspondence tab.

2189346 - FV RoJo navigated with caution around Lake Washington, southbound along the western shore [NOT an ACOE waterway], to pass under the highrises for the three I-90 floating bridge spans, west end.  RoJo cleared the 1st (northern) span (westbound vehicle traffic) of the northern bridge as it slowly worked its way under the spans, but due to operator misjudgment its upright outrigger mast struck the underside of the north bridge's southern span (reversible lane vehicle traffic).  Only upon close approach did the operator realize that the 2nd (center) span was lower; see photos in evidence.  His attempt to back down was too late to avoid minor overhead contact that resulted in the mast sliding along the underside of the highrise, damaging only the mast.  Seattle PD harbor patrol investigation verified no bridge damage or operator use of alcohol.  Contributing:  (1) vertical clearance is not displayed on these bridges; (2) location of span with the least vertical clearance is difficult to discern; and (3) charting does not specify useful information, like which bridge has the lowest span.  See Safety Recommendations to D13(oan).  Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.

This incident is a reportable marine casualty iaw 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1).  IAW G-MOA Policy Ltr 2-02, the investigation of this reportable marine casualty has been conducted as a data collection activity.

UTV PERRY LYNN, was pushing four inspected (unloaded) barges east on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway when the aft port side barge (PEN 147) allided with the fender system of the SR 84 (Grand Lake) Pontoon Br. at MM 231.4.  Bridge tender reported no damage to bridge, and negligible damage to fender.

REPORTING PARTY STATES: AT 22:30 01 AUG 2004 M/V J. ANDREW ECKSTEIN W/15 LDS WAS DOWNBOUND ON UMR MI 179 APPROACHING THE POPLAR ST BRIDGE. VSL STEERED OUT OF TOW CAUSING TOW TO ALLIDE W/POPLAR ST BRIDGE & BREAK APART. BARGE MAC 611 SANK JUST ABOVE THE DOUGLAS MACARTHUR BRIDGE. OTHER BARGES WERE GATHERED & SECURED IN VARIOUS FLEETS

INVESTIGATION BY CWO DETERMINED THAT VSL'S PORT FACE FIRE BROKE CAUSING VSL TO LOSE CONTROL OF TOW. BARGE MAC 611 WAS PORT STRING LEAD BARGE. IT STRUCK THE RIGHT DESCENDING PIER OF POPLAR ST BRIDGE HEADON. THE TOW THEN BROKE APART.

On August 1 2004, a collision occurred between the barge GL73 and the motor yacht NICKY D's.  Prior to the incident, both vessels were waiting on opposite sides of the N&S Railroad Bridge for the bridge to open.  The barge along with its tug were on the south side of the bridge, while the yacht and many other recreational vessels were on the north side of the bridge.

The bridge tender communicated with the captain of the tug to let him know that there would be a break in between trains and that he would partially raise the bridge to allow the tug and barge through.

Due to circumstances (nearby vessel, maneuverability restrictions, etc.) prior to and after the tug and barge crossed under the bridge, there was a collision.

The port stern of the yacht struck the port bow of the barge.

No pollution or injuries reported.  The full incident narrative is available in correspondence.

At 1229, 30 September 04, Sector Boston received a call from the office of Boston Public Works (BPW) about a Chelsea Street Bridge. BPW stated that while transiting outbound through the bridge, the Tug  EVENING MIST, towing the Tank Barge B-35 hit the dolphin (fender) knocking over a navigational light located at the fender. The light was repaired by BPW and it is fully operational. The Tug FREEDOM was assisting the Tug EVENING MIST during the transit. The Coast Guard did not receive a verbal notification of the incident.

M/V MARY HARTER WAS MAKING HIS APPROACH TO MCALPINE LOCK.  LOWER GAGE WAS 38.5 FEET.  THE VESSEL WAS EXPERIENCING A BACK LASH FROM THE CURRENT OVER THE DAM, CAUSING THE COAL BARGE EFC 9221 TO LAND ON THE BULL NOSE OF THE LONG WALL.

13 OCT 04 - S/S HALIFAX was outbound to Lake Michigan on the Calumet River, when it allided with Chicago's 92nd Street Bridge.  HALIFAX had two assist tugs (M/V COLORADO & M/V ARIZONA) while transiting.  During time of allision, one tug was on bow and one on the stern.

Investigator boarded S/S HALIFAX to conduct interviews.  The Master of the Halifax, stated that due to bank suction he was having difficulty swinging HALIFAX bow to starboard in order to line up ship to make the next bridge.  He ordered the bow tug to pull bow to starboard, and stern tug to push stern to port to assist swing of bow to starboard.  The Master also backed to help break bank suction.  When suction broke, stern swung quickly to port, striking the underside of the left descending bridge span (open position).  The vessel master is responsible for directing tugs.  He failed to anticipate rapid swing of stern to port when bank suction broke, causing allision.

Allision resulted in 4' x 10' hole in S/S HALIFAX port quarter, just below the main deck.  Bridge sustained damage to underside of left descending span, which was repaired and fully operational within 24 hours.

14 OCT 04 - Vessel crew made temporary repairs, which were approved by class (Lloyds), and proceeded to Canada to make permanent repairs.

21OCT04 - Got underway with Port Ops boat crew to investigate allision at Sister's Creek Bridge.  Bridge fendering system was damaged and blocking waterway.  Initial damage assessment of the fendering system is $230,000.  Conducted visual inspection of barge.  No apparent damage to the barge.  Directed vessel masters to be drug tested and also required a CG-2692 Report of Marine Accident, Injury, or Death to be filed with the Coast Guard within five days.

22OCT04 - Received CG-2692 as well as drug test results for the masters.  Drug test results are completed.

Spud barge L1029, one of six barges being pushed eastbound on the GICW by the UTV SELENA MARIE, allided with Ellender Bridge.  Spud barge height was known by UTV Captain to be 52 feet, and Ellender Br. in "down" position is 50 feet above water. 

Incident referred for Personnel Action...

On the 24th of October 2004, the F/V KATHY ROSE struck the 2-mile drawbridge in Cape May, NJ causing concrete damage to one of the pillars of the bridge.  The damage is estimated to be at $50,000.00.  The fishing vessel was on an outbound course for a 12-day fishing trip.  Weather O/S - outgoing tide, with strong currents, strong winds from the east, and good visibility.

Initially the vessel approached the bridge by paralleling it, then took a port turn through the bridge opening.  While in the turn the vessel took a 10-15 degree starboard  list (due to the strong currents and winds) and proceeded through the bridge opening.  While under the bridge, the vessel after stay wire from the out rigging caught the concrete curbing of the bridge, this in turn pulled and cracked the concrete on the pillar.  The drawbridge was in the open position and was unable to close after the incident.

The fishing vessel was unaware of the damage and proceeded out to sea.  The Bridge Tender notified Coast Guard Station Cape May of the situation.  Station Cape May contacted the fishing vessel and ordered the vsl to return back to port for examination and investigation.  Station Cape May along with New Jersey Marine Police conducted a survey of the vessel and found no damage except to the out rigging of the vessel.  Station personnel also conducted a field sobriety test.  

The 2-mile bridge was repaired 4 days later.  At no time did the bridge repair hindered vessel traffic.
WHILE MAKING MARKLAND LOCK THE TOW SET OUT TOWARD THE OUTSIDE WALL.  THE CAPTAIN COULD NOT GET THE TOW FLAT ON THE WALL OR STOPPED BEFORE IT BECAME WEDGED IN THE CHAMBER.  MINOR DAMAGE TO TWO BARGES.
UPON ENTERING THE LOCK, THE STARBOARD BOW OF THE TOW MADE CONTACT WITH THE BULL NOSE ON THE SHORT WALL, BREAKING A BARGE WIRE.  NO OTHER DAMAGE.

On 11OCT04 the UTV ALBOB and 5 loaded rock barges were attempting to navigate through the Galveston Causeway bridge.  The ALBOB's lead barge L-1017 struck the bridge fendering system.  The result of the allision was $1000 damage to the L-1017 and an estimated $150000 to the bridge fendering system.  The bridge was not damaged and remained operational and the waterway was not shut down.  Drug and alcohol test were completed for the crew of the UTV ALBOB.

Operator of the UTV CAROLINE GUIDREY, reported an allision with the I-10 bridge where it crosses the San Jacinto River.  No pollution, No Injuries, No Damage to the Bridge, and the barge received less than 25K in damages.

This incident is a reportable marine casualty iaw 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1).  IAW G-MOA Policy Ltr 2-02, the investigation of this reportable marine casualty has been conducted as a data collection activity.

According to reporting source, the empty T/B IB 968 struck the northwest guide wall of the SR 384 (Black Bayou) bridge.  The IB 968 was being pushed westbound by the UTV MARY KAY with five other barges in tow.  The IB 968 (lead starboard barge) made contact with a piece of angle iron that was protruding from the guide wall.  No damage was noted to the barge or guide wall.
While entering the Galveston Causeway Bridge, wind and tide set the tow of the M/V REGINA ANN, barge CT 102, into a fender dolphin, causing damage to the dolphin and barge's number one tank.

On 07NOV2004 at 0450 the Tug Michaela McAllister was transiting inbound Chelsea river under the McCardle Bridge when the bridge was closed on top of the vessel. The vessel sustained heavy damage to the upper wheelhouse and mast. The Michaela McAllister was following 2 other Tugs, the Freedom and Liberty, from Boston Towing, up the channel and was the third and last tug transiting through the open bridge. The Master of the Michaela McAllister stated that he had spoke with the Bridge Operator on VHF-FM Channel 13 and confirmed that he would be following the other 2 tugs through. The other 2 tugs crew's verified this in statements provided during the investigation. The bridge operator stated he only recalled speaking with the Tug Liberty prior to opening and he stated they said that "a couple" of tugs would be going through.

See correspondance 38593 for IO statement.

32/165/04 - TST

11/04/2004 - Approximately 0230 04 Nov 2004 the UTV MYRNA ANN (1123120), begin driven by responsible party was pushing ahead an empty six-pack configuration of barges.  The towing vessel and barges were passing underneath the Bayou Dularge Bridge when the second port barge, ING 5707 (989774), was pushed by a gust of wind into the leg of the bridge.  No damage was reported by the bridge and the barge received black marks on the hull attributed to rubbing the fender.

UTV ROBIN LANETTE proceeding east bound through the Brazos East Gate when outbound current caused tow to move out of position. With too much headway to stop, tow hit north side of the Brazos East Gate wall.

Notified by Group Atlantic City that a Bridge Tender for the 2 Mile Bridge telephoned to report an allision had occurred involving the F/V MARY MAGDALINE while traveling outbound to the ocean. The Bridge tender stated that the F/V struck a wood bumper. Station Cape May made contact with the vessel and escorted them to the piers at the station. A baording was conducted and the vessel was provided with a form CG-2692. 

Investigation found that there is a known problem with cross currents in the area, however, the Captain of the vessel is new to the area. Contacted the Cape May County Bridge Commission via telephone and was informed that the initial repair estimates for the bumper system was $20,000.00.

A tug & barge owned by Kelly Brothers Marine Construction struck the Sanibel Causway Bridge Span A at approx 0645.  The tug/barge was proceeding southbound in the Okeechobee Waterway when it was set by the strong current.  The tug operator lost control of the tug/barge and glanced off the bridge fendering system.  After hitting the fender system, the tug/barge came to rest against the bridge supports.

MSD Fort Myers investigator arrived onscene and observed the tug/barge resting against the bridge supports on the west side of the span opening.  MSD investigator boarded the tug/barge and interviewed the master and deckhand.  The master stated that he departed the dock at Sanibel Harbor Resort (approximately 1/2 mile north of the incident scene) at 0630 in darkness and did not notice which direction the current was moving.  The current took control of the tug/barge and the master lost control.  The tug/barge spun around, glanced off the bridge fendering system and came to rest against a bridge support.  The master was able to free the barge from the bridge after the current decreased with the change of the tide.  In addition, a small outboard powered assisted in pushing the tug/barge free.  The bridge tender stated the current was very strong outbound at the time of the incident and that he noticed the tug and barge was "crabbing" all the way down the channel.  A Regulated Navigation Area is in place for tugs using the bridge span.  The Regulation specifies that tugs and barges must transit at slack water only and that tugs must be of adequate horsepower to fully maneuver barges.  This case is being refered to enforcment for further action.

13 NOV 2004 - The captain of the CFV V. J. O'NEAL, a 75 foot wooden hull scallop vessel, attempted to maneuver the vessel from Captain Fish's restaurant, which is on the Chincoteague wharf, to a different location on the same wharf.  The V. J. O'NEAL allided with the CFV TWO BROTHERS and the Chincoteague swing bridge fender system before successfully mooring alongside another CFV moored to the wharf. Received notification that the tug vessel LUCY REINHAUR, was towing the RTC 105 on a head-to-tail configuration, with the barge on the starboard side. Data collection level of investigation conducted in accordance with message dtg 051545Z OCT 01 from COMLANTAREA COGARD Portsmouth, VA //AM//.

On November 10, 2004, the vessel SUNDREAM allied with the Broad CSWY Bridge at approx 0200 hours, causing damage to the vessel. Shortly after the vessel collided with one of the towing vessels that was taking the vessel in tow and allided with an unknown object. 

The master was not operating within the scope of their COI; he had a crew of 2 when the COI required 4.

On 13NOV04 the M/V Nadine Baker allided with the CSX Spottsville Railroad bridge and sustained a hull fracture on the starboard stern quarter below the laminated rubber rub rail.  On 16NOV04 at approximately 0325 local time, the vessel sank at Green River Mile 28.5 near Curdsville, Ky.  Operator reported approximately 10,000 gallons of diesel fuel on board.  Salvage operations and oil spill clean-up completed on 26NOV04.  Required post casualty chemical drug and alcohol testing on 6 crewmembers.  James Marine of Paducah, Ky. completed stripping the fuel tanks of the vessel on 28JAN05 and reported removing 3600 gallons of diesel fuel from the tanks.  This means that approximately 5000 to 7000 gallons of diesel fuel was discharged into the Green River.

On September 15, 2004 during the passing of  Hurricane Jeanne U.S. Coast Guard Marine Safety Office San Juan Duty Inspector and Facilities personnel investigated damage at Gulf CAPECO terminal in Cataño, PR. Damage was caused by an allision from the Barge JAX SAN JUAN BRIDGE.  Due to the extent of the damage at the terminal, it was determined to be unsafe for vessels over 200 Gross Tons to moor or perform any cargo transfer operations at the facility.   COTP #2198004 was issued. 

SECTOR SAN JUAN Duty Inspector personnel responded to pier 15 to check damage incurred to Barge. The operator of the attending tug, Gauntlet, stated that a gust of wind broke the barge away from the Trailer Bridge Dock, the bow of the barge swung around and allided with Gulf Capeco Oil dock.  The barge had been moored starboard side to the Trailer Bridge Pier stern to the RO/RO ramp at the time.  Noted two insets forward, one in the bow and the other port side shell near the bow approximately 11 feet above ten of the barge located.                    

Duty Inspector issued 2 requirements.  See Activity #2198426.
UTV MARY EDWARDS WAS WESTBOUND AT CAUSEWAY BRIDGE.  WIND PICKED UP AND PUSHED BARGE MGM 602 INTO NE DOLPHIN.  SMALL DENTS ON THE MGM 602.  MINOR SCAPE TO THE BRIDGE FENDERWORKS.

29NOV04: ICC JACKSONVILLE RCVD NOTIFICATION THAT A DECK BARGE WAS AGROUND IN VICINITY OF THE STATE ROUTE 312 BRIDGE IN THE ICW. ST. AUGUSTINE POLICE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO THE SCENE AND REPORTED THAT THE OWNERSHIP FOR THE BARGE WAS BEING QUESTIONED BY SEA TOW.

SEE IO NARRATIVE IN CORRESPODENCE FOR ADDITIONAL DETAILS.

Received a report of a bridge allision by the UTV BUCHANAN 3 pulling 2 light scows under the Pelham Parkway Bridge.  Phone investigation with tug/bridge revealed that the vessel unintentionally used the bridge fendering while navigating under the bridge. 

No damage to the vessel or bridge.

32/182/04 - TST

11/26/2004 - Approximately 1130 the UTV BIG DADDY (294085) owned by Callais & Sons, L.L.C., was pushing 6 empty barges ahead.  The vessel was headed westbound from the IMC Salt to GIWW 139 at approx. 4 knots.  The captain was onboard the vessel .  The lead starboard barge the ACBL 2968 (577669) was caught by a gust of wind and pushed into a leg of the Bayou Blue Bridge.  The bridge and barge both reported zero damage.

At 0250 the Tug RIVER CAT and Barge 1164 allided with the Black Point RR bridge's dolphin in the Petaluma River. The Port corner of the barge caught the bridge dolphin causing the tug and barge to be swung around by the winds and river current. No damage was reported from the tug for the bridge dolphin and the barge.  MSO and D11 bridge branch director were unable to contact the bridge owner/operator. Bridge has not been operated for at least the last 5 years.

UTV MISS MARIANNE headed west bound through Galveston Causeway Bridge, started back down unsuccessfully and landed on NE tires of a dolphin. Two tires were damaged on the bridge, no damage to barge HICO 3001, no injuries.

The Boy Scouts of America sailing school vessel ODYSSEY proceeded through the open BNSF Bridge #4 without first signaling the bridge operator as required by 33 CFR 117.21.  Bridge tender, did not check if there was any vessel traffic in the area; unknowingly, he closed the bridge on the mast of the ODYSSEY.    

Based on current evidence, this matter is referred for enforcement.

UTV BOB HELTON was eastbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway with two loaded barges, including an uninspected freight barge with eight pipe stands welded to the deck.  Vertical height of pipe stands on barge was about 52 feet, and allided with Ellender Bridge in its down position (50 feet).  Load broke free from deck, and three pipe stands fell into waterway, requiring closure of GICW and dive/recovery operation.  

Incident referred for enforcement.

10Dec04- While piloting the LPG/C ALRAR, inbound Portsmouth Harbor with 4 Moran Tugs, the tug on the starboard bow touched the fender system of the Memorial Bridge. The Tug Eugenia Moran was backing half while assisting the ALRAR through the bridge. The stern of the tug swung out and grazed the Maine side wooden fender system of the Memorial Bridge. The pilot was watching the tug while she backed, and when she started to swing out, he stopped the tug. With the ship only doing 4 knots, he didn't expect the tug to swing out that far. No damage was done to the tug. NH DOT inspected the bridge and reported no damage. The 3 pieces of wood that were damaged on the Memorial bridge fender system were repaired within an hour.

On December 21, 2004, at approximately 1300, the Towing Vessel American Eagle was involved in an allision with the Sister's Creek Bridge Fendering System on the Intercoastal Waterway in the vicinity of Statute Mile 740.  At approximately 1515 investigators from MSO Jacksonville boarded the  Towing Vessel American Eagle from CG25505 in the ICW between Markers "75" and "77".  After several safety discrepancies were found, including unserviceable lifesaving and firefighting equipment, the Captain of the Port terminated the voyage of the vessel.

Drug testing was conducted, alcohol test was not conducted, employer determined that alcohol test was not required after interviewing the Master (subject) immediately after the incident.  Coast Guard boarding team concurred with employer.  Subject is referred for Enforcement Action.

M/V Eva Kelley allided with a RR bridge while transiting down bound the Green River near MM 79.6. The allision resulted in a 6" vertical crack in the port quarter of the stbd head barge. The report of the allision was made approximately 24hrs after the occurrence.

1/3/05  at 0750Tug PACIFIC COMBI underway from South West Marine, LA 245 with South Bay Barge #1 in tow enroute to Long Beach 247, Pier J.  Weather conditions were heavy rain and wind. Tug heading east in Cerritos Channel and stop approximately 150 feet from Badger Avenue Bridge (Henry Ford R&R Bridge).  Bridge was in down position allowing two trains to pass over.

0845  Tug proceeded underway about 1knot when gust of wind pushed it off station. Front Port Fender (large tractor tire) made contact with Bridge Fendering system.  No damage to Tug fender or Tug.

Bridge fendering system and light sustained damage. Preliminary reports determined two pilings of fendering system were snapped ($5K per piling to replace).  A navigation light was also destroyed ($100 to replace).

On 06JAN05, at 0557, a total of 16 barges broke free from their moorings at Cardinal Operating Company in Brilliant, OH. There were a total of eight loaded coal barges and eight unloaded coal barges. After breaking away  Cardinal Operating Company's tow vessel, the M/V Boonesboro attempted to recover the barges. Due to swift river conditions at the time, the M/V Boonesboro was only able to recover two of the loaded barge's and one empty barge. The other thirteen barges floated down where one loaded barge grounded itself into the river bank. Five empty and three loaded barges allided with the Pike Island Lock and Dam lodging themselves against the dam gates. Two empty barges and two loaded barges went over the Pike Island Lock and Dam. The four barges that went over the Lock and Dam floated downriver where one loaded and one empty barge allided with the I-70 bridge in Wheeling, WV. After colliding with the bridge all four remaining barges were recovered. The five barges that were still lodged against the Pike Island Lock and Dam were passed over the dam on 07JAN05 and recovered without further incident.

Receive report that while waiting for the Raritan River Rail Road to open, the master of the UTV MISS JEAN lost partial control of the tug and barge when the strong current and winds pushed the vessels making the light barge to allide with the fendering system.   No damages to the barge reported.  Bridge damages consisted of various broken timber wale.    

Data collection level of investigation conducted iaw msg dtg P 051545Z Oct 01 fm COMLANTAREA COGARD  PORTSMOUTH VA//AM//.

The bulker ATLANTIC SUPERIOR was transiting the Fore River inbound with a state compulsory pilot on board.  As the vessel approached the Casco Bay Bridge it was not properly lined up and went through the span toward the south bank.  The Tug Vickie McCallister attempted to push on the starboard side of the freight ship to push it away from the bridge, but was almost pinched between the ship and the bridge fender and allided with the bridge with no damage to either.  

The ship proceeded through the bridge but could not correct in time to avoid a collision with the dredge JAY CASHMAN and the attending tug AMERICAN CHAMPION.

19 Jan. 2005 at 0145 local time: While pushing ahead at MM 735 LMR the M/V ROBERT A. KNOKE's tow of 12 barges allided with HARAHAN R/R BRIDGE breaking away 6 barges. Please see Investigators notes located in correspondences.
