On 06Jan05, MSO Pittsburgh received a report of two barges that broke free from the McKee's Rocks Industrial Enterprises, Inc facility mooring and had lodged against the CSX Transportation Railroad bridge, located at mile marker 5.3 on the Ohio River causing extensive structural damage to the bridge and one of the barges.  MSO Pittsburgh dispatched a team for investigation.  During the investigation it was found that the barges had broken free during the night and were not noticed until the next mooring when personnel came into work.  There was a period of six hours that passed between the inspection of the barge fleeting area by facility personnel.  

No pollution or injuries occurred as a result of this casualty.

On 20Jan05 the UTV Zeus was transiting northbound on the Intercoastal Waterway Morgan City to Port Allen route with two barges when they allided with the Bayou Sorrel swing bridge. The Bayou Sorrel swing bridge was left out of service for seven days. There no further casualties as a result of this incident.
On 27 Jan 05, at approximately 0325, the UTV JOYCE HALE was traveling southbound on the Lower Mississippi River, and allided with the Vicksburge Hwy 20 Bridge at MM 435.8 LMR.

On January 29 at 1440, the M/V CECIL was northbound pushing two loaded (Vacuum Gas Oil or VGO) tank barges,  MMI 3026 and MMI 3027 at MM 88.2 Lower Mississippi River (LMR). In that same area the M/V BRIDGET CAULLEY was exiting Algiers Lock in the vicinity of MM 88.2 pushing six non-red flag barges scheduled to go northbound. Due to severe high water conditions, the stbd lead barge (VL 81249) in the BRIDGET CAULLEY tow collided with the lead barge (MMI 3027) in the CECIL's tow. The MMI 3027 sustained a 10" by 3" hole in portside bow rake knuckle, above the water line, estimated at appx. $8900. The uninspected VL 812249 sank at MM 88.2 LMR, was deemed a total constructive loss, & is slated for salvage.  Estimated cost of VL 812249 was appx. $1.2 million and $800,000 of alumina (cargo). No injuries or pollution reported. Sunken barge has been marked with a lighted buoy and poses no haz to navigation.

Received report that the M/V YM KAOHSIUNG had allided with the Bayonne Bridge in Kill Van Kull.   The allision occurred as the vessel was transiting under the bridge.  M/V YM KAOHSIUNG suffered damage to the top most masthead lights.  Damage to bridge reported as secondary span nav lights, on west side of bridge.  No additional damage reported.

Vessel's top most masthead light allided with the bottom of the Bayonne Bridge. Investigation revealed that vessel provided incorrect pilot card data to Pilot, who accepted the information as accurate, deemed the vessel safe to proceed under the Bayonne Bridge.  Bayonne Bridge clearance is noted at 151 ft.  Pilot calculations (although erroneous due to vessel pilot card), noted the vessel at 149 ft.  This calculation included 4 feet of actual tide observed at time of transit.

On 03 Feb 05, discussed investigation with Commissioner, New Jersey Maritime Pilot & Docking Pilot Commission.  Their investigation concurs with CG investigation, that pilot card information was incorrect.  They will be looking further into vessel particulars to ensure safe passage during future transits.

F/V outrigger fouled on bridge fendering system aiding in the capsizing of vessel.  Master of the F/V survived and his crewman drowned while trying to exit F/V.  Vessel recovered, total loss.
Medical Examiners report verifies cause of death as drowning.

M/V L. J. Sullivan was northbound on the Illinois river near MM 254 when the captain made a controlled landing with the Chessie Railroad Bridge (a.k.a. Seneca RR Bridge). Captain made contact with bridge protection cell with his vsl when he was to far to the left of the channel center and knew he would contact with the bridge and adjusted as much as he could to lessen the impact. No damages reported to bridge or vsl.

The M/V DEWEY R was Southbound on the Illinois River pushing three tank barges when the tank barge APEX 3506 allided with the stbd protection cell at the Florence Bridge at mile 58 ILR.  After the allison the APEX 3506 had fractures in the No. 5 and 6 voids causing voids to flood to river level.
M/V Chris Ann pushing CBC 2762 allided with the dolphin on the stbd side of the CSX RR Bridge.  No damage to the barge, tug or bridge dolphin, no injuries or pollution.

On 02Feb05 the UTV Hortense B. Ingram was pushing 24 barges on a southbound transit.  At approximately 1000 the ING 822 allided with the Interstate 20 Hwy Bridge in Vicksburg MS. Due to the allision the ING 822 sank and was a total loss, and several other barges sustained damage.

On 06 July 2004, the tug CAPT. HARDHEAD (290084) was towing the dredge CHARLESTON (1102692) astern when the dredge allided with the DICK MISENER BRIDGE.  The tow was transiting westward under the bridge in the Intracoastal Waterway (ICW) of Tampa Bay, Florida.  Two assist tugs, the tug NORFOLK (278099) and the tug PUSHER #10 (1079486), were positioned on the stern of the tow during the transit.

As the flotilla approached the bridge, the dredge CHARLESTON, which is 240' Long, started to drift to the southwest toward the southern fendering system.   After two warnings from the assist tug captain and the leverman aboard the dredge, the CAPT. HARDHEAD's master put the helm to starboard in an effort to avoid alliding with the bridge.  His efforts were not successful and the CHARLESTON struck and destroyed some forty feet (40') of fender system and damaged an additional twenty (20) feet of fender system.  The master of the tug CAPT. HARDHEAD was negligent in his poor planning and execution of the bridge transit.  The master further neglected his duty to direct his assist tugs as the tow started drifting towards the bridges fendering system.
On 29 Jan 05 at approx 0850 the tank barge (T/B) COASTAL 3309 L broke away from it's mooring and floated down river alliding with the west bank span of the Sunshine Bridge.

ON FEBRUARY 10, 2005, AT APPROXIMATELY 1730,  MASTER OF THE TOWING VESSEL LOU ANNA GUIDRY, NOTIFIED INTEGRATED COMMUNICATIONS CENTER MAYPORT THAT HIS VESSEL HAD ALLIDED WITH THE SISTERS CREEK BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM.

THE LOU ANNA GUIDRY (NO. 629888) IS AN UNISPECTED TOWING VESSEL AND IT WAS PUSHING AHEAD THE BARGE MOBRO 1600 (NO. 1047101) WITH A CRANE ON ITS DECK.  THE TUG AND BARGE WERE NORTHBOUND EN ROUTE TO THE LANIER BRIDGE IN BRUNSWICK, GA.

ON FEBRUARY 11, 2005, AT APPROXIMATELY 0800, AN INVESTIGATION TEAM FROM MSO JACKSONVILLE MET WITH THE TENDER OF THE SISTERS CREEK BRIDGE AND THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION DISTRICT BRIDGE TENDING MANAGER.  

THE BRIDGE TENDER, WHO HAD BEEN ON DUTY AT THE TIME OF THE ALLISION,  ADVISED THAT THE TUG AND BARGE HAD APPROACHED THE BRIDGE TO THE PORT SIDE OF THE CHANNEL WITHOUT SUFFICIENT WAY TO ADEQUATELY DEAL WITH THE INCOMING FLOOD TIDE AND WESTERLY CROSS WIND OF APPROXIMATLEY 10 MPH.  

THE PORT FORWARD QUARTER OF THE BARGE STRUCK THE WEST SIDE ENTRANCE OF THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM.  THE TUG AND BARGE CONTINUED DIAGONALLY ACROSS THE CHANNEL AND THE STARBOARD BOW OF THE BARGE STRUCK AND PENETRATED THE FENDERING SYSTEM ON THE EAST SIDE AND REMOVED FENDERS AND PILINGS FROM UNDER THE BRIDGE TO A POINT APPROXIMATELY THIRTY FEET NORTH OF THE BRIDGE.  APROXIMATELY FORTY FEET OF FENDER AND PILING MATERIAL WAS REMOVED AND APPROXIMATELY TWENTY ADDITIONAL FEET OF FENDER AND PILING MATERIAL WAS DAMAGED.

THE BRIDGE TENDER FURTHER STATED THAT HE HAS OBSERVED THAT MOST VESSEL MASTERS APPROACHING THE SISTERS CREEK BRIDGE ON A FLOOD TIDE LINE UP ON THE STARBOARD SIDE OF THE CHANNEL TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE CURRENT FLOW.  THE TIDE WAS AT MORNING FLOOD STATE AS THE INVESTIGATION TEAM WAS PRESENT AND THE BRIDGE TENDER WAS ABLE TO CLEARLY POINT OUT THE NEED FOR A VESSEL TO APPROACH FROM STARBOARD RATHER THAN THE PORT SIDE OF THE CHANNEL.

ON FEBRUARY 11, 2005, AT APPROXIMATELY 1545, A FORM CG-2692 WAS RECEIVED FROM MOBRO MARINE.  THE INFORMATION PROVIDED IN THE REPORT DID NOT MATERIALLY CONTRADICT THE BRIDGE TENDERS ACCOUNT OF THE EVENT.

THE DAMAGE TO THE FENDERING SYSTEM WAS ESTIMATED TO BE $150,000.00 BY THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION.

ON FEBRUARY 17, 2005, THE MASTER OF THE LOU ANNA GUIDRY AND A REPRESENTATIVE FROM MOBRO MARINE MET WITH THE ACID, SIO, AND IO.  DURING THE MEETING, THE MASTER INDICATED THAT THE VESSEL HAD SUSTAINED A STEERING CASUALTY PRIOR TO THE BEGINNING OF THE VOYAGE TO BRUNSWICK, GA.  THE MASTER INDICATED THE CASUALTY HAD BEEN SUFFICIENTLY CORRECTED FOR HIM TO GET UNDER WAY.

THE MASTER STATED THAT AS HE WAS APPROACHING THE SISTERS CREEK BRIDGE THE STEERING HAD AGAIN DEVELOPED A PROBLEM WHICH HE COULD NOT OVERCOME AND HE HAD STRUCK THE FENDERING SYSTEM OF THE BRIDGE ON THE PORT SIDE OF THE CHANNEL AND THEN STRUCK THE STARBOARD SIDE OF THE CHANNEL.

THE CAUSE OF THIS ALLISION WAS THE MASTERS NEGLIGENCE BY NOT HAVING THE VESSEL STEERING CASUALTY RESOLVED PRIOR TO GETTING UNDER WAY AND NOT TAKING INTO ACCOUNT THE EFFECTS OF THE FOLLOWING FLOOD TIDE AND TEN MPH WIND WHEN HE APPROACHED THE SISTERS CREEK BRIDGE.

ON FEBRUARY 17, 2005, HE MASTER AGREED TO A TWO MONTH SUSPENSION OF HIS MASTERS LICENSE WITH TWELVE MONTHS PROBATIONARY SUSPENSION AS PART OF A SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT.


//S//
MSTCS
INVESTIGATING OFFICER
MSO JACKSONVILLE

Rcvd rpt frm Chief Dispatcher NJ DOT, the TUG TRADE WIND SERVICE alongside the T/B ENERGY 6504 allided with the fender system of the south channel of the Raritian River Railroad Bridge at approx. 1410 while heading upbound the Raritan River.  An MI was dispatched and visual inspection revealed no apparent damage and no apparent leakage of cargo was observed.  Rub marks on the barge were consistent with the accounts provided by the crew.

No injuries or pollution reported.

Data collection level of investigation conducted iaw msg dtg P 051545Z Oct 01 fm Comlantarea Cogard Portsmouth Va//Am//.

The Captain of the UTV EXPRESS EXPLORER notified ACTNY SCC of an allision with the Whitt-Penn Bridge on the Hackensack River.  While downbound on the Hackensack River the UTV EXPRESS EXPLORER was pushing an empty coal barge, EMI 1151, when it allided with the bridge.  At the time of the incident the Tug Captain reported no damage to the barge and Bridge Operator reported no damage to the bridge.

THE T/V PASCAGOULA WAS EAST BOUND ON THE ICW AT APPROX MILE 191 EHL.  WHILE PASSING UNDER THE PENSACOLA BEACH HWY BRIDGE A STRONG N.E. WIND SUDDENLY BLEW.  THIS CAUSED THE BARGE SCF-2009B TO ALLIDE WITH THE FENDER WORKS OF THE BRIDGE AND BREAK LOOSE FROM THE TOW.  THE BARGE WENT SOFT AGROUND.  THE SCF-2009B WAS RECOVERED AND SECURED BACK IN THE TOW.  NO DAMAGE WAS REPORTED TO THE SCF-2009B OR THE FENDER WORKS.  THE VESSEL CONTINUED ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

Tug DIANE H w/barge MILLER 209 was made up w/bow of the barge to stern of the tug.  Tug/barge were transiting inbound up the Duwamish River.  Port spud of barge contacted north side of Spokane St. Bridge, mid-span, causing minor damage to bridge.   Tug & barge were traveling about 2 knots.  Master understood from Forman of the barge, a Canadian citizen, that he was going to lower the spuds.  The Forman does not recall this conversation & conversation can not be verified.   Master understood the clearance of the bridge, center span at mean low water, was 55 feet.  She was also clear the tide was on the ebb.   A deck hand on the tug was also monitoring the spuds & misjudged the height of port spud.  Master acknowledges she relied on the Forman to lower the spuds & deck hand to monitor clearance of the spuds.   Master acknowledges she did not specifically check spuds to confirm that they were both down nor did she verify actual spud height in relation to bridge clearance.  Master did not request a bridge opening.  Based on the current evidence, this matter is referred for enforcement. No other pertinent factors. See NARRATIVE in CORRESPONDENCE.

M/V BOB KOCH WAS SOUTH BOUND W/ 12 LOADS AND 1 EMPTY IN TOW. WHILE NAVIGATING BRIDGE NEAR MILE 151 IL R. PORT STRING BARGE ACBL 3228 CAME INTO CONTACT WITH LEFT DESCENDING PIER. NO DAMAGE TO BRIDGE WAS REPORTED

Received notification that the tug vessel JUNE K had allided with the Lincoln Highway Bridge.  While transiting underneath the bridge, the vessel's masthead impacted the bridge and snapped off.  No additional damage to vessel.  No damage to bridge reported.  Vessel's master had failed to lower mast upon approach to bridge.  No pollution or injuries.  Alcohol tests conducted.


Referring matter for enforcement.

On the 23rd of February 2005 at 10:00, the M/V ATLANTIS allied with the Ship's Channel Bridge, Somers Point, NJ.  The M/V ATLANTIS is a newly constructed vessel and was on an outbound transit to conduct sea trials.  The weather on-scene was gusty winds, 35 degrees, unlimited visibility, with a ebb current at 2 knots.  The vessel was issued a temporary COI on the 10 February 2005.  Previously the vessel was under construction at Yanks Marine, which is located along the Tuckahoe River, NJ. 

At the time of the incident the initial estimated cost of repairs was below $100,000 and no chemical testing took place.  Both the Coast Guard and NJ Marine Police boarded the vessel after the incident and found no evidence of the Master impaired by alcohol or drugs.

Notified on 24 February 2005 that the F/V ARABELLA was operating unsafely with a barge in tow.  Conducted a boarding.  The boarding officers found safety discrepancies for which the voyage could be terminated.   While the Investigating Officer and the boarding officers were still onboard, the operator misjudged the high tide current and allided with the Benicia Auto/Railroad Bridge.  The barge and the F/V were pinned against the bridge fendering system for two hours.  No damage, other than cosmetic, to the bridges or the vessels was reported.

See IO Narrative in correspondence for additional details.

The M/V Pat White was Southbound on the Illinois River near MM270.5 when the empty starboard stern barge GMH 204 rubbed the right descending pier of the EJ&E RR bridge. Barge was drafting 1'6" FWD and AFT. No damages reported to bridge or barge. Tow consisted of 9 barges, 3 empties and 6 loaded with steel coils. No report of injury or suspected drug or alcohol use reported. Company faxed 2692 and Captains License. Incident occurred after departing Dresden Lock and Dam. Captain stated 15 kt winds and 10' of water from the gate were factors in the allision.

3/8/2005- M/V APAC LEADER with 9 empty barges in tow, lost power to starboard MDE. See Correspondence. In the opinion of investigating officer the damage to MAC 618 as per CG-2692 was determined to be from a prior event, due to amount of water in #3 wing tank.

ON FEB 23, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 2030 HOURS THE M/V MARK C WAS PUSHING (6) EMPTY HOPPER BARGES ING2053, ING2056, ING1571, OR5465, OR4793 AND WG2135 SOUTH BOUND IN THE INTRA COASTAL WATERWAY WHEN A BEARING IN THE STEERING LINKAGE OF THE TUG FAILED, RESULTING IN REDUCED STEERING. THE HEAD BARGE ING1571 HIT THE NORTH FENDER SYSTEM OF THE GULF SHORES BRIDGE. NO DAMAGE TO THE BARGE WAS NOTED. TWO TIMBERS OF THE FENDER SYSTEM WERE DAMAGED. THE STEERING LINKAGE SYSTEM OF THE TUG WAS REPAIRED, AND THE TOW CONTINUED ON TO IT'S NEXT PORT OF CALL WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

ON FEB 16, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 1015 HOURS THE M/V TALLAPOOSA WAS PUSHING THE BARGE SJT 203 WHEN THE BARGE MADE CONTACT WITH THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM CAUSING DAMAGE. THE TUG AND TOW CONTINUED TO IT'S NEXT PORT OF CALL WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT. NO DAMAGE TO THE BARGE.
On 08 Mar 05 at approx 2215 the T/B WEB232 under the control of the UTV CHARLES E. MARTIN allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge.

AS PER THE CG-2692, WHILE PASSING THROUGH THE NAHEOLA BRIDGE THE CTC-0409 MADE CONTACT WITH THE EAST PIER.  THERE WAS NO REPORTED DAMAGE TO THE BARGE OR THE BRIDGE.  THE VESSEL CONTINUED ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

The Tug TJ Express was pushing a construction barge through the Sanibel Causway Bridge "A" span when a gust of wind pushed the tug/tow off course.  The tug subsequently brushed the fendering system.  The bridge tender and Lee County Officials reported no damage to the bridge or fendering system.  

CG STA FMB conducted a boarding on the tug.  The tug operator was cited for not having original documentation on board and not having vessel's name stenciled on PFDs.

The tug operator was operating the vessel in compliance with the RNA that is in place for the channel under the bridge.  

This investigation is complete.

On February 9, 2005, while attempting to transit outbound to sea, the M/V Majesty allided with the John's Pass Bridge.  At the time of the incident there was a 5 knot flood current (inbound through the pass).  The vessel was sliding toward the south fender as she was making her way through the pass.  Steering and full power was used to attempt to correct the slide.  Her port engine, at full power, tripped the electronic controls and power was momentarily lost to the port engine.  Power was restored and she maneuvered out of the pass.  Her port side allided with the south fender of John's Pass bridge.  No damage was reported to the vessel or fendering system reported.  Vessel was allowed to continue on her voyage.  These weather conditions are problematic for the vessel's transit and make her vulnerable to allision even under full power.

While transiting northbound on the Hackensack River under the Lincoln Highway Bridge, the upper mast of the TUG PENN No. 6 allided with the bridge, causing damage to the Tug's mast and flying bridge aft window.  Approx 20' of the mast snapped off while the bridge reported no damage. 
 
D1 Bridge Branch plans to take action against the bridge. 

Data collection level of investigation conducted iaw msg dtg P 051545Z Oct 01 from COMLANTAREA GOGARD Portsmouth Va//Am//.

Received notification via GRUOHV, M/V CAPT O. A. FRANKS w/ 6-empty dry-cargo barges allided with RR Bridge Mile Marker 190.4 Cumberland River.  No damages reported and no pollution associated with incident.  UMIB broadcast initiated.

Bridge inspector/s dispatched and have reported no structural damage to bridge.  UMIB cancelled.

MSD Investigating Officer and Pollution Investigator dispatched.  No damage.  Weather (wind) and vessel speed (9 mph) contributing factors.  

No further agency action.

On March 11, 2005 at approximately 1700 hours the M/V Int'l Navigator was in the vicinity of the Pascagoula CSX rail road bridge attempting to maneuver with one engine down. According to the master the vessel was enroute to Callie Marine for repairs.  After they cleared the bridge, the master attempted to moor when the current caught the vessel and pushed it down stream into the bridge. Fenders were put out to protect the vessel and the bridge from damage. The vessel sustained minor rail damage on the starboard side of the vessel. The M/V Int'l Navigator was towed into a slip by another unidentified tow vessel.

NJ DOT reported an allision with the Raritan River Draw Bridge and the tug CARIBE SERVICE and T/B ENERGY 6504.  The barge was fully loaded with 60,000 barrels of gasoline.  While heading into the River, the ebb current set the starboard bow of barge down on the bridge fendering system. The bridge is operational and sustained only minor damage to the fendering system. No damage to barge.

2015 hrs 04 March 2005:  DDO Myrtle Beach MCI notified by DNR and STA Georgetown of a barge/dredge/tug tandem blocking the navigable channel IVO Barefoot landing.  MCI identified and contacted vessels' owner, vessel's moorings failed and drifted into channel.  Owner reps arrived on scene and tried to move vessel but could not due to low water.  Vessels were eventually repositioned out of the channel and later departed the area.

The dredge barge Captain A. J. Fournier allided with the Southeast dolphin of the Casco Bay bridge fendering system.  The barge was in along side tow with the Tug Captain Gary while transiting inbound Portland Hbr.  Excessive winds caused the barge to be set into the Casco Bay bridge fenderng system. No damage to the barge or tug.  No personnel injuries.  Minimal damage to fendering system.  Bridge fully operational.

On March 29, 2005 at 2340 during outbound transit with the empty sand scow, the starboard bow of the barge rubbed against the south fendering system of the Raritan Railroad Bridge. While straightening the tow to pass through the draw, the port bow of barge struck the inner fendering of the bridge. 

No damage to the barge. At least two fendering beams on the inner draw were cracked.  The bridge inspector attended the bridge and reported a ten-foot beam was sticking out into the channel, therefore no water traffic would be allowed.

Received notification from Foss Maritime reporting that their TG SHELLEY FOSS was pushing the Crowley owned FTB 411 when it allided with the western portion of the sheer wall surrounding the 1st avenue south bridge, Seattle, Washington.  Tug operator states in his 2692 that there was a current (3kt EBB) at the time of this un-intended allision which caused the barge's port quarter to slightly impact the sheer wall.  Both the Tug operator & Bridge operator confirmed there was no damage.

Based on current evidence, no enforcement activity is contemplated at this time.

BN/SF RR Bridge sustained damages to the bridge pier protection sheer wall located on the western side of the bridge.  Damages due to contact by the (Canadian) Freight Barge (loaded with rock) SEASPAN 250 in tow of the TUG BARBARA FOSS, assisted by the TUG EMMA FOSS.  Vessels were making 3kts at the time the barge touched down against this sheer wall.   Both TUG crews were  immediately drug tested.  The initial sheer wall damage estimates (2692's) indicated damage at zero dollars.  Incident occurred at 0115 at which time there appeared to be no visual damage.  It was not discovered that the sheer wall had actually been damaged/shifted (approximately 6'0") to the west until 18MAR05 by Patrick & Associates, Inc Marine Surveyors.  This $195,000 estimate was not forwarded to the CG until 05APR05.    

Based on current evidence, no enforcement activity is contemplated at this time.

On 30MAR05 at 1845 the down bound tow M/V Amber Brittany ran into the I-65 (Big Four R.R.) Bridge at OHRM 602.9 and Clark Memorial Bridge OHRM 603.7 due to a combination of wind, current, and Captains negligence. M/V Amber Brittany was pushing 8 total red flag barges. Duty team conducted an inspection of the barges for damage. No damage other than paint scraping.
Passenger vessel lost control and impacted two other recreational vessels moored in the vicinity.  The vessel later allided with a nearby bridge.  No damage done to the bridge.

M/V Joyce Hale with a 15 barge tow grounded between the R/R and highway bridges in Beardstown, IL (approximately 88.5 on Illinois River) and on the channel side of the right descending bank buoy line.  Prior to the incident reports had been made concerning shoaling in area by both ACOE and USCG.  Several barges in tow were loaded over 10 feet.  Master of Joyce Hale, with two assist tow boats, broke tow and proceeded down bound with 9 barges.  Directly under the highway bridge, the tow grounded again and the tow topped toward the left descending bank and allided with the left descending, main channel, bridge pier, holing the barge that contacted the bridge pier.  No other damage or groundings occurred.

On 05Apr05 the UTV Harry Brindle was pushing 6 loads of dry cargo through the Bayou Sorrell floating bridge. While transiting the through the brige the UTV Harry Brindle caught the bridge cable, pulling it loose from the reel. The bridge was stuck in the open position until repairs could be made.

On April 5th, 2005 at approximately 0840 the M/T CARIAD departed the Citgo Braintree Terminal. At approximately 0858 the M/T CARIAD was transiting the Weymouth Fore River outbound underneath the Weymouth Fore River Bridge. The Tug LIBERTY was made up at the M/Ts port bow quarter during the transit and the Tug FREEDOM was made up on the starboard stern quarter.  As the three vessels progressed underneath the bridge the Tug LIBERTY made contact with the Quincy side fendering system for a distance of approximately 55 feet.  No initial report was received from the master of the tug. Bridge tenders on the Weymouth Fore River Bridge witnessing the allision notified the Sector Boston Command Center at approximately 0929. There was no apparent damage to the Tug LIBERTY or the M/T CARIAD.

See IO Summary in Correspondence for additional details.

Recommend Enforcement Referral for failure to report Marine Casualty.

On or about 1500 on April 6, 2005, the UTV HANNAH C SETTOON (N.O. 588739) w/ the one empty barge, the BBTC 101 (N.O. 528197), owned and operated by Settoon Towing of Pierre Part LA, allided with the BNSF Railroad Bridge in Amelia, LA. 

$40000 damage to bridge.
No damage to the UTV or barge.
No pollution.  
No injuries.
See correspondence.

UTV ROBERT T was pushing six deck barges, including two spud barges, westbound in the GICWW.  While transiting under the Ellender Lift Bridge near Hackberry, LA, fwd spud tower on barge L-1031 struck horizontal span of bridge mid-channel, resulting in minor damage to bridge.

Enforcement action recommended.

This incident is a reportable marine casualty iaw 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1).  IAW G-MOA Policy Ltr 2-02, the investigation of this reportable marine casualty has been conducted as a data collection activity.

M/V Harry Waddington, pushing 16 loaded barges struck the ICG Railroad Bridge on the Ohio River, near Cairo, Illinois.  M/V Harry Waddington was holed as the result of striking a bridge pier, and it's tow set adrift.  Drifting barges from the tow contacted barges moored in the Louisiana Dock Company #1 and #2 mooring fleet.  Barge MEM 5067 sunk as a result of the casualty.

On 10APR05, at approximately 1930, Marine Safety Office (MSO)  Pittsburgh received a report from USCG Group Ohio Valley that four to five barges broke free from their moorings at an unknown fleeting facility in the vicinity of mile marker 14 - 16 on the Ohio River.  

See Investigators report attached in correspondence tab.

While transiting eastbound on the GIWW, the UTV BAYOU BLACK allided with the BAYOU BLUE bridge, causing the bridge to be shut down from 03/25/2005 to 04/29/2005.  The UTV BAYOU BLACK was pushing six open hopper barges. See Correspondence.

UTV pushing 1 barge, partially loaded w/ diesel fuel, traveling west bound in Galveston Channel.  As UTV maneuvered through PELICAN ISLAND BRIDGE, master misjudged effects of wind and/or current.  Tow landed on fendering system, pushing over pilings, breaking walers, and dislodging catwalk.  Barge received paint scrapes.  No pollution, or release of chemical.

On 09 APR 2005 while outbound in John's Pass, a navigable waterway of the U.S., the M/V FRIENDSHIP IV allided with the John's Pass bridge.  The master took evasive action to avoid a small recreational vessel traveling inbound.  The FRIENDSHIP IV struck the southern fender system with its starboard pontoon and bow.  The allision caused damage to the fender and to the hull of the vessel.  The master took the vessel out of the pass and assessments were made as to the seaworthiness of the vessel.  The master determined there was no significant damage done and continued outbound with the passengers.

The decision to continue underway following an allision with a bridge and a damaged vessel demonstrated negligence on the part of both licensed captains on board.  Discussion between the two masters resulted in an agreement between the two that they should continue underway and not return to the dock.  This decision put the lives of the crewmembers and the passengers at risk.  Although the crew conducted a preliminary assessment of the vessel, they were not able to assess the full extent of the damage adequately from the deck and the void spaces.  Furthermore, the damage was extensive enough that CG inspectors required the vessel undergo repairs before they could continue operating the vessel.  Both mariners were issued a Letter of Warning for negligent endangerment of the passengers by deciding to continue underway after sustaining damage to the vessel.

M/V River Beaver had loss of propulsion and allided with Aberdeen Rd. Bridge in Maysville, KY.  A subsequent inspection was conducted and various discrepancies were found.

Please see case #226583 for more information on EXCELL MARINE and the M/V RIVER BEAVER.

On 07Apr05 the UTV John C. Terral was pushing 6 barges on a southbound transit on the Atchafalaya River. While transiting throught he Melville Railroad bridge the lead barge allided with the center span. There was no damage to the bridge, barge, or vessel.

On March 1, 2005 at approximately 1910, the M/V Majesty's port beam/quarter allided with the southern portion of the John's Pass bridge fendering system.  There was no reported damage to the vessel or fendering system.  The winds were 14-16knots out of the northwest and there was an ebbing current of approximately 2knots in a westerly direction.  The winds and current caused the vessel to be set to the South and allide with the fendering system.  The master took appropriate measures to attempt to counter the prevailing conditions, but the vessel's beam in relation to the pass and its power plant was insufficient to overcome the forces acting on the vessel.

A Cape May County Bridge Tender telephoned the USCG that the Barge SMITH 52, pushed by the M/V SAM M, struck one of the fendering systems for the Grassy Sound Toll Bridge located in the Grassy Sound Channel near the Hereford Inlet, Wildwood, NJ. Station Cape May Responded and performed a 4100 boarding of the tug M/V SAM M. The Master was unaware of the reason for the Boarding. During the course of the boarding one of the mates of the M/V SAM M informed the boarding team that they had lost the starboard engine and that caused the barge to strike the bridge. Station Cape May performed an alcohol test of the Master.

The owner operator of the Tug Company has performed drug and alcohol tests of the crew of the M/V SAM M.

On March 7, 2005, the M/V MAJESTY allided with the John's Pass bridge fendering system.  She was transiting outbound the pass for gaming operations with 73 passengers and 41 employees.  The wind was blowing from the South at approximately 10-15 knots.  The tide was flooding and current speed (running inbound approximately parallel to the fendering system) was estimated at 5 knots.  The vessel only has enough power to make 8-9 knots under good conditions.  The wind and current condition in the pass created a situation in which the master was unable to use her inadequate power to overcome the forces acting on the M/V MAJESTY.  The master attempted to "wiggle through the pass," but the port quarter of the vessel allided with the fender system after several evasive tactics were attempted.  Subsequent to the allision, a new company policy was drafted that incorporated operating parameters (including weather conditions).

AS PER THE CG-2692 THE M/V MARY CLAIRE WAS SOUTH BOUND ON THE TENNESSEE TOMBIGBEE WATERWAY.  WHILE TRANSITING UNDER THE NAHOELA BRIDGE THE TOW MADE CONTACT WITH THE EASTERN FENDER WORKS.  THERE WAS A 3" INSET MADE TO THE CA 514 AND NO REPORTED DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE.  THE VESSEL CONTINUED ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

THE M/V HELOISE WAS SOUTH BOUND ON THE BLACK WARRIOR- TOMBIGBEE WATERWAY PUSHING 8 LOADED HOPPER BARGES.  WHEN PASSING UNDER THE JACKSON RAILROAD BRIDGE, AT MM 90, THE TOW MADE CONTACT WITH THE WESTERN FENDERING SYSTEM.  THERE WAS NO REPORTED DAMAGE TO THE TOW OR THE FENDERING SYSTEM.  THE VESSEL CONTINUED ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

Master of the tug Buchanan III, contacted the VTS and stated that around 2300 on 22 APR he was towing 2 barges (Richmond and #52) in Jamaica Bay.  As his tug approached the Marine Parkway Lift Bridge the captain stated that he lost his radar and bearing on the bridge.  With increased winds and current the stone barge Richmond swung and alided with the bridge fendering.   The allision caused a hole in the port rake of the barge and damaging the fendering system of the bridge.

While inbound to Johns Pass, the M/V FRIENDSHIP IV allided with the Johns Pass Bridge fender system.  There was a strong flood current (following) through the pass at the time of the allision.  As the vessel entered the pass, the current set the port quarter towards the NW fendering system.  The requirements for transit through Johns Pass are documented in the company's transit procedures.  The master of the vessel failed to follow those procedures by not accurately assessing the tidal currents prior to the transit through the pass.

The FRIENDSHIP IV had poly balls along both sides of the hull.  Contact occurred between one of the poly balls and a section of the bridge's fender system.  The poly ball absorbed the force of the impact and a survey of the vessel and the bridge did not reveal any damage (see activity#: 2342046).

The Master of the FRIENDSHIP IV was navigating inbound to John's Pass at approximately 2247 on April 23, 2005, when the vessel allided with the John's Pass Bridge fendering system.  This was the second such incident in two days.  The current at the time of the incident was a max flood and there was a 25 knot wind out of the West.  The port beam of the vessel struck the north fender and caused some weld cracking in its aluminum hull.  There was no reported damage to the fender system and no resultant injuries to the 147 passengers and 6 total crew.  Vessel was required to conduct weld repairs and create company transit plan for transits through the pass. 
A full moon coincided with higher than normal tides and currents during this period.  This coupled with strong wind gusts contributed to the allision.  In addition, the master did not use all available means at his disposal to plan for and safely navigate the pass.

On April 11, 2004 at approximately 2:40 a.m., the tug BUCHANAN 3 was pushing ahead two loaded scows in the Norwalk River when the lead barge, the B 109, allided with the fendering system of the Metro-North Railroad bridge.  The tug/barges were traveling upriver with a flood current; the draft of the tug was 7.2 feet; the draft of the scows was 8 feet forward and aft.  The complete length of the tow was 303 feet with a width of 38 feet.  There was no damage to the tug or barges.  An Inspector with Metro-North Railroad inspected the damage to the bridge and determined only the fendering system was damaged; there was no damage to the brick structure of the bridge.  Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was conducted.

See Correspondence #34254 for Investigating Officer's narrative report.

The UTV Oscar Walter was pushing two equipment barges southbound on the Atchafalaya River when the lead barge allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge.  The barge PINE BLUFF 0612 was damaged.  The bridge was not damaged.

ON 09 APRIL, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 0040 HOURS THE M/V CADDO WAS ASSISTING THE M/V RITA IN PUSHING 7 EMPTY HOPPER BARGES (JG1103, SCF131, CG5005, CG677, CG758, CG5020, CG08, CGE12, LGD206) ON THE TOMBIGBEE RIVER IN THE AREA OF MILE MARKER 173 (NAHEOLA BRIDGE). THE CADDO WAS AT THE HEAD OF THE TOW AND THE RITA WAS AT THE REAR WHEN THE TOW GOT CAUGHT IN A CROSS CURRENT CAUSING THE TOW TO BRUSH AGAINST THE FENDERING SYSTEM. THE CG5005 AND JG1103 MADE CONTACT WITH THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM AS THE TOW PASSED UNDER THE BRIDGE. NONE OF THE BARGES SUSTAINED DAMAGE AS A RESULT OF THIS INCIDENT. THE BRIDGE DID NOT SUSTAIN DAMAGE TO THE FENDERING SYSTEM. THE TOW CONTINUED ON TO THE NEXT PORT OF CALL WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

The M/V Piachi was at Beelman Dock, UMR mm 182.7, and shifting 2 loaded open hopper barges (WGN9708 and WGN350) to the dock when the air control shifter valve on the port marine gear failed in forward.  The Master steered the tow using the starboard engine gear into the current which turned the tow away from the McKinley Bridge, UMR mm 182.5.  The stern of the Piachi brushed the east pillar of the bridge breaking one winch rope and a barge coupling wire.  The 101 valve was repaired and voyage resumed.
On 02 May 2005 at approximately 0300, While down bound on the Susquehanna River near Havre De Grace, MD, a tug with barge engaged in pushing gear allided with an abandoned bridge abutment.

Hornbeck Towing dispatcher reported UTV LIBERTY SERVICE w/light barge ENERGY 7002 alongside allided w/the south side of center span of the Raritan River railroad bridge.  No damage to the tug or barge.   Bridge suffered some damages (still waiting on the official report).  During interview master stated that there was not enough room for the barge and UTV (hip configuration) to maneuver.  Company considering different options for when transferring through the Raritan Railroad bridge, including the use of a smaller UTV.

On 23APR05 the vessel Caitlin (Easy Street) was pushing six rock barges westbound at mile marker 289 on the Intracoastal Waterway when the vessel's head barge (OR 5557) struck the timbers on the Northeast portion of the West Port Arthur Bridge. The Captain of the vessel determined that the reason the vessel hit the timbers was due to a strong current pushing on the stern of the vessel while setting up to make the turn to go underneath the bridge. 

IAW message P131525Z NOV 01 CGDEIGHT NEW ORLEANS LA//M// para 3, (M) and G-MOA Policy Letter 2-02, the marine casualty investigation of the subject case has been conducted as a data collection level of investigation.

On 07MAY05, M/V Alice allided with the Spottsville R/R bridge at mile marker 8 on the Green River.  There was no damage to the bridge, but a barge, Crounse 782, was damaged.  There was a small fracture on the port stern.  The void was pumped out, and the fracture was shingled.  The barge was dropped off at Ohio Valley Marine, then sent to Cattletsburg, KY for permanent repairs.

On May 15, 2005 at 1000 the fishing vessel CECILIA was southbound heading toward the Chef Menteur Bridge and experienced a main engine failure and subsequently allided with the Chef Menteur Bridge. No pollution or injuries reported.  The Chef Menteur Bridge sustained minimal damage. The F/V CECILIA sustained minor damage to the rigging. Apparent cause of the main engine failure was a faulty throttle cable.

Tug ISLAND BOY (525429) pushing BARGE SJ170 allided with Lafayette Bridge in Georgetown, SC ooa 0715.  Master had 0-1/8 mile visibility due to morning fog conditions.   Master was sailing out of Sampit River in AICW when he observed the tow was not properly aligned with bridge fendering system.  The Master attempted to correct misalignment by turning to port, but the barge struck the southern bridge support fendering on it's starboard stern.  The force of the impact forced the tow to strike the northern bridge support fendering with the port side of the barge and tow boat, esstentially destroying the northern support's fendering system.  The barge and tow boat suffered minimal superficial damage.  The South Carolina Dept of Transportation gave an initial estimate of damages to the bridge fendering system of $200,000.00.

05/13/2005 - Received call from the UTV Grand Knight reporting its allision with the HWY 182 bridge. UTV was pushing the construction barge BT-803, which was equipped with a large A-frame. The vessel was pushing the barge north bound on the Port Allen Route of the Atchafalaya River. Captain of the UTV did not use his assets to ensure proper clearance between the A-frame and the bridge prior to proceeding. The A-frame made contact with the bridge and caused damage to the rail system as well as the pedestrian walkway. The bridge was closed until an inspection could be conducted by Louisiana D.O.T. 

No damage was reported to the UTV or barge. Minor damage reported to the bridge.

Enforcement activity spawned from this Investigation.

Drug and Alcohol tests conducted on the UTV crew. Tests were not required, but conducted at the company's discretion.

The UTV BEVERLY G. BARROIS pushing two empty tank barges ran aground at red can bend.  The strong current and wind pushed the vessels off aground.  As the master was attempting to regain control of the flotilla, the  vessel T/B KIRBY28067 allided with the Galveston Causeway Bridge causing damage to the barge and concrete piling of the bridge.  Coast Guard ordered drug testing of crew.

Tow was southbound.  Wind and cross current set tow over on the upper ice breaker of shear fence on left descending span of the Crescent Railroad Bridge.  Bridge tender reported no damage.  ACO-125 damage consisted of a leak in #4 & #5 wing tanks port side.  Wing tanks were pumped & shingled.

On April 12, 2006, the M/V J. W. Hershey was southbound with 5 barges in tow.  While navigating railroad bridge near mile 518 UMR in high water and strong current, tow was set to starboard when starboard stern barge PV 5999 came in contact with bridge pier.  No damage to pier reported.

The M/V HARVEY SBISA was pushing the barge FMT 3134 under the CSX Chicksaw railroad bridge when the starboard stern of the tug made contact with the fender works of the bridge. The resulting damage was limited to a cracked timber in the fender works of the bridge. The vessel and tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

Came into bridge running slow when vessel started sliding to the starboard side. Operator started backing down and stopped to lay on the north wall of the bridge. Operator picked up the tow and cleared the bridge.

On 31 May 2005, while outbound through John's Pass, the passenger vessel FLORIDA FISHERMAN II's (D953498) port bow struck the John's Pass Bridge's southern fendering system.  The allision knocked approximately 15' of catwalk boards loose from the fender.  The master of the vessel was unaware of the tidal currents, claiming there was an ebb tide when in fact there was a flood tide.  He allowed the vessel to set towards the southern fender and when he attempted to perform evasive maneuvers, the starboard engine shut down unexpectedly.  There was minor paint scuffing on the vessel's hull.
MASTER REPORTED SHIFTER VALVE FAILED AND STEERED TOW WITH STARBOARD ENGINE AWAY FROM BRIDGE, BUT STERN ALLIDED EAST PILLAR. ONE WINCH ROPE AND BARGE COUPLING WIRE BROKE.

2 Jun 05 @ 2010L- The CFV DEL-ANN was mooring near the Chincoteague Swing Bridge in Chincoteague, Virginia after a scalloping trip.   As the vessel approached its berth a mate threw a bow spring line onto the pier; however, the line parted and the vessel drifted into the Chincoteague Bridge.  The outriggers allided with the upper portion of the bridge and a telephone pole.  Station Chincoteague was notified at 2030L and responded.  The boat crew verified that the outriggers allided with the bridge.  The boat crew conducted alcohol testing on the crew of the DEL-ANN.  The vessel maneuvered away from the bridge and made fast to the dock nearby.  The VDOT bridge tender reported there was no damage to the bridge.

On 4 June 2005 at 1030, UTV SARAH GRACE was exiting the Industrial Locks, MM1 ICWE with barge HUNT OIL CEMENT BARGE 1.  The contact tower on the barge allided with the Claiborne Bridge.  No injuries reported.  The bridge sustained no damage.  Estimated damage to the barge was $75,000.  The master estimated a 1/2 cup to 1 cup of diesel fuel was discharged into the water. Apparent cause of the allision was misjudgment by the master as to bridge clearance.  Company surveyor estimated the damage to be $100,000 after the time frame for drug and alcohol testing.
M/V GEORGE KING allided with  river mooring cells due to a pleasure craft being anchored near the cells.

10 Jun 05 @0300L - The SPV KALMAR NYCKEL was proceeding inbound to the Port of Hampton Roads under sail.  At 0326L the vessel passed Thimble Shoal Channel Lighted Buoy "8" (LLNR 9240) on the port beam, with inbound and outbound vessels in the traffic separation lanes.  The vessel was sailing north of the auxiliary channel.  As the vessel approached the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel it was being set toward the tunnel's man-made island by the ebb current.  At approximately 0335L the vessel grounded on the island rip-rap for 20 minutes.  The master used astern propulsion to back off the rocks.  The master notified the Coast Guard at 0400L.  The vessel's worm shoe was damaged from the bow to the rudder and the rudder was splintered.  The damage did not affect the vessel's maneuverability.  There was no pollution or injuries.

On 03 May 2005, while inbound through Johns Pass, the passenger vessel PATRIOT (1131648) was set towards and allided with the northern fender of Johns Pass Bridge by an ebb tide.  The allision was minor and no damage was sustained by either the vessel nor the bridge fendering system.

This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M) of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.

14JUL05 - The CFV HIGH NOON was casting off from Chincoteague Town Pier with only one main diesel engine operational.  The steering gear failed, leaving the operator with only one engine and no steering, drifting with the current toward the Chincoteague Swing Bridge.  The HIGH NOON subsequently allided with the bridge, which was undamaged.  The CFV EAGLE towed the HIGH NOON off the bridge and assisted in mooring at the Chincoteague Town Pier.  The operator made repairs to the steering gear, which were inspected by CG Station Chinocteague and found to be satisfactory.

On 6/8/2005 while navigating SB MM 838 LMR a strong out draft set the vessel to starboard. The tow allided the I-155 bridge causing the entire tow of 40 barges to breakaway and subsequent groundings. ACBL 1365 loaded with scrap metal sank in channel.

Salvage company Budwine & Associates began salvage operations immediately.

This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M) of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.

19 Jun 05@ 2000L - The UTV BUCHANAN 11 was northbound on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River in the vicinity of the Gilmerton Highway Bridge, pushing ahead two empty deck barges, made up one behind the other.  Just after 2000L the tug passed from the lee of several buildings, about 100 yards before the bridge.  The easterly winds, gusting to 20 knots, pushed the two barges to the west.  At 2015L the mate turned to starboard in an attempt to lay the barges flat alongside the fender system.  After initial contact with the fender system he put the rudder hard left to put the bow of the tow into a left turn through the bridge.  At this time the port bow of barge BUCHANAN #201, the second barge in the tow, allided with the corner of the fender system, causing a hole of 18 inches by 5 inches in the bow rake, above the waterline.
M/V DENNIS COLLINS pushing barge EIDC-54 allided with Black Bayou pontoon bridge causing minimal damage to bridge or barge.

On or about 0415 on June 20, 2005, the UTV TAKO INVADER (574379), owned and operated by Tako Marine Towing of Harvey LA, was eastbound on the ICW pushing six salt barges when the lead barge AB 135 allided with the Highway 24 Bridge bulkhead located in Houma, LA, following the loss of the main steering and while the Mate was switching the steering to the backup system. 

$40,000 damage to Barge AB 135.
$225,000 damage to bulkhead.
No pollution.  
No injuries.
See correspondence.

On June 8, 2005 at approximately 1:20 p.m., the tug MISTER T (official number 1121020), was outbound in the Norwalk River, towing astern two empty scows when the port bow of the first scow allided with the center fender system of the west passage of the Metro-North Norwalk River Railroad Bridge (Walk Bridge), causing damage to the fender system and no damage to the scow or tow line.  The damage sustained to the center pier did not effect the opening or closing of the bridge.  The Mate of the tug was on the helm and was not aware the scow had allided with the fender until the bridge operator raised him on the VHF radio.  The Mate immediately notified the CG.

24JUN05: The RUDEE WHALER, a 65-foot, fiberglass small passenger vessel, departed its slip in Rudee Inlet, Virginia Beach, VA, carrying 54 passengers on an excursion cruise.  The operator was using the rudder and engines to maneuver in close quarters with other vessels.  He reversed the engines to allow a pontoon boat to cross the bow as the RUDEE WHALER entered the channel.  The port engine stalled and the RUDEE WHALER drifted into the north side fender system of the Rudee Inlet Bridge at approximately one knot.  There were no injuries, no pollution, and no damage to the bridge or the vessel.

25JUN05:  CG inspectors attended the vessel and inspected and tested the engines, with no deficiencies noted.

ON 22JUN05 AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 THE CANADIAN S/V MARALGA'S FORWARD MAST ALLIDED WITH THE HIGH RISE BRIDGE (ROUTE 55) IN ORIENTAL, NC.  THE VESSEL WAS HEADING NORTH ON THE ICW AND THE MASTER MADE A WRONG TURN WHEN THE ICW CROSSED THE NEUSE RIVER.  THE MASTER WAS UNDER THE ASSUMPTION THAT ALL BRIDGE CROSSINGS ON THE ICW ARE 65 FEET OR GREATER.  SO WHEN HE APPROACHED THE BRIDGE IN ORIENTAL, THE MASTER DID NOT CONFIRM THE CLEARANCE HEIGHT.  THE VESSEL'S MASTS ARE APPROMIMATELY 55 FEET ABOVE THE WATER LINE AND THE HIGH RISE BRIDGE WAS ONLY 45 FEET ABOVE THE WATERLINE.

On 30May05 at 1940 M/V Pat White was southbound on the Illinois River at mm 270.5 awaiting northbound lock traffic.  Head of tow on M/V pat White set over to far and port lead barge GMH 203 hit left descending upper protection cell of EJ&E RR bridge.  Port bow corner of barge GMH 203 sustained 2 cracks 18" long on head loge near rake end above waterline.  No damage to bridge protection cell reported.

ON MAY 5, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 1620 HOURS THE M/V TAHOME WAS EAST BOUND IN THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY WITH 4 EMPTY HOPPER BARGES AND A DECK BARGE WITH A CRANE ON IT. AT MILE MARKER 189 THE WIND BLEW THE DECK BARGE (RM 735) AGAINST THE NORTH FENDERING SYSTEM OF THE PENSACOLA BRIDGE. NO DAMAGE WAS SUSTAINED TO EITHER THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM OR THE BARGE AS A RESULT OF THIS ALLISION. THE TOW CONTINUED ON ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

On 29 June 2005, the tug JENNY allided with Longboat Pass Bridge while outbound through Longboat Pass.  The allision damaged approximately 10' of the south east fendering system.  The tug captain misjudged the currents, believing there was an slight flood current of 0.25 knots when there was a slight ebb current of the same speed.

26JUN05: A work barge broke free from the LADY ANNA, now named the CAPTAIN ED.  The work barge had dredge pipe on it's deck and the pipe allided with the guide walls of the Brooks Bridge.  The waterway was Santa Rosa Sound, a navigable waterway of the U.S.  CG Station Destin responded to find no damage to the bridge guide walls, and the tug pulled the barge back together and began to make way again.

On 22 June 2005, while inbound through Johns Pass, the passenger vessel FRIENDSHIP IV (1020565) allided with the northern fendering system of Johns Pass Bridge.  The vessel was running with a flood current of approximately 4 knots.  As the vessel began to set towards the north fender, the master cut the throttle and allided with minimal speed.  The allision did not cause any damage to either the vessel or bridge fendering system.

On 30Jun05 at 0445 M/V T.E. Ragsdale was transiting underneath the CSX RR bridge with empty barge VL 81218 when stern coaming of barge lodged under bridge due to coaming height.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

Found most damage was old but did cause some additional damage to the bridge including bending small stiffeners and sheering 2 bolts.  Bridge officials inspected the bridge and found it was sound.
Received notification that the UPV EMPIRE STATE had allided with the Madison Avenue Bridge.  Vessel broke its telescopic radar mount.  No damage to the bridge.  No injuries or pollution.

T/V SAM M. called to report that while pushing the Barge SC-152 the struck the Grassy Sound Toll Bridge (also known as the Ocean Drive Bridge)  with the barge. The mate / Relief Captain was operating the SAM M. at the time. According to the Mate's written statement, the barge entered between the fendering systems of the bridge. When he did so, the port side of the barge struck the fendering system and bounced off causing the starboard side of the barge to strike the opposite fendering system. The strike to the opposite fending system caused the fender to tear and allowed the barge to scrape along the concrete portion of the bridge. The mate further provides a drawing of the area in order to depict the incident. The Mate further states that there was an assist boat present, however, further questioning discovered that the assist boat was not tied fast to the barge because the Mate did not feel it was necessary.

This is not the first strike to this bridge by a barge being pushed with the SAM M. Waterways Management is addressing the situation along with the Bridge Commission. Damage estimates for this incident are over $100,000.00

Due to the Mate's actions in this incident it is referred for enforcement.

On 23JUN05 at approximately 0530, the M/V Kay Templeton allided with the rub rail on the Spottsville Railroad bridge at Green River Mile 8.9.  The M/V was transiting southbound with 4 loaded coal barges There was no damage to tow, barges or bridge, no pollution and no other casualties.

CAYAH MICHELE, official number 1093860, allided with the moored recreational vessel MEANDER while proceeding outbound in the Mianus River and waiting for the opening of the Cos Cob rail road bridge.  Winds and currents set the starboard stern onto the vessel MEANDER whcih was tied to the end of a t-dock at Palmer's Point Marina.  The MEANDER was not encroaching on the navigable channel.  The Master of the CAYAH MICHELE was a new hire; this was his first time operating the vessel in Cos Cob.  The CAYAH MICHELE was not damaged; the MEANDERER was damaged by the impact and required repairs to the hull and internal structure.

On 14May05 at 0920 M/V Lexington was southbound on the Illinois River near mm 288 with 15 barges in tow.  While navigating Cass St. Bridge with the assistance of a helper boat port string barge ACL 1716 rubbed bridge pier.  No damage reported to barge or M/V Lexington.  No damage reported to bridge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 09-JUL-05 while traveling in the New Jersey ICW the F/V WHITE DOVE TOO reported that they struck the 2 mile Bridge in Cape May, NJ with their port side outrigger. The outrigger broke, causing damage to other equipment on the vessel. Both NJ State Police and Station Cape May responded. NJ State Police boarded the vessel.

Investigation found that the vessel was outbound at the time of the incident. The vessel travels through this area each time she sails. In order to proceed out to sea the vessel needs to pass under the bridge. The vessel's outrigger were stowed properly at the time of the incident. The outrigger cleared the first "i" beam of the bridge and then struck the second (seaward side) "i" beam. This broke the outrigger causing the cable and diver to fall; breaking equipment as it went. The Master contacted the bridge tender via radio and advised him of the incident. He further requested that he Leave the bridge open so that the vessel could return to their peir. They returned through the bridge without any further incident.

None of the damage effects the seaworthiness of the vessel.

2426539 - Barge towed behind swung hard to port in a latent unseen cross-current generated at floating bridge's open drawspan, and stern of barge GC 40 bumped the bridge resulting in a minor cosmetic dent.  The incident is a reportable marine casualty because the allision with the bridge was not intended.  Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.

7/15/05: Tugs HEIDI and JOSEPH A were towing SARA EXPRESS up the MIAMI RIVER, through the 5th Street Bridge when she allided with the North span of the bridge and damaged her starboard bridge wing extensively.

Vessel CAYAH MICHELE, O.N. 1093860, allided with the Cos Cob railroad bridge while waiting for an opening and cracked a window on the port side.  It was low tide and the winds were pushing the vessel into the bridge, so the Master decided to lay up on the bridge to wait for the opening, resulting in the cracked window.

Uninspected tow vessel (UTV)  towing a deck barge with a crane from New Bedford to Fall River, MA attempted to pass under the Sakonnet River Highway bridge when the crane struck the bridge.  The vessel's backed away and the barge spudded down for inspection and investigation.

There were no injuries; the bridge was inspected by a Rhode island DOT bridge engineer who verified that the damage did not impact the structural safety of the bridge. 

The master of the UTV failed to ensure that the air draft of the crane was properly calculated.  He stated that he thought shore parties using the crane had lowered it sufficiently.  The owner stated that a visual comparison of the crane's height relative to the barge spuds was the normal practice.  If the crane was below the spuds, it would easily clear the bridge.

On 10July05 at 0030 M/V Bob Koch was southbound at mm 288 Des Plaines River when they made a controlled landing (allision) with Cass St. Bridge.  No damage to tow or bridge pier.  No injuries reported.

On 12JUL05 1100, the M/V DAY PECKINPAUGH being pushed the TUG BENJAMIN ELLIOT allided with the Webster Street Bridge.  The Webster Street Bridge spans the New York State Barge Canal in Tonawanda, NY.  The M/V DAY PECKINPAUGH sustained minor damage to a spotlight and horn mount.  The center green navigation light on the Webster Street Bridge was completely destroyed and the minor damage was inflicted to the navigation lighting-wiring conduit.  The Master of the TUG BENJAMIN ELLIOT failed to ensure adequate vertical clearance for safe passage of his tow (M/V DAY PECKINPAUGH).  The published clearance represented clearance center span and did not acount for lower end of "uphill" bridge.  Total damage estimate to the Webster Street Bridge is $500.00.

The M/V KEVIN FLOWERS was Southbound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) pushing 15 loaded hopper barges in a tow arranged 3 barges wide 5 barges long. While making the Eads Bridge near mile 179 UMR the M/V KEVIN FLOWERS' rudders were to the stbd and would not come back to port. Despite assistance from the chief engineer in the pilot house the rudder control would not steer tow to port. The tow continued to set to stbd and the stbd string lead barge ACBL 2922 came in contact with the right descending bridge pier. This caused the stbd string of five barges to breakaway from the M/V KEVIN FLOWERS. Numerous fleeting vessels assisted with catching the breakaway barges. The barges were caught and did not allide or collide with any other objects. No damage to the Eads Bridge pier was reported.

After securing the barge ACBL 2922 the ACBL crew commenced making effort to transfer the cargo (Corn) and pump water from the barge's wing tanks.  About one hour into this offloading effort, barge ACBL 2922 sank along the left descending bank at mile 178 on the UMR.

The M/V KEVIN FLOWERS was dry docked at National Maintenance repair at Wood river, IL and the rudders were there and in good condition. The steering system was inspected and maintenance was conducted. The steering system was inspected by MSO St Louis inspectors. The vessel was refloated and MSO St Louis inpsectors witnesssed operational steering test while underway. All test conducted were to the satisfaction of the MSO St Louis inspectors.

03JULY05: M/V Judson B was pushing Barge SCF 131 as well as three other empty hopper barges. A gust of wind blew the vessel and tow while crossing under the Navarre Bridge. The Master over compensated for the wind and rubbed the cribbing on the bridge fender system with barge SCF 131. No damage was done to the bridge or barge.

While transiting up the Taunton River to the Somerset Power Plant, the M/V DORSET loaded with coal grounded when the ebb tide pushed the vessel out of the channel.  Incident occurred near the Brightman Street Bridge.  Vessel was aground for approximately 1 hour.  ABS survey did not find evidence of damage.   There were no injuries.

The bridge transit was intended to be at slack water but the ebb was well underway when the vessel was able to
pass throught the bridge.  Vessels involved in bridge construction caused at least some of the delay of the DORSET.

As reported in the 2692, two crewmen in an unnamed work skiff were assisting in loading of a coal barge by monitoring draft readings when they decided to ride up the creek to look around. On the way back to the barge, the skiff struck the fender system of CSX railroad bridge resulting in both crewmen receiving injuries. Mariners were immediately transported to the hospital for treatment where they were also tested for drugs.  Further related enforcement activities were deemed not necessary.

This incident was downgraded to the data collection level of investigation as authorized by Subparagraph (M) of COMDT MSG P 042025Z OCT 01.

25JUL05 - The CFV DONALD LEE was waiting to dock at D. L. Edgerton's Pier in Chincoteague, VA when the main engine stalled.  The main engine could not be restarted immediately because the start air compressors were not on line.  The vessel drifted with the current toward the Chincoteague Swing Bridge and subsequently allided with the bridge, which was undamaged.  Once the air flasks were fully charged the engine was started and the vessel docked as planned. The DONALD LEE suffered minor damage to the upper portion of the net rack, which was repaired by the owner at no cost.

On 26July05 at 2230 M/V Kiowa was southbound at mm 319.8 CSSC pushing 06 empty barges when barge MSC 8802 had an allision with Illinois Central RR Bridge.  No damage to bridge reported.  Barge sustained rub rail damage of approx. 1 1/2'x1' crack.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On July 12, 2006 at approximately 1315 hours the M/V Shawnee was heading south bound in the Mobile River  pushing 9 hopper barges in the area of the mile marker 14 CSX rail road bridge. The master stated that the head of the tow cleared the bridge and the empty barge (CA 505) located on the port stern of the tow, swung outward approximately 4 feet. The barge made contact with the bridge fender works, causing damage. The crew suspected that the cause as a broken line holding the barge against the tow. The crew was told to apply additional safety lines and or cables to all low couplings and breast rigging to all future tows.

The M/V ELVIS H was pulling approximately 500 feet of pontoon pipe southward under CSX railroad bridge #193 when one of the pontoons in the tow hit the east side fender system of the bridge. One of the timbers of the fender broke as a result of the impact. The vessel and tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

Vessel was involved in an allision with the 5th street bridge. Vessel was being "Dead Ship Towed" up river by two tug boats.  5th street bridge tender has provided a report indicating that the bridge was completely open with all green lights on at the time of the incident.

Tug boats claim that bridge was not fully open even though it was indicating open with a green light. When Sector Miami Investigation Officers attended scene they observed bridge to be fully open.

When Sector Miami Investigation Officers attended M/V Tallin a Flag State Representative was on board to assess damage and provide a temporary fix while determining a repair proposal. IO determined vessel to be seaworthy and no operational control will be issued.

On August 9, at approximately 0330 the barge THE PATRIOT was outbound on the Chelsea River with the tug DONALD C at her stern (pushed).  The Bridge tender for the Chelsea St Bridge opened the draw on request for the transit.  During the transit the bridge tender heard a loud scraping noise from the fendering system on the East Boston side.  The tug DONALD C radioed they were clear of the bridge via VHF and the tender lowered it again at 0333.  After inspecting the poorly lit fendering system the bridge tender observed no damage had occurred and returned to his post.  At daylight, when the new bridge tender was on scene a second inspection was conducted.  At that time it was observed that three sections of the hanging fendering system were missing, presumably at the bottom of the channel, and that the shackles were broken clean.  Notifications were then made by the Superintendent of Bridges for the City of Boston. The tug DONALD C was directed by the COTP Boston to hold station at the southern tip of the SEC BOSTON AOR to await damage assessment inspections. 
Sector Boston Investigators/Inspector boarded the Tug DONALD C at sea. Horizontal scratches and wear were observed on the barge THE PATRIOT. These marks were consistent with the alleged allision with the Chelsea Street bridge. No structural damaged to the vessel noted. After the damage assessment survey, the vessel was allowed to resume its operations. 
Drug and alcohol test was conducted for the crew of Tug DONALD C.

At approx. 0300 on 25 June 05, while transitting the Louisiana RR bridge at mile 282.1 UMR, the M/V Deana Ann pushing barges TAF-935B and CC-95513 allided with the left descending bridge bull works, causing the two barges to break free from tow and push barge SCF-24037 under port bow corner of M/V Deana Ann.  Barges TAF-935B and CC-95513 were lightened and dropped at fleet. SCF-24037 was taken to its destination in the Gulf.  There were minor damages to bridge, unworthy of repair, no damages to M/V Deana Ann.

32/093/05 

04 August 2005 - While traveling southbound in Bayou LaFourche, the UTV Capt. Crosby was pushing the shale barge OR 5319 when it allided with the Leeville Bridge. Vessel was forced to far side of bridge opening by oncoming shrimp vessel with its outriggers extended. No damage was reported to the barge, minor damage was reported to the fendering system of the bridge. Bridge is operational and there were no injuries or report of pollution. 

Incident is a reportable marine casualty due to the allision with a bridge.

On 08/05/2005, at or about 1500, the UTV MISS AMANDA was pushing the Crane Barge UNITED I on the Intracoastal Waterway in the vicinity of the Bayou Dularge Bridge.  The Crane Barge allided with the Bayou Dularge Bridge, resulting in no damage to the bridge and approximately $3000-$5000 damage to the UNITED I.  See Correspondence. No injuries or pollution. The involved personnel were tested for drugs and alcohol.

The M/V JEANNE MARIE was westbound in the ICW pushing two barges in line. As the vessel went underneath the Dauphin Island Bridge, the lead barge, the RM 1475 grounded on shoaling on north side of the channel immediately west of the bridge. No damage was reported to have occurred to the barges or the vessel as a result of this grounding. Upon high tide, the barge was refloated, and the vessel continued on its voyage without further incident.

M/V J. W. Hunter pushing 8 loaded and 01 empty unregulated barges Northbound on the Cumberland River at mm30 allided with the bridge pier on the right descending bank of the Eureka Bridge.  No damage to the bridge or barge.  Cause determined to be increase outflow from Barkley Lock & Dam and lack of horsepower on the towing vessel.  No further action necessary or desired.

At approximately 1400 hours on 21 May 2005, while passing through the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad Bridge, barge MCR-207B landed on the left descending pier of the bridge.  There were no damages to barge MCR-207B, the Bridge, or any other barges in tow of the M/V Raymond Grant Eckstein.  Drug/alcohol testing was not conducted in conjunction with this incident.  As for corrective safety measures, none are recommended at this time.

The M/V Raymond Grant Eckstein and its tow allided with the Clinton Railroad Bridge at Mile 518 UMR causing the steering coupling to break and a block of nine barges to drift downriver.  The M/V James Buky caught the block of nine barges and held for the M/V Raymond Grant Eckstein.  The M/V Raymond Grant Eckstein proceeded through the bridge, and re-assembled its tow.  Empty Barge RBP-106 suffered damage to the #1 wing compartment with water entering the cargo box.  Pumps were placed on barge and temporary repairs were made.  Barge was dropped at Comanche Fleet for drydocking and repairs.  No other barges in tow of the M/V Raymond Grant Eckstein sustained damages.  Approximately 60' of the bridge's shear fence was damaged.  Voyage resumed at approximately 2230 hrs on 31 March 2005.

The M/V KANSAS CITY was northbound pushing nine barges in the Tombigbee River. As the tow went under the Jackson Rail Road Bridge, the operator maneuvered the tow in order to avoid hitting the anchor buoy of a dredge barge just north of the bridge. As a result, the starboard aft barge of the tow, SCF 2570 B, bumped the eastern fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained to the barge or bridge as a result of this incident. The vessel continued on its voyage without further incident.

While making the Sabula Railroad Bridge, tow got out too far, tried to line tow back up, but the boxes on the head caused tow to go into upper part of bridge port side.  It was too late to back up and barge CC-8152B landed on bridge concrete.  CC 8152 sustained some damage, the deck was pulled up and pushed in about 2'x35" and void pushed in from top to bottom.  No leaks in barge.

2474564 - 
Cable catenary wrongfully hanging at night from the new bridge's worksite swept away the transiting tug's mast.

At 23:25 on 23Aug05, tug "MAIA H" towing a loaded log barge southbound allided with unseen wire rope cable wrongfully dangling from the center span of the new Tacoma narrows bridge.  The cable swept away the tug's mast and damaged a light on a log loader parked on the barge's deck.  The height of the tug's mast was 35 feet.  The highway bridge contractor intended for the cable to be raised much higher.  The tug's operator was aware of construction in the area and did transit the center span at a time after the cabling operations were to be clear for the day.  Tug "ISLAND MIST" also in the area reported that the object hit the mast of the "MAIA H."   The apparent cause of the allision was the failure of the contractor to cause the cable to be raised high, out of the way of navigation.  Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.
While departing Duluth/Superior the M/V Vlieborg allided with the north wall of the Duluth/Superior harbor ship canal.

Steering through Burlington R. R. Bridge the starboard stern barge landed on guard fence.  It is thought that stress in the coupling caused crack in stern void of Ing 4533.  Stern barge that rubbed guard fence is ING 5755 (was ING 363) no reported damage to ING 5755 (was ING 363, then renamed in 2001).

The pilot was attempting to navigate through the channel span of the Crescent Railroad Bridge with a tow of fifteen empty coal barges.  The wind was blowing approximately 6-12 MPH toward the right descending pier.  As the pilot approached the bridge and started steer in the bridge he felt that the wind was forcing him in to a slide.  He decided to stop his forward motion by backing up and allowed his starboard lead barge to land on the shear fence to gain control of the empty tow in the wind.  After landing, he worked his tow off the bridge, checked for damage, and communicated with the bridge tender.  No damage occurred to the bridge or barge.
Received report of allision of CG Inspected T/B in-tow/under the control of the M/V W.W. DYER with PICKWICK L/D, TNR MM 207 at 0200 17SEP05.  Investigation/Inspection team dispatch.

While M/V Baxter Southern was maneuvering through the Burlington RR bridge, with assistance from a tug, starboard engine died, resulting in starboard stern of tow bumping RR bridge, causing tow to pivot to port, forcing port bow of tow to strike sheer fence of bridge and lower bridge protection cell. 20 feet of sheer fence was damaged along with a dent in the barge, CF 103.

The bulk vsl OAK HARBOUR, while maneuvering up the Duwamish River under power w/the assistance of tugs CHIEF & GUIDE, stern first, struck the NW wing wall of the Spokane Street Bridge. The port side of the OAK HARBOUR, in the vicinity of the house, grazed the wing wall causing damage to the wing wall but no substantive damage to the vessel. Initial damage estimates were not available for the wing wall. There were no injuries & no pollution.  Weather, tide & night transit were not a factor. Based on observations of a Fed Pilot Observer & Master of the CHIEF, evidence indicates a port rudder command was ordered by the Pilot to prevent the stern from contacting the wing wall but a starboard rudder was executed by the Deck Officer/Helmsman causing the stern of the OAK HARBOUR to strike the wing wall.  The Deck Officer & Helmsman state they heard a port rudder command ordered & executed a port rudder command.   SEE NARRATIVE in CORRESPONDENCE. Based on the evidence, no enforcement action is anticipated at this time.

The Tug Miss Jennifer was transiting the Inner Coastal Waterway Atlantic Beach NC with two barges in stern tow and one assist tug Royal Engineer made off to the stern of the second barge.  While transiting under the Atlantic Beach Bridge, the lead barge was caught by the ebbing current and was pushed into the port side fendering system.  Immediately after contacting the port side fendering system the barge bounced across and struck the stbd side of the fendering system, destroying approx 20 feet of the fendering system.  No damage to the barge or bridge structure noted.

THE SUNCRUZ V was preparing to enter John's Pass and noticed another vsl possibly outbound.  Master attempted to contact the vsl with neg results and then lost sight of the vsl.  Master realized his vsl had traveled off course and attempted to correct his course.  Matsre stated that he over steered the vsl causing it to allide with the John's Pass Bridge on the north side of the fendering system.
Mast of UTV DANIELLE GUIDRY struck I-10 bridge at the San Jacinto River, resulting in the aluminum mast shearing off and no damage to the bridge.

On 29 August 2005 Hurricane Katrina impacted the Port of Mobile AL with heavy winds and substantial storm surge. During the course of the storm's impact, the barge MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER, carrying the MODU CHEMUL, broke away from Bender Shipyard 9 on the Mobile Ship Channel where the CHEMUL was engaged in dry dock repairs. The wind and current pushed the MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER and CHEMUL west and northward, colliding with the M/V FONARUN NAREE, which was moored at the Alabama State Docks. Next, the MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER and CHEMUL allided with the Alabama State Docks coal terminal loading arm, Dock D2, and Berth E resulting in approximately three million dollars of damage. As the MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER and CHEMUL continued northward, they struck the Plains Energy pier and the BP pier causing substantial damage and destruction to each. The MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER and CHEMUL continued northward in the Mobile Ship Channel and proceeded underneath the Cochran Bridge on the north end of Mobile. As they went underneath the bridge, a boom on one end of the CHEMUL impacted the bridge, and stopped the northward progression of the barge/MODU combination. The impact with the bridge caused the center portion girders of the bridge to shift four inches northward on their bearings. The girders rebounded back and ended up at rest two inches from their original position.  Additionally, chunks of concrete varying from inches to two feet were broken off from the bridge as a result of this allision. The electrical wiring, which ran along the southern side of the bridge, was damaged from the impact. As the storm surge receded, the current changed to southward, freeing the CHEMUL and MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER from their position underneath the bridge. The barge was intercepted by two tugs that assisted in pushing the barge aground on the east side of the channel until a more positively controlled means of recovery could be arranged.
	Bender Shipyard submitted the mooring plan for CHEMUL / MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER for Hurricane Katrina on 26 AUG 2005 in order to comply with USCG Sector Mobile MSIB 20-05. The plan was given a verbal approval by a USCG representative over the phone prior to the hurricane based on a verbal agreement with the shipyard that the same plan used for Hurricane Dennis would be submitted for Hurricane Katrina. Further investigation revealed the faxed submission of the plan for Hurricane Katrina was flawed in that it was actually the plan for Tropical Storm Arlene, not Hurricane Dennis. Furthermore, the fax transmission of the plan was incomplete, only displaying a portion of the text and diagrams. Following the hurricane, when investigators questioned the shipyard Superintendent on what plan they followed to secure the MOBILE HEAVY LIFTER, a diagram of mooring arrangements for Hurricane Dennis was given to investigators, confirming the verbal arrangement made between Sector Mobile and Bender Shipyard. A major discrepancy between the diagram and actual preparations is that the diagram called for the heavy lifter to be submerged, and additional mooring lines used, which did not occur in advance of Hurricane Katrina.
A VESSEL WAS S/B ON THE ILR MAKING THE PEKIN RAILROAD BRIDGE AND LANDED ON THE LEFT SIDE PROTECTION PIER. A BARGE WAS HOLED IN #1 AND #2 WING TANKS.

32/108/05 

UTV Jeanne James was pushing barge Weeks 589 southbound on Atchafalaya.  Capt was turning vsl in front of bridge to maneuver upriver when barge allided with fendering system of bridge.  No damage to barge.  LA DOT attended and determined no damage to bridge.

The M/V Adam E. Cornelius was transiting inbound on the Rouge River Short cut passage, while passing through the Short Cut bridge (draw bridge) the vessel damaged the red navigation light located on the north fender on the west end of the bridge.

October 8, 2005:  Received notification of allision with Rochester rail road swing bridge fender in the Genesee River.  Note bridge has been out of service for several years and was not damaged from allision.  Vessel's received damage to decorative non-structural sheet metal on the portside at 10 foot above the waterline.  Allision was intentional as means to pivot vessel for approach to dock due to high wind. No actionable negligence on the part of the Master.  Investigation down graded to data collection as bridge was out of service.

On August 27, 2005 at 1010 hours the master of the F/V VANNA LAVIE stated they passed under the Popps Ferry bridge in Biloxi Mississippi when he was hit in the stern by the F/V KING OF THE SEA. The anchor of the KING Of THE SEA crashed into the deck of the VANNA LAVIE. The force of the collision caused the deckhand to fall backward, hitting her right shoulder on the galley bunk. The vessel sustained damage to the deck, hull, boom and lost nets.
