The master of the F/V KING OF THE SEA stated that he was first in line to go under the Popps Ferry bridge during the Hurricane Katrina evacuation process. He said his vessel was first in line to pass under the bridge when the F/V VANNA LAVIE tried to cut in front of his vessel. The master of the KING OF THE SEA said he tried to stop and let the F/V VANNA LAVIE go by, but a rope hanging off the vessel hooked on to his anchor. The master of the KING OF THE SEA said he tried to un-tangle the two vessels as the two captains exchanged words. The two vessels were untangled and the boats separated. 

The facts reported concerning this case were unable to be substantiated by investigators, 2692 information only.

13 October 2005 @ 1825L - The UTV TOWN POINT was assisting the UTV SEA RAVEN, which was pushing the tank barge ATC-23, loaded with styrene. The vessels were heading south on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River to NOVA Chemicals, with the TOWN POINT positioned alongside the barge with one line on the port bow of the barge.  As the vessels approached the Gilmerton Bridge, the operator of the TOWN POINT noticed that the space between the barge and the eastside fendering system would not be adequate for safe passage.  He engaged the bow thruster to clear the fendering system, but this action came too late.  The 
TOWN POINT allided with the fendering system along its port side.  The operator of the TOWN POINT  contacted the bridge tender and SEA RAVEN to notify them of the allision.  There was no damage to the bridge or  vessels.

18OCT2005: As a result of hurricane RITA, the CFV GOD'S BLESSING sank at her moorings at the pier of Bridge Point Marina.  
On 20OCT, the vessel was refloated by owner, no longer a threat to navigation or the environment.

10/15/2005 - UTV Cathy M. Settoon was tag boat on the stern of a rig tow.  When turning into Bayou Terrebonne the stern of the Cathy M. Settoon hit fender wall of bridge over bayou, cracking one board on the Bridge fender wall.  
Upon further investigation, it was discovered that the Master of the vessel was working more than 12 hours in a consecutive 24hour period 46 CFR 15.705 and the tankerman was unlawfully operating the vessel 46 CFR 15.610

M/V Bill Carneal northbound with 16 empties in tow. While making bridge near UMR MM 283 in windy conditions, tow was set to starboard and lead barge in starboard string (WTT834) came in contact with right pier protection cell. No damage reported to pier.

There was no indication that drug or alcohol use by operator contributed to this incident.
On October 30, 2005, the M/V SAM M hit the fendering system of the Nummy Island (Ocean Drive) Bridge while transiting through Hereford Inlet. Minor damage reported to bridge and vessel.

On November 4, 2005, the tug CAMERONS POINT (official number 506508) was transiting the Norwalk River, pushing ahead the empty split dump hopper scow EDDIE CARROLL (official number 1116538), when the scow allided with the fendering system of the west passage of the Metro-North Railroad Bridge (the Walk Bridge), causing minor damage to the bridge fendering system.  Metro-North personnel inspected the fendering system and determined the bridge was fully functional.  

See Correspondence #43078 for the Investigating Officer's report.

ON 29 OCT 05 AT APPROXIMATELY 1045 HOURS THE M/V NANIABA WAS ON THE BLACK WARRIOR RIVER IN THE AREA OF MILE MARKER 268, PUSHING 8  OPEN HOPPER BARGES (2 EMPTY AND 6 LOADED). THE BARGES WERE CONFIGURED 3 X 3 X 2. THE STARBOARD SIDE OF THE BARGE WGN 349 SCRAPED ALONG THE EAST PILLAR OF THE NORFOLK SOUTHERN BRIDGE. THE MASTER STATED THAT HE NAVIGATED TOO CLOSE TO THE RAIL ROAD BRIDGE AND MADE CONTACT WITH THE BRIDGE. THE BRIDGE AND BARGE SUSTAINED MINOR SCRAPES. THE BRIDGE INSPECTOR CHECKED THE BRIDGE AND REPORTED THAT THE BRIDGE DID NOT SUSTAIN ANY DAMAGE AS A RESULT OF THIS ALLISION. THE VESSEL CONTINUED ON ITS VOYAGE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

6NOV05: The HIGH NOON, a 54.7-foot commercial fishing vessel, was shifting berths in Chincoteague Harbor.  One of two main engines was inoperable because the fuel system had an "air lock."  The tide was flooding and the current estimated at three to four knots.  At approximately 1000L the vessel allided with the bridge when the operator was unable to control the vessel in the tidal current with only one engine.  There was no damage to the bridge or vessel.

ON 11 November 2005, at 0640, TUG DAVID BRUSCO allided with North Bend, OR,  Railroad Bridge, with BRUSCO 401 barge.  Waterway not impacted.   The port side of the log cargo made contact with the center span guard wall at the inside southwest end of the railroad bridge opening.   Detached Duty Officer conducted interviews and inspected vessels and bridge.  No damage to tug, barge, or railroad bridge. ATON verification conducted with all ATON watching properly.

At approximately 1300, the TUG ETHLYN P pushing the barge M839 was maneuvering to align the tug/barge into a position for mooring when the stbd "z" drive malfunctioned. The tug/barge was approximately 400yds from the bridge proceeding parallel to it moving from west to east. The tug/barge was ivo of the Sanibel Causeway Bridge Span "A" when she turned to south and began to make a loop. The master explained that he was maneuvering to bring the barge out and around to position her on the stbd side of some other barges already moored. When the tug/barge reached the apex of this maneuver the steering failed. 

The master was unable to maintain enough control to prevent the tug/barge from striking the bridge fender. As the tug barge was positioned in a northerly direction facing the bridge, without positive steering controls, she was set by the in coming tidal current. The wind gust from the same direction also contributed to the inability to maintain positive control. 

The tug/barge than drifted at a slow rate of speed into the Span "A" fender. The stbd side of the barge made contact with the east fender and the stbd side of the tug made contact with a test pile for the new Sanibel bridge structure. The tug/barge rested against the structure until she was assisted by another Boh Bros. tug. The was no damage to the fender or to the test piling.

On November 13, 2004, at approximately 1100 (local),  the Master of the M/V Manhattan Bridge reported to USCG Sector Charleston that they had an equipment failure while conducting a quarterly lifeboat drill.  2 of the crewmembers were thrown from the boat into the water and 2 others were still in the boat.  All 4 members were eventually recovered and accounted.  3 of the crewmembers were taken to a local hospital and given basic first aid and returned to the vessel.  The 4th crewmember, the Chief Officer, required surgery as a result of his injuries.

It was determined that there was a malfunction in the release mechanism on the lifeboat causing the bow hook to be released pre-maturely.  A post accident inspection of the lifeboat showed a section of the release mechanism to be damaged.  It was not possible to determine if the damage was pre-existing or happened as a result of the accident. A visual inspection of the release mechanism did not reveal any maintenance issues.  An inspection of their drill logs indicated that the lifeboat was deployed September 1st, 2005,  without incident.

The personnel that were involved in the casualty were directed to get drug tested IAW 46 CFR 4.06.  The Three (4) crewmembers that were treated for first aid were tested immediately.  The Chief Officer, who was more seriously injured, was not tested because he was at a local hospital.  The vessel agent stated that he would be tested as soon as possible.  When the results of the tests were delivered to Sector Charleston, it was determined that the Chief Officer was not tested.  I spoke with the agent and he stated that there was an apparent "mix up" in the communications between himself, the Master and the testing agency.  I advised him of the severity of this "mix-up" and the possible repercussions that could be levied as a result.  The vessel had departed and the Chief Officer had returned to his home country and he was never tested.

The tug MUDCAT (U.S. VIN 1067220) was transiting down the Sacramento River enroute to Mare Island with 2 barges (CS-39 & CS-42) in tow. One of the barges (CS-42) had 2 spuds in the up position and the spuds struck the Union Pacific Railroad Bridge. The bridge operator notified VTS and the MUDCAT immediately backed down. CG Investigations Officer and UP Railroad Bridge Inspectors conducted an inspection of the bridge, tested the operations, and deemed the bridge operable. Minimal damage was found on the bridges fendering system and walkway, and the barges spuds were bent.  Alcohol and drug testing were conducted at Mare Island after the vessel moored. 

Recommend a Letter of Warning be issued to the tug operator for negligence and misconduct (violation of Comapny Policy).  See EA #2716099

26OCT05 The unnamed Boh Bros. tug (FL6705NA) pushing the barge Granite II ahead allided with the Sanibel Causeway Bridge Span "A" fendering system.

The Master on the tug attempted to transit through the "A" span heading south when the tug/barge struck the west fender. While making his approach, the master overcompensated for the current and was unable to make the necessary corrections. Subsequently, after striking the west fender, the east fender was also hit. There was no damage to the tug/barge. 

The FLDOT representative was on scene and determined that there was no damage to the existing bridge structure.

15 November 2005 @2100L - The tug CAPE HATTERAS, operated by Moran Towing, was assisting the tug 
SEA RAVEN and tank barge ATC23.  The flotilla was passing northbound through the Gilmerton Bridge, located on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  The captain of the SEA RAVEN was directing and controlling the movement of all vessels in flotilla.  The typical method was for one assist tug to push on the bow of the barge to align it with the draw, then pass under the bridge ahead of the barge and wait on the other side.  During this evolution, the CAPE HATTERAS did not have room to proceed ahead of the barge and waited for the passage of the barge and SEA RAVEN.  After aligning the barge with the draw, the CAPE HATTERAS stopped pushing and fell back, laying up on the detached fendering system of the Gilmerton.  Since the contact was not intentional, this was a reportable marine casualty.  There was no damage to the fendering system or vessels involved.

Vessel was lined up to transit inbound through the bridge at Johns Pass. The Master lined up the vessel a little further to the North than usual due to 25 knot winds from the North West and currents running to the South due to a flood tide. As he began his transit through the pass he experienced an unexpected push to the North. The Master attempted to maneuver the vessel through the bridge, but allided port side with the north side fender system.

11/27/05 - While operating with a tow comprised of 6 empty barges, tow allided with fendering system while passing Bayou Blue vehicular pontoon bridge.  The Master reported that a sudden gust of wind caused the allison.  Bridge was swung open at the time and was undergoing repairs for unrelated reasons. On 12 Nov 2005 at 0845 the T/V CAPT ERIC DUET was eastbound in the Algiers Canal (Alternate Route ICWW West) and allided with the Belle Chase Bridge. The bridge has been non-operational to marine traffic due to Hurricane Katrina. The T/V CAPT ERIC DUET slowed on approach, checked clearance and a piece of equipment allided with the bridge.  No damage, pollution, or injuries reported.  Apparent cause of the allision was the misjudgment of clearance by the Master.

22 NOV 2005 - The towboat LOUIS I and tow were locking through the James W. Trimble L&D (13) on the Arkansas River at 13:55 hours when the spud of the dredge barge JOLLY RODGER was left in too high a position and caught the understructure of the Hwy 59 bridge that passes over the Lock & Dam.  The bridge was inspected and suffered no damage.  The spud of the barge was only slightly bent & required no repairs.

On 01 December 2005 at 1945, the operator was navigating the certificated sailing vessel LADY WASHINGTON, O.N. 944970, when he clipped the masts on a bridge. During the investigation, the operator admitted that his license had been suspended and he was currently on probation for an earlier grounding incident on the U.S. east coast. 

The operator stated that he was approaching the Benicia UP Railroad Bridge on the Sacramento River and he noticed that there may not be enough room to clear the bridge span.  He stated that he glanced at the local chart which showed a clearance of 135 feet for the auto bridge, but he failed to read the note on the chart which stated that the UP Railroad span had a clearance of 70 feet while in the down position. Thus, he allided with the bridge and caused about $3600 of damage to the masts.

According to the operator's Settlement Agreement dated 15 July 2004, (Activity 2098874), the operator agreed to a twelve (12) month outright suspension if issued a Complaint for violation of a law or regulation during the probationary period.

The operator had been the subject of four previous Enforcement Activities prior to this incident, 738267 in 2001, 1939100 and 1942909 in 2003, and 2098874 in 2004.

Recommend Revocation Enforcement and a Voluntary Deposit, either Good Faith or Surrender, from operator ASAP.

Letter of Warning for Captain at the wheel.

12/07/2005 - Approx 0610 the OSV KRISTIN FAGAN was enroute east to Houma using the ICW.  The vessel made preparations to go underneath the bridge. 03DEC05:  The M/V CROSBY EXPLORER was pushing 3 barges that allided with the Navarre Bridge fender system, partially due to weather.  The third barge in the tow, KS 530, caught the bridge fender system. The Pilot turned the vessel hard starboard and the tow broke apart.  At this time the master came on the bridge and took control of the tow.  The master retrieved the two barges that broke away.  As the vessel was maneuvering back on course the tug softly grounded causing the #1 and 2 barges to break away again.  The barges drifted onto the southeastern side of the bridge.  As the tug was maneuvered off bottom, a line fouled the starboard propeller, the vessel only has control/use of the port engine.  The tow laid-up alongside the bridge, out of the channel, until divers could remove the line from the starboard propeller. There was no damage to the barges or tug.  However, the second section of the bridge fender system was damaged, FDOT was notified.  The allision was caused by the weather, the pilot tried to correct the situation, no enforcement was deemed  necessary.

The M/V ROBERT GREENE was southbound pushing 7 loaded barges and making an approach to the Clinton RR Bridge.  The Captain reported a strong current set the tow to STBD and the starboard stern barge ML 802 rubbed the protection cell on the upper end of the bridge.

Nov 11, 2005/ 1600:  M/V APOLLO, while enroute eastbound in the ICW near Forked Is. Bridge.  M/V CREOLE SUN was westbound, on approach ivo bridge.  Vsls agreed on port to port passage, M/V APOLLO would meet M/V CREOLE SUN aft of the bridge.  M/V CREOLE SUN however altered course to starboard.  Unclear of intentions, M/V APOLLO immediately took actions to avoid collision. M/V CREOLE SUN, as a result of close quarters situation, allided w/ fender system of bridge.  negligible damage to bridge and vessel.

On 28 November, 2005, at approximately 0750, the UTV MISS RICA was eastbound Harvey Canal pushing spud barge DEAN/1 and the front starboard spud allided with a support brace on the Lapalco drawbridge.  The drawbridge was closed for one hour, inspected and found to have sustained no damage.  The barge DEAN/1 sustained superficial paint scrapes.  No injuries or pollution resulted.  The apparent cause of the allision was the master's misjudgment of the appropriate clearance.

32/161/05  

11/11/2005 - The UTV DIXIE EXPRESS was traveling eastbound through Bayou Dularge Bridge approximately 15' off the port column and approximately 300' through bridge when the master at the helm said that UTV DELTA OWL came north out of Houma Navigation Channel and proceeded across the UTV DIXIE EXPRESS's bow to turn westbound through the bridge. UTV DELTA OWL's logbook reflects that they were moored at the Chet Morrison dock that entire day.  Confirmed with Chet Morrison that UTV DELTA OWL was moored at that time.  Chet Morrison dock and Bayou Dularge Bridge are within a mile of each other.  Negligence, alcohol or drugs were not considered to be a factor.

M/V Butch Barras was pushing ahead northbound 11 loaded barges at 2 mph when the port lead barge SER 171 made contact with the sheer fence on the Dubuque Rail Road Bridge.  It was night time, but overall visibility was good and the winds were out of the NNE, 6 mph.

M/V CSL LAURENTIEN was transiting downbound in the Rouge River when the top of the radar scanner came into contact with scaffolding underneath the I-75 bridge.  No damage to scaffolding or bridge reported.  Radar scanner fell onto the aft bridge of the vessel.  No injuries reported.  No alcohol or drug involvement suspected.

Vessel allided with 3rd Avenue bridge after she became unmoored due to a storm. Bridge sustained no damage. Owner claimed damage close to $100,000 but these costs include drydocking costs. Therefore, this incident does not qualify as a Serious Marine Incident.

On December 7, 2005 at approximately 1235 the Motor Tanker (M/T) ETERNITY departed Global Revere, outbound on the Chelsea River, Chelsea, MA.  The M/T ETERNITY was accompanied by the Tug LIBERTY, Tug MAVERICK, Tug H.J. REINHAUER, and Tug VINCENT TIBBETTS JR.  At approximately 1311, while passing through the Chelsea St Bridge, the M/T ETERNITY made contact on her port side with the fendering system of the Chelsea St Bridge.  The master of the M/T ETERNITY contacted the shipping agent to report the incident.  A shipping agent representative made contact with the docking master in control of the M/T ETERNITY at the time to confirm the report of an allision.  After speaking with the docking master, the shipping agent agreed that notification to the CG was not necessary as the docking master asserted that the allision was "intentional" and an action required to make safe transit through the bridge during inclimate weather.  The docking master had not notified any tug operators or the master of the M/T ETERNITY that he intended to make contact with the fendering system.  Notification of the incident was made to the CG by the supervisor of Boston Tug and Towing Pilots at approximately 1500, who believed the docking master was making an inaccurate interpretation of the regulations.  Upon investigation by Sector Boston no damage was found on the Chelsea St Bridge fendering system.  No damage was reported by the M/T ETERNITY.  A 2692 Report of Marine Casualty was not submitted.
A commercial vessel allided with the 3rd Avenue Bridge after it became unmoored due to a storm surge.  The incident caused heavy structural damage. The bridge sustained damage to her fender system.

On 28DEC05 at 1645 near mm 271 Illinois River M/V CODY BOYD was northbound with 15 loads and rubbed/allided with the EJ&E RR bridge.  No damage reported to bridge or barge CBL-223B.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required in conjunction with this incident.

On 29DEC05 at 1110 near mm 287.3 Illinois River M/V BETH WILSON was northbound with barges WEB 228, 229 in tow and approaching the McDonough St. Bridge.  The vessel had to steer to port to line up for the bridge n/b.  Barges WEB 228, 229 started sliding to stbd.  Slide could not be stopped until WEB 228 touched up against the east side fender work of the bridge.  No damage reported to barge or bridge fender.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On January 4, 2006, while berthing at Garden city Terminals in Savannah, GA, the M/V RHEIN BRIDGE suffered a loss of propulsion.  The engine failed to answer an astern order.   The vessel was assisted to berth by tugs.  COTP order 001-06 was issued requiring the vessel to remain at berth until a Classification Society Surveyor could attend vessel to asses the diagnosis and repairs.

The surveyor discovered that the main engine fuel mechanism failed for the No. 7 and No. 10 cylinders.  The shaft that moves the fuel pump to reverse the engines sheared at a taper just prior to some threads.  There were no spare shafts onboard so the existing shafts were welded and tested satisfactory.  The remaining eight valve shafts were examined and confirmed to be satisfactory.  Agency action complete.

Vessel was outbound from Oregon Inlet. As the vessel was nearing the Bonner Bridge the current on the stern of the vessel caused it to lose steerage. Vessel was pushed against the fender system of the bridge and its outriggers became entangled with the fender system. The vessel's crew was able to cut the wires to the outriggers and free the vessel. The vessel tried to transit back into Oregon Inlet for a post SAR boarding by STA Oregon Inlet personnel. Vessel was unable to make headway against the current and was pushed onto a shoal by the current. Vessel was able to free itself. Vessel was taken under tow by a Station Oregon Inlet vessel and proceeded to a safe location for the post SAR boarding. 

Vessel sustained some damage to its stbd outrigger and trawl door during the allision. No damage was sustained due to the grounding. No pollution or injuries occurred.

Due to the ice covered channel, M/V Joyce Hale had difficulty manuvering the barges in tow.  When the tow, going southbound, approached the Dubuque Rail Road Bridge, barge ART 388 landed on the turn table of the sheer protection fence, resulting in a gash in the #1 and #2 wing tanks on the stbd side.

On January 14, 2005, at appx. 1145 the UTV CORY MICHAEL was westbound with barge M 966 at MM 12 ICW near the Hwy 45 Wagner Bridge and the rear spud on barge M 966 contacted the bottom of the fixed bridge, the spud broke in two sections into the water, knocking over a 500 gal capacity portable tank on deck into the river, spilling appx. 100-150 gallons of diesel oil.  No injuries reported.  No damage to bridge or UTV CORY MICHAEL.  The M 966 sustained damage to port quarter deck knuckle consisting of a minor inset with a 3 in crack, two cracks in a 3,000 temp portable diesel storage tank, and the lost spud estimated at appx. $5,000.00.  The cause was the Master's error in judgment of clearance with false information from previous captain and non verification of vessel/tow configuration.

January 16, 2006 @ 0730L - The UTV MCALLISTER BOYS and freight barge MAC4001 were passing northbound through the Gilmerton Bridge on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River in Chesapeake, VA.  To avoid a close quarters situation with a vessel docked at Southern States Fertilizer, on the left descending bank upriver of the bridge, the captain "twisted" the barge while in the draw.  The mate was stationed on the barge as a lookout.  The working stern starboard quarter of the barge allided with the bridge fender at a slow speed as the captain executed this maneuver.  There was no damage to the barge or bridge.

While navigating south bound near mile marker 838 LMR with 3 barges in tow, the subject vessel's tow allided with the I 155 bridge. Tank barge AF 15 was damaged.

Tennessee Regional Bridge Engineer stated  no damage to I 155 bridge reported.
M/V R W Naye was at MM 254 when it rubbed a steel protection cell.  No damage reported to the bridge, boat, or barges.

14 Jan 2006. Vessel was mooring when the port engine stuck in clutch ahead. Once Master realized this he placed port engine in neutral and backed down hard on Stbd engine. This slowed the vessel to below .5 kts as the vessel struck a 18 piling cluster at the base of the Morehead City high rise bridge. Pilings were push up against the bridge structure and fractured the pilings but no explosive splintering of the piling occurred. NC DOT department of Bridges conducted and investigation and no structural damage was found. Compass towing company conducted an extensive review of the air control system and noted a bypass valve was partially opened on the air dryer system, allowing moisture to migrate through the air control system.  The valve was closed and a additional air dryer installed on the bridge. The air system was completely cleaned out as well and the selector control valve removed and cleaned. System tested several times satisfactory.

1/21/2006 @1045L - The UTV McALLISTER BOYS was southbound on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River, towing the loaded scrap barge MAC 4000 to Waterway Marine Terminal.  As the tug and barge approached the Gilmerton Bridge from the north, the operator maneuvered away from a ship moored at the Southern States fertilizer facility on the right descending bank north of the bridge.  A 15 knot northwest wind was setting the tug and tow closer to the moored ship, so the operator chose a course closer to the western side of the draw.  As he attempted to straighten up through the bridge, the starboard side of the tug made contact with the wood fendering system.  The bridge tender reported that one of the wooden stringers fell from the area where the tug hit.  The tug and tow proceeded without further incident.  No further damage was reported.

1/24/06 @ 0140L - The UTV BRIDGET MCCALLISTER was underway in the Elizabeth River undocking the 
M/V SEALAND INTEGRITY at Portsmouth Marine Terminal (PMT).  During the maneuver the stern of the  BRIDGET MCCALLISTER allided with Elizabeth River PMT Bouy "3" (LLNR 9815).  Due to reduced maneuverablity, the tug moored at PMT immediately following the allision.  The aid was reported missing and later found to be fouled in the tug's cort nozzle.  Divers removed the bouy and discovered minor damage to the propeller.

U/W northbound on CSSC with two loaded asphalt barges. Vessel cleared CSX Transportation RR Bridge, and while making turn rubbed northwest protection cell. No damage to vessel or protection cell / bridge.

On January 21, 2006, at approximately 1130, UTV LADY JEANETTE was pushing barge CBY253 and CBY257B south-bound from Port Bienville, MS enroute Michoud Slip, LA when barge CBY253 allided with the CSX Rigolets Railroad Bridge (GIWW) fender system (dolphin structures), subsequently causing a failure of the coupling on barge CBY 257B.  No injuries, pollution, or damage to dolphin structures or barges resulted.  The apparent cause was strong currents.

Vessel was southbound on the Ohio River pushing 15 barges when the tow allided with the B&O Railroad Bridge in Parkersburg, WV.  The impact of the allision caused the tow to break up causing the barges in the tow to collide with each other and ground.  The breakaway barges were recovered and secured. The incident resulted in damage to several barges.

The M/V Ardyce Randall was U/B at MM 151.2, ILR, pushing a 14 barge tow. While transiting the Pekin RR Bridge, the barge XL-659B, port side, allided with the bridge's protection cell. The barge was damaged, no damage to the bridge or tow. Tow was allowed to proceed to discharge cargo and then transit via COPT order for repair.

On 28 January 2006 MSU Baton Rouge was notified that the UTV BILL RODGERS was S/B w/ 8 loaded rock barges on the LMR and had allided with the Natchez, MS. bridge at M/M 363 resulting in damage to 2 barges and a terminal.  MSU dispatched a Marine Investigator (IO) and a Marine Inspector into the AOR of MSD Greenville as agreed.  Company failed to provide alcohol test within allotted time due to the fact that the vsl was working to catch adrift barges.

No further damage, pollution, or injuries reported.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to have played a role in this incident.

At approximately 1945 on August 19, 2005, the tug ELSBETH pushing the barge BEAN 19 lost control of her tow due to strong currents and struck both the east and west fender system of the Sanibel Causeway Bridge "A" span.  There was no confirmed damage to the barge or fender system reported to the Coast Guard.

The master waited for currents to slacken, but was warned by the bridge tender to wait for slackwater as the current was still strong.  At the time of the incident, a duly established Regulated Navigation Area was in place requiring tugs and barges to transit through the "A" span during slackwater only.

Pilot of M/V KELLY LEE was making approach towards McAlpine Lock when current took head of tow out towards van dike.  Once pilot realized that head of tow was being pushed towards van dike, pilot throttled all-ahead to help make turn against current.  Head of tow didn't respond so Pilot throttled full reverse (making about 5 mph) when tow allided with van dike head-on.  M/V KELLY LEE's 3 barges (MM 53, MM54B, & MM55) broke up with barge MM 53 & barge MM 55 going over the dam.  Barge MM 53 is now resting on it's side against K & I R/R bridge at MM 608.  Barge MM 55 & MM 54B have been recovered and damage to each is being assessed at this time.

While transiting under the Benicia Bridge, the satcom antenna cover of the SAGA TUCANO came into contact the 680 Bridge and the Union Pacific Rail Bridge causing damage to the cover. The cover was replaced on arrival at the Port of Stockton.

The towing vessel ISLAND BOY was inbound with the loaded coal barge SJ 400 and the towing vessel ISLAND EXPRESS located on the forward end of the SJ 400. While transiting the draw of the Navassa RR Bridge the current forced the SJ 400 tow against the fenders, the damage was minimal.

On 30JAN06 at 0600 near mm 254.1 Illinois River M/V BERNARD G was S/B when the stbd radar scanner struck the underside of the CSX RR Bridge.  Stbd radar scanner was damaged.  No damage reported to bridge, verified by contacting the bridge via telephone.  Vessel was able to continue S/B using port radar scanner.  Stbd radar scanner set to be replaced on 01FEB06.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing was conducted or required in conjunction with this incident.

On 1/27/06 at 0645, M/V ALIQUIPPA was pushing nine (9) empty hopper barges upbound on the Monongahela River at mile marker 8.5. While proceeding through the P & LE Railroad bridge the barge MRT 451, the second of three barges in the starboard string, contacted the bridge footings. Neither the barge nor bridge were damaged. A steersman was at the helm at the time, under supervision of the master. The master felt the steersman held a course correction too long as he attempted to pass through the bridge, so they conducted a controlled pivot on the bridge.
VSL broke free from mooring lines during hurricane and allided with the Middle River Bridge.  Minimum damage occurred.

On February 8, 2006 the UTV P.J. Allided with the Bridge of Lions fendering system.  After the allision the vessel continued his way north bound to its final destination MOBRO Marine at Green Cove Springs. Bridge tender contacted Sec Jax Waterways Division and notified the allision.  Sec Jax  Command Center contacted vessel via VHF radio channel 16. Master id' himself as Harry heard.  Sec Jax Investigations Department arranged boarding of the vessel in the ICW south of Palm Valley.

01/30/2006 - Received report that the UTV EDDIE TOUCHETTE allided with the fendering system of the Harrisonbourgh Swing Bridge on the Ouchaita River at MM 55. UTV was pushing  two barges, the one that made contact was the HINES 422. No damage reported to the UTV or the barge, but minor damage was suffered by the fendering system. Swing Bridge remained fully operational. No pollution or injuries reported.

The Tug HERO was transiting downbound in the Petaluma River with 1 empty deck barge when it struck the fendering system of the Haystack Railroad bridge.  The channel was 54' and the barge was 55' wide.  See IO Narrative in correspondence for complete details.

Investigation referred for enforcement due to negligence of master.

Commercial Fishing Vessel was in route from Wanchese, NC to fishing grounds in Atlantic Ocean. Vessel was making turn to cross under the Bonner Bridge over Oregon Inlet. As vessel made turn the main engine stalled. Vessel was pushed into the bridge supports. The main engine was restarted.  As vessel was backing away from the bridge the outriggers were snagged in the bridge pilings. Vessel was able to free itself, but the outriggers were damaged.

The M/V ISLAND BOY was transiting down bound on the Cape Fear River with an empty coal barge SJ 600 working in a tandem tow arrangement with the M/V ISLAND EXPRESS. While attempting to maneuver through the Navassa Railroad Bridge opening the master detected a delay of approximately 5 seconds in helm response. Due to the response delay the tug and barge struck the north side of the bridge causing damage to the fendering system, walkway and railing and lighting structure. Master engaged second steering pump and was able to regain helm control and complete remainder of transit without further incident.

On 01JAN06 at approx. 0345 near mm 290 Illinois River M/V HARVEST RUN allided with E J & E RR Bridge.  After sticking head of tow down inside of left descending bridge cell the tow touched up and bounced the head of tow to stbd and in contact with lower protection cell.  Stbd string of 02 barges were broken from tow and resecured with lines to complete bridge transit.  No damage to bridge reported.  Barge ABC 911 sustained 02 broken winch wires, 01 broken ratchet, 01 broken strap, and a small crack/damage to stbd bow.  Approx. estimate of cost repair for these items is $1500.00  No injuries reported.

The UTV Lil Al Cenac was the lead tug pulling a Drill barge.  The Falgout Canal bridge allowed little clearance on either side of the drill barge. The Drill barge hit the bridge fender on the North West side and then made contact on the South West fender system.  There was no structural damage to the bridge, just the bridge fenders.

On 09FEB06 at approx. 0530 near mm 287 Illinois River M/V LOREE ECKSTEIN was southbound and while attempting to stop tow to wait for northbound traffic to pass, laid stern of tow (barge JIMBO-321) against the left descending protection pier of the McDonough St. Bridge.  Worked head of tow out to clear for northbound traffic.  Once traffic was cleared, lifted stern and shoved on downriver with no damages to barge JIMBO-321, vessel, or bridge protection pier.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

UTV  S. Bound @ Ohio River, MM 265 w/17 empty hopper barges, 1160' X 105' was caught by a strong gust of wind while transiting under  RR Bridge. Tow turned sidewayse and barge rubbed against the left descending pier of the bridge.  No reported damage to bridge, barge, or other vessels in tow.

On 13FEB06 at 2300 near mm 317 CSSC M/V AGGIE C was transiting Cicero Ave. Bridge when barge CBC 195 came in contact with bottom of bridge because barge was taller than bridge clearance.  CBC 195 sustained a bent shutoff valve on vapor line and 04 valves were damaged on the stern port side.  No injuries reported.  No damage to bridge reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.  Barge CBC 195 headed to New Orleans for repairs.

On 02/23/06 the M/V MARY ELIZABETH was transiting the Inter Coastal Waterway, (ICW) at approximately  mile marker 288 pushing four, (4) barges headed to Port Lavaca, Texas.   At approximately 0930 the M/V MARY ELIZABETH began to make a turn to adjust the tug and barges for westbound approach.  Tidal currents contributed to the M/V MARY ELIZABETH setting upon an uncontrollable Southerly course vice the intended Westbound course. The lead barge being pushed allided with the West Port Arthur Bridge, causing negligible damage to the barge but some damage to the bridge fendering system.

The M/V BIG AL was eastbound in Pensacola Bay pushing one loaded red flag barge KIRBY 29310T. The operator of the tug was maneuvering the tow as to compensate for a strong north wind. As the barge passed under the Pensacola Bay Bridge, the starboard aft end of the barge made contact with the south wall fender system of the bridge, resulting in the head of the barge swinging to the north and the forward port side of the barge making contact with the north fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained by the barge or the south fender system of the bridge as a result of this incident. The north fender system of the bridge sustained a broken timber on the outside of the fender system. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

11Oct2005 Vessel David Brusco allided against the North Bend Railroad Bridge during foggy weather due to poor visibility during operations.  Discovery of damage was reported to include broken logs near midship on the port side of the Barge.

On 22FEB06 at 0545 near mm 287.2 Illinois River M/V BILLY JOE BOLING was northbound while making his approach to the McDonough St. Bridge there was fleet work being done below the bridge encroaching into the navigable channel.  The capt. stopped tow in bridge and heeled off of the left descending side to line up his approach for the next bridge.  The capt. intended to land tow on bridge and there was no damage to the McDonough St. Bridge or barge IRTC-102.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing was conducted or required.

On 26JAN06, the M/V Kelly Lee was downbound entering the Portland Canal when the 3 asphalt barge tow broke free from the M/V.  One was corralled and two went over the McAlpine Hydroelectric Dam.  From the two that went over the dam, one struck the K&I RR Bridge and was corralled by a local fleet boat.  The other struck the K&I RR Bridge and was pinned against the bridge.  That barge, MM53, later flipped 90 degrees to the port side and sank.  The MM53 is currently pinned against the bridge with the portside cargo tanks underwater and the stbd tanks above the water.  There is 220,000 gallons of asphalt unaccounted for

On 24th of February 2006, the F/V ENTERPRISE struck the 2 mile bridge, Cape May, NJ causing very minimal damage to both the vessel and bridge.  The allision was caused when the vessel lost steering control when the rudder stop broke off, causing the ram to go hard over.  The vessel had just gone under the 2 mile bridge when the steering failure occurred.  Due to the outgoing current and the wind, the vessel was pushed towards the bridge striking the north side of the bridge.  The vessel was later towed by sea tow for repairs.
Captain did not ensure that crane on his barge was low enough to clear the bridge.  The crane allided with the bridge.  The bridge was checked by DOT.  The crane was estimated at $20,000 for repairs.

Received a call at approximately 0905 from Golden Gate Ferry Port Captain stating the M/V SONOMA (O.N. 578765) experienced a steering casualty.  The vessel safely made way and moored in San Francisco.  All personnel were safe.  Vessel was taken out of service.  Cause of the loss of steering was a failure of the steering ram.

The unnamed Shugart Barge allided with the Sanibel Causeway Bridge Span "B" piling (Bent #10). The barges were pushed ahead by a 19' skiff (FL9358LY) with a 90hp outboard in an alongside towing configuration. The barge was moored on the north side of the bridge prior to attempting to make a transit through the span piling (Bent #10 & #11). 

While underway, the operator was unable to maintain positive control of the barges. At approximately 100ft from the bridge, the operator noted that the barges were potentially being affected by the environmental conditions. Attempts were made to back down to slow the forward momentum of the barges toward the bridge. Once it was inevitable that the barges could not be stopped from hitting the bridge, the operator waved off the guide boat (skiff). The bridge sustained significant structural damage to the piling (Bent #10). The impact of the lead barge damaged the exterior concrete casing of the pile exposing the structural members. A vehicle weight restriction (15,000 pds GVW) was placed on the bridge until repair could be completed to the piling. There was no damage to the barge. No injuries and no pollution.

The incident occurred at approximately 0920. The CG was not notified of the incident. At approximately 1500, a third party contacted STA Fort Myers Beach to inquire about the weight restrictions placed on the bridge as a result of the incident. The investigator spoke with the o/o of the barges and the construction project manager for Jacobs Construction Co. to inquire about the failure to notify the CG of a reportable marine casualty as per 46 CFR 4.05-1.

Rcvd report via SOHV.  M/V W. W. DYER upbound TNR MM 256 with tow of 12 barges (10 loaded and 2 empty hoppers) and no CG inspected barges, allided with the ONEAL HWY Bridge.  Bridge closed for inspection.  M/V W. W. DYER proceeded to TNR MM 259 RDB for de-watering and temporary repair of damaged dry cargo barge (MAC 272) loaded w/Gypsum.  No pollution and/or injuries reported.  Bridge inspector/s cleared and re-opened bridge late evening of 8MAR06.  M/V W. W. DYER reports completed temp repairs and received clearance from NASD DO to proceed to Decatur, AL for CG Investigation Activity and damage survey AM 09MAR06.
T/B KIRBY 10417 ALLIDED WITH THE  FENDERING SYSTEM OF THE GALVESTON CAUSEWAY RAIL ROAD BRIDGE CAUSING MINOR DAMAGE TO THE FENDERING SYSTEM.  THE BARGE WAS BEING PUSHED BY THE UTV FREMONT.
The UTV MARY ELIZABETH caused the T/B HTCO 3006 to allide with the Galveston Casueway Fendering system causing damage to the fendering system and the TExDOT barge N22.

On March 6, 2006 the barge SC-219 was dropped off by the tug SAM M. at a mooring ball at the mouth of the Luce Creek. At that time the barge was loaded with about 976 tons of riprap. Between March 6-13, 2006 a local marine construction company removed approximately 350 tons of the riprap from the barge for a shoreline development project and loaded the timber and other debris onto the barge. 

At approximately 0930 on March 14, 2006 the unmanned barge dragged its mooring and was drifting in the Severn River. At approximately 1010 the barge allided with the Route 50 Bay Bridge (William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge). The barge now contained riprap, timber, and other rocks. 

At the time of the allision, winds were noted to be 22 knots, gusting to 28 knots out of the NW. The barge was in approximately 13.8 feet of water when the first CG asset arrived on scene.

There was no pollution or loss of life as a result of the allision; however, the allision caused damage to the barge and damage to the bridge. Vehicular bridge traffic was suspended and enforced by Maryland State Police. USCG Station Annapolis launched several assets and was the first on scene. Maryland's Department of Natural Resources also responded on scene. Additional CG assets transported two investigating officers from Sector Baltimore and the Structural Bridge Engineer to the scene. The Bridge Engineer cleared the bridge for vehicular traffic pending the removal of the barge. The investigative team conducted a preliminary survey verifying the seaworthiness of the barge and to document the scene. Once the owner was identified, two company tugs and a crew boat were dispatched to the scene. Upon arrival, one tug took the barge under control and towed it to a facility in Baltimore, MD for further investigation. The bridge was reopened to vehicular traffic.

N/B BELOW THE NED McWHERTER BRIDGE, PILOT MADE CONTACT WITH THE S/B BOAT ABOVE BRIDGE.  THE LOEDDING ELECTED TO RUN THE LEFT DESCENDNG SPAN.  ABOUT 200 - 250 FEET BELOW THE SPAN, THE TOW BEGAN TO FALL TOWARD THE RIGHT HAND PIER.  THE PILOT THROTTLED UP TO GET AS MUCH OF HIS TOW THROUGH THE BRIDGE.  WHEN THE TOW WAS 600 FEET THROUGH THE BRIDGE THE PILOT BACKED STERN OF TOW AWAY FROM PIER TO REDUCE IMPACT.  THE TOW LANDED ON THE 2ND COUPLING.  THE STERN OF THE (ING 4261) WAS DAMAGED.

On March 7, 2006, at 0415, the tug vessel AVENGER was transiting the Cerritos Channel when the mast of the tug vessel AVENGER struck the underside of the Commodore Heim Bridge. The vessel's mast is designed to be lowered into a horizontal position when the vessel is transiting an area with a height restriction.  In this incident the operator failed to lower the mast, leaving it in an upright position, as the vessel transited under the Commodore Heim Bridge. As a result of his action, the mast struck the bridge and was bent at a 40 degree angle.  The Commodore Heim's bridge operator reported no structural damage to the bridge

On 02MAR06 at 0530 near mm 287.3 Illinois River M/V ERNA E. HONEYCUTT was northbound with 8 loaded barges and 6 empty barges.  While navigating through the McDonough St. Bridge barge ING 7542 rubbed stbd side of protection cell.  Bridge tender notified and confirmed no damage to bridge.  02 personnel from MSU Chicago responded to meet vessel at Lockport Lock & Dam.  Confirmed no damage to barge ING 7542, pictures taken at scene.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 07MAR06 at 1210 near mm 254.1 Illinois River M/V LEMONT TRADER was southbound with 09 empty barges in tow.  Pilot noticed a set to stbd while making Seneca RR Bridge due to light wind blowing port to stbd and current set.  He attempted to correct but could not do so and rubbed right descending protection cell on up river side of bridge.

On January 19, 2006 at approximately 1500 hours the M/V Capt. Colle was heading north on the Mobile River Channel pushing a flexie barge and freight barge CBC 212. At the 3 Mile Creek (CSX Rail Road Bridge) the wind and current pushed the tow into the bridge fendering. The port side of the barge CBC 212 made contact with bridge fendering causing a 4 inch X 4 foot piece of wood fall into the water. The barge was not damaged, continued to it's next port of call without further incident.

On Jan 21, 2006 at approximately 1710 hours the M/V Martin Admiral was east bound in Pensacola Bay pushing several un-named barges. The tow cleared the Bob Sykes Bridge when the Martin Admiral made contact with the north fender works. Neither the vessel nor the bridge sustained damage. The tow continued on to their next port of call without further incident.

30JAN06, 0510:  M/V EDDIE TOUCHETTE is S/B on the Ouachita River @ M/M 54.7 when the T/B HINES 422 in her tow allided w/ a bridge w/ no damage noted to the barge.  Local PD inspected bridge and reported no damage.
No further damage, injuries or pollution reported.

With the assistance of a helper tug (M/V Bette Lynn), M/V Darin  Adrian transited southbound with 9 loaded barges at mm 403.1 under the Burlington Northern RR bridge.  The captain had the vessel at clutch speed with a box load on the port corner of the tow and a rake load on the starboard corner.  The captain came ahead approx. 2 knots after lining up for the bridge when the port barge set hard and caused the tow to go to the port, causing an allision of the port barge, CC 9281-B with the bridge.  One barge on the starboard string, MTC 281-B, rubbed against the protection fence of the other side of the bridge.  Four barges were set adrift from the tow, but were recovered by the M/V Bette Lynn and M/V Burlington, both vessels from Mattson Marine of Burlington.

On March 16, 2006 the M/V ASTRAL EXPRESS was outbound on the Weymouth Fore River when the vessel came into contact with the Quincy side of the Fore River Bridge.  Both the Master of the M/V ASTRAL EXPRESS and the docking pilot witnessed the allision but did not immediately report it to the Coast Guard.  When the docking pilot returned to station he notified the Coast Guard via cell phone.  No confirmation of damage was made by the Fore River Bridge tender, who was on duty at the time of the allision but received no radio transmission from the M/V ASTRAL EXPRESS of the incident.  The M/V ASTRAL EXPRESS was outside the Sector Boston AOR when the allision report was received, and notification was made to the vessel's next port of call.

On 01MAR06 at 2230 near mm 189 Illinois River M/V NORMAN P. PROEHL was pushing T/B CTCO 3011 when they brushed ground (bump and go), then allided with Lacon Highway bridge protection cell.  No damage to bridge reported and verified.  T/B CTCO 3011 sustained extensive damage to the headlog.  No injuries reported.  Post casualty chemical and alcohol testing was conducted in conjunction with this incident.

M/V Lime Rock transiting southbound pushing ahead 3 empty barges.  The Captain attempted to maneuver the vessel and tow to pass under the Sabula Rail Road Bridge.  The river was covered with 3-5" of ice, preventing the vessels from maneuvering accordingly.  Barge Kirby 30305 allided with the north bull nose of the bridge. Just prior to the allision, look out informed captain that they were going to allide with the bridge.  The Captain responded by backing down the tow, but was unable to stop the forward momentum of the tow.  This backing down resulted in barge Kirby 21003T to allide with the starboard side of the bridge, the guide rake of the bridge.

On 21 March 2006 at 1625 local time, the towing vessel CAPT TUCK, O.N. 509434 with the barge HT-207 on the nose allided with the already damaged Navassa RR Bridge fendering system causing slightly more damage.  Because the original damage had not yet been repaired, it is impossible to detail exactly what further damage this allision caused.  There was a temporary light placed on a piling after the first allision, and that piling was knocked down during this allision.

01 APR 2006 1900:  SFO Grand Haven notified MSD Grand Haven that the Tug DEFIANCE O.N. 502057 pushing the barge AMC300 O.N. 584983 allided with the north dolphin of the St Joseph CSX rail road bridge.  The north dolphin is approximately 150 feet from the bridge structure.  The bridge tender reported no damage to the bridge and the bridge is fully operational.  There was no damage to the barge.  

02 APR 2006  0900:  MSD IO arrives at St. Joseph to meet with company supervisor.  Conducted towing vessel inspection, inspected bridge dolphin and outer barge for damage.  The ACM300 was moored on the starboard side of another crane barge.  When the tug captain began pushing the AMC300 away from the crane barge the wind caught the AMC300 and pushed it into the dolphin of the CSX bridge.  The tug vessel captain corrected and pushed the barge up river to Consumers Asphalt dock.  There is an approximately 4 inch by 4 inch notch less than 1/2 inch deep in the north dolphin of the CSX rail road bridge from where the barge hit it.  The barge AMC300  has an approximately 4 inch by 4 inch dent less than 1 inch in the rub rail of the barge on the port side stern third.

The Tug CROSBY SKIPPER was pushing the loaded LPG barge APACHE inbound in Old Tampa Bay, FL. The Master started to make his turn into Rattlesnake when he noticed the steering would not go past 15 degrees stbd rudder. The tug was unable to complete the turn and allided with the Gandy Bridge. The Master tried each steering station, but with neg results. The Gandy Bridge was severely damaged, causing one lane to be closed. 

The Master of the CROSBY SKIPPER was able to reposition the tug and pull the barge off the bridge, and then safely transited into Targa Midstream Services. The barge APACHE was damaged in the incident, but no product was released.

While outbound transiting John's Pass, Madeira Beach, FL, with approx. 70 POB, vessel observed a small 17 ft. recreational vessel inbound.  Capt. of DOLPHIN RACER set up for a port to port pass.  The recreational vessel changed course making a sharp turn to port turning into the path of the DOLPHIN RACER.  The master of the DOLPHIN RACER put the throttles in neutral in an attempt to prevent a collision with the recreation vessel.  The outgoing current caused the DOLPHIN RACER to allide with the John's Pass bridge fender.

On 04 APR 06, at approx 1600, the M/V LIL RAY allided with the Almonaster Bridge while transiting through the Inner Harbor Navigational Canal.  There was no damage to the LIL RAY and the Almonaster Bridge sustained minor damage to a support brace.  No injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.  The apparent cause was vessels's ability to counter the swift current.

On 15MAR06 at 1810 near mm 287.3 Illinois River M/V ERNA E. HONEYCUTT was down bound with 11 barges in tow.  Vessel made controlled landing with EJ&E RR Bridge.  No damage to bridge reported and verified by MSU CHICAGO response team.  Barge ING 4656 sustained minor paint scrapes but no actual damage.  No injuries reported.
Vessel was west bound with tree empties, when the wind came up and caused it to make contact with the Galveston Causeway Bridge.

On 04 APR 06, at approx 1830, the barge SER 183 being pushed by the UTV MURRAY L. II, allided with the Rigolets Railroad Bridge on the Rigolets Pass while pushing 4 barges. No injuries or pollution resulted. There was minor damage to the barge which allided with the bridge and minor damage to the bridge.   The apparent cause was vessel's inability to counter rip-tide.

On 18MAR06 at 0720 near mm 270.8 Illinois River M/V OLMSTEAD was up bound with 12 barges in tow.  A controlled landing (allision) occurred at EJ&E RR Bridge with barge ING 2170.  No damage to bridge reported and verified by MSU CHICAGO response team.  No damage to barge ING 2170 other than minor paint scrapes.  No injuries reported.

32/68/06 

04/07/2006 - Received report that the OSV Challenger had allided with the Larose / Cutoff bridge at MM 35 on the ICWW. Inspector attended vessel to conduct inspection / investigation of vessel and circumstances. Vessel was able to lower the affected leg and maneuver away from the bridge prior to the CG Inspector arriving. Investigation concluded that there was no damage to the bridge or the vessel and that bad communication was the reason for the allision. It was stated by the Bridge Tender that the bridge was fully opened and had a clearance of 72'. The vessel made it approach and needed a clearance of 63' to pass safely. While maneuvering through the bridge opening, one leg made contact with the bridge and trapped vessel under bridge. As stated above, vessel lowered leg and maneuvered clear. Received all required reports for incident and completed as casework. Nothing pends with case. No enforcement will be conducted due to circumstances. Changed status of case and submitted for closure.
08 April 2006 1945: The ITB INTEGRITY/G L OSTRANDER allided with the CSX bridge, St. Joseph, MI.  Both the bridge tender and vessel personnel report no damages and no injuries.

4/05/2006 - Received report from the UTV Miss Crosby that their tow had allided with the fendering system on the Morgan City Railroad Bridge. Master stated that wind and current caught the drydock and shifted tow during approach through bridge opening. The fendering system suffered minor damage to the wooden vertical fenders, the bridge did not suffer any damage and was fully tested. No damage was reported to the drydock. All required reports received and all data entered into MISLE case. Changed status of case and submitted for closure.

On 11MAR06 at 1135 near mm 317 CSSC M/V DALE WHITE was pushing 04 empty hopper barges when barge MG 494 contacted/allided with center pier of Belt RR Bridge.  Barge MG 494 sustained seven inch fracture to the stbd bow (above waterline).  No damage reported to the bridge and verified by bridge inspectors.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 02MAR06 at 0930 near mm 287 Illinois River M/V JULIE WHITE was northbound below McDonough St. Bridge when stern of barges started to slide to stbd.  Vessel slowed down and landed barge OLY 306B up against protection cell to stop the slide.  No damage reported to bridge and verified by bridge tender.  No damage to barge OLY 306B.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

During loading operations on 27 Feb 06, the barge MARTHA E was observed listing towards the port stern quarter. A check of the compartments revealed water persent in the stern central space. While dewatering a patch was placed, covering a 3 inch hole located port aft portion of the space. Prior to getting u/w a 4 inch layer of cement was placed over patch. Then all manhole accesses were cleaned, lubricated and the knife edges were sealed with cement. The tug JUNE T hooked up tow to the MARTHA E and one other barge getting u/w on 02 Mar 06.

On the morning of 06 Mar 06 the MARTHA E was observed again listing to the port stern quarter. A check with the small boat showed the stern awash with no way to access the compartment that was patched. Before the small boat was recovered the JUNE T had a problem with their CPP that resulted in the JUNE T hitting MARTHA E. The damage was 4 ft x 6 ft hole to the JUNE T's port stern quarter. No confirmed observable damage to the MARTHA E. At around sunset that day the MARTHA E rolled over to the port and slowly capsized near the WNW  coast of Buru island. JUNE T cut the tow and maintained a radar watch through the night. The JUNE T alerted the local authorities of the situation. Divers were put in the water the next morning that conrfirmed that the MARTHA E remained afloat. The deck clear of anything that was secured to it. Shortly after the JUNE T departed the scene. Arrangements were made to salvage MARTHA E in the near future.

Activity transfered to FEACT August 2006. 

Frequent contact with Company representative between August 2006 and August 2007 while waiting for final dispostion of the vessel. Responsible Party reported in Jun 2007 that the barge would be sold to a foreign company.  He was directed to notifcy this office upon sale to arrange handover of all USCG issued documents.

On 06FEB06 at 1315 near mm 287 Illinois River M/V PAT WHITE pushing barge ART 485 rubbed up against (allision) rubber padding on protection cell of McDonough St. Bridge.  No damage reported to either bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 23 FEB 2006, MSU Paducah responded to a report from Sector Ohio Valley of an allision with the Scott-Fitzhugh Highway Bridge by the M/V SEVERN (ON 1092256).  Investigators interviewed the crewmembers involved and took statements.  No damage to the bridge was sustained.  Minor damage to one barge in tow.

Towing vessel Columbia was transiting south bound in Bayou Boeuf, LA pushing two empty barges.  The master of the towing vessel allowed his barge to strike and break a bridge fender at the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge.  The bridge was tested and determined not to be damaged.
M/V JOHN D. GEARY ALLIDED WITH THE IL SPAN BRIDGE PIER OF THE ICRR WHILE S/B ON THE OHIO RIVER PUSHING 28 LOADED HOPPER BARGES.  NO DAMAGE TO BRIDGE PIER.  MINOR DAMAGE OCCURRED TO TWO HOPPER BARGES.

On 12 APR 06, at approx 0130, the barge SER 211 being pushed by the UTV KEVIN D allided with the Rigolets Railroad Railroad Bridge while transiting the Rigolets Pass.  No injuries or pollution resulted.  The barge SER 211 sustained minor damage and there was minor damage to the bridge.  Apparent cause of allision was strong current and error in judgment of current. The barge and bridge are operational.

On 11APR06 at 0915 near mm 317.4 CSSC M/V LYDIA E. CAMPBELL was south bound with barge CBC 195 in tow when transiting the Cicero Ave. Bridge the rising header valves and stems contacted the bottom of the bridge.  No damage to bridge reported and bridge owner notified.  Barge CBC 195 sustained damage estimated at $5,000.00.  See damage survey associated with this case for further details.  No injuries reported.  

No action on Pilot as the valves on this barge were placed straight up when historically they were at a 90 degree angle.  At replacement, valves were placed at original angle.

On 06APR06 at 1420 near mm 332.6 Calumet River M/V CODY BOYD was south bound approaching the 92nd St. Bridge when winds picked up pushing tow towards the bridge.  Capt. of vessel called bridge and notified tender that he would be stopping tow and making a controlled landing (allision) on the bridge.  No damage to bridge reported.  No damage to barge MEM 2122 which made controlled landing on bridge.  No injuries reported.

On 07APR06 at 1350 near Miles Marker 270 Illinois River M/V LEMONT TRADER was s/b approaching EJ&E RR BRIDGE.  Steersman was setting to port and got head of the tow through the bridge but noticed the stern getting close to the protection cell.  Barge RMT 219B made a controlled landing (allision) against the bridge.  Bridge tender notified and no damage reported to bridge.  No damage to barge RMT 219B.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

M/V SUSAN L. STALL, PUSHING 25 LOADED HOPPER BARGES S/B AT MM 977.7, OHIO RIVER, ALLIDED WITH THE BRIDGE PIER ON THE RIGHT DESCENDING BANK SIDE OF THE MAIN CHANNEL.  ALLISION CAUSED SEVERAL BARGES TO BREAK AWAY, AND 3 BARGES TO SINK.  NO DAMAGE REPORTED TO THE BRIDGE.  BARGES LATER SALVAGED.  2 BARGES DETERMINED TO BE TOTAL LOSS.  SEE SURVEY REPORT (ECN 2628466 #08) FOR ALL DAMAGE DETAILS.  NO EVIDENCE OF MARINER NEGLIGENCE, MISCONDUCT, OR VIOLATION OF LAW AS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR IN THE CASUALTY.

On April 21, 2006 Sector Baltimore received a phone call from the MD pilot on board the M/V Bow Prosper reporting that the vessel suffered a loss of propulsion and had grounded while outbound of the port just south of the Key Bridge.  Vessel directed to anchor in the Annapolis Anchorage and await Coast Guard inspectors and investigators.  No pollution or damage was reported.  When Coast Guard investigators arrived on scene, they were told as per the captain that the vessel did not run aground,  but that it had the potential to do so.  It was determined that a pneumatic closure on the High fuel Suction from the service tank had closed erroneously and the low fuel pressure alarm resulted in engine shutdown. The vessel stayed inside the channel and when the vessel speed slowed to where the anchors could be dropped in accordance with ship procedures, the vessel did so and assessed the situation. It was determined that no grounding occurred.

The 2692 for this occurrence was misplaced and is not available on file.  The pilots names are also not known for this incident.

23APR06: The chemical tanker BOW PROSPER was being towed stern first through the Number 7 Railroad Bridge and Gilmerton Highway Bridge on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  The 
UTV JAMES R. MORAN was made up to the stern with a single line and the UTV CAPE HENRY was made up to the bow with a single line.  Both tugs were backing, with the CAPE HENRY being used to maintain alignment.  There was approximately 6 feet of clearance on each side of the vessel as it passed through the draw.  The starboard stern of the hull made contact with the railroad bridge fender system, but there was no damage to the vessels or fender system.

On 19APR06, M/V Alice was transiting downbound on the Green River with 6 empty open hopper barges.  It allided with the Rockport RR bridge.  The bridge was inspected, and no damage was found.  Also, no damage was reported to the barges.

On 18APR06 at 0110 near mm 254 Illinois River M/V W.W. CRUM had a loss of communication with the man on the head of tow while making Seneca RR Bridge (Chessie Railway Drawbridge).  The head of the tow was through the bridge but stern portion of empty barge MM 42 rubbed up against protection cell (allision) and broke 3 deck wires.  No damage reported to bridge.  No other damage to barge MM 42.  No injuries reported.

28 Apr 06:  UTV PATRICIA was westbound when passing under the Galveston Causeway pushing 2 barges.  UTV PATRICIA struck the temporary fendering system, which pushed into the BERTHA D (a construction barge on scene), which struck a concrete barrier.  No pollution or injuries.  Wind was the contributing factor.

On April 28, 2006 at 15:30, the mud barge CM 9B pushed by tug RITA M allided with the Rigolets Railroad Bridge.  Barge CM 9B suffered minor damage 9 feet above the water line.  The CM 9B was used by the ACOE as a mud barge to rebuild levees in Chalmette, LA following Hurricane Katrina.  Mud was loaded via truck in Port Bienville, MS and transported via ICW to Chalmette for levee repair.  The Bridge was closed to marine traffic pending repairs.  At 17:30, the Bridge was re-opened to rail traffic.  At 19:30, barge CM9B arrived at Port Bienville Industrial Park in Bay St. Louis for repairs.  No pollution, injuries.  Repair cost to barge CM9B less than $5,000.00.  Repair cost to bridge approximately $10,000.00.
Empress of the North struck Union Pacific Bridge KTD261 with the top most portion of the aft mast.  No damage to the bridge.  Vessel was being operated by Second Mate.

On April 1, 2006 at approximately 0115 hours the M/V RUSSELL P. PAINTER was pushing 9 barges in the area of Back Bay Biloxi (Pops Ferry Bridge) when the lead barge (PC108) allided with the bridge. The pilot was at the helm at the time of impact and he stated that he called the unidentified bridge attendant and she offered to open the bridge prior to his arrival. The pilot declined her opening the bridge because his approach was slow and he wanted to align his approach before she opened the bridge. The pilot said he expected her to watch his approach and open the bridge when he got closer, but she did not see his approach and he hit the bridge. The 2692 stated that the bridge sustained damage and the barges did not sustain any damage. The impact was slight because the tow was moving at approximately 2 miles per hour.

The UTV Miss Janice was headed S/B on the Port Allen Route on Feb 3, 2006. When coming around the bend at 21:55 towards the Gross Tete Bridge at mm 47 the pilot tried steer to the port side. The water level was at 22ft. and Morgan City was using precautionary assist tows at the time. The current was holding the head of the tow in and pilot could not line up properly which caused the allision to the bridge and damage to the protection peir. The bridge has been inspected by the LADOTD and repairs are underway. No damage to the vessel or the barges in tow. No pollution or injuries occured.
M/V Richard E. Waugh was pushing southbound 14 loaded and 1 empty barges through the Crescent Railroad bridge passage when ING 5760 allided with the bridge, causing a crack in the #1 wing tank.

M/V Butch Barras was pushing southbound 14 loaded barges underneath the Burlington RR Bridge.  The starboard lead barge, ACL 1115 rubbed against the protection cell of the bridge.  There was no damage to either the bridge or the barge.

On April 6, 2006, M/V Show Me State and tow of nine barges were transiting the Upper Mississippi River at the Sabula Railroad Bridge, river mile 535. One of the barges, CC-7953, rubbed lightly against the bridge protection pier of the railroad bridge, causing no damage to either vessel or bridge. Vessel and tow continued south on the river.
Recd report of M/V L.B. EDGIN w/3 empty dry cargo barges rubbing (allision) the CSX RR Bridge at CMR MM 190.5.  No damage to bridge and/or vessel reported.

Vessel upbound on Willamette River while passing under the half lifted Steel Bridge in downtown Portland, struck mast on lifted section of bridge.  A 20 ft piece of mast broke and fell to deck.  With the current water level of the river the vessel needed a lift of the lower and upper section in order to pass but bridge tender only opened the lower level.  Miscommunication between the vessel's operator and bridge tender resulted in no specific heights being exchanged between the vessel and bridge tender.

While transiting in the vicinity of Sunset Beach NC M/V SARA KAITLIN was pushing on barge ARLINGTON using a tender boat which came into contact with a pontoon from the bridge causing minor damage to handrail on bridge.

5/9/06 @ 1047L - The UTV SEA RAVEN was pushing the loaded tank barge ATC 23 southbound through the open draw of the Norfolk Southern Southern Branch Rail Road Bridge on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  While the tug was still in the draw of the lift bridge the bridge tender began to lower the bridge.  The starboard antennae of the SEA RAVEN may have made contact with the bridge.  There was no damage to the vessel or bridge.

The bridge tender stated that he received a call from an approaching train.  He checked for river traffic and saw the tug "a couple hundred feet away."  Because the bridge closes at .2 feet per second, he started his descent when the bow of the barge entered the open draw so that the bridge would be down for the train.  He stated the bridge was at 110 feet when the SEA RAVEN called and said they needed 105 feet of clearance.  The bridge tender stated the tug cleared by a few feet.  This incident was referred to the Commander, Fifth Coast Guard District Bridge Branch for followup action.

M/V James Buky and tow of five loaded barges was traveling southbound on the Upper Mississippi River around mile 480. As the vessel approached the Illinois Central Railroad Drawbridge, the Master reported experiencing a swift current in the river. The current pushed the barge further to starboard than was intended, causing the stern-most starboard barge of the tow to come into contact with the bridge protection cell. Minor damage was done to the barge and the bridge protection cell remained undamaged.

The M/V DERRYL MCKINNEY was eastbound in the GICW pushing the empty coal barge M/G 112, approaching the Dauphin Island Bridge, when the DARRYL MCKINNEY softly grounded immediately outside the bridge on the north side of the channel. When the tow got back underway, the barge made contact with the north fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained to the fender system or the barge as a result of this incident. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident. The master reported that buoy #14 just west of the bridge was missing, contributing to the incident. Upon verification by ATON team, a BNM was issued the following day, and a temporary buoy placed at the location.

Received a report that the tug EMILY CHERAMIE with the crane barge FRACTOR, allided with the Bayonne Bridge.  The tug was made up to the crane barge which was in the process of lifting the spud from a dredge barge.  At the time of the incident the boom on the crane was fully extend and when the tug began to back dow (aiding the crane in lifting the spud), the boom allided with the bridge.  

No damage was sustained as a result of the allision.

On October 21, 2005, at approximately 1350, the UTV PONCE INLET (O.N. 546748) pushing the un-inspected barge LOL 102 allided with the south fendering system of the Ortega River Bridge. CG IOs attended vessel and administrated a breath alcohol test to the master in addition IOs conducted a UTV examination, details of this examination revealed that the UTV was not in compliance with Part 27 of the 46 CFR, in addition there were other discrepancies (please refer to MISLE Activity No. 2520736 for details). It has been determined that the cause for the allision as the inability of the master to realize the proximity of the UTV/Barge combination to the bridge, and the lack of communication between the bow watch stander and the master.  

The Master will be referred for enforcement.  No further investigation needed.

05APR06: Towing Vessel NANCY B (607444) was transiting northbound on the Atlantic Intercoastal Waterway (AICW) pushing 2 deck barges (TCC28/TCC29).  At approximately 1130, the barge in front allided on its starboard side with the fendering system of the Morehead City bridge.  The allision caused no damage to the barge but broke 4 or 5 of the vertical fender boards.  

The cause of the allision was a perpendicular current caused by a large vessel moored at the NC State Port.  The current in the AICW was bouncing off the hull of the vessel moored at the NC State Port and caused the tug/barge to drift to starboard while transiting the bridge fendering system.  The operator immediately notified the USCG and continued his voyage with no further incident.  CG-2692 received.  No enforcement action taken.  Case closed.

M/V Charlotte was heading northbound with a tow of 4 loaded barges. While traversing the Burlington Railroad Bridge, the tow was set towards the turntable portion of the bridge. Barge KIRBY 29308B allided with the bridge's upper bull nose, receiving a crack at mid-barge. The bridge sustained no damage.

18APR06-  Tow being pushed ahead by M/V BADGER allided with the sheer fence of the Hannibal Railroad Bridge.  Barges CC95118 and BUNGE 459 broke from the tow after contact with the fence.  Unspecified harbor tugs assisted reassmbling the tow.  M/V BADGER then proceeded without furthur incident.

23MAY2006:  Personnel from Norfolk Souther R/R reported that damaged timber protruding from fence had been removed. (See evidence for further detials)

On 01MAY06 at 2250 near mm 288 Illinois River M/V DALE WHITE was north bound with 08 barges in tow.  While making Cass St. Bridge, tow landed on upper left descending protection cell (allision) with barge C-543.  No damage to bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  

08JUN06 found out Master was at the helm during this incident.

5/19/06 @ 1430L - The UTV AIRES was pushing five loaded gravel barges east bound on the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River en route the Vulcan facility near the Campostella Bridge.  As the tow passed through the draw of the Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge 5 freight barge B-137 allided with the bridge fender system.  There was no damage to the tug or barges, but the bridge fender system was damaged.  Drug and alcohol tests ordered by the marine employer.

While transiting the McDonough St. Bridge M/V MELINDA BRENT pushing barge KIRBY 28706 rubbed the rubber on the fender wall of the bridge.  No damage reported to bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

The M/V MELVIN L KING was northbound in the Tombigbee Waterway, pushing three loaded hopper barges and the loaded caustic soda barge OL 106. The OL 106 was the starboard aft barge in a 2x2 configuration. As the tow was passing under the Jackson RR Bridge, Jackson, AL, the OL 106 made contact with the fender system of the bridge, resulting in an approximate 2 foot section of the rail of the bridge fender system to break off. Another approximate six foot section of fender railing was dislodged, and left hanging loose. No damage was sustained to the bridge itself as a result of this allision. The barge sustained an approximate four inch deep by six feet long indentation outside an aft starboard void, on the starboard side hull, approximately one foot below the deck and nine feet from the stern. 

The master stated he had made this passage regularly over the last nine years, and he felt that this time he had waited a moment to long to make the swing of the tow under the bridge. 

Sector Mobile Inspectors instructed the owner/operators of the barge to continue to its destination in Columbus, MS to offload prior to conducting required permanent repairs. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

UTV DIANE B. SIEGEL was down bound at MM 88.9 on the Tombigbee River negotiating the Jackson Railroad Bridge when the port stern corner of the barge C257 struck the fender work around the bridge pier.  The rubber bumper on the fender system was pulled off.  No other damage to the bridge or the barge was noted. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

On 09MAY06 at 1300 near mm 271 Illinois River M/V LEMONT TRADER pushing 11 barges south bound rubbed the protection cell of the EJ&E RR Bridge with barge RCI 253B.  No damage to bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

M/V MARHTA MAC made a controlled landing (allision) on the protection cell at McDonough St. Bridge with barge MST 819.  No damage reported to bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

24 May 2006 @1030L - The UTV POOLES ISLAND was towing a dredge pipe line and associated pontoon using a line approximately 15 feet long from it's stern.  As the vessel was attempting to tow the pipe and pontoon through the channel span of the Lesner Bridge at the Lynnhaven Inlet, the pontoon struck the fendering system of the bridge, causing minor damage to the wood.  The operator of the POOLES ISLAND incorrectly assumed that a second vessel picked up a trailing line from the pipe in tow, and was going to assist in keeping the pipe in line and straight.  The second vessel never picked up the trail line.

This is the second such incident involving the POOLES ISLAND in May 2006.  As a result, Sector Hampton Roads requested the vessel's owner/operator prepare a written tow plan and train all crewmembers in the contents of the plan.  The plan was received and is attached as correspondence.

M/V RALPH E. PLAGGE with 15 loaded hopper barges allided with the EJ&E RR Bridge, Joliet IL mm 270 Illinois River.  Barge T13537B made a controlled landing against the protection cell.  No damage reported to bridge or barge.  No injuries reported.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 02 May 06 at approxiametly 1340. the UTV Jean Pierre Cenac was headed Southbound at mm 4  of the Atchafalya River when the lead barge CTCO 345 allided with the Simmsport Railroad Bridge. The damage to the CTCO 345 consisted of a 14ft crack in the port bow to the centerline of the barge further defined by activity #2640105. A Chip in the piling was reported on the bridge, however,  Bridge Maintence reported no damage on the Simmsport Railroad Bridge. There was no pollution, or injuries involved with this incident.

M/V Angela K was heading downbound on the Mississippi River at the Clinton Railroad Bridge, with a tow of 15 loaded barges. While transiting the bridge, barge MTC330B briefly rubbed the left descending pier of the bridge. No damage was done to either barge nor bridge, and tow continued traveling south.
The M/V CALUMET was transiting Manistee Harbor in bound and struck the U.S. 31 Memorial Bridge.
On 07 June 2006 the passenger vessel (P/V) Harbor Bell struck the Northern Avenue Bridge after experiencing a loss of propulsion. No major damage to the bridge or the vessel. No injuries reported.

M/V Show me state pushing southbound 12 loaded barges landed on the right decending pier of the Burlington North Santa Fe Railroad Bridge with barges CC-8259 and MTC-373.  There was no damaged reported for either vessels or the bridge.

On 09 April 06 at approximately 0430 hrs, UTV MISS ROSLYN was pushing 4 empty barges:  T13929, T13811, ING5711, ING5751 heading westbound.  Barge T13811 rubbed against the Galveston Causeway RR Bridge due to wx and current.  No pollution, injuries, or damages.

28 Jun 06:  Investigation complete.

The M/V EDNA was pushing the partially loaded open hopper barge DALE PYATT 561 from the Rt. 90 Bay St. Louis Bridge demolition site, Biloxi, MS to Henderson Point for offloading.
