As the tow proceeded under the CSX railroad bridge, a deckhand on the barge utilized a handheld radio to attempted to instruct the master of the tow to turn to port. The master misunderstood the instruction and turned the vessel to starboard resulting in the starboard bow of the DALE PYATT striking the west fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained by the barge as a result of this incident. The west fender system sustained four broken timbers. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

On 14 Jun 06 at approximately 0850 hrs, UTV DONNA T allided with Pelican Island bridge, GIWW MM 356.1, while transiting eastbound causing substantial damage to southeast corner of bridge fendering system due to incoming tide.  Bridge operations remain normal and vessel traffic not impeded.  UTV proceeded with transit and moored at a nearby facility.  No reported injuries or pollution.  Damages to the fendering system of PELICAN ISLAND BRIDGE.  UTV had two construction type barges:  utility/deck barge MCD370 and crane barge SAND FIDDLER.  MCD370 is barge that impacted the fendering system.

12 June 2006 - UTV KIMBERLY TURECAMO towing empty tank barge DELAWARE through the Chelsea Street Bridge. UTV FREEDOM was made off to the stern and Pilot was on the deck of the barge. As DELAWARE proceeded through the opening at approx 1-1.5 knts, the barge rubbed on the Chelsea (north) side fendering system. No damage resulted to fendering system or barge. No injuries or pollution reported. No further action.

Rcvd report of the M/V MARY BURK LILES w/3 loaded asphalt barges in-tow, alliding with L&N RR Bridge TNR MM 100.5, no damage to bridge and/or tank barges.  The tow vessel's VHF antenna's and anchor light made contact and were damaged as vessel passed under the bridge.

On 24-Jun-06 at 14:55, tug VANCE M. THOMPSON, while pushing two empty open hopper barges through the Rigolets Railroad Bridge, the lead barge, SER 201, allided with the bridge.  Barge SER 201 sustained a 6" wide by 10' long rip on the starboard bow that was 9' above the water line.  The Rigolets Railroad Bridge was subsequently closed to marine traffic indefinitely pending damage assessment and repair.

A semi-submersible ship carrying huge road-deck sections for the new Tacoma Narrows Bridge had to turn back when the giant load brushed the underside of the existing bridge.  The deck sections themselves didn't strike the old bridge, but a temporary scaffolding atop the sections grazed it.  The ship immediately stopped, turned around & headed back to Tacoma's Commencement Bay.   The semi-submersible vessel was being positioned underneath the bridge at the time by 2 tugs & reportedly transiting at less than 1 knot at the time of incident.

THE PILOT STATED HE MADE HIS APPROACH TO THE BROOKPORT BRIDGE.  HE WAS POINTING HARD TO THE KENTUCKY SHORE SO HE BROUGHT THE TOW BACK AROUND SO HE WAS POINTING BACK AT THE GREEN LIGHT ON THE BRIDGE.  A GUST OF WIND HAD CAUGHT HIM, AND  HE DECIDED TO DRIVE (POWER) IT THROUGH AT FIRST AND THEN DECIDED TO STOP AND TRY TO CORRECT, BUT IT WAS TOO LATE.  THE TOW CAUGHT THE CORNER OF THE (LSI 3205) ON RIGHT DESCENDING PIER OF THE BROOKPORT BRIDGE ON KENTUCKY SIDE.
On 22JUN06 at 0958 M/V MAUMEE allided with the NE bridge fender of 92nd St. Bridge.  No damage reported to bridge or vessel.  Bridge tender was notified of situation.

M/V Kelly Rae Erickson was pushing ahead a tow of 15 loaded barges southbound and crossing the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge. While traversing the bridge, the starboard front-most barge, MTC 608 came into contact with the sheer fence protection of the right descending pier of the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge. The damage resulted in twenty broken timbers of the sheer fence and some damage to the barge located above the waterline. Both vessel and bridge were able to continue normal operations.

TUG REPORTED THEIR BARGE ALLIDING WITH THE FENDERING AT THE HACKENSACK JACKNIFE BRIDGE (MM 7.7) ON THE HACKENSACK RIVER, CAUSING EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO THE FENDERING OF THE BRIDGE.  DAMAGE DID NOT AFFECT OPERATION OF THE BRIDGE FOR MARINE TRAFFIC.

Investigation revealed no damage to barge.  Damage to bridge appears to be restricted to the navigational lights and minor damage to the fendering system.  No structural damage.  Apparent cause appears to be restricted navigational approach and limted visbility.

Data collection level of investigation conducted in accordance with message dtg 051545Z OCT 01 from COMLANTAREA COGARD Portsmouth, VA //AM//.

At approximately 0300 hours (local time), the tug CLEARWATER was blowing a steady 35 mph with gusts to 50 mph.  The tug was pushing 3 barges.  In an effort to get a clear lineup past the floating wall of the McNarry Dam, the master backed too close to the Washington State side bank of the Columbia River and hit hard against the rocks.  The grounding sheared off the port rudder, damaged the propeller, and snapped through the port propeller shaft.  Due to the loss of propulsion on the port side, the tow was subject to the wind's power.  As the vessel landed against the wing wall, barge ST 33 hit the upper end of the wall and the empty grain barge sustained damage.

M/V Frank R Alter was headed southbound at UMR mile marker 309.9 making approach to the Hannibal Railroad Bridge.  Barge AGS248 allided with the left descending bank protection cell due to cross current.  The framework that holds the timbers dislodged and struck the barge at the # 5 wing tank on the port side at the 10' draft mark.  Barge was dropped in the Hannibal, MO fleet, and off-loaded.

11 July 2006 @ approximately 0800L - Two S&ME workers were attempting to secure a soil sample drilling barge adjacent to the Black Narrows Bridge in Chincoteague, VA using the barge's two spuds.  The barge was being maneuvered by an open jon boat with a 15 horsepower outboard motor.  The forward spud was successfully lowered but began to drag across the muddy bottom because of the current.  The barge and jon boat drifted toward the bridge.  Both of the crewmen were focused on getting the second spud lowered to keep the rig from drifting into the bridge.  The crewman aboard the barge was facing south, away from the bridge.  Intent on setting the second spud, he was not aware of the distance remaining between the barge and bridge.  An I-beam along the bridge span met him squarely in the back and he was caught between the I-beam and a part of the barge's drill rig.  The force crushed his chest and caused severe internal trauma.  He was pronounced dead at CG Station Chincoteague by local EMS.  See the IO Statement, attached as ECN 2710039 #20 KRS, for details.

7/11/06 - TUG JO MARY while pushing a deck barge with a crane allided with the Broad Causeway North Bridge.  The crane's boom had not been lowered and it became caught on the bridge.  Miminal damage to the bridge or the crane.

At approximately 1150 03July2006 MSD WPB received a phone call from the bridge tender concerning an allision with the Jupiter Island Bridge and the Tug Lee.  The bridge tender reported that sometime around 2300 02 July the Tug Lee was pushing the Barge JMC-143 southbound through the bridge when the port bow of the barge struck the NE side of the wooden catwalk under the bridge causing some damage to the catwalk and the scraped the wooden guards on the opposite side of the bridge as it pushed through.  Bridge supervisor inspected bridge and all lights and structure sound for operation.

   The captain of the tug stated that he has transited the same bridge 100-150 times and never had a problem, however on this occasion the bridge tender turned on flood lights as he made his approach to the bridge causing him to lose his night vision and allide with the bridge.    

    The bridge tender stated that the flood lights are standard practice for the bridge openings at night. The white lights are oriented to shine across the channel and not into vessel traffic.

On 13 July 2006, the UTV MISS SUSAN (O.N. 565934) was pushing the barge BUNGE 206B (O.N. 505213) on a course of 270 degrees at .5 knots. While trying to pass through the CSX railroad bridge, the barge rubbed the fender system causing damage to a light on the fender system on the bridge. The contact caused $500.00 in damage to the bridge light. There was no damage to the barge. On scene conditions were daylight, with good visibility. On scene weather was clear with a southwest wind 10 - 15 knots, the current was moving to the west at 1 knot.

WHILE N/B UMR MM 1.3 THRU CAIRO HWY BRIDGE, PILOT HAD LARGEST PART OF TOW THRU WHEN LEFT HAND DRAFT SET TOW TOWARD THE LEFT HAND PIER.  TOW STERN STEERED AWAY FROM PIER BUT COULD NOT OVERCOME DRAFT.  STBD STERN LANDED AGAINST PIER, STBD HEAD TOUCHED GROUND IN SHALLOW WATER & TOW BROKE APART.

ON 26 APR 06, THE TOWING VESSEL R.G. MAYES, PUSHING 15 LOADED BARGES, MADE A CONTROLLED LANDING ON THE PIER OF THE NED MCWHERTER BRIDGE LOCATED AT MM 66.3, TNR.  OPERATOR WAS FORCED TO MAKE A LANDING WHEN HE REALIZED THAT HE COULD NOT OUTRUN THE SET OF THE CURRENT.  OPERATOR THEN BACKED THE TOW TO A COMPLETE STOP, AND ALLOWED THE CURRENT TO LAND THE TOW ON THE BRIDGE.  ONCE THE TOW LANDED ON THE BRIDGE, THE OPERATOR WAS ABLE TO SLOWLY MANUEVER THE TOW OFF THE BRIDGE PIER AND CONTINUE WITH HIS TRANSIT.  NO DAMAGE TO TOW OR BRIDGE OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF THIS INCIDENT.

On 31 July 06 the UTV Ted W Ewing with 6 hopper barges was north bound at MM 57 Port Allen Alternate Route. When passing under the Morley Railroad Bridge, the Captain steered to the starboard and could not bring it back to port. The barge ACBL 4353 hit the bridge.  6 fenders, one Piling Cluster and one walk-way was damaged. No damage to the barges, pollution or injuries resulted. On 24 Aug 06 Repair bid was submitted to company and repairs to the bridge started.

On 1 Oct 06 UTV Clearwater, Pushing 4 empty barges ahead, down river when it allided with the Oregon side of the Hood River Bridge abutment.  Vessels lashing lines parted.  No further damage oil, or pollution.

On July 12, 2006 M/V Tallapoosa moored 4 loaded open hopper barges full of rocks, just north of the Orange Beach toll bridge on the Intracoastal Waterway. The barges were on standby to be offloaded in the area.  On July 13, 2006 at approximately 0200 hours the barges were seen adrift by an Orange Beach Police Officer.  The barges drifted down stream and one of the barges CA 511 hit the South East bridge fendering causing minor damage.  The barge did not sustain any damage.  The barges were secured to the banks by the M/V Tallapoosa.  No other damage was reported.

On August 24, 2006 @ 0800L, the CFV JOANN B was underway in the Chincoteague Channel outbound for a fishing trip on the Atlantic Ocean.  As the vessel began to pull away from moorings located near the Chincoteague Swing Bridge, the operator placed the throttle in neutral to swing the vessel using the current.  While in neutral, the current pushed the starboard quarter into a support pillar of the Chincoteague Swing Bridge.  The allision damaged a PVC pipe conduit containing telephone wires.  Coast Guard Station Chincoteague personnel boarded the vessel and conducted alcohol testing on the operator.

On 6 February 2006, barge WTT 409B allided with the Pekin Railroad bridge (mile 152 ILR) while under tow by the M/V W.A. KERNAN. At time of allision, towboat operator was lining up to make southbound approach with the bridge. Due to misalignment with the narrow bridge span, barge rubbed the left descending bank protection cell, causing no damage to the barge, bridge, or tow vessel.

On August 23, 2006 at 1810, the vessel GORDON V SR. was transiting west down the ICW mile 11.5.  An east bound tow radioed the vessel GORDON V SR. and informed the master that he could see the barge crane's boom above the bridge.  The master of the GORDON V SR. immediately put his vessel in full reverse, but was unsuccessful in coming to a complete stop.  The barge crane's boom rose above the bridge by about five feet and  struck the very top portion of the bridge's concrete guardrail breaking off two small pieces. LA state police inspected guardrail, said there was no significant damage and did not make a report.  Barge crane's boom was also undamaged from allision.  No injuries or pollution resulted from incident.

While moored at the dock in Laughlin, Nevada on the Colorado River, an out of control jet ski struck the bow of the ARR 18.  The operator and the passenger on the jet ski entered the water.  The operator was pulled to safety by the crew of the ARR 18 and the passenger was recovered by bystanders.

M/V Loree Eckstein while S/B on the IL River at MM 151.2, allided with the Pekin R/R Bridge (LDB pier) with its 3rd barge (OLY-301B) back on the port string.  Allision broke 3 wires. No other damage to barge, bridge or tow.

9/03/2006 -   UTV E.J. RICHARD, pushing one red flag barge, allided with the Dulac Swing bridge in La Fourche Parish, LA.  There was no structural damage to the bridge.  There was damage to the wooden fendering system and minimal damage to the barge.

Vessel allided with railroad bridge on 05 September 2006, and caused damage to RADAR scanner/antenna and VHF-FM antenna while transiting underneath bridge; Vessel made contact with bridge deck, not support pilings/stanchions.  Refer to Investigating Officer's comments in correspondence section for further details.

Tank barge CONNECTICUT allided with the Amtrak rail road bridge over the Connecticut River between Old Saybrook and Old Lyme, destroying the northeast (Old Lyme north) fendering system for the railroad bridge.  No injuries and no oil was spilled as a result of the allision.  Post casualty drug and alcohol testing was completed.

M/V JOSEPH M. HAMILTON was n/b with three loaded barges in tow near mm 239 Illinois River when vessel's mast struck underside of Ottawa RR Bridge, causing mast to break off and fall onto the vessel.  No injuries reported and no post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.  Verified with bridge superintendent that there was no damage sustained to the bridge.  MSU Chicago boarded vessel at Dresden Island Lock and Dam to conduct investigation.

02 Oct 06 Rcvd document from vessel rep. that shows height of vessel as 47 ft. 5 in.
SECTOR UPPER REPORTS THAT THE M/V MARY D ALLIDED WITH THE CASS ST BRIDGE IN JOLIET, IL AT MM 288 ILR. THE MARY D WAS PUSHING 5 EMPTY BARGES AND REPORTED NO DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE OR BARGE ACO 132.
While transiting out bound with two assists tugs, M/V Spruceglen allided with the 92nd Street Bridge.  No damage was done to bridge or vessel.

M/V Billy Joe Boling was Norhtbound with 15 barges in tow when they allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.4 on the Illinois River.  Damage was done to the lower protection cell and barge MEM 2209.  A surveyor was brought out to assess all damages.

STBD bow rake corner damaged in a 4' x 4' section all above the water line.

On 25AUG06 at 0445 Station Calumet Harbor notified MSU Chicago of some barges that had broken loose in the Calumet River area.  Barges MBL 415 and DAS 1B were recovered off of the stern of M/V SPRUCEGLENN AT 0500 and secured at KCBX dock by M/V TANNER.  Barges IMT 109 and IMT 201 were secured in fleet under Skyway Bridge by M/V TANNER.  Prior to these events happening, one of the four broken loose barges caused damage to Crowley's Yacht Yard dock and a sailboat named EQUAL TERMS at mm 332.2 of the Calumet River.  MSU Chicago IO conducted investigation into the matter by gathering witness statements and collecting photographs of the dock damage and sailboat damage.  The cause as to why the barges broke loose and which barge caused damage to Crowley's Yacht Yard dock and sailboat EQUAL TERMS is unknown due to lack of information and unknown circumstances.

LONGFELLOW BRIDGET was ascending the boat ramp out of the Charles River when the port side aft bilge-bottom contacted a submerged object. Master found deformation to the hull in the lower port bilge area but determined that the hull appeared to be intact and sound and kept the vehicle in service. On the next trip, more than half way through the tour on the Charles River, the Master noticed the bilge pump come on (indicator light and visible discharge) for that same bilge. It reportedly activated for a "few seconds", shut off and then reactivated three more times for the same amount of time. The Master took the vessel out of the water and it was taken out of service. 

Object later found to be a large rock that had been dislodged from the side wall due to local construction. The rock had rolled down onto the ramp, below the surface of the water. It was later removed.

On the 30th of October 2006 - F/V ALEXANDER II struck Townsends Inlet Bridge on the vessel's port side amidships.  The vessel drifted over while trying to transit through the bridge. No damage was done to either the bridge or vessel.
While traveling down bound at MM 288 on the Des Plaines River, M/V Bill Arnold rubbed the right descending lower protection cell of the Cass Street Bridge.  No damage to barge or bridge.

UTV TYON NO 5, pushing an empty uninspected spud barge BWS 104 (fwd spud removed and on deck w/aft spud up). TYON NO 5 was heading westbound on the ICW to the P&R Shipyard when the aft spud allided with the bottom of the West Larose lift bridge @ mm 25.7 on the ICW. No pollution, no injuries, no reportable damage to the bridge, spud was bent back 45 degrees.

01AUG2006 0930: Notified that a 25'9" push boat pushing a 30'x60' deck barge traveling south in San Carlos Bay allided with the fendering system of the Sanibel 'A' span bridge.  Neither the bridge nor the vessel sustained damage.

Upon interviewing the Master and crewmembers, all stated that as the vessel was approaching the bridge at approximately four (4) knots, the current caught the barge and an allision occurred with the bridge fendering system.

Vessel  was making a turn to return from their evening cruise from down bound to upbound Ohio River just above the Clay Wade Bailey Bridge.  Vessels Starboard quarter at the rub rail allided with the bridge pier.
VESSEL N/B ON OHR AT/NEAR MM 980, BARGE MEM-92109 ALLIDED WITH A PIER OF THE CAIRO HWY BRIDGE, BREAKING 11 WIRES.
On 18 Sep 2006, approx 1830 the Tug Alexandra was pushing barge Mobro 907 through the Stuart,FL FEC railroad bridge when the barge allided with the NW corner of the bridge.

M/V Loree Eckstein made a controlled landing on the pier of the Ruby Street Bridge at MM 289 on the Illinois River with the starboard stern barge, DE-8221, to straighten its tow.  

No damage to bridge or barge.

25 AUG 06: While M/V Bridgett Caulley was IVO Greenville, MS a leak was discovered in the stern void of the tank barge Kirby 15301.

No further injuries, pollution or damage was reported as a result of this incident.

Alcohol and / or drugs did not appear to play a role in this incident.

15 OCT 06: U/W South bound on the Lower Mississippi River at mile marker 531, Vessel tow allided with the Greenville bridge.  

No further damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

S/B WITH 21 BARGES.  WHILE NAVIGATING BRIDGE NEAR MM 976 OHR, TOW WAS SET BY CURRENT AND OPERATOR UNABLE TO POWER OUT.  PORT STRING BARGE SCNO 8026 RUBBED LEFT DESCENDING BRIDGE PIER.  NO DAMAGE TO PIER REPORTED, MINOR INSET IN WAY OF #4 PORT WING TANK

M/V ANNE B allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.5 on the Illinois River.

No damage to vessel or bridge.

While travelling down bound at MM 270.5 on the Illinois River, M/V Gladiator allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.

No damage to bridge.

Welding popped on the STBD Bow corner of barge ART 195 where contact was made with bridge.

The PARKER DRILLING RIG 21B was moored at the A&B Shipyard in Amelia, LA and was secured and abandoned due to the incoming hurricane Katrina. When personnel returned to the scene after the hurricane, the rig was found to have broken loose from it's moorings and was resting against the Bayou Beouf railroad swing bridge. No injuries, no pollution, no damage to the bridge, but there were broken bits from the vessel and the piling it was moored to at the shipyard was broke.

Old case, was completed with limited information.

On 16  Oct 2006 M/V MISS JANICE was pushing 6 empty hopper barges, unintentionally allied with the Krotz Springs Rail Road swing bridge.  No damage was done to the two barges that hit the bridge, nor was there damage to the bridge.

On 13 Oct 06 the UTV SIVI SHIRAH was heading northbound on the Port Allen Alt Route. On approach to the Bayou Sorrell Bridge the UTV SIVI SHIRAH was advised of a bad cable on the bridge by UTV Donald E. Clark. UTV Sivi Shirah contacted the bridge about the problem and was told that the problem had been resolved. As they passed through the bridge one of the barges caught the cable which caused it to break. Vessel did not come into contact with the bridge at any time. No damge to the vessels, no pollution and no injuries.

While transiting the Atchafalaya River, the OSV Gulf Scout made contact with the underside of the old Hwy 90 Bridge.  The bridge is charted as the Long Allen Fixed Bridge, with a vertical clearance of 50 feet listed.  The OSV Gulf Scout clearance is 51.9 feet.  The mast light was broken, but the bridge sustained no damage.  The master of the vsl claims he  calculated the vessel air draft with the charted clearance and thought he would make it through.

VESSEL AND TOW, U/B MM 41 TNR, STOPPED BELOW BRIDGE TO WAIT FOR A BOAT TO PASS.  CAPTAIN STARTED WORKING AHEAD AND STEER AT AN ANGLE TO LINE UP FOR THE BRIDGE.  THE TOW SET TOWARD THE BRIDGE PIER AND CAPTAIN OVERSTEERED AND DID NOT GET THE SWING STOPPED IN TIME.  STBD STERN LOAD HIT THE BRIDGE PIER.

On 22 Oct 06 the UTV JOSEPH M. HAMILTON was pushing 2 red flag barges southbound on the Atchafalaya River when the tow came in contact with the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge. The stern of the Hinds 0431 rubbed against the bridge pier.  No damage, pollution or injuries resulted. The captain stated that he normally runs the wider span of the bridge but due to the height of the tug he had to go through the swing span.

M/V NANCY ALLEN WAS TRANSITTING THE IL R/R BRIDGE WITH 4 LOADED BARGES WHEN  A COUPLING BETWEEN VL7782 AND VLX7550 BROKE CAUSING THE LEAD BARGE SCNO8146'S PORT BOW CORNER RUBBED THE INSIDE OF THE KENTUCKY SPAN OF THE BRIDGE.

AT 10:05, M/V CAPT O.A. FRANKS WAS N/B AT MM 28 CMR WHEN HE GROUNDED 2 BARGES (ING 1949, ING 2095) IN THE STBD STRING.  BARGES WERE WORKED OFF GROUND W/O ANY DAMAGE.

AT 13:00, PILOT REPORTED BARKLEY LOCK HAD INSCREASED DISCHARGE FROM 18,000 TO 29,00 AND HE COULD NOT PUSH THROUGH THE EUREKA BRIDGE AT MM 50 AND TOW STALLED OUT.  TOW FLOATED DOWN AND LANDED ON THE RD BRIDGE PIER.  NO DAMAGE REPORTED TO EITHER TOW OR BRIDGE.

M/V JOHN J. BOLAND was proceeding downbound stern first from Hennepin Point to the Detroit Edison Power Plant in Trenton.  Two tugs were escorting the M/V JOHN J. BOLAND during this evolution.  As the M/V JOHN J. BOLAND started through the Grosse Ile bridge transiting to the west the bos'n gave 48ft. to the good.  The tug then started to pull the stern to the east to clear the center again.  The bos'n said we were floating rapidly and tried using the stern thruster to keep it off the bridge but couldn't override the tugs power. We came up on the east side of the bridge resulting in damage to the starboard quarter of the ship.  No damage to bridge.

Up bound within the Buffalo River: Tug Washington lead tug of barge Primary 1 with tug Gregory Busch behind pushing.  Arrangement departed east side (river right) of river proceeding to starboard turn at CSX bridge with a 18 - 24 knot gust off port side.  Lead tug proceeded to the center of channel with barge and push tug being set to starboard with gusting wind and insufficient way on, track insufficient to clear bridge fendering system, barge starboard forward rake struck bridge fendering system.  Inspection of barge concluded that starboard section of rake suffered several vertical and horizontal indentations however internal inspection provided no broken welds or distorted frames.  Referred for enforcement.

TOW OF M/V DOTTIE JOHNSON ALLIDED WITH RDB BRIDGE PIER WHILE TRANSITTING UNDER BRIDGE.  ALLISION WAS CAUSED BY COMBINATION OF WHEEL WASH FROM M/V HORTENSE B. INGRAM TESTING IT'S ENGINES ON RDB AND PILOT ERROR WHEN PILOT OVERSTEERED ATTEMPTING TO CORRECT SET.  DAMAGE LIMITED TO 16' LONG INSETS ALONG PORT SIDE OF BARGE RF415.  NO DAMAGE NOTED TO BRIDGE PIER.

Master of the M/V Ryan Cenac reports hitting the Harrisonburg Bridge fendering sytem located approx. MM57.5 Ouaciha river. 

No further damage, injuries or pollution reported.
On 3 Nov 2006 at 0030 the M/V MYRA H was north bound at MM 1 Monongahela River when it allided with the Port Transit Bridge.

THE M/V Richard Neale while heading downbound pushing a crane barge, the crane's boom hit the route 50 highway  (New blennerhassett) bridge at MM 189 on the Ohio River. The bridge is currently under construction. The crane's boom wrapped around the bridge, preventing the barges from being moved. The river was closed to traffic from  1137 to 2113,  while the crane's boom was being freed from the bridge.

D8 conducted a conference call with the Union Pacific RR Bridge Tender, who stated the UTV Ryan Cenac allied both of his empty red flag barges with the pier of his bridge. MSU Baton Rouge responded and confirmed no damage to the bridge / barges and no secondary casualties. No pollution, damage or injuries reported with this case.

The vessel LADY TAMPA BAY allided with the Franklin Street Bridge in Tampa, FL. The Master attempted to moor the vessel but miscommunication with a new First Mate on the stern resulted in the vessel being set down too close to the bridge by the current. The Master stated the pilot house side windows were fogged over which also restricted his view. The vessel made contact with the bridge amidships in way of the port rub rail causing three paint scrapes in the rail. The bridge was not damaged.

While the UTV BRIDGET MCALLISTER was transiting in the Atlantic Ocean, near Barnegat Light, the port shaft coupling failed, resulting in the propeller becoming jammed against the rudder and in addition allowing water into the engine room space.  Pumps onboard the vessel were able to keep up with the flooding.  Vessel safely towed to New York for repairs.

The F/V ANDY AND CHARLIE JR. allided with the Leeville bridge at mm13.3 Bayou Lafourche after suffering a partial loss of steering. Steering was fixed onbard soon after, no other damage to the vessel. Navigation lighting wire top one nav light on the bridge fender was severed and reconnected, no other damage to the bridge. No injuries and no pollution.

The UTV MISS KORI allided with the SR315 bridge at mm3.1 on the Falgout Canal. No damage to the bridge or vsl, no injuries or pollution. Vsl laid along the guide wall in order to pass through without incident (intentional allision).

The M/V ABERDEEN was pushing two redflag barges loaded with light cycle oil westbound on the GIWW when the pilot attempted to hail the Bayou Blue Pontoon bridge tender on the radio when coming around the bend in the waterway at approx 0430 lcl. Bridge tender replied back that it would be open however he failed to start opening it in time and the pilot at the helm took evasive maneuvers when he noticed this when approx 0.5 mile away by putting the engines in full reverse. The tug & tow had too much momentum and the bridge struck the lead barge (MMI 3038) while halfway open on it's port bow. Minimal damage to the barge, extensive damage to the bridge, no injuries and no pollution. Alcohol and drug testing was performed on the vsl crew. Bridge was repaired and is operational.

M/V OLMSTEAD called to inform that their tow allided with the EJ&E Bridge at MM 271.1 on the IL Waterway.  The vsl had a 9 barge tow and did a "controlled landing" on the barge INGRAM 1914 carrying Pet-Coke.  No damage to the vsl and it touched only the timbers.  EJ&E notified and notified Master to send a CG 2692.

No damage to bridge.

M/V ERNA E HONEYCUTT allided with the Seneca Railroad Bridge at MM 254.1 on the Illinois River while doing a "controlled landing".

No damage to bridge or vessel.

The M/V NONNIE was northbound in the Mobile river pushing four empty and one loaded open hopper barge. As the vessel went under the Chickasaw railroad bridge, the river current pushed the port side of the port lead barge BIG 533 into the west fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained to the fender, bridge, or barge as a result of this incident. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

AT APROX 1930 IB 11/30/06 WHILE S/B ON OHR AT/NEAR MM 937 WITH 25 LOADED BARGES, THE M/V CAROLINE N AND ITS TOW ALLIDED WITH THE RIGHT-HAND PIER OF THE CHANNEL SPAN ON THE IRVIN COBB BRIDGE CAUSING TOW TO BREAK APART.  A BLOCK OF 12 BARGES REMAINED WITH THE M/V WITH 13 BARGES BREAKING AWAY.  BARGE CGB-416 WAS PUSHED INTO THE ILLINOIS SHORE AND BEGAN TAKING ON WATER.  BARGE WAS LIGHTERED.  ASSIST TUGS RETRIEVED THE BARGES AND RE-WIRED THE TOW.

On October 9, 2006 at approximately 1745 hours the M/V Gilbert Taylor allided with the Naheola RR Bridge.  The current set the bow of the barge C738 on to the east pier as the tow passed under the bridge.  The M/V Gilbert Taylor was pushing 8 loads of coal and the only damage done to the vessel and the tow was 2 broken coupling wires.  There was no damage done to the bridge.  The wires were replaced and the tow proceeded on its voyage.

SPV LADY TAMPA BAY was moored at her home pier on 18SEP06.  At approx. 0318 Tampa Police Department (TPD) received a call through 911 reporting the LADY TAMPA BAY was adrift and resting against the Harbour Island Bridge.  TPD notified the owner of the vessel, who responded to the scene.  Upon arrival on-scene the owner noticed all mooring lines and the shore power tie were still attached to the vessel.  M/V LADY TAMPA BAY's owner and crew were able to board vessel and maneuver it back to it's home pier without incident.  Upon return to dock, a  survey was done by the crew with no damage noted.

An investigation by TPD revealed that this incident was a random act of someone setting the vessel adrift.

M/V MARY C was traveling d/b at MM 300.4 on the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal when the #7 cover of barge ACL 98001 caught on the underside of the Burlington Northern RR Bridge.  The Captain misjudged the height of the covers to the clearance of the bridge.

No damage to bridge.

On November 7, 2006, UTV MR. NICK was pushing a spud barge west bound on the ICW at the 60 mile marker. As the tug Mr. Nick transited under the Bayou Delarge Bridge, one of the legs of the spud barge allided with the bottom of the bridge, causing the spud to fall into the water near the side of the channel.

M/V PETER FANCHI was traveling d/b at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River pushing ahead a tow containing 12 barges when it allided with the right descending side of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.  The allision resulted in a 4"x2" hole in the port stern bilge knuckle of barge ING 2041.  Temporary repairs made and the void was pumped out.

No damage to bridge.
Barge repairs complete.

On 15NOV06, at approx. 1630 EST, the SPV SUNCRUZ V (1039137) was inbound John's Pass, on the Gulf of Mexico.  While transiting inbound (eastbound) through the John's Pass bridge, the vessel allided with the north side fendering system, by making contact with it and the port side stern quarter.  Damage to the vessel was limited to minor paint scraping.  No damage was noted to the fendering system.

VSL SOUTHBOUND OHR ABOVE CAIRO HWY BRIDGE.  CURRENT WAS SETTING VSL TOWARDS THE RIGHT DESCENDING BANK AND WIND BLOWING VSL TOWARDS LEFT DESCENDING BANK.  WHILE ATTEMPTING TO STEER INTO 2ND SPAN, TOW LANDED ON PIER APPROX 300 FT OUT FROM BOAT.  HEAD 9 BARGES BROKE LOOSE.  ALL RECOVERED BY LOCAL TUGS.

While traveling D/B at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River, M/V Lemont Trader allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.  Barge FJC 10B, part of a 12 barge tow, made contact with the bridge's wooden protection fence on the barge's port side.

No damage to barge or bridge.

17Nov06 @ 1100L:  The CFV JORDANS FREEDOM was transiting from Wanchese Fish Dock to Egreton Fish House to procure ice.  The operator misjudged the current and allided with the Chincoteague Swing Bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge or vessel.  SFO Eastern Shore boarded the vessel and conducted a breath alcohol test of the operator.

11/23/06 @ 1000L - The CFV MISS DOLLIE grounded outside of the channel while attempting a starboard 180 degree turn to the south to transit the Chincoteague Swing Bridge.  After holding position with the bow to the north, awaiting a bridge opening, the operator turned too wide to starboard and grounded outside the channel.  The operator was unfamiliar with the area and was not aware of a marsh outside of the channel that was not visible due to an exceptionally high tide caused by a Nor'easter.  The vessel was undamaged and refloated at high tide.

While passing under the RR swing bridge, Krotz Springs, vessel allieded with the cement pilling.  MSU Baton Rouge responded and confirmed no damage to the vessel or to the bridge was noted as well as no injuries and pollution.

M/V RIVER PHOENIX outbound from New Bedford allided with the New Bedford Swing Bridge.  Vessel dropped anchor on the south side of swing bridge, contacted Coast Guard, and awaited inspectors/investigators.

See IO statement in evidence for further details.

While transiting in vicinity of Wrightsville Beach Drawbridge in attempt to assist M/V AMERICAN EAGLE ,the  tender vessel CHARLIE in service with Norfolk Dredging Company struck the bridge causing damage to the dolphin piling system.

The M/V R.W. NAYE was underway Southbound pushing 13 barges (4 empty tank barges and 9 loaded dry cargo barges) on the Illinois River. While navigating through the Florence Highway Bridge at mile 56 on ILR the dry cargo barges WTT 0842 and WTT 0873 rubbed the bridge protection cell. No damage to the cell. 

The barges sustained the following damage: 
1. WTT 842 the rake had damage to the side shell and allowed river water to enter the bow rake void.
2. WTT 873 the stern void, #3 wing tank and #4 wing tank had damage to the side shell and allowed river water to enter the spaces.

December 1, 2006 @ 1545L - The UTV WILLIAM E. POOLE was downbound on the James River with nine loaded hopper barges.  The operator was attempting to pass underneath the Benjamin Harrison Bridge, Rt. 158, in Hopewell/Prince George, VA.  The tug and tow approached too closely to the fender system along the left descending bank.  The first barge on the port side of the flotilla, number 215, struck the cross members of the fender structure and pushed the pilings of the structural dolphin back approximately two feet.

M/V COLORADO was pushing KIRBY barge 29700 from fleeting area to Citgo dock 7.  KIRBY 29700 allided with the T/V TOWER BRIDGE while moored at Valero oil dock 4.  Damage consisted of paint scrapes to barge and dent in TOWER BRIDGE forward, starboard side of hull in way of #1 WBTK.  No injuries or pollution.

T/B HT 207 while being pushed down bound on Cape Fear River by M/V CAPT JIMMY in the vicinity of the Navassa Rail Road Bridge experienced strong currents. In order to avoid potential Allison with the RR Bridge, the Tug and Barge grounded to await assistance in order to safely complete transit. Barge was empty and no release of product was reported.

At 0950 M/V PACIFIC II was being towed outbound of the Miami River by tugs JEAN RUTH and ATLAS. When the vessel approached the 5th Street Bridge (bridge is out of commission and is fixed in the open span position) the floodlight on the port side bridge wing struck the bridge. The port side smoke stack touched the bridge and was ripped backwards as the vessel allided with the bridge.

M/V JW HERSHEY was n/b with 15 loaded barges in tow.  While navigating Chessie RR Bridge near mm 254.1 Illinois River starboard stern barge DM 3001 rubbed left descending pier.  No damage reported to bridge or barge.  No post casualty chemical or alcohol testing conducted or required.

On 28 August 2006, M/V BERNARD G was attempting to transit the Lacrosse, WI RR bridge southbound and landed on the right descending side of the left descending span near the turntable protection. The resulting damage was a bent stanchion and cracked timbers. Surveyors and the bridge tender both stated that there was previous damage to these same timbers. Damage to the bridge is estimated at less than $5,000. No damage to any barges or to the towboat.

On December 06, 2006 the M/V L.R. CHAPMAN was transiting downbound on the Cumberland River with 12 barges in tow.  The fifth barge in the port string, BIG 555, allided with the protective cell of the Bordeaux Railroad Bridge located at mile marker 185.2 Cumberland River.  All barges in tow were empty except for the CGL 22 which was loaded with steel.

M/V J N PHILIPS WAS PROCEEDING S/B ABOVE THE IC RR BRIDGE MM 977.7 OHR.  PILOT ON WATCH WAS ADJUSTING FOR THE NATURAL SET IN THE BRIDGE.  IN DOING SO, HE OVER CORRECTED, AND SCRAPED THE LEFT HAND PIER WITH THE PORT SIDE OF THE TOW, CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE RF 524 & RF 522 LOADS OF STONE.  THE BARGES WERE THE SECOND AND THIRD BARGES OUT FROM THE BOAT IN THE PORT STRING.

On 15 November 2006, Sector UMR received a FOIA request from BNSF railroad regarding 31 October 2006 allision of M/V CINDY L. ERICKSON and the Burlington, IA railroad bridge. The incident was not previously reported to the Coast Guard. Further investigation found that vessel allided with the bridge at approximately 0100 on 31 October 2006. Vessel was headed southbound near UMR mile marker 403.2 with 9 loaded corn barges in tow. Vessel captain controlled rate at which the tow landed on the RDB protection cell. Initial reports were no damage to vessels or bridge. Later that day, bridge re-evaluated and determined damage had been done. No injuries as a result of the incident.

UTV CHRISTINA RENEE reported alliding with the fendering system on the Galveston Causeway RR bridge.  Vessel requested assistance from UTV DANIEL STAPP, however the capitain on board the vessel was unable to assist since the tug and its tows were already under the bridge.  Prior to the incident he did not feel the vessel needed assistance, he was motoring behind the CHRISTINA RENEE.  During routine background checks it was discovered that the captain on board the UTV DANIEL STAPP was curently under a settlement agreement with MSU Port Arthur and had surrendered his license in February of 2006.

M/V Pin Oak was U/B at MM 71.3, ILR, RDB when it allided with the Meredosia Highway Bridge. The vessel port bow was damaged. The bridge's concrete pier was scraped. No report was made to the CG until seven hours later.

M/V TOM FRAZIER WHILE PUSHING A 15 BARGE TOW D/B, MM151.3, ILR,  BARGE ACBL4341 ALLIDED W/ THE CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RR BRIDGE (LOWER PEKIN RR BRIDGE). THE BARGE SUSTAINED SLIGHT DAMAGE.  A THREE INCH FRACTURE WAS  REPORTED IN #3 STBD VOID. A COTP ORDER WAS ISSUED ON THE BARGE. NO DAMAGE WAS REPORTED TO THE TOWING VESSEL OR THE BRIDGE.

UTV CREOLE TUT PUSHING TWO EMPTY TANK BARGES (DOUBLED UP) INTENTIONALLY ALLIDED WITH THE FENDERING SYSTEM OF THE GALVESTON RAIL ROAD BRIDGE DUE TO THE CURRENT PUSHING THE TOW TO PORT.  NO DAMAGE REPORTED TO BARGES.  MINOR WOOD SPLINTERING REPORTED TO THE FENDERING TIMBERS.

INVESTIGATION COMPLETE: 03JAN2007
M/V JACK D WOFFORD was underway southbound pushing 10 loaded barges.  One of the barges rubs the protection cell around the bridge support.  No damage to the barge or the protection cell.

A crew member onboard the Fishing Vessel Gale Warnings II was hauling in fishing gear.  A hard float that was attached to the bottom of the net came through the net reel and struck the crew member on the right side of his head.  The crew member did not expect the float to come through the reel as soon as it did.  The Captain hailed the Maine Marine Patrol to have a local doctor meet him at a pier in Milbridge Maine.  Once the vessel reached shore, the injured crew member was transported to Bangor Eastern Maine Medical Center for treatment.  The crew member sustained a concussion.

The M/V WA KERNAN was underway headed southbound on the Upper Mississippi River pushing 5 loaded barges.  While transiting through the span of the Burlington Railroad Bridge at MM 403, one barge rubbed the sheer fence protecting the bridge supports on the left decending bank of the railroad bridge.  No damage to the barge or the sheer fence.

The M/V Deanna Ann was underway headed southbound on the Upper Mississippi River pushing 15 loaded barges.  While transiting through the span of the Sabula Railroad Bridge, two barges on the starboard string contacted the protection cell around the supports for the railroad bridge.  One barge is damaged.  No damage to the protection cell.

The vessel SUNCRUZ VII was attempting an outbound transit of the Johns Pass Bridge. The Master lined up and began the transit at approximately 7 knots. The Master stated he felt the vessel was a little to the north and took action for course change, but with negative results. As the vessel transited the bridge's fendering system the vessel made contact in way of the aft starboard bow. The vessel and the bridge's fendering system suffered no damage.

While traveling D/B at MM 271 on the Illinois River, M/V DIXIE CHALLENGE allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.

No damage to barge Kirby 10525 or bridge.

On 20 December 2006, at approximately 1910, the tow of the M/V MYRA ECKSTEIN allided with the Florence, IL highway drawbridge right descending bank pier (ILR MM56). Damage occurred to barges CC-8278 (voids 1 and 2 flooded to river level) and MTC-212 (stern void flooded to river level). 15 loaded dry cargo barges in tow. High water levels existed on the Illinois River at time of incident. No injuries occurred as a result of this incident.

While traveling d/b at MM 288 on the Illinois River, M/V PAT WHITE allided with the upper left decending protection cell of the Cass Street Bridge.

No damage to barge or bridge.

M/V THRUSTON B MORTON was pushing 15 total barges, including 1 red flag, d/b at MM 288 on the Illinois River. M/VBILL CARNEAL was underway southbound pushing 9 barges.  At MM 403 Upper Mississippi River, one of the barge in the tow rubbed against the sheer fence surrouding the bridge supports on the right descending bank for the railroad bridge.  No damage to the sheer fence or the barge.

Jan 11, 2007: Investigation complete.

M/V JB KLEINPETER was underway southbound pushing 15 barges.  One of the barges rub against the concrete protection cell while passing through the open span.  No damage to the protection cell or barge.

25-Dec-2006: UTV TEXIAN was eastbound pushing the MMI 602 (lead) and MMI 601 (empty) through the Galveston Causeway bridge. Due to high wind, the tow was set down on the south fender wall to keep from landing on the work barges at the bridge. Water was discovered in the number one void. No injuries, no pollution.

M/V JB KLEINPETER was underway headed northbound pushing 15 loaded barges.  One of the barges allided with the concrete protection cell around the bridge support at MM 364 on the Upper Mississippi River.  No damage to the concrete pier.  Minor damage to the barge.

While outbound John's Pass, the SUNCRUZ VII allided with the John's Pass bridge fendering system. M/V LEXINGTON was s/b with 16 barges in tow.  While navigating near mm 254 Illinois River stbd lead barge ACBL 300 rubbed right descending sheer fence of bridge.  No damage reported to bridge or barge.

While traveling U/B at MM 270.8 on the Illinois River, M/V ERNA E HONEYCUTT allided with the right descending protection pier of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.

No damage to bridge or tow.

While traveling D/B at MM 270.8 on the Illinois River, M/V ERNA E HONEYCUTT allided with the right descending protection pier of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.

No damage to bridge or tow.

THE MSD RCVD A CALL FM A CONCERNED CITIZEN RPTG THAT SHE HEARD ON VHF FM CH 10 THE M/V PAMELA DEWEY TALKING TO AN UNKNOWN VSL ABOUT TAKING ON WATER. UPON FARTHER INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT THE VESSEL HAD ALLIDED WITH THE PEKIN RR BRIDGE AND GROUNDED TWICE WHILE D/B ON THE ILR. ALL INCIDENTS WERE WHILE THE VESSEL WAS UNDER THE CONTROL OF THE SAME MASTER. THREE BARGES WERE DAMAGED. NO NOTIFICATION WAS RECEIVED FROM THE VESSEL OR THE COMPANY.

M/V BECKY ANN  (BARGE ST-2) ALLIDED W/ THE LOWER PEKIN RR BRIDGE MM 151.2 ILR WHILE DB ENROUTE HAVANA, IL PUSHING 2 EMPTY GRAIN BARGES AND 1 CRANE BARGE (ST-2). THE STBD STERN OF THE ST-2  ALLIDED WITH THE RDB PROTECTION CELL.  MSD PEORIA'S INVESTIGATION VERIFIED NO DAMAGE.

When the operator of the tug KRISTINA H got underway pushing ahead the barge TALLY HO, they thought the crane boom was low enough to clear the Ballard Bridge.  It was not and the crane boom struck the closed Ballard Bridge causing damage to both the bridge and the crane.  The bridge was tested and fully operational following this incident.  The repairs will be made to the bridge when time allows.  Also, during the course of this investigation it became apparent that the tug KRISTINA H was operated by an unlicensed individual.  The tug is over 26 feet and is required to have a licensed operator.  A letter was sent to the owner of the tug directing them to cease all operations until a licensed operator is found for all tugs over the length of 26 feet.  This letter was considered adaquate remedy by Chief of Prevention Department and sent per his direction as opposed to a formal enforcement action.  Also, now operational control was documented in MISLE per Chief of Prevention Department direction.

Based on the current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.

The UTV CHRISTINA RENEE, pushing the TM 3601 and TM 3600, allided with a piling while going throught the Galveston Causeway/ railroad bridge. The TM 3601 was the lead barge and struck the piling at the coupling on the starboard stern. No damage was reported to the barge. No injuries, no pollution.
M/V NANCY STURGIS was transiting upbound the Monongahela River, Mile 14.2 pushing 15 empty hopper barges when it allided with the McKeesport-Duquesne Highway Bridge.

While traveling downbound at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River, M/V CODY BOYD allided with the upper left descending protection pier of the EJ&E RR Bridge.

No damage to bridge or barge MBL 1367B.

On 7 January 2007, at approximately 0345, M/V CORAL DAWN was transiting southbound on Illinois River in vicinity of mile marker 56, when vessels tow allided with the right descending bank pier of the Florence Hwy Drawbridge. Two barges within the tow received extensive damage, and two other barges received minor damage. No injuries occurred as a result of this incident.

UTV Donna York w/9 loaded coal barges down bound at MM 251, Ohio River. Light fog on river, high water conditions. Master stopped tow on LDB, approx 3/4 mile above Pomeroy HW Bridge to evaluate conditions. While there, Pilot came on watch, stern of tow started to drift out into channel and tow started to top around (spin out of control). Pilot drove tow forward to regain control and became committed to bridge. Stern port barge in tow (C-963) scraped for approx 70' along LDB bridge pier.

On 08Jan07, at 1620, The M/V Dennis Collins pushing two empty anhydrous ammonia barges (AF12 & AF 15) South bound at m.m. 184.3 on the Ohio River, allided with the B&O R.R. bridge in Parkersburg, WV.  The barge AF12 contacted the bridge port side mid-ship.  No damage was incurred by the bridge or barge.  No injuries or other casualties reported.

While travelling downbound at MM 270.6 on the Illinois M/V CITY OF PADUCAH, pushing barge KIRBY 10559, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge.

No damage to barge or bridge.

16 JAN 07 The M/V TOM FRAZIER was southbound pushing 15 loaded grain barges ivo MM 183 UMR when its stbd face wire parted.  The Captain was able to navigate under the Merchants RR bridge but the port lead barge landed on the left descending bank causing the tow to top around.  The port face wire parted and the captain tried unsuccessfully to push the tow under the McKinley Highway and RR bridge.  The tow allided with McKinley Highway and RR bridge causing tow to break apart and damage to two barges.

On February 08, 2006, the bridge operator for the Bridge of Lions, St. Augustine notified CG SEC Mayport that the UTV P.J. (O.N. 635514) towing the barge CMC 826 (O.N. 658967) allided with the bridge at approximately 1100. There was no apparent damage to the bridge.

Details of the incident ara as follow; the vessel approach the bridge with enough power to maintain steerage, the ebb tide caused the towing vessel to drift to the west and the crosswinds forced the barge to drift the opposite direction therefore causing a soft impact on the fendering system.

CG team board the vessel at the ICW. Alcohol tes was conducted. Drug testing was ordered under 33 CFR Part. 95.  Upon examination of the vessel's official documents and vessel's equipment the following discrepancies were found. No fire pump, fire detection system, and general alarm installed. No means to secure fuel to all engines. No fire control panel installed/approved. All portable fire extinguishers beyond the required annual service date. Certificate of Documentation expired and not present (both Tug and Barge). Other vessel documentation not onboard (FCC Certificates, vessel registration, drug testing and training records). A COTP Order was issued (see evidence for details).

Although facts indicates that weather conditions caused the tug/barge to allide with the bridge fendering system, all fire fighting components on the vessel and proper documentation were unsat. Based on the evidence collected the Master will be referred for enforcement action (see enforcement activity for details).

No further investigation needed.

0807 15 September 2006, the Sector NY Command Center received a call from NY State Throughway Bridge Maintenance Division reporting that a  ship had hit the Castleton Bridge.  No apparent structural damage to the bridge was reported however, there was damage to the tram tracks.  Original report was received by the DOT command center via e-mail from a New York State Sea Pilot at 0943 14 September 2006.  The name of the ship was not reported.
WHILE TRANSITING THROUGH EGGNERS FERRY BRIDGE, SUDDEN WIND INCREASE BLEW TOW, RESULTING IN BRUSHING OF BRIDGE.

20JAN2007 (0544 lcl time):  The M/V INEZ ANDREAS was transiting n/b with 32 barges in tow at or near MM 735 LMR.  After passing the three (Interstate 55, Burlington Northern RR, and Union Pacific Harahan RR) bridges at MM 735.5 LMR, the current overpowered the M/V INEZ ANDREAS' steering and was pushing the tow and vessel to starboard toward the left descending bank.  After clearing the bridges and continuing a port turn, the starboard facing line spool casing on the M/V INEZ ANDREAS separated from the deck.  The tow of the vessel broke away and the port string of tow allided on the second bridge pier of the HARAHAN RR bridge in the span of the secondary channel.
M/V PAT PICKETT ALLIDED WITH THE CHICAGO AND NORTHWESTERN (LOWER PEKIN) R/R BRIDGE AT MM 151.2 ILR. NO DAMAGE TO THE VESSEL OR THE TOW.

The M/V JOE CAIN was southbound in the Tombigbee River pushing eight loaded open hopper barges. The tow was passing under the Jackson RR bridge while maneuvering for an right-hand bend in the river just beyond the bridge. As the tow was slowly passing under the bridge, the port side of the barge RMW 16 came to rest along the east fender system of the bridge. No damage was sustained by the bridge, fender system, or the barge as a result of this incident. The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

24JAN07, 0515:  Master of M/V CITY OF CLEVELAND hits Natchez bridge (upper) w/ the freight barge AD 755 on the Vadalia, LA side.  Barge broke away and was caught by the CITY OF CLEVELAND just down river, and pushed to the bank where it sank at M/M 362.

All lights on the Natchez side of the bridge were found extinguished during an inspection by the bridge authority the evening of the 24th.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to have played a role in this incident.

29 JAN 07:  Drug and alcohol tests were complete with negative results.  

Tow hit Bayou Dularge Bridge South fender system.  7 protective pads from the second row were removed and
a nav light was knocked out.  The tow was made up of UTV Trevor towing Barge 506 with Delta Fox as the assist tug on the stbd side of the tow.  There were no injuries, pollution, or damage to tugs and barge.

M/V Limestone Lady allided with the Natchez bridge Mile Marker 363 Lower Mississippi River while pushing 25 rock barges southbound. All barges became adrift, and 16 barges were damaged. No further damage, injuries or pollution reported.

M/V DELL BUTCHER ALLIDED  W/U.S. 41 DUAL HIGHWAY BRIDGE MI 787 OHR. CAPTAIN ADVD THAT HE HAS ALLIDED WITH THE UPPER BRIDGE WHILE TRANSITING S/B. HE HAD 15 BARGES GO ADRIFT   WHICH THEN STRUCK SOME BARGES IN A FLEETING AREA CAUSING UP TO 5 TO GO ADRIFT. CAPTAIN ADVD THAT HE HAD NO RED FLAGS IN TOW, HE WAS PUSHING 15 LOADED LIME BARGES. HE IS CURRENTLY WORKING WITH SEVERAL ASSIST BOATS TO SECURE THE BARGES ADRIFT.  

RECOVERY OPS COMPLETE

The Hopper Barge PB-0131 allided with the Melville Bridge on the Atchafalaya River.  The barge was being pushed S/B by the UTV BILL RODGERS at the time of the incident. No pollution, no injuries and no damage to the bridge and bridge fender system resulted. Minor damage to the port bow of the PB-0131.  When the tow approached the bridge the captain lowered the pilot house on the UTV to clear the bridge, with his view of the bridge restricted he was not able to notice the current setting his tow towards the bridge.

While pushing two empty barges through the Galveston Causeway Bridge, a high wind caused the FMT 3070 to rub against the protection cell. The bridge tender confirmed there was no damage to the bridge. No damage, no pollution to the barge.

Barge CBL 8301, being pushed south bound by M/V EILEEN C, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.  Vessel was pushing 6 empty hopper barges.

01FEB07, 2100:  UTV JOHN ROBERTS is S/B on the LMR when the Master apparently misjudges his approach to the Vicksburg Railroad bridge @ M/M 437.8 and causes the tow to strike the right descending pier. Supply boat was southbound on Bayou Lafourche in strong current and gusty conditions as it approached the Leeville Bridge. Barge ACL 0501, while being pushed south bound by M/V LEXINGTON in a tow of 12, allided with the left descending protection cell of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.  There was no damage to barge or bridge.
Tow Boat US unit #3 was towing a 25' sail boat under the 79th Street CSWY bridge (west side) and stuck the bridge's navigation light with the sail boat's mast.

RCVD CALL FM THE M/V TONY LIPPMAN D/B AT MM 151.2, ILR RPTG THAT ONE OF THE VESSEL'S BARGES, FMT-3051 HAD ALLIDED WITH THE LDB UPPER PROTECTION CELL OF THE PEKIN RR BRIDGE. Barge CHB 0143B, while being pushed south bound by M/V ANNE B, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

M/V RALPH PLAGGE allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

On 19JAN07 at approximately 0230, the M/V Larry Tilley allied with the Big 4 railroad bridge at ORM 602.9 while transiting s/b through the Louisville area.  The Captain attributed the allision to strong current and gusts of wind.  The vessel had 15 empty hopper barges in tow, 2 of which on the port string contacted the bridge pier.  Eight of the wires in the tow were broken, but no barges broke completely loose.  Two assist vessels were on scene quickly, and help to re-wire the tow without further incident. 
SOHV Duty team boards vessel in Portland Canal at approximately 0500 to investigate/assess damage.  Statement taken from captain of the vessel. On January 29, 2007 at approximately 0045 hours the UTV CRIMSON WHITE was heading south bound on the Black Warrior River.  At mile marker 268 (AGS North Fork Southern bridge) the vessel lost power and aft starboard stern barge (VOL 7734) made contact with one of the bridge pilings.  The pilot was the operator of the UTV CRIMSON WHITE and states in the 2692 that the starboard generator started surging which caused the electrical service on the vessel to fluctuate.  The port main steering breaker kicked off causing loss of steering. The tow then slid around the curve and the pilot was not able to control the vessels slide. The aft starboard stern barge (VOL 7734) made contact with the piling. The damage to the barge was a 2' X 8" split at the bilge knuckle on the stern quarter.  The barge was taking on water, but they used 2 pumps to keep up with the flooding until they moored safely in Mobile Alabama for repairs.

No apparent damage to bridge, tug and barge.  Crane inspection revealed minor damage.  No injuries., pollution or hazard to navigation.  Bridge was inspected SAT and remains open to traffic.

On February 13, 2007 @ approximately 1740L, the UTV ELLIE J was northbound in the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River and pushing the tank barge KTC 21 under the control of the tug's mate.  The vessels were approaching the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge #7.and experiencing E/NE winds at approximately 10-15 knots. When the vessels were abeam of the Triport Terminal, the captain, who was in the wheelhouse observing the mate, took control because he was not satisfied with the alignment.  He ordered hard left rudder, but it the action was too late to prevent the barge from striking the fender system.  The barge sustained a 14 inch fracture in the port bow rake about three feet above the waterline.  A portion of the fender system sustained significant damage.  Drug and alcohol testing was conducted.

During normal working hours while working in the cargo reefer,  a crewmember attempted to close the reefer door unaware that his right index finger was in the path of the door.  He sustained a contusion/avulsion to the tip of his finger as a result of being caught between the hinge side of the door and the door frame.  The crewmember  was treated by the embarked medical services officer and then taken by helicopter to the USS John C. Stennis for X-rays and additional medical treatment.  The X-rays returned with a report of no bone damage and his finger was simply sewn back together.  No mechanical problems were found with the door, the injury was determined to be a result of the crewmember's inattention to detail.  The crewmember was returned from the USS John C. Stennis to the USNS Bridge the following day and placed on light duty.  Three days later he was sent home to receive more medical treatment from his personal physician.  It was reported that this injury was not a result of use of alcohol or dangerous drugs.

27FEB07, 2245: BRIDGE ALLISION – MM 49.8 GICW: The Bayou Blue bridge tender reported the UTV MISS AUDREY DEAN struck the northeast fender system of the bridge. Tug pushing two red flag barges loaded with Cat gas. Phone investigation with the master of the vessel revealed he came around the turn approaching the bridge and fog greatly reduced visibility.  Captain was unable to see the nav lights on the bridge in time to slow down to avoid striking the northeast fender boards and the nav lights.  No pollution or injuries occurred.  Bridge operating normally.  UTV pushed up at MM 51 due to thick fog and is awaiting MSU Houma DMI and Morgan City IO arrival during daylight.  BTM released for extinguished nav lights on bridge. Case pends.

On scene investigation revealed that a dense fog pocket enveloped the bridge minutes before the accident and that the vessel Master slowed as he approached the bridge and had a moment of indecision about whether to proceed.  He dispatched a deckhand as a lookout to the bow of the tow and continued.  The lack of visibility as well as lack of speed and control caused the forward barge to allide with the far end of the bridge fender system as the tow came through.  Damage to the fender was significant and was estimated at $40K.  No other damage or injuries were reported.  The bridge itself was not damaged, nor were the vessels.  The Master admitted his error in judgment and was very cooperative.  The tow was allowed to continue on its way

The  M/V LOUISE S (513659) was downbound on the Ohio River pushing 17 empty coal barges when a gust of wind  caused the tow to allide with the Parkersburg Railroad Bridge.   Four wires were broken while pushing off the bridge to back the tow.   No reported damage to the bridge or the tow.

--With ANDREW FOSS made up astern the barge in control, assisted by SHELLEY FOSS ahead towing the barge's bow by line, as barge MARMAC #12 was transiting the span of the Ballard Bridge outbound, the barge was set and the port quarter of the barge contacted the bridge's south shearwall that protects the bridge, with only cosmetic scrape damage resulting.  
--The 240'-long barge is 72' in width; horizontal clearance at the bridge is charted as 100'.  With the westbound barge well on its way through the bridge's horizontal opening, and with its bow becoming exposed to southerly wind, the Master of the control tug ANDREW FOSS, operating astern the barge, was unable to effectively apply the tug's power so as to fully correct a set to port taken by the barge's stern.  The bridge's fendering system prevented damage by working as intended in such a situation.

On 15MAR07, at approximately 2130 local time notification was received from the Addison Point Bridge Tender that the tug BANTAM and the barge SEI-10 had allided with the bridge fendering system while north bound in the Indian River.  The allision damaged the bridge's fendering system.  Florida DOT was notified and requested to inspect the bridge immediately for any structural damage that could render it unsafe.  Bridge inspection was carried out and no damage, other than to fendering system, was noted.

MSD Canaveral investigators along with Station Canaveral personnel boarded the vessel underway to investigate the incident.  Alcohol testing was conducted for the crew.  The operator was questioned regarding the allision and stated the wind had caused him to allide with the bridge fendering system (winds estimated to be 15 kts at the time).  Operator did not have his license onboard.  No damage to the tug or barge was noted.  Investigation to continue AM the next day.

16MAR07  

Vessel was boarded again by marine inspectors/investigators to follow up on the previous evenings casualty.  As a result a Captain of the Port Order was issued terminating the vessels voyage (see inspection activity 2889313) for unsafe conditions.  Tug and barge proceeded to Port Canaveral to moor and effect repairs.  Tug was only able to make 1.5 kts during its transit and did not arrive until late the evening of the 16th.

17MAR07

Drug testing of crew conducted.  Check of MISLE records for the operators MMLD were negative.  Follow up interview with operator of the vessel at the time of the casualty revealed that he had in fact lied to investigators and did not possess any MMLD or CG credential.  Additionally, onboard relief operator, although licensed, did not possess a towing endorsement on his license.  

The tug BANTAM was hauled out of the water for repairs and it was found that the vessel did not have a rudder for it's starboard propeller - thus contributing to the casualty due to the fact that the vessel could not be controlled.  It was also noted that the screws were severely fouled with line, reducing the vessels ability to operate correctly.  Repairs monitored and vessel placed back in service on 22MAR07.  Unlicensed operator was relieved by the company.  

Company contacted in regards to non-receipt of CG-2692 and barge addendum.  Owner/operator claimed he was unaware of the requirements to provide this - copy e-mailed to him.  Enforcement activity against the owner/operator to be processed for failure to provide a written report of a marine casualty within 5 days, employment of an unlicensed operator on a towing vessel, and failure to notify of a hazardous condition (missing rudder, fouled screws, reduced propulsion)

23MAR2007

At 1604 MSD Port Canaveral received a faxed copy of forms CG-2692 and Barge Addendum required for a reportable marine casualty as per 46CFR4.05-1 from DANA TUGS although the time frame requirement had been exceeded.

The foreign freight vessel AFIYA was inbound to the State Docks at Chickasaw AL.  As the vessel passed under the Cochran Bridge, it began to make its turn to the north west toward Chickasaw Creek.  At the entrance to Chickasaw creek is the Chickasawbogue Railroad Bridge, a swing bridge, which spans the creek running from NE to SW.  As the vessel entered the creek, the starboard bow bulwark made contact with an upper structural member on the north side of the swing bridge, which due to the swing of the bridge was aligned along the east side of the channel.  This structural member was bent along the side for approximately two feet from the impact.  About the same time, the starboard side of the AFIYA made contact with the east fender system of the bridge, causing them to lean slightly northward.  As the vessel proceeded through the bridge the starboard lower side of the vessel also made contact with the southernmost fender system of the bridge, damaging approximately 10 horizontal feet of the fender system and scraping the paint on the side of the vessel.  The vessel proceeded to the dock where it moored without further incident. The bridge was shut down immediately following the incident, but was opened approximately four hours later following an inspection by bridge personnel.  Marine surveyors have estimated the damage to the bridge to be between $65-80K.

The Pilot reports he approached the Chickasawbogue Bridge at approximately 5 knots.  As he realized an allision was possible, he put the port engine full astern in an attempt to achieve maximum swing or the bow to port.  The response of the vessel was not as he had expected.  Moments after the allision the vessel had slowed to approximately two knots of headway approximately halfway through the bridge channel.  From there the vessel increased its speed and passed the rest of the way through the bridge.  It is likely that during the maneuvering to make the bridge, not enough water was affecting the rudder in order to properly swing and align the ship.  Additionally, the bridge tender reports observing that an unusually low tide had occurred approximately 3 hours earlier resulting in more dry areas than usual.  It is possible that there was not enough water under the vessel to properly turn the ship as it approached the bridge.  Additionally, the resulting flood tide may have set the vessel more ahead than anticipated in its turn into the creek.

A damage survey was conducted on the AFIYA by Lloyds. They determined that as a result of this incident, the starboard forward gunwale from frame 125 to 130 was set in from the top of the rail to the main deck. Brackets in way of attachment between gunwale and deck were found tripped and buckled.  Bulkheads in bosuns store at frames 125 and 127 found buckled in way of deck connection to a depth of 20cm below deck.  Also, the deck plating of the f'ocsle was slightly set in way of the aforesaid damages.  Lloyd's recommended the vessel be allowed to proceed from berth with a recommendation that permanent repairs be carried out within one month.

On April 10, 2007 at approximately 2000 hours the barge JAC 1B broke away from it's mooring when a storm came through the area causing the mooring lines to part.  The barge was pushed west into the Singing River Island Bridge.  Initial reports received indicated no damage to the bridge or barge.  On April 11, 2007 CG investigators met on the bridge with Mississippi Department of Transportation (MDOT) and observed the damage under the bridge.  A small 10 inch section of the cement was chipped away exposing the tension cables under the bridge. MDOT engineers determined that the damage is to the span which supports the roadway.  The span has cables that are placed under tension when the cement is poured.  When the cement is fractured this releases the tension in the span rendering the span useless.  The span needs to be replaced which will cost approximately $250,000 dollars to repair.  MDOT closed the north bound lane of the bridge until repairs are completed.

The M/V DONNA RUSHING was southbound pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges. The captain of the M/V DONNA RUSHING called on channel 14 VHF to the Florence Highway bridge operator at mile 59 ILR to request the bridge be opened for his tow. At mile 57 ILR the captain of the M/V DONNA RUSHING again called the Florence Highway bridge operator to verify that he was clear to proceed to the bridge, again the bridge operator stated he was clear to continue to proceed. At mile 56.5 the bridge tender contacted the captain of the M/V DONNA RUSHING on channel 16 VHF stating he was having a problem raising the bridge and he needed to stop the tow. The captain on the M/V DONNA RUSHING commenced attempting to back and flank the M/V DONNA RUSHING. The M/V DONNA RUSHING was traveling at 4.5 miles per hour and the Illinois River was at flood stage. The bridge was finally opened but the captain was unable to get the tow back to the appropriate position to properly navigate through the bridge opening. The M/V MILTON underway down bound Ohio River mile marker 265 with a spud barge and crane. Spuds on barge were in the up position. At the top of the spuds are pad eyes used for lifting. As the tow went under the New York Central R/R Bridge the pad eye of the stbd spud struck the bridge and was knocked off the spud. No other damage to either bridge, barge, or tow.

Barge CHEM 233, while being pushed north bound by M/V JAMES G HINES, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.
Barge KIRBY 10429, while being pushed north bound by M/V CITY OF PADUCAH, allided with the Ottawa Railroad Bridge at MM 239.5 on the Illinois River.
Barge CBC 150, while being pushed north bound by M/V LYDIA E CAMPBELL, allided with the Ruby St Bridge at MM 288.7 on the Illinois River.

while maneuvering throught the longboat pass bridge span, the subject vessel allided with the fender, timber support, causing slight splintering damage. vessel suffered structural damage to the port sideshell.

Barge ACBL 3052, while being pushed south bound by M/V JAMES G HINES, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

M/V MIDLAND allided with the Seneca Railroad Bridge at MM 254 on the Illinois River.

No damage to bridge or vessel.

Barge MST 834, while being pushed south bound by M/V MARTHA MAC, allided with the Ottawa Railroad Bridge at MM 239 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

Motor Vessel (M/V) Jane G. Huffman (O.N. 564321) grounded above Lock & Dam 13 at mile marker 522.5 Upper Mississippi River (UMR) damaging  barge ACBL 3212 at approximately 210630APR07Z.  The M/V Jane G. Huffman then allided with the left descending protection cell of the Clinton Railroad drawbridge at Mile Marker 518.0 UMR causing damage to barge WTT 409B at approximately 210930APR07Z.

On April 21, 2007, at 0650 the UTV TREY DELOACH (517110) was pushing Kirby Barge 10529, Kirby 14802, and Kirby 20011 through the Galveston Railroad Causeway bridge.  The barges were strung out and an assist tug was helping them through the causeway, when Kirby 20011 allided with the north cell.  The tug was able to steer back on course without further incident.  there was no damage to the barge.

Barges EL 914 and TXM 410 broke away from Kindra Lake Towing fleet at MM 331.9 on the Calumet River.  They slowly drifted toward Lake Michigan and allided and came to rest upon the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Bridge at MM 332.1 on the Calumet River.

The M/V WILLIAM C, at the request of the Coast Guard, responded to the adrift barges and secured them back to the Kindra Lake Towing fleet.

24 April 2007 @ approximately 1556L - The M/V MARLIN, a Bahamian flagged bulker loaded with coal en route  Giant Cement in Chesapeake, Virginia struck the fender system of the Beltline Rail Bridge over the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  The vessel was under the control of a docking master and two tugs; one at the bow and the other aft.  The MARLIN was traveling south on the Elizabeth River, Southern Branch, stern first to facilitate docking at Giant Cement on the left descending bank.  The west fender system pylons were destroyed and the concrete foundation for the bridge was struck by the port quarter.  The side plating in way of the engine room opened up as a result of the allision.  Two frames were bent and several brackets were tripped as a result of the impact.

On 23 April 2007, at approximately 1130, the M/V RAYMOND GRANT ECKSTEIN was northbound with 16 barges in tow transiting the Upper Mississippi River at mile marker 326.9. When passing through the Left Descending Bank span of the Quincy Memorial Bridge, the empty dry cargo barge CC-95568 allided with bridge pier along the starboard side. No damage resulted to either the bridge or barge. No injuries reported as a result of this incident.

UTV BILL STEGBAUER was coming up on the 64 bridge and holding on the green buoy line. Vessel started sliding sideways toward the bridge pier due to river current. Vessel captain tried to get around it but allided with the bridge pier protection cell.  

UTV MISS DIXIE confirmed the fast flow of water in the river.  CAPT said that he was holding up before the going through the bridge due to the fast head water after the release from the dam above.
M/V TOM FRAZIER RPTD THEY ALLIDED WITH THE DUBUQUE DRAW BRIDE AT MM580 UMR. PUSHING 15 EMPTY GRAIN BARGES AND NO DAMAGE WAS RPTD TO THE BARGES OR VESSEL. THE BRIDGE ALSO RPTD NO DAMAGE.

UTV CHERYL M. SETTON pushing the barge SMI 204 heading westbound on Falgout Canal at 5mph when the SMI 204 allieded with the Falgout Canal Bridge due to strong currents near the bridge.  The barge struck the finder system of the bridge, breaking 2 pilings and a light.  Barge struck bridge pylons on its Starboard Bow rake, damage was limited to paint removal.  No damage to the barge, No pollution, No injuries.
M/V TOM TALBERT WAS TRANSITING THE CLINTON R/R D/B MM 518.0 UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER, AND ALLIDED WITH THE PROTECTION CELL, WITH NO REPORTABLE DAMAGE TO BRIDGE OR BARGE.

On 26 April approx 2030 Tug SARA KAITLIN towing barge MOBRO 139 w/crane struck McTeer bridge in Beaufort River.  While u/w south bound heading to Savannah, the crane on the barge struck the ceiling of McTeer bridge.  Tow line parted, tug returned to barge, lowered crane, retrieved barge.  Minimal damage to crane reported.  On 27 April approx 1600 SC DOT reported damage to 3 beams of bridge and closed bridge to vehicular traffic.  A press release indicating the facts of the incident was issued and subsequent press releases went out as needed.  Interviews of crews of both Savannah Marine Services and CML Equip Compay were conducted.  Sector Charleston worked closely with South Carolina Department of Transportation and Beaufort County Emergency Operations Center to minimize impact to commerical and vehicle traffic and expedite the investigation.

On April 30, 2007, Sector Delaware Bay was notified that the tug vessel CHARLES HUGHES pushing the barge VB35 southbound on the Schuylkill River, struck the fendering system of the Passyunk Ave bridge, PA due to high winds.  No damage was reported to either vessels. There were minor damages to the bridge's nav lights and minor damage to its railings. Inspections Division was notified 0845 May 1, 2007.  Vessel reported west winds 15-20 knots, gust 30-35, and ebbing current at 2 knots. No further action.
LTJG

M/V Joyce Hale was D/B with a 15 barge tow. While transiting the Pekin RR Bridge, with the help of the assist boat (Chris White) , the barge XL-666 allided with the RDB bridge protection cell. The barge was holed. Barge was dewatered and shingled. Tow resumed transit. River was at high water stage.

Barge MTC 314, while being pushed north bound by M/V MYRA ECKSTEIN, allided with the right descending protection pier of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

While transiting S/B on the Illinois River, the M/V Joyce Hale was pushing a 15 barge dry cargo tow when the F/B AT-161 allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge in Pekin, Illinois. Barge was removed from service and is currently being used as a spacer barge at a local facility in Peoria.

06MAY07 CG rcvd notification that the subject vessel was wedged between the fenders of the Matanzas Pass Bridge main channel span. No damage, no injuries and no pollution. The vsl became wedged between the fenders when she was set by the high winds and strong current. As a result, the operator was unable to maintain positive control of the vsl and it was pushed into the fenders by the opposing forces. After approximately 40 mins, the vsl was able to free itself using spring lines w/o further assistance and returned to dock.
While transiting downbound on the Upper Mississippi River the M/V Senator Stennis had an allision with the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge turn table structure. No reported damage to the tow or bridge.

M/V Amy Frances allided (rubbed) the RDB protection cell of Pekin Railroad Bridge. The M/V was D/B, pushing 3 empty asphalt barges with a draft of 2.5' to 3'. Barge MM-75 contacted the protection cell. Their was no damage to the tow, barge or the bridge.

On 10MAY07 the UTV KATHRYN WATSON was pushing 2 red flag barges (KIRBY 30304 and KIRBY 30501B, loaded with oil gas) northbound on the Port Allen Route when the KIRBY 30304 allided with Union Pacific RR Bridge, MM 56 Port Allen Route.  Deck hand stated once the battery was charged, he switched the generators, which lagged between generators, causing the steering to go down while the pilot was maneuvering through the bridge.  Vsl was northbound, about 5 miles from bridge when the crew switched generators and lost steering pump.  The deck hand never checked the location of the vessel nor did he tell the operator he was switching generates before doing so. The KIRBY 30304 suffered only cosmetic damage. No injuries, pollution or further casualty resulted.

M/V MIDLAND allided with the protection pier of the EJ&E RR Bridge at MM 270.5 on the Illinois River.  There were 9 barges in tow at the time of occurrence, none sustained damage.

No damage to bridge or vessel.

UTV VICKI LYNN was south bound on Bayou Bouef pushing UTV MAMA LERE in a dead ship tow when it allided head on with the Bayou Bouef Rail Road Bridge.  There was major damage to the bridge; the bridge tender was taken to the hospital with shortness of breath and pain in upper torso.  There were no other injuries, no pollution.

M/V BUTCH BARRAS REPORTS ALLIDING W/ THE THEBES R.R. BRIDGE MI 43.7 UMR.  REPORTED THAT CURENT SET TOW TOWARDS BRIDGE, RESULTING IN ALLISION AND  DAMAGE ABOVE THE WATERLINE TO ONE LOADED CORN BARGE (ACBL 9901).
