M/V PAT WHITE allided with the right descending protection cell of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge while traveling south bound at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to bridge or tow.

On May 5, 2007, the UTV VICKIE LYNN was pushing 6 loaded open hopper barges in Back Bay Biloxi when the master lined up the tow to go through the I-110 Biloxi Bridge.  The cross current caught the stern of the tug and the tow swung and allided with the fendering system on the bridge.  There was minor damage to the fendering system (one board split) and no damage to the barges.  The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

M/V CINDY CELESTE allided with the protection cell of the I.C. Railroad Bridge and MM 225.4 on the Illinois River.

No damage was sustained by the bridge, vessel or tow.

Barge ACL 00607, while being pushed south bound by M/V RICHARD BAKER, allided with the upper protection pier of the Chessie Railroad Bridge at MM 254 on the Illinois River.

No damage to bridge, vessel or tow.

M/V Captain Bear Ivie reported they allided with the Dubuque Railroad bridge at mile marker 580.0 UMR.  They report they are carrying 7 loads of fertilizer and 7 empites.  They are drafting 9'0".  They are northbound to St. Paul, MN.  They report no damage to barges, boat, or bridge.  They are currently in the lock chamber at Lock & Dam 11 at mile marker 583.0 UMR.  They will remain in the lock until investigators arrive on scene to inspect the barges.  Lock & Dam 11 will remain closed until investigation is complete.

M/V BOB STITH WAS U/W NORTHBOUND WHEN THE TOW ALLIDED WITH THE SABULA RR D/B MM 535 UMR.  THE BARGE THAT ALLIDED WITH THE BRIDGE WAS WTT 850. IT IS THE SECOND BARGE BACK FROM THE HEAD OF THE TOW. M/V BOB STITH RPTD NO DAMAGE TO BRIDGE OR BARGE. THE TOWBOAT WAS PUSHING 15 EMPTY BARGES WHICH PREVIOUSLY CONTAINED DRY CARGO.

Tug KLICKATAT reporting an allision to Vancouver upper bar channel lighted Buoy 14 and later reported allision with the BNRR bridge.   Master called CC and gave more details on allision with Buoy 14 and BNRR Bridge.  Bridge Tender notified.  Station and IO conducted a boarding and issued breathalyzer to Master.

M/V LAURIE S JOHNSTON was southbound pushing 15 loaded barges IVO the Louisiana RR bridge.  Barge CC 7950B made contact with the protective cell of the turntable causing minor damage to the barge.  No damage to bridge or other barges in tow.

On May 5, 2007 at approximately 0400 hours the UTV BAYOU BLACK was pushing 4 barges heading west just past the Dauphin Island Bridge MM 127 EHL.  The pilot stood up on a chair in order to adjust the VHF radio and accidentally bumped the steering sticks with his leg.   When he bumped the sticks it caused the barges ( ING 1556, IB 962) to go aground.  The barges were pulled off ground with the help from the UTV TH Kelly.  The tow was reconfigured and got underway without further incident.  None of the barges were damaged.

Barge KIRBY 10018, while being pushed south bound by M/V CITY OF JOLIET, allided with the protection cell of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 of the Illinois River.

No damage to barge, tow or bridge.

UTV RON HULL w/3 barges FMT 3186 (empty), FMT 3188 (empty), FMT3088 (Raffinate), allided w/ fender system on Galveston Causeway bridge.  No damage, pollution, or injuries reported for vsl.  Minor damage to fender system.

Received report of a bridge allision from the M/V Frank Stegbauer.  Barge had been piloted at approximately 7 mph into the protection cell for the Illinois RR bridge, MM 239.4, Ottowa, IL.  Impact was enough to stop barge and towboat dead while 2 barges on the hip broke lines and continued forward, through the bridge cut, and down river.

Barge sustained heavy crush damage to starboard corner at deck, proceeding downward approximately 12 feet, 9 feet side to side, and 5 feet deep at apex.  Inset included one 2 ft by 2 ft hole near deck and (2) separate 2 in by 18 in fractures, as well as rolling of the steel and heavily damaged internal structural members in way of inset.  All damage was limited to the impact area, forward of 1st transverse floor frame on the starboard corner and did not appear to transmit to other members in compartment.  No other damage was evident as determined by deck walk and examination of compartments for water from main deck.  Entry was made into bow void compartment by deck seamen from the M/V Frank Stegbauer (following O2 evaluation) with lights both illuminating and describing internal damage.  

Due to location of the damage and severity, no temporary repair was applied as no risk of water ingress was detected.  Barge was issued PTP and COI was removed.  Noted expired COD, near ISE date (May 5) and nearly expired COFR on board.  Operator faxed new docs and MISLE checked prior to issuing PTP.  All current.   No damage to bridge, vessel or other barges in tow.

M/V PRAIRIE DAWN HIT THE PROTECTION CELL ON THE LACROSSE R/R DRAWBRIDGE CRACKING ONE TIMBER.  BRIDGE TENDER ASSESSED DAMAGE. BROKEN TIMBERS DID NOT EFFECT BRIDGE OPERATIONS. M/V IS PUSHING 12 LOADED BARGES OF GRAIN.  M/V REPORTS NO DAMAGE TO BARGES. CONDUCTED INVESTIGATION. CONFIRMED NO DAMAGE TO BARGES.

M/V GENE HERDE allided with the downstream protection cell of the Lacrosse Railroad Drawbridge. The vessel is currently U/W downbound enroute to ST. Louis. The vessel is pushing 15 dry cargo barges. No damage has been reported to bridge or barge.  Investigators verified no damage to tow.

AT APP 0100 ON 26 MAY 07,  THE RANDY ECKSTEIN S/B, ALLIDED WITH THE CAIRO BRIDGE PIER , MM 1.3 UMR, RESULTING IN ALL OF THE BARGES BREAKING OUT OF TOW. ONE BARGE, MMB 3508B, LOADED WITH ROCK, SUBSEQUENTLY SANK OUTSIDE THE NAVIGABLE CHANNEL NEAR MM 1.3.  THE SUNKEN MMB 3508B HAS BEEN MARKED WITH A LIGHTED WRECK BUOY.

Lacrosse Railroad Drawbridge reported the M/V Deana Ann allided with the sheer fence on the turn table of the bridge.  The M/V reports no damage.  The bridge tender reports they have broken timbers on the bridge.  M/V Deana Ann is carrying 8 grain barges and final destination is St. Louis, MO.

On 29MAY07 the UTV KOOLCAT with 8 loaded hopper barges were navigating downriver on the LMR when the two lead barges struck the center pylon of the Hwy 190 Bridge located at LMR MM 233. Major damage to the AD 752 and BUNGE 423, which were the two lead barges. Damage is estimated to be $64,356 for the BUNGE 423 and $104,587 for the AD 752.  No pollution, injuries and further marine casualties resulted.
While the tow CAPATIN RUSSELL SIMPSON  was transiting through the Burlington RR bridge the BARGE CC-95142 came in contact with the sheer fence.   No damage to Barge CC 95142.

A Boh Bros. towboat (FL6705MA) was moving a crane/barge with the towboat IDA P configured ahead (bow-to-bow) heading easterly along the Matanzas Pass when the fwd-most stbd spud made contact w/ the underside of the Matanzas Pass Bridge. As a result, the bridge sustained minor damage to several girders and the bridge was closed to both vehicular and vessel traffic until inspected and clear by FDOT engineers (7 hrs). There was no pollution or injuries.  All crew members involved were ordered to take drug & alcohol test.

Oversize tow allision with West Larose Bridge.  UTV Admiral Lee was lead tow and UTV Norah Lynn and UTV Andrew P. Dietz were the push tows.  No damage to vessels, minor damage to bridge fender system, no injuries, and no pollution.
UTV MR LEWIS allided with the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge.  No damage to the UTV MR LEWIS, which was running light ship, and the damage to the bridge consisted of one split timber.

On 31MAY07 at approx. 0505 the M/V JOHN M. RIVER was southbound pushing 15 barges (13 loaded dry cargo barges, 1 empty dry cargo barge and one loaded tank barge). After transiting through the Merchant Railroad bridge the captain was now setting up to transit through the McKinley Bridge and the barge's wire couplings begin to break causing the barges to break a part. The forward nine barges begin to swing to the stbd side. The captain begin backing down and was unable to control the barges. The lead port barge (INO75008) allided with the McKinley Bridge's right descending pier. After alliding with bridge pier all 15 barges brokeawy from the M/V JOHN M RIVERS. Barge INO75008 had  major damage to the bow area and the barge partially sunk at mile 182 UMR in the navigable channel.
M/V MATTHEW T, WHILE PUSHING 6 EMPTY COAL BARGES, CAUSED BARGE ING 1808 TO ALLIDE WITH THE CATTLETTSBURG-KENALA HIGHWAY BRIDGE CENTER PIER MILE 1 BIG SANDY RIVER.

On 18-May-07 at 09:30, UTV SKATCAT pushing 3 loaded grain barges down-bound 3 wide (105’ total width) had its port barge, BUNGE 611B, allide with the  Huey P. Long Bridge Pier at Lower Mississippi River, MM 106, New Orleans, LA.  SKATCAT slowed before allision to allow up-bound ship to pass through middle of bridge's 750' span.  After up-bound ship cleared bridge span, SKATCAT maneuvered toward middle of bridge piers through ships backwash.  Captain underestimated backwash effect & outside edge of tow allided bridge pier.  Two barges damaged totaling $50,000.00.  No pollution, no injuries, no bridge damage, drug/alco testing conducted.
M/V Erna E. Honeycutt was transiting S/B on the Illinois River at approximately MM 151.0 when it allided with the Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to vessel or the bridge.

On 3 June 2007 at approximately 0550 the TUG PETALUMA pushing ahead BARGE201 (J5200), began maneuvering to await the Mare Island Bridge opening and the movement of an anchored sailing vessel out of the channel.  While maneuvering, the vessel sustained an equipment failure of the rudder angle indicator and subsequently allided with the fendering system along the base of the west side of the navigational opening of the Highway 37 Bridge.  Apparent cause of the marine casualty was human error combined with a minor equipment failure.  

Damage:  BARGE 201 (J5200) sustained minor scratches in paint to the port bow rake.  The Highway 37 Bridge fendering system, approximately 60-70 feet of the north west fendering system, was extensively damaged and/or destroyed.

While transiting down bound on the Upper Mississippi River the M/V Robin B. Ingram allided with the Sabula railroad bridge at UMR mile 535. The M/V was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges and reports no damage to bridge or barge.

M/V Roy E. Claverie allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge UMR MM 403.1, vessel was pushing 15 grain barges downbound enroute St Louis, no damage to vessels barges or the bridges protection cell.
While transiting northbound on the Upper Mississippi River the tow of the M/V Capt. Bear allided with the Fort Madison railroad bridge. No damage to vessel or bridge.

UTV BROWN WATER VII, east bound, was pushing 4 barges strung out. Master stated the current caught the head of the tow upon entry to bridge. The starboard side of the lead barge, ACL 98001, struck the starboard fender works of the Galveston Causeway Bridge. The barge then bounced off the fender works and rubbed the port side of the lead barge against the port side fender works. No damage to the barge, no injuries, no pollution.

Coast Guard received a report from John's Pass Bridge tender that The Big M casino vessel had bumped the fendering system on the bridge.  No damage to the bridge and minor scratch damage of 4 foot on the vessel; paint scratch only.

The UTV Cindy Brent was northbound on the Atchafalaya River.  While making way through the crossings of the Simmesport RR Bridge.  Once the lead barge was through the crossings there was an eddy on the northern side, which sucked in the barges to the port side of the vessel and string, causing the allision with the RR bridge.  The K28024 allided with the bridge, causing a 15 inch inset, and a 2-3 inch tear.  No damage to the bridge, bridge is operational.  There was no pollution or injuries.

Bridge Allision- M/V Algowood.  M/V Algowood departed St. Mary's cement downbound the Rouge River.  While passing under the Conrail RR Bridge, Algowood struck the bridge causing minor damage to the vessel.
M/V DAVE CARLTON STRUCK THE CAIRO HWY BRIDGE MM 1.3 UMR WITH 20 LOADED COAL BARGES ALL BROKE LOOSE: GRP OF 16, GRP OF 4 BARGES ALLIDING WITH PIER, 1 IS DAMAGED

The UTV CINDY BRENT was pushing KIRBY barge through the Galveston Rail Road bridge when the current and high wind started to push the tow into the fender system. The Captain went full astern when she noticed the barge being pushed over to the north fendering system. The barge rubbed the fender works. No damage, no pollution, no injuries.

During normal ship operations, a A/B suffered a broken ankle when it was run over by an electric forklift.  The victim was removed from the vessel for medical attention.  The license of the forklift operator was suspended pending outcome of investigation.  No alcohol or drug use suspected or found.

The M/V John H. Macmillan Jr. was transiting S/B on the Illinois River with a 15 barge tow when the port lead barge XL 272 allided with the Meredosia Highway Bridge at approximately MM 71.0 LDB. Their was no damage to the barge or the tow.

The subject wiper, a citizen and native of Bangladesh arrived to Sea Land Terminal Berth 92 on June 9, 2007 on board the vessel Rhein Bridge arriving from Post Said, Egypt. The subject joined the vessel on Jan 06, 2007 at Shanghai and had been working in the position of wiper. Subject was in possession of a valid C1/D US nonimmigrant visa issued in Dhaka. According to the vessel's agent (TF Marine), the subject suffered burns on his body while performing his duties. Accident occurred shortly after he came on watch at 0800 on 10 June 2007. He was taken to the hospital by emergency response team. After the treatment on June 11, 2007 subject was transferred to the hotel room awaiting to join the ship in Savannah, GA. While in the hotel subject disappeared and his whereabouts are unknown at this time. He is now considered a crew deserter. Vessel is currently docked at Savannah, GA and sailing foreign on Jun 14, 2007.
13Jun07: Duty IO requested CG-2692 from agent Norton Lilly.
M/V J. B. Kleinpeter allided with the Sabula Bridge at mile marker 535 Upper Mississippi River. No damage or injuries as a result of this incident.

M/V HENRY J SOUDELIER III allided with the Illinois Railnet Bridge at MM 239.6 on the Illinois River.  The Vessel's mast allided with the underside of the bridge and sustained damage in the way of broken navigation lights and bent piping.  Vessel is north bound to Citgo Lemont pushing 3 loaded Refined Naptha barges.

Illinois Railnet contacted.  MSU Chicago team enroute to inspect and investigate.

On 12JUN07, at 2150, the UTV Mr. Cass was pushing the red flag barge EBL 2992 from Trinity Marine located in Mandeville, LA to Berg, LA for topside and painting work. On the approach to the Industrial Canal, the Captain on board the Mr. Cass misaligned the vessel with lights on the Seabrook Rail Bridge and allided with the fendering system on the Seabrook rail/Ted Hickey auto bridge, which run side by side.  No injuries or pollution resulted.

Recd rpt via SLM that vessel allided with bridge, removing a 5 ft wood board from fendering system.  Contacted vsl and master stated that he was intentionally rubbing against fendering system (15 non-reg hoppers) when barge must have caught the edge of a board and broke a section off of the fender.  No damage to tow or further damage to bridge.

subject vessel was underway outbound through Johns Pass with passengers onboard.  The master observed two jet ski operators inside the pass and slowed his vessel to allow them to clear the pass.  The vessel was pushed to the south and the port side allided with the southern fendering system of Johns Pass bridge, scraping the vessels portside rub rail and causing no apparent damage to the fenders.  The jet ski operators could not be identified.  No further action will be taken given the unforeseen circumstances and missing information regarding the jet ski operators.
The tow of the M/V J.W. Hershey allided with the Dubuque Highway Bridge at MM 579 on the Upper Mississippi River. No damage to tow vessel, barges, or bridge. No injuries as a result of this incident.
M/V TOM TALBERT WAS TRANSITING THE CLINTON R/R D/B MM 518.0 UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER, AND ALLIDED WITH THE PROTECTION CELL, WITH NO REPORTABLE DAMAGE TO BRIDGE OR BARGE.

M/V Sierra Dawn reports they allided with the Sabula Railroad drawbridge at mile marker 535.0 UMR.  The reason for the allision was a loose wire on a barge, wire has been repaired and no damage reported to the vessel, barges, or bridge.  M/V Sierra Dawn is heading northbound to St. Paul, MN.  M/V Sierra Dawn is carrying 15 loaded barges (4 fertilizer and 11 limestone).  The port stern barge  (TCB407) allided w/ the bridge and contains limestone.
MSD QC IO boarded vessel at Lock 13 confirmed no damage to bridge or vessels.

THE M/V O.H. INGRAM ALLIDED WITH THE SABULA RAILROAD BRIDGE AT MILE MARKER 535.0 UMR. THE CAPTAIN OF THE M/V REPORTED THERE IS NO DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE, AND THE ONLY DAMAGE WAS TO A CORN BARGE. THE BARGE IS TAKING ON WATER IN THE NUMBER 1, 2,  AND 4 WING TANKS. THEY WILL TRY AND SHINGLE THE LEAK TO PREVENT FURTHER WATER FROM COMING INTO THE BARGE.

M/V ROBIN B INGRAM WAS TRANSITING THE LACROSSE RAILROAD DRAWBRIDGE AND ALLIDED WITH THE PROTECTION CELL,  WITH NO REPORTABLE DAMAGE TO BRIDGE OR BARGE.  COAST GUARD INVESTIGATORS RESPONDED AND VERIFIED THAT THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO TOW.  BRIDGE TENDER REPORTED NO DAMAGE TO BRIDGE.

The barge GL 134, allided with the Brooks Bridge when the master of the tug vessel steered the tow to hug the starboard side of the channel and the current and wind pushed the barge into the fender system.  One tire from the barge was ripped and part of the fender system was splintered.  Minimal damage occurred to both the barge and bridge fender.

The M/V John H. MacMillan Jr. was transiting N/B on the Illinois River at MM 151.2 pushing a 14 barge tow (7 loaded with coal and salt, 7 empty), when the F/B ART 954 allided with the Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the barge, vessel or the bridge.
Barge CAPE COD while under the control of TUG CYGNUS allided with the south western approach fendering system of the Fore River Bridge damaging several timbers and a navigation light.

Barge SCNO 08033, while being pushed southbound by M/V STEVE MCKINNEY, allided with the underside of the Railroad Bridge at MM 327 on the Cal Sag Canal.

The barge sustained damage in the way of a bent lift eye and a crack in the port stern of a cover.

No damage to bridge.

On June 12, 2007, at approximately 0400 the CFV Miss Elle was transiting north under the L&M Rail Bridge from Lake Ponchartrain into the Inner Harbor Navigational Canal behind another fishing vessel when the L&M Rail Bridge was lowered down on the CFV Miss Elle.  No pollution or injuries resulted.
MARY SCHEEL WAS N/B OHR IVO 940.7 WHEN STERN BARGE GROUNDED OUTSIDE OF CHANNEL.  INITIAL NO DAMAGE WAS FOUND BUT FURTHER INVESTIGATION SHOWED DAMAGE TO THE MEM1802

Barge MSC 8802, while being pushed northbound by M/V MALLARD, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

M/V Prosperity allided with Lacrosse R/R Bridge mile 699.8 while transiting downbound on the Upper Mississippi River.  No damage to bridge or barge, they were pushing 15 loaded grain barges (corn,& soy) with a 9'3'' draft.  Investigators verified no damage to tow.

The M/V LYDIA E. CAMPBELL was southbound pushing 9 barges when barge CHEM 73 made contact with the protection cell of the Florence Highway bridge.  The bridge reported no damage.  The pilot of the LYDIA E. CAMPBELL initially reported no damage but later reported CHEM 73 to have a stbd list with approx 4' of water in the #4 wing void.

THE BARGE CAPE COD ALLIDED WITH THE FORE RIVER BRIDGE.  THE CAPE COD WAS UNDER TOW OF THE TUG PHOENIX  AND ASSISTED BY THE TUG MR JOSHUA. THE BRIDGE SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE TEMPORARY SHEETPILE CONNECTED TO THE OUTBOUND SIDE OF THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM, BUT IS STILL OPERATIONAL. NO POLLUTION, NO INJURIES, OR FURTHER MARINE CASUALTIES RESULTED FROM THIS INCIDENT.

Hopper barge 153 began taking on water and listing at MM 1.6 Monongahela River while in the fleeting area, outside of the channel. The upstream line had parted, allowing the barge to swing around and eventually point down stream.  Water eventually made its way into the hopper, increasing the rate of flooding and eventually causing vessel to capsize and lose cargo into river - vessel never completely sank.  The vessel then slipped free of the remaining mooring line (it came off the top of timber head) and began to float free down river towards 4th of July fireworks/3 Rivers Regatta spectators. CG had a 25' on-scene, monitoring situation. Received call from Fleeting area operator on 5 July 0800 stating that he has a salvage company working out the salvage/safety plan.
UTV JOANNE MARIE allided with the Bayou Sale Bridge fender system.  The bridge itself was not damaged, there were no injuries, and there was no pollution.

06JUL7 0555 local: MSD QC rcvd call from Sector UMR concerning report of UTV James W. Buky rubbing Sabula Bridge.   Master stated no visible damage to bridge or barges.

MSD Quad Cities IO met vessel down river at lock and dam 13.  Barge ACBL 4314 had small hole one foot below water line in it.  Hole size was 1/4 inch with a spray.  Master in process of plugging hole.  No issues with sea worthiness of vessel.  Bridge reported no damage. Vessel cleared to continue voyage.

On 02 June 2007, the bridge tender for CS6 Trout River Bridge, called to report a allision with the bridge causing minor damages to the fendering. The M/V LOU ANNA GUIDRY was traveling downriver through CSX Trout River Bridge with one empty barge. The vessel laid the port bow of barge against fendering system while driving through. Starboard bow however drifted over striking the wooden handrails which was part of the construction of the wooden walkway on starboard side of the barge. The Incident was caused by wind blowing from the left. Damage was limited to a cracked upright stanchion of CSX fendering system walkway handrail.

UTV CUSTOM pushing the red-flagged barge S-35 with a partial load of diesel fuel south bound in Bayou Lafourche allided with the Leeville bridge.  Due to high winds and cross current the barge S-35's starboard side was pushed into the Leeville bridge's west fender system.  Bridge tender reported fender system pilings were pushed back into the concrete bridge structure and the northern most light is inoperable.  No pollution or injuries reported, bridge is operational, no damage reported to UTV or the barge.  Master of UTV was alcohol tested and entire crew was drug tested.

On 12 July 07 @ approximately 1800L, the UTV MCALLISTER SISTERS was underway in the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River with the hopper barge MAC4000 made up to the portside.  While attempting to pass through the Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge 7, the operator noticed the bow of the barge setting to the east side of the draw.  He felt "uncomfortable" and decided to back full on the throttle.  While backing up, the barge made contact with the edge of the fender system on its starboard bow.   There was no damage to the barge or the bridge fender system.

While docking, the MV Rotterdam lost propulsion due to a generator failure.  No 1 & No 2 generators were tripped offline when the bow thrusters were started.  No 3. generator was left to take the full load and subsequently tripped offline.  No 4. generator was started, but not before No 3. generator tripped offline.  There was a brief period (5-10 seconds) that the vessel was without total power.  No 4. generator was started, and No 1 & No 2 generators were restarted.  It took about 8 minutes to regain full power, and for the generators to take the full load. 

During that 8 minute period, while the vessel was under reduced power and maneuverability, the port bow allided with mobile gantry crane # 10 on the facility.  The collision caused paint minimal damage to the vessel, as well as minimal damage to the pier and crane.  The gantry crane was taken out of service by the facility as a precautionary measure, to be inspected.

The design of the system provides that all generators are supplied fuel by 1 fuel line.  According to the class survey, the vessel changed over from fuel oil to gas oil  to the generators prior to arrival in LA/LB.  The lines were gravity fed lines, and Class considered the capacity of the gravity lines not sufficient enough for all the generators that were hooked up to it.  The gravity line was unable to supply the proper amount of gas oil when the load of the generators suddenly changed (i.e. the addition of the bow thruster.) and prevented full capacity operation. When the bow thruster was brought online, the load was too much, and  the generators tripped offline momentarily.

The UTV DAMON WAXLER pushing (3) empty red flag barges allided with the fendering system of the Black Bayou Bridge on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway. The only damage sustained was to the nav light on the bridge's North fender. No damage sustained to any of the barges.

On 12 July 07 @ approximately 1915L, the UTV MCALLISTER SISTERS was underway in the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River with the hopper barge MAC4000 made up to the starboard side.  While attempting to pass through the Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge 7, the operator noticed the bow of the barge setting to the east side of the draw.  He continued through the draw and the barge allided with the east side fender system.  There was no damage to the barge or the bridge fender system.  As a result of this incident and an earlier allision on the same day involving the same vessels, (see IIA #2993490), the operator was placed in a subordinate position and his vessel route was changed until the operating company regains confidence in his abilities.

The fire on board the Kelly Bros. barge started as a result of hot work being performed earlier in the day. It is believed that a hidden ember was the initial source that sparked the fire of the one timber damaged... the fire was isolated to that one timber only! While cutting bolts from the timbers to be removed from the fendering system, the ember simmered throughout the evening and ignited early this AM.

M/V BOB HELTON with 2 empty barges allided with a south piling on west side of Galveston RR Bridge.  The bridge tender lowered the rail road bridge in order to allow a short train to pass.  The M/V BOB HELTON was being assisted by the M/V BRIANNA ELIZABETH while waiting for the bridge to open. The lead barge, KIRBY 17802 struck the piling on the Barges starboard bow.   A combination of wind and outgoing tide contributed to the allision with the piling.

On 15 July 07 @ approximately 1500L, the UTV BUCHANAN 11 was downbound in the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River pushing ahead four light hopper barges.  While attempting to pass through the Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge 5, the barge tow was set to the east side of the draw.  A deckhand was on the starboard bow of the barge giving distances, and shouted to the operator that "the wind was taking him down."  The operator took off headway and placed the vessel in full reverse.  Despite this action, the starboard bow of the barge 
MARY H PETRILLO allided with the northeast fender system.   Three fender timbers were damaged at an estimated replacement cost of $3,000.  The operator did not immediately notify the CG of the hazardous condition because he felt "it was minor."

The M/V JOHNATHON THOMAS allided with a portion of the Galveston Causeway Bridge fendering system that was hit earlier in the day and knocked down.  The Captain of the M/V JOHNATHON THOMAS was unable to see the submerged portion of the fendering.  The barge the vessel was pushing did not allide with the submerged portion of the fender.  No damage was reported.

While heading southbound on the ICW, subject barge transited the fixed bridge span of the Memorial Causeway Bridge with the onboard crane in an elevated condition.  Although the crane's boom was lowered prior to transiting under the bridge, the boom wheel of the crane allided with the bridge.  Owner/company of tug and barge made necessary repairs to the minor damage on the concrete underlining of the bridge.

UTV CAPT ALPHA DOUCET w/ 1 barge (cargo-Slurry oil) allided w/ East side timbers/fendering at San Bernard RR Bridge while transiting outbound toward GICW. No damage to tug/barge. Minor damage to fendering (4 timbers crushed).  Bridge remained operational.

UTV GINGER GRIFFIN NEW pushing T/B GRIFCO 2510 (empty red-flag, last cargo-#6 oil) allided w/ Traylor Brothers' work barge at the Galveston Causeway Bridge.  Vsl lost steering while transiting westbound through Causeway.  Vessel's follow-up steering linkage assembly consists of a ball joint assembly which is where the failure occured.  The ball joint seperated from it's housing causing the steering gear to swing to starboard.  Awaiting damage estimates for the fendering system and crane barge that was struck.
25-Jul-07: Received cost estimate for damage done to fenders (160,000).  Investigation upgraded.

On May 26, 2007 at 1040 the UTV CARRIE MAYS, was transiting southbound from Vulcan Materials on the Atchafalaya River when it allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge. The Freight Barges M 7651 and R 9023 sustained damage to their port sides.  The total damage estimate for the barges is $50000.  No injuries, pollution or further marine casualties resulted.

Barge VL 81424, while being pushed northbound by M/V JAMES BUKY, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

On July 26, 2007 at approximately 1100 hours the UTV ANTHONY TAYLOR was pushing the barge MISS DARLENE when she allided with the Biloxi I-110 draw bridge.  The initial report was that the crane onboard the MISS DARLENE made contact with the bridge.  It was determined that crane never made contact with the bridge, but the port side of the MISS DARLENE did make contact with the fendering system, as stated by both the tug operator and bridge tender.  In addition, CG investigators did not observe any point of contact on the crane.  The bridge tender also stated that neither the bridge or fendering system sustained any damage.

The UTV MISS JANICE, was transiting south-bound on the Atchafalaya River when it allided with the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge.  The Hopper Barges SG528B and CGB232 flooded due to damage to their starboard side.  Their was no damage to the bridge.  No injuries, pollution or further damage resulted.

27 July 2007 @ approximatlely 1800 local - The container barge COLUMBIA NORFOLK was moored away from the piers of Colonna Shipyard on a series of three mooring clusters, each with a center "king pin."  A quick-moving thunderstorm came in from the west.  The barge was struck by lightning approximately where it was made up to the western cluster.  The lightning resulted in the aft mooring line parting and the stern swinging to the north toward the middle of the river.  As the starboard side of the barge caught the wind the barge pulled over the eastern cluster and then broke away from the remaing.  The barge rotated, drifted down river and struck the northwest fender system of the #5 Railway Bridge with its stern.  There was some damage to the fender system, but the extent is unknown.  After the strike, the bow rotated and the starboard side came to rest against the west side of the fender system.  The storm calmed and the barge drifted up river and grounded approximately 200 feet from the bridge.  Tugs recovered the barge, towed it to Colonna Shipyard and secured it to Pier 5 west.
The UTV Doris McKinney had hit the Bayou Sorrel Bridge on the Port Allen Route tearing off one of the padeyes off the bridge.

20July07 @ 1632:  received report from the Beaufort Emergency Dispatch that the Tug G.A. Franklin or its tow allided with the Ladies Island Swing Bridge in Beaufort, SC.  the vessel was southbound in the ICW.  No injuries, hazard to navigation or structural damage to the bridge was reported.  SCDOT confirmed only damage was to the fendering system.

Master of the vessel was directed to get Drug and Alcohol tested but complained that he did not feel well and called 911.  He was taken to a local hospital where he later departed.  Local police escorted the USCG Investigators to a hotel where the mariner was located.  

The IO's obtained the mariners contact information and his Merchant Mariner information.  After further review of his MMS, it was suspected to be fraudulent.  Additionally, after a review of the tug's bridge log it was discovered that the tug had struck the Wappoo Cut Draw bridge as well and not reported it.

On 25 July 2007 at approximately 0920 CST the M/V LINDA LITTLE (O.N. 566044) allided with the Sidney C. Lewis Highway Bridge located at mile marker 88.8 Cumberland River.  The M/V LINDA LITTLE was transiting upbound with 15 loaded coal barges at the time of the allision.  The stern barge in the starboard string, C525, allided with the bridge pier nearest to the left descending bank.

Barge WTT 4158, while being pushed southbound by M/V THRUSTON B. MORTON, allided with the protection cell of the EJ & E Railroad Bridge at MM 270 on the Illinois River.

Barge sustained a 2 inch crack in the bow void and a 3 inch crack in the #2 starboard wing void. Satisfactory temporary repairs were made.

No damage to bridge.

Barge CBC 224, while being pushed southbound by M/V WALTER HAGASTAD, allided with the McDonough Street protection pier at MM 287.2 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

Towing Vessel CAPTAIN BRUCE STAPP was southbound in the ICW. As the tow was clearing the Queen Isabella Causeway the head of the tow was swept to the west by strong current and the lead barge grounded on the west ICW embankment. No damage, no injuries.

On 12 August 2007, at approx 0015, UTV CHELSEA was transiting southbound in the Industrial Canal when it drifted and allided with the Almonaster Railroad Bridge while waiting for the bridge to be raised.  Damage was limited to minor paint scrapes on the starboard bulwarks.   No pollution or injuries occurred.

The F/V BIRDIE P was transiting the New Jersey Intercoastal Waterway and while proceeding under the Middle Thoroughfare Bridge the vessel's starboard outrigger brushed up against the underside of the bridge.  No damage was done to either the bridge or vessel.

M/V City of Joliet reported they allided with the Lower Pekin RR Bridge at MM 151.2 ILR. M/V reported that they caused some damage to the protection cell of the bridge but no damage to their barges. They reported they are pushing 11 loaded barges of chemical oil products all red flags.   MSD Peoria IO conducted cursory exam on scene to facilitate vessel movement.  No damage noted, vessel voids clear, minimal damage to bridge protection cell.  Vessel cleared to continue voyage.

The M/V PATTY WHITE was pushing the seagoing barge HELEN II southbound, approaching the Chickasabogue swinging R/R Bridge.  The pilot and two deckhands were stationed on the bow of the barge.  The pilot was issuing commands via VHF radio.  The M/V RUSSELL T was assisting on the starboard bow of the HELEN II.  As the vessel approached the bridge, the line from the HELEN II to the RUSSELL T parted and the HELEN II turned to port, striking the upper structural member of the Chickasabogue R/R Bridge.  Following impact, the bridge tender was able to swing the southern half of the bridge back into position to prevent additional impacts.  The vessel straightened out, and made it the rest of the way through the bridge without further incident.

The RUSSEL T had been positioned on the starboard forward side of the HELEN II, and was being pulled by the HELEN II, while in neutral, by a headline which was connected from the forward starboard cleat on the barge to the head of the towing vessel.  Immediately prior to the allision, the RUSSEL T had come ahead to slacken the tow line, and prepare to bring it in.  The pilot who was on the tug was not aware that the tug had put the engine in gear.  As the RUSSELL T came ahead, the bow of the HELEN II swung to port.  The pilot asked the tug if they were pushing on the barge.  They tug stated they were not, and the pilot immediately ordered the tug to back down on the tow line to stop the swing of the barge.  As the tug attempted to back down, the line parted.  Investigation revealed the line was in poor condition prior to parting.

As a result of the loss of drag on the forward starboard cleat from dragging the RUSSEL T when the RUSSEL T came ahead, in combination with a steady wind out of the southwest pushing on the nearly empty barge, the head of the barge swung to port impacting the bridge.  The bridge was immediately shut down to train traffic, but remained open to navigation.  Approximately 12 hours later, following inspection, the bridge was reopened to trains at a 5 MPH limit.  Initial damage estimates to the bridge were in excess of $100,000.  A main diagonal structural frame and a vertical structural frame, the fourth upright, were bent as a result of the allision.  The barge suffered only a split rail at the bow, on the immediate port side of the stem.  The barge was able to continue on its voyage without further incident.

Barge WEB 225, while being pushed southbound by M/V JAMES L OBERSTAR, allided with the Cass Street Bridge at MM 288 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

Barge FMT 3080, while being pushed southbound by M/V SUGARLAND, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River. Upon impact, one securing cable broke. No personnel injuries reported.

CAPT ALPHA DOUCET WAS ATTEMPTING TO NAVIGATE THROUGH THE SAN BERNARD RAIL ROAD BRIDGE WITH THE T/B KIRBY 24704 WHEN THE BARGE ALLIDED WITH THE BRIDGE FENDERING SYSTEM AND CAUSED MINOR DAMAGE.  NO DAMAGE TO BARGE.

M/V COUSHATTA WITH TWO EMPTY BARGES ALLIDED WITH CANEY CREEK SWING BRIDGE. INITIAL REPORT MADE TO WRONG COTP ZONE.  INITIAL INVESTIGTION WAS CONDUCTED BY SEC CORPUS CRISTI AND WAS PASSED TO MSU GALVESTON.

This is a data collection only, could not delete Causal Analysis.

M/V James Buky after transiting the Pekin RR Bridge, had an allision with Midwest Grain Dock located at 151.4 ILR causing damage to their starboard stern barge that contains salt. The M/V was pushing a total of 15 loaded barges north bound when the allision occurred causing damage to the barge and dock.

Received notification of an allision at 0627 between UTV Tobie K. Devall, pushing two red flag barges, and the Victoria Barge Canal Bloomington Railroad Bridge.  The UTV was pushing DCBL 62 and lead barge EIDC 61, both loaded with 10,000 bbls of Cyclohexane.  The Captain stated after the lead barge cleared the bridge the tide set to the starboard, he attempted to steer away when a cable popped.  The starboard side of DCBL 62 rubbed the boards, the railroad bridge was not struck.  No injuries or pollution noted.  The barge received no damage; the east boards for the railroad bridge received slight damage to the walkway.  Per the Port of Victoria, owners of the bridge, all damage was determined to be normal wear and tear.

M/V BILL ARNOLD allided with the 106th Street Bridge at MM 331 on the Calumet River.  Landing was made to maneuver around moored vessels in the area.

No damage to bridge or vessel.

M/V GLADIATOR pushing 9 empty hopper barges allided with the protection cell at the Cass St. Bridge at MM 288 on the Illinois River.

No damage to bridge or vessel.

RCVD NOTIFICATION THAT THE BARGE CBC 762 WAS INVOLVED IN A BRIDGE ALLISION. THE CAPTAIN OF THE UTV SMITH INVADER REPORTED THAT WHILE MAKING THE INBOUND TRANSIT TO CASHMAN'S PIER IN QUINCY MA, THE STARBOARD QUARTER OF THE BARGE CAME IN CONTACT WITH THE RIVER GAUGE MARKER LOCATED ON THE STARBOARD SIDE OF THE FORE RIVER BRIDGE.  NO DAMAGE TO THE BARGE, AND MINIMAL DAMAGE TO THE RIVER GAGUE MARKER.

Received report from M/V THRUSTON B. MORTON that it had an allision with the EJ&E Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River. The allision caused a crack in the port side bow void of the DM 954. Vessel proceeded to Channahon Fleet where inspectors identified damage: a 2 and 1/2" crack on port bow above the water line.

09/15/07 - The UTV CAPT TED was pushing the deck barge SUSQUEHANNA northbound in the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  At 0423L the barge allided with the east fender system of the Norfolk Southern Railway Bridge 7, without damaging the fender system or barge.  The operator stated that wind gusts and the ebb tide pushed the barge to the east, forcing him to back down while still in the draw of the bridge.  The operator stated that a ship moored just north of the Gilmerton Bridge was also a factor in his decision to back while in the draw.

Barge CC 97139, while being pushed northbound by M/V C MICHAEL REEVES, allided with the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270.6 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

The Panamanian containership MANHATTAN BRIDGE reported two missing crewmembers last seen on the upper deck of the ship after departing Port Elizabeth, NJ. A search of the ship was conducted with negative results. USCG and NYPD search and rescue assets were deployed. One of the crewmembers was recovered and taken to a local hospital for medical treatments. Local law enforcement agents interrogated the rescued crewman, who revealed that he and the other crewmember jumped off the vessel on their own accord to rendezvous with family already in the United States. He was deported back to his native country after his release from the hospital. The body of the second crewmember was eventually found on 21Sep2007 in Perth Amboy, NJ.

Case to remain at data collection level of investigation as the act of the two personnel in the water was an intentional act and not an accident.

The UTV BAYRIDGE SERVICE was enroute to BP Oil terminal in the Maumee River.  The UTV was towing an empty tank barge along side. While transiting through the CSX bridge on the east side of the river, the UTV struck the east side abutment on the southern edge. Damage was minimal.  CSX survey team (dive team) reported cosmetic damage consisting of a 6 inch gash about 2 feet long above the water line and a smaller gash below the water line.  At the time of the incident both damaged areas were above the water line (see pictures in evidence folder). The bridge has no fender system in place in the damaged areas.  The UTV's fender system caught protruding bolts from the bridge abutment and ripped an 8 foot section of fender from the vessel.  There was no structural damage to the vessel or bridge.  No pollution.

On 18 SEP 2007, at approximately 0900, the construction barge STCO-503 veered to starboard, when the port winch broke and let go and allided with the east bound span of the I-10 bridge over Lake Ponchatrain. The barge was being pushed by the M/V CAPTAIN JOHN.  No injuries or pollution resulted and no damage to the barge.

At above date at approx. 12:02 Received report from the Master of the vessel that a fire had develop inside the engine room while towing the freight barge Chicago Bridge from San Juan to Jacksonville Fl.  Master stated that the CO2 system had been energized and that all of the crew members were safe.  UTV requested tow assistance from owner/operators, ATT UTV was dead in the water.  Vessel was inspected in San Juan upon return and given instruction to affect repairs.
M/V Robin B. Ingram allided with a protection cell on the Burlington Iowa Railroad bridge. The barge Ingram 4630 has reported damaged.

Crescent RR Bridge mm 481.4 UMR reported M/V Butler (ACOE) vessel allided with the bridge.   MSD QC contacted vessel master.  Master stated that he was getting set over and rubbed the protection cell.  Master had already spoken with the bridge on radio.

While traveling down bound at MM 254 on the Illinois River, M/V GLADIATOR allided with the Chessie Railroad Bridge protection pier.

No damage to bridge or vessel.

A crewmember onboard the Traylor Bros. vessel, N240, was injured when the vessel he was operating struck a piling cluster of the Galveston Rail Road Bridge fendering system. The vessel operator was pitched forward and struck the steering wheel and windshield, injuring his mouth.

HOU2007/0170: Operator of the UTV NITA E pushing the freight barge EFC-9658 allided with the Buffalo Bayou RR Bridge causing substantial damage to the South side fender system. Investigation determined operator struck the fender system while transiting under the bridge and failed to provide notification of being involved in a marine accident. No damage was done to the barge. S&R proceedings against the operator to follow.

The tug PHYLLIS MORAN is an un-inspected, 66-foot, steel hull towing vessel owned and operated by Moran Towing of Virginia.  The freight barge DMT 406 is a 260-foot, single skin, steel hull barge owned by Dann Moran Towing, LC.  On October 2, 2007 at approximately 0230L, the DMT 406 allided with the northwest fender system of the Great Bridge Locks on the Chesapeake-Albemarle Canal, VA while being pushed ahead by the PHYLLIS MORAN.  There was no damage to the tug or barge, but one section of the fender system was destroyed, with repairs estimated at $100K.

The M/V BEN R JOHNSON was pushing 2 barges loaded with construction supplies and a crane westbound in the ICW.  As the tow approached the bridge, winds out of the south aided by a strong current out of the west pushed the tow toward the north-east fender system of the bridge.  As the tow vessel approached the north side of the channel, it softly grounded.  Immediately after the tow vessel grounded, the south wind continued to push the lead barge north until it rubbed the fender system.  The tow was able to immediately get underway, and proceeded through to the west side of the bridge, where it sputtered down to inspect for damage.  No damage was found to have been sustained by the tow vessel, its barges, or the bridge as a result of this incident.

The UTV MASON ANDREWS is a 62-foot, steel hull towing vessel, owned and operated by Norfolk Tug Company.  The DERRICK BARGE is a 60-foot, steel hull deck barge, owned by Cottrell Contracting Corporation.  On October 2, 2007 at approximately 1345L, the MASON ANDREWS was towing a flotilla astern that was 1,856 feet in length, comprised of a dredge, two deck barges (including the DERRICK BARGE), a fuel barge, 250-feet of pontoons, and 1000-feet of pipeline on the Intracoastal Waterway (ICW).  Just minutes before the flotilla proceeded under the Route 168 Bridge, the crane operator aboard the DERRICK BARGE radioed the tug operator to let him know the crane boom was lowered to the proper height to proceed safely under the bridge.  As the flotilla proceeded under the bridge, the derrick boom allided with the west span of the Route 168 Bridge.  The City of Chesapeake inspected the bridge and noted only cosmetic damage requiring no repairs.  The damage to the boom cost $300 to repair.

M/V STEVE MCKINNEY was northbound with 8 barges in tow. While approaching bridge near MM 287 ILR, a controlled landing was necessary on the protection cell of the bridge in order to make the transit of the next bridge safely. Port stern barge CHEM 230 was the barge that struck the protection cell. MSU Chicago responded and confirmed no damage to barge or cell.

M/V Andrea Leigh had an allision with the protection cell sheer fence on the Clinton R/R bridge.  No damage to bridge, the M/V discovered a one foot six crack on the STBD lead barge.  All barges are loaded with coal.  The M/V has dropped barges at the Beaver Slue at MM 512.6 and the M/V will be DB to Keokuk Iowa.  Both the M/V and the tow are currently at MM 512.6 UMR.

On 24 SEP 07, at approximately 0645  the M/V DELTA BENGAL was outbound on Barataria Waterway pushing COASTAL RIG 20. The 5 ton crane on the COASTA RIG 20 was left out of the rack. The crane boom grazed and slid under the Wagner Bridge, damaging the crane. The crane boom was the only part of the rig that sustained any damage. LA DOT responded to the incident, completed an assessment, and reported no damage to the bridge. The crane boom was replaced when COASTAL RIG 20 arrived offshore to complete work for Exxon Mobil. There was no pollution or personnel casualties.
Tug Miss Rachel-Kirby was passing under bridge in Victoria Barge canal enroute Corpus Christi. Tug was halfway under bridge when the barge 13954 allided with bridge on starboard side amidships.

The UTV BAYRIDGE SERVICE (while towing along side the ENERGY 6505 (empty)), was transiting to the BP Oil terminal through the CSX swing bridge on the Maumee River and made light contact with the bridge abutment.  There was no damage to the tug, barge or bridge and no pollution.  Contacted CSX to get an assessment from the bridge surveyors, no reported damage.  

This is the second incident with this particular UTV within a month (Case #3059755).  MSU Toledo has contacted the company to ascertain the reasoning for UTV's two allisions.  Hornbeck Offshore has engaged their causal analysis team to research the recent events and will report back to the MSU Toledo.  The manager for Hornbeck has also held meetings with the tug captains reiterating the severity of the events and to prevent any further allisions.
D/B VESSEL ALLIDED WITH R/D BRIDGE PIER OR THE R/D SPAN ON CANTON BRIDGE.

The M/V Charles Southern had an allision with the upper protection cell of the Louisiana Railroad Draw Bridge at MM 282.1 UMR. The Charles Southern was down bound enroute MM 167 LMR pushing 2 empty Anhydrous Ammonia tank barges. There is no damage to the bridge or to the tow.

M/V Joyce Hale hit the protection cell on the Sabula R/R draw bridge, no damage to bridge or tow reported.  The cargo is 12 loaded barges of grain (beans and corn). Destination is St. Louis, MO.  No damage noted to barges or vessel.

M/V Angela K allision with the Lansing HWY bridge protection cell. M/V pushing 14 barges of loaded grain and 1 barge of loaded scrap.  Barge CC- 8156-B is taking on water #3 void is open to the river with undetermined damage to hull.   The channel is blocked. Assist vessels are the M/V JACOB MICHAEL ECKSTEIN, M/V ADAM B, and M/V JESSE-Y.  Tow safely removed from protection cell and moored alongside the tow of the M/V BRUCE R BIRMINGHAM.  The only vessel damaged is the F/B CC-8156-B.  Voids 1, 2 , 4 and 5 have progressive flooding due to leaking bulkheads between the voids.  The bow and stern voids are watertight.  Marine surveyor arrived on board to attempt a temporary repair and assessment of damage to tow.  The crew and surveyor were unable to dewater void 3 due to extent of damage allowing water to enter void.   The water level fluctuated between 3 and 4 feet in void.  All other voids had 6 inches or less of water and the dewatering pumps in those spaces are sufficient.  Vessel is stable and will be moved downriver to Brennan Marine fleeting area at mile 660 to be maintained by fleet personnel until vessel cargo can be offloaded to another barge.

M/V Queen City reported a controlled landing on the Dubuque Railroad Drawbridge.  The fourth barge out from the towboat on the starboard string was damaged.  The Barge number is ING 825. The Queen City reported a pump was keeping up with the water coming in from the crack.

MSD QC IO boarded vessel in Savanna, IL.  Barge wandered out from line and caught bridge.  No broken wires or other damage noted. Barge sustained damage below waterline that pumps could not keep up with.  The barge was placed on inside of tow and drafts 9'8" at lowest point.

M/V KATHY ELLEN  allided with the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge at UMR mm 518.  The barge number AGS 769 rubbed against the left descending bank upriver protection cell of the bridge.  No damage to any vessel or the bridge.
UTV HOWARD BLANK WITH TWO EMPTY RED FLAGS RUBBED THE NORTH SIDE OF THE BRIDGE HEADING WEST BOUND. NO DPI RPTD.  BARGES DOUBLED UP FMT 3176 MADE CONTACT WITH BRIDGE.
UTV ISIDORE CENAC PUSHING TWO EMPTY BARGES, CTCO 326 AND CTCO 325,  ALLIDED WITH THE CANEY CREEK PONTOON BRIDGE WITH THE CTCO 326.  NO DAMAGE TO EITHER SUBJECT.

Barge ME 9902, while being pushed s/b by M/V MALLARD, allided with the right descending protection pier of the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at MM 270 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

On October 22, 2007 the UTV ELIZABETH HUGER was heading north bound near MM 38 on the Port Allen/ Morgan City Alternate Route and lost visibility due to heavy rain.  The CBC 0184 consequently allided with the south west corner of the Bayou Sorrel bridge. No damage, no injuries, and no pollution resulted.

VTS port Arthur received a phone call land line from the UTV Lake Charles that she had just had a allision with the West Port Arthur Bridge Fender System NW side.  He had 2 loads of Asphalt and the Barge was the Canal 7019 with minor damage and no pollution.

27 Oct 07
The UTV Lake Charles with two loaded asphalt barges collided with the West Port Arthur Bridge fendering system causing damage to the North fender.  The Pilot on watch during the time of the incident stated he was making his approach to the bride heading to west to Houston.  He stated he was line up to go through the bridge opening when the current changed his approach and the barges were heading towards the bridge.  He tried to power up the vessel with no effect on his course then he tried to back down hard and steer for the bank, which caused him to collide with the fendering system for the bridge.  Pilot wrote a statement to these facts and is recorded as evidence.

  A 15 point inspection was conducted to the vessel were no deficiencies were noted.  Barge inspection was conducted and two small cracks were located and issued 8-35 for repairs.  (Notes) on the barge were that large amount of sand and wood from the fenders was on deck.  This was photographed and is being entered as evidence.  Drug and alcohol testing were conducted.

28 Oct 07: MSD conducted an MC investigation on CFV DOUBLE E after an allision with Matanzas Pass Bridge fendering, FT Myers Beach. Vessel is a 80.5 ft, 144 GT, 12 ft draft. steel hull Shrimper. Weather night time clear, good visibility, winds 10 kts with flooding tide. Conducted interviews with crew, received CG- 2692 & statements,  vessel speed 1 knot. Three POB onboard, no pollution or injuries. CG Station FMB witnessed the incident and performed 4100 boarding. Met with DOT rep who inspected bridge-sat, minor damage to vessel outrigger stbd side. Vessel outrigger were half way down during inbound transit under bridge. Vessel and Operator involved in previous allision with same bridge on 2007/05/06. 

Operator stated vessel's ceiling clearance is 66 ft. The bridge main channel ceiling clearance is 65 ft. Operator indicated the current and wind set the vessel into the bridge. The vessel drifted free and moored at the dock. Vessel operator stated to CG Inspector he not had any sleep since Friday night 26 Oct and had been at the helm from 3:00 pm on Saturday until the vessel moored. Vessel's operator lack situation awareness during transit through restricted waterway at night, which contributed to this incident.

MSD St. Paul was notified by  Upper River Services that the MV JL FLEMING made contact with the protection timbers for the railroad swing bridge at Mile Marker 14 on the Minnesota River. Investigators verified that the sheer fence for the bridge turntable was damaged.  Minor insets in barge not affecting seaworthiness also verified.

On the 29th of October 2007, at 0248, The M/V GRAND RACE was transiting westbound through the C&D Canal enroute to the Port of Baltimore, MD, when during the transit the radar mast struck Reedy Point Bridge and a short period later also struck Summit Bridge.  No damage was done to either of the two bridges but the vessel's mast buckled back from the impact and knocked out the radar.  The Chief Mate onboard admitted he inadequately measured the air draft for the vessel.  

The case has been referred for enforcement for several violations, including negligence, failure to report a marine casualty, and not providing vessel characteristics to the State Pilot.

On 30 OCT 2007, at approx 0300, the  UTV NAN allided with the Belle Chasse Highway Lift Bridge.  The mast of the vessel struck the bridge and approx 6 feet broke off.  The bridge tender conducted test lifts following the incident and found the bridge to be operating properly.  No subsequent damage or injuries were reported.

ON OCTOBER 23, 2007 AT 1000, THE M/V POWERBALL WAS TRANSITTING THROUGH RIGOLETS PASS AND LOST POWER AND ALLIDED WITH THE RIGOLETS BRIDGE. THE VESSEL SUSTAINED MINOR DAMAGE TO ITS PORT SIDE RIGGING, THE BRIDGE WAS NOT DAMAGED. NO POLLUTION AND NO INJURIES.

The USCG SEC MIA received a notification of an allision while transiting The George Bush Highway Bridge. While  M/V LOU ANNA GUIDRY was towing a Barge, M/V ARKANSAS; the East Span from the bridge started lowering. VSL operator sounded the danger signal and backed, alerting bridge tender who opened the span. The lowering span caused damaged to the gantry on the dredge, and also on the Bridge itself. Bridge was deemed safe to reopen for highway traffic. Damage evaluation pending.

The M/V THERESA L. WOOD'S tow hit the protection cell of the Florence hwy bridge at MM 56 ILR.  The port lead barge received a 2' X 3" hole in the bow void, no flooding.  No damage reported to the protection cell.

At 0808 on  November 7, 2007, the container ship COSCO BUSAN departed the Hanjin Terminal, Oakland Inner Harbor, Berth 56, bound for sea.  A San Francisco Bay Pilot had the conn, and intended to pass under the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge between towers Delta and Echo.  Visibility at departure was less than one-quarter mile in fog.  At 0827, a watch stander at Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) San Francisco contacted the COSCO BUSAN because he noted the vessel's heading was Southwest of the intended track.  The COSCO BUSAN confirmed their intention to use the Delta-Echo span.  At 0830, the COSCO BUSAN allided with the Delta Tower of the Bay Bridge, damaging the fender system and causing a breach in the port side shell, above the waterline, between frames 128 and 150.  The breach affected ballast tank #2, fuel oil tank #3, and fuel oil tank #4, which discharged an estimated 53,653 gallons of Intermediate Fuel Oil (IFO).  The COSCO BUSAN initially anchored in Anchorage 7 at 0855, but subsequently moved to Anchorage 9 at 1105 due to limited under keel clearance in this location.  Damage to the COSCO BUSAN and the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge exceeded $4.5 million dollars, not including the cost of the oil spill response and cleanup.

M/V J.W. HERSHEY allided with the upper protection cell of the turn table of the Illinois Central R/R D/B (Dubuque R/R D/B) at mm 579.9 UMR. The M/V was downbound with a destination of St. Louis pushing 11 loaded and 3 empty grain barges at time of incident. The allision caused damage to barges VL 81406 and ABC 805B. There was no damage to the bridge.

25APR07: UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY is U/W N/B at MM570 on the LMR pushing 4 barges when it experiences a problem with the STBD MDE. Master safely manuevered vessel to LDB using PORT MDE.

No further damage, pollution or injuries were reported.

Drugs or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this event.
M/V JEFFBOAT rubbed against the Sabula RR D/B mm 535 UMR.  The M/V JEFFBOAT reported no damage to bridge or barges.  MSD QC IO met vessel at Lock 13 and confirmed no damage.
The M/V Ed Renshaw, north bound, allided with the lower protection cell of the La Crosse Rail Road bridge.

On November 14, 2007 the UTV TIM BURNS was pushing two tank barges, FMT 3182 and FMT 3184, loaded with gasoline northbound in the Mobile River enroute to the Shell facility in Saraland.  As the tug was making turn to approach the CSX Railroad Bridge at Chickasaw Creek, the port side lead barge FMT 3182 rubbed the south side fender piling, causing the bow to glance off to the starboard.  The starboard bow of the FMT 3182 then landed on the north side fender works and destroying approximately 125 feet of the fender works.  There was no contact with the bridge and no damage to the barge.  After the investigation, the tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

While transiting southbound at MM 288.1 on the Illinois River M/V KIOWA allided with the Cass St. bridge. KIOWA had 6 empty hopper barges in tow with no damage reported to barges or bridge. The pilot on board the KIOWA stated he had to allide with bridge due to 03 recreational boaters moored up in a no-mooring zone at the Bicentennial Park in Joliet, IL. The high cross-winds in the area were also posing a possible threat of the vessel barges approaching the recreational boats if the pilot did not take excessive action to compensate. MSU Chicago responded and confirmed report of no damage and report of possible unsafe navigational conditions. Recreational boaters instructed to move to a safe-mooring location.
On 09 November 2007, the M/V JOEL SMITH allided with the Highway 23 Bridge while transiting the GICW Algiers Route.   No injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.
On November 2, 2007, the Container Ship Zim Xiamen allided with the Bayonne Bridge, while inbound to Port Newark.  The vessel continued its voyage to berth without further incident.

11AUG07:  Barge GL 62 allided with the Wappo Bridge while under tow by the Tug CAPT HARDHEAD along the ICW near Charleston SC. SCDOT bridge inspectors were notified.  No damage reported to vessels or to bridge.  No pollution.  No injuries.

The UTV BIG BAY grounded while trying to push it's two barges up on the bank in Pelican Cut moorings. The UTV has to wait for the Galveston Causeway Rail Road bridge to open again. The UTV was pushed by a strong ebb tide and got it's aft stuck in the mud. The UTV JANICE CAROL came to assist by holding the BIG BAY's tow while he freed himself from the mud. When the JANICE CAROL came up along side the BIG BAY, the BIG BAY'S head wire fell overboard and became entagled in JANICE CAROL's starboard wheel.

ON 29 NOV 07, AT APPROX 2030, THE UTV SHARON GAIL PUSHING SPUDBARGE KS-392 ALLIDED WITH WEST LAROSE BRIDGE ON ICWW MM 35 WHL.   NO DAMAGE REPORTED TO THE  WEST LAROSE BRIDGE PER THE BRIDGE SUPERVISOR, NO INJURIES, NO POLLUTION.  MASTER WAS DRUG TESTED.

The UTV CHEROKEE was northbound in the Black Warrior River pushing one crane barge and 6 open hopper barges configured 1,3,3 long.  As the tow proceeded under the SL & SF RR Bridge at MM 219, suction from the east bank influenced the tow to shift slightly to starboard.  The starboard stern or the WGN 9712 and the starboard bow of the WGN 360 simultaneously impacted the east concrete bridge fender leaving a scuff mark.  No damage was reported to have occurred to the bridge or barges as a result of this incident.  The tow continued on its voyage without further incident.

Received report of a allision involving the Melville Bridge and the M/V Archie Wilson at MM 29 Atchafalaya River. No damage reported to the bridge, the vessel received minor damage to one radar, no pollution, and not to be considered a hazard to navigation.

On November 26, 2007 at 1200, while transiting southbound on the Morgan City/Port Allen Alternate Route the UTV SUE ELLEN allided with the Bayou Sorrel Bridge's control cable.  No damage was done to the vessel but the bridge's cable broke.  No injuries and pollution was reported.

UTV THE STING with construction spud barge BWM 68 lost control due to strong currents in the Port Isabel ICW resulting in light contact of the spud of the barge with the Queen Isabella Causeway. No damage to Queen Isabella Causeway.  No injuries.  Port bow spud of the barge was bent in the process of stopping the barge, no other damage to barge.

The BRIDGEBUILDER VIII is a 25-foot, U.S. flagged towing vessel, owned and operated by American Bridge Company.  The SEI 150-2 is a 150-foot, single skin deck barge, also owned and operated by American Bridge Company.  On December 5, 2007 at approximately 0907L, the SEI 150-2 allided with the Chincoteague Swing Bridge fender system while being pushed ahead by the BRIDGEBUILDER VIII.  The center piling on the south side of the fender system was damaged.  American Bridge Company repaired the fender system and held training with the crew of the tug and barge.
JW HUNTER NTFD STBD LEAD BARGE (AGS 747) ALLIDED WITH RD CHNL PIER OF IRWIN COBB BRIDGE WHILE S/B AT MM 937 OHR AT 1240. THE M/V BLAIR WILSON ASSTD WITH THE ADRIFT BARGES.

MAGDALENA GREEN allided with dolphin system of the Odgen St. bridge in Menominee, MI.  No injuries, pollution, or waterway obstruction.  Minor damage to dolphin (head lamp damaged) and paint damage to vessel.  Coast Guard found out about the incident via the internet on Monday, December 10, 2007.  
(http://www.boatnerd.com/passage/defaultpassage.htm)

On December 2, 2007 at approximately 0435 hours the UTV TH KELLY was heading south bound pushing 7 hopper barges, as they passed under the 14 Mile CSX Bridge barges SCF 2202 and IP 6062 made contact with the bridge fendering system.  The other barges listed in the tow are Big 9914B, IP 6073, SCF 2202, B0759, SCF 2207.  According to the bridge tender the contact broke 5 boards on the fendering systems.  The flood tide caused the tow to set on to the fendering system.  None of the barges were damaged and the tow continued on to its next port of call without further incident.

On 12 December 2007, at 2015, while transiting southbound on the Atchafalaya River the side of the UTV EDNA T GATTLE 's tow collided with the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge. Both the ING 1953 and the OR 9023 were damaged.  No damage was done to the bridge and no pollution and or injuries resulted.
M/V NADINE BAKER (299166) ALLIDED WITH THE SPOTTSVILLE RR BRIDGE AT MILE 8.3 GREEN RIVER, THEY WERE D/B PUSHING 04 LOADED COAL BARGES AND STRUCK THE RIGHT DESCENDING PIER ON THE SPOTTSVILLE BRIDGE.

The M/V Frank Stegbauer was D/B with two breasted, empty, anhydrous ammonia barges when it allided with the bridge. Both barges sustained damage. Bridge sustained major damage to the RDB fendering system. PTP and CG-835 issued on the barges. Initial estimates appear to be a SMI.

M/V ALGONORTH allided with Norfolk & Southern Railroad Bridge while transiting outbound on the Maumee River, Toledo, OH with two assist tugs.  Stern of vessel struck southwest protection cell, glanced off it, then struck the north west wooden protection abutment.  No structural damage to bridge or vessel.  Bridge sustained approximately $225K damage to protection structure and catwalk.  No injuries.  Drug & alcohol testing conducted.  

M/V ALGONORTH wheelsman tested, but is a Canadian citizen.  CGIS investigating.

Masters of assist tugs IDAHO & NEBRASKA did not have Merchant Mariner Licenses onobard.  Referred to enforcement & issued Letters of Warning.

M/V DAVID K. WILSON reported making a controlled allision with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Bridge at mile 190.4 on the Cumberland River while transiting down bound with 6 empty coal barges.  The second coal barge on the starboard side made slight contact with the RDB bridge abutment.  No damage to the vessel or the bridge.

Bridge inspector from CSX inspected bridge and cleared it to resume normal operations.

On 21 December, 2007 at approximately 0554 the Tug EDNA allided with the Beverly Railroad bridge. While on out bound transit barge made contact with wedge supports, steel on steel contact made with no injuries or release of fuel or oil release reported.

HUGH C. BLASKE WHILE S/B IVO 941 OHR, STRUCK THE R/D PIER OF THE I-24 BRIDGE.  TOW BROKE CONFIGURATION WITH THE TTBL 4031 SINKING BELOW THE BRIDGE.  THE ACBL 1455 IS PUSHED IN ON THE LDB.   VSLS EVA WALKER & SUE KOSSOW ASSISTED IN ROUNDING UP BARGES BROKEN OUT OF TOW.

The Galveston Causeway RR bridge tender reported an unknown breakaway barge had allided with the bridge, and has become hung up on the bridge. No cargo on board. Minor damage to the cement truss on the bridge.

The M/V David L. Griggs was transiting S/B on the Illinois River pushing 15 loaded corn barges when the SCF 24107 allided with the Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge in Pekin, Illinois at approximately MM 151.0. No damage was sustained to the bridge, tow, or vessel. Three tow wires were broken.

Vessel was traveling from Bolivar to Pt. Comfort when the master over-compensated for the fair tide causing the vessel to strike the north timbers and the barge to strike the south timbers.  No damage to vessel or barge.  Master was able to straighten out tow and proceed to destination.

Station Pensacola received a report from the Escambia County Sheriff, who received a report from a train engineer who was traveling across the Escambia Bay CSX Railroad Bridge and saw a barge on fire in the vicinity of the I-10 Bridge.  Station Pensacola launched UTB 41486 to investigate.  Escambia County Sheriff dispatched a helo to investigate.  The helo verified that there was a barge with a small fire onboard beneath the I-10 Bridge.  Gulf Breeze Fire Department was notified and dispatched resources on the I-10 Bridge but was unable to assist from their location.  A tug was deployed by the company and successfully extinguished the fire using a 2 inch water hose.  The cause of the fire was smoldering timbers on the deck of the barge.
WHILE N/B, THE JAMES H HUNTER SCRAPED THE R/D PIER OF THE HENRY R LAWRENCE MEMORIAL BRIDGE IVO MM 63 CMR.   NO DAMAGE TO BARGE OR BRIDGE.

Barge MEM 1002, while being pushed north bound by the M/V CODY BOYD, allided with the Jefferson Street Bridge at MM 288 on the Illinois River.

No damage to barge or bridge.

On 30 December 2007 at 0030, while traveling northbound through the Bayou Sorrel Bridge, the UTV RAY ECKSTEIN allided with the Bayou Sorrel Bridge fender system and 2 private docks.  There were no injuries, pollution.

M/V Cooperative Ambassador was transiting S/B on the Illinois River pushing a 12 barge tow, at approximately MM 151.0 when the F/B TCB 282 allided with the lower Pekin RR Bridge. No damage sustained to tow, bridge, or vessel.

On January 10, 2007, at approximately 1800, the double-hulled barge CASCADES allided with the fendering system of the eastern tower of the west span of the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge in San Francisco Bay.  There was significant damage to the fendering system and to the forward rake of the barge.  The barge was being towed astern by the towing vessel PACIFIC WOLF with the assist of the towing vessel DELTA DEANNA in the stern.  The towing vessels did not sustain any damage.  The vessels departed from the Rodeo Conoco Phillips refinery in Richmond, California outbound to sea.  There was no pollution or injuries.

The Tower 35 (San Rafeal Bridge) fendering system sustained damage to the wooden pilings and framing, approximately a 10' wide section.  Cost of bridge repairs are estimated at $2,000,000.  The Barge CASCADES sustained damage to the bow rake and main deck above the bow rake.  The bow rake sustained an inset approximately 6'-7' in length by 2'-3' in width by 5' in depth, with a vertical crack approximately 4' in length , ranging from 6" wide at the top all the way to 1" at the bottom, running thru the inset.  The main deck above the bow rake is buckled with a 4' opening.  All damage was approximately 8'-10' above the waterline.  Cost of barge repairs are estimated at $300,000.

See IO Report of Investigation under the Correspondence section for details of investigation.

M/V Sarah Elizabeth was transiting N/B with a 12 barge tow when the F/B SCNO 8122 allided with the Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge causing a 12" crack in the #1 void at the 6' draft mark. No damage sustained to the vessel or bridge.

On 05JAN07, at 1100, the UTV MEGAN E. DUPRE was pushing the MANTI PRODUCTION BARGE IVO the HWY. 90 Chef Menteur Bridge. Approximately 100 ft. from the bridge the barge swung to port and hit the bridge. The bridge was tested and no damage to bridge was reported. Minor damage to MANTI Production Barge. No injuries, no pollution.

M/V Susan L. Stall allided with the Lower Pekin Railroad Drawbridge.  No damage to the towboat, bridge or barges. Master was transported after the incident with chest pains. Later reported it was not a heart attacked. Master was released to the care of his local physician.

On 16 January 2008 at approximately 0230, the Tug TRIG LIND was upbound the Petaluma River pushing the Barge SJ-144 loaded with rock/sand when it allided with the swing span fendering system of the Black Point Railroad Bridge.  The allision resulted in damage to the fendering system in way of cracked wooden timbers and cross members.  No damage was reported to the barge or tug.  No pollution or injuries were reported.  The damage was described as being 10 feet above the water and 15 feet wide.  The bridge Repair Estimate is $10,000.

Recommend Enforcement Action (EA) aginst the Operator for negligence.

M/V Jacob Michael Eckstein allided with Lower Pekin RR bridge.  That allision caused the front end of the tow to swing toward the LDB and allide with a moored barge. The moored barge broke loose for a short period of time before being secured.  M/V Jacob Michael Eckstein reported no damage to his tow but a dent in the moored barge.

UTV CSS ATLANTA reported via cell phone that he had allided with the NE fender of the West Port Arthur Bridge, NO Injuries, NO pollution and NO major damage.  Captain was unable to determine extent of fender damage as the fender had previous damage from another allision from another vessel.

Vessel was pushing 4 barges Westbound on the ICW. CSS ATLANTA was waiting for traffic to clear at the West Port Arthur Bridge, when the outbound current set her to the south side of the channel towards the work barges tied up on the South side of the channel. The pilot started to steer towards the North and the current caught the stern. With the current on the stern it was forcing the vessel's head to the North side. According to the pilot all he could do was flank with the current rather than fight it. The Port lead barge (MG  200) allided with the bridge. 

The only damage noted was on the MG 200 barge and it was a small inset in the center of the head log. The  inset to the barge will NOT be replaced.  Surveyors investigated and concluded that the Damage to the West Port Arthur Bridge was due to a previous Allision.  There was no cost to repair West Port Arthur Bridge.

The M/V Sarah Elizabeth was D/B and allided with the Lower Pekin R/R bridge upper protection cell at MM 151.2, ILR. The M/V was  pushing 1 loaded EAL red flag, 5 empty red flags, and 6 loaded dry cargo barges at the time of incident. Barge ACBL-6021 was fractured in the port #4 void.  The master has contacted the bridge tender who confirmed that there was no damage to the protection cell.

VTS RECEIVED A CALL FROM M/V GINGER GRIFFIN CONCERNING A BRIDGE ALLISION IN THE LAKE CHARLES AREA. CALLER STATED THAT THE M/V DELTA OWL WAS TOWING THE  DRILLING RIG BASIC 14 WHICH STRUCK THE ELLENDER BRIDGE (SR-27). VTS ALSO RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE RESPONSIBLE COMPANY'S REPRESENTATIVE CONFIRMING ALLISION. COMPANY REP STATES THAT THERE WERE NO INJURIES, POLLUTION, OR DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE.  dOT RESPONDED AND CONFIRMED NO DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE.

M/V Bryan O'Daniels was transiting S/B on the ILR with a 2 barge tow at approximately MM 151.0 when the T/B FMT 3044 allided with the Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the tow, vessel, or bridge.

HARRY R JACOBSON WHILE D/B, IVO 941 OHR,  ING 1954 IN TOW,  ALLIDED WITH RIGHT DESCENDING PIER OF THE KENTUCKY SPAN  OF THE I-24 BRIDGE, CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE BARGES ING-1913, ING-4653b, AND ING-1654 (SEE DAMAGE REPORT FOR DETAILS).

The M/V MAGGIE B. YAGGER while conducting tow operations and de-drifting of crane barge IVO OHR MM 756.3 was involved in a marine casualty involving an allision with the HWY 231 Glover H. Cary Bridge.  The vessel's master was backing down to remove drift caught up on the head of the crane barge.  In the process of backing down the vessel came in close proximity to the bridge and allided with the bridge.  No pollution or injuries were reported.

24 January 2008 @ approximately 2303L - The bulk freight vessel M/V SWAN allided with the Noroflk Southern Railroad Bridge No. 7, adjacent to the Gilmerton Bridge on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River.  The ship was under the control of a docking master with the master of the vessel, chief officer, VA state pilot, and helmsmen on the bridge.  All members of the bridge team were alcohol tested with negative results.  Drug testing was ordered for all individuals directly involved but was only completed by the docking master and the tug operators.  All parties testedfor alcohol and drugs.  The ship sustained an inset and damage to the port sideshell between frames 192-194, approximately 21 feet above the waterline and four to five feet below the weather deck. The rail bridge suffered significant damage to a steel bulkhead surrounding the tracks and misalignment of the number two (north) track.

While being pushed south bound at MM 317 on the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal by M/V EILEEN C, the smoke stack of barge CBC 122 allided with the underside of the Cicero Avenue Bridge.

Barge CBC 122 lost its smoke stack in the allision.  No damage to bridge.
The M/V DONNA YORK (#563108) was transiting the Monongahela River upbound pushing 15 empty hopper barges when they allided with the Railroad Bridge at mile 14.4.
AN EMPTY HOPPER BARGE BROKE AWAY FROM JAMES MARINE SERVICES, MI 4.3 TNR. IT BLEW UPRIVER AND STRUCK THE US 60 BRIDGE MI 5.3 TNR ON THE RIGHT DESCENDING PIER.

On 30JAN08, MSD Panama City received notification that the M/V HARVEY SBISA had allided with the Middle Bay Bridge in Choctawhatchee Bay.  The towing vessel was pushing a 297 ft barge containing approximately 50,000 bbls of JP8 jet fuel.  Due to rough seas and strong winds (30-45kt winds), the vessel was pushed to the south as the vessel was setting up to go through the bridge.  To compensate, the pilot of the vessel came full ahead on both main engines to correct the set and line up on the bridge.  It was at that time that both main engines unexpectedly shut down, port first, followed by the starboard.  As crewmembers immediately headed to the engine room to restart the engines, the tow drifted into the southwest bridge fender, damaging 50 ft of the cribbing.  The vessel hit on the starboard side of the barges in tow, damaging wires on the coupling and the wooden fender system.  There were no injuries and no pollution.
Master of the Tug Vessel CENTURION (US) IMO 7647560 was found in his stateroom unresponsive. Local EMS dispatched on scene and called into Sector San Juan to confirm death.

On 29JAN08 the M/V YOCONA tied up to uninspected barge DB14 and PTT7215, broke away from it's moorings and spuds due to high sustained winds with strong gusts. After breaking away, the unpiloted vessel and tow were blown up river into the Norfolk and Southern Decatur Drawbridge at mile 304 on the Tennessee River.
ELLY LANE ALLIDED WITH THE EGGNERS FERRY HWY BRIDGE MI 41.7 TNR ON THE LEFT PIER.
