The SUNCRUZ VII allided with the fendering system of the John' s Pass Bridge resulting in only several paint scrapes along the rub rail of the port quarter of the vessel.  The allision also led to the severing of an electrical cable providing power to three (3) bridge navigation lights on the port fendering system of the John's Pass Bridge.  Following the allision, the Commerical fishing vessel, DOLPHIN 1, while transiting outbound collided with the outbound SUNCRUZ VII approximately 3 miles offshore from John's Pass Bridge.  The collision resulted in multiple fractures in the fiberglass stem of the DOLPHIN 1, as well as a small set in the port side, amidships of the SUNCRUZ VII.  No injuries, flooding, pollution, or significant property damage was caused by the casualties.

It was determined that the operator of the DOLPHIN 1 was not at the helm of the vessel at the time of the collision with the SUN CRUZ VII.

UTV SARAH HUNTER reported striking the Cincinnati Southern R.R. Bridge MM 472.5 on the Ohio River.  The vessel was pushing 12 loaded coal barges (3 wide 4 long) down bound. The starboard string, third barge back (C-417) made contact with the bridge amidships. That barge along with the starboard string, fourth barge back (C-145) were damaged.  C-417 was taking on water in the #1 and #2 void.  The C-145 was taking on water in the port stern compartment.  The C-145 was placed in the tow with the stern forward. The C-102 broke free and was set adrift upon tow allieded with bridge, barge may have possibly went aground prior to retrieval.
AT 19:15 WHILE S/B IVO OHR 978, JOE BOBZIEN ADVD THAT THE CGB 252 AND THE ACBL 1410 BRUSHED UP AGAINST THE L/D PIER OF THE CHANNEL SPAN ON THE IL CENTRAL R/R BRIDGE.  NO DAMAGE TO TOW OR BRIDGE.

The KIRBY 30006, pushed by the UTV AJAX, was headed westbound through the Galveston Causeway Railroad Bridge when strong winds pushed the barge into the bridge's north dolphin. The barge did not sustain any damage. One chain and some concrete on the dolphin was broken. No pollution, no injuries.

UTV PATRICIA experienced a loss of propulsion while pushing two sand barges through the Galveston Causeway Bridge. One of the barges, BROWN 920, scraped the side of a work barge near the bridge. The UTV was able to get her engine back on line. No damage to the barge, no pollution.

On 14Feb08 @ approximately 1145L, the UTV ROBERT BURTON was towing the barge JMC-85 astern in Chincoteague Inlet, Virginia.  While shifting tow configurations, wave action caused the bow line and towing hawser to part and the tug to bounce off the bottom.  The exact sequence of events is not known; however, the net result was that the port rudder was mssing and the starboard propeller became fouled with the parted towline.  The tug placed a towline on the barge and anchored to wait for assistance. Two assist tugs towed the barge into port and returned to safely escort the tug into Chincoteague. 

Note:  As per the Safety Manager  Norfolk Tug Company intends to search for the broken rudder and will retrieve it if found.  Waterways Management Branch was briefed on the situation.

On February 18, 2008 at 1611 the M/V WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE lost propulsion while inbound to Oakland Berth #25.  The vessel was located in the San Francisco Bay between Alcatraz Island and the Aquatic Park.  Several attempts were made to start the Main Diesel Engione (MDE) but all failed.  The Pilot decided to position the vessel with the use of the bow thruster and by dropping the anchor near the edge of the shipping channel.

At 1735, the vessel was able to re-start MDE with Emergency Engine Controls.  The vessel lifted its anchor and safely proceeded to Anchorage #9 with 2 assist tugs.  The vessel was safely anchored in Anchorage #9 at 1845.

A Sector San Francisco Captain of the Port (COTP) Order issued to the vessel limiting its movement until the problem is corrected and will remain in effect until the NKK Class Surveyor attests to satisfactory repairs.

On February 15, 2008, at 0917, the  NKK Class Surveyor confirmed satisfactory repairs had been completed and all tests were complete.  The COTP order lifted.

THE MSU HARPAT WITNESSED A SOFT GROUNDING FOLLOWED BY AN COLLISION BETWEEN THE M/V CITY OF GREENWOOD AND A WORK BARGE IN THE AREA OF WEST PORT ARTHUR BRIDGE.

M/V CITY OF GREENWOOD WAS TRANSITING WESTBOUND TOWARDS THE WEST PORT ARTHUR BRIDGE PUSHING 1 LOADED (KIRBY 24020) AND 2 EMPTY BARGES (KIRBY 30040B AND KIRBY 24020) STRUNG OUT.  ACCORDING TO THE PILOT OF THE VESSEL, HE ATTEMPTED TO MANEUVER UNDER THE BRIDGE, BUT WAS BEING PUSHED BY THE WIND TOWARD THE BANK.  HE BEGAN BACKING DOWN THE VSL.  THE WIND BEGAN TO SET THE TUG AND BARGES TOWARDS THE FORWARD "G" RANGE LIGHT. THE KIRBY 30040B BARGE MADE CONTACT ALONG THE BASE OF THE FORWARD "G" LIGHT. THE CITY OF GREENWOOD CORRECTED THEIR POSITION AGAIN AND MANAGED TO STRAIGHTEN HERSELF OUT IN THE TEXACO ISLAND CHANNEL AND ATTEMPTED TO NAVIAGATE UNDER THE BRIDGE. 

WHILE TRANSITING UNDER THE BRIDGE, THE M/V CITY OF GREENWOOD ALLIDED WITH ONE OF THE VERTICAL STABLIZATION SPUDS ON A CONSTRUCTION BARGE WORKING UNDER THE BRIDGE. AFTER PASSING UNDER THE BRIDGE THE VESSEL PUSHED UP ALONG THE NORTH BANK AT THE WEST PORT ARTHUR MOORINGS. NO INJURIES OR POLLUTION.

MASTER OF THE M/V CAPT. BILL STEWART (575823) ADVD THAT WHILE HEADING D/B WITH 15 LOADED COAL BARGES IN TOW, THE FOURTH BARGE ON THE STARBOARD STRING (AEP 248) ALLIDED WITH THE CHESSIE BALTIMORE & OHIO R/R BRIDGE IVO MILE 184.3 OHR AT APPROX 0545 EST.   BARGE AEP 248's HULL WAS BREACH IVO STARBOARD BOW RAKE JUST BELOW THE WATERLINE, CAUSING THE BOW VOID TO FLOOD.  FLOODING WAS CONTROLLED USING THREE PORTABLE PUMPS.  TOW/TOWBOAT CONTINUED ITS TRANSIT.

The M/V Donna Rushing was transiting S/B on the ILR pushing a 15 barge tow(no red flags) at approximately MM 151.3, when the F/B MEM 1852 allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge in Pekin, lIllinois. No damage was sustained to the vessel, tow, or bridge.  Helper boat was used.

At 0320 the UTV NORWEGIAN SEA with Barge DBL 103 struck the Raritan River Railroad Bridge while inbound in the northern channel.  Barge DBL 103 is double-hulled and carrying 98,000 barrels of No. 2 Fuel oil (Fully loaded). The barge sustained minimal damages, which was concentrated on the point of impact- on the port bow, forepeak section. Soundings were taken with no change in cargo volume. The tug and barge moored at Hess Terminal and was boomed off for precautionary measures. No pollution or damages to the tug were found. No structural damages were noted on the swing bridge itself. Rail traffic was not hindered. Structural damage was noted on the catwalk. Several supporting beams were broken and the navigation light was extinguished. Sector NY Inspector completed satisfactory steering tests, noting no adverse conditions.

On 29 February 2008  the M/V INDRA was passing through the Norfolk Southern Rail Road Bridge #7 with the assistance of two tugs.  The UTV STEVEN McALLISTER had a line up to the ship with a backup line attached to the primary line.  Both lines had an eye in each end, and the two eyes in the middle were spliced together.  A heaving line was made up to the eye of the backup line.  This configuration was used to allow for quick replacement of the primary line in the event of a line failure.  At about 1540L the primary line parted.  The ship's crew immediately pulled up the backup line and mistakenly attached the bitter end of the primary line to the ship.   When the tug took a starin on the backup line the eye splice of the primary line, which was attached to the ship, simply pulled out. The crew should have attached the eye of the backup line to the ship.  The ship's crew passed a mooring line to the tug, but before the tug could take a strain on this line the port quarter of the INDRA allided with the fender system of the bridge.  McAllister Towing has switched to a line with twice the breaking strength.

TUG JOHN PAUL was towing alongside (port) a crane/work barge and transiting south bound in the Thames River when the crane/work barge allided with the eastern wood fendering system of the Thames River Amtrak rail road bridge, causing minor damge to the wooden fender and no damage to the barge or tug.  The bridge fendering system remained intact.

On 4 March 2008 at approximately 1250CDT the M/V L.B. EDGIN (O/N: 601230) was downbound in the vicinity of Mile Marker (MM) 190.4 Cumberland River (CMR) with 4 empty deck barges in tow.  The starboard side of the deck barge IMC 133 in tow by the M/V L/B EDGIN allided with the right descending pier of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Drawbridge located at MM 190.4 CMR.  Neither the barge IMC 133 or the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Drawbridge suffered damage.

On February 24, 2008, the UTV PIACHI was pushing 4 empty open hopper barges inbound on the Chickasaw Creek.  As the tow was transiting the Chickasaw Creek CSX Railroad Bridge the wind pushed the barge WGN 9705 against the fendering system on the south side of the bridge crossing.  There was no damage to the bridge or barge and the tow continued on its voyage.

On Feb 27, 2008 at approximately 1520 hours the M/V Tombigbee was pushing 4 loaded and 2 empty hopper barges heading south bound at mile marker 173 in the Black Warrior Tombigbee River.  The tow was transiting the east span of the old Naheola Bridge when the current pushed the tow into the east pillar.  The barge WGN 9616 made contact with the bridge causing the tow to break apart. Eight wires were broken and replaced.  The barge WGN 9616 also had a 30 foot crease down the port side and a minor leak in the #4 tank.  The bridge was inspected with no damage noted.   At 2330 hours the tow was back together and underway heading south bound.  The WGN 9616 will be repaired at the Warrior & Gulf Chickasaw Terminal.

The NEPTUNE is a 95-foot, U.S. flagged towing vessel, owned and operated by Tug N. Two, Inc.  The KTC 50, which is now named the I-50, is a 299-foot tank barge owned and operated by K-Sea Operating Partnership LP.  On March 5, 2008 at approximately 0920L, the I-50 allided with the Norfolk Southern #5 Bridge north fender system while being towed by the NEPTUNE.  The tank barge was empty, with a wind-sail area approximately 20-feet above the water line.  The prevailing winds were from the southwest, gusting between 15 and 20 knots.  The captain posted the mate as a lookout before proceeding through the draw.  As the tug and barge proceeded through the fender system, the tow was set off its intended course by the wind, and made contact with the north fender.  There was no damage to the barge or fender system.

The RANGER is a 52-foot, U.S. flagged towing vessel, owned by Carolina Tug Company, Inc., and operated by Intracoastal Marine, Inc.  The GERARD is a 120-foot, deck barge, owned by Smith Brothers, Inc.  On March 7, 2008 at approximately 0258L, the GERARD's port spud struck the lower chord, just south of the midspan of the James River Bridge, in Newport News, Virginia while being pushed ahead by the RANGER.  There was no damage to the RANGER,  but the port spud on the barge was bent and required minor repair work.  Virginia Department of Transportation (VDOT) estimated the monetary damage to the James River Bridge at $10,000.  The crew of the RANGER was administered post casualty alcohol and drug tests.
The tow of the M/V Andrew Cannava allided with the Florence Highway Drawbridge at Illinois River mile marker 56.0. Barge VL 81429 and ACBL 1375 received damage as a result.
The tow of the M/V JAMIE LEIGH allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge at UMR mile marker 282.0. No damage to the tow vessel, barges, or bridge.

11MAR08 - Vessel was moored at LB Berth 229.  When Pilot came onboard and proceeded to move from berth, the vessel experienced a main engine failure and ultimate loss of propulsion.  During interviews, the Captain stated that he was unable to restart the main engine and had no remote control at the bridge and no remote control in the engine control room.  The vessel crew had installed a jumper wire to bypass a potentially faulty solenoid, which allows remote operation of the engine.  The temporary repair was tested with Class society and Semar representatives were present.  The main engine was never started during the test.  The ships electrician sent an email to the company asking if the jumper wire needed to be permanent, or should it be removed.  After he did not receive a response, he decided to remove the jumper wire by cutting it.

The vessel tested main engine prior to getting underway at local control with no problems.  Remote locations were never tested.  Once all the lines were off the vessel, control was shifted to the bridge with negative results.  Control was immediately shifted to engine room controls, where the engine nearly immediately went down.  

When the main engine failed to properly operate, the Captain told the Pilot that he wanted to simply push back to the pier, to diagnose the problem.  However, the Pilot stated that he thought it would be better to deadship tow the vessel to anchor, since they had already pushed away from the pier and had escort tugs in place.  

Class Society examined the vessel and determined that the cause of the control problem was determined to be two micro switches which are actuated by the remote control level at the local control station on the engine.  The micro switches were found to have bad contacts.  The effect was the inhibit the remote control transfer function.  After removing the switches and reconditioning them, the proper operation of the remote control was restored and tested satisfactorily.

On March 10, 2008, the UTV RACHELLE MARIE was pushing eight empty open hopper barges and making the approach to the Back Bay Biloxi CSX Railroad Bridge.  The wind started gusting at over 20 mph broadside on the port side of the tow.  Once the master saw that he was safely inside the protection of fendering system of the bridge, he stopped the tow and made a controlled landing on the starboard side on the fixed fender system.  The UTV RACHELLE MARIE and tow then safely maneuvered through the bridge without further incident.  There was very minor damage (two broken top boards) to the fendering system and no damage to the barge.

On 15Mar08, at approximately 0615, the UTV EDNA T. GATTLE was pushing ahead four loaded hopper barges when the tow allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge.  The incident occurred at MM 28.5 on the Atchafalaya River.  There was no injuries, pollution, or further marine casualty as a result of the incident.
JERRY TINKEY, AT 1015 ALLIDED WITH THE IC R/R/ BRIDGE IVO OHR 977.7

The UTV CAPT GEORGEwas transiting west bound with 3 sand barges (DB 3600/3601/3602) & was pushed by the wind. The DB 3601 allided with the north fendering dolphin causing a coupling wire to break on the port side of the tow. The vessel backed-down to maintain tow & struck the south wall. No damage, pollution, or injuries.

At approximately 0415 hours on 16 March 2008 while proceeding southbound with a tow of 12 loaded and 11 empty barges, the M/V Dale Cathorall and its tow allided with the left descending pier of the 155 Highway Bridge at or near Mite 835 on the Lower Mississippi River. Barge KIRBY-10426 suffered heavy bow rake damage. KIRBY-5600 starboard bow bilge knuckle set in 0-6' for 8' x 5' area. The M/V Dale Cathorall suffered significant damage to the port second deck bulwark handrails and first deck handrails.  Drug/alcohol testing was performed in conjunction with this incident.

The Small Passenger Vessel Horizon's Edge scraped the south side fendering system of the John's Pass Bridge causing damage to the forward gangway mount.  No damage to the bridge was confirmed by the bridge tender.  Vessel returned to the pier to await Coast Guard inspector to arrive.  The gangway mounts were removed from the vessel because they were no longer being used.
The M/V Charlie Newton lost all power and allided with Eads Bridge at mile 180 UMR..

Vessel allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge in St Joseph, MI.  Due to a possible SMI, drug test was directed.  Conducted interviews with crew and bridge workers that were on scene at the time of the incident.  The initial damage estimate verbally passed via railroad employees was $250,000.  This report should have stated $2,500.  This is not the final damage assessment, but the monetary damage to the bridge is less than the threshold of $100,000 which does not meet the criteria for an SMI.  Damage to the vessel was cosmetic, alcohol testing was completed.  Chemical testing is deemed not needed as this was not an SMI.

The company that owns the bridge refuses to pass on any information that may add to the investigation.  As a result there is no final damage estimate to the bridge, so the incident will be treated as if the bridge had received no damage.

The M/V BILL CARNEAL was pushing a 8 loaded grain and 1 empty freight barge southbound ivo MM 282.1 UMR when the tow allided with the Louisiana R/R bridge protection cell.  No damage was reported to the bridge.  The port string lead barge landed on the protection cell causing a 18" x 1/2" crack in the port #4 wing tank below the water line.  The crew made temp repairs and dewatered the wing tank.

THE PILOT REPORTS LAYING UP AGAINST THE BRIDGE DUE TO WIND CONDITIONS. HE ADVD THAT HE WAS ALMOST STOPPED WHEN HE REALIZED THAT HE WASN'T GOING TO MAKE IT THROUGH, AND LAID UP AGAINST IT AS GENTLY AS HE COULD ON THE RIGHT DESCENDING PIER. HE HAS 6 EMPTY HOPPERS IN TOW D/B ENROUTE TO MI 184 CMB.

M/V DAVID K. WILSON reported making a controlled allision with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Bridge at mile 190.4 on the Cumberland River while transiting down bound with 6 empty coal barges. The M/V George King's tow allided with the left descending center span pier of the Veteran's Bridge (MLK) at MM 179.0, UMR. The M/V was down bound pushing 12 loaded grain barges enroute Cairo, IL.  Damage occurred to barge MEM 1518, no damage reported to the MLK bridge.  Crew dewatered barge and conducted temp repairs.

SECLMR CC received report from Vicksburg 911 (601-631-8800) confirmed report of bridge allision I-20 bridge MM 435.8 LMR in Vicksburg, MS.  Report is that there are barges adrift and at least one barge appears to be sinking.  Tow Vsl name not known at this time.  No further details available.

26MAR08:  The M/V KEITH DARLING is S/B on the LMR w/ 30 loaded F/B's.  The Steersman misjudges his approach to the Vicksburg R/R Bridge at M/M 435.8, and strikes it w/ the F/B MEM 5002, resulting in the sinking of that barge, damage to the #2S wing void of the MEM 2090, and the break-away of 8 other barges.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to have played a role in this incdent.

Coast Guard crew witnessed the Commercial Fishing Vessel (CFV) Michelle Marie allide with the John's Pass Bridge fendering system. The subject vessel was outbound at approximately 2030 when it approached the span to cruise under the John's Pass Bridge.  The Captain advised that he was just about to increase the speed of the vessel to transit through the span when the current caught the vessel and pushed it into the fendering the system (outbound transit, south side of fendering system, 3 feet in under bridge).  No damage visible on the bridge's fendering system. Moderate damage occurred to the subject vessel's port side railing.

The  M/V JEFFREY A. RAIKE was transiting southbound  on the OHR with 15 loaded coal barges.  The steersman was maneuvering the vessel to stbd to clear the bridge. The swing to stbd was not fast enough and resulted in vessel being set to port. The master stated that the steersman was shifting engines to get more swing to stbd but kept backing on engines, the master thought they were going to clear the bridge pier by 20 feet, bent over to tie shoes looked up and the vessel was setting down on the pier.  The steersman turned to port to avoid the pier but they allided with the port stern barge on the left descending pier of the  HI Carpenter Memorial bridge at mile 155.4 OHR at approx 2150 EST. The port stern barge was taking on water in the #1 & #2 wing void and flooding was controlled by pumps. Some wires and couplings were broken and the first twelve barges came partially loose from tow.  The M/V Charlie Neal assisted with keeping tow together. Their final destination was  Chester, OH at mile 258 OHR

On March 23, 2008, during the vessels outbound transit from CITGO  Linden, NJ, the M/T DA QING 452'S mast struck the Arthur Kill Railroad Bridge . The pilot reported that the strike damaged what he believed was a television antenna on the mast.

30MAR08:  UTV TALLAPOOSA allided with Mopac RR Bridge fendering system w/ 2 red flags in tow, rptd damage to lead barge AT1900 in rake and #1 Wing Void.

No further damage, pollution, orinjuries reported.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to have played a role in this incident.

M/V David L. Griggs,  barge SCF 26032 (lead barge on stbd string) allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge protection cell.  M/V is carrying 15 loaded barges of grain. The bridge tender for the Mopac Bridge (MM 90, Red River) stating that the UTV RENEE T. WHATLEY struck the side of the bridge on the Southwest pier. The UTV Superstone is on scene as an assist vessel.

Final destination is Shreveport, LA.

On March 5, 2008 at about 2030, the M/V  GATE CITY was downbound on the Ohio River MM 265 with 17 empty coal barges in tow.   As the vessel made its approach to the center span of the New York Central RR bridge, the Master maneuvered to avoid alliding with the Custom Fuel dock, high winds were setting the tow toward the dock. As the head of the tow cleared the bridge span, the Master, realized his tow was out of alignment with the bridge piers. He backed down engines to slow headway and minimize impact with the bridge as the barge CTC 9689 allided with the left pier. Wires parted at time of allision and 07 barges were set adrift and were then recovered by the  M/V NELL. There was a soft inset to the CTC 9689 and  no damage observed on the other 7 barges.

M/V Thruston B. Morton allided with Lower Pekin R/R Bridge protection cell. Pilot reported no damage to bridge or vessel/cargo.  Vessel was pushing 15 BARGES (9 LOADED DRY CARGO, 6 EMPTY RED FLAGS).
Barge ACBL 3152 allided with the bridge and had a crack from the knuckle up 8-10" X 1/2-1" in the #3 void.
Crack was shingled and a void was pumped out with a pump on standby.

Vessel was transiting under the Commodore Heim Bridge in LA/LB when the Captain forgot to lower the mast on top of the wheelhouse.  When the vessel went under the bridge, the mast contacted the bridge, and the shaft snapped off and fell back onto the deck, landing on top of a deck mounted light mast pole.  No personal injuries were noted, and no visible damage to the bridge was noted.  California Transportation Authority  (CALTRANS) examined the bridge and found no damage to the bridge.

The UTV SKIP JACK was northbound in the Tombigbee River pushing two loaded red flag barges configured two long.  As the tow passed under the Naheola Bridge, and attempted to make a right hand turn in the river, the aft port quarter of the stern barge made contact with a bridge piling.  The bridge was inspected by state inspectors and found to have sustained no damage as a result of this incident. 

The aft barge was being pushed stern first, with the bow tied to the SKIP JACK, and the stern tied to the aft end of the lead barge. As per the tow configuration, the impact against the bridge was against the port stern, when in fact, structurally, the impact affected the starboard bow of the aft barge.

The barge sustained a vertical dent in the starboard side hull approximately thirty feet back from the bow, and extending from the deck of the barge to just below the waterline. The dent was approximately 12 inches wide by 6 inches deep. At the top of the dent, at the deck, was an approximate one inch split on the deck, creating a small opening into the starboard forward wing tank. 

The tow continued on its voyage to Tuscaloosa, where the barge was offloaded. Following the offload, the barge proceeded to New Orleans for repairs.

LT. reports that the UTV Robert E. Frane hit the Vicksburg, MS railroad bridge and there is approximately 4-5 barges adrift. LT. wants COMMCEN to close the river from MM 440-430 LMR until further notice.

2 barges and the vessel have been damaged in the allision; damage is also evident to the Baxter Wilson power plant dock below the Vicksburg RR bridge. No other damage, pollution or injuries were reported.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to be a factor in this event.

No further damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

0415 - 05APR08: M/V AMY FRANCIS (MAGNOLIA MARINE) Allided with the Fort Loudon Railroad Bridge at MM 531.3 TNR.  No injuries and only minor scrapings to the T/B MM63.  No damage to the bridge reported.  Barge has no structural damage, simply cosmetic, no repairs needed.

The M/V Erna E. Honeycutt was transiting S/B at approximately MM 151.0 ILR pushing 12 loaded barges(no red flags) when the F/B ING 5778 allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the vessel, barge, or bridge. An assist boat was used.

The UTV Tom Behringer was transiting S/B pushing a 14 barge tow when the F/B JCS 4B allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge. The UTV Edmund L was used as an assist boat while to transited the bridge. No damage to the vessel, tow, or bridge.

UTV CINDY CELESTE allided with Vicksburg RR Bridge w/19 barges in tow, 8 barges went A/D, no damage and no injuries reported.

The M/V W T Toutant was transiting S/B at approximately MM 151.0 ILR, when the F/B ACBL 3086 allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the vessel, barge, or bridge.

The barge POTOMAC, being pushed by the Tug FORT PIKE, ran aground in the Occoquan River at position 38-39.508N 077-14.021W. The tug was able to free the POTOMAC without assistance but could not continue their transit due to low water conditions; therefore, the tug Master intentionally re-grounded the vessel to wait for a higher tide at 0525. No pollution or injuries from this casualty.

The vessel laid flat against the stbd down bound peir, knocking out the stbd keel cooler on the vsl.  There were no injuries and the vsl is not taking on water.  Prevention duty team responded.
