Small Passenger Vessel Horizon's Edge was traveling outbound through the John's Pass Bridge when the fast current pushed the vessel into the southern part of the bridge's fendering system.  No damage was sustained to the bridge and only minor damage to the vessel.  The vessel sustained some paint scrapings and small dents on several cleats.

On March 28, 2008 at approximately 2230 the UTV BUTCH was pushing three empty open hopper barges , configured two long with one deck barge along side.  The UTV BUTCH approached the CXS R/R Bridge on Three Mile Creek when the deck barge made contact with the fender work near the bridge.  There was no damage to the deck barge and one timber that was on the end of the fender work was broken from the impact. The UTV BUTCH was able to continue its voyage with no other incident.  The master stated he notified the bridge tender and the bridge tender reported that there was no significant damage, so small that repairs would not even be made.

On 9 April @ 2325L, the UTV JANE BLESSEY reported their empty tank barge (WEB 309) allided with the Eads Bridge at Mile 180.0 on the Upper Mississippi River. The captain reported no damage to the bridge. There was minor damage to the tank barge. The M/V JANE BLESSEY was pushing two empty tank barges, last cargo was Raffinate. The damage occurred to the tank barges stbd side shell at the deck knuckle. The damage was above the waterline.

11APR08- Received report of an bridge allision involving a red-flag barge and the Sunshine Bridge at the MM 167.5 LMR. The UTV RICKY J LEBOEUF w/ 2 flag tank barges in tow (KIRBY 30743/KIRBY 28742) loaded with #6 oil got underway from MOTIVIA at MM 168.1. The vessel and tow floated astern downriver and attempted to top around as the tow was under the bridge. The current pushed the port bow of the KIRBY 30743 into the center span fendering system. The operator was able to regained control of the tow and safely moored north of the bridge on the LDB. Center Fender suffered damaged above the water line. Due to river condition LA DOT was unable to obtain a full assessment of the fender. The fender system remains in place. Barge was survey on scene and was noted to have no damage due to this incident. See activity # 3182388.  No pollution, injuries, hazard to navigation.

On 11 April, 2008, the UTV R. CLAYTON MCWHORTER allided with the Louisiana Railroad Swing bridge at Upper Mississippi River mile marker 282. The freight barge OR 6319 sustained damage to the #3 port wing tank as a result of the incident.

Master of tow vessel reports tow allided/collided with HWY 41 Bridge on the Ohio River at MM 786.8.  Tow consists of 15 loaded dry cargo barges and broke apart on impact, setting 10 barges adrift.  Assist vessels in the area collecting the barges.  Five barges reported damaged.  Bridge inspector(s) report no damage to bridge.  No injuries or pollution were reported.

While moored at Container Berth # 8, the  M/V NINGBO parted it's moorings and struck the stern of the M/V VECCHIO BRIDGE.  Both vessel suffered damage however damage was minor and was well above the water line.

MSD Fort Smith received a report of barges adrift that allided with the Highway 62 bridge in Muskogee County, at River Mile 393, on the Arkansas River.  Vehicle traffic was stopped on Hwy 62 until the DOT could assess the damage.  The initial report was of 9 total barges loose, three of which had already been caught by the assisting tug, and 6 barges still adrift.  The barges were empty hopper barges from the Johnston's Muskogee Barge Fleeting Area.  One tug was on scene and another tug was to be underway soon to assist.

MSD Fort Smith investigators arrived on scene and learned that 10 barges had broken free, all were recovered and moored at the dock of Johnston's Terminal.  There was no evidence of damage to the barges but a full assessment could not be conducted until daylight.  The bridge was surveyed by the DOT, deemed safe to transit and was reopened to vehicle traffic in both directions.  A full survey of the bridge would be conducted the following morning.

The surveys found no damage to either the barges or the bridge.

Received call from the UTV JANE G HUFFMAN reporting an allision with the Burlington R/R D/B at MM 403.1 UMR. The UTV was upbound enroute St. Paul, MN pushing 15 dry cargo barges loaded with pig iron and coal when it brushed the RDB protection cell. No damage to the tow or the bridge reported.

Received call from the M/V Queen City reporting an allision with the Burlington R/R D/B at MM 403.1, UMR. The M/V was downbound enroute St. Louis pushing 1 loaded soybean and 2 loaded corn barges at the time of incident. The tow struck the LD protection cell causing unspecified damage to all three barges.

The starboard lead barge of the M/V NELSON LEWIS's tow allided with the Point Pleasant Henderson Highway Bridge at mile marker 0.7 of the Kanawha River while attempting to maneuver upriver through the bridge span.  Vessel had three empty barges in tow. No damage to bridge, barge, or tow vessel. No injuries.

On 18 April 2008 the M/V Jennie K., pushing 5 empty grain barges, allided w/ Dubuque RR D/B, MM 579.9 UMR.  No damage to tow or bridge reported.  MSD QC IO confirmed no damage from bridge.  No wires broken or marks noted on vessel.

M/V Jennie K reported alliding with Sabula RR Bridge.  They reported 1 barge was adrift. There was damage to the barges but was unknown initially.  Helper tow Karen Renee is on scene assisting.
MSD QC IO responded to scene.  Confirmed Barge BUNGE 413 aground 1 mi south of bridge.  BUNGE 24001 stuck underneath bridge, damage to bow rake, flooded in bow only.  BUNGE 146 had small leak in #2 port compartment. AD754 had pulled fitting.  Bridge operator noted minor damage to turn table protection cell; trains still operating and crossing, vessel traffic still transiting with no issues.  MSD QC IO ordered JENNIE K to fleet remaining barges in order to maintain availability for tow to recover two loose barges.  UTV KAREN RENEE on scene to assist.

On 20 April 2008 the M/V Bill Berry reports alliding with the protection cell on the Sabula Railroad Bridge.  The vessel tore off the 4 to 5 feet of steel banding that was previously protruding from the right descending span from an earlier allision.  There is no damage reported the barges.  ING 4746 (Loaded corn) made contact with the protection cell.  Barge configuration was 3x3 with 8 loaded corn and 1 empty.  Vessel is downbound to St. Louis, MO.

On April 16, 2008 while in route to San Juan PR from Jacksonville, FL in the Atlantic Ocean, the UTV GAUNTLET (Official # 575769) slung a fluke off of the port propeller while pulling the Barge Jax-San Juan Bridge (Offical #667879). The engine was shutdown immediately and the shaft was locked. On April 25, 2008, the vessel is currently enroute to Jacksonville, were it will be in dry docked on April 29, 2008. Sector is awaiting arrival for inspection.    

30 April 2008 attended vessel dry dock at NF Shipyard.  No damage to vessel hull or equipment Shipyard to repair and place back in service.

M/V TOM BEHRINGER reported alliding with Fort Madison Drawbridge.  They have 4 loaded salt barges and 12 empty dry cargo barges.  1 salt barge has a hole below the water line. There is approx 1 ft of water in #1 wing tank and 6 inches in #2 wing tank.

UTV with light barge allided with the new Brightman St. Bridge. ( the bridge still under construction). The vessel was south bound and was set on the bridge fendering system which was just north of the bridge by wind. The allision was considered very minor resulting in no visual marks on either the bridge or vessel. No other damage or personnel injury occurred.

Union Pacific Railroad Bridge operator reports UTV Miss Janice allided with bridge. UTV Miss Janice was pushing 6 barges loaded with gravel, barges are adrift. UTV Miss Janice is taking on water, not requiring Coast Guard assistance. 3 barges taking on water with pumps on them. No Damage to bridge.  Vessels safely moored

UTV LONNIE T pushing the empty barge LF142B allided with the south pilings at the Galveston Causeway Rail Road Bridge. The vessel was pushing two other empty barges, ACL 07614 and ACL 0609 which did not sustain any damage.  The LF142B sustained a hole on the starboard side. No pollution or injuries.

29APR08:  UTV ROBERT N STOUT is pushing 24 barges N/B when it allides with the Natchez Hwy 84 bridge at MM 363.3 LMR.  All barges set adrift.  

No further damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

Alcohol or drugs do not appear to have played a role in this incident.

On April 18, 2008 1539, the M/V  ALGORAIL (O. N. 325747) with Canadian registry, struck the Flats Industrial Railroad Bridge over the Cuyahoga River, while the vessel was transiting outbound from Osborne Concrete and Stone facility.  The outbound navigational light was severed from the light pole and was found on top of the vessel's conveyor system "A" frame.  The light received minor damage, and the rail mechanic was able to repair the light and had it working in 48 hours.  The bridge received paint scrapes along the outbound side and underneath the bridge from the mast light pole and the radar.  The vessel on the other hand received damages to its radar scanner, the base of the mast navigational light and the whip antenna base.  The tugs CALIFORNIA and ILLINOIS assisted the M/V ALGORAIL as the vessel transited from Osborne Concrete and Stone facility to Dock 20 at the Cleveland-Cuyahoga County State Port Authority facility.  The tug CALIFORNIA was made fast to the M/V ALGORAIL by bow-to-bow tow line and the tug ILLINOIS was made fast to the M/V ALGORAIL's stern by stern-to-stern tow line.  
         The M/V ALGORAIL's draft was recorded as being 16'-7" when the vessel departed the facility.  The air draft (extreme) is at 108'-00" (32.92 m) at the top of the forward mast above keel and the top of the aft mast above keel is at 109'-9" (33.45m).  The US Coast Pilot 6-Great Lakes, has the Flats Industrial Railroad Bridge vertical clearance at 97'-0". The vessel was issued a Letter of Deviation to depart the Port of Cleveland Harbor with inoperable radar en route to Sarnia, ON, for permanent repairs.

On May 1, 2009 Report Received from Burlington Iowa Police Department of 5 barges adrift from Matteson marine Fleeting area at MM 407 on the Mississippi. The barges have struck the Great River Bridge (Burlington Hwy Bridge) and are heading for the Burlington Railroad Bridge. The Police believe the barges came from just above the Highway bridge on the Illinois Side of the river. The Highway bridge has been closed to vehicle traffic until a bridge inspection is conducted. 
Barge AGS 431B landed on Burlington RR Bridge.  RR Bridge closed for RR traffic.  AGS 411B and SCNO 8144 aground at MM 405.5 on Illinois side. AGS 175 recovered and returned to fleet.  ACBL 4130 recovered and moored at ADM dock in Burlington.  USCG MSD Quad Cities personnel responded to scene.  
Alter Barge Line tug Bernard G. on scene to render assistance with AGS 431B recovery.

M/V Cooperative Venture's tow allided with the protection cell on the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge while traveling northbound to Quincy, IL.  The M/V was pushing 15 empty barges and 1 loaded fertilizer (16 total barges).   Barge AT 692B was 2nd barge back in port string and made contact with the protection cell.  No damage to the bridge or barge.

M/V JINCY WAS TRAVELING UP BOUND ON THE OHIO RIVER PUSHING 11 EMPTY HOPPER BARGES SHAPING UP FOR A STARBOARD TO STARBOARD MEETING WITH A DOWN BOUND TOW.  THE ARRANGEMENT WAS TO MEET IN THE PITTSBURGH POOL, ABOVE THE WEST END BRIDGE.  THE JINCY WAS HUGGING THE LEFT DESCENDING BANK TO SHAPE UP FOR THE MEETING, WHEN A STRONG GUST OF WIND CAME UP AND SET THE TOW DOWN ON TOP OF THE LEFT DESCENDING BANK BRIDGE PIER.  THE ALLISION TOOK PLACE AT ABOUT 1 MPH AND CAUSED NO DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE PIER OR BARGE.

On 01May2008 at 0556 the M/V MR. CAMDEN was towing a 1100 foot dredge pipe near the Grand Lake Pontoon Swing Bridge, the derdge pipe bowed and struck the southwest fender wall causing damage to the vertical and horizontal pylons.  The swing bridge was was not damaged and is still operational.  LADOT closed  the bridge marine traffic so damage assesment could be conducted but highway traffic was not affected.  It was later determined that the bridge was not hit but rather the guide wall was what was damaged.
CHRISTOPHER M. PARSONAGE ALLIDED WITH THEBES R/R/ BRIDGE MI 43 UMR AT 0030 CST. M/V WAS PUSHING 25 BARGES. TWO BARGES BROKE FREE AND ONE SUBSTAINED SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE.

M/V JINCY was traveling down bound on the Monongahela River pushing 6 hopper barges loaded with coal when they had a bridge allision with 2 bridges at mile 11.6 and 11.7.  No damage, pollution, or injuries resulted.
On May 12, 2008 the M/V James W. Buky allided with the Burlington RR bridge, MM 403.1 UMR.  No damage to the tow or bridge reported.

On May 22, 2008, the Tug FATCAT pushing the Barge # 24 with the workboat TROJAN tied along the starboard side of Barge, attempted to pass through the Three Mile Slough Bridge at 0425.  The workboat TROJAN tied on the starboard side of the Barge, made contact with the Bridge fendering system, causing damage to the catwalk along the edge of the Bridge.  The Master stated that as he attempted to maneuver the tow through the Bridge opening, a gust of wind caught his starboard quarter and pushed him into the Bridge. There was no damage to the Tug or Barge.  Damage was done to bridge fendering system along wooden catwalk on the Northwestern side of Bridge is estimated at $100k.  There was no pollution or injuries reported. There was a wind advisory in effect for the area forecasting gusts as high as 38 miles per hour were possible.

On May 5, 2008 the freight barge HONEYWELL A-5-8 allided with the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge No. 5 on the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River, VA.  The barge was being pushed by the UTV TAR BAY at a speed of 3.5 knots.  The allision caused no damage to the barge, and the fende system was inspected and found to be undamaged.  The master of the tug stated that a 10 to 15 knot gust of wind blew the bow of the barge into the fender system.  

No action was taken against the tug's captain for negligence because there was no damage.  The captain was verbally advised of the presumption of negligence and that licensed captains were expected to be prepared for weather and tides when navigating, especially in proximity to fixed objects.

On 22 May, 2008, an empty freight barge in the flotilla of the UTV KEVIN CONWAY allided with the sheer fence on the turntable of the Burlington Rail Road swing bridge. The vessel was being assisted by the UTV BETTY LYNN.  No damage occurred the flotilla or the rail road bridge.  The vessel continued its voyage without further incident.

30 May 2008, the UTV ASHLEY CHANEL was pushing the freight barge BILL JR. outbound when the port bow of the barge allided with the left descending back fender system of the Lesner Bridge.  The Lesner Bridge spans the Lynnhaven Inlet in Virginia Beach, Virginia.  The fender was destroyed from the mid-point to the flair.  Repairs were made to the Lesner Bridge by the City of Virginia Beach.

After transiting the navigation locks at McNary Dam the vessel had a partial loss of power on port main engine. Sector Inspections notified, subsequently identified port side propeller damage. Vessel was able to maneuver on starboard engine.

The barge KIRBY 28313, pushed by the UTV LIME ROCK, allided with the Galveston Causeway Railroad Bridge south fendering system and dolphin. The barge received a hole in it's starboard bow rake. A 4' section of the deck plating was peeled up 4' and approximately 2' up from the water line.

On 02 June 2008 Rcvd call from the M/V Coral Dawn reporting an allision with the LDB side of the center turntable of the Sabula R/R D/B located at MM 535.0, UMR. The Coral Dawn was U/B enroute St. Paul pushing 15 loaded barges of salt and urea at the time of the allision. The two barges in the port string just fwd of the tow vsl made contact with the outer sheer fence and the concrete protection cell which ripped away 20 ft of fence and cracked some of the concrete. There is no hazard to navigation and the bridge is fully operational. A more thorough inspection of the damage will be completed in daylight hours with any further damage being reported to the CG. There is no reported damage to the tow at this time.
MSD QC IO boarded vessel at Lock 11.  No damage noted on barges.

On 3 June, 2008 at approximately 11:39, the M/V COSETEE allided with the Weymouth Fore River Bridge fendering system.  The M/V COSETTE was under the control of the Tug LIBERTY and Boston Docking Pilot. The fendering system sustained minor damage, and the M/V COSETTE received minimal paint scrapings on the port bow.

Rcvd a rpt from the M/V Dewey R. that they allided with the EJ&E Bridge at MM 271 ILR. Vsl was pushing 4 barges with CS Oil, they parted two wires and there was no report of pollution or damage to the bridge or barge,  APEX 3507, that struck the bridge protection system.  (Rock)

7/30: It is apparent from examining the records/documents that the outflow of the nearby dam effected transit and the master intentionally landed the tow against the protection cell in order to regain full control.  No further action warranted in this incident.

On June 5, 2008, at approximately 1930 Pacific Standard Time (PST), the Barge TSG-230, being pushed ahead  by the Tug WILLIAM R, allided with the Miller-Sweeny Bridge (Fruitvale Avenue) while transiting from San Leandro Bay to the Oakland Inner Harbor in the vicinity of Alameda, California.  The starboard side of the barge glanced the fendering system on the bridge, causing no damage to the barge.  The bridge tender was notified immediatetly and the bridge was checked by the bridge authority.  The only damage reported was to the fendering system.  The status of the fendering system at the time of the allision was subject to various opinions.

M/V WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE was on an inbound transit into the port of Long Beach, Berth G 229, when the vessel lost power. On scene were tugs SANDRA HUGH and CAMPBELL FOSS. A pilot was also onboard. While on the bridge, the pilot noticed black smoke coming from the exhaust for the No. 1 generator. The master of the vessel informed the engine control room through the chief engineer about the black exhaust coming from the diesel generator funnel. The chief engineer then went to check the condition of the No. 1, 3, and 4 generator which were running in parallel. The chief engineer found that the No. 1 RPM gauge went over  the setting from 720 RPM to 840 RPM and was stuck. The chief engineer then attempted to start the No. 2 generator which was on standby. Prior to getting the No. 2 generator functional the No. 3 and 4 generators were not able to sustain the supply of power and a blackout occurred.  The No. 2 generator was started and power resumed.  There was not a loss of propulsion reported.

On 10 June, 2008, the Freight Barge BMI 101 allided with the Julian Dubuque Highway Bridge (Upper Mississippi River MM 226) while being pushed by the UTV RAYMOND GRANT ECKSTEIN.  As a result of the allision the port string of barges were pushed back and broke free from the flotilla.  As the RAYMOND GRANT ECKSTEIN overtook the port string, the MTC 516 caught the quarter of the RAYMOND GRANT ECKSTEIN just to the port side of the toe knee tearing open the side shell. The UTV's forward void flooded to river level.  Flooding was not progressive, the vessel pumped potable water and shifted ballast and was stable at the ARTCO fleeting area.

The freight barge BMI 101 is on the bottom of the river towards left descending bank of Julian Dubuque Highway bridge, the BOI 226 was attached to BMI 101.  MTC 516 was aground on left descending bank on wing dam.

On June 11, 2008 at 1645 while transiting Westbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Water Way at mile marker 288 the UTV NORTHWIND was pushing the barges Kirby 23732B and KIRBY 20708 strung out. The lead barge KIRBY 20708 allided with West Port Arthur Bridge south fender. The only damage noted was to the West Port Arthur Bridge south fendering system. No injuries or pollution. 

Initial estimate on bridge fender system damage is $800k (includes labor, materials, and construction equipment).

On 6/6/2008 at 0735, the M/V DARIN ADRIAN was south bound on the Ohio River with nine loaded coal barges in tow.  While passing beneath the Pomeroy-Mason Replacement Bridge, the master of the M/V DARIN ADRIAN conducted evasive maneuvers to avoid alliding with a work platform hanging from the bridge.  This maneuver placed the head of the tow in line with ice breakers along the right descending bank just downstream of the bridge.  Despite an attempt by the vessel master, the center lead and starboard lead barges allided with the river most ice breaker.  The starboard string of three barges broke loose and the starboard lead barge sunk.  Two other barges were damaged.  Another towboat in the area is able to recover the other two barges and place them back in the tow of the M/V DARIN ADRIAN.

On 15 June 2008, while attempting to move two loaded coal barges manually at the Beelman River Terminal Dock, workers lost control of the TCP 6B and VLB 9167 allowing the barges to drift away from the facility. The TCP 6B struck the first pier of the McKinley Bridge as the  two barges drifted down river.  The Bridge suffered no reported damage.  Two tug boats secured the drifting barges and returned the barges to the facility without further incident.  The TCP 6B is scheduled for repairs the last week of July 2008.

The Tug FISHER HAYDON was  pushing the barge HANNAH AVERY,  when the barge allided with the protection cell at the CSX RAILROAD bridge on the Saint Joseph River.  The tug had reduced speed as it reached the bridge.  When the speed was reduced, the current pushed the stb stern quarter of the barge into the protection cell of the bridge causing minor damage to the cell.  No damage was cause to the barge.

The CSX Railroad company will not release the monetary amount of damage to the bridge, so the allision will be treated as one that caused no damage.  The CSX Railroad company has not been cooperative when this bridge has been struck in the past.

On May 25, 2008 at 0230L, while navigating Southbound at or near mile 282 Upper Mississippi River the UTV WAYNE P. LAGRANGE allied with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge protection cell.  The towboat  was pushing 12 loaded corn barges and was enroute to St. Louis. The ACL 569 and the ACBL 441 hit the bridge protection cell. Incident occurred due to high water and unexpected amount of set in at bridge. The ACL 569 sustained damage to its port side, approx. 50' of its side shell has been pushed up and the #3 and #4 wink tanks were flooded to river level. The ACBL 441 sustained damage to its stbd stern corner and side shell causing the bulkhead to leak into the #4 and #5 wing tanks. No damage was reported on the Louisiana Rail Road bridge. No injuries reported.
One empty and one loaded dry cargo barge broke away from the Lange-Stegmann dock at mile 182.7 UMR.  Loaded barge allided with the Missouri center channel bridge pier of the McKinley Bridge.

On 14 June 2008, the barge ING 6519 being pushed by the UTV RAY GEE in a tow of 12 empty hopper barges, allided with the Crescent City Connection Bridge fendering system, MM 95 Lower Mississippi River.  Barge received only minor denting and bridge fendering system was undamaged.  No injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.

At 1430 on 27JUN08 Sector UMR was contacted by (owner rep/BECKY THATCHER and TOM SAWYER) stating he witnessed an allision between the North bound UTV STARFIRE's tow and the EADS Bridge.

Sector UMR investigating officer responded on Friday (27JUN08) to an allision of the UTV STARFIRE and the Eads Bridge. The UTV STARFIRE was transiting North bound pushing 15 barges (12 empty dry cargo barges, 2 empty tank barges and one loaded dry cargo barge). The tow was 1149 feet long and 105 feet wide. The Allison happened at approx. 1430 local time.

The following empty dry cargo barges allided with the Eads Bridge: ART 24022 and JB 57. The two barges had damage to the fiberglass tops and some minor damage to the cargo tank coaming. The JB 57 had six fiberglass tops damaged and the ART 24022 had three fiberglass tops damaged.

The pilot of the UTV STARFIRE stated he hit the right descending section of the bridge span as he was attempting to transit through the bridge span.  The pilot stated he didn't like the way the tow was shaping up, so decided to stop and back away from the Eads bridge. While backing down the barges allided with the right descending bridge span. The pilot was alcohol tested. No injuries reported.

The M/V PASCAGOULA was northbound on the Mobile River at the railroad bridge at MM 14 with 2 loaded and 2 empty open hopper barges configured 2-wide and 2-long.  While exiting the north side of the bridge the current began to set the tow to the east.  While trying to counteract the current the barge wire broke between to the 2 head barges causing the 2 strings to separate.  The port loaded string swung around and laid against the bridge cribbing (no damage noted by the bridge tender).  The vessel recovered both strings and continued north.
M/V Susan Elizabeth allided with the Crescent Railroad Bridge, MM 481.1.  M/V Susan Elizabeth was pushing 3 empty liquid fertilizer barges.  The bridge tender reported no damage to bridge.

Rcvd a call from the 2 mile Landing Bridge operator that the F/V Captain Ralph's port side stabilizer rope had struck a concrete barrier around the the bridge.  Bridge tender and follow up investigation by CG Sta Cape May confirmed no damage to the Bridge.  Master of vessel confirmed no damage to his vessel and that he had misjudged current causing his vessel to drift into the fender system.

On 05JUN08, the M/V GLASS BOTTOM BOAT, while heading west along side the Destin Bridge, attempted to maneuver the vessel to turn around.  The vessel headed back into the bridge to start the turn and in the process of making the turn, the vessel drifted and allided with the Destin Bridge.  It was reported that there was a loss of power due to the transmission slipping that caused the vessel to drift into the bridge. There was no injuries or damage to the bridge.  CG Inspectors went onboard to assess the damage on the vessel and reported broken welds located on the portside of the wheelhouse.  The estimated amount for the damage to the vessel was $499.00.

On 5 July 2008 at 2100, while the UTV CITY OF NEW ORLEANS was navigating southbound on the Atchafalaya River with four empty red flag barges, the two middle barges, Kirby 30040B & Kirby 28061, allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge, mile marker 29.5.  One barge has a dent on the side, and the damage to the other barge is unknown at time of report.  No damage reported to bridge at time of report.  No pollution, injuries, and no hazard to navigation.

UTV EDMUND L  while  backing out barge MST 865 from American Milling was caught by the current and allided with the Lower Pekin Railroad Drawbridge at mile 151 on the Illinois River. MST 865 was loaded with grain and no damage was found. Vessels radar and flood lights were knocked down due to bridge height at the time of the  incident. No damage was found by the Union Pacific Railroad. No injuries occurred during the incident.

The UTV DELTA TIGER & UTV DELTA PINTAIL were pushing 2 deck barges with one crane on it through the Leevile Lift Bridge on Bayou Lafourche when the bridge was lowered onto the crane boom. The crane boom was cracked in half w/ approx $100k damage, and minor scrapes & dents to the bridge, no injuries & no pollution. The bridge was inspected by the State bridge foreman & is fully operational. Drug & alcohol testing completed.
One dock barge and 3 loaded grain barges broke free from fleet ivo MM 48 UMR.  Barge SME-102 allided with the Thebes RR bridge and the barge was damaged.  All barges were corralled.

RCVD telephone call from the M/V Curtis Moore (573-579-5685) employee reporting that the crane he was pushing struck the Bill Emerson Memorial Hwy bridge in Cape Giradeau, MO.  The only damage is to some electrical conduit.  He is currently moored at his facilitiy and the cause was he had the crane too high and did not have enough clearance.

MV WAYNE C was upbound transiting the Cincinnati and Covington bridge when a crane arm on one of the barges struck structure underneath the bridge.  Greater Cincinnati marine, owner of towing vessel, has put in written procedures and a checklist for all of its vessels to follow when pushing crane barges.

2100- CGSTA Calumet Harbor notified Lake Michigan SCC the M/V ALGOWOOD allided with the 92ND Street Bridge , MM 332.10 on the Calumet River.  MSU team attended subj vsl and UTVs Colorado and South Carolina to conduct preliminary investigation.  Initial findings indicate while maneuvering through the 92nd St bridge and setting up for the EJ&E RR bridge, vsl encountered difficulty turning to stbd, even with tug assistance.  Vsl and tugs engaged full force to turn to stbd and when vsl began swing it could not be stopped in time to avoid being set to port and its port quarter contacted drawbridge pedestal, causing damage to vsl hull (30' above wl) and pedestal of bridge.  Alc/Drug testing submitted and statements/photos obtained.

Further investigation has determined the following facts:

1) Vsl captain and captains of both towboats believe that either shoaling exists in vicinity and bow was aground preventing swing, or that wx conditions (13 kt winds from north up channel) caused sail effect and current drag on vsl signifcant enough to inhibit vsl maneuverability in tight channel.  Wx conditions at time of turn were not present when vsl departed dock/began transit.

2) Bridge tender interruption on the radio made it difficult for the tug captains to fully ascertain the steering commands from the captain of the Algowood- their primary duty.

3) Lookout on the Algowood was not fully cognizant of the distance between the bridge and the vessel as apparent by his quick adjustment of distances between each prior to the allision.  This could have been due to darkness and position/height above water.

4) All involved parties stated "nothing could have been done different to avoid incident."  

5) Distance between bridges is appx 650 ft.  Channel width is 180 ft.  Vsl size involved is 740 ft wide by .  Risk of allision seems high given normal operations and is backed up by MISLE recording nlt (15) allisions with either the 92nd St bridge or the adjacent EJ&E RR bridge in the past 4 years.  In none of these incidents has the operator been charged with wrongdoing (Oct 13, 2004- M/V Halifax- same conditions).

6)  Damage to bridge consisted of distorted support beam requiring replacement, closing the bridge for appx 2 days.  

Recommend no further action in this investigation.

On 21 June 2008 at approximately 0730, tug Z-THREE, transiting westbound in the Cerritos Channel struck the Commodore Heim Bridge with its Navigation Mast. The vessel with two (2) people aboard, was completing their graveyard shift and was transiting towards LA Berth 240Z when the incident occurred. The Engineer (also a properly licensed Master) stated that he contacted the bridge tender to confirm clearance and was given a response of 41 feet. Assuming that his mast was in the down position (it was not) with a maximum height of 36 feet, he proceeded under the bridge and allided with the bridge. There was no damage to the bridge, no injuries, nor any pollution as a result of the incident. Master stated that he was below deck and had the engineer on the helm as relief.  Case closed.

On 25 July, 2008, the operator for the Louisiana Railroad Bridge Operator reported the tow of the UTV ROY E/ CLAVERIE allided with the pier of the railroad bridge due to an unexpected cross current which set the tow to port.  The only vessel which came in contact with the pier was the open hopper freight barge TI 3692.

The vessel, City of Natchez, while transiting through the Martin Luther King bridge located on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway, struck a protective dolphin causing significant damage to the lead barge and the protective dolphin. The captain reported that his barges became misaligned prior to reaching the bridge and he attempted to reverse course, but still could not avoid alliding with the protective dolphin.

Port face wire parted while M/V Judi transited the Eads Bridge with 15 barges in tow.  Vessel master was able to keep tow together and transited most of the next bridge (Poplar Street Bridge) before a barge in the tow allided with bridge pier causing damage on two barges.  All 15 barges became adrift.  Assist tow boats helped regain control of all barges without further incident.  The bridge operators reported no damage after surveying the bridge.

Two crewmembers, under the chief engineer's supervision, were performing maintenance on the #4 fuel pump shock absorber aboard the M/V VINCENT THOMAS BRIDGE while at the Norfolk International Terminal. When they removed the cover to the shock absorber, hot fuel oil sprayed out of the pump and burned the two crew members. Both crew members sustained burns over 2-3% of their body. They were transported to the Norfolk General Hospital, treated, and released on the morning of 10Aug08

Tug SIBERAN SEA was pushing the Coal Barge COLUMBIA NORFOLK when the barge allided with the fendering at the Brightman St. Bridge. The allision occurred after the tug and barge went through the opening of the new bridge currently under construction and then shifted several degrees to starboard. This maneuver requires a several degree shift of the vessel to starboard to align itself with the old bridge opening. The allison occurred during this maneuver when a increase in wind further shifted the barges approach to the bridge, striking the fendering system. Damage was limited to the bridge fendering system and no damage occurred to the structure integrity of the barge or bridge. Only paint transfer and scrapes from the wood fendering system were observed on the hull of the barge

SLM CC received report that the M/V Manistee, O.N. 242406, allided with the Memorial St. Bridge, Manistee, MI.  Investigators from SFO Grand Haven examined the vessel and interviewed the crew. Please see attached evidence number 330249.05JLB (IO Statement) for further details.

17JUL08-The UTV MISS CLAIRE tow consisted of pushing the deck barges, Barge Houston, KS 427 while towing the UTV EDITH ANN along side. As the tow approached the Simmesport RR Bridge the bridge tender swung the bridge open to allow the tow enough clearance to transit through the bridge pylons. As the tow was passing through the pylons the aft barge stuck the pylon causing the tow to shift to port which cause the boom of the crane to strike the underside of the R.R. bridge. Due to the allision of the crane boom and the open span of the R.R. bridge, the boom of the crane collapsed into the river. The vessel and tow were able to maintain position out of the naviagable channel until salavage operations were completed several days later. No injuries, no further damage or pollution resulted.

20AUG2008: UTV Ruby M was pushing the Barge Energy 6505 astern on the STBD hip outbound from Sprague Terminals.  STBD aft corner of barge made contact with bridge fendering system.  Assist UTV Roderick McAllister was in contact w/barge, but w/no line attached to barge.  No damage/No pollution/No injuries.
On August 19, 2008 the M/V Queen of the West was attempting to navigate the McNary Dam Lock, was set into the lock wall by wind and current, buckling the deck on the starboard pitman arm room.

The UTV BOB STITH was transiting south bound with 12 empty red flag barges when the Tank Barge (TB) Chem 131 allided with the Beardstown RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the barge, tow, or bridge.  No damage or injuries occured during the incident.

McAlpine L&D lockmaster reports tow vessel is in the lock chamber, and has a limestone rock barge that is taking on water in the bow void. He advised that the lower approach to McAlpine has been dredged, and has a depth of 13ft at this time. An assist boat helped the tow and tow vessel into the chamber, and they've spoken with the subject vessel regarding the cause and eliminated grounding before entering the chamber as a causal factor.

On 29 August, 2008, the UTV ELLIE J. was approaching the Gilmerton Bridge on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River, Chesapeake, VA towing the DREDGE RICHMOND astern.  The total length of the tow was approx 1800'.   While transiting through the Gilmerton Bridge, the DREDGE RICHMOND rubbed up against the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge. There was not any damage to the tug or the fendering system. The bridge clearance sign was knocked off and the Gilmerton Bridge will be billing Norfolk Tug Company for the sign.

On August 30, 2008, the UTV L. J. SULLIVAN allided with the protection cell on the right descending bank of the Burlington Rail Road Bridge.  The protection cell was not damaged and the ACBL 6015 which struck the bridge was also not damaged.

Received call from Responsible Party reporting that the UTV KRISTIAN D II, allided with theGalveston Causeway Highway Bridge wile pushing the barge William T with a crane bolted to its deck. The boom of the crane impacted the side of the bridge and concrete was seen to break off the bridge and fall into the water.

The Unnamed Uninspected Towing Vessel, state registration FL4435HX, was attempting to push a barge through the Longboat Pass Bridge, when the current and wind contributed to the vessel alliding with the bridge's fender system causing damage to the system.  An alcohol breath test were performed on the Captain by a U.S. Coast Guard boarding officer and a drug test was administered afterwards.  Drug testing was performed as required by law.

On 09 SEP 08 at 0100, while navigating through the Melville Bridge near mile 30 on the Atchafalaya River, the UTV MISS ABBY allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge, no pollution, no injuries and it did not create a hazard to navigation
Tug Jack Newman Bridge was pushing the barge MOBRO 1220 and while passing under the Wappoo Creek Bridge, South ICW / Charleston, SC, allided with the fendering system.

Received NRC# 883651, report of approximately 200 gallons of diesel fuel discharged into the Bayou Warehouse a tributary of the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway from an inland drilling rig. The owner or operator of the rig is currently unknown.  Discharge was due to hurricane Ike pushing the barge into the Bayou Warehouse Bridge Located at 29-49-29.77N 91-47-41.13W. A tank on top of the drilling rig containing the diesel fuel  fell into the water due to the bridge collapsing onto the rig creating a sheen. Incident occurred above the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway Locating it inside the EPA's jurisdiction. The EPA decided not to respond to the location. LA DEQ responded to the location along with the LA State Police and will ensure that the responsible party when located will hire contractors to cleanup any pollution. MSU Morgan City will follow up with who is the responsible Party and that cleanup contractors were hired. 

The owner of the barge is Parking drilling located in New Iberia. Owner of the barge stated that the barge was empty and only had water onboard.  Received additional NRC From Exxon Mobil. Exxon Mobil Stated that the Barge was laying on top of one of their 6 inch steel pipes saying the sheen may becoming from the pipe. Salvage operation is underway. All information was passed to EPA by the LA DEQ.
**********************
IO
09/13/2008 - N Hobson Wheless owned by Parker Drilling USA hit the HWY 83 Bridge in Warehouse Bayou, LA.  Parker Drilling does not have any shore side Emergency Response Procedures similar to their US Offshore operations.  Barge was sunk with water in Warehouse Bayou.  During Hurricane Ike, storm surge raised the sunken barge from its position and the barge floated down the bayou consequently striking the HWY 83 Bridge  causing total destruction.

CG RCVD A REPORT FROM THE SHORT CUT BRIDGE IN RIVER ROUGE, DETROIT RIVER THAT THE M/V ALGORAIL ALLIDED WITH THE SHORTCUT BRIDGE. NO REPORTED POLLUTION OR APPARANT DAMAGE TO M/V ALGORAIL. SECTOR DETROIT SPOKE WITH BRIDGE TENDER AT 0930 ON 15 SEP 08 AND STATED THE A SURVEYOR FOUND SOME DAMAGE TO THE NORTHEAST SIDE OF BRIDGE. BRIDGE IS STILL OPERATIONAL.
On September 14, 2008, the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) LEXIE B allided with the east and west fendering system of the John's Pass Bridge, causing over $100,000 estimated damage to the bridge.

On 14 SEP 08 at approximately 0955 the UTV SUSAN FRANCES, with 6 loaded hopper barges in tow, allided with the Bayou Sorrel Bridge knocking the bridge pontoon adrift. The vessel and tow was headed southbound and was set to port. The operator attempted to straighten out the vessel and tow to prevent from making contact with the open bridge pontoon. He applied full power and steered to starboard, but the vessel did not respond. The operator then backed full astern to mitigate the collision and sounded the general alarm. The port lead barge (MEM 1009) made contact with the corner of the bridge pontoon and knocked the pontoon adrift. The barge MEM 1009 sustained a hole in the portside head log of approximately 6-8 inches. No pollution or injuries resulted.

Sector Command Center received call from the Terminal Railroad Police Department reporting that a barge was adrift IVO the Merchant's R/R Bridge (MM 183.2, UMR). The original report was from a Norfolk and Southern R/R train crew who was transiting the Merchant's Bridge at around the time of the incident. The train crew saw an adrift barge and contacted their dispatch. At the time no other information was passed to the CC
The M/V Sally Archer allided with the Cairo Highway Bridge at mile 1 UMR.

Fleet operator advises that 15 barges have broken away from fleet at MM 750 OHR, and are drifting upriver. Tow vessel(s) underway for assist/recovery.  One of the barges (deck/crane barge) reportedly allided w/231 Hwy bridge in vicinity of MM 746 OHR and is resting alongside the bridge pier.  KY DOT and bridge inspector(s) notified and have reported no damage to the bridge.

Subject vessel allided w/ the Cape May Middle Thorofare Bridge in the Cape May Inlet (ICW).  The towing vessel (North Star 6), was towing the commercial fishing vessel (Jason Danielle),  the (Jason Danielle), set slightly to port while under tow, striking the fendering system.  (Minimal damage to vessel - paint scrapes/Minimal damage to the piling system - was previously damaged & temporarily repaired).

On September 9, 2009, the UTV RON SHANKIN allided with the Florence Highway Bridge at mile 56 on the Illinois River. The RON SHANKIN was pushing 12 barges (4 corn, 3 distiller pellets, 3 wire rods, 2 empty styrene)  down-bound en route mile 118 on the Upper Mississippi River. Two of the barges, DM 3030 (corn) and ACL 9726B (wire rod) were damaged. Barge DM 3030 stern tank was flooded and wing tank had water coming in. Barge ACL 9726B had flooding in the bow void. Pilot stated the draft of the barges prior to the incident was 9 feet. Draft is at after the allision was 11'6". The damaged barge was stabilized and moored, no damage was reported to the bridge.

On the 28th of September 2008, the M/V R.W. Naye transiting up the Mississippi River pushing 11 loaded barges when it struck the La Crosse RR Bridge.  Investigating Officer met up with the vessel at Lock & Dam #6.  IO met with Master, discussed incident involving barge allision with  Soo Line railroad bridge (LaCrosse, WI  RR bridge) UMR MM 699.8 which occurred at 0540 on Aug 28 2008.  Master stated tow lost headway, a controlled landing (barge LF 112B) was made at middle of turntable; after landing barges check and no damage observed.  Viewed Tow Boats controls, equipment & operation of machinery from the pilot house during tows lock thru, all appeared to be operating satisfactory.  Viewed all barges, walked barges decks, no damage or de-watering pumps on deck were observed.   Confirmed via telephone with RR Bridge tender; bridge operational and appears to be unaffected.

Recd rpt fm MSU Duluth that vsl arrived in port requesting inspection of repairs to damage incurred as a result of bridge allision in Calumet River, Chicago, IL on 9/24.  Vsl sustained damage to nav mast including restricted maneuverability nav lights.  MSU Duluth attended to verify damage and collect evidence.  MSU Chicago contacted pilots, rr bridge (NS, mm 332) and CBP, began process of demading surety bond.  Vsl agent indicated that incident was reported to operating company, who in turn reported it to OCMI Duluth upon arrival and was under impression that CG had been notified.  Bridge sustained no damage from contact and mast was repaired on vsl.  Indications are that bridge was not at full vertical clearance height due to misadjusment of mechanical switches/indicators on bridge/in control cab.

The foreign flagged tank/chem ship, (TUCHKOV BRIDGE), ran aground in the C&D Canal - Delaware City.  The vessel is holding the following cargo: 752,000 gallons of #2 diesel fuel - (17,924 barrels); and 6,092,434 gallons of unleaded gasoline - (145,000 barrels).

Weeks Marine notified the command center that the Weeks Tug Virginia was pushing a Crane on the Weeks 541. The crane onboard Weeks 541 struck the paint scaffolding attached to the Brooklyn Bridge. Weeks 541 was being pushed by UTV Virginia.

The Caney Creek Swing Bridge operator contacted District 8 reporting an allision. The M/V BALTIMORE (no further info) allided with the bridge fendering resulting in wood debris. The bridge is closed to marine traffic while debris clean up is underway. ICW MM 418

06NOV2008 SPC - The BALTIMORE pushing the MMI 2806 was u/w IVO Caney Creek Swing Bridge when the MMI 2806 allided with the bridge fendering system breaking one timber valued at $200.

Commercial F/V SASSY GIRL's port stern quarter made contact w/ the port side wooden fendering system, and her port side outrigger planer made contact w/ the concrete pier below the bridge control house, while outbound Cape May, NJ.
UTV WILLIAM J WEBBER PUSHING BARGES LCD4903, CHEM3700 BOTH EMPTY PREVIOUS CARGO NAPTHA COLLIDED WITH THE FENDER SYSTEM OF THE CANEY CREEK SWING BRIDGE.

On 06 October 2008, at approximately 1406, the UTV TALLAPOOSA had an allision with the Pops Ferry Bridge on the Biloxi River.  Drug and Alcohol testing were performed on entire crew.  A surveyor was sent out to inspect the bridge, barge and vessel where no damage was found.  Vessel en route to Gulfport, MS with no further incidents

On 21 OCT 08 at 2020, the UTV AMY SUE was transiting down river on the Atchafalaya River pushing 1 tank barge(AX-3202) loaded with caustic soda.  The vessel was a quarter of the way through the Melville Rail Road Bridge when the port side of the AX-3202 allided with the bridge.  The vessel sustained no damage except a 15" x 3/4" dent in the port side.  No damage to the bridge, no pollution and no injuries resulted.  The port #3 wing void was later air tested and no deficiencies were found.

Sector UMR received a telephone call from the La Crescent RR bridge, MM 481.4 UMR reporting that the M/V MINNEAPOLIS allided with the bridge.  The M/V has 5 barges in tow and is holding underneath the bridge.  The bridge tender does not see any damage to the bridge, but wants to wait until daybreak for a complete survey.  Currently the bridge tender is unable to raise the M/V MINNEAPLOIS on VHF-FM Ch 16.
No damage apparent to barges or bridge.  MSD QC IO will meet vessel at L&D16.

UTV AMY SUE ALLIDED with the Kansas City Southern Rail Road Bridge in Monroe, LA. at MM 167 on the Ouachita River.

No other damage, pollution or injuries were reported.

Drugs or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this event.

24 Oct 08: M/V BBC ELBE allided with the Ogden St. Bridge on the Menominee River in Menominee, MI.  The vessel was inbound heading up river to KK Integrated Logistics stern first under tug assistance.  While under tow the vessel struck the Ogden St. Bridge (Marinette, WI side) causing damage to the vessel's starboard bridge wing and the bridge itself including an adjacent protection dolphin.  The bridge tender has deemed that the bridge has not sustained significant damage and it is fully operational (WI DOT has been notified).  The vessel damage appears to be minimal; the Captain of the BBC ELBE does not feel that the damage affects stability or sea worthiness.  No navigation hazard exists, no flooding, no pollution, and no injuries.

The CFV MISS DONNA being towed by F/V KAREN J. BELLE bumped the fendering system of the Longboat Pass Bridge while transiting inbound from sea.  The CFV MISS DONNA sustained a steering casualty (see IIA# 3352197) and was being towed by the CFV KAREN J. BELLE through the Longboat Pass Bridge when the port bow of the CFV MISS DONNA struck the Northwest fendering system of the bridge.  The vessel did not sustain any damage

On October 27, 2008 the M/V NORMAN L SNODGRASS is up bound on the Ohio River with 15 empty hopper barges in tow approaching the B & O Railroad Bridge at MM 184.3.  As the master proceeded beneath the bridge, a strong wind began to set the tug and tow towards the left descending pier of the bridge.  The master, realizing he was not going to clear the bridge, backed up and then came to a stop touching the bridge pier with the starboard corner wrapper of the starboard lead barge. No damage to bridge or barge

29OCT08 (0615) - Tugs MARGARET MCALLISTER (fwd) and CARLO MCALLISTER (aft) were made fast to the M/T SITEAM EXPLORER for departure from the Kinder Morgan dock. 

0618 - M/T SITEAM EXPLORER unhooked its last line from the dock and began backing away from the Kinder Morgan dock with the assist of the two tugs.

0620 - M/T SITEAM EXPLORER requested for an opening of the Isabel Holmes Bridge. 

0636 - M/T SITEAM EXPLORER allided with the Isabel Holmes Bridge.   

(0730) - MSU WILMINGTON Notified by docking pilot that M/T SITEAM EXPLORER "bumped" the Isabel Holmes fendering system during outbound transit. Immediately contacted bridge personnel who advised that NC DOT and maintenance crew were aware of allision, assessing damage, and would advise of findings ASAP.

0800 - MSU I/Os and Inspector dispatched to bridge and to rendezvous with vessel to conduct interviews, collect statements, and inspect damage.

0916 - Received CG 2692 and 2692B from McAllister Towing of Wilmington. The docking pilot’s statement indicated that there was a delayed response to the master's command to come "dead slow ahead" as the SITEAM EXPLORER approached the Isabel Holmes Bridge. Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was conducted on the docking pilots.

0930 - Completed visual assessment of Isabel Holmes Bridge fendering system damage and interviewed bridge tender. Vessel did NOT contact the bridge. 

0945 - IO boarded SITEAM EXPLORER at the "old yacht basin" near Southport, NC, via STA OAK ISLAND 41' UTB to inspect the damages caused by the allision and to investigate the casualty. The results of the inspection can be found in Activity # 3354441, which is attached to this case. As a result  of the findings, the vessel was issued a COTP order. Details can be found in Activity # 3353659, which is attached to this case.
IO collected witness statements and evidence. IO informed Master of the requirements SMI drug and alcohol testing requirements and of the need of a CG-2692. 

30OCT08 - M/T SITEAM EXPLORER was boarded to inspect the repairs made to the vessel. The COTP order was rescinded. IO reminded Master of the requirements SMI drug and alcohol testing requirements and of the need of a CG-2692.

MSU Wilmington held a meeting with the docking pilots to discuss this incident and other near misses of the bridges in the area. Specifically, we discussed the importance of good communications between the master and docking pilots.

Cause determined to be the docking pilot's lack of knowledge regarding the vessel's propulsion system. No further action taken. Case closed.

On 20 Oct 2008, Able Seaman aboard the Washington State Ferry Tacoma was handling a tie-up line and twisted his right ankle.  AB was basically twisting his body to pull on line when his ankle rolled over. There was no identifiied trip hazard and activity was part of his normal duties. AB was sent for medical evaluation. Injury was determined to be an ankle sprain.  Incident was determined to be an SMI because Mariner missed work until 05 November, 2008. DOT post casualty drug & alcohol testing performed. 

Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.

While transiting southbound, the sewage sludge barge LISA allided with the Erie Jackknife Bridge.  Barge was being pushed stern-first by the UTV Turecamo Girls. Tug and barge was making approximately 3 knots when the Master saw that the barge was being set by the tide.  The starboard quarter of the barge made contact with the fendering system of the bridge.  Bridge engineer reports that the damage is minimal.

The tug MORGAN PAGE was pushing ahead a small, undocumented pile barge through the Norwalk Railroad bridge opening when the port spud on the barge snagged the overhead linkage rod assembly on the railroad bridge and bent it.  There was no damage to the tug or barge.  When the railroad bridge closed, the linkage failed to make a good connection which prevented the trains from running.  Metro North electricians and mechanics arrived on scene and repaired the linkage.  The bridge was tested and operated properly

The M/V Dale White, pushing 2 barges ahead, allided with Chicago Ave Bridge on the North Branch, Chicago River with initial estimates placing incident in SMI category.  Investigation initiated iaw 46 CFR subpart 4, MSM Vol V and all other applicable references.  DWP

On 26 September 2008, the M/V LAWSON was transiting north bound on Black Warrior River when the MM219 Alabama & Gulf Coast RR (automated unmanned) bridge began to close on the vessel while it was approaching to pass under resulting in allision between the a crane on the barge and the underside of the bridge arm.  The Captain stated that the light was green until he was 100 ft from the bridge when the bridge began to close at which time he put it in full astern to avoid hitting the bridge as it was coming down.  The crane on the barge hit the bridge at which time the lights on the bridge were flashing red.  The allision caused $60,000 in damage to the crane.
-At the time of the incident, the bridge did not appear to have any damage.

On 3 November 2008, the CG was asked by the Army Corps of Engineers to investigate this incident.

Reporting party for bridge allision in case # 429940 also reported that the same vsl had allided with the same bridge on two previous occasions.

No other damage, pollution or injuries were reported.

Drugs or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this event.

Reporting party for bridge allision in case #429940 also reported that the same vsl had allided with the vehicle bridge upriver on another occasion.

No other pollution, damage or injuries were reported.

Drugs or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this event.

UTV Dennis Ross (544705) reports alliding with the Bordeaux R.R. Bridge (aka Walking Horse) at mi 185.2 CMB. They have 3 empty asphalt barges, and one barge hit the bridge as they were heading downbound. They are reporting no damage to the barge, and no visible damage to the bridge.

No reported injuries or pollution.

On 13 November 2008, at approx. 1130, the UTV WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE pushing the deck barge, LOCKWOOD 2001, allided with the Derek Hines Memorial Bridge in Amesbury, MA during an inbound transit on the Merrimack River. As a result of the allision, the bridge is unable to close properly for vehicle traffic, therefore the local police have closed off access to the bridge and created a vehicle detour. No pollution or injuries occurred. 

Due to the initial cost estimate for the bridge repairs, the CG directed the company to have all crew members drug and alcohol tested. Amesbury Police conducted a simple portable breath test to all crew members; all completed. Drug test results pending. 

18NOV08: Received the drug test results; all crew members tested for drugs. Official cost estimate for the bridge repair is pending.

A tug and barge allided with and ripped off approximately 80 feet of the fendering system on the north side of the John's Pass Bridge.  The only portion of the tow making contact with the fendering system was the barge.  There was no damage reported to either vessel.  Drug and alcohol testing was conducted on the crew.  Tug Master did not have proper towing vsl endorsement on MML to operate towing vsl and company permitted MM to operate without proper credentials.

On 14 NOV 2008, the UTV LORETTE MORAN experienced a steering casualty on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River while pushing the BARGE M3105.  As a result of the steering casualty, the BARGE M3105 allided with the Gilmerton Bridge damaging the fendering system.  The bridge is operational. 

** Unable to conduct causal analysis on the initiating event due to the fact that the technician was unable to duplicate the steering casualty or determine its cause.

On 17 November 2008, a third party reported that the Tow Vessel ATLANTIC DAWN pushing the Dredge 54 allided with the Chelsea Street bridge during outbound transit. Minimal damage was caused by the allision.  A Letter of Warning was issued to the Great Lakes Dredge Company because it failed to report the incident to the USCG.

On December 2008, the Sector Boston received the Letter of Warning returned, which had been signed and accepted.

On 18 NOV 2008, at approx 0510, the UTV ROBERT BURTON, a 68-foot, U.S. flagged, steel hull towing vessel, allided with the GEORGE P. COLEMAN BRIDGE in Yorktown, VA.  The Mate on board the ROBERT BURTON had the vessel on auto pilot while transiting northbound on the York River enroute to West Point, VA.  On the approach to the bridge, while on auto pilot, the rudders shifted to the right which caused the stbd bow of the UTV ROBERT BURTON to allide with the center caisson of the GEORGE P. COLEMAN BRIDGE.  The COLEMAN Bridge lost power after some submerged power cables were hit by the ROBERT BURTON and the ROBERT BURTON suffered cosmetic damage to the stbd side handrails and superstructure.  The crew of the ROBERT BURTON was administered post casualty alcohol and drug tests.

On 31 October 2008, the UTV PERRY LYNN, pushing tank barge MPC-812, allided with the Rigolets Railroad Bridge on the intracoastal waterway.  Neither vessel was damaged.  No injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.  Bridge sustained damage estimated at $300,000.  All chemical tests were completed

While offloading gasoline at the pier at the Kinder Morgan Perth Amboy, NJ facility, the M/T Torgovy Bridge touched bottom during a period of low tide. A dive survey was conducted and found no damages to the vessel. No discharge of cargo was also noted.

F/V BALD EAGLE II (1038900) REPORTED THAT WHILE TRANSITING UNDER THE MOREHEAD CITY HIGHRISE, ITS OUTRIGGERS HIT THE BOTTOM OF THE BRIDGE. VSL REPORTED TO BE TRANSITING IN THE CENTER OF THE CHANNEL AT THE TIME OF THE ALLISION. NO DAMAGE REPORTED.

UTV R.W. NAYE was towing 15 barges (13 grain and two empty) south bound on the Upper Mississippi River when  one of the barges (ACBL 1362) struck the LaCross RR bridge on the left side of the descending bank. No damage was received to the barge or tow.  The barge side swiped the protection cell knocking off one timber.  No other damage was sustained to the bridge and the bridge remained operational.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge reporting the passenger vessel "Majestic" allided with the bridge.  The bridge tender reports he had the blinds shut when he heard a "crunch" noise.  The bridge tender exited and saw the vessel leaving.  The tender reported that the vessel operator stated "I guess I didn't have 21.5 feet".

M/T NEVSKIY PROSPECT allided with the Arthur Kill Railroad Bridge with its antenna while transiting south bound in the Arthur Kill. There was no damage reported to the Railroad Bridge and minor damage on the antenna of the vessel.

On 02DEC2008 at 11:05 the UTV SANDY DRAKE pushing 15 empty hopper barges allided with the Parkersburg railroad bridge mile 184.1 OHR due to high winds.  The Starboard #1 barge C 1057 made contact with the bridge.   No injuries, no damage, or pollution reported.

On 03 December 2008, at approximately 2125, the M/V AMARANTH BRIDGE was entering the Bonnet Carre Anchorage, Lower Mississippi River,  MM128, Left Descending Bank, when it experienced a loss of propulsion.  Vessel safely anchored.  No damage, injuries or pollution resulted from this incident.

The M/V Ardyce Randall was transiting up bound through the Lower Pekin R/R, at mile 151.2, Illinois River and allided (rubbed) the U/S, right descending bank, protection cell. There was no damage to the bridge, barge (XL-767) or the tow. The M/V Ardyce Randall was pushing 11 loaded barges (3 coal and 8 salt).
06 NOV 08:  Tug and work barge with crane/boom allided with the allision bridge.
WHILE D/B AT APPROX 0915, HORNET ALLIDED WITH HENRY R. LAWRENCE BRIDGE ON MI 63.1 CMBR.

SSP received a report from STA FMB that the CFV Eunice Lemay allided with the Matanzas Pass Bridge.  The vessel is a 77 FT Shrimper with 03 POB.  The vessel had raised its outriggers to transit underneath the bridge, and its starboard outrigger struck the bottom of the bridge and it dragged the entire length of the bridge.  SSP established a safety zone around the bridge.  Bridge was closed to all vehicle and vessel traffic for one hour. CG33126 is staying on scene with the shrimper until the duty investigator from MSD FMB arrives.  SSP made appropriate briefings, and SECCOM directed SSP to cancel the safety zone.

MSD Fort Myers personnel conducted interview with the vessel Captain who indicated that after striking the bridge, vessel lowered the outriggers an additional 18" and the flooding tide carried the vessel through the bridge. Vessel then safely moored. Received CG 2692 and statements from the vessel crew. Vessel had been previously boarded at sea by CG STA FTMB. No alcohol testing conducted. Captain estimates damage sustained to the starboard outrigger to be app. $500.00.

On December 12, 2008, while southbound on the Black Warrior River, the UTV DIANE B. SIEGAL with 6 open hopper, loaded coal barges allided with the AG&S Northfolk Railroad Bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge and very minor cosmetic damage to the tug and barge.
Rcvd a rpt that the UTV Captain Whitey had allided with the Morgan City RR Bridge.  At the time of the incident, the river was above normal stage levels.

RCVD: HE ADVD THAT THE M/V SMITTY OFF NR 260029 WITH GATE CITY RIVER TRANSPORTATION WAS TRANSITING THROUGH THE SOUTHERN HARBOR IVO OF MI 472 OHR AND 03 BARGES BROKE AWAY - HE RETRIEVED 02 AND A TUG GOT THE OTHER ONE AND TOOK IT TO A FLEETING AREA - ADVD HE HAS 05 BARGES IN TOW ALL OF WHICH ARE RED FLAGS - ALSO ADVD THAT HE BELIEVES THAT THE ONE BARGE MAY HAVE STRUCK THE SOUTHERN RR BRIDGE - PHN: 606.547.7112

M/V DENNIS ROSS reported that they allided with some coal barges at the Miami Fort Power station while heading upbound at mile marker 490 OHR.  The M/V DENNIS ROSS stated he is pushing 03 loaded red flags in a single string with the lead barge being loaded with asphalt and taking on water in the bow void.  The allision with the coal barges caused four barges to breakaway from the fleeting area.  The M/V CANADIAN immediately retrieved three of the loaded coal barges and secured them.  The M/V CANADIAN then proceed to go after the fourth loaded coal barge headed down the river toward the I 275 Bridge. Master of tug COUSHATTA reported strong winds pushed tow against swing bridge while in the open position.  Subsequently as tow pushed forward along bridge the starboard bow of the lead barge, 7021, was pushed into the GICWW bank and landed on a large rock causing damage to barge's bow rake. The crew involved in the marine casualty were directed to undergo chemical tests.  Please see evidence number 3386357.013JLB  for further details.

On 04 JAN 2009, the BARGE JMC-85, being pushed ahead by UTV HUNT GILRS, allided with the fendering system of the Chincoteague swing bridge. Slight damage to the fendering system and damage to the red light on the SW side of the fender was repaired. No damage to tug or barge.

The UTV THOMAS was made up to the starboard side of the deck barge Weeks 246 with the assist tug KATHLEEN made up to the port bow of the barge. During transit through the Jordan Bridge, the KATHLEEN rubbed against the west fender system of the bridge. Pieces of the fendering system were knocked in to the water, no damage to the vessel.

While transiting in-bound Houston Ship Channel (HSC), enroute City Dock (CD) 10, the M/V GIBRALTAR (O.N. 7642663) allided with Interstate-610 bridge in way of the radio antennas and mast running light.  The vessel struck the centerline portion of the bridge.  No damage to the bridge was sustained, the vessel incurred damage at the top 8 feet of the mast, specifically, the mast was bent aft at approximately an 80 degree angle, affecting operation of the VHF radio and the mast white running light.

The I-610 is charted at 136 feet (NOAA Chart), above the HSC at mean high tide.  USCG Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) requires vessels with an air draft over 129 feet to check in with VTS at the Sea Buoy and make VTS aware of the air draft.  VTS watch supervisor will then contact the Port of Houston Police Department to get the current gauge readings at the bridge.  The VTS watch supervisor will relay this information back to the vessel, who will then adjust the vessels ballast/draft to ensure it fit underneath the bridge.  In this particular incident, the pilot was relying on the information presented to him from the pilot card.  The pilot card indicated the air draft was under 129 feet, specifically, the air draft for the vessel was 121.74 feet, thus falling under the criteria for notification for transit underneath the I-610 bridge.

After the allision with the bridge occurred, there was obliviously a discrepancy at some point.  The vessel conducted a survey of the mast, and it was determined that the air draft as indicated on the pilot card should be approximately 155 feet.  The source of the discrepancy on the original pilot card and vessel drawings is unknown, but it is suspected that some point during the vessel's history, there were add-ons to the mast.  Since the conclusion of the survey, the vessel's drawings, and pilot card has been correct.  All damage sustained by the mast as a result of the allision has been corrected to the satisfaction of the vessel's classification society, and the operation control placed on the vessel by the USCG has been removed.

14Jan09: Forwarded for review
M/V Keith Darling was headed N/B when barge CHB0505 had an allision with the I-155 Bridge at MM 839.

Rcvd a rpt that while the UTV General Ellis was pushing two sugar barges through the Adeline Bridge, the capt. of the UTV misjudged the current and the lead port barge allided with the bridge's timbers.

The Tug Pamlico was transiting from Radio Island Terminal to the PCS facility and struck the fendering system of the Morehead to Beaufort Norfolk Southern Railroad bridge.  The master reported that there was no damage to the tug or barge (Cargo Molten Sulphur).

3397216 - Tug RED BLUFF allided with the wooden fendering (only) of Burlington Northern/Santa Fe Railroad's bascule lift bridge that obstructs the westerly fork of the Duwamish River, near the river's mouth in Seattle, WA.  In this bridge allision the railway span was open with the span structure upright on shore and entirely unaffected.  On ebbing tide with 2-knot current downstream, the tug undocked the barge at General Construction's yard close upstream from the bridge and transited northward downstream.  Cross-current turbulence, generated occasionally as the river splits to go around Harbor Island, set the tug/barge combination toward the west side of the west fork of the river and was unexpectedly involved in this casualty.  A tire fender on the barge's port quarter rubbed against the fendering's shearwall at its southern end.  The barge's deckhand spoke with the bridgetender; the tug phoned the bridge and confirmed that there was no serious damage.  BNSFRR provides initial estimate of damage, taking into account that damage from this allision had added to damages which had occurred during several prior allisions.   Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time

On 18JAN09 at approximately 1015 CST a towing vessel with 06 empty coal barges allided with a bridge support column.  No damage was done to the bridge and slight damage was done to the starboard bow of one of the empty tow barges.  The cause of the allision is reported to be a parted facing wire.  Repairs were made and vessel is back in service.

UTV BETTY BRENCE pushing four red flag barges transiting through the Louisa Bridge, MM134 on the ICW.  The lead barge KIRBY28068 allided with the bridge fendering system suffering a 4'x1' dent on the stbd stern 2' above the water line.  No injuries or pollution reported.

On 16 January 2009 at approximately 1200 the UTV JEFF BRUMFIELD was inbound on the Mobile River passing the Chickasaw Railroad Bridge and made a flat controlled rubbing landing on the bridge fender system.  There was no damage to vessel, barge or bridge fender system. No further incidents.
THE UTV SAN CARMEN PUSHING THE BARGE GSS-35 ALLIDED WITH THE GALVESTON CAUSEWAY FENDERING SYSTEM DUE TO WIND GUST.

On 26 Jan 09, the barge WESTERN PROVIDER (O.N. 648826) allided with the Burlington Northern Rail Bridge #37 swing bridge over the Snohomish River. The barge was being towed down bound thru the narrow channel by the Tug FLYER (O.N.  636922) with Tug PACIFIC (O.N. 522088) tied into the stern for assistance.

During the transit through the railroad bride opening, the stern of the Western Provider swung toward the bridge protection wall on the south side.  The tug Pacific attempted to pull back the stern.  However, the port stern of the Western Provider struck a handrail stanchion on the bridge protection pier.  There was no structural damage to the bridge or its protection (fenders).  Bridge inspected by BNSF Bridge Engineers. No damage to either Tow Boat or Barge.

Based on current evidence, no enforcement action is contemplated at this time.

Master of the M/V Azzura rptd the Sat-C antenna struck the centerline light, breaking the lens, of the Sidney Sherman Bridge (Hwy 610) while transiting outbound on the HSC. VTS rptd height of the bridge to be 136', with the light hanging down to 135-134' clearance. Master estimated the air draft initially for the vsl to be approximately 134' and as such the agent advised the master to ballast down to 133' to ensure adequate clearance.  However the master did not ballast down and contact was made with the bridge light. Final air draft was measured at 135'. Master took responsibility for the miscalculation and requested agent coordinate with the USCG and TX DOT to ensure payment was made to effect repairs on the bridge. Case closed no enforcement action to follow
UTV BILL STEGBAUER was pushing four empty barges NB on the Arkansas River at mile marker 118 alighted with interstate 30 bridge pier. No damage to barges or bridge.

On February 1, 2009, the UTV LUCKY D allided with the Lower Hack Bridge and Owen Corning's pier in the Hackensack River, New Jersey. The UTV LUCKY D was pushing the Tank Barge (T/B) DELAWARE loaded with 31,500 BBLS of asphalt. Prior to the allision, the vessels were delayed when two of the bridges did not open as previously scheduled. There was minor damage to the forward rake of the T/B DELAWARE but no damage to the bridge fendering or the tug. Following the allision, the T/B DELAWARE moored to the facility without further incident.

On the morning of January 8, 2009 the tug vessels Centurion, Stacy McAllister, and Isabel McAllister were in transit, towing the Barge Jax San Juan Bridge from Blount Island to North Florida Shipyard under the direction of a docking pilot.  At approximately 0605 the towing cable of the tug Centurion caught St. Johns River Buoy 59 and the buoy was pulled off station.  The docking pilot was looking out on the starboard bow on deck of the barge.  He could not see buoys on the port side of the tow so he utilized the tugs STACY MCALLISTER AND CENTURION as port side lookouts.  The TUG CENTURION was aft of the TUG STACY MCALLISTER.  After the CENTURION passed buoy 57  the master notified the docking master that they were being set on buoy 59.  The docking master  instructed the STACY to push against the barge to get the CENTURION off of it.  At this point the TUG STACY could not follow the docking master's instructions because it would have caused the TUG STACY to collide with buoy 59, instead the TUG STACY laid beside the barge in order to miss the buoy.  This action allowed the port side aft section of the barge along with TUG CENTURION to continue to be set on the buoy.  The buoy passed between the TUG CENTURION and the barge.  The tow line connecting the two vessels caught the buoy and it was pulled off station.

While transiting outbound through Townsend Inlet Bridge, the UTV (Northstar 10), pushing the crane barge (Northstar 140), allided with the wooden fendering system on the southwest side of bridge.  While transiting inbound through Townsend Inlet Bridge, the UTV (Northstar 10), pushing the construction barge (Northstar 140), allided with wooden fendering system on the southwest side of bridge.

The UTV STEVE YOUNG was transiting down bound on the Monongahela River pushing 8 hopper barges loaded with coal.  As they were passing underneath the Masontown Bridge at Mile 79, the starboard aft barge brushed against the right descending bank bridge pier (unintended bridge allision) causing no damages, pollution, or injuries and appropriate notifications made.  Swift river conditions from warm weather and snow/ice melt coupled with low visibility conditions (fog) contributed to the incident.

Drugs and alcohol were determined not to play a role in this incident.

The  M/V Thomas E.  Erickson was D/B, ILR at MM 151 when it port barge allided (rubbed) the LDB protection cell on the Pekin RR bridge. Their was no damage to the barge, tow or bridge. Crew inspected the barge and continued transit. The vessel was pushing 12 loads of grain.

On 13 Feb 2009, M/V SHANGHIGH BRIDGE called reporting a loss of propulsion. The vessel was escorted to anchorage (dead ship) via tug operating only on the emergency generator. IO/INSP team arrived on the vessel at 23:30; the vessel suffered an unintended shutdown of all 3 main generators. The investigation shows evidence that the fuel piping system and the fuel pump was not working correctly. Investigation points too residual heavy fuel oil in the fuel lines becoming cold resulting in decreased viscosity and clogged the fuel lines and the fuel pump. The clogged fuel lines prevented the pump from supplying proper fuel to the generators.   
(See Report of Investigation in Correspondence for further details.
Barge ATC 1303 allided with the Pekin Railroad Bridge at Mile Maker 151.2 on the Illinois River while under the control of UTV BRUCE L. HAHN. No damage or injuries occurred during the incident.
Limestone Lady (545338) allided with the HWY 60 Bridge (MM 2.7 CMB).  Limestone Lady was pushing 25 loaded rock barges.

The M/V J.W. Hershey allided with the Lower Pekin R/R D/B protection cell at MM 151.2, ILR. The M/V WAYNE P. LAGRANGE reported while navigating southbound near MM 287 ILR and 6 empty hopper barges in tow allided with their port stern barge (ACL 00557) against the left decending bank upper protection cell at the McDonough St. Bridge due to strong winds. On 22 February 2009, at approximately 0315, while northbound on the Black Warrior River MM219, the UTV HELOISE had an allision with the Yo-Yo Bridge owned by Alabama and Gulf Coast Railroad.  The starboard middle barge struck the concrete bridge column and no damages are reported.  Pilot stated that barge just slid into bridge and is pushing eight empty coal barges. Cumberland Express, while downbound on the Ohio River (Mile 971), landed on the Right descending bank pier of the Irvin Cobb Bridge with the empty hopper barge ING5503.  Tow was pushing 08 empty open hopper barges at time of allision.  No damage was reported to the barge or the bridge.

27 Feb 2009: The UTV Steven J. Durbin reported that they allied with the Westbound Natchez-Vidalia HWY 84 Bridge at MM 364 LMR. VSL has 30 grain barges, 22 of which were adrift. The VSL has one assist VSL on scene (Miss Aimee) and another enroute (Bettye M. Jenkins). VSL is unsure if the bridge was damaged. Tow configuration is 5 long and 6 wide. On 5 March 2009, at approximately 2158, while transiting the Tombigbee River, northbound the M/V JO ANNE STEGBAUER had an allision with the Meridian Bigbee RR Bridge, when the starboard stern barge (SL14) allided with the starboard bridge pier. ON 10FEB09 AT APPROX. 2330 UTV PIMLICO WAS S/B PUSHING TWO RED FLAG BARGES WHEN THE TOW STRUCK THE RR BRIDGE AT LMR-734.7 NEAR MEMPHIS TN.  NO DAMAGE OCCURED TO THE TOW OR THE BRIDGE.
