The allision caused one of the spuds from the CHARITY to break free which resulted in the barge getting stuck under the bridge. No damage reported to the bridge, no pollution or injuries reported.  Drug and alcohol testing completed

12 MAR 2009 - UTV ISLAND PROGRESS pushing 03 barges, 80 CM 0828, 80 CM 0829 & 80 CM 0830 allided w/ the HWY 278 bridge west fendering system over Skull Creek, SC.  UTV allided w/ fender system, no damage to barges, no pollution or injuries reported.

Coast Guard Sector New York received a report from the Trainmaster on the "Triple Bridges" stating that a towing vessel, the PETER J. GELLATLY, pushing the empty barge GCS 235 struck the fendering system on the center span of the Conrail Bridge (Hack Freight), the second bridge of the "Triple Bridges" on the Hackensack River. The bridge was reported to be fully operational and the tug master notified both his company and the bridge tender.

On 13MAR09, MSD Panama City received a report that the Apalachicola River RR Bridge had been damaged by an allision involving a tug and barge.  At the time of the report, it was not known what vessel hit the bridge.  By utilizing GIS, we successfully tracked the location of the most recent transited vessel in the vicinity of the bridge, the M/V INLAND CARDINAL.  FL FWC personnel were first to respond and located the M/V INLAND CARDINAL.  The vessel captain said that the barge in tow did strike the bridge as it passed through.  After investigating, the vessel's captain on watch at the time of the incident, stated that there were two timbers sticking out from the bridge's cribbing approximately 4-5 ft into the south side passage.  As the barge in tow transited through, the starboard stern of the dredge barge in tow came in contact with the timbers, damaging the handrail on the dredge.  The captain was asked why he didn't report the incident, and he stated that he didn't think it was an incident serious enough to report.  He stated that he thought it was the bridge's fault for the allision due to the condition of the bridge, and that since it wasn't their fault, they didn't have to report it.  The captain was informed of the proper notification requirements during the interview.

M/V Tom Behringer allided with the right descending upper protection cell of the Burlington, Iowa railroad drawbridge.  The M/V Tom Behringer was transiting in the channel, down bound on the UMR at Mile Marker 403.1 IVO Burlington, IA when they allided with the protection cell.  The M/V Tom Behringer reports they were pushing 12 loads (9 corn, 2 soy bean, and 1 grain) and the impact to his tow occurred on the rake of the lead stbd barge.  The M/V Tom Behringer reports the rake end of the lead stbd barge is rolled up approximately 10 to 12 feet and the bow void is flooded to river level.  The M/V Tom Behringer reports they plan to back up river for 1 to 1.5 miles where they can safely pull into the bank and further assess the damage.

On 14 March 2009, at approximately 1430, the M/V NANIABA was southbound on the Tombigbee River near MM 173.  The M/V NANIABA was pushing 6 loaded open hopper barges configured 3-wide by 2-long.  As the M/V NANIABA approached the Naheola Bridge at MM173; the starboard barge, WGN 9615, allied with a pillar at the  Naheola Bridge.  There was no reported damage to the Naheola Bridge but WGN barge 9615 developed a small leak in the #4 tank.  The leak in the barge was controlled with the use of a pump.  The M/V NANIABA was able to continue its voyage with no other delay.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a radio call on VHF-FM CH. 22A from the M/V Prosperity reporting they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The M/V Prosperity reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the ILR at Mile Marker 56.0 IVO Florence, IL, and they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The M/V Prosperity reports they were pushing 15 loaded barges of grain and the impact to his tow occurred on the 3rd barge back from the head on the stbd string.  The M/V Prosperity reports no damage to the bridge however the barge that impacted the bridge has the # 2 and # 3 wing tanks flooded to river level, which is causing water to fill in to the #4 wing tank.   The M/V Prosperity reports they do have pumps on the #4 wingtank at this time

After CGC BAINBRIDGE ISLAND (BBI) terminated the uninspected fishing vessel VIGOROUS voyage due to numerous safety concerns, At 2015L, STA Jones Beach 25' rescue boat relieved  CGC BBI of the escort at East Rockaway Inlet and escorted the vessel into Hog Island Channel. At 2115L; while underway in Hog Island Channel, the VIGOROUS lost power. The vessel quickly anchored in the channel and began to trouble shoot the problem, which turned out to be a clogged fuel filter.  At 2135L, STA Jones Beach reported the VIGOROUS regained power and continued the voyage to homeport. Duration of power loss estimated to be 15 minutes.  At 2207, VIGOROUS moored safely at homeport in Hog Island Channel, Oceanside N.Y. SLIS CC notified MSD CORAM.

MSD Coram Duty IO conducted phone investigation with vessel. He instructed the captain of the vessel to fill out/ submit a CG 2692. CFV Examiner and MSD Duty IO visited the vessel the following day to conduct onsite investigation and conducted a commercial fishing vessel exam

On 20 March 2009, at approximately 0730, the UTV CHERYL STEGBAUER allided with the Popp's Ferry Bridge, the tow was pushing 8 rock barges.  One barge sank two spans and one column from the bridge collapsed.  There was 1 vehicle, belonging to the bridge tender, in the water and no persons entering the water.

On 16 MAR 09, at about 1530 while transiting northbound, the UTV ELIZABETH HUGER pushing the deck barge CBC 1253 allided the deck barge on its port stern with the Simmesport Railroad Bridge center span at MM 4.8 on the Atchafalaya River.  No damage, no injuries, or pollution.

On 19 March 2009, the UTV CRIMSON WHITE was southbound with 6 barges on the Tombigbee River when she allided with the Naheola Bridge at mile 173.5.  There was no damage to bridge or tow.  No further incidents.

At approx 0319L Sector Portland received a call from Tidewater Co. stating that the TUG DEFIANCE was pushing 3 barges ahead (2 empty grain and 1 barge loaded with empty containers). While attempting to pass under the Hood River Bridge empty wheat barge 79 allided with the north abutment of the Hood River Bridge at MM 169 resulting in minimal damage to both the bridge and the barge. The barge sustained an inset in the #1 port void tank of approximately 6 inches, spanning 12 feet fore and aft and extending from the chine up to the 12 foot draft mark on the barge.  After the incident The barges were tied up to an SDS Lumber Spud Barge in Bingen, WA awaiting CG investigator and replacement mate.

On 29 MAR 2009, the UTV ROBERT BURTON was towing the empty BARGE 18 and BARGE 19 astern on the York River in route to Norfolk.  Approximately 1700, the BARGE 19 allided with the West Point Spit Junction Daybeacon near West Point, VA.  *This allision was not initially reported to the Coast Guard and was only reported two days later*.  

Later that night, approx 1.5 hours after the midnight relief, the Mate noticed that the BARGE 19 had broken away from the tow. It was determined that the BARGE 19 broke away somewhere in the Chesapeake Bay near the Back River Channel.  The BARGE 19 was later spotted in the Chesapeake Bay just West of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel (CBBT).  The BARGE 19 subsequently drifted East and allided with the North and South spans of the CBBT and then grounded just East of the CBBT on Fishermen's Island.  The BARGE 19 was retrieved by the UTV ROBERT BURTON and towed to Norfolk Tug Co.  There was no damage to the BARGE 19 or the CBBT.  Drug and alcohol test were administered to all crew members.

On 27 March 2009, the UTV HELOISE was pushing 08 coal barges northbound on the Black Warrior River when it allided with the AGS railroad bridge at MM 268.  The starboard stern barge struck the eastern bridge pillar.  There was no damage reported to the bridge or barge.

Received notification that at 0500 on 1 April 2009, the UTV RICHARD GONSOULIN II (official #1194709) and the red-flag barge GONSOULIN 502 allided with the Charenton Canal (Baldwin) Railroad Bridge, mile marker 0.4, Charenton Canal.  Several timbers were broke on the fendering system, no damage to the barge reported -  bridge tender reports bridge operational.  Barge max capacity 30,000 bbls - Mate unsure of crude onboard currently.

Vsl and tow were outbound (southbound) out of canal, waiting on bridge traffic, when vsl got crosswise in holding...mate reports wx as southerly current, NW'ly winds, clear.  Vsl spun stern (wind/current while holding) and the stbd corner of barge (red flag loaded with crude product) hit fender wall system.

Master of vsl witnessed mate take alcohol test strip.  Mate said company folks would determine if drug screen would be conducted.

BOTH Master and Mate license checked clean/current in MISLE.  

MISC. Information -  
-No pollution, no injuries
-no additional bridge/barge damage reported
-UTV was stopped at bridge for 1.5 hrs, then proceeded Eastbound to make way to Bourg via ICW (Morgan City/Houma).

At approx 1310 the research vessel ALPHA HELIX allided with the  BNSF Railroad bridge near Ballard Locks. The impact of the vessel did considerable damage to the wooden fendering system around the bridge support structure with no visible damage to support structure .  BNSF bridge engineer/inspector was given detailed phone report of incident and made the decision to keep the bridge operational for RR traffic.  ALPHA HELIX has reinforced hull for ice operations and suffered only minor scraping to paint on vessel bow.  Vessel remained operational, but because vessel controls were suspect, Ballard Locks insisted the vessel be towed thru the Locks. 

Preliminary alcohol screening was conducted by USCG IO on crew of ALPHA HELIX with negative results.  Damage amount approached but did not meet SMI, as a precaution, Marine Employer had drug testing performed.

The M/V Anne B was transiting S/B on the Illinois River pushing a 13 barge tow when the F/B CGB 447B allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the UTV or bridge. F/B CGB 447B and F/B MM 9719B sustained damage. Barges were temporarily repaired and resumed transit.

The M/V Sheila Johnson was transiting S/B on the Illinois River at approximately 151.0 when the F/B SCNO-8135 allided with the Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge. No damage was sustained to the towboat or bridge.  The barge F/B SCNO-8135 sustained minor damage and was shingled and resumed transit.

UTV Jeff Montgomery pushing two empty red flag barges, strung out, was transiting through Bayou Blue swing bridge when winds of 20-25 mph gusted and pushed the stern of the last barge into the fendering system of bridge.  No damage, no injuries reported.

On 1 April 2009, at approximately 0835, the M/V THELMA PARKER II was transiting down the Mobile River pushing eight loaded open hopper coal barges configured 3-wide X 3-long.  The M/V THELMA PARKER II was center of the last row.
