WHILE U/B IVO MI 937.3 OHR WITH 02 EMPTY HOPPERS AND 01 FLAT DECK BARGES, MV JOANNE ALLIDED WITH THE RDB PIER ON THE IRVIN COBB BRIDGE.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a radio call on VHF-FM channel 16/22 from the M/V Prosperity (645129) reporting the vessel has allided with the Burlington RR Drawbridge at mile marker 403.1 on the Upper Mississippi River (Burlington Iowa). The vessel was transiting up bound pushing 14 barges (13 empty, 1 salt) en route Linwood Iowa when it struck the lower protection cell on the left descending side of the turn table. Damage reported includes the second barge back on the port string. The barge is the AT734B and is empty. Pilot reports minor damage to the port forward corner and a small amount of water is coming in. No pumps have been installed. No injuries have been reported with this incident.
The F/V LADY ANNA allided with the Oregon Inlet Bridge. No reported damage was done to the bridge. The vessel received minor damage to its rigging.

MV GLOBAL WISDOM allided with the Aberdeen Reach Bascule Bridge. The starboard ship's side made contact with the bridge. There was damage to the signal light that was attached to the top of the wood fenders of the bridge post. The only damage to the vessel was scratched paint

UTV MISS HEATHER allided with Port Isabel light 156 and destroyed it, causing minor damage to the barge.    Found moderate damage to KIRBY 27711.  Approximately 30 minutes afterwards, the MISS HEATHER and the barge it was pushing allided with the causeway bridge, causing substantial damage to the fendering system of the causeway.  No pollution or injuries associated with the incident.

The M/V David K Wilson called to advise that while headed d/b mile 184.9 Cumberland River they might have allided with the Bordeaux railroad bridge pushing 4 empty coal open hopper barges.  Strong winds pushed them off course and towards the bridge structure. The vessel moored at mile 184.7 Cumberland River and the crew inspected their tow and vessel and found no damage or pollution. CSX Bridge inspector conducted a survey and noted no structural damage to the bridge.  Although contact with the bridge was not confirmed, vessel submitted a CG 2692

On March 27, 2009, M/V ARCHIE WILSON was pushing two empty tank barges south bound making the approach to go under Florence Bridge at mile 56.0 ILR. During this maneuver the tank barge KIRBY 23850 allided with protection cell of the Florence Bridge on the North side left descending bank. This caused multiple 3 to 4 foot vertical hairline fractures and one 6 to 8 inch open crack on the portside of the KIRBY 23850. The damage was above the waterline, no injuries occurred during this marine casualty.  No damage was reported to the bridge or bridge protection cell.

On 28MAR09 the same captain of this incident allided the M/V ARCHIE WILSON's tow with the Melvin Price Lock and Dam on the Mississippi River. (MISLE Activity # 3452328)

The M/V WASHINGTON was southbound on the Illinois River pushing 13 barges (5 empty tank barges and 8 loaded dry cargo barges). While transiting through the Florence Highway Bridge at mile 56 ILR the dry cargo barge NBI 9607B's port side allided on the port side of the bridge's left protection cell.
MARY HARTER (642287)  allided with the third pier from the kY side on the Cario bridge mi 980.4 OHR.

Commercial Fishing Vessel DIVECOM was underway in Newport Harbor with the single crewmember setting lobster traps and the crewmember's dog onboard. The dog ran out on deck chasing a seagull and the crewmember was concerned the dog would become entangled in the lobster pot rigging and be dragged overboard. The crewmember then left the helm to retrieve the dog and as the vessel was still in engaged in forward motion, it allided with the Newport Bridge fender system. No pollution or injury reported.

Rcvd call that while traversing under the 2 mile landing bridge, the F/V Brenda K's port side chain bird on outrigger  hit a concrete block on the underside of the bridge.  The Bridge operator reports minimal/no damage to the bridge (scratch marks) and will have a bridge inspector conduct an inspection on Monday to determine the severity of the allision.  Master of BRENDA K reports only minimal damage to the chain on the outrigger which was verified by Sta Cape May.

20APR09:  Bridge Inspector completed inspection and verified no damage to the bridge.
01 0400Z Mar 09 - UTV Integrity involved in allision.
On 21 Apr 09 the M/V LOUISVILLE broke its' mast light and weather gauge on the Clarksville Bridge at MM 126.5 on the Cumberland River while transiting in High water conditions.

25 APR 2009 - While transiting under the highway 182 bridge, Capt of the Green Provider misjudged the clearance between the vsl and bridge.  Capt knew the clearance of the bridge was around 50'; Capt had no experience with this vsl or transiting under the 182 bridge.  Allision caused $2k worth of damage and bent the mast back to a 45 degree angle.  No pollution or injuries reported.  No damage reported to bridge.

On 26 Apr 09,  at approx 0750 the UTV Zephyr allided with the Melville Railroad, MM29 Atchafalaya River. The pilot of the UTV Zephyr misjudged the height of his vessel in relation to the bridge. The vessels searchlight and an antenna dome hit on the Bridges superstructure as they were passing underneath the bridge. The search light and dome were bent, no other damage to the vsl or bridge. No injuries or pollution were associated with this incident.

The vessel experienced a loss of propulsion while transiting inbound just past the jetties. A harbor tug and sea tractor are en route to assist the vessel to Bolivar anchorage.

2009-05-02 TST - Preliminary investigation via telephone with the Master.  The vessel conducted engine checks at 1247 prior to embarking a Pilot.  They were inbound just north of the jetties when they noticed a low coolant pressure.  The bridge received notification from the engine room and the pilot decided they should proceed to Alpha anchorage to investigate.  En route to oil tanking in Houston TX at 1430 the engine died.  They coasted to allow their speed to drop and then they dropped anchor.  They have a tug with them right now, they are engaging they aux propulsion, and they are still investigating the cause but they assume they have a leak.  They are filling out the 2692 and I am in direct contact with them via email.  I am waiting for their cargo information.  

2009-05-03-TST - Investigation revealed the vessel had a cracked cylinder.  Vessel will make repair and then be certified by class.

2009-05-06-TST - Classification society has attended vessel and verified repair.  Vessel is fully operational.  No Injuries or Pollution.

03MAY09 at 0715 the UTV SAM LITRICO was downbound on the Illinois River pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges. The tow was three barges wide by five barges long. While attempting to navigate through the Florence Highway Bridge the tow's stbd lead barge (UBL 2) allided with the bridge's downbound stbd bridge protection cell. The downbound stbd bridge protection cell was pushed into one of the bridge's main vertical concrete support members (stanchion). The bridge's protection cell is made of concrete and steel. The dry cargo barge (UBL 2) had major damage to the barge's bow rake. After the UBL 2 allided with the protection cell the UTV SAM LITRICO lost control of all barges. The UTV SAM LITRICO's face up wires broke and the center string of five barges and the port string of five barges broke away from the stbd string of five barges and the UTV SAM LITRICO. The port and center string of ten barges went through the open bridge span and never hit the bridge. After the allision the captain of the UTV SAM LITRICO began attempting to face up to the stbd string of five barges. While attempting this maneuver the UBL 2 went under the Florence Highway Bridge's stbd  bridge span and caused damage to some of the bridge's steel structural members.

At 1613 hrs the vessel Kestrel was out bound from Quincy.  The vessel made contact with the fendering system of the Weymouth Fore River Bridge.  
The harbor master attested to no damage to the bridge or its fendering system.
The I/O attended the vessel at Global Chelsea and attested to no damage to the vessel.  Vessel touched on the port quarter of the vessel. Only minor paint scrapes visible.

HOU2009/0136: UTV Filly was transiting the San Jacinto River in the vacinity of the San Jacinto River Bridge. The Captain noticed that the Kirby Barge  28049 was sitting high and the potential existed for the manual tester arm on the  barge pressure valve to come in contact with the bridge. The deckhand was instructed to manually push down the valve arm while going under the bridge, but the deckhand let go too soon and the top of the valve arm touched underneath the bridge bending it slightly, however there was no damage observed to the bridge. The valve arm was straightened. No further action taken.

On 5 May 2009, the UTV JUDSON B was south bound in the Mobile River pushing one empty red flag barge.  The UTV JUDSON B waited for the CSX 3 Mile Rail Road Bridge to open and on it's approached the vessel was off center causing the port bow of the barge to allide with the bridge.  There was minimal damage to the bridge (dent) and no damage to the barge.   The master also submitted to a post-casualty drug screen.  The UTV JUDSON B continued on its voyage without further incident

On 1 May 2009, at approximately 1010, the UTV CHERYL STEGBAUER was southbound on Biloxi Bay pushing 8 empty open hopper barges configured 3 wide X 3 long.  As the tow approached the Popps Ferry Bridge there was a gust of wind and the tow shifted alliding with the port side of the bridge fender system, no damage reported.  Then, at approximately 1100, the UTV CHERYL STEGBAUER allided with the I-110 Bridge fender system where again, there was no reported damage to the bridge or the vessel.  The UTV CHERYL STEGBAUER continued its voyage with no further incidents.

On May 5 2009 while transiting thru the Albany CSX Swing Bridge, a barge being towed by the UTV CATHERINE C. MILLER allided with the fendering on the bridge. The barge received no damage and some of the Bridge fendering was broken requiring repair. A structural engineer from CSX attended the bridge and determined that the bridge was sound for continued rail use but restricted marine use until company could verify that there was no horizontal bridge opening reductions.

Master of Duck Boat 46 reported being disabled just North of the Ben Franklin Bridge with passengers on board.  Cause found to be burned out fuse in primary fuel pump.  Pump failed causing engine to shut down.  Master eventually switched to auxiliary fuel pump and proceeded back to yard for full replacement of primary fuel pump.

Britney Lee, while d/b at mi 980.5, struck the left descending pier on the KY side of the Cairo Hwy Bridge.  Vessel advised he was backwards, facing the other direction and had 02 barges break free.  Advised that there were high winds at the time of the incident.

While D/B, the barge MEM 2023 allided with the LDB protection cell of the Pekin Lower Rail Road Bridge while under the control of UTV MARY SCHEEL. The allision cause 3 of the 9 barges to break free, due to the wires snapping. One of the barges in the group that broke free was the MEM 2023. All barges were recovered. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident.

18MAY09: Louisiana Dept of Trans rptd that UTV  MYRTLE E GRIFFIN's two barge tow had allided with the Harrisonburg Bridge fendering system on Friday afternoon.  Incident was not rptd by vsl. SECLMR COMMCEN reported to Investigating Officer Detached Duty Greenville that a Marine Casualty had occurred on Friday 15MAY09 which apparently wasn’t reported. Investigating Officer contacted Louisiana Bridge team and Port Captain of the UTV to determine the facts in the matter. Both parties are preparing statements to send to Detached Duty Greenville along with a CG-2692.

Responsible Party with the UTV CORPUS CHRISTI (IMO #1049181) called reporting that while in transit to Freeport thru Galveston Causeway Bridge they bumped the fender.  He informed that the Bridge tender called him via radio to inform him that he had damaged the fender.

On or about 1530 of 18 May 09, the UTV MARY KAY was pushed onto the Belle Chasse Rail Road Bridge in the Algiers Canal by high winds while pushing 4 empty dry cargo barges.  No injuries or pollution was caused by this incident.

On 19MAY09 at approximately 2300 an empty (new) gasoline barge (KIRBY 28100) was set adrift from Trinity Marine Products, Inc. on the Cumberland River mile marker 163.7.  The barge allided with one of the support columns for the Veterans Memorial Bridge (Montgomery Bell Highway Bridge) at 0130 before being retrieved by the M/V JAMES H HUNTER at 0145.

The barge was damaged but the support column for the bridge only had minor cosmetic damage.

Three barges (Crane barge LEHIGH) tied together, broke from their holding spuds, swung around and allided with the Tacony Palmyra Bridge, resting on the south side, Pennsylvania site. No damage reported to the barges or the bridge.
Miss Saidy was pushing a deck barge thru Dulac pontoon bridge and allided with the bridge. No damage to bridge or barge.

On 30MAY09 at 0345 the UTV WILLIAM G. PORTER was fleeting 5 loaded coal barges at US STEEL in Clairton, Pennsylvania at MM 19.5 on the Monongahela River, with the assistance of the UTV USS 3, when one of the barges, the OR 5507,  had an allision with the right descending pier of the Glassport Highway Bridge.  The cause of the allision was miscommunication between the two UTV operators.  There were no damages or injuries.

On 28 May 2009, the M/V MARGARET while heading outbound in the Back Bay of Biloxi, and pushing 04 empty deck barges and 01 crane barge, allided with the I-110 fixed bridge and ran aground.  The tug got off ground with no damage to the bridge or the tug and barges.  There was no further incident.

On 27 May 2009, the M/V GREEN WAVE allided with the 14 Mile CSX Railroad Bridge.  The current sent the tug into the bridge fendering system.  There was no damage to the bridge, tug, or barges.  There was no further incident.

On or about 0800 on 03 May 09, the M/V Sue Ellen was transiting west bound on the western canal of ICW in the vicinity of mile 35.5 when the M/V Sue Ellen allided with the fendering system of the West Larose Bridge.  No pollution or injuries occurred due to this incident.

Recieved a report from Danny Snider, captain onboard the M/V Elizabeth Ann, reporting that thier vessel was involved in an allision with the Belle Chase Hwy Draw Bridge. It was reported that while transiting underneath the bridge the tug hit the bridge. There was no damage to the bridge or the six loaded cement barges that the vessel was pushing. The only damage reported was that the mast was bent back, a radar was knocked down, and four antennas were also knocked down. The vessel is currently at Stone Fuel Dock, MM 7 GIWW, waiting a technician to come onboard the vessel. Notified DIO, DMI, DOT, and D8.

On 05 June 2009, the UTV JOHN O PEARLE allided with the Burlington R/R bridge, MM 403 UMR.  As a result of the allision 3 of the 5 total barges in the flotilla broke away from the tow.  The adrift barges were recovered by the UTV's "JANE" and "BURLINGTON".  Barges ING7630 (soybean) sustained damage to bow rake. Barge ING7910 (gypsum) sustained damage to side shell at #2 and #3 void approx 5 feet below water line.  The Burlington R/R Bridge sustained visible damage to the timber structure and lower turntable protection cell.

Since the occurrence of this casualty the Burlington R/R Bridge has been demolished and construction of a new bridge has begun.  Demolition is part of the Truman Hobbs Bridge Alteration project where bridges were identified as either difficult to transit, a hazard to navigation or a beyond serviceable life.

While shifting berths from Radio Island Terminal to NC State Port, vsl lost propulsion power and allided with railroad bridge that spans the Newport River. A 20-30 foot section of bridge trestle which supports the railroad track was knocked down and fell into the water. Damage to vessel consisted of numerous insets in the side and bottom plating port and stbd at the stern.  No through hull punctures were found and no visible damage to upper rudder/post or propeller was noted.  No injuries or pollution occurred.

On June 6, 2009, the Bahamian flag freight vessel M/V ICE PEARL allided with the Gilmerton Bridge, Chesapeake, VA, when leaving the Chesapeake Energy Terminal. Three Moran tug boats, the UTV APRIL MORAN, UTV SURRY MORAN and UTV TOWN POINT, assisted the vessel through the outbound transit, and when passing through the Gilmerton Bridge, the M/V ICE PEARL hit part of the fender system causing a pile on the western side of the bridge to split.  The vessel was aligned slightly to starboard and the pilot ordered the vessel to port for better alignment for the transit.  The port side of the vessel hit the fender before the vessel's swing had completely stopped.  No damage was reported to the vessel, and the allision caused minor damage to the fender and is not a hazard to navigation.  All involved parties were instructed to conduct alcohol testing, and all tests were done for alcohol.

A damage estimate for the Gilmerton Bridge has not yet been provided to the Coast Guard, since the split piling has not yet been inspected by the City of Chesapeake.  The damage appeared to be minimal but no monetary estimate was given.

Received Report from the Spuyten Duyvil Bridge operator that the M/V VIRGINIA WEEKS while transiting from the Hudson River to the Harlem River pushing a deck barge allied with the finder system of the Spuyten Duyvil Bridge.  Investigation revealed minimal damage to the fender of the rail road bridge and no damage to the vessels.

The M/V ERNA HONEYCUTT (barge ING 1978), while D/B, allided (rubbed) the RDB fending system of the Chicago and Northwestern (a.k.a. Pekin R/R bridge), at MM 151.2 ILR, while pushing 9 loaded dry cargo barges and 3 empty red flag chemical barges.  There was no damage to the tow, barge or bridge. No helper boat was used. This bridge has been deemed obstructive under the Truman-Hobbs Act.

Vessel manager called and reported that the M/V Pride of Susquehanna had allided with the 8th span of the Market St. Bridge. The vessel was making 3-4 kts and was heading through the bridge when a gust of wind caught the vessel turning it sideways to the bridge.  Master attempted to correct vessel's position and angle of approach, but the vessel's starboard bow struck the bridge's concrete pillar.  The master was able to re gain control of the vessel and headed back to the dock.  Damage was confined to the stbd bow area, no damage to the hull and no flooding.  10  passengers were injured, 06 were treated by EMS for bumps and bruises, 04 were treated beyond first aid at local hospital as a result of the allision.  All were treated and released.  Master went to hospital to complete Drug and Alcohol tests.

See IIA 3505619 for further details on damage survey, on scene inspection confirmed damage was limited to the stbd bow approximate 4' deck extension that had been installed approximately 1.5 years earlier. Inspected port & Stbd forepeak compartments in the original hull, all sat. noted that the seam where the new bulwark, for the new deck, was welded to the original bulwark on the stbd side was cracked. And the stbd bow corner of the bow rail (approx. 4" x 4" sq tube) was cracked (open) in two places. Also, two of three of the hinges for the stbd gate in the bow rail were broken.  All repairs to be completed to satisfaction of MI.

On 09 June 2009, the UTV JACKSON III was southbound on the Tombigbee River pushing 5 empty barges and one barge containing ductwork.  The tow began to slide near the Naheola Railroad Bridge when the starboard lead barge (empty IB 976) made contact with an unfendered piling on the Naheola Railroad Bridge.  There was no damage to the barge, piling, or towboat.  No other incident occurred.

The UTV POSEIDON was transiting up bound through the Bayou Sorrel Bridge with 3 loaded barges in tow when the cable for the bridge got caught on the middle barge in the tow, the USL 136. The cable ripped the pad eye out of the bridge and caused the bridge to swing out into the channel making contact with the USL 136. No damage was found on the barge, but there was a hole left in the bridge barge above the waterline where the pad eye was located and the arm of the bridge was left bent. No pollution or injuries resulted.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Jane G. Huffman reporting they conducted a controlled landing (allision) on the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge at mile 403.1. The vessel contacted Sector after the incident. The vessel is pushing 15 barges (14 dry cargo, 1 empty, no red flags) en route St. Louis Missouri. No injuries or damage reported the vessel or bridge. Pilot reports that the M/V Bette Lynn assisted with the controlled landing to help the vessel pivot. Pilot stated the reason for the controlled landing was simply being careful to avoid the damaged protection cell at the Burlington Railroad Bridge.

Contacted the Burlington Railroad Bridge operator who confirms there was no damage to the bridge.

MSD Quad Cities conducted preliminary investigation. Vessel was informed to submit a CG-2692.

All notifications conducted in accordance with the Sector UMR Response Matrix.

On 24 May 2009, the UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY, lost steering while up bound on the LMR in the vicinity of MM 133.  The vessel's tow which included the BIRBY 28047 and KIRBY 26400 turned and stuck the INO95011, T13878B, and T13915B barges in the CGB Laplace Fleet.  The barge had minor damage.  It was found that a log was stuck in the steering rudder causing a loss of steering.  No pollution, injury, or additional damage was found from this incident.
TUG LUKE BRYAN W/ 3 EMPTIES MADE CONTACT WITH GAL CUASEWAY BRIDGE CRACKED TOP TIMBER. NO POLLUTION RPTED NTFD MSU GAL IO AND DOM.

On July 1, 2009 the M/V Jill P. Harvey w/ 3 empty tank barges rubbed the left descending protection cell of the Florence Highway bridge at mile marker 56.0 on the Illinois River. No damage was reported to the bridge.  T/B FMT 3104 sustained a small dent in the port bow side shell near the 10.5' draft mark.

No breach of hull or pollution noted.
The F/V Lucky Star struck the 2 Mile Landing Bridge while inbound damaging a fixed navigation light.

At approximately 1700 local time on June 26, 2009 the T/V KRITI JADE struck the Union Pacific Railroad Bridge (UPRR) and, possibly, the Benicia-Martinez highway bridge. The mast of the KRITI JADE was laid back approximately 30 degrees and the inmarsat antenna was knocked off.  Despite the allision, all navigational  equipment appeared to be working satisfactory.

All bridge crew members of the KRITI JADE were alcohol tested via breathalyzer by the Coast Guard Station San Francisco Boarding Team.  In addition, all crew members on watch on the bridge were drug tested, including the San Francisco (SF) Bar Pilot and his Apprentice.

The Investigating Officer (IO) was unable to obtain any Voyage Data Recorder (VDR) data due to the fact that the VDR had been inoperable prior to the KRITI JADE's initial entry into the port of San Francisco.  While the KRITI JADE remained in port following the allision, a radio technician was onboard was able to fix the VDR.  

Preliminary investigation shows that the vessel measurements from the shipbuilder may be incorrect.  It appears that the KRITI JADE's Chief  Officer, 2nd Officer, the SF Pilot and SF Pilot Apprentice all did separate calculations and came up with the same numbers.  According to the Pilot Card onboard, there should have been approximately a 2-5 foot air gap/clearance under the two bridges.  

Subsequent investigation revealed that the KRITI JADE and its sister-ship had modifications done to the mast during the build in the shipyard and the yard neglected to re-measure the overall height from keel to the top of the mast.  This measurement has been corrected on both vessels.  Based upon the revised measurements, it is clear that there would be inadequate clearance under the bridges for the KRITI JADE to safely pass.  There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this casualty.

M/V BAILEY ANN w/ barge SALVAGE RANGER were transiting from the ICW to Lake Ponchartrain via the Industrial Canal, vessel was traveling northbound and was attempting to cross under the L&N R/R bridge when the current and wind pushed the vessel toward the west side of the canal. The Mate (Pilot) saw the A-frame crane was going to strike the R/R bridge while it was in the up position, so he split the throttles (PORT FWD,  STBD AFT) in and attempt to pull the bow away from the bridge. The barge made contact with the Bridge Tenders building, and the current pinned the vessel to the west bank of the canal while being laid up against the building. The building sustained damage and the bridge tender sustain a sprained knee while attempting to escape the building. Chemical testing was administered to the Relief Captain (Mate Pilot) on watch, the Master who was on the bridge and the deckhand that was on bow lookout.

The UTV Bridget Cauley was up bound around 81 mile point. The Operator was manuevering inside of the buoy on its port side and grounded the barge Kirby 10002. No pollution, damage, or hazard to navigation.

At 0817 local time on July 8, 2009, Coast Guard San Francisco Vessel Traffic Service (VTS) informed the Investigations Office (IO) that the Tug M/V SAN JOAQUIN RIVER (VIN 295630) pushing BARGE TS-G230 (VIN 674881) from Oakland Berth 99, bound for Richmond Berth 4, allided w/the Fruitvale Bridge fendering system.  The operator of the M/V SAN JOAQUIN RIVER informed VTS that the Barge rubbed against the bridge piling, however, there was no visible damage to either the bridge or the Tug.  The Duty Investigating Officer (DIO) responded on-scene shortly after the incident to perform on-scene investigation.  There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this allision.

On 04JUL09 at approximately 0330 local time, a recreational vessel with 2 POB allided with an unlit barge, which was spudded down and protruding from the east bank of the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway underneath the Fantasy Harbor Bridge in Myrtle Beach, SC.  2 persons transported to hospital by Horry County EMS.  SC Department of Natural Resources conducting marine casualty investigation.  No pollution reported

On 27 June 2009 at approximately 2345 hrs the UTV LARRY TILLEY (ON 511120) pushing 8 empties headed through CSX Railroad Bridge in Biloxi/Ocean Springs alliding with the fendering system.  No damage reported to the vessel or the bridge.  No further incidents.

UTV LAURIE S. JOHNSTON TRANSITING SOUTHBOUND WITH 12 LOADS DRY CARGO THROUGH SABULA RR BRIDGE, PORT LEAD BARGE  (BUNGE 569) ALLIDED WITH BRIDGE. BARGE SUSTAINED DAMGE TO KEVEL, WATERTIGHT INTEGRITY NOT COMPRIMISED. MSD QC ENROUTE TO MEET VESSEL AT LOCK 13.

On 10 June 2009 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Charlie G reporting the vessel allided with the Burlington Railroad Bridge right descending protection cell at Mile 403.1 on the Upper Mississippi River. The Vessel is pushing 15 barges down-bound for St. Louis. Reports the barges just rubbed the bridge and there was no damage to the barges or to the bridge protection cell. 

Contacted Burlington RR Bridge - Bridge Operator confirms no damage.

On 6 JUL 09 at 0610, the excavator barge KS 4003 broke free from its mooring. Wave action caused the rope that was used to secure the barge to chafe on a sharp edge of the fair-leads plating of the barge. The barge drifted to rest against a trestle of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. The barge was towed to Little Creek Harbor where chocks were installed to prevent recurrence of this type of casualty.

COAST GUARD SECTOR UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER RECEIVED A RADIO CALL ON VHF-FM CH 16 MHZ FROM THE M/V DAVID L. FIELDS REPORTING AN ALLISION WITH THE DUBUQUE R/R BRIDGE AT MM 579.3 UMR.  THE M/V BRUSHED UP ALONG THE LDB PROTECTION CELL DUE TO 30 MPH CROSS WINDS. M/V IS PUSHING 15 BARGES OF DRY CARGO, NO DAMAGE TO TOW, BARGES, OR BRIDGE.  M/V DESTINATION IS ST. PAUL, MN.

On 26 May 2009 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V W. W. Crum reporting they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The M/V W. W. Crum reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the ILR at Miler Marker 56.0 IVO Florence, IL, and they allided with the Florence Highway bridge.  The M/V W. W. Crum reports they were pushing 3 empty red flag barges (previously contained asphalt) and the impact to his tow occurred on the stbd lead barge.  The Florence bridge tender reports further damage has been done to the cat walk on the bridge.  Sector Upper Mississippi River BNM # 0209-09 is current and was issued as a result of a previous allision that caused moderate damage to the bridge and protection cell.

On 3 July 2009 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the Florence Highway Bridge Operator reporting the M/V Warren W. Hines struck the damaged protection cell on the right descending side of the navigation span. The protection cell is now submerged. The vessel was pushing 12 barges downbound at the time of the incident. Bridge Operator has notified ILDOT supervisors of this incident. No barges broke free and the bridge operator was not injured during this incident. No details
ALLISION WITH STBD CELL OF FLORENCE BRIDGE

On July 11, 2009, Sector UMR Command Center received call via VHF-FM Ch 16 from the M/V RICHARD A. BAKER reporting an allision with the Poplar St. Bridge at MM 179.2, UMR in St Louis resulting in a barge breakaway. The RICHARD A. BAKER was downbound enroute MM 177 pushing 10 loaded coal barges in a 2 X 5 configuration at the time of the incident. The RICHARD A. BAKER was conducting fleeting operations between MM 184 and 177 when the allision occurred. At the time of initial report, all ten barges had broken away from the towing vessel and several tow boats within the St. Louis harbor assisted in recovery of all barges.  Barge ACL 1881 was retrieved and pushed into bank by fleet boat, but later sank.  Barge ACL 1881 was salvaged.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Bill Berry reporting they allided with the right descending protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge at MM 403.1 Upper Mississippi River.  M/V Bill Berry reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the UMR at mile marker 403.1 IVO Burlingtion, IA, and they allided with the protection cell on the bridge.  The M/V Bill Berry report they were pushing 15 loads of dry cargo and the impact to his tow occurred on the stbd lead barge (ING 5888).  M/V Bill Berry reports neither the barges or bridge appear to have damage at this time.  M/V Bill Berry reports the bridge inspector was on scene at the time of the incident and is stating they are calling it a routine bridge rub with how soft the barge hit.  M/V Bill Berry reports the reason for the allision is miscommunication between the vessel Captain and the assist vessel.

1708Z:  Notified MSD Quad Cities (MST2 Garcia)

1712Z:  Notified St. Louis command duty officer (OSC Dorsey)

1714Z:  Notified District 8 Bridge Branch (Mr. Wiebusch)

1728Z:  MSD Quad Cities (LT Martin) reports he conducted an over the phone preliminary investigation with  the vessel captain and does not plan to go out and inspect the vessel.

1730Z:  Notified St. Louis Chief of Preventions (LCDR Allen).

Vessel was transiting ICW with barge in tow (aft) when barge swung to starboard and struck a vessel, dock, and moorings.  Vessel then continued to transit under the Oak Island, NC bridge and scraped the bridge protective pilings.  Vessel then was contacted by owner of dock via radio and notified of damage.  Dock owner contacted CG STA Oak Island and a boarding team dispatched.  MSU personnel boarded vessel conducted interview of vessel personnel.  Dock owner was then contacted and an interview conducted.  No pollution, no injuries, no hazard to navigation, no damage to bridge fendering system. NCDOT contacted and conducted inspection of bridge; no damage noted.

Lake Michigan SCC received notification from Station Manistee of an allision of the M/V MANISTEE(243406) and the US 31 bridge on the Manistee River.
 Vessel was held just outside the St Joseph River entrance channel to await investigators.  

Investigator arrived onscene assessed bridge damage.  There was slight damage a walkway connect underneath the bridge.  Investigators got underway with STA Manistee personnel to Board the M/V Manistee and interview crew member.  Please see Investigator statement evidence number 3540353.09JLB.

On July 22, 2009, at approximately 0215 local time, the UTV ISLAND BREEZE allided with the bottom of the Ballard Bridge, which is a double leaf Bascule bridge, while transiting from Kenmore to DuPont, Washington.  The vessel's air draft exceeded the height of the bottom of the bridge which resulted in the vessel's mast impacting the bridge.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V JACOB MICHAEL ECKSTEIN reporting that she allided with the Sebula Railroad Bridge, MM 535.0 UMR on its right decending protection cell.  The M/V was pushing 8 loaded corn barges.  There was no damage reported to either the tow or the protection cell.

NJ Transit reported the Tug PEGASUS with light scow, had allided with the fendering system on the Raritan River Draw, breaking several of the timbers.  Tug stated they had been affected by current and leaned on the fendering, causing some timbers to crack.  No damage to tug or light scow.  Bridge is not affected, still in service.  

Investigation revealed there was no damage to the vessel or the bridge. The fendering timbers had some scratches. The vessel was caught in the current and drifted into the fendering system of the bridge causing the allision. This incident meets the data collection IAW MSM Vol 5.

The Bayonne Bridge Port Authority reported that the M/V APL JAPAN starboard side stores crane allided with the Bayonne Bridge while transiting the Kill Van Kull. Investigation revealed a crewmember was staging to bring on stores from a barge. The crewmembers had boomed up the crane prior to the vessel transiting under the Bayonne Bridge and the top of the crane scraped the bridge while transiting under it. There was no damage reported to the bridge and paint scrapes on the crane. This incident is at the data collection level due to the amount of damage.

Captain of the tug JACKIE B (ON 1034180) reported that the starboard stern section of the barge MAXIMUS (ON 1211701) attached to the port hip of the tug grazed the fenders of the MLK Bridge. The barge is a deck barge that is loaded with machinery equipment. Captain reported no damage to the barge or the fendering system.  MSU Port Arthur Boat Forces took pictures of impacted fenders and confirmed no damage to fendering system from allision.   Vessel was enroute to the Port of Port Arthur from Mexico.  A Sabine Pilot was onboard the JACKIE B and the assist tug SAMSON was at the starboard bow of the tug.

The M/V BAILEY ANN with the SALVAGE RANGE in tow, was transiting north bound on the Industrial Canal enroute to Lake Pontchartrain. After having an allision with the L&N bridge earlier in the day, the Master decided to attempt maneuvering the vessel in reverse under the bridge with an assist tug steadying the bow of the barge. As the vessel passed under the bridge, the current & wind pushed the vessel into the fenders on the starboard side (west side of channel). the vessel bounced off of the fenders and drifted across the channel into the fenders on the port side (east side of the channel) causing damage to the fenders.

M/V Walter Hagestad hit the bridge with it's forward port lead barge destroying 4 navigation lights on the bridge.  Beardstown RR Bridge was in the down position for maintenance and master miscalculated barge freeboard.  CBC 44 allided with bridge causing damage to vapor piping.  No injuries reported

The Tug BUCHANAN 12 reports the port and starboard search lights struck the span as the tug was passing southbound under the Northern Blvd Bridge (east bound traffic lane) at Mile 0.4 on Flushing Creek.  As a result, both the search lights and the TV antenna broke off and landed on the deck of the tug.  Follow-up investigation with the Mate indicated that the damage was not in excess of $25,000.  Therefore, this case will remain at the Data Collection level.

The M/V DELTA RAM was pushing the SCF-706 while transiting westbound under the Rigolets R/R Bridge and the SCF-706 allided with the fendering system of the bridge. Bridge tender reported a couple of boards broken, some metal uprights bent and the Red light broke on the east side of bridge. No pollution, injuries or damages (to vessels) sustained.

Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center received call over VHF-FM Ch 16 from the M/V L.J. Sullivan reporting an allision with the Illinois Central Railroad Drawbridge at MM 579.9, UMR near Dubuque, IA. The L.J. Sullivan was upbound pushing 16 empty dry cargo barges enroute St. Paul, MN at the time of incident. The starbord lead barge made contact with the left decending protection cell of the bridge. No damage to the tow has been reported. The captain of the tow reported that there was no damage to the bridge. The bridge tender called the CC after the incident and confirmed that there was no damage. The Sector OUW notified the Quad Cities duty I/O who stated that he would conduct a follow-up investigation during office hours and not perform an on scene response. OUW notifed C-PREV who concured with the I/O's decision. OUW also contacted D8 Bridge Branch. No further CC action was required beyond initial notifications.

The M/V Mary Elizabeth allided with the Lower Pekin R/R D/B at MM 151.2, ILR. The Mary Elizabeth was down bound pushing 4 empty liquid fertilizer (non-inspected) barges enroute Donaldsonville, LA at the time of incident. Master stated that he misjudged his approach to the bridge and the port corner barge (Hines 414) in a 2X2 configuration landed on the bridge protection cell. There was no damage reported to the tow or the bridge. This was a phone investigation only.

ON AUG 06, 2009 Sector UMR CC received call on VHF-FM CH 16 from the M/V Richard D. Waugh reporting an allision with the upstream right decending protection cell of the Clinton R/R D/B at MM 518, UMR. The M/V RICHARD WAUGH was downbound pushing 12 loaded dry cargo barges (soybean, corn, scrap) enroute St. Louis at the time of the incident. M/V RICHARD WAUGH stated that he very lightly rubbed the cell with the last barge in the starboard string of the tow. M/V RICHARD WAUGH stated that he slightly misjudged his approach to the bridge which caused the allision. There was no damage reported to the bridge or the tow. The M/V RICHARD WAUGH confirmed with the bridge tender that there was no damage to the bridge. The Sector OUW notified the MSD Quad Cities I/O who stated that he would make arrangements to board the tow and conduct a follow up investigation on AUG 7th. The OUW notified the C-PREV who aggreed with the I/O. The Sector CUW confirmed with the bridge tender that there was no damage and notified the D8 Bridge Branch Chief via e-mail message.
MSD QC IO boarded vessel at Lock 16.  2" hairline crack in rake end of barge.  Crew shingled, vessel cleared to transit.

Barge TLB 14 allided with the Pekin Lower Rail Road Bridge upper LDB sheer fence while under the control of UTV MARTHA MAC at MM 151.2 of the Illinois River. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident.

Sector Upper Mississippi River (UMR) received a telephone call from  M/V Sierra Dawn reporting that the M/V Sierra Dawn allided with the protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge located at UMR MM 403.1. Pilot reports the vessel is pushing 12 loaded dry cargo barges heading downbound towards St. Louis. Pilot reports no damage to the barge that allided with the protection cell (AB 240), or the protection cell itself

On 13Aug09, SCC Hampton Roads, VA RCVD a report from the Gilmerton Bridge tender that while maneuvering the coal ship ENERGY ENTERPRISE, the tug STEVEN MCALLISTER allided with the North West side fender system of the Gilmerton bridge. The allision destroyed the west side fendering system causing the waterway to become impassible to large commercial traffic.

On August 17, 2009, at approximately 0700 local time, the tug PACIFIC TITAN and the tug WESTRAC were moving the inspected freight barge SOUTHEAST PROVIDER on the hip when the barge allided with the Duwamish River Rail Bridge causing minor damage to the west fender system.

On 08/04/09 the ELIZABETH ANN was towing the Scow 6002 downriver on the York River heading for dump site to discharge cargo.  At 1927LT, the current pushed the 6002 to the starboard side of the channel and it allided with the Coleman Bridge.  The master made appropriate calls to the bridge operator and confirmed that no damage had been done to the bridge or barge.

ON 01AUG09 the UTV  Robert Shelton w/three empty red flag barges were westbound at the MM 238 on the GICW when the stern barge H409 allided with the Black Bayou pontoon bridge with the stern barge. No injuries, pollution or damage resulted. For further details please see IO Statement in correspondence.

Received call from F/V JASON & DANIELLE on Channel 16 VHF-FM reporting they were outbound Cape May Harbor and had lost their transmission.  Due to loss of ability to maneuver forward or reverse, the vessel's starboard side drifted into wood pilings on outbound side of the 2 mile landing bridge causing cosmetic paint scrapes to starboard side above waterline and slight inset to rub rail.   Bridge tender reported no damage to bridge structure or pilings.  Vessel was able to diagnose and fix problem by tightening loose transmission oil line and adding lost fluid to system. 

Vessel proceeded safely back to Lund's for further inspection by MI/IO.  Repair technician later checked system and found it in satisfactory condition.

UTV MARGUERITE L TERRAL rptd allision with Natchez Hwy Bridge center span. Tow consisted of 12 rock barges with one contacting the bridge in a glancing blow. Rptd 12-15 feet long inset in STBD Lead barge, inset is in the deck knuckle approx 2 iches deep. No damage reported by state bridge inspector.

On 24 April 2009 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Jonathan Erickson reporting they allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge.  The M/v Jonathan Erickson reports they were transiting in the channel up bound on the UMR at Miler Marker 403.1 IVO Burlington, IA, and they allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge turn table.  The M/V Jonathan Erickson reports they were pushing 15 empty barges and the impact to his tow occurred on the 3rd barge back in the stbd string (standard 3 wide by 5 long configuration).  The M/V Jonathan Erickson and the bridge tender both report no damage to the barge or bridge.

0530:  SOHV CC received notification from operator of the UTV MARY L (565425)  that while upbound on the Cumberland River w/ 12 loaded hopper barges: 01 pea gravel, 10 coal, amd 01 cover top cement, they allided w/ the Veterans Memorial Highway Bridge near MI 158. The right descending pier was struck. There was a reported scuff mark on the bridge that a TDOT bridge inspector later verified as cosmetic damage.  The bow of the pea gravel barge was damaged and taking on water.  The towboat pushed in along the right descending bank just oustide the channel at mil 157.8 to keep the barge from sinking. The tow remained in tact after the allision.  TDOT reopened the bridge for vehicular traffic at approx. 0715.

No reported injuries or pollution.

Bridge Operator for the Spuyten Duyval Bridge reports that a tug pushing a barge allided with the bridge's southern fender.   Investigation revealed damage to the fenders of the bridge estimated at about $20,000. This will leave the incident at the data collection level per MSM vol 5.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Phillip M. Pfeffer reporting the vessel allided with the right descending protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Bridge at mile marker 403.1 on the Upper Mississippi River. The vessel is pushing 15 barges (14 grain, 1 scrap) downbound en route St. Louis Missiouri. No damage or inuries were reported. Pilot stated he had poor alignment and a poor approach to the bridge causing this incident. Pilot state he has contacted the bridge and there is no damage to the protection cell.

On 2 January 2009,  the M/V Frank T. Stegbauer allided with the Florence Highway Drawbridge.  The barge STC 3207 made contact as the tow transited the draw of the bridge.  The barge and bridge were undamaged.

THE M/V BILL CARNEAL ALLIDED WITH THE BURLINGTON RAILROAD DRAWBRIDGE AT MM 403.1 ON THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER. THE CAPTAIN REPORTS HIS SECOND BARGE ON THE PORT STRING HIT THE PROTECTION CELL LIGHTLY. NO DAMAGE WAS REPORTED TO THE BARGES OR THE BRIDGE. THE VESSEL IS PUSHING 13 EMPTY BARGES ALL PREVIOUSLY FILLED WITH GRAIN.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Sir Randy J pushing 3 empty concrete barges downbound reporting they allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge.  No damage to bridge, one barge broke away and recovered by UTV Burlington.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the UTV Wayne P. Lagrange reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the UMR at Mile Marker 518.0 IVO Clinton, IA, and they allided with the protection cell of the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V City of Louisville reporting they had a "controled landing" with the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge rdb sheer fence.  The M/V City of Louisville reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the UMR at Mile Marker 481.4 IVO Bettendorf, IA, and they allided with the rdb sheer fence of the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge. No damage.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge stating that the M/V Laurie S. Eckstein hit the protection bullnose on the right descending side. The bridge tender reported the vessel did not call the bridge prior to transiting through. The bridge tender was not sure if the bridge was damaged, but reported that an inspector will inspect the bridge in the morning. The bridge tender also reported the port lead barge on the vessel had been banged up.

The M/V ELIZABETH DEWEY was pushing 25 loaded coal barges and  reported that his port stern barge allided with the Cairo Hwy Bridge (LLNR 17665) MI 1.3 UMR while downbound at 2330.  The barge received a 5" crack above the water line.

At 0734 local time, on September 10, 2009, the engine on the M/V WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE, while docking at the Oakland Terminal, failed to respond to a "dead slow" bell command ordered by the Pilot.  Seven minutes later, the vessel responded normally to the command.  Tugs were on-scene when the incident occurred and assisted the WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE into Oakland Berth 25.  After safely mooring the vessel, the engineering department found a loose air connection on the Main Diesel Engine (MDE).  The bolt was re-tightened, and tests conducted.  All tests were satisfactorily completed.  There was no pollution or injuries reported as a result of this incident.

Tug RE Pierson IV was pushing a 40' wide construction barge (no name) through the 50' opening of the Route 52 bridge in Ocean City, NJ, when the current took the barge and it allided with the wooden fendering system on the bridge. The bridge tender reported some minor damage (splintering) to the bridge's wood fendering system, but bridge was fully operational.   No damage reported to the Tug or barge.

Bridge inspected by bridge commision, no further action required, bridge fully operational.

On 17 SEP 09 at approximately 2049, while transiting down bound through the Melville Railroad Bridge, the UTV LOUIE C. with two deck barges in tow, allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge. No damage was caused to the bridge or tow. No injuries or pollution resulted.

The master of the vessel was found to be operating under an expired license. His license expired 12 AUG 09.

On 17 SEP 09 at approximately 2320, while transiting down bound on the Atchafalaya River at MM 41, the UTV LOUIE C. with two deck barges in tow, allided with the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge. No damage was caused to the bridge or tow. No injuries or pollution resulted.
The M/V Eran E. Honeycutt w/ tow allided with the Pekin Railroad bridge causing damage to the bridge breaking the light on protection cell.  In damage to the vessel or injuries were reported.

UTV SARAH HUNTER was towing 15 empty coat barges in a 3 x 5 configuration, heading northbound on the Mississippi River.  During the transit, the tow struck the La Crosse Rail Road Bridge.  The 2nd barge on the port side (CBX2068) brushed up against the protection cell timbers on the left descending center span. The pilot had a south west wind at 9 knots and was trying to compensate for the weather, but over compensated for the wind.  Both engines were engaged at the time and the tow was proceeding at 1 mph.  Two mates were stationed on the most forward barge of the tow to provide a lookout.  The pilot has gone through this area approx 10-12 times before.  No damage was done to the barge.  Bridge reported one of the timbers 12 x 6 splintered on one end.

The up bound UTV Sylvia M. Leboeuf pushing 5 barges was transitting through the Mellville RR Bridge when the stern starboard barge (PB 8707) allided on its starboard bow corner with the concrete bridge dolphin.  There was damage to the PB 8707 port timberhead.  No pollution, no damage to the bridge, or hazard to navigation.
On 13 January 2009 at approximately 1700, the UTVs SAM-T and MR. JUNIUS allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge.  No injuries, pollution, or additional damage resulted from this incident.

Bridge tender for the 9th Street Bridge in Great Egg Inlet N.J. called to inform us that the tugs RE PIERSON #1 and RE PIERSON #2 were escorting a construction barge through the bridge opening when the barge allided with the wooden fendering system.  Tender reports no apparent damage to the bridge and that it is fully operational.  Master of the RE PIERSON #2 reports no damage to either tug or to the barge.

Lake Michigan SCC received notification from the M/V PAT WHITE reporting an allision with the Cass Street Bridge, Joliet, IL, Des Plaines River MM 288.1. The Captain stated the while pushing 06 empties and one barge loaded with alcohol allided with the bridge and incurred no damage to barges . The captain contacted the bridge operator and bridge engineers will be inspecting the bridge.  The landing was intentional due to change in set and operator attempting to better control tow while transiting restrictive channel.  MK1 responded and confirmed report.  No further actions anticipated.

Rresponsible Party with Brazoria County Marine Division was conducting a marine patrol when he witnessed the F/V RAINDEAR (uninspected) passing underneath the FM 1495 bridge on the old Brazos River.  The vessel's outriggers allided with the underside of the bridge, snapping the port outrigger and damaging a light on the bridge.  TEXDOT bridge inspectors determined there was no structural damage to the bridge.  The pilot of the F/V, an unlicensed mariner, was arrested by the Brazoria Marine Patrol for having an outstanding warrant.  All crewmembers aboard the vessel were unlicensed mariners. One crewmember suffered a cut index finger on his left caused by port outrigger's wire stay line.
05 Oct 09 UTV Show Me State and starboard lead barge (CC-95548) collided with small work flat above pier outside the span of the Burlington Northern Railway Bridge. No damages to any property.
Worker inserted middle finger into the mounting holes of a trailer stand. The stand moved, shearing the tip of his finger.

An uninspected towing vessel sank under the Cortez Bridge, spilling approximately 5 gallons of diesel fuel into the waters of the Gulf Intracoastal waterway.  It created a sheen upon a navigable waterway of the United States.

An allision occurred between the [uninspected] Tug CAPTAIN D (VIN 554079) and the Witt Penn Bridge over the Hackensack River (MM 3.1).  The bridge tender reported that the impact "rocked" the bridge and that a dolphin was pushed into a fender causing minimal, non-structural damage.  After the investigation was conducted there was no damage to the bridge. The allison involved a dolphin near the fendering system of the bridge with minimum damage reported. This incident will stay at the data collection level due to the amount of damage that was caused by the allision

On 19OCT09 at approximately 1300 the deck barge L 1031's spud tower struck the Ellender Bridge. At the time of the incident the L 1031 was the port aft barge of a 4 deck barge configuration being pushed by the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) BIG JOE. The bridge suffered minimum damage and remains still operational. The vertical clearance of the bridge was approximately 51 feet at the time of the incident. The barge including the spud tower suffered no damage, furthermore no pollution or injuries resulted from this incident. 

 For more details please see IO Statement in correspondence.

On Oct 18, 2009, the Barge SCOW 107 broke away from the CURTIS BAY (floating crane) and allided with the James River Bridge. The barge was recovered by Norfolk Tug and secured in their facility at East Indian Road.

On Oct 20, 2009, the tug Tender FALCON was pushing the Dredge RICHMOND through the Lesner Bridge located in Lynnhaven Inlet, when a spud from the Dredge RICHMOND hit the top lateral span of the Lesner Bridge. No damage was visible on the bridge. The tug's operator was administered post casualty alcohol and drug test.

SLM CC received call from the M/V Ragsdale reporting that they had allided with the Lemont Bridge in the Chicago Sanitary Ship Canal. The M/V Ragsdale was pushing 10 empty barges. The barge that hit was red flagged, number THT192 (CHEM 192). No damage was reported on the bridge. MSU Chicago MI/CDO investigated and observed repairs.

Barge TTBL allided with the Pekin Lower Rail Road bridge's RDB upper protection cell while under the control of the UTV JAMES W. BUKY at MM 151 on the Illinois River. This uninspected dry cargo barge had a pin hole leak in the #2 starboard wing tank, 18 inches above the bottom, at the water line. No other damage or injuries occurred during this incident. Barge was allowed to resume transit under the D8 one compartment flooding guidance.

On 26-OCT-09 at approx. 2100 the UTV DELTA TIGER was pushing two equipment barges strung out s/b on the Atchafalaya River. The spud barge AB4 allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge, MM 29.6 on the Atchafalaya River, as the UTV DELTA TIGER attempted to steer through the port span. There was no pollution, damage or injuries as a result of this casualty.

M/V FEDERAL MIRAMICHI (AG) was unbound in the Maumee River when the top of its mast struck the underside of the Anthony Wayne bridge. Vessel's upper section of mast, the GMDSS antenna and navigation lights were damaged. No pollution or injuries, minor damage to the bridge lights and wiring. The upper section of the mast was on a hydraulic ram operated swivel, but it was not completely lowered prior to proceeding under the bridge. Investigation revealed that the air draft height measurement on the ship's particular's was taken from the 2 side posts that are fixed. The upper section of the mast was lowered onto a center post that was 15" higher. The center post can be lowered to let the upper section of the mast rest on the 2 side posts horizontally for additional clearance, but it was not completely lowered at the time the upper mast struck the bridge. With the upper section of the mast resting on the higher center post, it is on a forward/upward angle which added to the air draft which was calculated. The Master of the vessel provided the Pilot with an incorrect air draft for the vessel during the Pilot briefing as evidenced by the pilot card/ship particulars.
Although this casualty was not a serious marine incident, the Pilot conducted drug and alcohol testing completed.

During the late evening of 22JUL09, the Powhatan Creek Bridge was struck by an unknown vessel.  The Coast Guard and National Park Service (NPS) immediately launched an investigation to determine the responsible party and the extent of damage to the bridge.  Several vessels were visited and the operators of those vessels were questioned, but everyone interviewed denied responsibility.  

One vessel, the Towing Vessel SHAMROCK, showed signs of contact that could be attributed to striking the concrete pilings of the bridge.  When interviewed, the operator of the vessel and the other crewmember denied any involvement in the incident. Approximately one month later, the operator of the vessel and the crewman admitted to hitting the Powhatan Creek Bridge on the night in question.  The operator explained that he was transiting under the Powhatan Creek Bridge when the vessel's clutch malfunction and he was unable to control the vessel.  Once the vessel lost maneuverability, the vessel's starboard bow allided with the last piling on the east side of the bridge. 

After the crewmembers admitted to alliding with the bridge, they were immediately fired by the vessel owner. The NPS is seeking enforcement and criminal actions against the individuals involved.  The Coast Guard did not pursue any enforcement action for failure to report a marine casualty because the company did not know about the casualty and the individuals involved are already being charged by the NPS for violations. None of the crewmembers were credentialed mariners.

As of 23MAR10 an estimated cost for the damages sustained to the Powhatan Creek Bridge could not be provided by the NPS for legal reasons. Sector Hampton Roads will move forward with closing the investigation without the estimate.

On October 31, 2009 @ 1140, the port face wire made from the UTV CINDY CELESTE to the ACL 333X failed at the Aluminum eye fitting.  As a result of the failure the pilot of the CINDY CELESTE attempted to turn away to the starboard to keep the tow together then the stbd face wires failed..   After turning the tow the center barge in the flotilla (SER 0302) struck the center span of the Douglas McArthur Rail Road Bridge breaking up the tow.  Two of the barges from the flotilla sank, one of the two remains against the McArthur Bridge the other is completely submerged in the vicinity of the McArthur Bridge, the remaining 13 barges from the original flotilla of 15 floated downstream and struck fleets belonging Osage Marine on the left and right descending banks of the Mississippi River.  Subsequent to the strikes of the two fleets four additional barges broke free and the fleet tug UTV JOHN F WALKER was damaged after one of the previously fleeted barges struck it.  All barges have since been recovered or accounted for.  All area bridges are open at this time.
  
The Pilot of the UTV CINDY CELESTE was tested for alcohol @ 1320 local time

On 02 NOV 2009, Sector NOLA received a report of an allision between the UTV Regina Ann pushing three loaded (cargo of Ferro Alloy) open hopper bages and the Greater New Orleans Bridge (Crescent City Connection). No pollution or injuries reported.

USNS BRIDGE, moored Berth 4, Port of Fujairah, UAE was struck on the port quarter by the barge MARASOL 23 (under the control of tug assist WADI HAYL and WADI MAI). USNS BRIDGE sustained 4 ft x 1 inch gash/crease in the hull of the vsl adjacent to the after mooring station, approx 25 ft above waterline.  Primary site of impact location is the main deck port side btwn frames 510 to 660.  IWO fr 660 minor deformation of approximately 6 square feet of main deck noted.  Flight deck drain severed. Hull coating from fr 510 to 660 is compromised.

The striking barge MARASOL 23, which was being moved within the Port of Fujairah, did not sustain significant damage, neither did the attending tugs, WADI HAYL and WADI MAI.

There is no evidence to suggest that the action or inaction of the USNS BRIDGE officers and/or crew contributed to the incident and its outcome.  Environmental factors, e.g. weather and sea conditions, did not contribute to the incident.  USCG ACTEUR authorized the USNS BRIDGE to hold in abeyance drug and alcohol testing of their crew; drug and alcohol testing not conducted on the foreign nationals operating the foreign flagged tugs involved in the incident.  The responsibility for the striking of the USNS BRIDGE by the barge MARASOL 23 lies solely with the operators of the tugs WADI HAYL and WADI MAI.

Barge SCF 2557 allided with the Pekin Lower Railroad Bridge while under the control of the UTV PAT PICKETT and assist by the UTV EDMUND L. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident. Since this incident involved a non-certificated barge with no damage, no onsite investigation was conducted.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V LYDIA CAMPBELL reporting that she allided with the right-descending bridge pier protection cell of the Burlington R/R bridge, MM 403.1 UMR RDB.  The protection cell had incurred some damage to its timbers previously, and this allision caused no further damage (as reported by the captain and the bridge tender).  The M/V was pushing 15 loaded petroleum coke barges, and the allision caused no damage to the tow, either.

M/V Rhea's stern tow barge hit the Southwest fender of the Gulf Gate Bridge while transiting inbound on the Sabine Neches waterway.  Master of the Rhea reports a dent in the barge; 3 feet long, 4 inches deep and 12 feet above the waterline.  Rhea is moored at the Port of Port Arthur. Fender for the MLK bridge over the Sabine Neches waterway sustained damge to the top of the concrete ring.

The UTV D.W. Griffith, pushing the ferry New Rhodes allided with the Melville Railroad Bridge while transiting down bound on the Atchafalaya River.  The bridge is operational and the bridge was inspected and found no damages. The New Rhodes ferry sustained a small dent in the portside rack.  No pollution or injuries reported.

The UTV Miss Roselyn was headed up bound when the vessel's barge allided with Bayou Sorrel Bridge fender system, MM 38.5, Port Allen Route. The UTV Miss Roslyn was pushing 5 barges, 3 Alumina, 1 Styrene, and 1 Othelyene, the red flag barge, Chem 1300 and Chem 153 allided with the southeast fender which caused a crack in the fender, but no other damage to the bridge which is still operational. The Chem 1300 was loaded with Othelyene and there was no damage to the barge.  The Chem 153, loaded with Styrene, sustained a 15 inch x 2 inch crack in the #2 void tank.  No injuries or pollution reported.

Received notification of UTV EMILY C CHERAMIE (1104495) towing the CROSSMAR 21 (643889) alliding with Bayou Dularge Bridge. No damage to barge, UTV or bridge was reported. No injuries, no pollution. Bridge watchstander confirmed no damage resulted from allision.

On 12 November 2009, at approximately 0700, the UTV ALISON HAUN was southbound on the Black Warrior River flanking the AGS Rail Road Bridge at mile marker 268 when it set its tow out to fast and allied with the bridge's east side support.  The Master immediately reported the incident to the Coast Guard and checked for damages.  The bridge support was lightly scraped and one of the UTV's barges, PTC 495, had a small hole.  The hole was quickly plugged and the vessel was allowed to continue southbound to Mobile.  An inspection of the bridge support was done and no structural damage was reported.  No further incident.

The uninspected crane barge 149 was IVO the Townsend Inlet Bridge when weather conditions (Seas 10', winds gusting to 60 Knots) caused it to break free of anchorage and drift towards the bridge.  During the movement of the crane barge towards the bridge, the port spud broke causing it to drift into/allied with the Ocean Drive bridge over Townsends Inlet.  Damage on the bridge  confined to 4' section of railing and sidewalk.  Damage to the barge confined to several small holes in the bulkhead.  Bridge opening fully operational.  Tugs were able to capture the barge and beach it on the sand in the inlet.  Bridge later repaired, spud located and being recovered by SEA TOW on or around 04J-AN-10.

On November 1, 2009 at 1550, the UTV ALICE PARKER was underway southbound in the Tombigbee River with 08 loaded coal barges when it allided with the Jackson Railroad Bridge fender system located at MM 90.  Barge C-188 broke from its position in the tow and was retrieved without further incident.  Damage was reported to the corner of the barge that made contact; 06 broken wires on tow and broken face wire on the UTV.  Repairs were made and no further incident.
16 NOV 2009: Subject vessel allided with the protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge. No damage to bridge or barge.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V PRAIRE DAWN reporting that they allided with the Burlington Railroad bridge, MM 403.1 UMR.  The M/V was pushing 15 total barges (13 fertilizer, 1 salt, and 1 caustic soda).

On 14 November 2009, at approximately 1330 hrs, the UTV RANDY BAYGENTS was traveling through the Frisco Railroad Bridge located on the Tombigbee Waterway at the 219MM.  The Demopolis Lock called the vessel's pilot and advised him he had struck one of the pillars on the bridge.  The pilot could not find any evidence of contact with the bridge.  Also, there is no report of any damage from the Demopolis Lock to verify an allision occurred.  No further incidents.

22NOV 0630, BRIDGE ALLISION, OSV KRISTIN FAGAN W/ HWY 182 BRIDGE MORGAN CITY, LA: Rcvd report that the OSV allided with the bridge. Only 4 inches of antenna made contact and broke off. No damage reported to the bridge. No injuries, pollution, or secondary casualties. LADOT was notified and will inspect the bridge Monday, traffic is not impacted. IO is enroute to investigate.

On 24 NOV2009, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a radio call on VHF-FM CH. 22A from the M/V Penny Eckstein (O.N. 569492) reporting they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The M/V Penny Eckstein reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the ILR at Mile Marker 56 IVO Florence, IL, and they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The M/V Penny Eckstein reports they were pushing 15 loaded barges (14 corn and 1 coke) and the impact to his tow occurred on the 3rd barge up from the vessel in the stbd string of his standard 3 x 5 barge configuration.  The M/V Penny Eckstein reports the vessel does not appear to be damaged at this time and he is unsure of the bridge, but did state he did not hit the bridge very hard.

On 28 November 2009, at approximately 0335, the UTV BILL JR. was underway pushing ahead 4 empty barges to Mobile, AL.  While passing under the Bob Sikes Bridge, the UTV hit the fender works of the bridge.  No damage was reported for the bridge or the fender works, but one of the barges, RF 510, had its port bow knuckle dented inward.  The vessel reported no flooding or other damage and was allowed to proceed to its destination.  No further incident.

The M/V GENERAL E. LEE with the crane barge WEEKS 545 in tow and the M/V GERARD D in following tow, struck the Lapalco Bridge with the crane barge A frame on the north side of the bridge. at approximately 2333 on 09NOV09. The A frame to the barge received significant damage. The Lapalco bridge way also damage and closed to automobile and foot traffic for approximately 2 days and will support reduced traffic (1 lane) for several weeks. The Master and the Deck Hand on watch onboard the GENERAL E. LEE were chemically tested by the direction of the IO and all crew members of the GERARD D were chemically tested under the direction of the vessels operating company. There was no pollution or injuries sustained during this incident.
Vessel Allided with Sabula RR Bridge Bridge Pier transiting downbound at MM 535UMR.

On 02 December 2009,  the UTV SCOTT QUEST (ON 554619) while pushing ahead one loaded barge (ING 2316) southbound on the Mobile River was attempting to turn starboard to line up with the CSX Railroad Bridge.  When the tow made its approach the barge allied with the bridge causing minor damage to the barge and damage to the bridge.  Repairs were made to the bridge and it was reopened after 18hrs.  No further incidents.

On 27 November 2009, at approximately 1415, the UTV CADDO was transiting southbound to Mobile with 6 loaded hopper barges.  While passing under the Jackson RR Bridge at MM 90 of the Tombigbee River the port stern barge struck the bridge.  No visible damage was done to the bridge, however 3 facing wires parted and the port stern barge, WGN-364, has a 6 to 8 inch split in the side along the waterline.  The tow held together thanks to the safety lines on the barge.  Temporary repairs were made to the barge, and the UTV was allowed to proceed to Mobile.  No further incidents.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call f reporting that the M/V Cooperative Venture rubbed  the pier on the Iowa side of the bridge. Bridge Operator reports that no damage was done to the bridge. Railroad traffic over the bridge has not been affected.

The towing vessel Sunflower was northbound on the Illinois River with eleven barges in tow when they allided with a concrete embankment. Eight barges were loaded with salt; two were loaded with caustic soda and one was loaded with steel. One of the salt barges was involved with the allision. There was light damage to the barge and the tow was not broken. It was reported by the captain that there were three small fractures above the waterline. The vessel is in route to Lemont IL.

06.19.09 M/V MARQUETTE #275663 departed Ogden Slip Chicago, IL heading down river.  Due to high river levels from ongoing rain, deck hand was positioned to report distance between top of mast and bridge.  It was believed that they would clear the bridge as they had 45 minutes earlier, however, they were unable to clear the bridge and knocked off the mounting bracket, Port and back stays pulled from pad eye on deck.  Cabin top cracked at mast step.   No damage to bridge was reported.
Drugs or alcohol not suspected as a causative factor.

On 04DEC09, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V STEPHEN L. COLBY (O/N: 506770) reporting that she allided with the right descending pier of the Florence Highway Bridge, MM 56.0 ILR, while transitting downbound.  The M/V was pushing 15 loaded grain barges, and the pilot reported no damage to his tow as a result of the allision.

The M/V Tiffany G. Barrois allided with the Upper Baton Rouge Bridge, MM 233.9, Lower Mississippi River. The master of the vessel reported that while transiting down bound in the Lower Mississippi River pushing eight loaded rock barges when the current took pushed the tow into the bridge alliding with the bridge and causing a hole in the JWA 04 barge. The barge started to take on water and the vessel crew used 3 pumps to keep up with the flooding. Vessel pulled off to the side at MM 228.3, Lower Mississippi River in hopes of pumping out all the water and fixing the barge on the spot and transiting to their destination.  The barge JWA 04 sunk at MM 228.3 right decending bank.  No pollution and no injuries reported.

On 12 December 2009, the UTV TIM PARKER was pushing 8 empty barges and allided with the Naheola Bridge.  While preparing to transit the Naheola Bridge the UTV slightly missed the turn causing the port stern barge to scrape against one of the bridge pillars.   No reported damage to the barge, UTV or bridge.  No further incidents.

On December 17, 2009, at 1200, the UTV JACKSON III was pushing 5 hoppers; 2 w/wood chips, 2 rolled steel & 1 empty, when the empty barge on starboard head allided with the Jackson RR lift Bridge.  No reported damage to barge or the UTV but minor damage reported to hand rail and attached marine traffic signal light on the bridge.  No further incidents.

A call from a U.S.-flagged uninspected towing vessel pushing a U.S.-flagged inspected tank barge reporting that the barge had allided with the fendering system on the south center span of the Raritan River Railroad Bridge. The tank barge was loaded w/ 74,380 bbls of Low Sulfur Fuel oil.  There were no reported injuries or damage to any vessels involved.  The fendering system was reported to be damaged but an inspection revealed no structural damage to the bridge.
On 17Dec09, the UTV MERRIMAC's  crane barge configuration struck and damaged the NW fender system for the Gilmerton Bridge.

On December 24, 2009 at approximately 1900, an empty red flag barge (MF 732) allided with the Melville RR bridge while being pushed down bound by the UTV Pic at MM 30 on the Atchafalaya River. Only paint scrapes on the bridge were noted. The barge had a dent approximately 10' long along the portside. The voids were checked with no water ingress. There were no injuries or pollution reported.

At 1252R on 24 Dec 2009, SECNY received a report from facility representative stating the tug MCCORMACK BOYS and a scow barge caused "substantial" damage at the Eastern Terminal Howell St Docks on 23 Dec 2009.

On 26 December 2009, at approximately 0320, the UTV TAHOME was southbound with 4 loaded coal barges.  During the transit the UTV was set into the 14 Mile R&R Bridge fender works.  The contact was described as very light and no damage was reported to the UTV, the barges, or the bridge.  The incident was reported to the CG and UTV was cleared to continue with its transit. On 20 December 2009, at approximately 0430, the UTV ASHLEIGH was pushing 4 loaded barges northbound on the Tombigbee River to Columbus, MS.  As the tow was passing under the Jackson Rail Road Bridge it lost headway and the port stern barge (RCT 105) drifted into the west bridge pillar.  No damage was reported to the bridge or to the barge.  The UTV was given clearance to proceed.  No further incident.

On 17 December 2009, the UTV MELINDA BRENT was pushing 2 red flag barges strung out when it allided with the Naheola Railroad Bridge in the Mobile River, during high water.  The barges were loaded with a combined 37,000 barrels of #6 fuel oil and barge Kirby 26701, sustained damage to the number 2 starboard wing tank.  A diver was brought on scene to repair a 3 ft. long gash.  Repairs were made with no further damage to report to vessel or bridge fendering.  No further incident.

On 24 Dec 2009 the barge was moored at the Rt 35  bridge on the Tenn River, when the crew returned on the 30 Dec 2009 they discovered the Barge had been overturned.  Barge is not impeding traffic.  There was a storm with high winds the night of the incident.

No pollution or injuries.
Construction deck barge FL5650MH allided with the Longboat Key Bridge fendering system. No damage to the vessel or bridge.

Sector Lake Michigan received report from the M/V George King stating that they have allided with the protection cell of the Seneca Rail Road Bridge. The bridge is at MM254 on the Illinois River, the operator is on board. The vessel has 15 non red flag loads of coke.

UCN: 2010 - 0006
   On January 5, 2010, the M/V DANIELLE GUIDRY, an uninspected towing vessel, was en route to the Lyondell Channelview facility to deliver its empty barge, the Kirby 10023.  At approximately 1400, the vessel's navigation light mast struck the I-10 vehicle highway bridge in the vicinity of Southwest Shipyard.
   The vessel's mast struck a steel girder of the bridge causing the mast to break at its base and fall straight back onto the vessel's upper deck.  No other damage was incurred and the vessel continued on its voyage to Lyondell without further incident.  There was no damage reported to the bridge.

The UTV DALE WHITE allided with the Cicero Ave (Rt. 50) bridge at MM317.2 of the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal.  The vessel reported damage to the anchor light on the mast of the vessel. On 15 DEC 09, at approximately 1835, the UTV MR WAYNE and the UTV SEA TIGER were headed downbound on the Atch River MM 30 with a pipe on pontoon barges in tow when the pipe allided with the south pier of the Melville Bridge. No damage, pollution, or injuries resulted.

Salem Hbr Master reported the barge being transported by Tug Creole Miss allided with the Salem/Beverly Bridge causing minor damage to the bridge and barge. MBTA traffic was delayed approx two hours.

Sector Boston I/O made contact with the Bridge tender and obtained that the tug/barge were O/B at 0747 and the barge got wedged between the fendering system. Vsl u/w with tow of 6 barges ivo Marseilles L/D, water height restricting navigation under bridge.
