Sector Upper Mississippi River received a  telephone call from the M/V Andrea Leigh (O.N. 585079) reporting they grounded with a draft of 9'3".  The M/V Andrea Leigh reports they were transiting in the channel down bound on the UMR at Mile Marker 194.1 IVO Wood River, IL, and the current set them causing them to run aground on the tip of Chouteau Island.  The M/V Andrea Leigh reports they were able to back off and continue downbound.  The M/V Andrea Leigh reports they were pushing 9 barges (4 empties and 5 loads "4 soybean and 1 loaded refined corn oil, red flag").  The M/V Andrea Leigh reports the impact to his tow occurred on the lead center barge (loaded soybean).  The M/V Andrea Leigh reports a 4" by 2" crack was found in the floor of the bow void and has been shingled to a stop.  The M/V Andrea Leigh plans to take the barge to Reidy Terminal at MM 179.0 UMR.  M/V Andrea Leigh reports there were no injuries.

Rcvd report that the UTV DIXIE Challenge allided with the Morgan City RR Bridge while pushing 02 loaded kerosene barges. The UTV's stern was the only area to make contact, and it barely made contact. VTC Berwick Bay saw the allision on camera. Only reported damage was a broken face wire connecting one of the barges to the UTV. No injuries or pollution.

At approximately 2008 on February 11, the bridge tender for the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge contacted MSU Baton Rouge to report that the UTV LIL' AL CENAC had struck the bridge with the boom of a crane barge which it was pushing down bound.  The bridge tender reported that the UTV had sunk and that he could see one person on the deck of the crane barge which was tangled with the bridge supports.  MSU Baton Rouge contacted Sector for possible SAR case and then made contact with Point Coupee and St. Landry Sheriff's deputies for assistance.  Duty IO and Duty PI were dispatched as well.  Received word at approximately 2100 that 2 crewmembers from UTV had been recovered safely from the water and there were no other personnel to account for.  At approximately 2310 Duty IO and Duty PI arrived on scene, Duty PI began assessment of waterway and Duty IO proceeded to Opelousas Hospital to interview crewmembers.  
 
According to Duty IO, the master claimed that as he approached the open bridge headed down bound monitoring channel 16, the bridge began to close unexpectedly forcing him to back down which swung the head of his tow to Starboard where the barge struck the bridge and became stuck on the supports.  The stern of the boat swung to Port and the boat began to sink.  The master and his deckhand were able to egress from the boat and were recovered by local sheriff's and a boat from the nearby Alon Refinery.  Duty IO will be getting a statement from the bridge tender as follow up, he had already departed prior to Duty IO's arrival.
 
The Duty PI stated that the barge was stuck on the West side of the bridge just outside of the channel and was being held in place by the boom and wires which were tangled in the bridge supports.  The UTV had been spotted downriver by a commercial fisherman near MM 44.  The fisherman stated that he pushed the partially submerged UTV onto a sandbar and then continued upriver thinking it would hold in place.  The Duty PI received transport downriver in a boat and after searching 2 miles past where the fisherman reported the UTV's last position they were unable to find the UTV or any signs of its whereabouts.

On February 23 McKinney Towing began salvage operations and identified that the vessel was the Lil' Al Cenac. 

On February 25 the vessel was salvaged and was returned to a free-floating position. Approximately 100 gallons of red diesel discharged from the Lil' Al Cenac into the Atchafalaya River, a U.S. navigable waterway, creating a visible sheen on the water. The on-scene OSRO was immediately activated. A second OSRO team was called in to minimize the impact.

On February 26 clean up of the red diesel spill was satisfactory to the Coast Guard.

UTV "M/V FRANK L." (O.N. 639522) pushing 01 red flag barge, "SMITTY 18" (O.N. 1074641)  allided with the Houma Navigation Canal Bridge.  No pollution, no injuries.  State bridge inspectors were notified and approved bridge for full operation.  Barge had 14,300 bbls of #2 Diesel as cargo.  The UTV was heading west on the GICW and turned left to enter the Houma Nav Canal. The CAPT stated that the bridge tender would not open the bridge until the vsl is within sight and that he had called the bridge moments before making the bend around the north bank.  The current and wind were pushing the vessel toward the bridge.  The barge made contact with the north east corner of the bridge as it was opening.  The barge was punctured in the forward headlog w/ a 4" inset.  DMI found no water intrusion in rake, and approved temp repair and issued 835 to proceed to S/Y for repairs after unloading cargo in Port Fourchon.

On the morning of May 4, 2009, at approximately 0810, 38 YOA commercial diver, died while conducting diving operations from a closed-bell at approximately 212-fsw. 

The saturation diving operation was being conducted from the DSV KINGFISHER (O.N. 8509193), a Vanuatu flagged, 295-foot, 3672 GT dive support vessel operating in Vermillion block 321.  The saturation divers are employed by Veolia Environmental Services.

The job assigned to the divers was to install a 22-inch diameter Grip Lock Connector, weighing 7,060 pounds, into a sub-sea pipeline at approximately 212-fsw.  The Grip Lock Connector was attached to a Canflex Lift Bag with 12,000 pound rated lifting capacity.  

The Job safety Analysis, signed by the divers on May 4, 2009, at 0000, states: "Never inflate lift bag until rigged to object, 1" invert line to the top of bag, and Secondary rigging to DMA or stationary object is complete."  Note: 'DMA' is a deadman anchor. 

Investigation finds the previous diver did not adequately attach the liftbag rigging; the restraining line was not deployed/secured to a stationary object, and the inverter line was connected to a PVC pipe that was pulled from the seafloor bottom during an uncontrolled ascent of the liftbag.   

The diver was wearing a Kirby Morgan Superlite 17C / Ultrajewel 601 Reclaim Helmet consisting of a the Divex Ultraflow 601 Demand regulator and Ultrajewel 601 Exhaust Reclaim Regulator connected to a Superlite 17C Helmet. The diver was breathing a 6.5% heliox mixed-gas (6.5% O2) at the time of the uncontrolled ascent. Based on the diver's video, it appears the reclaim system was periodically free-flowing during the previous days.  The helmet appeared to be dry inside when it was removed inside the diving bell after the diver was recovered.

During the uncontrolled ascent of the lift bag with Grip Lock Connector attached, it appears the diver was entangled in the PVC pipe and lift bag dump line strap connection. In sum, the diver was involved in an uncontrolled ascent from approximately 212-fsw to approximately 50 to 70 fsw. A pneumo-fathometer reading taken at 0816 indicates the diver was at 70-fsw when communications were ceased with the diver in distress.

On 18 FEB 2010 @ approx 0530, the UTV ROBERT BURTON pushing the loaded hopper barge DMT 406 allided with the Steel Bridge in Chesapeake, VA.  There was no damage to the bridge and the barge received a minor scrape down the starboard side.  Alcohol testing was completed.

On February 9, 2010, at 0730, the Master of the UTV BILOXI reported alliding with the Nahoela RR Bridge on Black Warrior/Tombigbee River MM173.  UTV BILOXI was pushing 4 loaded coal barges.  Initial report was no damage to bridge, no damage to barges, or UTV with the exception of parted barge coupling cables (rigging).  USCG Investigators along with Bridge Inspectors attended vessel.  Initial investigation and bridge inspection revealed severe damage to bridge structure.  Bridge closed to railroad traffic until temporary repairs could be made.  Estimated damage to repair bridge is approximately $45,000.00.

MSU Chicago responded to a call from the UTV DALE WHITE that was pushing a string of hopper barges including the JB45B when it allided with the EJ & E Railroad Bridge South of Dresden Island Lock. M/V Alice I Hooker's tow allided with Cairo Bridge. Two loaded coal  barges sank.

M/V Luke Burton reported that they have allided with the EJ&E RR bridge on the Illinois River, MM 270.5. Sector Lake Michigan received report from the W.O. Watson that they have allided with the EJ&E Bridge on the Illinois River MM270. The vessel had two barges in tow both empty red flags. The starboard barge has a 2-3 inch hole in it, the barge number is NMLP316.

The tow consisted of two unloaded asphalt barges and the tow boat.  The operator miscalculated the set of the tow and allided with the inside of the bridge draw.

  The Bridge, Tug boat and unloaded barges were undamaged and remain operational.

On 25FEB10, at 0322, the UTV Natalie Alexander pushing the loaded GRIFCO 3810 and GRIFCO 3807 down bound on the Lower Mississippi River MM 167 allided with the Sunshine Bridge.  The GRIFCO 3810 suffered damage to the center bow.  The Sunshine Bridge suffered damage to the fendering system.

The M/V KNOCKOUT allided with the Louisa Bridge while transiting eastbound on the GIWW.  Cause of the allision was Captain's misjudgment of the wind, which set the vessel toward the fender. DMI dispatched to scene, issued 835 to have the fuel tank drained, gas freed and prepped for a Marine Inspector to verify extent of damage and informed Captain damage must be repaired immediately. Drug & alcohol testing not required, being done by company.

As the tow passed under the bridge it was set west and the lead barge, R-8467 rubbed the bridge pylon.  No damage was done to the barge or the bridge and the NONNIE was cleared to proceed southbound.  No further incident.

Received a report that the M/V J.W. HUNTER allided with the Bordeaux Railroad Bridge at mile 185.2 CMB with 3 empty grain barges in tow. Advised no damage reported to the vessel, barges, or bridge. Vessel reported cause of allision was wind.

UTV Warren Hines was attempting a controlled landing on the EJ&E Railroad Bridge at M/M 270.5.  Starboard barge in tow of (3) jumbo tank barges (108' width) was rubbing along RDB fendering when a lapped plate/butt weld midships on barge caught, altering headway to starboard, causing port aft barge in tow to conact LDB fendering and lead 2 barges to twist to starboard upon leaving bridge.  Force caused 1 wire to part and 1 timberhead to separate just above the base plate.  No damage to barge hull or injuries to personnel.  

Shortly after the incident, while rearranging tow, the port side generator failed.  Vsl had previously reported port generator failure 2-3 days before which had been addressed by tech.  Vsl is to remain pushed in at mm 270 ILR until generator assessment/repairs can be completed.  Techs were scheduled to arrive soon after response team departed.

On 03 March 2010, at approximately 0950, the UTV CRISTO SANTO was transiting northbound near MM2 of the Escambia River when it did not make the turn past the HWY 90 Bridge while pushing the barge HBM3052.  The barge went aground on a sandbar along the west bank of the river.  The UTV was able to pull the barge off the sandbar without any damage and continued on its way.  No further incidents.

5 March 2010 - TUG CARDINAL was towing (astern) barge S-2007 from Guam to Saipan when the tug and tow approached the 2.5 mile point from Tango Buoy.  Short tow operations involves beginning in shallow water where the chain and shackles are connected to the chaffing gear and prevent the bowline from moving back and forth.  04 Crewmembers went to the stern to help remove the chaffing gear from the towing wire.  The retaining chains were removed and then the crew went to unbolt the chaffing gear from the wire.  Crewmember was using a wrench to unbolt the chaffing gear and standing at the port side of the wire when the towing wire shifted port causing the wire to strike the crewmember in the left leg below his knee.  

Crew and Captain all have at least 1 yr experience working on Tug boats and sea state was 3-4ft waves, 10-15MPH ENE winds, and current 1kt.  TUG CARDINAL was underway making 2.5kt at course 210 when the crewmember was injured. 

27April2010 - Injured crewmember is currently in the Philippines and his return date is unknown.  According to Cabras Marine Corporation, crewmember has not returned to work and will be recovering for another 2months from doctor orders.  Brother of injured crewmember reports that he is recovering as scheduled.

No further action required.  Coast Guard satisfied.

Barge was moored, with spuds, on the Potomac River, north of the 14th Street Bridge.  The barge broke free from the bottom during high river levels due to heavy rain and snow melt.  The barge drifted down river where it allided with the bridge.  Barge owners and contractors were unable to get a tug assist to the barge due to weather conditions and bridge clearance.  Barge was relocated approximately 2 days later when environmental conditions allowed.

M/V Charlie Everhart reported a "controlled landing" on the Louisville and Nashville RR Drawbridge.  M/V is reporting no damage, injuries or pollution, stating the wind pushed the tow into the right descending bridge pier "just rubbing it".  M/V is pushing 06 empty open hopper coal barges d/b.

MSD Nashville, D8 CC, and the CSX Bridge Inspector all notified.

Bridge Inspector dispatched and found no damage to the bridge.

MSU MORGAN CITY receives report that supply boat CHARGER (being pushed by UTV MISS HILLARY) hit Long Allen HWY 182 fixed span bridge while traveling northbound on the Morgan City/Port Allen Alternate Route.    Damages to vessel and bridge are minimal (no more than $100 in repairs).  No pollution or injuries were reported.

3-15-2010 IO placed call to reporting party.  Awaiting statement from UTV HILLARY, owned by Stagg in Morgan City.  

$10 repair of light on vessel.  No major damage, no pollution or injuries.
M/V MR. LEWIS (ON 512671) tow allided with the Thebes railroad bridge with his starboard side.  No damage was detected.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the Florence Highway Bridge tender reporting the M/V Billy Waxler allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.  The bridge tender reports the M/V Billy Waxler was transiting in the channel down bound on the ILR at Mile Marker 56.0 IVO Florence, IL, and they allided with the Florence Highway Bridge.

STA SPI was enroute to another location when they saw the Tug HENRY CENAC aground next to the Queen Isabella Causeway.  The vessel was pushing ahead two red flag barges when it experienced a strong flood tide current.  The tug/barge combo was caught in the current.  The barge CTCO 309 came to rest on the causeway's fender system.  No damage to bridge or vsl.  No injuries.

On 16 March 2010, the UTV RANDY BAYGENTS, 8 barges, H pattern, port side center coal barge (PTC 479)rubbed up against east side pillar of the AGR Railroad Bridge (Yo-Yo) at MM 219 on the Black Warrior River in Demopolis. Minor damage reported to a few wires on the barge and no damage to the bridge.  No further incident.

On 22MAR10 at 1940Z, Sector New Orleans received call that the motor vessel HOLY ROSERY struck on the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge. Motor vessel HOLY ROSERY pushed fender in and broke brackets at the railroad bridge.

M/V SUNFLOWER reported an allision with the Vicksburg Railroad Bridge at MM 435.8 Lower Mississippi River.  The M/V SUNFLOWER has 11 total barges, 9 loaded and 2 empty. 10 of the barges are Red Flags, 9 loaded and 1 empty.  The last empty was dry cargo, corn.

22 Mar 2010: At approx. 2000L the steersman under the direction of the Master of the UTV Sunflower, allided with the Vicksburg Railroad Bridge. The tow was NB with 11 total barges, 9 loaded reds, 1 empty red, and 1 empty hopper. The master usually transits through the  2nd alternate channel; however, due to reports of shoaling north of the bridge he decided to transit the bridge through the 1st alternate channel. Master stated he instructed Steersman to line up with the 1st alternate channel, and reported his speed to be 4 kts, and slowing. When the 2nd row of barges was clear of the bridge the master noted that the vessel was being set to stbd by current and instructed the steersman to attempt to compensate for it. However, the UTV was already under the I-20 bridge and could not compensate enough without forcing the UTV into the bridge. Master stated that the stbd stern of the UTV "rubbed" the bridge causing minimal damage to the vessel and bridge. Master also reported 9 broken wires and one broken timber head on the Hines 0440. 

Vessel continued to transit NB to Kings Point Landing and pushed in to assess damage and await CG inspectors next morning.

On March 23, 2010 at approximately 1850, the UTV W. STANLEY JAMES was downbound with 15 empty hopper barges when it allided with the center span of the Chessie Baltimore and Ohio RR bridge at MM 184.3 on the Ohio River near Parkersburg, WV.  State bridge inspectors verified no damage to the bridge and CG Investigating officers responded and verified no damage to the barge or towing vessel.

The UTV Joseph Merrick Jones while U/B, allided (rubbed) the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Bridge (AKA Lower Pekin R/R) at MM 151.2, ILR.  All barges in the tow were red flags. The port head barge (Kirby 15430, empty) made contact with the right descending bridge pier protection cell. There was no damage to any of the barges in the tow, the UTV nor the bridge. Master reported that there was a strong current in the vicinity of the bridge and that the current was a contributing factor to the incident.  No helper boat was used. This bridge has been deemed obstructive under the Truman-Hobbs Act.

M/V Charlie Everhart (534782) reported alliding with the Louisville and Nashville RR Drawbridge at MM 190.4 CMB.  M/V is pushing 6 empty open hoppers and is reporting no damage, injuries or pollution.  The barge ING 4549 allided with the bridge.  M/V reported no damage to the bridge pier, which was struck by its center barge of the starboard string.

CSX dispatch notified and dispatched a bridge inspector to inspect the bridge who verified that no damage was done to the bridge.

Commercial Fishing Vessel (CFV) MISS DONNA was in tow by the CFV MISS REBECCA transiting the Longboat Pass Bridge in Bradenton Beach, FL. The MISS DONNA had no steering as the result of a previous steering casualty the day before. The MISS DONNA drifted in the current and rubbed against the northern fendering system of the bridge. No damage to the vessel or bridge as a result of this incident.

Barge AB215 while under the control of UTV ARDYCE RANDALL allided (rubbed) the LDB fending system of the Chicago and Northwestern (a.k.a. Pekin R/R bridge), at MM 151.2 ILR, while pushing 6 barges (4 dry cargo and 2 red flag barges). There was no damage to the tow, barge or bridge. This bridge has been deemed obstructive under the Truman-Hobbs Act.

On the 21March2010 DDO Myrtle Beach personnel received a call from Georgetown County Sheriff  about a  dredge boat that was partially submerged with an oil sheen around it. When DDO personnel arrived on scene the owner of the dredge boat was there with the owner of the company, Waterbridge Marine Construction. Company had placed boom around  boat to contain any other oil. All oil was residual from deck of  boat. The boat was  then raised. A NOFI was issued to the company and an LOW was also sent to company. 


10MAY10- DDO Myrtle Beach personnel spoke with Mr. regarding the above incident.  Nothing new to report, search for the lost sunk vessel continues.

12MAY10- DDO Myrtle Beach personnel spoke with Mr. regarding the above incident.  Mr. confirmed that search methods being used were: Sonar, depth finders and divers.  Mr. also stated that they are still unable to locate the vessel. 

17MAY10- DDO Myrtle Beach personnel spoke with Mr. regarding the above incident.  Nothing new to report.  The search for the lost sunk vessel continues.

Tugboat DANNI SUE allided with the Dupont Bridge.  The Tugboat was pushing ahead with two empty barges (which carried sodium hydroxide).  The Captain of the vessel reported that he was trying to avoid hitting a kayaker when one of his barges scraped the Dupont Bridge's fendering system.  No damage was reported.  USCG personnel went underway to conduct an inspection and an investigation.  Due to heavy fog with zero visibility at night, the investigation and inspection was postponed until the following morning.  DANNI SUE was advised to remain overnight.

On 05APR10, USCG personnel went underway to conduct a vessel inspection and investigation.  No damages were observed on the barge that allided with the Dupont Bridge.  USCG personnel also did not observe any damage to the bridge fendering system.  Inspection and investigation was completed without further incident.

On 3 April 2010, at approximately 1430, UTV WILLIAM WEBER was underway westbound on the ICW pushing 2 empty barges.  As the UTV was passing under the Bob Sykes Bridge in Pensacola one if its barges, CHEM 3211 came in contact with the bridge pylon.  No damage was reported for the bridge or the barge.

The UTV CAPT LEE LEJEUNE (O.N. 1181939) pulling drilling rig with tail boat UTV KK was lining up to transit through bridge when it hit the east fenders. LADOTD notified of damage to timbers (fender system).  No further action required/requested by LADOTD.  No damage to either vsls, no pollution, no injuries. Bridge is operable to both vehicle and vsl traffic.

Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V Frank Stegbauer reporting that the vessel allided with the center span (vertically) of the EADS bridge, MM 180.0 UMR while transiting downbound.  The only damage reported was as follows: 1 broken radar, 2 broken search lights, 1 broken GPS antenna, 8 - 9 broken vhf antennas, 1 broken AIS antenna; 2692 has damaged estimated at 25k but call from company rep later estimates damages at 15k.  The vessel was pushing 3 empty Ammonium Nitrate barges drafting 3 feet and no damage was reported to the tow.  The M/V Frank Stegbauer is currently at Osage fleet MM178 UMR.

On 10 APR 2010, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V ROBIN B INGRAM reporting that the vessel allided with center span (vertically) of the Eads Bridge, MM 180.0 UMR while transiting downbound.  The only damage reported was as follows: 2 broken radar antennas, 1 broken starboard spotlight, and 1 broken pilot house window.  The vessel was pushing 3 loaded corn barges and 1 empty tank barge (caustic soda), but there was no damage reported to the tow.  The M/V MISS SHIRLEY is assisting the vessel in transiting to the Ingram Fleet at MM 173 UMR.

On 08 April 2010, at approximately 0750, the UTV RHETT PARKER was traveling southbound on the Mobile River.  The UTV was pushing 6 empty barges when barge PTC 475 allided with the east side cribbing of the 14 Mile RR Bridge.  The Bridge Operator verified there was no damage to the bridge and upon inspection, it was verified that the PTC 475 was undamaged from the allision.

On 23 March 2010, at approximately 1422, the UTV ANTIETAM was underway with 1 loaded red flag barge through Chickasaw Creek.  While attempting to pass under the bridge the UTV rubbed up against the fender works of the bridge.  No damage was reported to the barge, UTV, or bridge.

On 12 APR2010, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a radio call on VHF-FM CH. 22A from the M/V Cooperative Mariner reporting they were transiting in the channel up bound (en route to Clinton, IA) on the UMR at Mile Marker 282.1 IVO Louisiana, MO, and they allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge.  The M/V Cooperative Mariner reports they were pushing 15 barges (3 loaded ammonia fertilizer, 9 empties, and 3 empty red flags) and the impact to his tow occurred on the 3rd barge back (empty dry cargo barge) in the port string.  The M/V Cooperative Mariner reports he was pushing a standard 3 x 5 configuration  and the 3 empty red flags were the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th barges back in the stbd string.  M/V Cooperative Mariner reports neither the barge or bridge appears to have sustained damage.

Received report of tow vessel alliding with Parker Bridge on the ICW in North Palm Beach, FL.  Master of the vessel stated he was transiting to work awaiting the draw bridge to open; as the bridge started to open the master had a crewmember lower the crane on the barge to its' lowest point; then master then had the barge spuds raised and proceeded to transit under the bridge even though the bridge was not fully raised.  At that time the port forward barge spud struck the bridge span.  The force of the allision caused the spud to break off the top twenty feet of the spud, and fall into the channel.  The tug continued under the bridge and the crane rope fouled around a part of the bridge, but freed while the vessel passed under the bridge.  The tug proceeded and spud down fifty yards west of the bridge.

14APR10 (0100)- M/V MISS CLAIRE with two loaded mud barges (set up end to end) held position west of the Rigolets bridge awaiting opening after a train passed drifted south and struck the SW portion of the bridge fending system with the STBD aft corner of stern barge while attempting to top around to port, causing damage to the bridge fender  system. IO made contact with vsl and found that they were laid up on the bank NW of the bridge. IO instructed vsl to wait first light before moving vsl. Due to the vsl's remote location, chemical testing was not conducted until the next port call.  No damage occurred to the vessel and no pollution.

UTV THOMAS E. ERICSON was pushing 11 barges north bound on the Mississippi River near mile marker 699, when a barge (AEP-7293) located port side on the second line of the tow, struck the outer protection cell on the La Crosse Rail Road bridge causing damage to one of the timbers.  The barge that struck the protection cell was empty and no damage was caused to the barge.

Uninspected barge "AEP 7224" broke free at Cargill West facility located at mile marker 14.75 on the Minnesota River.  The barge broke free while the dock workers were moving barges.  The barge that broke free was the first barge of three in a string tied up at the docks.  Dockworkers were shifting all three barges down their pier to load remaining cargo in the last barge.  During the shift the second barge in the string struck a inside piling causing the lines to snap,  which in turn broke free the first barge - AEP 7224 . The barge broke free and floated down the river.  The barge was loaded with corn.  Cargill facility manager contacted Upper River Services who dispatched the UTV J.L. FLEMMING which retrieve the barge just below mile marker 12.  No damage resulted to the barge or the facility.  The breakaway barge did pass safely under a rail road bridge located at mile marker 14.3 without damaging the bridge.

On April 23, 2010, at approximately 0945, the Master of the towing vessel LITTLE E reported while pushing the barge EBC-2 under the Lesner Bridge the barge hit a newly installed fender board that was sticking out about 4 feet.  The contractor working on scene installing new boards was preparing to trim the board, but had not prior to the incident.  There was no other damage to the bridge and both vessels with crew were undamaged.

Received call fm UTV JERRY MCNEIL (272258) advising that they allided with the right descending bridge pier of the Highway 41 dual highway Bridge mile 781.8 OHR. Master reports pushing 15 empty hoppers; barge involved is CBY-419. Master reports cause as current and that there is no damage to barges or bridge.

A commercial assistance towing vessel was towing a disabled 41-foot sailing vessel in stern tow configuration approximately 20 feet off of its stern.  As the towing vessel navigated through the center span of the Longboat Key Bridge, a 20 knot southerly winds pushed the sailing vessel into the bridge's fendering system.  The sailing vessel was not pulled through the center of the bridge span, but ended up being pulled alongside the bridges port side fendering system resulting in minor damage to the bridge's fendering system and the vessel's wooden rub rail.
09APR2010: UTV TROJAN allided with Burlington R/R bridge protection cell.  On scene response verified no damage incurred to bridge, vessel, nor tow.

Vessel began to have engine trouble while transiting to Murrells Inlet.  The weather became foul with water splashing over the stern which drowned the batteries causing the bilge pumps to fail.  The two persons on board climbed onto the barge as the vessel sank.

During the course of a vessel inspection conducted on the vessel ANNABEL LEE on April 12, 2010 in Stamford, CT, a Marine Inspector from Sector Long Island Sound received notification from the Master of the vessel ANNABEL LEE that he had struck the swing bridge on the Cape May Canal while transiting from Florida to Connecticut.  The Master did not immediately notify the Coast Guard in Cape May, despite speaking with the Officer of the Day at Station Cape May on March 22, 2010 just a few hours after the allision occurred.  Nor did the Master notify the nearest Coast Guard Sector Office (Sector Delaware Bay) at the time of the incident.  The vessel sustained minimal damage to the forward gangway and rails - the Swing Bridge was not damaged.

On 05 MAY 2010, at approx 1006, the M/V SEA PEARL was transiting through the Gilmerton Bridge with the assistance of the Tug KAYE E MORAN, DRUM POINT, and CANDICE L.  While being towed stern first by the assisting tug boats, the SEA PEARL allided with the east side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system.  The vessel never acknowledged that they hit the bridge, but the bridge tender heard and saw the SEA PEARL pushing against the fendering system as the vessel transited through the bridge.  It was determined that there was not any damage to the fendering system.  The IO's and a marine inspector boarded the SEA PEARL at Sewell's Point Anchorage to conduct investigation, check crew documents, and perform navigation and steering safety inspections.  It was determined that there was not any damage to the SEA PEARL and all navigation and steering was satisfactory. The Docking Pilot was alcohol tested.

On 05 MAY 2010,  Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the UTV Jennie K. reporting  they were transiting in the channel up bound on the UMR at Mile Marker 282.1 IVO Louisiana, MO when they allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge pier.  The UTV Jennie K. was pushing 15 empty grain barges and the impact to his tow occurred on the 3rd barge back in the port string of his standard 3 x 5 barge configuration.  UTV Jennie K. reported wind pushed the barge against the bridge pier.  The UTV Jennie K. reported neither the barge or bridge appear to be damaged.  The bridge reported no damage and was able to swing the bridge over the span with no problems lining up.

UTV Hazel (Crounse Corp) allided with the Clark Memorial Bridge (2nd St) in downtown Louisville.  He had 6 loaded coal barges, 4 of which have broken loose.  Master cited high water as contributing factor/cause.

On May 6, 2010 while underway Westbound on the GICWW at MM 237 the UTV MARY KAY was pushing 3 empty red flag barges. While transiting, the middle and stern barge starboard side rubbed against the fender of the Black Bayou Bridge (pontoon bridge). No injuries, pollution or damage resulted.

On May 6, 2010, at approximately 1600, the towing vessel GOLD COAST was pushing the tank barge JNB-22 (in light condition) when the tug lost steering transiting through the Gilmerton Bridge. The JNB-22 hit the eastside fendering system, however the operator of the tug reported no damage to the barge. The GOLD COAST moored north of the Gilmerton Bridge and made a temporary steering repair. The engineer of the Gilmerton Bridge reported no damage to the fendereing system. An investigator from Sector Hampton Roads responded and conducted a visual inspection of the JNB-22; no damage to the barge. The investigator allowed the towing vessel FIRST COAST to relieve the tow and take the JNB-22 to Craney Island. Although the GOLD COAST made a temporary emergency steering repair, a COTP was issued to the GOLD COAST. The GOLD COAST was escorted by the tug TREASURE COAST to the shipyard to conduct repairs.

Lake Michigan SCC received notification from the M/V CAPT. ROGER D. ADAMS (1132227)  reporting an allision with the Belt Line RR Bridge, mm 317 CSSC while eastbound pushing two red flag barges carrying asphalt.  The lead barge (WEB 228) allided with the concrete turnstile which caused a large inset on the port side bow/headlog of the barge.  Bridge suffered what appeared to be minor concrete damage.   Barge damage could not be internally assessed, no penetration of shell observed, IO issued requirement for internal exam w/in 30 days due to local unavailability of marine chemist and barge w/in window for annual exam.

26 APR 2010: UTV THERESA L. WOOD allided with protection cell of Burlington railroad bridge due to protrusions of beams and work in progress on left descending bridge pier.  No damage to tow, vessel, nor bridge incurred.  No further follow up required, investigation complete.

CG MSU Port Arthur received a phone call from Kirby Marine reporting the CITY OF NEW ORLEANS hit the Black Bayou Bridge on the ICW. The UTV was pushing 04 empty barges when the stern barge made contact with the bridge. There was no damage to the barge or bridge that is visible. No pollution, No injuries reported. LA DOT attended bridge, and verified no damage.

Barge SCF 26011 allided with the Pekin Lower Railroad bridge upper right protection cell while under the control of the UTV PAT PICKETT while south bound on the Illinois River at MM 151.2 with 6 empty dry cargo barges. SCF 26011 was the starboard lead barge of the tow and had minor damage to the starboard bow, and no damage was reported to the protection cell. No injuries occurred during this incident.

On 17 May 2010, the UTV DAVID L GRIGGS reported they allided with the protection cell on the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge at Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282.  The UTV DAVID L GRIGGS was pushing northbound with 16 empty dry cargo barges.  The UTV DAVID L GRIGGS, freight barge BUNGE-937 and Louisiana Railroad Bridge were all undamaged and remain operational.

On May 17, 2010 at approximately 0300 local time while underway on the Colorado River pushing two empty barges the UTV LUKE BRYAN allided with the 521 bridge. The starboard stern of the UTV LUKE BRYAN made contact with the bridge fender system.

On 18 May 2010, The ITB PHILADELPHIA (US) was the 15th the vessel in a 19 vessel northbound convoy in the Suez Canal. At 1200, the RHEIN BRIDGE (Panama) was seen leaving anchorage and appeared to be joining the convoy in front of the ITB PHILADELPHIA. Efforts to contact the RHEIN BRIDGE by the Egyptian pilot onboard the ITB PHILADELPHIA were unsuccessful. The pilot and, subsequently, the master of the ITB PHILADELPHIA made engine speed and course adjustments to try to avoid a collision.  At 1209, the RHEIN BRIDGE struck the ITB PHILADELPHIA on the port side. The bulbous bow of the RHEIN BRIDGE penetrated the hull of the ITB PHILADELPHIA's port engine room. The probable cause of the incident is that the RHEIN BRIDGE violated Rule 10 of the Vessel Traffic Separation Schemes in joining a vessel lane while a convoy was in transit.  The collision resulted in significant damage to the RHEIN BRIDGE and the ITB PHILADELPHIA was declared a total loss.

Rcv'd notification from bridge operator that the UTV EMILY C CHERAMIE pushing the CROSSMAR 21 (an inspected industrial barge) allided with the fendering system of the HOUMA NAV bridge.  Did not recv notification from vsl operator.  Bridge is fully operable.  DMI to attend vsl at nearest dockside facility.  Vsl will arrive at facility in about 3 hrs.  MC IO conducting investigation.

Vessel was pushing an uninspected spud barge when the bow rake of the barge hit the fendering system on the bayou Dularge bridge. The allision caused minor damage to barge (small crack in Knuckle top of rake).
No damage to bridge. The Bridge is still operating.
15 MAY 2010: UTV RAYMOND G ECKSTEIN towing 15 dry cargo barges allided with Crescent railroad bridge protection cell.  No damage to bridge, vessel, or barges incurred.

14 May 2010, MV CORAL DAWN towed barge RRS 8021 allided with Burlington Railroad bridge during downbound transit.  Vessel was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges.  No damage was reported to vessel and tow nor bridge from the allision.  No further follow up required, investigation complete.

Coast Guard Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the M/V J.W. Hershey reporting a bridge allision.  The tow rubbed against the protection cell on the Burlington R/R Bridge, MM 403 UMR, resulting in damage to the third barge up on the STBD string (WWT 0839).  The barge has approx 2 ft of water in the #1 void from a small hole.  The M/V is currently pushed in on the RDB at MM 401.3 UMR.  MSD Quad City IO responded.

UTV ROVERTA TABOR was pushing 12 barges (6 empties, 2 pet coke, 4 grain) southbound on the Mississippi River from St Paul enroute to St Louis.  During the transit at mile marker 836 the tow struck Pig's Eye railroad bridge.  Loaded grain barges located on the starboard string in the #2 and #4 position struck the bridge protection cell.  Only slight damage (paint scraping) was done to the protection cell.  Barge #2 (RRS 8008) received damage in the #4 wing tank, in which crewmembers were able to shingle.  Barge #4 (Art 313) received damage in the stern section.  This barge was unable to patch and was dropped off at upper river fleeting area for repairs.

The UTV Capt. Alex (WDE4329) contacted VTS Port Arthur on VHF-FM ch. 01A and reported losing steering when the starboard generator failed due to a broken drive belt The port bow of the barge Duval#3 made contact with the fendering system of the West Port Author bridge. Notified CDO and VTS contacted traffic in the area to hold up.  Capt. Alex contacted VTS on the telephone and reported bridge was clear to pass through and his generator went down as he was approaching the bridge from the east and the barge laid up on the south fender works as he passed through the bridge. 
Investigators found extensive damage to the south west cell and fender works of the bridge. The barge sustained minor damage to the deck vents and rubber tank mounts.

The barge was taken Houston South West ship yard for repairs.

On 22 MAY 2010, at  approx 1420, the Tug MERRIMACK was making the approach to the Gilmerton Bridge with three barges in tow when one of the barges (FLEXI-FLOAT BARGE) allided with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge.  There was no damage to the tug, the barges, and minimal damage to the bridge.

On 23 MAY 2010, Sector UMR CC received call from the UTV Theresa L. Wood reporting that the vessel's tow allided with the Louisiana R/R at UMR MM 282.1 in Louisiana, MO. The Theresa L. Wood was upbound pushing 11 empty and 4 loaded dry cargo barges enroute Prairie Du Chien at the time of the incident. There is no reported damage to the bridge or the tow. Pilot stated that a strong cross current in the vicinity of the bridge was the cause of the allision. The Sector OUW called the bridge tender who confirmed that the vessel rubbed the left descending side of the #3 swing span pier of the bridge. He also confirmed that there was no damage and that the bridge is fully operational.

Small passenger vessel FLORIDA FISHERMAN II was returning to John's Pass when it slightly rubbed the corner of an anchored barge.  The barge was anchored and partially stuck out into the channel.  At the same time the passenger vessel was transiting under the bridge, two persons on jet skis came through the bridge in the opposite direction forcing the passenger vessel to move closer to the protruding barge. 

The incident caused minor cosmetic damage to the FLORIDA FISHERMAN II consisting of a 10 inch scratch mid-ship approximately 2 feet above the waterline.

Small passenger vessel FRIENDLY FISHERMAN was coming back into John's Pass when it allided with a deck work barge that was anchored at the corner of the bridge and partially protruding into the channel. Only minor cosmetic damage to the hull of the FRIENDLY FISHERMAN. No injuries as a result of this incident.

23 May 2010: Vessel allided with Clinton Railroad Drawbridge protection cell.  Vessel was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges at time of incident.  No damage incurred to bridge nor boat and no injuries reported.  No further action required, investigation complete.

At approximately 0658 26 May 2010, the M/V BBC RIO GRANDE (9368326) allided with the northeast bridge dolphin of the Ogden St. Bridge in Menominee, MI while transiting up the Menominee River from Lake Michigan.  The M/V BBC GRANDE entered the port under tug assistance provided by the JIMMY L.(643848)  The dolphin navigation light, clearance gauge, and sign sustained damage as a result of the allision.  Bridge is fully operational.  No vessel damage, pollution, waterway restrictions, or injuries.

MSU Chicago notified SLM CC of an allision that took place at the Seneca RR Bridge at MM254 on the Illinois River. The vsl RALPH PLAGGE was pushing 5 loaded hopper barges (corn and soy) and 2 empty hopper barges. One of the loaded barges allided with the bridge. MSU responded and observed minor damage to subject barge and also to the barge immediately to stbd in center string.  Leaking was heard INO96103 and separated kevel and starboard stern corner inset with kevel missing.

On 19 MAY 2010, Sector Upper Mississippi River (SUMR) received a radio call on VHF-FM Channel 16 from the UTV Dick Tomayko reporting that their one loaded grain barge (IN 107022) is aground on an unmarked steel pile IVO MM 181.2 UMR RDB. The #1 bow tank of the loaded barge is currently taking on water. The UTV Dick Tomayko was heading up bound conducting fleeting operations at the time of the incident. The UTV Tripper and the UTV Robert W. Taylor are enroute to assist. The UTV Dick Tomayko also reports that the damaged barge is going to have to be off loaded due to the damage. Western Rivers BNM NR 0164-10 UM applies.

On 22 May 2010 M/V Cooperative Ambassador reporting that an empty barge in the port sting barge (WE 200) allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge at mile marker 282.1 on the Upper Mississippi River. Pilot of the Cooperative Ambassador stated that while transiting through the up bound span of the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge, high flow and current caused his port string to drift to port which caused barge number (WE 200) to allide with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge. No damage to the barge or bridge was reported. M/V Cooperative Ambassador was pushing a total of 15 barges( 12 empty, 2 Caustic Soda (Red Flag), 1 Fertilizer) and their destination is St. Paul, MN.

On May 29, 2010, at approximately 1345, the towing vessel FORT PIKE while pushing two empty barges (side by side), bumped one of the barges to the east side fender system of the Gilmerton Bridge. The barge VMC 202 made contact with the fender system, but there was not any damage to the barge or the fender system. Additionally on June 1, 2010, the Engineer of the Gilmerton Bridge inspected the fender system and found no evidence of damage.

Received a report of the UTV James H. Hunter alliding with the Henry R. Lawrence memorial bridge at MM 63 CMB. Breakaway barges with damage to 1 sand barge. Vsl had 15 loaded non red flag barges. UMIB issued and river closed to vsl traffic. Locals authorities notified and recommended to shut down bridge to vehicle traffic. 

MSU Paducah notified.

HOU 2010/0157: 

On 04Jun10, M/V RICHMOND BRIDGE lost propulsion inbound (Fred Hartman bridge) to the  ITC terminal on the Houston ship channel.  Propulsion loss was approx. 1 minute due to a blown control fuse.  As the result of propulsion loss no damage occurred to the vessel.  Sector Houston was notified by pilot of the loss of propulsion after docking at the ITC terminal. 

Fulfillment of the reporting requirements under 46 CFR 4.05-1 are in question by the vessel.  

In addition, on 07Jun10, at departure from Bolivar anchorage Galveston, TX, the vessel experienced an unrelated equipment failure. The main engines failed to start. See IIA #3760848.  OPCON hold was placed on the vessel in the Bolivar anchorage prior to departing on 08 June, 2010. CG-2692 received and entered as ECN 002.  Sector Houston Investigating officer and a MSU Galveston port state control  member attended the vessel in the Bolivar anchorage for the above mentioned marine casualties. Class surveyor attended vessel to ensure repairs were completed, tested to the satisfactory of the OCMI; OPCON removed. 

Case closed, Enf action to include Civil Penalty LOW.
Main propulsion engine failed to start. Vessel was anchored out a Bolivar Anchorage. Class was requested to verify repairs.

David C. Duvall allided with Texas 35 Bridge (over the Victoria Barge Canal) fendering system. There were no injuries or pollution. There was a 7ft. by 2in. gash above the water to Barge DCBL 73  The only damage to the bridge fendering system was a few bent and broken steel beams. No damage to the bridge itself was reported.

Vessel's Master reported rubbing bridge protection cell at L & I Bridge during upbound transit with 15 loaded coal barges in-tow.  Minor damage discovered aboard lead barge of port string.  The hopper barge (ING 5095) sustained a 9" crack/slit 18" above waterline of the ING 5095.  Transit continues and temp repairs (shingled) effected as precaution.

On 24 April 2010, at approximately 1800 the UTV SONNY IVEY was underway with 6 empty barges approaching the Black Bayou Bridge. The conditions were windy and when they were passing through the starboard stern barge, ACL 9514 B, rubbed the apron which was extended out beyond the fender. No damage was done to the apron or the barge. No pollution, damages, or injuries.

5 Jun 10:  M/V FRED A. BUSSE allided with  SE side of Michigan Street bridge in Sturgeon Bay, WI.  Vessel sustained a mechanical failure, which prevented the vessel from going in reverse.  This resulted in the vessel not being able to stop forward momentum during mooring.  Eight people were on board (6 passengers & 2 crew).  No injuries, pollution, or waterway restrictions.  Bridge has been closed due to bridge repairs since summer 2009.  The only damage to the bridge was scaffold, not the actual bridge.  The vessel's starboard bow guard rail was bent and torn.  No damage to the vessel's hull.  Damage was minor.  Alcohol and drugs are not a causative factor.

Vessel was about to transit beneath the 14th Street Train Bridge when the Captain noticed that he had not lowered the forward mast. At this point the vessel could not be stopped and the mast could not be lowered in time. The mast contacted the bridge and was forced back on to the top of the boat. The mast broke in half, there was no damage to the equipment attached to the mast and no damage to the bridge.

On June 11, 2010, the M/V HERO, a Panamanian registered 800 foot loaded tankship, under the control of two Sabine pilots was inbound on the Sabine Neches waterway enroute to Sun Oil terminal in Nederland, Texas. The ship, carrying crude oil, was assisted in its transit by two tugs - one positioned on either side of the HERO's bow.  While navigating under the Rainbow and Veterans bridges located along the waterway in Port Arthur, Texas, the conning pilot observed that the ship's rudder was not responding to the helmsman. The pilot immediately issued a series of commands that included ordering the tugs to full astern propulsion, the HERO's engines to full astern, and ordering the HERO's crew to drop both port and starboard anchors. These combined actions by the pilot, however, failed to sufficiently stop the vessel's forward momentum enough to avoid an allision with the bridge fendering system and the vessel struck two of the bridge's protective dolphins.  The allision caused significant damage to the bridge's protective dolphins, but the HERO suffered only minor damage. One of the assist tugs similarly suffered only minor damage while the other tug went unscathed.  No injuries were reported to any of the seamen on the HERO or to the seaman on the tugs providing assistance and no pollution was reported.  Shortly after the incident, as the HERO lay anchored near the bridge, the HERO's engineers reportedly determined the cause of the steering casualty, corrected the problem, and the ship was able to complete its transit to the Sun Oil facility in Nederland, Texas without further incident.
Tug allided with Whitestone Expressway overpass, damaging both spotlights on vessel.

M/V William C was pushing ahead 6 barges (5 empty, 1 loaded)  and had lowered the wheel house to transit beneath the Lemont Bridge and was raising back up.  The Master did not see anything out ahead of tow and was letting head of tow widen out to center of the river when he allided with moored barge ART 421 at MM 300.2.   Barge ART 421 broke loose from Artco fleet.  Backed up and tied off.  Requested assist from M/V Mary C to secure Barge that broke loose.  Alcohol testing conducted.

10 June 2010: Vessel's starboard side of tow allided with Fort Madison Drawbridge.  Tow was comprised of 15 loaded dry cargo barges.  No damage incurred to the bridge nor tow.  No further action required, investigation complete.
The Tug and Barge unit allided with a bridge.
On 09APR10 at approximately 1420 the UTV TIGER SPIRIT and its tow transited through the Rigolets Bridge IVO of MM 35 ICW when it allided with the CSX Rigolets Railroad Bridge.
The whip antenna on the German flagged cargo vessel MSC UGANDA struck the underside of the Bayonne Bridge.

On June 23, 2010 at approx 2305, the UTV EVA KELLEY, while transiting north bound with 06 empty hopper barges in vicinity of MM 173.5 of the Black Warrior River, allided with the Naheola Railroad Bridge.  Uninspected hopper barge C-715 made contact with bridge. There is no damage to the vessel. The bridge was inspected and there was no damage found.  No injuries reported.  No further incidents.

23 June 2010, Towing vessel LAYTON I allided with the Sunrise Dr. draw bridge in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Bridge inspectors reported no damage to the bridge. Operator of tug operating vessel without proper license. Towing vessel inspector on scene with vessel. No damage to tug or barge. Light paint scrape on spud of unnamed barge. NOV sent to party via certified mail on 08/03/2010.
M/V Addi Belle reported alliding with the Egners Ferry Bridge MM 41 TNR.

UTV John G Morgan allided with the Bayou Du Large bridge.

No pollution or damage to the barges. Paint scrape damage to the bridge; Bridge is operational.

UTV JOE PATRICK ECKSTEIN was pushing 9 barges (all loaded with grain) en route to St Louis, Missouri.  During the transit at mile marker 835.7 on the Mississippi River the tow brushed up against the Beltline Railroad Bridge.  No damage was done to the bridge nor the barges that struck the bridge.

17 JUN 2010: While down bound on the Upper Mississippi River the M/V KATHY ELLEN allided with the Burlington R/R bridge protection cell (M.M. 403.1). No damage incurred to bridge, vessel, nor barges.  No further action required, investigation complete.

While U/B, the UTV Roberta Tabor (allided) rubbed the lower Pekin Railroad Bridge (MM 151.2 ILW). The pilot stated the cause of the allision was high water. The vessel was pushing 15 empty hopper barges with no Red Flags. Since there was no report of damage or red flags involved. This is a known Truman/Hobbs obstructive bridge. No damage or injuries reported.
Tug MEAGAN ANN allided with a platform attached to the Greenpoint Avenue bridge, damaging their mast.

On 26 June 2010, Received telephone notification from the M/V CAIRO reporting while downbound on the UMR MM 182.5 their radar dish allided with the green light on the McKinley bridge causing a 1" rub mark to the radar scanner.

UTV W.A. KERNAN was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges en route to St. Louis, MO southbound on the Mississippi River.  At mile marker 663.7 the UTV was making a turn with the tow to proceed under Lansing's bridge.  During the maneuver the Master over flanked the turn which resulted in a barge (SCN08121) landing on the left descending protection cell.  No damage was done to the protection cell or barge.

03 JUL 2010: M/V Kathy Ellen allided with the right descending protection cell of Crescent R/R  bridge while transiting downbound.  The allision caused a 4 foot by 3 inch crack in side of barge AGS 251B resulting in flooding of 1 stern void.  No damage to bridge incurred.

04 JUL 2010: UTV Thomas K conducted a controlled landing (allision) on protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge or his barges and no injuries. Vessel was pushing 15 dry cargo barges.

05 JUL 2010: UTV PENNY ECKSTEIN allided with Sabula R/R bridge protection cell. Second stbd side barge (CC-95522) incurred minor damage.  The allision created  an 8" x 10" hole in the in the bow void that flooded.  The vessel was patched and pump placed on barge, controlling flooding until repairs could be made.  No damage incurred to bridge.

At approx. 0130 hours on 18 June 2010 the M/V Jonathan T. Erickson O.N. 500995 was southbound with 9 loaded barges in tow. The starboard barges, AEP - 4002, MEM - 2151 made contact with the protection cell on the Seneca Railroad bridge at MM 254 on the IL River. There was no damage to any of the barges, and also no damage to the bridge.
The M/V OCEAN PRINCESS 1's antenna hit the Arthur Kill Rail Bridge while enroute to Stapleton Anchorage.

The uninspected barge CRIMSON TIDE was being pushed by the UTV SCOTT QUEST and assisted on the port side by the UTV JUDSON B. The UTV's were attempting to transit Northbound through the Chickasaw RR Bridge at MM 3 Mobile River. As the vessels approached the RR Bridge, the JUDSON B was pushing on the port bow of the CRIMSON TIDE to hold it up against the outgoing tide. The JUDSON B stayed on the port side as long as it could  prior to going under the bridge. As the barge neared the bridge the clearance "looked good" at approximately 10', so the JUDSON B backed off to allow transit of the barge. The barge suddenly began moving South  There was a small fishing boat anchored near the pylon and the wheel wash from the JUDSON B put the vessel in immediate danger. This prevented the JUDSON B from adequately maneuvering to prevent the barge from alliding with the bridge. When the barge hit the protection cell it broke 03 boards estimated in value between 12-15K. There was no damage to the barge. Bridge was inspected and no structural damage was noted. No further incidents.
M/V HANNA C. SETTOON PUSHING SMI 30014 & SMI 30015 REPORTEDLY ALLIDED WITH THE WEST LAKE RAILROAD BRIDGE. NO APPARENT DAMAGE TO BRIDGE, VESSEL OR BARGE. NO POLLUTION, INJURIES OR DAMAGE.
Holy Rosary allided with the West Port Arthur Bridge fender works.

On 05 July 2010, loaded sand barge number HSG 19, which was moored to Holiday Sand's unloading dock in Kansas City, MO (mm 360 MOR). The barge began to take on water due to rain collecting inside it's raised deck containment area, causing the sand to shift to the barge's port side, causing a port-side list. Eventually, this list put the port side under water, ultimately causing the barge to flip over & capsize, drop its cargo, and break it's shore lines. The barge drifted 5 miles downriver, through a railroad bridge & 1/2 mile down river from the HWY 291 bridge, (at mm352 MOR). The barge was recovered by the UTV Dakota, and returned to mm 360 MOR.  No damage to the bridges or barge was reported.

UTV Charlie White, while re-positioning some barges in the  ARTCO fleeting area near mile 160.7, on the Illinois River, a barge broke free and struck the Peoria RR Bridge protection cell.  This occurred while attempting to top around 3 barges, a new wire came loose from the winch releasing the barge from the tow. The vessel was pushing 3 total barges (1 empty DAP fertilizer, 1 empty scrap, and 1 empty coal). The empty coal barge (TRI 903 empty coal) struck the bridge protection cell.  No injuries or damage reported to the barge or bridge.

On 10 JUL 10, Sector Upper Mississippi River (SUMR) received a telephone call reporting that the UTV Cindy Celeste struck the right descending pier of the Eads Bridge, UMR MM 180.0, and their tow is currently pinned sideways against the bridge pier. The number of barges, cargo in each barge, extent of the damage caused by the allision, and if there are any barges adrift are unknown at this time.

UTV CHARLIE EVERHEART advised they allided with the Louisville and Nashville railroad draw bridge on the starboard right descending bridge pier at mile marker 190.4 Cumberland River. They were pushing 6 empty non red flag barges and report no damage, injuries, or pollution. 

CSX bridge inspector came out and inspected the bridge and said there was no damage to bridge.

On 11 JUL 2010, SECUMR received a telephone call from the UTV DELL BUTCHER reporting that while transiting up bound on the UMR, they allided with the protection cell of the Louisiana RR bride MM 282.1. UTV Dell Butcher was pushing 16 barges; 9 loaded with slag and various dry cargoes, and 7 empty. No red flag cargoes were in the tow. UTV Dell Butcher reported the 3rd barge back, located on the port string, rubbed against the protection cell. Barge was loaded with slag with no damage. Bridge tender confirmed that it was the protection cell that was rubbed and reported no damage.

SLM CC rcvd a call from M/V Kiowa Master  who was reporting that they rubbed the bridge and had a tow run hard aground. Position was out of the channel on the Illinois River above the EJ&E RRB MM270 on the left descending bank. No damage reported to the bridge or the vessel.  M/V Kiowa was pushing four sand barges.

08 JUL 2010: UTV MIDLAND allided with left descending protection cell of the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge at UMR MM 518.0. No damage was reported to the barge, vessel, or bridge protection cell and no injuries reported.  No further actionr required, investigation complete.
11 JUL 2010: UTV Loyd Murphy's third barge in the starboard string allided with the Burlington R/R D/B protection cell.  No damage to bridge nor vessel incurred.

On 06/24/2010 the 1st Mate was on watch in the pilot house of the TUG ISLAND FOX (O.N. 639266).  Southbound on the Inner Coastal Waterway and approaching the Great Bridge Locks, the ISLAND FOX entered a passing situation with the TUG LORETTA with tow.  The LORETTA was pulling to the side of the channel to allow for a port to port agreed on passing situation.  The LORETTA was pushed up as close to her side as possible.  The ISLAND FOX proceeded to pass the LORETTA to enter the locks.  The operator of the ISLAND FOX noticed that his loaded hopper barge was moving towards the bank due to bank suction, so he tried to pivot his vessel but was unable to prevent the barge from alliding with the  Lock's fendering system.  Two pilings and a section of timber, estimated value of damage is approx $40k.  There was no damage to the barge or tug. Alcohol screening was performed on the 1st mate and deckhand.

21 JUL 2010: UTV Mary Lucy Lane's port lead barge allided with the Crescent Rail Road Drawbridge. High water and current in the area caused the allision. The damage report from the bridge tender was described in a fax to Sector Upper Mississippi River as scrapes and gouges in the concrete of Pier number 3 of the Crescent Railroad Bridge. The damage to barge number IMT-136 was described as a dent 3 feet long and 6 inches deep on the port side near the port bow. No injuries reported.  No further action required, investigation complete.
The Vessels VHF whip antenna hit the bridge, while transiting..

The UTV MARK SHURDEN was underway on the Illinois River with four red flag barges in tow, three loaded and one empty.  As the tow was entering the EJ & E bridge at MM 270.6 it started to get set to Stbd.   The starboard side of the first barge grazed the bridge.  MSU Chicago responders attended the vessel, conducted an investigation and found no damage to the bridge or barge.

UTV TOM FRAIZER was pushing 15 barges (14 loaded dry cargo and 1 empty) down bound on the Mississippi River en route to St Louis, MO.  At mile marker 663, the pilot on watch was maneuvering the tow around a turn in the river then to proceed under the Lansing Highway Bridge.  During the turn; headway on the 1st string of barges was lost and the tow started to go sideways down the river.  The pilot recognized the situation and immediately put both engines full ahead to intentionally ground the first string of barges on the right descending bank.  In doing so the first string of barges grounded, however the tow continued to move sideways down the river which then lead the tow to strike the protection cell around the 3rd and 4th string on the port side of the tow.

The tow was now fully blocking the channel resting bank to bank and resting on the protection cell.  Damage occurred to UTV TOM FRAIZER port rudder (due to grounding on the left descending bank), starboard first string barge (ACBL 3262) with a 4" crack in the bow rake, due to grounding on right descending bank, the 4th port side barge ( WTT 406B) with a crack (12” x ¼”) in the #4 starboard wing tank, due to allision with protection cell, and damage to 4th port string barge with an indent on the transom lap seam, most likely due because of the allision with the protection cell.

MSD Quad Cities received call from Sector UMR CC indicating the UTV Midland had allided with the Clinton RR bridge at Upper Mississippi river MM518. I/O contacted the Captain of the Midland who reported that vessel was pushing 15 barges (10 loaded cement, 2 loaded coal, 3 empty grain) on an up-bound trip. Captain stated that original intentions upon bridge approach was to not make contact; however, strong currents due to high water set vessel over to where the safest action was to make a controlled touch with the bridge cell and top vessel around and proceed through. Capt indicated there was insufficient time to contact bridge ahead of time to inform them of change of intentions.  No damage to vessel or barges reported, No injuries reported. I/O contacted bridge and confirmed no damage to bridge.

23 JUL 2010: UTV Kevin Michael allided with the Fort Madison Draw bridge  D/B UMR MM 383.9.  resulting in a 2 barge breakaway. The 2 barges were  recovered by an assist vessel, the M/V Don Marie. The barge that allided with has a 4 inch inset in the starboard bow knuckle.  No other damage reported.  No further follow up required, investigation complete.

09 AUG 2010: UTV R.W. NAYE's port lead barge (DML 3009) allided with protection cell of Burlington RR Drawbridge protection cell.  No damage incurred to barge nor protection cell.  No further follow up required, investigation complete.

Coast Guard Sector Upper River received a radio call on VHF-FM CH 16 reporting a MS-bridge allision/barge break away. The UTV W.A. Kernan reports they hit the center span of the Hannibal R/R Bridge at MM 309.9 UMR resulting in a 12 barge break away.  Barges are carrying dry cargo, damage to the bridge is unknown at this time, damage to barges is unk at this time.

01 AUG 2010: BILL STEGBAUER allided with the Crescent R.R. Bridge.  No damage incurred to the bridge, vessel, or barges. No injuries occurred as a result of the allision. No further action required, investigation complete.

On 5 Aug 2010, SECTOR NEW ORLEANS received a report from the bridge tender, (Union Pacific Melville RR Bridge at MM 30 Atchafalaya River) that the UTV HERBERT J. PLAISANCE (Crescent Marine Towing; ON 1216424) struck the bridge.  The UTV had 3 loaded rock barges in tow.  While approaching the bridge, the UTV was overcome by the current and pushed sideways, causing the middle barge to strike the bridge. The bridge sustained minor chipping in the concrete pillar; the barge (L1010) sustained a 6 inch gash on the rake and timberhead.  No injuries, secondary casualties or pollution was reported.  The bridge tender reports the bridge is safe and open for traffic.

30 JUL 2010: UTV Jacob Michael Eckstein allided with Sabula Railroad Drawbridge protection cell.  No damage to bridge, barge, nor vessel incurred.  No injuries reported.  No further action required, investigation complete.

30 JUL 2010: UTV ED RENSHAW allided with the Crescent R/R D/B. The Ed Renshaw was downbound pushing 15 empty dry cargo barges enroute Keokuk, IA when the tow was caught by the current and was forced to land on the right descending protection cell of the bridge. All 5 barges in the starboard string of the tow made contact with the cell. There is no reported damage to the vessel, tow or bridge. The bridge tender also reported the allision and confirmed that there was no damage to the bridge.

02 AUG 2010:  UTV Midland allided with the Clinton R/R Bridge (short pier). No damage reported to the vessel, barges, or bridge.  Also, no injuries reported.  No further action required, investigation complete.

On 12 Aug 2010 at approx 2230L UTV JOSEPH  PATRICK ECKSTEIN's tow allided with the Old Greenville River Bridge (no longer operational), MM 531.4 Lower Mississippi River. Tow was 25 hopper barges loaded with grain (corn & soybean) Tow struck the Arkansas side bridge pier with the second to last barge (LTD 708 B) on the port string, resulting in 9 barges breaking-away, and set adrift, from tow. 8 barges recovered that morning by assist vessels in area, the final barge ran aground and eventually pulled off by the Joseph Patrick Eckstein following day13 Aug 2010. Two barges experienced significant damage, LTD 708 B and BUNGE 229. Barge LTD 208 B cleared for transit on 13 Aug 2010 to LaPlace in middle of tow and pumps st-by. Bunge 229 was partially submerged at bow, and during the afternoon 13 Aug 2010, barge sank in place at MM 523 LMR. Dive, salvage, and transit plans approved 14 Aug 2010. 

During transit of Greenville bridges, pilot o/b had a posted pilot, who has not transited area in over 13 yrs,  make the initial approach on bridges. Once pilot recognized the approach was flawed, he attempted to correct course, but was unable to properly align barge and tow to safely transit both bridges. This resulted in the tow's port string alliding with the bridge peir.

UTV CODY BOYD while transiting up bound ILR MM 147.9 collided with a anchored recreational fishing vessel.  Rec boat was anchored in restricted area surrounding Peoria Lock and Dam. Recreation vessel had only minor superficial damage and no injuries were reported.  Illinois Department of Natural Resources conducted initial investigation.

06Aug2010 - At approximately 1635 (local), the tug VANE BROTHERS, while pushing the light tank barge VB-33 on the starboard hip, allided with the Norfolk & Southern Bridge #5 fender system in the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River (Norfolk, Virginia).  The company notified the Coast Guard Sector Hampton Roads Command Center.  An investigation into the incident revealed no damage to the fender system, the tank barge VB-33 or injuries.  Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was conducted on all involved crewmembers of the tug and barge by the marine employer.  See findings of fact for additional details.

On 15 Aug 2010 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from the Florence Highway bridge tender, reporting an allision and explained that UTV Mark Shurden had allided with the upper left descending protection cell of the Florence Highway drawbridge at mile marker 56.0 on the Illinois River. Bridge Tender could not confirm whether there was any damage to the protection cell because the incident occurred at night. Sector Upper Mississippi River contacted the UTV Mark Shurden on VHF-FM channel 16 and requested the pilot to contact the Sector Upper Mississippi River command center at 314-269-2332. The pilot of the UTV called Sector Upper Mississippi River and confirmed that they had allided with the Florence Highway drawbridge's upper left descending protection cell. UTV Mark Shurden was heading down bound to New Orleans, LA with 3 loads of Slurry and 1 empty barge while transiting through the Florence Highway drawbridge.  Master of the UTV stated that the combination of "current and misjudging the set" caused his loaded port stern barge of Slurry, MM 68, to allied with the protection cell. The following is a description of the damage to barge number MM 68: "about 250 feet from the rake of the barge is a dent that is a 1/4 inch deep and 20 feet long. The height of the dent starts 4 feet from the waterline and appears to run all the way to the keel of the barge." The barge has a maximum draft of 12 feet. UTV Mark Shurden was drafting 8'9" at the time of the incident. Master of the UTV reported that the barge MM 68 was not leaking any product or taking on any water. No injuries were reported. Sector Upper Mississippi River made all notifications in accordance with the Sector Upper Mississippi River response matrix. Sector Upper Mississippi River Duty IO conducted a preliminary investigation of this incident and concluded that this is a reportable marine casualty and will conduct an on scene investigation at Mel Price Lock and Dam at mile marker 200.8 on the Upper Mississippi River. The UTV Mark Shurden is expected to arrive at Mel Price lock and dam tomorrow 16 AUG 10 at 1630 GMT.

17 AUG 2010: UTV Mary Elizabeth allided with the Clinton railroad drawbridge. While making an approach to transit through the Clinton railroad drawbridge, misjudgment of the river current in the area caused the barge  FMT 2903 to allide with the upper right descending protection cell.  The allision did not cause any damage to the barge or the protection cell. No injuries and pollution were reported. Investigation complete.
Bridge tender of the Two Mile Landing Bridge in Cape May reported that the CFV VOYAGER - ON: (1160897), struck the bridge fendering system pilings, causing some minor splintering of the structure.

27 AUG 2010: UTV Prairie Dawn allided with Clinton R/R D/B at MM 518.0 UMR. Barge JB51B made contact with the left descending protection cell. The operator of the tow reported the allision as a controlled landing. There was no damage incurred to either the bridge nor barge.

On  August 24, 2010, at approx 1630,  the UTV MARGARET while pushing four empty uninspected barges and one crane barge laid its tow against the fender system of the Pascagoula River Bridge during a controlled landing.  Barge BIG413 was the only barge that made contact with the fendering system of the bridge.  The bridge tender was notified and no bridge or barge damage was reported.  No injuries reported and no further incidents.

13JUL2010: While enroute to Majuro, Marshal Islands with barge in tow, the starboard main engine was secured in order to change out fuel filters. When the engine was restarted it ran roughly and then quit. Trouble shooting was performed underway, however the engine was not able to be restarted. Vessel diverted to Chuuk for repairs. Company maintenance personnel attended the vessel and found several issues with the engine which are specified in the engineer's statement.

Alleged gross negligence on behalf was reported by the C/E against the master and company. C/E stated that the vessel got underway in an unseaworthy condition. C/E was relieved due to "mismatched personalities." The 2nd Engineer was fleeted up to the C/E position. He reportedly admitted to raping a young lady and getting away with the crime. USCG SIO referred the lead to CGIS to follow-up on. CGIS contacted the DA for the region the charges were filed in hope to provide additional key witnesses for prosecution. 

The first notice of the incident occurred was received by Sector Guam's CID on the 16th of July. Incident occurred on the 13th of July.  Sector Guam initiated enforcement pending approval and adjudication of previous violations for the same offense. The offense for failure to make immediate notification (3rd offense) and failure to submit timely 2692 (first offense) were referred by the SIO. COTP requested historical background data for Cabras Marine and affiliates. Background check reveled a multitude of violations or varying sorts.

02Sep2010 - It was reported that the M/V DOVE (O.N. 720745) allided with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge.  The vessel was northbound stern ahead from CEC terminal (Dominion) heading to Cape Charles, Virginia anchorage in anticipation of Hurricane Earl.  It was being assisted by three Moran tugs at the time of the incident.  The APRIL MORAN was the lead tug (aft/centerlead); the WENDY MORAN was made up to the fwd/centerlead pushing on the vessel's port bow; the CAPE HATTERAS was on the vessel's fwd/starboard side.  The City of Chesapeake engineering department came out and verified that there was no damage to the fender system or the bridge.  The vessel did not sustain any damage.  No further action was required.

While transiting through the Bayou Dularge Bridge in Houma, LA., the stern spud on the unloading crane barge LA  # GD 984 hit the lower girder plate on the bottom of the bridge and bent the spud barge approximately 45 degrees.

Drug and alcohol tests were conducted.

On 03SEP10 at 0252Z, Sector New Orleans received call from bridge operator that the tugboat Herbert J. Plaisance hit the span lights and the navigational lights. The allision was heard by the bridge operator and noticed that the tow lights of the vessel where also out.

The vessel was westbound in the GIWW at approximately mile marker 35.5.  The Captain shone the spotlight on the bridge clearance sign, and misread 45' instead of 35'.  Upon realizing that the vessel's mast would not clear the bridge, astern propulsion was engaged.  The vessel proceeded under the bridge with the mast striking and damaging one of the lights marking the center structure of the bridge.  The vessel's mast was bent back approx. 45-degrees, damaging one anchor light and one masthead light.  Bridge personnel and USCG were notified of the incident.  Subsequent follow-up inspections and conversations revealed no add'l known damages.

On 5 Sept 2010 Upper Mississippi River (UMR) Mile Marker (MM) 535.0, Sabula Railroad (R/R) Drawbridge (D/B).

River Master reporting that their third barge out in their starboard string (INO 85137) allided with the right descending bridge pier of the Sabula R/R D/B. The UTV John M. Rivers is pushing 15 empty coal barges heading down bound to St. Louis, MO. No damage was reported to the bridge pier or the affected barge. 14 SEP 10 - UTV ISLAND PROGRESS pushing the deck barge SJ 199 heading northbound on Wappo Creek towards the Ashley River in Charleston, SC allieded with the wood fendering system of the Wappo Creed Bridge. The Bridge Tender on the Bridge reports the UTV may have allided with the bridge's fender system harder than normal.  The UTV was towing a barge astern with a tail tug assisting northbound on the river. The tail tug reports the barge did rub the fenders, but did not cause any damage that they could see.

01MAR07:  The UTV R. T. ENTERKIN allided with the Hwy 278 bridge at Hilton Head Island, SC. while transiting southbound in the ICW.  SCDOT was notified immediately.  Contact occurred between the vessel's port side tire fenders and the fenders on the bridge column.  No damage was reported to either the vessel or the bridge.  No injuries.  No pollution.

UTV David L Griggs allided with the Dubuque rail road bridge down bound at UMR MM 579.9. The starboard side of the tow lightly rubbed the east (left descending) side of the turn pier. There was no damage to the tow or bridge

SITUATION: At 1913L, the Niantic Bridge Operator notified the SCC that the TUG FIREFLY towing a Crane Barge allided with the bridge while transiting in bound.
