On 1 OCT 2010, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (SUMR CC) received a telephone call from the Bridge Tender on the Louisiana R.R. Bridge UMR Mile Marker 282.1 stating that the UTV BILLY WAXLER allided with their bridge. The Bridge Tender stated that no damage occurred as a result of the allision. SUMR CC contacted the UTV BILLY WAXLER and filled out a standard towing vessel incident report. The UTV BILLY WAXLER was pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges at the time of the incident (0415Z). The Pilot on the UTV BILLY WAXLER stated that no damage occurred to either their towing vessel of their tow as a result. The barge that rubbed the bridge was their port stern barge. UTV BILLY WAXLER was heading Northbound at the time of incident enroute to Clinton, IA.

CH 9970 while under the control of the UTV LAURIE BECNEL allided with the Lower Pekin Rail Road Bridge LDB lower protection cell at MM 151 on the Illinois River. UTV LAURIE BECNEL was pushing 12 dry cargo barges at the time of the incident. Lower Pekin Rail Road Bridge LDB lower protection cell was completely destroyed as a result of the allision, knocking it into the channel.  The Illinois river was closed until such time as it could be removed. No damage was sustained to the barges, the towing vessel, or the bridge, and no injuries occurred as a result.

On 28SEP10 the master of the M/V MISTER T, while waiting for a bridge opening, positioned his vessel along a dolphin which was part of the Ferry Street Bridge fendering system.  Upon bridge opening the vessel departed from its resting point and pushed the fendering dolphin over.  No personnel injuries were reported. The actual bridge and MISTER T were not damaged. Damage repair estimate for the dolphin is below $10,000.

CG Sector New York received a report that a U.S. flagged, uninspected deck barge involved in the deconstruction of the Willis Avenue bridge over the Harlem River in the Port of New York grounded, flooded and subsequently sank as it was moored starboard side to, the Bronx, NY.  An Investigating Officer and representative from the Waterways Management Division arrived on scene to evaluate and coordinate Sector New York's response efforts.

UTV BAXTER SOUTHERN was pushing 3 empty red flag barges (anhydrous ammonia) down bound on the Upper Mississippi River, when the lead starboard barge struck an observation pier along the river as well as striking the Hastings Lift Bridge protection cell. The starboard lead barge (CF 103) received damage near the port bow section just above the bilge knuckle with a 1-2' insert approximately 4-6' in length.  In addition, the port stern box received damage consisting of 6”-12” insert along a 10' vertical section.   The tow configuration was arranged with two lead barges with the third barge behind the port lead barge.  Both lead barges were being pushed stern forward.  The tow previously had just past under highway 61 bridge.  The tow was somewhat diagonal to river when they came out under the bridge.  Highway 61 Bridge is just south of a bend in the river.  When the tow came out of the bend and under Highway 61 Bridge, the current push the tow towards the right descending bank.   The Mate on watch tried backing astern and towards the left descending bank, but the current was too strong and push the lead barge onto the structures.  The observation post received damage to handrail and the protection cell received a 5” crack.  Post chemical testing was conducted on the mate with negative results.  Due to the damage to CF 103, an 835 was issue to conduct repairs with the COI removed.

On 09 OCT 2010, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a report from the UTV L.J. SULLIVAN via VHF-FM that they allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge at Mile Marker 282.1 along the Right Descending Bank. UTV L.J. SULLIVAN was pushing 15 barges at the time of incident (1 loaded Caustic Soda, 1 loaded cotton seed oil, and 13 empty hopper barges). UTV L.J. SULLIVAN reported no damage was done to the bridge, vessel, or the tow. SUMR contacted the Bridge Tender and confirmed no damage. Duty Investigator followed up with a telephone interview of the Bridge Tender and Pilot confirming no damage. On 10 OCT 2010 Sector personnel visited vessel, confirming no damage.

M/V Bethany Dawn had an allision with the Cairo bridge at MM 1.4 on the Upper Mississippi River. The vessel was down bound pushing 16 loaded rock barges. The port stern barge struck the bridge causing 13 of the 16 barges to break free. All 13 barges grounded outside the channel and were recovered. The bridge was inspected and cleared.

17 AUG 2010: UTV Capt Richard Sides had allided with the upper protection cell of the Sabula railroad draw bridge. No damage to the bridge nor vessel incurred and no injuries reported.  No further action required, investigation complete.

On 28 September 2010 the UTV VIRGINA INGRAM reported that they made a controlled landing on the Dubuque RR Bridge mm 579.9 UMR due to high water. UTV has twelve barges (2 RF, 1 loaded linseed oil, 1 empty caustic soda) and a loaded corn barge made slight contact with the protection cell.  Bridge tender confirmed there was no damage and only slight contact was made.
06 OCT 2010: UTV Coral Dawn allided with the Burlington R/R bridge protection cell while pushing 15 loaded various dry cargo barges. No damage was incurred to bridge, vessel, nor barges.
On October 4th 2010 the UTV JONATHAN T. ERICKSON reported a allison between the starboard stern of Barge RF-608B with the Clinton Railroad Bridge. No damage incurred to bridge, barge, nor vessel.

12 OCT 2010: UTV Butch Barras allided with the Sabula R/R D/B port protection cell while pushing 1 barge of soy bean with a draft of 9' 3". No injuries were reported and there was no damage incurred to the bridge nor vessel.

07 OCT 2010: UTV Tom Frazier had an allision with the Sabula R/R bridge protection cell. No damage was reported to the bridge.  There was minor damage to one barge consisting of a small dent (BLB 9171) and a slow leak in barge (ACL 4122). Less than one inch of water was in the void, which was controlled. Allision was caused by strong currents in area
UTV EDMUND loss steering at MM 152 on the Illinois River will assisting the UTV TERRI C through the Pekin Lower Rail Road Bridge. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident.

On 8 Oct 2010 at approximately 0830 hrs the UTV RACHELLE MARIE allided with the CSX MM14 railroad bridge.  Vessel was pushing 8 empty rock barges northbound while attempting to line up with the bridge, the Captain was steering hard to starboard and when he attempted to steer the vessel to port the steering did not respond . The UTV struck the bridge fendering system with the lead starboard barge causing approximately $80,000.00 dollars worth of damage.  CSX inspectors have cleared the bridge for normal operations. After doing an inspection the Captain of the UTV was advised that the backup battery for the steering system had failed and caused the steering casualty. Repairs were made to the UTV's steering system. No further incidents.
On Oct 15 2010 Received a radio call on VHF-FM Channel 16 from the UTV GREGORY DAVID reporting he allided with the Crescent R/R D/B.  No damage reported to bridge and minor damage to barge incurred.

16 OCT 2010: UTV AARON F. BARRETT allided with the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge at MM 535 Upper Mississippi due to strong currents in the area. No damage to the vessel, barges, or bridge resulted from the allision.
No further action required, investigation complete.

On October 17, 2010, at 0606 local time the M/V VENICE BRIDGE (O.N. 9293442) reported an air leak on the #2 exhaust valve.  The vessel was transiting outbound the Port of  Long Beach en route to Oakland, CA.  The vessel was coming up to full engine ahead when it experienced heavy vibration of the main engine.   The vessel proceeded to the F-12 Anchorage to conduct emergency repairs.  The sealing ring on the #2 Exhaust Valve was found to be worn resulting in the air leak.  The sealing ring was replaced.  A test of the Main Engine was conducted in the presence of Port State Control Inspectors and was determined to be operating satisfactorily..

On Sunday, October 17, 2010, a commercial assistance towing vessel, (hereinafter referred to as "SEA TOW DUSKY") with one person onboard and an unnamed recreational bass boat (hereinafter referred to as "BASS BOAT") with two persons onboard were operating on the James River near Newport News, Virginia.  At approximately 0949, the SEA TOW DUSKY was traveling in the main channel upriver in a northwest direction towards the James River Bridge (US-17/258/32) at an approximate speed of 41 mph.  The BASS BOAT was traveling southwest and parallel to the James River Bridge on the bridge's northwest side at approximately 45-51 mph.  At approximately 0950, the SEA TOW DUSKY passed through the James River Bridge's main channel vertical-lift span without slowing down and upon exiting struck the BASS BOAT's port side.  The SEA TOW DUSKY ramped over the BASS BOAT, flipped to port ejecting the operator and capsized.  The operator of a nearby recreational vessel (hereinafter referred to as the "GOOD SAMARITAN") heard the collision, responded and retrieved the operator from the water.  The GOOD SAMARITAN notified the Coast Guard and with the assistance of the SEA TOW DUSKY operator, attempted to render assistance to the BASS BOAT, which had come to an abrupt stop and was drifting downriver.  The BASS BOAT was significantly damaged and the passenger was fatally injured.   The operator suffered severe injury.  The SEA TOW DUSKY had hull damage and the operator was seriously injured.

Enforcement recommendations:
1) Forward evidence to the Virginia Commonwealth Attorney’s Office for their review of possible violation of Virginia Code.
2) Pursue Personnel Action (S&R) against operator of SEA TOW DUSKY, a credentialed mariner.

No Safety Recommendations offered.

Recommend this activity be closed.

On October 27, 2010, at 1935, the Tug TIM QUIGG was made up to the port quarter of tank barge DAVID FANNING en route to LA 187.5 in the Cerritos Channel. The vessel began its approach toward the Henry Ford Bridge, when the barge began setting to the North of the channel. The master made steering corrections to regain course down the center of the channel. The barge began to set to the South as it transited underneath the bridge. The Master initially attempted to correct the crab angle, but chose to take all way off due to the proximity of the barge to the bridge. The barge bow rake made contact with the cement East bridge abutment on the port side approximately 6-8 feet above the waterline. The master backed the tug and tow out from underneath the bridge, and proceeded to intended destination by transiting around the ocean side of the port. The impact did not puncture the barge, nor was there extensive damage to the bridge aside from broken cement. There were no injuries to personnel, nor did any pollution enter the water.

UTV J.B. KLEINPETER was pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges northbound on the Mississippi River. At mile marker 699, the tow was proceeding through the La Crosse Rail Road Bridge, where the starboard lead barge struck the bridge's protection cell. The Master stated the wind pushed the tow more towards the left descending bank of the river then he anticipated. The wind was out of the northwest at 10 knots.  No damage was done to either the barge or the protection cell.

01 NOV 2010: UTV J. Andrew Eckstein (581143) allided with a protection cell and sheet pilings of the bridge. No damage was reported on the bridge. The vessel reported that the port forward barge (AEP94119) allided with the sheet piling causing the starboard back barge (AEP7226) to allide with the protection cell. No damage was reported to either barge. Two cables on the barges came loose and had be to reattached. The UTV was heading downbound while pushing 15 grain barges.

24 OCT 2010: UTV Andrea Leigh allided with the Crescent Railroad bridge while heading downbound and pushing 9 barges(9 empties).  UTV Andrea Leigh stated that high wind and river current caused barge number SER 214 (empty) to allide with the Crescent Railroad Bridge at mile marker 481.5 on the Upper Mississippi River causing the port string to break away.  Damage was reported for this incident and described as follows: bent rake on barge SER 214.

UTV MIDLAND was pushing 6 loaded dry cargo barges southbound on the Mississippi River, en route St Louis, MO.  The Master on watch maneuvered the tow to proceed under the La Crosse Railroad Bridge on the right descending bank side. While proceeding through the starboard stern barge struck the protection cell of the bridge.  The barge was located on the third string starboard side. Deckhands conducted a damage survey of the barge and found no damage, while the bridge tender reported back no damage to the protection cell.

UTV PHYLLIS was pushing 9 loaded dry cargo barges south bound on the Mississippi River en route to St Louis, MO.  At mile marker 699.8 one of the barges (PML 618B) in the tow struck the La Crosse Rail Road bridge protection cell.  The barge was located on the second string port side.  No damage was done to barge, the protection cell received damage to two timbers. The UTV and tow was proceeding under the bridge on the left descending bank side.  The Mate on watch was unable to compensate the tow when the current push it towards the left descending bank.

Barge CC 9279 allided with protection cell on the Lower Pekin Rail Road Bridge while under the control of UTV BECKY ANN at mile marker 151.2 of the Illinois River. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident.

UTV ARDYCE RANDALL was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges south bound on the Mississippi river en route St Louis MO.  The tow was setting up for a bend in the river and then to proceed under the Lansing Railroad Bridge.  The mate on watch slowed the tow and was maneuvering for a left flanking turn, however too much current got caught on the starboard stern side which pushed the tow towards the left descending bank.  The tow then landed on the bridge's protection cell causing the tow of barges to breakaway.  Barge AT 715 (located on the third string port side) received damage due to the allision.  The damage consisted of 9' gash causing water to enter the void wing tanks.  The cargo envelope remained intact.   None of the breakaway barges received damage and remained north of the bridge's protection cell.  Several assist tugs arrived on scene and assisted in securing the barges.  Flooding was control in barge AT 715 and shored within the wing tank.  Several pumps were placed onboard and were able to keep up with the flooding.  The tow was remade up and the damage barge placed in the middle for further protection during the transit.  Bridge officials check the structure and the protection cell and only found a minor crack within the cell.

UTV Roberta Tabor was pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges southbound on the Mississippi River en route to St Louis Mo.  While transiting through La Crosse Rail Road Bridge, two of the barges in the tow struck the protection cell of the bridge.  No damage was done to either the barges or the protection cell.  The tow was on the right descending side of the bridge, when the current push the tow further to the right then the Master on watch anticipated.  Once the allision occurred the Master brought the tow to a stop and then proceeded through.  The Master did not notify the Coast Guard until 24 hours.  The Master was not fully aware of the reporting requirement.

UTV Larry Y. Strain allided with the left descending pier on the Cairo bridge at mile 1.3 IMR. Vessel was pushing 25 loaded coal barges and hit with the port stern barge. 07NOV2010 At 0050 local time the UTV Dennis C. Bottroff was traveling SB pushing 29 loaded barges and 1 empty barge. An assist vessel arrived on-scene and re-captured the 3 adrift barges, and returned them to the tow. some of the cargo was lightered off of the damaged barges. The tow was then re-secured and then continued on its SB journey.

On 11/8/2010 at about 10:00, the fishing vessel ABRACADABRA, O.N. 612315, was underway in the Wilmington Canyon area of the Atlantic Ocean, about 90 miles east of Ocean City, MD fishing for squid. The coupling connecting the drive shaft to the tail shaft failed and the vessel lost propulsion. The cause of the failure was improper assembly in that the shaft retention nut in the drive shaft portion of the coupling had not been installed in 2007, the last yard period in which work had been done on the shaft. This allowed the coupling to slip off of the drive shaft causing a loss of motion in the tailshaft. The vessel was towed back to Cape May, NJ where repairs were effected.

On December 24, 2010, Coast Guard Sector San Francisco's Inspections Division received a call from the Marine Superintendent of the company that manages the ferry MARIN reporting that the MARIN had a loss of propulsion in the vicinity of the Larkspur Ferry Terminal, with passengers on board at approximately 1145 local time on the same date as notification.  The starboard Main Diesel Engine (MDE) shut down while maneuvering in the basin due to air in the fuel line.  The MARIN returned to the terminal and disembarked all passengers.  No injuries, pollution or damage was reported.  

The MARIN was removed from service so that maintenance personnel could affect repairs.  The mechanics traced the supply system, and noted some unions and valve packings to be sufficiently loose thus allowing air into the supply piping.  They tightened all connections, purged the fuel system, and the engine started normally.  They ran the engine at various speeds for about an hour with satisfactory results.  The MARIN underwent sea trials with satisfactory results.  The Duty Marine Inspector (DMI) responded on-scene and through interviews with the maintenance personnel it was determined that air in the line was the cause of the casualty.  The DMI witnessed satisfactory sea trials and cleared the verbal 835 given to the vessel.  See activity # 3916513.  Drug and alcohol testing was not administered.

On December 17, 2010 at 0630 local time, the M/V MARIN was maneuvering near the Larkspur Ferry Terminal when the vessel's port Main Diesel Engine (MDE) stopped operating.  No passengers were on board at the time of the occurrence.  The MARIN immediately returned back to the dock and the crew was reassigned to a different vessel.  The Ferry Maintenance Staff restarted the engine and discovered a faulty fuel pressure modulating valve that was allowing engine RPM to fluctuate beyond the control of the electronic governor at low RPM. The fuel modulator valve was replaced and the problem corrected.  No pollution or personnel injuries occurred as a result of this casualty.

On December 18, 2010 at 1302 local time, the Sector San Francisco's Investigations Office (IO) received notification of this reportable marine casualty via fax.  A phone interview with the Ferry Company's Operations Manager revealed the reason that immediate notification of this incident was not given to the local Coast Guard was due to a companywide misconception that since passengers were not on board at the time of the occurrence it was not a reportable marine casualty.  The Operations Manager was made aware of the laws and regulations pertaining to immediate notification of marine casualties to the local Coast Guard.  The Operation's Manager was also made aware that the company could receive civil penalty action for this violation.  A Notice of Violation (NON) is recommended. 

On March 29, 2011, it was determined by the Sector Commander that the NOV, as issued in this case, should be rescinded and the Enforcement Action (EA) Case Status changed to closed opened in error.  In addition, the IO was instructed to instead issue the Company (Owner and Operator) a Letter of Warning (LOW) in lieu of a civil penalty (previous NOV) for failure to timely notify the Coast Guard of the casualty.  In the addition, the Master will receive an LOW for failure to make the required notification as well. 

Commencing immediately, Sector Policy will be to upon the first violation (failure to immediately notify the CG of a marine casualty), (1) to provide verbal and written education about the reporting requirements; (2) second violation, issue a Letter of Warning (LOW) to the Owner/Operator/Master as appropriate, for non/late notifications of reportable Marine Casualties; and (3) for all subsequent violations, issue NOVs in successively increasing amounts as per current CG guidance.  Verbal and written education has been provided to the Owner/Operator and Master of the regulations and laws governing notification of Marine Casualties.  In addition, LOWs to the Owner/Operator and Master will be issued in lieu of the previously recommended NOV and as part of the effort to ensure continued history building within the MISLE database.

On December 27, 2010 at approximately 1330 local time, the Sector San Francisco Inspection Division received a call from the Marine Superintendent of the company that manages the M/V MARIN (ferry).  He stated that the MARIN had a reduction of propulsion near the Harding Rock buoy with passengers on board.  The reduction gear on the starboard Main Diesel Engine (MDE) slipped out of gear (ahead clutch/propulsion) while the vessel was en route to the Sausalito, California Dock  The MARIN continued on to the terminal using the port engine only and disembarked all passengers.  No injuries, pollution, or damage was reported. 

The MARIN was removed from service by the company and a verbal no sail CG-835 was issued by the Duty Marine Inspector (DMI).  The company's in house mechanics determined the cause of the slippage was due to a damaged ahead rotary oil union.  The union was replaced and the engine and reduction gear were tested sat.  The Duty Marine Inspector (DMI) responded on and witnessed satisfactory sea trials and cleared the verbal 835 given to the vessel.  See activity # 3916796.  No further action is recommended.  Drug and alcohol testing was not administered.

On December 28, 2010 the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) BILL SEYMOUR with 2 tank barges loaded with jet fuel was underway westbound on the GICWW when the lead barge of the tow (FMT 3036) allied with the BLACK BAYOU pontoon bridge. The bridge suffered some mechanical damage, in way of the bridge's pivot arm system which force the bridge to remain open to marine traffic however it was not functional for road traffic. No injuries, pollution and no damage to the vessel resulted. See IO statement for more details.

On February 7, 2011 the Black Bayou pontoon bridge was repaired and place back into service.

Received call from the Master of the UTV OMAR pushing 11 barges, 3 were red flag, that they had allided with the  E J & E Railroad Bridge on the IL River at MM 270.6.  No damage was reported to the barges or the railroad bridge.

Coast Guard Marine Inspectors/Investigators attended and verified that there was no sign of any damage.

Barge MEM 1845 allided with LDB upper protection cell of the Pekin Lower Railroad Bridge at MM 151.2 of the Illinois River while under the control of the UTV THOMAS E. ERIKSON. UTV THOMAS E. ERICKSON was pushing 6 dry cargo barges, with barge MEM 1845 located at the lead of the port string. Barge MEM 1845 sustained a 12" x 1" crack on port side at the number 4 void, no damage was report to bridge. No injuries occurred during this incident.

4 Jan 2010: Sector Lake Michigan Command Center received a report from the Pilot onboard the UTV Luke Burton stating that they had  made a controlled landing on the EJ&E Rail Road Bridge at approximately 2350 (local). The CBC had made contact with the port cell.  This morning after the pilot was relieved from his watch went out on deck and discovered that the CBC 223 sustained 02 cracks (1 approximately 2ft down from top and another approximately 6 in and parted two lashing wires within the tow. 

The barge contains benzene, a red flag, hazardous cargo. The Master claims that the contents is secure and is not leaking. They are underway, currently in the Marseilles Locks and en route to Ottawa, IL to take on an additional load.

Coast Guard Inspectors/Investigators attended the vessel on 5 Jan and conducted a damage survey under Activity #3921712. 

Issued PTP allowing the barge to proceed and effect repairs at Southwest Shipyard in Houston, Texas.

The M/V BEARCAT advised that while headed down bound they allided with the Southern Railway Bridge, MM 647 Tennessee River.  The allision occurred due to swift current. Their final destination is MM 463 Tennessee River. There was no damage/pollution/or injuries reported by the BEARCAT or bridge representatives.  Following report of incident, Southern Railroad dispatched a bridge inspector.  Results of bridge survey indicated no damage.

On January 6, 2011 the tug GOOSE CREEK was towing an approximately 1800-foot "dragon tow" of dredging vessels and their equipment through the Gilmerton Bridge opening.  The tugs FALCON and SHAMROCK were on scene assisting. As the last section of the tow, the pipe barge RANDALL, approached the bridge fendering system the tug FALCON over corrected the RANDALL's position and it allided with the Northeast side of the fendering system and prepositioned signage.  The tug SHAMROCK pushed the RANDALL from the fendering system and through the channel.  Minimal damage sustained on the fendering system and posted sign.  Minor paint scraping found on the RANDALL.  No damage to the SHAMROCK or FALCON.  Chemical testing was conducted. Recommend no further action to include enforcement.

On 09JAN2011 at approx 1400 LCL the M/V CHRISTOPHER M. PARSONAGE, while heading southbound on the Lower Mississippi River, sustained a head-on allision of its port lead barge with the Helena, AR (Hwy 49) bridge pier (left descending pier on AR side), LMR MM 662. Allision determined to be a result of a navigational miscalculation on the part of the Pilot. Pilot stated that while setting up for his approach through the bridge, his tow was caught in a left-hand draft towards the bridge pier. The entire port string in the tow sheared off upon contact. The lead barge (AEP 7513) sustained heavy bow damage and sank approx 1000-1200 ft south of the bridge and approx 600 ft from the AR bank in the channel; remaining partially buoyant by the stern. Sector LMR issued UMIB closing river from MM 663 to 660. The bridge was also closed to traffic until safety inspection was made. The barge was loaded with soybeans. The 4 other barges in the sheared off string were captured by an assist vessel and restored to the tow. Subsequently over night the sunken AEP 7513 was moved out of the channel towards the LDB where it was marked with a lighted wreck buoy. Salvage operation was conducted by J. O. Smith Salvage Co. Barge successfully salvaged on 18JAN11.
Accu X pushing two empties had an allision with the Westlake Railroad Bridge Fendering System while traveling southbound. No damage, injuries or pollution reported.

UTV Holy Rosary with UTV Connor P as assist were pushing 6 open hopper barges eastbound on ICW. During approach to bridge allided with work barge and fendering system of Black Bayou Bridge. No injuries, pollution, or damage resulted from the incident.

The towing vessel Chamorro secured the stbd main engine due to a noise in the reduction gear. The engine was put on standby for emergency and maneuvering only. The vessel then proceeded to the nearest island for repair.

On  21-JAN-11@ 0545  received a report that the UTV ORCA ONE pushing 6 barges loaded with limestone, allided Simmesport RR bridge at MM 4.8 on the Atchafalaya River.  Damage was sustained on the lead barge (901 MMD)  which was a hairline fracture below the water line.  One tow wire snapped during the allision.   The vessel continued its voyage to New Iberia.  There were no pollution, injuries or secondary casualties reported.

On Jauary 24, 2011, at 1315, Sector New Orleans received notification that the UTV PARACLETE pushing 6 loaded salt barges allided with the fendering system of the Wagner Bridge at MM 12 on the GICWW. No injuries, no pollution reported.

At approximately 1600 on 05 Feb 2011, the UTV AMBER BRITTANY (646598, Imperial Towing) was underway at OHR 184.3 with 19 empty hoppers when strong winds and current set the tow into the left descending pier of the Chessie Baltimore and Ohio RR bridge. The allision caused damage to the port side below the waterline just aft of the rake turn on CTC 961.

The Towing Vessel DOTTI J. allided with fendering system on the approach to the Figure Eight Island Bridge.  Only minor damage to the fendering system was reported by the bridge tender.  Bridge operations were not impacted.

On 16FEB11, Sector New Orleans received a report that the UTV RENEE T. WHATLEY, pushing the barge AX 3202, rubbed the barge on the fendering system of the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge while transiting southbound on the Atchafalaya River. There were no reports of pollution, damage, or injuries associated with this incident.
On 17AUG10, at 1330 the UTV Born Again was pushing the crane barge LEVIATHON. The ramp of the LEVIATHON struck the 4th St. Bridge on the Harvey Canal. No injuries, no pollution reported.

UTV CORAL DAWN (Barge TRL325R5) allided with the left descending bank protection cell at the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Bridge (AKA Pekin Railroad Drawbridge). The UTV CORAL DAWN was pushing 6 loaded dry cargo barges at the time of incident (grain, soy beans, cornmeal.) The operator stated that he did not hold close enough to the right descending pier and had too much slide which resulted in the port string making contact with the protection cell causing two wires to be broken.  No damage to barge or bridge, pollution, or injuries reported.

UTV CAPT. RICHARD SIDES allided with the Lower Pekin RR D/B, ILR, MM 151.2 IVO Mapleton, IL. The allision caused several wires on the tow to break.  The M/V BECKY ANN and EDMUND L assisted the UTV CAPT. RICHARD SIDES in putting his tow back together. The UTV CAPT. RICHARD SIDES was U/B pushing 5 liquid fertilizer tank barges (uninspected barges) enroute Hennepin, IL.  No other damage or injuries were reported with this incident.  No damage to the bridge was reported. Vessel safely resumed transit.

On 02 MAR 2011, Sector New Orleans received notification that the UTV JOHN G. MORGAN, pushing six empty open hopper barges, allided with a concrete dauphin which is part of the bridge fendering system of the Belle Chasse Rail Road Bridge on the Algiers Canal Mile Marker 5 GIWW. No damage, no pollution or injuries reported.

While transiting north through the Intracoastal Waterway, the UTV JENNY, pushing the barge CEE BEE 21, became set by current and wind subsequently allided with the Blackburn Point Bridge.  Barge CEE BEE 21 contacted bridge fender system on port side; bridge and vessel sustained minor surface abrasions.  FDOT conducted dive survey of bridge; results indicated bridge did not sustain structural damage.  UTV JENNY and barge CEE BEE 21 were not damaged, no injuries, pollution, or waterways closure.

M/V NARODNY BRIDGE while transiting inbound on the Houston Ship Channel experienced a temporary loss of propulsion due to the pilot lowering the speed too quickly.  The VSL has a variable pitch propeller, and lower the speed too quickly overloaded the computer which triggered a shutdown of the main engine.

The UTV CAPTAIN ED (O.N. 511777) was made fast to the port side stern quarter of the Hopper Barge 6001 (O.N. 1144192). The CAPTAIN ED was pushing the 6001 from Craney Island to the Norfolk Dredging Company's property near the Gilmerton Bridge in Chesapeake, VA.  As the tug and barge were transiting through the Gilmerton Bridge at approximately 0940, the CAPTAIN ED allided with the bridge's northeast fendering system.  This resulted in damage to the fendering system and a trussel to a new bridge under construction, which will eventually replace the existing Gilmerton Bridge.  No damage reported or noted to the CAPTAIN ED or the  6001. 

The individual operating the CAPTAIN ED did not hold a valid Coast Guard Credential as required by federal regulations. Referred to enforcment. Activity Closed.

The UTV CAROL MCMANUS tow allided with the Paducah and IL R/R bridge at mile marker 944.1 OHR while headed down bound. They were pushing 23 dry cargo barges. 18 loaded coal, 2 loaded grain, and 3 empty grain. One coal barge was damaged and flooded.

SEC UMR CC Received a report from the UTV EUGENIE stating that Barge CTCO 339 allided with the Louisiana R/R D/B North Protection Cell. The UTV EUGENIE was transiting down bound on the UMR, pushing the CTCO 339 and two additional empty red flag tank barges enroute to Memphis, TN. The UTV A JAY was the assist vessel for the UTV EUGENIE while she transited the bridge span. There were no reports of damage to the UTV's, bridge, or tow. No injuries or pollution resulted from the incident.

16MAR2011 UTV Bethesda was heading south bound at MM 661.5 on the Lower Mississippi River when its stern barge (MMI 612) allided with the Helena Bridge. After the allision, the lead barge (HTCO 3002) broke away from the tow but was recovered and received no damage during the casualty. The MMI 612 had received heavy damage from the impact with the bridge and was leaking product at a high rate. The Oil Spill Response Organization arrived on scene the following day along with USCG personnel and representatives from Higman Marine. The MMI 612 was lightered and received temporary repairs and permission from the COTP to continue S/B to shipyard for permanent repairs.

UTV Mike Kennelly was D/B pushing four barges when the port lead corner of the barge, FMT1040 allided with the upstream protection cell of the Pekin Railroad Bridge.  No other damage was reported to the tow or protection cell. All the barges damage was above the waterline and vessel had no flooding or loss of stability. This is an informal investigation only because the estimated damage repair cost was 30,000.

210800K MAR11-USCG Sector Guam received a call from Master on board the TUG CARDINAL reporting loss of steering outside of Guam.  Tug left Port of Guam on 20MAR11 at approximately 2200 after delivering deck barge, S2011.  At 0615-0630, eight hours after departing Guam, vessel lost steering due to unknown cause.  At or about 0845, USCG Sector Guam contacted Master on board vessel; vessel is northwest of Rota and is currently maneuvering on own propulsion back to Saipan; TUG RADAHAO will assist vessel when transiting through Tanapag Harbor.  TUG CARDINAL's expected arrival to Saipan is 2000 to 2200 on 21MAR11.  Vessel will hail Saipan's Emergency Management Office every two hours on status.

On March 13, 2011 at approximately 2050, the UTV RHETT PARKER (O.N. 643590) transiting southbound pushing six (06) empty barges, allided with the 14 Mile Railroad Bridge. While setting up to transit the bridge, the vsl Master misjudged the current and wind. By the time he realized he had miscalculated, it was too late to stop the port stern barge (PTC 464, O.N. 10448419) from alliding with the north cribbing of the bridge. No damage to the Barge or to the Bridge. No injuries. No further incidents.

On 03/16/2011 at 1430 hrs the GREENWAVE, UTV (ON 273292) was assisting the Barge CRIMSON TIDE go through the bridge when the stern of the  GREENWAVE hit the bridge fender system causing two of the timbers to break. There was no damage to the GREENWAVE or the bridge which was inspected and found to be in working order No further incidents

Subject tow vessel reported its tow has alliding with the US 41 Highway Bridge, while downbound in the vicinity of mile marker 787 Ohio River.  The tow consists of 12 empty hoppers and the vessels master reports wind and current caught him and he allided with the bridge. Seven of his barges broke away and have been rounded up by assist vessels. Master does not believe he hit bridge very hard and will have to assess damage to barges when he gets his barges back in-tow.

On 14 March 2011, at approximately 0905 LT, the UTV Heliose was pushing 8 loaded hopper barges down the Black Warrior River.  While in the vicinity of MM 268 on the Black Warrior River, the UTV attempted to pass under the AGS Rail Road Bridge.  The Master of the UTV miscalculated the high water current and rested one of the barges, PTC 523, up against the east bridge pillar.  No damage was done to the bridge or the barge, and the master made all reports and was cleared to proceed.  No further incidents.

20 March 2011: Master of the UTV Joshua David Esper advised that while heading N/B he allided with the  Vicksburg R/R bridge IVO mile 437.8 LMR at approx 0220 CDST. He also advised that his stern barge (empty) in STBD string hit the right descending pier of bridge. He advised that there is no damage to his barge (just 03 broken wires) and he didn’t see any damage to bridge pier. He reports that he has 10 loaded and 18 empty barges in tow all salt barges. Mariner reports the cause was due to currents in area. He concluded by stating that his final destination is St Louis Mo and his parent company is Marquette Transportation. MSD Vicksburg IO boarded at MM 441, found all as rptd. Vessel rptd to be making 3.9 mph while transiting bridges.

On 19-MAR-2011 at 20:30, Sector NOLA received a report of that the Ferry St. John experienced a Propulsion Loss at Robin Street Wharf, MM 96.5 LDB.  There were no secondary casualties, pollution or injuries.

On 19 March 2011, at approximately 1230, the UTV JACKSON III (O.N. 240322) was pushing 4 loaded hopper barges from Demopolis, AL to Mobile, AL via the Tombigbee River.  While attempting to pass under the Jackson Railroad Bridge at MM 90, the UTV's tow allided with the bridge pylon causing the tow wires to break and set all 4 barges adrift.  The lead 2 barges continued down river undamaged, however, the aft barges BIG 9718B and MEM 2391 slipped under the west side of the bridge and broke the fiberglass coverings on the barges cargo tanks.  No other damage was reported for the  barges or the bridge.  The UTV was able to gather barges back together, rebuild its tow, and continue on to its destination.  No further incidents.

Subject towing vessel was pushed up to Fleet at Ohio River mile marker 602 on the left descending bank waiting for winds to subside before continuing voyage.  Upon resuming downbound transit the propellors began to lose RPMs due to debris buildup on both screws.  RPMs dropped to the point of being unable to hold position and the UTV and tow drifted downriver and allided with the Louisville & Jeffersonville RR Bridge/Big Four Bridge, which is being converted to a pedestrian bridge. There was light damage to the UTV, damage to the stonework on one of the bridge piers/supports, and damage to two barges in the tow.

22MAR11 1930, the M/V CAYAH MICHELE drifted soft aground while waiting for the Mianus River railroad bridge to open.  While the vessel was aground a hydraulic fitting on the starboard steering gear ruptured.  The ram was bypassed and the vessel proceeded to the McKensey's Marina under its own power.  The fitting ruptured due to the rudder being stuck in the mud while the master attempted to crank the wheel over.  An internal examination of the hull and structural components revealed no apparent damage.  The vessel has not had a valid certificate of inspection since 2009.  The vessel is being sold at a U.S. Marshal's auction on 30MAR11.  The Mianus River was experiencing an extreme low tide at the time of the grounding.  No injuries or pollution were reported.
Dredge equipment including the barge G.L. 108 allided with the Long Boat Pass Bridge when it's anchor did not properly hold.  No damage reported from diving report.

UTV Jennie K struck a submerged object not visible above the water line while transiting through the Burlington Rail Road Bridge, Mile Marker 404.2 Upper Mississippi River  and put a large hole in the Starboard  lead barge.  causing the bow tank to flood to river level.

Vessel allided with Blackburn Point swing bridge on Intra Coastal Waterway.  Vessel and Barge were transiting through the open bridge and struck the bridge on the aft starboard of barge, vessel pilot overcorrected and struck aft port of barge.  Allision caused minimum damage to bridge fendering system.

At approximately 2010 hours on 30MAR2011, the dredger BAYPORT allided with a natural gas pipeline near buoy #28 (West Cameron Block 62) in the Calcasieu shipping channel while removing shoaling on the east side of the channel. This resulted in the COTP closing the shipping channel to any vessel traffic.  The dredging operation was an Army Corps of Engineers (ACOE) project and contracted with Manson Construction Company, LLC to conduct the dredging who was also the owner of the BAYPORT. 

The pipeline located at West Cameron 62A was damaged and filled with approximately 1000psi natural gas at the time of release.  No damage was sustained to the dredger BAYPORT.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the dredger BAYPORT alliding with the natural gas pipeline located at West Cameron 62A. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) failure of Manson Construction Company, LLC to conduct preliminary survey of dredging area, (2) failure of the Master to verify depth and location, (3) failure of ACOE to include subject pipeline “SOLICITATION,” (4) inadequate oversight by ACOE, and (5) failure of ACOE to conduct follow-up surveys after installation.

30 March 2011- MSD Nags Head was notified by numerous sources that the vessel CANYON RUNNER had allided with the Bonner Bridge while transiting through Oregon Inlet. MSD Nags Head investigated numerous local marinas till the vessel was discovered at Spencer's Yacht and Boat Yard. The vessel had suffered damage to the hull above the waterline on the STBD side stern. MSD Nags Head called the master of the vessel and he admitted to alliding with the bridge. 

01 April 2011- MSD Nags Head met with the master of the CANYON RUNNER. He submitted the CG-2692 and admitted to not notifying the Coast Guard of the allision. The master was assessed a Notice of Violation (see enforcement activity # 3976762)

On 2 APR, 2011 at approximately 1730 the barge CSC 24 was Set Adrift at MM 317.5 Missouri River then grazed the Lexington Bridge (HWY 13) at MM 314.9 Missouri River. Missouri Department of Transportation (MODOT) was contacted by local authorities who closed and inspected the bridge for damage. MODOT cleared and reopened the bridge. The UTV ALLISON MARIE recovered barge CSC 24 and relocated it back to its original mooring at 2200.

On 06APR11 at 0847 while underway on the MERMENTAU RIVER the tank barge MOC 11 (empty) allied with the BNSF Railroad Swing Bridge. At the time of the incident the tank barge was being pushed by the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) APACHE. No injuries, no pollution or damage to the barge resulted. The RR Bridge suffered some mechanical damage to the point that the bridge is not able to open for marine traffic however the bridge is operational for rail traffic. MSU Lake Charles Marine Investigators and Inspectors responded and verified original report. See Inspection Activities 3980952 & 3980994 for details of the inspection on the UTV APACHE & T/B MOC 11. See IO statement in correspndence for more details.

06APR11, 0125:  The UTV KRISTEN ALEXIS is pushing 4 loaded barges and experiences a steering system failure, resulting in an allision w/ the Bayou Sorrel swing bridge @ MM 37 on the Port Allen Route.  There was minor damage sustained to the bridge.  

No further damage, injuries or pollution reported.

UTV JONATHAN ERICKSON notified SEC UMR Comcen that SCF 11108B allided with the Louisiana Railroad Bridge protection cell. UTV was transiting up bound pushing 16 empty grain barges destination Winona, MN. UTV reported the onset of a thunderstorm while they began the transit of the bridge span. High winds caught empty barges from the starboard side and pushed them over, causing SCF 11108B to rub against the protection cell. No damage was reported for UTV, bridge, or tow. No injuries or pollution resulted from the incident.
SSP RCVD a report of the CSX RR Bridge over the Alafia River being struck at 1400L yesterday 06APR11.

11 APR 11: UTV Charlie G allided with the Sabula RR Bridge IVO MM 535 of UMR. MSD Quad Cities IO spoke to Master of Charlie G. who stated swift water had pushed him off course causing the tow to rub the bridge protection cell. Damage reported to CG is estimated as approx 6 timbers on bridge and a small crack in dry cargo barge CP95181.

29MAR11- UTV Elizabeth Dewey advised that while heading southbound with 20 loaded coal barges in tow they allided with center span of the Natchez Highway Bridge at mile 363.3 LMR. With the river level rising, the oncoming pilot appeared to have made miscalcualtions with regards to vessel maneuvering as it pertained to river current characteristics leading to the incident. He also advised that  02 barges sank underneath the bridge and the other 18 broke away and were recovered. 

Drugs and/or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this case

No further damage, injuries or pollution was reported

On 24 March 2011 at 1745 the UTV BROOKE (O.N. 637613) was transiting thru the Cochran Bridge MM03 Mobile River pushing one empty barge MMLP 322 (O.N. 1223882). While shifting the Port engine from forward to reverse, master lost RPM causing the barge to allided with the wood fendering works on the bridge. There was no damage to the Bridge or barge.  The engine was examined by a company mechanic and found to be satisfactory.  No further incidents.

On 11 APR 2011, the UTV ELEANOR GORDON allided with the Crescent City Connection Bridge was traveling northbound on the Lower Mississippi River at mile marker 95.7.  There is no pollution, injuries or hazards to navigation reported.

Vessel experienced unexpected shutdown of port main diesel engine (MDE).  Vessel continued to operate on stbd MDE.  Tech determined cause of port MDE shutdown was corrosion on connector of engine control module.  Connector was replaced and sealed to prevent future corrosion.  No injuries or pollution reported.

M/V SHEILA JOHNSON (ON 566984), pushing 12 barges, allided with the Illinois Central Railroad bridge (IC RR bridge) at mile 978 OHR IVO Cairo, IL. 01 loaded steal cover top barge damaged. The reported damage to the barge consisted of a hole the size of a quarter.
Barge under the control of UTV  struck the outer SE corner of the Pelham Bay Parkway Bridge fender system..
Captain of the tug Radahao notified USCG MSD Saipan that their starboard propeller had become fouled by thier towline while they were trying to marry two towlines alongside the tug Cardinal.

M/V MARY L (ON 565425) had an allision with the Eureka Highway Bridge at MM 30 CMB, while transiting amid channel and turning tow to head D/B.  The second STBD string barge from the head of the tow landed against the Right Descending Pier of the Eureka Highway Bridge.  No damage reported.

UTV Arthur E. Snider (Official Number: 272142, 08 POB, 10' draft) advised they were pushing 08 Salt and 01 Urea barges U/B and allided with Illinois Central Railroad Bridge (MM 977.7 OHR) due to rudders locking up and causing loss of steering. As a result, 06 barges became adrift. There are 07 assist vessels and the Coast Guard 25746 on scene assisting with the recovery of the barges.

24APR11- UTV CATHY GOLDING reported that they have struck the Geenville Bridge at MM 530.4 LMR. The stern barge (GBL 730) struck the bridge resulting in a 15 foot long insEt on the STBD side #2 Wing tank. Barge was issued a PTP to MM127 to offload cargo and then to Big River Shipbuilders for repairs.

No further damage, pollution, or injuries were reported

Drugs and or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this case.

On 4/23/11, the UTV FORT PIKE (O.N. 524596) was pushing two hopper barges, the VMC 206 (O.N. 1127522) and VMC 210 (O.N. 1127527) southbound on the Elizabeth River in Chesapeake, VA. The mate on watch made appropriate radio calls to the bridge tender as the tug and barges approached the Centerville Turnpike Bridge. The calls were made over VHF Channel 13 requesting a bridge opening and the bridge tender made an agreement to have the bridge open by the time the vessels came through. However, as the FORT PIKE and barges approached the bridge, it became apparent to the mate that the bridge would not swing open in time and would not have the clearance needed for the vessels to pass through safely without hitting the bridge. The mate moved the throttle controls to astern in attempts to slow down the tug and barges. The bridge was opened to late and the VMC 210 allided with the bridge fendering system.  A marine surveyor attended the bridge and estimated approximately $18,000 in damage to the fendering system. No damage to the bridge or vessels was reported.  Enforcement action recommended against the bridge tender.

Bridge Allision, Leeville/Belle Pass Bridge, and fishing vessel due to a lack of clearance between vessel outriggers and the bridge. Bridge clearance is approx. 75 feet, and the outriggers on the F/V are 65 feet, but mounted 15 feet above the water line for a clearance need of minimum 80 feet. LDOT has inspected the bridge and reports minimal damage and no structural damage to bridge. No Pollution, No Injuries. STA Grand Isle boarding Team currently on board, states damage to F/V is bent outriggers, STA GI Boarding Team working with CBP to identify and clear crewmembers on vessel. 2692 is being completed by Capt of vessel.
Pilot on board M/V CSCL FELIXSTOWE reported that the vessel allided with the Bayonne Bridge while enroute to Port Newark.

BULLDOG (O.N. 582994): Tug pushing barge lost control due to strong wind.  Barge hit fenders on railway bridge causing damage; railway itself not damaged.  Slight damage to the barge, all pieces of fenders still attached.
Licensed mariners on board did not hold proper licenses/endorsements for towing vessels.
Towing vessel owner did not verify operators held proper endorsements for towing.

Damage to the bridge was estimated at $95K.  This does not meet the damage threshold of a Serious Marine Incident.

The subject vessel pushing 8 hopper barges loaded with corn reportedly allided with the Shawneetown Bridge, (US Hwy 56), located at mile 858 Ohio River.  All 8 hopper barges broke free from the tow and 3 were damaged.  There was no damage to the bridge other than concrete scrapes.  No injuries or pollution occurred.

On March, 29 2011 at approx 1255 in the vicinity of MM 173 of the Tombigbee / Naheola Bridge, the UTV TERAH HUCKABEE (O.N. 581853) while northbound and towing 8 uninspected empty barges, struck the center span of the Naheola Bridge.  The Pilot (secondary Master) was in control of the UTV at the time, misjudged the water-level leading to the bridge causing significant damage to the radar equipment atop the wheelhouse.  The UTV reported the incident, and a bridge surveyor was dispatched, to which no damage was reported. The UTV was cleared to continue on its course. No injuries reported and no further incidents.

UTV MISS KATE was pushing 3 loaded barges (carrying corn) southbound on the Upper Mississippi River.  The tow was about to proceed through the Pig's Eye Railroad Drawbridge, when the tow struck the middle protection cell.  The point of impact on the tow was the port side, 2nd barge within the tow.  No damage was done to that barge, with the protection cell receiving minor damage.  A nearby UTV decided to help the MISS KATE move off the center span.  During this maneuver, the tow swung towards the right descending bank, which struck the bridge's sheer fence.  The lead barge (CH 0069) struck the sheer fence on the port bow causing damage to both the barge and fence.  The barge received a 20' long incent with sheer fence topple over.  No injuries occurred with the allision.

4/27/2011 UTV Stacy Shelby while pushing two empties Web 318 and Web 319Trubbed up against fendering system of Black Bayou Swing Bridge. Master of tug contacted bridge tender and no damage reported by either parties. No damage, pollution, or injuries resulted from this incident.

See IO Statement in Correspondence for more details.

Rcvd call from Capt onboard Tug CHAMORRO which is currently towing the Tug TALAFOFO approx 32nm off Orote Pt; Capt rpts crewmember onboard CHAMORRO was transferring to the Talofofo when he slipped and reportedly broke his leg.  Capt rpts it is not a compound fracture, crewmember is laying down, conscious, talking to other crewmember onboard vsl with him.  No comms between the two vsls and in order to get further medical information a crewmember would have to transfer from the CHAMORRO to the TALAFOFO; after discussion w/ command and SARDOC determined this is not worth the risk; SARDOC recommends bringing crewmember pierside for ambulance transfer.  ETA to pier (Apra Harbor F-5) approx 241200Z MAR 11.  Duty USCG Investigator notified and on scene.  

It was discovered by the duty Investigating Officer that there was no chemical testing device on board for alchohol testing in addition to no first aid kit on board to administer to the injured crewmember.  Injured crewmember received initial medical attention upon return to pierside at F6, PAG after sailing 6-7hrs on board the TALAFOFO.

On May 10, 2011 The UTV Jennie K. was heading down bound through the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge and  reduced speed to avoid waking out the work barges that were tied up to the left and right descending side of the channel span of the bridge.  Upon reducing speed the current set the tow and the SCF11108B allided with the barges on the left descending pier.  The Damage to the bridge is some broken timbers. SCF11108B sustained small leaks in the 1/2/3 port voids and a major leak with 4' of water in the bow tank.  One of the work barges flooded and sank at the bridge pier and is still tied off.  No injuries or pollution were reported with this case.

16 MAY 2011: UTV Ardyce Randall (570927)'s center barge (ET 3B) in the starboard string allided with the left descending protection cell of the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge (UMR MM 518.0).  The UTV Ardyce Randall  heading up bound to Winona, MN.  No damage, pollution, or injuries were caused due to this incident.
Barge MM 9724 allided with the Pekin Lower Railroad Bridge at MM 151 on the Illinois River while under the control of UTV BEA BLACK. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident.

5/16/2011, while transiting eastbound on the Intercoast Waterway the UTV MCKENZIE WAXLER temporarily laid up one of its three barges, WTC 3015, on the southside of the Bayou Du Large Bridge, bullwork to straighten out the tow. The UTV reports no damage to the bridge nor to the barge(s). There are three empty red flag barges in tow, previously loaded with ethanol. The Bridge Operator told the UTV it may proceed but needs to notify the Coast Guard. The vessel has continued his transit eastbound and was at mile marker 58.2, Intercoastal Waterway at the time of the report.

UTV reported rubbing  Barge (CCL404, empty red flag) against the NE dauphin (fender) of the Galveston Rail Road bridge while en route to Point Comfort. There was no damage to the bridge or barge, the bridge authority reported no damage to the bridge.

19 MAY 2011: UTV Sierra Dawn (522413)'s center barges (ART 935B/XL 663B) in the starboard string allided with the right descending protection cell of the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge (UMR MM 403.1).  The incident put a small dent in ART 935B, and put a hole 8ft long by 8-10in wide above the water line in XL 663B.  XL 663B is not taking on water, and is not in danger of sinking.  The UTV Sierra Dawn is pushing 12 loaded barges (5 alcohol/4 corn/1 scrap/1 soy bean/1 corn gluten) heading down bound to St. Louis, MO.  835 issued to provide results of damage survey to attending marine inspector.
Tug allided with the Pelham Parkway Bridge on the Hutchinson River.  Bridge reported minor damage NW corner of the bridge fender.

On May 21, 2011 SUMR CC rcvd report from Southern Towing Company that barge CF104, in tow of UTV Scott Stegbauer was taking on water at CF Industries, Palmyra MO, UMR 320.0. Vessel Master reported hitting permanently moored construction related deck barge on May 19, 2011 at Burlington Railroad Bridge. Master did not make a report because no damage was found at the time of incident.  Vessel was loading product when water was noticed in two port voids.  The product transfer stopped and on board cargo was offloaded from barge exposing damage to hull plating.

On the evening of 17MAY11, the F/V MISS EMILIE ANN was holding station on the ICW north of the Bridge of Lions awaiting the opening of the draw bridge.  Once the bridge opened the vessel began to maneuver towards the opening of the bridge.  Unexpectedly, the vessel did not respond to propulsion commands given by the master and the vessels wheel was frozen preventing the use of the vessels rudder.  The vessel, at the mercy of the current, allided with the Bridge of Lions.  State Dept. of Transportation reported no damage to the bridge, and the vessels mechanical problems were later discovered to be the result of an improperly secured shaft coupling.  The jumper shaft separated from the main shaft allowing the screw to lodge against the rudder.  There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this casualty.

On 21MAY11, MSD Panama City received a call from Station Destin stating that a the rigging system on F/V LADY THELMA became entangled with a Dayboard #4 near the Brooks Bridge in Ft. Walton Beach, FL. While the vessel was trying to untangle itself from the Dayboard, the vessel's rigging system also hit the bridge's navigation lights, causing an outage.  Station Destin responded to the incident location and confirmed the damages.  ANT Pensacola and FL DOT was notified of this incident.  Temporary aid was deployed by ANT Pensacola.  Inexperienced vessel operator's misjudgment of the rigging system caused the incident. No injuries were reported to the 3 people on board.  CG2692 was received.  Vessel sustained approximately $200 in damages.  Only damage to bridge was to the navigation light and was repaired by FL DOT on scene.  No further action was necessary.

Recd from UTV JAY LUHR advised that while down bound mile 43 UMR pushing 25 loaded rock barges they allided with the Thebes RR bridge causing all 25 barges to break away. Master advises that the assist vessel Coal Express is on scene and assisting with rounding up barges. UTV JAY LUHR currently has two barges and is going to tie them off on the bank and gather more.

On 5/29/2011, UTV CAPT. Kirby Dupuis (1229999) reported that their port lead barge (FMT 5048) allided with the left descending protection cell of the Burlington Railroad (R/R) Drawbridge (D/B), UMR MM 403.1.  The UTV CAPT. Kirby Dupuis was pushing 4 loaded asphalt barges, transiting down bound through the bridge with the help of an assist vessel at the time of the incident.  River current was the reported cause of the incident.  A work barge also temporarily broke free from its mooring, and has since been secured.  No damage, pollution, or injuries were caused due to this incident.

26 MAY 11: UTV David L. Griggs allided with Burlington RR bridge while downbound to St. Louis, MO with 10 loaded corn barges. The pilot stated that he rubbed the upper RDB protection cell with the starboard stern barge (FCF24017) and rubbed the upper RDB protection pier with the starboard lead barge. Current and low visibility due to rain were cited as the cause of the incident. The damage reported was some broken wires and a small leak in the bow tank of FCF24017. The UTV James L was assisting UTV David L. Griggs through the bridge at the time of the incident. No injuries or pollution were reported.

On 26 MAY 2011, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a telephone call from Bulk Services East loading facility stating that while loading a dry cargo barge; it broke free IVO MM 179.3 UMR.  The barge landed on the Douglas MacArthur RR bridge pier on the LDB. Barge was retrieved by UTV John Walker with damage to the port #3 wing tank. There were no injuries’ to facility employee's onboard the adrift barge.

On May 31, 2011,  at approximately 0300, a 249 foot deck barge broke free from its moorings near the Dularge Bridge at mile marker 59.9 on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway. The drifting barge collided with and pinned a 26 foot aluminum skiff between the barge and the fendering system of the Dularge Bridge.  A crew member on the skiff was injured during the incident.  Drug and alcohol test completed.

On May 31 2011, recieved a report from Louisiana DOT that the Leo Kerner Bridge (Barataria Swing Bridge in LaFitte, LA), over the Barataria Waterway was hit by the M/V JULIE MARIE, a tug boat pushing 2 loaded barges with limestone. The Leo Kerner Bridge is stuck in the open position due to being knocked off track by the allision. The JULIE MARIE reported timberheads were knocked off the barge GD20102 that allided with the bidge, and no other damage was reported to the vessel or its barges.

01Jun11: Rcved report from SEC COMMCEN that the CANEY CREEK SWING BRIDGE was allided with by the UTV ANDERSON (#578281, owner Waxler Marine) pushing two empty red flag barges (WTC 3004/WTC 3003, previous cargo NAFTA)  and totaled the bridge's NW pilings.

 The UTV ANDERSON reported the allision in agreement with the bridge's report. Stated the WTC 3004 as the barge that struck the bridge. No further damage or pollution. IO and MI reported on scene and determined the pilings were destroyed and hindering the bridge from operating. MI cleared barges after completing inspection, IO informed Master that personnel involved would have to be alcohol and drug tested.

Pilings were removed from under bridge and bridge is operable, but major work will need to be done to the fendering system at a date TBD by TXDOT, which will make the bridge inoperable while construction is underway.

Barge and UTV cleared to depart.

The vessel was underway making ready to conduct underway replenishment (Unrep) with an Aircraft Carrier.  During Unrep, the procedure is to have a series of warning ship whistles prior to having the shot line being fired from the Carrier to the USNS BRIDGE.  First whistle (1 short) is from the Carrier and serves to give mariners notice the procedure is beginning. The second whistle (2 short) from the USNS BRIDGE indicates the stations are ready and personnel have taken cover (from the oncoming projectile on the shot line). The third whistle (3 short) from the Carrier indicates the shot line has been fired.

During this Unrep the Carrier gave 1 short whistle and the shot lines were fired.  The Ordinary Seaman was at her station and was not given time to take cover and was struck above the right eye by the projectile of the shot line. 

The small cut required 3 stitches. 

No drug and alcohol testing conducted.

While navigating the tow through the channel span of IC Railroad Bridge, the wheelman attempted to flank in order to clear the Dock at Bunge Inc.  The wheelman was unable to stop the tow and the lead barge (RF 511) contacted the protection cell of the Bunge Dock.

UTV WHITE WING (558867, Pine Bluff Sand & Gravel Co.) pushing 12 empty rock barges down bound at MM 30.0 Cumberland River allided with the Eureka Highway Bridge (US HWY 62). The lead starboard barge, PB 2349, double hull, received a 1-2 inch crease about 130 ft back from the bow. The barge hit the upper end of the right descending pier, upper column. No other D/P/I reported.

At approximately 1615 local time, the ferry vessel MARIN experienced a loss of propulsion of the starboard Main Diesel Engine. The MARIN, a 154-foot small passenger vessel (Subchapter K), operated by the Golden Gate Ferry Company, was underway from Sausalito, California en route to the San Francisco Ferry Building with 175 passengers on board when they received a Code 48 low fuel pressure alarm and an unintended shut down of the starboard MDE. The Captain of the MARIN attempted to restart the starboard MDE from the bridge with negative results. From the engine room, the Captain was able to start the fuel booster pump. The MDE restarted. The MARIN safely transited to the San Francisco Ferry Building and disembarked the passengers. 

Subsequently, an engineer technician from Valley Power attended the MARIN in Larkspur, California. The technician inspected the fuel lines and found no leaks.  After running diagnostics on the starboard MDE, the technician received low fuel pressure codes on the low and high side of the fuel system. The technician checked all of the fuel filters and found no clogs.  All fuel fittings were found to be tight and there were no fuel leaks observed.  The technician determined the loss of fuel pressure to be as a result of a possible "slug of air" going through the fuel line which then caused the starboard MDE to shut down.

There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this casualty.

On 07JUN2011 at approximately 1420 the Uninspected Towing Vessel ELIZABETH R (547300) was pushing one string of three barges (all empty) westbound on the GICWW when the lead barge the KIRBY 30022B (CG000035) allied with the Northeast guide wall of the Grand Lake Pontoon Bridge. No injuries, pollution or damage to the vessel resulted from this incident. The guide wall was destroyed. The debris currently does not pose a hazard to navigation to the GICWW. See IO statement for more details.
Vsl starboard engine shut down causing it to allide with the bridge.

3 Jun 2011: Sector New Orleans received a report that while transiting through the CSX Rigolets Railroad swing span bridge, the UTV TOMMY ANDREW with 4 empty rock barges allided with the fender system and made contact with the bridge itself.

UTV KEVIN MICHAEL notified SUMR CC via VHF-FM CH16 that there were 07 empty open hopper barges adrift in St Louis Harbor IVO UMR MM 179.0. UTV has contacted Eagle Marine and all available fleeters are being diverted to assist.  The northbound UTV was given too much rudder while steering to the port and the port face wires broke under the strain of the high water current and got crossways above the bridges.  Some of the breakaway barges allided with both the Poplar Street and MLK bridges.  Some of the barges hit fleeted barges in the Osage Marine Fleeting area.

The UTV ACCU VIII, pushing 2 empty barges, the CCM 3138 and CCM 3140, was traveling westbound in the ICW.  The UTV ACCU VIII made arrangements with the assist tug (Brianna Elizabeth) to help barge pass through the Galveston Causeway Bridge.  The assist tug did not position itself in time to counter effect the wind, causing the AP3138 to allide with the bridge fendering system. The UTV sustained a dent to the starboard bow rake, near the bottom of the head log.

On June 4, 2011, while transiting outbound from berth in New Bedford, the commercial fishing vessel POLARIS allided with the Fairhaven swing bridge fendering system. The bridge had had unexpectedly started to close on the vessel while it was transiting through the opening. The vessel took evasive maneuvers but still allided with bridge fendering system. The fendering system received minor damage and the vessel's hull was penetrated on its port side.

On 19 June, 2011 at 0815 the UTV THOMAS ERICKSON allided with the left descending protection cell of the Florence Highway Drawbridge at Illinois River Mile Marker 56. They were pushing 15 loads of corn south bound en-route from LaSalle, IL to St. Louis, MO. The Pilot and bridge tender both stated that no contact was made on the bridge structure and that there was no damage done to the bridge. The third barge from the lead on the port string (MTC-536) contacted the protection cell causing damage to the port bow above the water line. The second barge on the port string (AEP 3160) sustained damage to the 1,2,3, wing tanks and were flooded to river level. They repositioned the barge and conducted temporary repairs to complete the transit to St. Louis, MO. They offloaded the cargo to lighten the barge so repairs could be completed.

21 June MSU Chicago duty team responded to an allision of UTV EILEEN C & 106th St bridge Chicago, IL.  UTV was pushing 02 empty hopper barges. Operator reported the area was difficult to maneuver and pilot house was required to be up for vis, pilot was lowering the house at the time of incident and ended up clipping the radar & air conditioner. Duty team met with the vessel at the 106th St bridge, interviewed pilot & gathered statements. Pilot has good history w/no other issues; Chicagoland drug testing perform alcohol & UA tests, awaiting results. SLM contacted the bridge who is reporting no damage. UTV AGGIE C overtook tow and escorted damaged UTV to IMT LeMont, Il.
The Tug pushing the Barge  allided with the fendering system on the Lower Hack RR Bridge. .

20Jun2011 (approximately 1830L) - A deck barge operated by Skanska USA broke loose from its mooring at an unknown time and drifted under southbound mile marker 8 on the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel ultimately alliding with the northbound bridge structure.  A tug boat was dispatched and secured the barge. The bridge-tunnel was closed to northbound traffic while the bridge was inspected. It reopened just before 11 p.m.  

Investigation determined barge owner/operator failed to make immediate notification to USCG.  See enforcement activity 4062593.  No further action intended.  Recommend this casualty be closed.

22Jul11: Received report from SEC COMMCEN that the UTV Bubba John (581985) allided with the Pelican Island Bridge south fendering system due to high winds. UTV was pushing one uninspected crane barge. Bridge Operator reported no damage to bridge, and Master of UTV reported no damage to barge.

UTV AMMIE pushing the CTCO 3033 and the HORIZON 3035  reports the HORIZON 3035 allided with the Caney Creek Swing Bridge.  No Damage pollution or injury reported to the Barge.  The area of the Bridge that the barge allided with was damage previously and the operator reports the timbers where moved approximately one foot backwards.

6/25/2011, the UTV Charlie G allided with the Burlington RR Bridge UMR MM 405.  The current set vessel over into the right descending protection cell of the bridge. The forward barge on his stbd string (downbound, 12 loaded grain barges) rubbed against the protection cell, no reported damage or pollution.

UTV FLOYD H BLASKE was pushing 7 loaded dry cargo barges southbound on the Upper Mississippi River en route to St Louis, MO.  The tow had just stopped within the channel at mile marker 698 waiting for the La Crosse Rail Road Bridge to open.  When the bridge reopened, the tow was more towards the left descending side than the normal right side that tows proceed through.  The mate on watch decided to take the left side.  While proceeding under the bridge, the tow did not have the correct angle and the port second string barge struck the sheer fence on the left descending side of the bridge.  No damage was caused to the barge (VL 81266), but extensive damage was done to the sheer fence.  It was estimated that 75' of the 200' of sheer fence was destroyed.   The bridge company hired a local company the following day to start repair work on the sheer fence.  Sector Upper Mississippi River placed a broadcast notice to mariners closing the left descending side due to damage to the fence and advise all mariners to use the right descending side.

2 Barges allided with the Ledbetter Bridge after breaking away from a drydock and travelling upriver during a bad storm.  Allision caused a break in an electrical PVC pipe on the bridge, and damage to the barge SUEQ 41B.  No pollution or injuries resulted from this incident.

30JUN11:  While transiting northbound on the ICW (enroute to Rayonier Pulp Mill) , Barge TMI 101 allided with I-beams used for construction on the Kingsley Creek Bridge fendering system.  Once Tug Captain saw that the barge was approaching the construction area, he immediately backed down reducing speed however still made contact.  Forward stbd corner of barge allided with northern most I-beam, bending it. Barge sustained no damage and there was no pollution.  CG IO's responded.  

1JUL11:  FDOT representative confirmed that center channel lights on bridge were in-op during the time of the incident.  Repairs have been made to electrical panel, lights currently operational.  Fender lighting system was said to be operational (10 total lights, 3 lights around construction area) according to FDOT rep.   

Waiting on a repair estimate from FDOT project manager and Drug/Alcohol testing results from Captain/crew.

30JUN11:  BOLT Underwater Services, Inc. (for FDOT) performed dive inspection of the east fendering system. See full "Underwater Inspection Report" located in evidence.  

5JUL11:  Drug test results received for two crewmembers.

28SEP11: FDOT project officer for fendering system provided unofficial damage repair costs- $55,746.21. Explained that official repair costs cannot be given until contractor approval received.

SUMR CC received a report of a barge allision with the EADS Bridge at UMR MM 180 from the St. Louis Dispatch. SUMR CC contacted on-scene St Louis PD to get details. Officer stated that there is a barge wrapped around the pier and that the PD is in the process of getting the bridge closed. SUMR CC did an "any vessels" callout for St. Louis harbor and the UTV Tom Frazier responded claiming responsibility for the incident. UTV Tom Frazier was heading U/B to St. Paul with 15 barges (salt, pot ash, cement) in tow with no red flags. Of the 15 total barges, there were 3 barges that are adrift, 5 barges wrapped around the right descending pier of the EADS Bridge and 7 barges still in tow. The UTV Tom Frazier is currently enroute to secure the 7 barges that are in tow. The 3 barges that are adrift are currently being recovered by 3 vessels from the St. Louis River Coalition. The Captain of the UTV Tom Frazier is currently reporting no injuries, pollution and no visible damage. The channel is blocked and there is a hazard to navigation.

At approximately 2136 on 30 June, 2011, the starboard lead barge of the UTV Show Me State's 15 barge tow, VBT-0914B, struck the left descending pier of the Hannibal Railroad Drawbridge at river mile 310 on the Upper Mississippi River, causing the wires to break and a block of four barges to break away from the tow; SCF-2215, MTC-310, MAR-907B, and CHB-0135. Assist tugs helped to retrieve the barges and rewire the tow. Voyage resumed at approximately 0500 on 01 July with damage to barges VBT-0914, MTC-443B. The Hannibal Railroad Drawbridge damaged as well, including the upper walkway of the bridge section, and the power line to navigational light. 

The CG-2692 and other correspondence incorrectly referred to the Keokuk & Western Railway Bridge as the site of the incident.

The UTV Thomas E Erickson reported that while they were about to clear the Florence Highway Drawbridge, at Illinois River Mile 56.0, when they got something caught in their starboard propeller, which prevented the starboard engine from being put into gear.  The UTV Thomas E Erickson was able to push into the bank at Illinois River Mile 54.7, left descending bank, were they waited for a diver. The diver discovered a buoy in the starboard wheel and removed it. No damage was incurred. The UTV Thomas E Erickson was pushing 14 loaded dry cargo barges downbound to Cairo, IL.

7/4/2011, The tug EASTERN DAWN was pushing the barge WEEKS 100 in Reynolds Channel, NY.  The Captain maneuvered to avoid colliding with several pleasure crafts and in doing so allided the starboard bow of the barge with the fendering system of the Atlantic Beach Bridge.  No damage was done to the tug or barge and the only damage to the fendering system was a crack to the top timber.

On 01 JUL 2011, the work flat barges MCC 456 & MCC 466 broke free of their mooring cables which were secured to a construction fleeting area at mile marker 364.7, just 200 feet up river from the Christopher Bond Bridge. When the barges broke free and passed under the Christopher Bond Bridge, the MCC 456 struck the left descending pier of the upriver pylon of the bridge, causing some minor damage to the concrete on the corner located near the 43  to 45 foot watermark, and minor damage to the MCC 456. The barges continued down river and passed under several other bridges without incident until they were recovered by a fleet boat at mile marker 360.4. The equipment manager of the company owning the barges believes that both barges' anchors were pulled loose due to drift, the drift being a direct result of the recent surge of high water.

07JUL11 - UTV GOLDEN EAGLE allided with the Vicksburg Railroad bridge while northbound with 15 barges (8 loaded, 7 empty salt); Destination St. Louis. The Master piloted the tow through the second Louisiana span on the RDB. The vsl turned slightly to starboard in setting up for the left turn at Delta Point when the current caught the tow. When the Master could not counter by steering to port, he topped it around to stbd. The Master attempted to regain control of the tow but could not. The  lead starboard barge struck the railroad bridge breaking some facing wires. The vsl pushed in at MM 436.2 LMR RDB no barges broke away, some facing wires were broken, MV ERGON and MV GENERAL assisted in re-securing the facing wires.

No further damage, pollution or injuries reported.

On June 23 2011, the pilot of the UTV WENDY L reported the vessel allied with the left descending protection cell of the Florence Hwy Bridge mile marker 56.0 Illinois River. No damage to the bridge or protection cell. Pilot reported a few wires broken and pushed into the bank just below the bridge to re-attach broken wires. The UTV WENDY L was heading south bound pushing 15 loaded barges, 12 dry cargo and 3 caustic soda (red flag) barges. After further investigation the port string #2 and #3 barges (ACBL 3207) and (CHEM0175) received damage to the portside of each barge. No pollution or injuries reported.

On July 10, 2011 at approximately 1420, the tug boat G.A. FRANKLIN  O.N. 507367, was traveling westbound on the Chesapeake and Albemarle Canal with a derrick barge on the hip.  While transiting through the Centerville Turnpike Bridge the derrick crane barge struck the south east pile dolphin and the south east fender system.  Total estimated damage of $5,000.  Recommend no further action taken to enclude enforcement.

The UTV CAPT RICHARD SIDES allided with the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge at Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 403.1 along the left descending bank.while heading South bound with 4 empty dry cargo barges. The barge that made contact with the bridge pier was the port lead barge. There two cracks on the barge that were patched with shingles.  Some timbers were borken and a work barges were knocked loose when the allision occured. The barges were not damaged and were secured.

UTV DELL BUTCHER was pushing 9 loaded dry cargo barges southbound on the Upper Mississippi River en route to St Louis.  At mile marker 813.7 the tow was proceeding through Hasting Railroad Bridge.
