While transiting through the third string starboard barge (ALC 98017) struck the bridge protection cell damaging the corner plate and breaking a few of the timbers.  No damage was done to the barge and the tow continued southbound.

UTV Philip M Pfeffer was pushing 9 barges (2 empty red flags/7 loaded dry cargo) heading down bound on the Upper Mississippi River en-route to Columbus, KY.  At mile marker 835.7, the tow was proceeding under the Belt Line Railroad Drawbridge on the left descending side.  While transiting through the starboard stern barge (IN095039) struck the sheer fence of the bridge.  No damage was done to the barge or tow.  Also no damage was done to the bridge.

08JUL11: UTV Mary Evelyn (643657) allided with the bridge pier of the Burlington RR D/B (UMR 403.1). The pilot stated he was pushing 15 barges (12 fertilizer, 1 ethanol and 2 empty grain) up bound from St Louis to St Paul when pilot error caused the incident. There were broken wires to the tow and to the work barge but no further reported damage, pollution, nor injuries.

UTV Prairie Dawn allided with the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge in the vicinity of Mile Marker 481 on the Upper Mississippi River. The UTV Prairie Dawn was heading downbound pushing 12 barges (All loaded grain) heading for St. Louis, MO prior to the allision.  The starboard stern barge ART 483 slid out from wind and current which caused the barge to gently rub the turn table of the Crescent R/R Drawbridge.  No injuries, pollution, or damage was reported for this incident.

BRIDGE ALLISION; SOHV CC received a report from the UTV Jill P. Harvey (Twin Screw towboat, Florida Marine Transporters, 1152898)  notifying that while passing under the Right descending pier of the Cator/Kingston Bridge at mm 568 TNR a sliding maneuver caused the M/V to allide with the bridge. The very back of the M/V (the rubber part of the m/v) braised the bridge leaving a tire mark and no other reported damage to any of the barges, UTV or the bridge. UTV was pushing 3 empty red flag barges containing Asphalt with a 2 foot draft.  MSD Nashville notified and investigating.

UTV Susannah Griffin was pushing 4 loaded asphalt barges southbound on the Upper Mississippi River en-route to New Orleans.   At mile marker 699, the tow was about to proceed under the La Crosse RR bridge.  During the attempted maneuver, the port lead barge struck the north side of the bull nose of the protection cell.  This caused two of the barges on the starboard string to break free and float through on the right descending side.  The port lead barge (that initially struck the bull nose) bounced back and broke free and then went under the bridge on the left descending side.  The last remaining barge remained with the UTV.  The two starboard string barges struck a residential back yard damaging a 15' section of a steel bulkhead. Those barges were retrieved by a nearby assist tow vessel.  The port lead barge (GRIFCO 3003) went aground on the left descending side of the river and was retrieved by UTV Susannah Griffin.  Barge, GRIFCO 3003 received significant damage to the starboard bow headlog.  In addition, the top of the deck of the bow rake compartment received damage.  No damage was done to the cargo tanks, nor was there any oil pollution from the event.

A dry cargo barge own by ARTCO (AB 128) was just loaded with corn by facility workers at ADM Elevator D, located at mile marker 841.7 on the Upper Mississippi River.   The barge was being prepared to be transferred to an Upper River Service tow vessel.  Facility workers had three 1 ½” lines on the port side of the barge tied to the facility mooring system.  Facilities workers then placed a ¾ inch wire rope onto the stern cover top on the starboard side of the barge and to the facility.  This wire rope was used to bring the barge closer towards the facilities pier to allow the tow boat better access to transfer to.  The third line on the stern end was removed to allow the vessel to drift down the pier facing.  Due to high water conditions, the D ring on the cover of the barge broke off, allowing the barge to swing out towards the channel.  This in-turn caused more pressure on the line ropes.  Within in 15 minutes one after another each line broke.  When the second line broke, a facility worker jumped on trying to attach another line before the remaining line parted.  However, the last remaining line broke with the facility worker stranded onboard.  The barge drifted free and traveled down bound on the Upper Mississippi River.  While adrift it struck the Omaha Railroad Bridge north concrete piling side.  The barge bounced off the piling and proceeded under the bridge through the channel.  The barge then proceeded downriver and struck the State High Street Bridge on the left descending side.  A nearby by towing vessel (UGG the TUG), along with Upper River Services, and St Paul Fire boat was able to secure the barge and bring the facility worker off the barge.  The barge received damage to port wing tank and small set in on port stern.  The facility worker received no injuries.

The M/V JOE BOBZIEN allided with the Chester Highway Bridge at MM 109.9 UMR, while heading D/B with 20 loads of coal and no red flags.  The vessels port stern coal barge struck the Left Descending Pier of the Chester Hwy Bridge, and sunk at MM 108.6 UMR, apprx 100 yards off the LDB.  No other damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

7/25/2011, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (SUMR CC) received a report via channel 16 VHF-FM from the UTV NELLIE stating that they allided with the center pier protection cell of the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge while transiting Northbound at Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282.1. The UTV NELLIE was pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges. The Master reported that no damage to the tow or the bridge as a result of the incident. SUMR CC contacted the bridge tender at the Louisiana R.R. D/B and they confirmed that no damage occurred to the bridge. SUMR CC made all notifications in accordance with the SUMR notification matrix and sent an email to D8 Bridge Branch. No damage to bridge or barge.

At 0745, USCG Sector Miami received a call from the Captain of the M/V ANGER MANAGEMENT regarding an allision the vessel had with the fendering system of the Roosevelt Railroad Bridge in Stuart, FL.  

The Captain stated as his vessel was heading inbound the St. Lucie Inlet approaching the Roosevelt Bridge, his vessel made contact with the fender on the portside of the bridge with the M/V FL DO1095072 which he was towing on his portside.  The Captain stated he had slowed his vessel down to avoid a collision with a rec boat when that was heading outbound through the bridge.
On 24 July, 2011 at approx. 1911, vessel reported that the "touched" the Arthur Kill Railroad Bridge. As a result their top mast has been pushed over approx. 10 degrees.

Received a report of a Bridge Allision at mile marker 50 Gulf Intercoastal Waterway West of the Harvey Locks. Tug Captain of the UTV ELLY LANE was pushing two loaded deck barges with legs for drilling. UTV ELLY LANE landed on the fender work on the south side of the Bayou Blue Bridge. The bridge operator inspected the bridge and found no damage was found. Bridge is still operational and no damage, pollution or personnel injury reported from the tug captain.

35ft. commercial fishing vessel transited under bridge without incident.  Shortly after transiting under bridge, the vessel experienced loss of propulsion.  Strong current caused vessel to drift into bridge.  No damage to bridge, and appox 100 dollars damage to vessel outrigger.  No injuries or pollution as a result of casualty.

31JUL11: UTV Penny Eckstein allided with the Burlington R/R D/B with barges breaking away. The UTV was heading upbound on the RDB with 15 barges (loaded coal) in tow enroute to Lansing, IA. The reporting party stated that the vessels got caught in the outdraft and the barges hit on the left descending pier of the channel span. Six barges are stuck on the bridge and 3 barges went adrift. Damage to the bridge was described as the rubrail being broken off the pier. Some minor hull damage on 3 barges incurred.

A towing vessel, with no tow, was southward bound in the Arthur Kill about 1545 on 02Aug11.  The Arthur Kill Railroad Bridge made securite announcements that the bridge would soon lower, and then commenced lowering the bridge at about 1600.  The mate on the towing vessel was at the wheel alone in the lower wheelhouse and transited under the bridge.  The mast of the towing vessel struck the bridge as the bridge was lowering and the towing vessel was passing underneath.  The mast contains navigation lights and other electronic equipment.  The mast was bent aft at the base and pointed down, damaging a VHF whip antenna and other electronic equipment mounted on the mast as shown in the attached photographic evidence.

The J.B. Kleinpeter (562115) allided with the Sabula RR Drawbridge (UMR 535.0).  the two lead port barges lightly rubbed against the bridge in what the captain reported as a controlled landing, how ever ,he did not call ahead,   There was no reported damage to the tow or bridge.

7/26/2011, UTV Pere Marquette reporting that their port stern barge (MTC505) allided with the center sheer fence of the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge, MM 535.0 on the Upper Mississippi River. The UTV Pere Marquette was heading upbound to Redwing, MN pushing 5 empty dry cargo barges at the time of the incident. No damage, pollution or injuries were reported. The UTV reported pilot error was the cause of the incident.

03AUG11 0800 - BRIDGE ALLISION, UTV TIGER PRIDE(O.N. 629534) vs. HWY 182 BRIDGE in Amelia, LA on the ICW: The UTV TIGER PRIDE was pushing a crane barge and did not lower the crane when passing under the bridge. As a result the crane made contact with the underside of the bridge. No damage was reported on the tug, barge, or crane and no significant damage was reported on the bridge other than minor scrapes. Tug has been directed to hold position in Amelia above the 182 bridge until inspected and cleared by UTV INSP and DIO.  Louisiana DOT bridge inspectors enroute with an ETA of 1030. Currently there are no vehicle or vessel traffic restrictions.

The commercial fishing vessel Miss Ke-Ke departed the County Docks on Kent Island and as the vessel departed the marina the operator applied full throttle and as he prepared to turn north he stated the vessel lost steering.  The operator had already entered into Kent Narrows, with a flood current, and was being set by the current to the north.  The operator started to reverse the engines as the vessel was making a turn to port.  Unable to take all way off and place rudder amidships the vessels starboard bow struck the west side of the Maryland Route 18 Bridge.  After the collision the operator set his anchor and successfully anchored the vessel.

The operator began to troubleshot the steering failure and found that a copper hydraulic line had cracked and discharged all the fluid from the system.  The operator made temporary repairs and added additional fluid and was able to proceed to an adjacent boat ramp.

USCG Sector Upper Mississippi River rcvd a report from the UTV M/V KEN TUBBS (634310) stating that while loading coal into it, a barge broke away from the Beelman River Terminal (UMR 182.9) and struck the McKinley Highway Bridge (UMR 182.5) before it was recovered by the UTV M/V KEN TUBBS. The pilot of the UTV M/V KEN TUBBS (see reporting party) stated that there was no apparent damage to the bridge, but there was a one inch dent on the coal barge.  The Bridge Branch was contacted and reported no damage to the bridge.

While transiting through the Southport Bridge, Townsend Gut,  Boothbay Harbor, Maine, the rubber tire fender of a deck barge under tow caught the bridge safety railing.  There was a bent safety railing and no damage to the barge or towing vessel. No personnel injuries and no pollution.

14Aug2011 (approximately 0937L) - The M/V GREAT PEACE (O.N. 9116333) was transiting inbound when it struck the navigation light of the Old Virginia Railroad Bridge (also known as the Norfolk Southern Railroad Lift Bridge).  Bridge height incorrectly identified on Chart 12253. Vessel master failed to immediately report to USCG after addressing the result safety concerns in violation of 46 CFR 4.05-1(a).  Enforcement action recommended.

OSV Charger hit 182 HWY Bridge with Mast head light, broke light was only damage on vessel, LA DOT are being notified to access if any damage to bridge, Master of vessel stated that there was no damage to bridge.
On 08AUG10, at 2359, while transiting through the CSX Rigolets Railroad Bridge, the Freight Barges MAC 618 and ACBL 2650 allided with the fender system, damaging 3 boards.

22 August 2011 - DD-SFO Cape Hatteras received a report from the Dive Vessel UNDER PRESSURE that they had lost a diver during a dive, on 21 August 2011. A couple of mintues later the vessel had found the passenger. He stated that he had some pain in his shoulder and that his legs were weak. The crew put him on oxygen and contacted EMS to meet them at the dock. The passenger was taken to the Outer Banks Hospital then to Senterea Lei Hopspital and placed in a Hyperbanic Chamber. Captain and the Mate completed required Drug Testing.

22 August 2011 - DD-SFO Cape Hatteras contacted the injuried passenger. He stated that he was doing much better and was to be released that day.

08 Semtember 2011 - DD-SFO Cape Hatteras received statement from injured diver, statements from three passengers and Drug Testing Results.

19AUG11-As the MV BRIMSTONE was transiting south bound underneath the Greenville Bridge with 4 empty Urea barges, the stbd clutch tire blew. Vessel continued through the bridge before turning to port and pushing in on the left descending bank to tie off and assess damage.

Drugs and/or alcohol did not appear to be a factor in this case.

No further damage, pollution or injuries reported.

SCC NOLA RECEIVED A REPORT FROM MSU HOUMA CDO OF THE UTV ELLY LANE ALLIDING WITH THE BAYOU BLUE BRDIGE, MILE MARKER 49.8 GIWW. THE UTV ELLY LANE WAS PUSHING ONE DECK BARGE WHEN THE MASTER MISJUDGED THEIR ALIGNMENT WHILE APPROACHING THE BRIDGE AND RUBBED THE FENDER SYSTEM AND PART OF THE BRIDGE WITH THE STARBOARD STERN OF THE BARGE. THE VESSEL CAPTAIN AND THE BRIDGE OPERATOR BOTH REPORTED NO DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE OR THE BARGE. NO SECONDARY CASUALTIES, NO POLLUTION, AND NO IMPACT ON THE WATERWAY. THE VESSEL WAS PERMITTED TO CONTINUE ONTO ITS DESTINATION AND IS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT A 2692.

17AUG2011: UTV R. CLAYTON MCWHORTER  allided with the Clinton RR bridge. while pushing 15 barges ( 11 dry cargo, 4 empties) downbound for Columbus, KY. The operator explained that he made a controlled landing on the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge with barge number IN118541 (Corn) center barge on the port string. No damage, injuries or pollution were reported for this incident.  The bridge tender of the Clinton Railroad Drawbridge, confirmed that the UTV R. Clayton Mcwhorter rubbed up against the bridge protection cell that is concurent with controlled landings. No visible damage was reported for the bridge. Sector Upper Mississippi River made all notifications in accordance with Sector Upper Mississippi River response matrix.

UTV "KRISTY DUTSCH" (#1182302) pushing 3 loaded red flag barges allided with the Morgan City/Atchafalaya Rail Road Bridge.  Barges loaded with light cycle oil.  UTV was southbound when heavy rain storm began which reduced visibility.  Tow struck northeast Dauphin on bridge, vsl struck dauphin with port quarter of vessel.  Tow broke face wires upon contact.  Vessel currently holding at MM 102 GIWW while making up tow and waiting for USCG inspection team to come out and conduct post casualty inspection.

On July 28, 2011, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received notification that the Uninspected Towing Vessel CINDY HULL allided with the Morgan City Railroad Bridge.  

The vessel was transiting northbound on the Atchafalaya River pushing 02 empty tank barges at the time of the incident.  

The barges were arranged in a lead barge, second barge configuration, with the towing vessel pushing behind the second barge.  The lead barge made contact with the southwest guide wall and no damage was reported. 
  
No pollution or personnel injuries were reported.

14OCT08:  The UTV POPS and UTV CAPT JEROME were towing a 500 ft raft of pipe between them end-to-end when a section of the raft struck the fendering system of the Wapoo Creek Bridge in the Intra-coastal Waterway near Charleston, SC.  Vessels and cargo suffered no damage.  Damage to the bridge fendering system consisted of wooden pilings knocked loose and was reported to SCDOT.  No apparent damage to the bridge. The incident was determined to be caused from currents pushing the raft into the bridge column and exacerbated by the excessive length of the tow.  No damage or pollution reported from either UTV.
02 SEP 2011, Sector NOLA received report of an allision between the UTV SUSAN FRANCES and the Belle Chase Hwy Bridge.  There was no reportable damage and no secondary casualties.

VTS Berwick Bay observed the UTV MISS LORRAINE G striking the HWY 182 Bridge in Morgan City, LA on the Atchafalaya River.  Vessel was manuvering dredge pipeing and was caught by the current causing the vessel to push dredge pipeing into one of the bridge stancions.  LA DOT has been notified.  DINP, DIO, and JMI enroute to attend vessel in Berwick, LA.  Case Pends.

The TUG laid up along the fender system for the Raritan River Draw Bridge in the Raritan River.  The tug laid up against a 12 pile cluster until the bridge could be opened due to 4 trains passing over the bridge.

On 27 JUN 10 at 0400, while navigating southbound through the Rigolets Railroad Bridge, the UTV TROY JACOB allided with the bridge's guidewall but did not cause any damage.  There were no secondary casualties.  Sector New Orleans IOs did not respond to the scene.

5Sep2011 at approx 0100, the UTV J. A. WARD reported they struck the Old Greenville Bridge at MM 531.4 LMR. The bridge no longer carries vehicular traffic. After alliding with the bridge the tow of the J. A. Ward broke apart and was set adrift, 3 remained attached to the UTV, 7 ran aground between old and new bridge, 1 set adrift, 11 total deck barges.  UTV pursued drifting barge and was assisted by a local fleet boat with the remaining grounded vessels. All barges were refloated, tow remade and cleared to depart  6 Sep 2011 approx 1030.

04 JUN 2010 SEC NOLA received report of a bridge allision between the UTV GRACE NICOLE and the Luling Bridge.  The vessel sustained damage to one of its barges, bridge sustained no new damage.  No secondary casualties were reported.

01APR10 at 0625, while transiting downbound under the Huey P Long Bridge near mile 106 on the Lower Mississippi River, 2 antennas of the M/V PRISCO ABAKAN contacted the underside of the bridge, damaging the antennas.  There were no secondary casualties.  Sector New Orleans IOs responded to the scene.
The M/V  allided with the Bayonne Bridge while transiting outbound to sea.
Vessel allided with the Broadway Bridge on the Harlem River while transiting with passengers onboard.

MSD Quad Cities IO received call indicating UTV Penny Eckstein had allided with Crescent RR bridge near MM 481. IO conducted telephonic investigation with Master. Master stated vessel was pushing 15 empty barges Southbound and strong winds had pushed barges against sheer fence of bridge as barges passed through bridge span.

On September 13, 2011, at approximately 0130, the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel (CBBT) Police notified the Sector Hampton Roads Command Center that the tug RANGER was towing alongside the Skanska BARGE 29 (loaded with rocks) and allided with a bridge column on the southbound lane between islands two and three (37 01.35N/076 05.20W). The BARGE 29 was being repositioned under the bridge by the tug RANGER with the assistance of the crew boat CAPE CHARLES when the BARGE 29 began to proceed under the bridge, between the bridge columns, and the starboard bow of the barge allided with the inside column of the bridge. 

Recommended Letter of Warning to the operator of the tug RANGER.
Recommended Notice of Violation to SKANSKA for failure to conducted alcohol and drug testing.  

Case closed.

On 19 SEP 2011, the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge Operator reported that the UTV Pebble Beach allided with right descending protection of their bridge. When contacted, the UTV Pebble Beach confirms that their starboard stern barge (KIRBY 20304B) allided with the right descending protection cell of the bridge, while they were transiting down bound and approaching the bridge. The master of the UTV Pebble Beach reported that the landing was "controlled or intended," but the bridge operator was not contacted prior to the purported "controlled landing." The master stated that he intentionally used the protection cell to "line up" with the navigational channel of the bridge, and that the protection cells were there for that purpose. The vessel's master was told that bridge protection cells should not be used for that purpose. The UTV Pebble Beach was pushing 4 empty dry cargo hopper barges.  No damage, pollution, or injuries as a result of this incident.

On 20SEP11, the towing vessel GRACE MCALLISTER was assisting the docking of the USCG inspected cargo barge MEMPHIS BRIDGE at berth  #30, Blount Island, FL.  Communication problems between the personnel on the dock and the GRACE MCALLISTER led to the MEMPHIS BRIDGE contacting the dock harder than planned.  Damages of $14,500 and $18,000 occurred to the dock and barge respectively.  Damage did not affect barges fitness for service or route; no injuries or pollution as a result.

29SEP11: Dubuque RR Bridge (UMR 579.9) reported that the UTV Floyd H Blaske allided with their bridge, damaging timbers on the sheer fence. Floyd H Blaske reported they were upbound with 12 barges when, due to excessive winds, the port lead barge did make contact with the sheer fence. The barge was a salt barge. There were two red flag barges in his tow (liquid fertilizer, caustic soda) but pilot states they were not affected. IO's conducted a onscene investigation of the two red flags and found no damage. Minor damage to some bit's and buttons on other barges and damage to the sheer fence of the Dubuque RR Bridge.

Bridge operator reported the UTV Martin Admiral pushing two empty barges had its barge , MMLP 308, allide with Caney Creek Bridge.  Barge sustained no dmg, bridge has damage to some cabling and framework.
Barge being towed by tug allided with the fender of the Pelham Bay Parkway Bridge.

UTV ELIZABETH BLEILER west bound ICW w/KIRBY 10422, KIRBY 10354 and KIRBY 30304 allided with the Galveston Causeway Bridge. No damage to Bridge. KIRBY 10422 suffered a 1" x 2" x 18" fracture on the head log in the void above the water line. Damage was exacerbated by preexisting crack/failed weld of approximately 8" located in the center of the total length of 18”.

08SEP10, 1845: While attempting to transit through the Gross Tete bridge at MM 47 on the GIWW,  the lead stbd barge  (MEM 1010) of the UTV SAFETY EXPLORER's tow allided with the fendering system. Initial damage estimate by CG Marine Inspector was less than $100,000, indicating that the event was not a SMI.  Subsequent damage estimate by Independent Marine Surveyor was $400,000. The UTV and  barge did not sustain any damage. 

No other casualties, injuries, or pollution were reported.

THE MAST OF OSV GIS DILLON ALLIDED WITH THE 182 BRIDGE IN MORGAN CITY.  NO DAMGE REPORTED TO THE BRIDGE, LOCAL PARISH WAS NOTIFIED OF ALLISION.  DAMAGE TO OSV IS REPORTED TO BE BROKEN CABLES AND SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE TO THE MAST.  VSL IS MOORED TO ELI DOCK IN BERWICK, LA.  MSU MC DUTY INSPECTOR AND INVESTIGATOR WILL ATTEND VSL THIS MORNING FOR DAMAGE SURVEY.

The Scow Barge LEE II hit the fendering system on the Pelham bridge damaging the fendering system. Damage estimate classifying incident as SMI was not recieved until December 14th at which time drug and alcohol testing was too late.

On 28 OCT, 2011 at 1300 a 2 barge breakaway occurred from UTV Brimstone. While topping around at MM 183.2, right descending bank the UTV BRIMSTONE lost propulsion on the port engine. The BRIMSTONE drifted onto the Merchants R/R Bridge causing the facing wires to fail. The tow separated (MM-332, AO-109) from the UTV and struck the Merchant Bridge. The barges were docked at the Steadman Dock, UMR MM 182. The cargo of the barges is liquid fertilizer (non red flag).

On October 20, 2011 at 1700, Vessel Traffic Service Berwick Bay received a report that the UTV New Merrick pushing 3 red flag barges with crude oil allided with the Forked Island Bridge. Vessel was making a turn and the strain caused 2 couplings to break between the tug and barges. No damage to the bridge or tug was reported.

While underway in an eastbound direction subject vessel struck Smith Point Bridge with its mast and rigging.  No damage was done to bridge, vessel's mast and rigging were bent back.  Vessel proceeded to West Sayville repair/drydock facility for repairs.  MI attended vessel to ensure vessel was seaworthy, all found all was satisfactory with the exception of the bent mast and rigging.

On 07 NOV 2011, the UTV PERE MARQUETTE was transiting down bound thru the Chain of Rock Canal to St. Louis, MO, when the master of the vessel reported that they had allided with the McKinley Bridge in the vicinity of mile marker 183 on the Upper Mississippi River. The vessel was transporting a total of 15 barges of non-regulated dry cargo at the time of the incident.  Upon further investigation it was determined that the vessel's tow had been pushed to the left descending bank due to a stronger than expected current coming from the Mississippi River channel that forced the tow to ground on a stub dike on the Illinois shore.  The grounding caused tow wires to break, separating a string of 9 barges from the tow.  Sector Upper Mississippi River issued a river closure between mile markers 182.5-181.5 on the Upper Mississippi River and issued an Urgent Marine Information Broadcast until the barges could be rounded up.  The MTC-247 and NOMA-350 barges received damage from the grounding which resulted in a combined total cost of $16,400 in damages.  No injuries or pollution resulted in the incident.  A post-accident non-DOT alcohol test was conducted on the master by the pilot.

While proceeding to sea, the Boatswain Mate's left hand was crushed while attempting to secure the access port accommodation ladder for sea.

Prior to the injury, the Boatswain Mate was leaning against the Bulwark providing assistance adjacent to the access port to two other Boatswain Mates who were working over the side on the accommodation ladder. 

The master reported that the Boatswain Mate had left hand overlapping the side where the break in the bulwark was located for the access port at the time of the injury.

The Master then reported that the access port could not be properly secured & swung shut at the time, possibly causing the crushed left hand, resulting in an open compound fracture to the middle phalance fifth finger.

Initial first aid was administered on the vsl and the Boatswain Mate was then medevaced off the vsl to ashore medical services to be treated. Drug and alcohol testing was conducted following the incident.

Corrective Measures: The Master reported that a work order has been put in place to ensure the bulwark access port to the accommodation ladder will be modified as approved in the authorized MSC T-ALT 039 to prevent the access port from being locked and secured into place. Case closed.

On 03OCT2011 at approximately 0015, the UTV VECTURAIN, while transiting from the Port of Brownville enroute to ALCOA docks in Point Comfort, Texas, allided with the Queen Isabella Causeway Bridge.  The vessel was pushing 6 hopper barges, one empty and 5 loaded with scrap metal. The Master of the vessel was on the bridge and the crewmember was at the helm. After passing the Long Island Swing Bridge and the cut, the vessel was set to the red side of the channel.  In order to compensate, the vessel was maneuvered hard port. The port stern barges, VLB 9143 and ACL 07119 (both loaded) made contact with the southwest fender system of the bridge. The contact was a slight rub with no injuries and no pollution reported. Upon inspection of the barges by vessel personnel, no damage was observed and all void spaces where dry. Upon inspection of the bridge By TX DOT, minimal to no damage was observed on the bridge and fender system.
UTV NEIL N DIEHL allided with the Dubuque R/R D/B UMR MM 579.9 while transiting U/B to ST Paul, MN pushing 12 (6 cement and 6 empty dry cargo barges) resulting in damage to 3 barges.

M/V John C. Terral reported an allision with the Jonesville Bridge at approximately MM 40.6 Black River.  The M/V was pushing 04 barges of gravel. Pilot accidently turned off power to the steering pump. Pilot did not notice pump was turned off. Once pilot realized pump was turned off, tow allied into the Jonesville Hwy 84 bridge. Damage to both corners stbd and port of lead barges. 

Drugs and alcohol do not appear to be a factor.

No further pollution, damage, or injury was reported.

MSU Morgan City received a report from the bridge tender that the towing vessel TEETER MENARD pushing ahead 1 loaded diesel barge, TM 19, allided with the Bayou Boeuf Rail Road Bridge in Amelia, LA.  High winds pushed the barge into the fender system of the bridge.  No damage to the tug, barge or bridge reported.

On November 21, 2011 the vessel was maneuvering to dock, approx. 200 ft from Charleston Bridge, Coos Bay, OR.  Winds became strong, in the excess of 25 knots, causing vessel to blow broadside and allied with the Charleston Bridge.  Oregon DOT inspected bridge (no damage).  Damage to the vessel is estimated at $2600 to replace radar dome and one antenna.

Sector Upper Mississippi River (SECUMR) Command Center (CC) rcvd call from the Florence Hwy Bridge Tender reporting that the UTV DELL BUTCHER allided with the right descending bank protection cell. The vessel was approaching the bridge along the green buoy line when the starboard lead barge bumped bottom (bump and go) enough to pull the forward barges off the intended track line.  This shift in direction was enough to place the starboard lead barge in line with the right descending bank protective cell on the Florence Highway Bridge.  The forward barge scraped the cell as it was transiting through the bridge. No damage to the barge, no pollution, and no injuries to the barge or crew.  Florence Highway Bridge tender reported no damage to the protective cell or bridge.

On November 18, 2011 at approximately 1300 local time, the Sector San Francisco's Command Center (SCC) received a report from the Master onboard the ferry vessel M/V DEL NORTE.  He stated that the vessel's system detected low fuel pressure in the #4 Main Diesel Engine (MDE) engine (starboard aft engine).  The Master became aware of the problem from an alarm on the bridge.  He sent a crew member down to investigate.  The crew member discovered a leaking fuel line and the MDE was shut down as a precaution.  

The DEL NORTE is a four engine vessel and it was allowed to operate with the three remaining MDEs until the secured MDE could be repaired per Sector San Francisco's Domestic Inspection (MI) Division's protocol see activity #4193400.  The DEL NORTE had passengers on board at the time of the incident but safely made it to the Ferry Terminal at Pier 41 in San Francisco, California.  The passengers were safely disembarked and the DEL NORTE taken out of service to affect repairs.  Valley Diesel provided the repair services to the DEL NORTE and found a pin hole leak in the elbow of the low pressure fuel line on the aft side of the MDE between the filter and pump.  The line was replaced and the DEL NORTE returned to service without further complications. No injuries, pollution, or damage resulted from this reduction of propulsion capabilities.  Drug and alcohol testing were not conducted.  

No Enforcement Action (EA) is recommended.
UTV Mr. Lampton was south bound MM 838 LMR pushing 3 loaded red flag barges and allided with the I-155 Hwy Bridge at Caruthersville, MO.  Lead Barge MM64B received damage.

On November 28, 2011 At 2010, the UTV Creole Belle pushing 2 empty red flag barges heading eastbound allided  with the W. Larose bridge at mile Marker 35 on the Gulf Intercoastal Waterway.  The Creole Belle's mast struck the Bridge causing the mast to break.  The bridge tender reported the bridge to be fully operational with no visible damage.  

No damage to Bridge and minimal damage to Towing Vessel's mast.  Pilot stated that he had mis-judged the didtance based upon multiple trips under this bridge in the same vessel.

The subject vessel was transitting downstream on the Green River mile 8.3 with 4 empty hopper barges when it struck the bull nose on the long wall which is part of the structure of the Spottsville Railroad Bridge (aka CSX Railroad Bridge).  No damage, injuries, or pollution occurred.

M/V SUPER SHUTTLE experienced an exhaust leak in its main engine exhaust manifold.  After being underway for approximately 1.5 hours, vessel returned to dock for repairs prior to continuing voyage because they did not know the extent of damage.  Leak later determined to have come from a nickel size hole in the Main Diesel Engine exhaust manifold.  Temp repairs were made until pipe could be replaced per vessel's class society instructions.

Sector Boston Command Center received a report that the towing vessel BRIAN allided with the McCardle Bridge fender.  The towing vessel BRIAN and barge CB120 (crane barge) were transiting inbound when the port side of the BRIAN made contact with bridge fender.  Barge did not make contact with bridge and has no damage;  no damage to bridge fender or to the towing vessel BRIAN.

UTV AMERICAN was transiting through the Sister's Creek bridge and contacted  bridge fendering system.  No damage to vessels, but some damage reported to bridge fendering system.  Master of vessel reported he intended to use the fendering system to pivot through the bridge opening.  Florida Dept. of Transportation initially estimated damage to bridge to be ~10K.  Final damage survey found to be $6,950.00.  No injuries or pollution as a result of this casualty.

On 01 December 2011, the port side of M/V ALGOLAKE allided with the CONRAIL RAILROAD bridge on the River Rouge while the bridge was in a raised position to allow the vessel to pass through.  ALGOLAKE sustained damage to stanchions and a fairlead.  The bridge also sustained damage due to the allision, however the bridge is operational.  Final repairs have not been completed as of 16 April 2012.

Uninspected Tank Barge STC 2716, under the control of the UTV Frank Stegbauer, allided with the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Bridge (AKA Pekin Railroad Bridge) lower protection cell at Illinois River (ILR) mile marker (MM) 151.1. UTV Frank Stegbauer was forced to make a controlled landing awaiting the bridge opening. Vessel's tow laid up against the bridge pier and held position until the bridge was lifted.  Agreement with the bridge was made however due to a shift change the bridge was not opened as anticipated.  Once the bridge was lifted the vessel safely transited. There was no damage to barge or bridge. No pollution or injuries were reported.
190410Z NOV 2011 Allision: M/V W.W. Crum allided with the Henery R. Lawrence Memorial Bridge MM 61.3 CMB while headed D/B pushing 5 empty tank barges. ATON  and wind were a factor.

MS- Allision - 242255Z NOV 11; UTV Louise S (513659- Triple Screw, 4500 HP, Campbell Transportation Co.) was D/B on the OHR at MM 981 when he allided with the Cairo Hwy Br. (also known the Ohio River Bridge/Hwy 60 Bridge). Louise S was pushing 15 soybean grain non-red flag barges and 12 of them went adrift after the allision. 04 assist vessels were on scene and assisted in the roundup. All adrift barges were rounded up. The deepest draft was 9'6''.  Aton was not a factor.

Subject vessel was transitting down bound pushing 16 empty hopper barges when wind and current caught them and it allided with the Sherman Minton Bridge MM 608.8. Pilot reports no pollution , Damage, or Injuries.

Canadian flagged freight vessel allided with the N&S railroad bridge while outbound in the Maumee River. No injuries, no pollution, minor cosmetic hull damage to the vessel, extensive damage to the bridge pilings and fendering system. Casualty occurred following heavy rains which caused strong currents. Vessel was using 2 tugs to push away from the dock and line up with the bridge when the current and winds overpowered the vessels. Bridge damage estimates were originally minimal but upon further inspection the damages were estimated to exceed $100 K. By that time, the vessel had already departed the Toledo Harbor channel. A COTP Order was issued to return to the dock in order to conduct investigation and drug and alcohol testing.

The subject tow vessel, while pushing 4 loaded coal barges down bound at MM 8.3 Green River and  passing through the L&N CSX R/R Drawbridge, allided with the bullnose and 3 barges broke away. The remaining barge, C330 (stbd stern barge) sustained damage to the port stern void and is taking on water. The vessel has 3 pumps that are adequately keeping up with the water. The bridge was inspected and no damage reported.

The Tug JUDY M (official number 500523) was pushing ahead the crane barge DIGNITY in the Mystic River making its approach to the Mystic River Railroad Bridge.  The tug and barge were set by the winds and current into the fender system of the bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge fender system or the barge.
M/V hit their whip antenna on the Bayonne bridge.

On December 14, 2011 at approximately 0430 local time the UTV STEVIE ANN was pushing two empty barges westbound on the Gulf Intracoastal waterway when the barge KIRBY 27765 made contact with the Caney Creek Swing Bridge structure. No damage, pollution or injuries occurred.

15FEB12-USCG Sector Guam followed up with Naval Hosptial Guam Admin Records Department for copy of subject mariner's medical treatment.  Per In-Patient and Out-Patient Records Department at Naval Hospital Guam, there is no documentation on file with the facility of subject mariner's treatment.  No further action; case closed to file. 

16DEC11-Pending medical treatment report from Naval Hospital Guam. 

USCG Sector Guam received a report from the Master on board the USNS BRIDGE of a crewmember who was injured while on duty.  Crewmember was sent ashore to U.S. Naval Hospital on Guam for further care and treatment.  Due to unknown extent of injury, crewmember was discharged from the vessel and repatriated back to home of record after receiving medical treatment.

Note: Vessel is aa Government Owned, Government Operated (GOGO), not subject to the alcohol/drug test requirement in Title 46, CFR, Part 4 per the Memorandum of Agreement in the Civilian Marine Personnel Instruction  CMPI 792.  Vessel's Master is still subject to the reporting requirements fo a marine casualty and submitting a CG2692.  However, testing is for alcohol/drugs a CG2692B would need to be submitted along with the alcohol/drug test results.

Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) MISS KATIE allided with the Eggners Ferry Bridge (HWY 68) at Mile Marker 41.7 on the Tennessee River while passing under the right descending bank bridge span instead of the center channel bridge span.  Master reported the  bridge was missing lights.  The mast of the UTV and a fiberglass tank sitting on the deck barge in stern tow were damaged during the allision.  The Motor Vessel TRISTEN was faced up to the deck barge and was assisting the tow when the allision occurred.

The UTV ISSAQUENA (505721) was down bound when their port stern barge (SCF 24063) allided (rubbed the wooden fender system) on the left descending protection cell of the Pekin Railroad Drawbridge (Chicago Northwestern RR Bridge) .  Low visibility was reported to be the cause of the incident.  The UTV ISSAQUENA was pushing 7 loaded dry cargo hopper barges heading to St. Louis, MO.  No damage, pollution, or injuries were reported due to this incident. Since no damage or red flags were involved, only a phone interview was conducted. Vessel safely continued transit.

UTV BETTY BRENT allided with the Central Illinois Railroad Bridge at MM 977.7 OHR while transiting southbound with 4 empty red flag barges. The vessel sustained a 4' X 4' dent with 2" indent on the port side of the port lead barge, above the waterline.

UTV LANA LOUISE w/ Barge KIRBY 28059 (empty) transiting east bound was pushed by wind and struck the Caney Creek Swing Bridge. High beam on bridge was bent and barge sustained a minor scrape above the waterline amidships.  Bridge is fully operational. No pollution/injuries reported.

22DEC11, 1632:  M/V KATHERINE BERRY's tow allided with the SIMMESPORT bridge, located at MM 5 on the Atchafalaya River. The port side of the vessel rubbed the center turn span column of the bridge. 

The initial report went to MSU Morgan City, and after getting info from the bridge operator, they allowed the vsl to proceed N/B.  The only evidence of damage were paint scrapes on the bridge center span and IWO the port gunwale.

No pollution, injuries or further damage reported.

On 23 December 2011, received notification from Crowley representative that on 22 December 2011 UTV SEA HORSE was pulling freight barge MEMPHIS BRIDGE when center bit on the latter failed; subsequently, the freight barge's starboard aft corner drifted aground.  Moments later, the tow wire that was securing the freight barge to the tug entagled the latter's port propeller, compromising its manueverability.  Lastly, while receiving a line from an assist tug to help hold the entagled tug, the line was sucked into the starboard propeller, rendering the same without maneuverabilty drifting under the barge's port bow rack.  The tug suffered superficial damage on its port side.

SUMR CC received a report from the master of the UTV TROJAN (ON 566831) that their starboard generator was not cycling smoothly as he transited south bound at MM 180 Upper Mississippi River.  The affected generator was shut down and the crew switched to the port generator.  The UTV never lost headway and was without power for approx. 30 seconds. While operating on auxiliary power, the fuel filters were replaced. The UTV was heading downbound to UMR MM 174 with 1 empty barge in tow drafting 1-2 feet. No damages, injuries or pollution were reported and the navigation of the channel is unaffected. No CG assistance was requested.

On December 29, 2011 at 14:00, the subject vessel pushing 10 loaded coal barges reportedly allided with the US 2155 Highway Bridge, Owensboro, KY.  No pollution, injuries, or damage to the bridge occurred.  One hopper barge sustained minor damage.

On 25 December 2011, at approximately 0945, the UTV VOYAGER (O.N. 563475) was pushing 2 loaded red flag tank barges carrying oil up the Mobile River.  The Voyager started to negotiate the turn and entry into Chickasaw Creek through the CSX Rail Road Bridge at the mouth of Chickasaw Creek.  After completing the turn, the master was unable to account for the currents affect on the loaded barges, and the barges drifted through the starboard fending system and into the bridge.  The allision caused damage to both the bridge and one of the barges.  No structural damage was noted to the bridge.  The bridge and barge were sent for repairs, and all crew members were tested for drugs and alcohol.  No further incident.

Unnamed lift barge FL 0980 PE allided with the Siesta Key Bridge.  The barge was secured on 03 JAN 12 when the crew spudded the vessel down upon completing a construction project,.  As the tide rose throughout the evening, the vessel floated itself and subsequently allided with the Siesta Key Bridge.  The vessel sustained minor damage, the bridge was not damage.

UTV Dennis Collins and the Tank Barge AF-15, allided with the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RR BRIDGE (aka Pekin Railroad Drawbridge) at mile marker 151.2 on the Illinois River. The UTV Dennis Collins was heading down bound pushing 2 breasted empty CDC barges of Anhydrous Ammonia heading for Catoosa, OK. The operator of the UTV Dennis Collins stated that while transiting through the drawbridge with the assistance of the UTV Edmund L., the tow drifted close to the bridge causing the port side of the barge to make light contact with the fender system on the LDB bridge pier. While attempting to work the barge off of the fender system the UTV Dennis Collins, port stern, also allided with the same pier fender system. The bridge operator reported no damage to bridge.  The on scene investigation confirmed no damage to the barge or UTV.

On 01 January 2012, at approximately 0500, the UTV DIANE B. SIEGEL (O.N. 64336) was transiting southbound on the Tombigbee River at MM 173 with 8 loaded coal barges.  While passing under the Naheola Railroad Bridge, the Master did not calculate the clearence of the bridge accurately, and the vessel's antenna struck the bridge.  The antenna was dissabled, but there was no damage to the bridge.  The UTV reported the allision and had the antenna repaired.  No further incident.

the M/V VINCENT THOMAS tested the main engine in astern and noticed that the fuel pump roller guides for two cylinders did not shift to the astern position.  The vessel was coming into Long Beach, CA and was conducting pre-arrival checks.  The master ordered the test to astern and it was noticed that the fuel pump roller guide for cylinders # 5 and #7 did not shift to the astern position when operated from the bridge and engine control room.  When operated locally, the fuel pump roller guides operated properly.  With permission from the Captain of the Port, the vessel proceeded to berth with the assistance of three tugs.  Sector Los Angeles-Long Beach Investigating Officer and Marine Inspector attended vessel in port.  The Class Surveyor and a MAN Diesel Engine Technician also attended the vessel.  It was determined that the pneumatic reversing cylinders for the roller guides on cylinders #5 and #7 were not working properly.  The reversing cylinders were moved between the ahead and astern position manually by applying air directly to the cylinders several times.  Afterwards, the main engine was tested ahead and astern from the bridge, engine control room and locally three times each satisfactorily.  The Class Surveyor and MAN Diesel Engine Technician each provided reports attesting to the satisfactory operation of the main engine.

050731Z Jan: SOHV CC received a report from the M/V Al Gray that it allided with the Cairo/KY Bridge (MM 980.5 OHR) while passing under its third pier along the Left descending bank .  M/V was pushing 1 empty oversized Benzene barge with a 2 foot draft.  Barge struck pier with no damage other than a small 3 inch dent in the bottom rail, with no reported damage to the bridge, injuries or pollution.

On December 29, 2011, the Coast Guard was notified that the ferry vessel PARK CITY had allided hard with a dolphin cluster at the Bridgeport Ferry Terminal two days earlier - on December 27, 2011.  The starboard bow of the PARK CITY received scrapes and the passenger/vehicle ramp railing was damaged.  No passengers or crew members were injured.  The weather was rain and south-southeast winds of 25 to 35kts, with higher gusts.

On January 8, 2012, the Tug THOMAS DANN was outbound pushing the empty barge WEEKS 246 when it had to make an evasive maneuver to avoid a commercial fishing vessel that had drifted into the channel.  This maneuver caused the barge to allided with the fendering system on the New Bedford/Fairhaven swing bridge.  The Bridge operator reported minor damage to side planks on the fendering system but that there was no structural damage to the bridge and bridge traffic was not stopped.  The Tug and barge sustained no damage.

MARINE SAFETY UNIT MORGAN CITY RECEIVED NOTIFICATION THAT THE UTV MISS JUANITA BUMPED THE MORGAN CITY RAILROAD BRIDGE.

MISS JUANITA WAS WAITING ON THE SOUTHWESTERLY SIDE OF THE RAILROAD BRIDGE AS AN ASSIST VESSEL.

WHILE WAITING, MISS JUANITA'S STERN BUMPED ONE OF THE PILINGS OF THE RAILROAD BRIDGE

NO PERSONNEL INJURIES OR POLLUTION REPORTED AT THIS TIME

The barge CC-95585, while under the control of the UTV WISCONSIN allided with the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RR BRIDGE (aka Pekin Railroad Drawbridge) at mile marker 151.2 on the Illinois River. The UTV WISCONSIN was heading up bound to Morris, IL pushing 15 empty grain barges. The operator of the UTV WISCONSIN stated high winds caused the center barge in the port string, CC-95585, to make contact with the RDB protection cell. No damage to the vessel or the bridge occurred as a result of the incident.

On 18JAN12 at approximately 0010 the UTV DIXIE EXPRESS (O.N. 586008) allided with the AGS RR Bridge on the Black Warrior River IVO MM 267.8.  While transiting southbound and lining up for the AGS Railroad Bridge, the vessel was affected by current, which set the vessel down on the starboard pier of the bridge.  No damage to the bridge, and only minor damage to the side shell of the KIRBY 27755.  No further incidents.

On January 25, 2012, at approximately 1800, the DELTA MARINER, a 286.8 foot U.S. Coast Guard certificated cargo vessel departed Decatur, Alabama and proceeded downstream on the Tennessee River with an intended route continuing through the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers into the Gulf of Mexico with a final destination of Port Canaveral, Florida. The DELTA MARINER was manned by 18 personnel including the Master and two river pilot advisors. Two additional persons other than crew were also aboard as representatives of the cargo owner. The DELTA MARINER was carrying a cargo of Delta V rocket components. 

On January 26, 2012, at approximately 1950, the DELTA MARINER approached the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge from upstream at a speed of approximately 12 mph with reported weather of overcast conditions, light rain, 15 mph winds, and good visibility. The vessel was travelling with a river current which the vessel’s crew described as “fast”. Sunset occurred at 1709 and no other ambient light from the moon or other landside sources was reported. 

The Eggner’s Ferry Bridge is a girder style two-lane vehicle bridge for U.S. Highway 68 located on mile marker 41.7 of the Tennessee River. The DELTA MARINER’s voyage plan indicated that the vessel intended to pass under the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge thru span B. Span B is the only one of six spans with published navigational and air draft clearances. Spans B, C, D, & E have fixed navigation lighting in place. On the evening of January 26, 2012, only the navigation lights of span E were lit on the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge.   

At approximately 1953, and within 2.5 miles from the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge, the DELTA MARINER passed the first of four approach buoys to span B.  Immediately afterward, the River Pilot Advisor on watch directed the Chief Mate at the helm to steer the vessel towards the green light marking the middle of span E of the bridge and away from the approach to span B.

At approximately 1958, and within 2 miles of the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge, both the River Pilot Advisor and the Master gave contradicting navigation commands to the Chief Mate at the helm.  The Third Mate, junior to all officers on the team, never intervened or participated in this exchange despite being in the position of Navigation Officer and charged with the overall navigational safety of the vessel. Instead of attempting to turn or stop the vessel as ordered by the Master, the Chief Mate continued towards span E as directed by the River Pilot Advisor at a speed of approximately 12 mph.

At approximately 2000, the DELTA MARINER allided with span E of the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge at a speed of approximately 12 mph. The allision dislodged and destroyed a 322 foot section of the bridge and Hwy 68, leaving most of Span E draped over the bow of the DELTA MARINER and anchoring the vessel soon after impact. Vehicle traffic on Hwy 68 was able to stop prior to reaching span E and no injuries or loss of life occurred to either motorists or the vessel’s crew. As a result of the DELTA MARINER’s allision with the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge, the Eggner’s Ferry Bridge sustained $7,000,000 in damage and the DELTA MARINER sustained $500,000 in damage.

2012-02-07-Captain of the Uninspected Towing Vessel  GABRIEL E ALAINA called USCG to report that his vessel pushing 2 uninspected spud barges allided with the BAYOU BOEUFF RAILROAD BRIDGE. The allision did not cause any damage to tug and tows . Bridge tender reported 2 missing/broken guide timbers and bolts were pulled out of the concrete. Waterway navigation under bridge and bridge traffic were not impeded in anyway due to allision.  No pollution or injuries reported.

On 06Feb2012, D7CC received a report of a bridge allision by the Tug GEORGE ELI with barge and Brickell Ave Bridge.

Bridge and fender system fully operational.  Minimal damage to fender system: One timber wale was cracked (needing replacement); an adjacent timber wale showed wear.

Vessel was transiting up-bound on the Ohio River pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges through downtown Cincinnati, OH. While going through the Taylor South Gate Bridge, the starboard quarter of the tug scraped the right descending pier. Kentucky Department of Transportation was notified and they determined there was no damage to the bridge.

No pollution, no injuries and no damage was observed on the vessel or to the bridge.

Subject vessel reports; while pushing 15 empty open hoppers down bound on the approach to Portland Canal, a wind gust pushed them toward the L&I R/R bridge, the captain attempted a controlled landing on the upstream cell of the L&I R/R Bridge at MM 604.3 OHR. The starboard lead barge allided ("landed") with a protection cell and sustained a 1' X 1" gash, 5' above the water line. The company reports that the vessel did not allide with the bridge itself. The barge as been repaired and placed back in service.
While transiting the Arthur Kill the tug  struck the northern caisson of the Goethals Bridge. Damage was sustained to the northern most railroad tie and to the portside of the vessel.

The subject vessel was pushing 15 barges (14 empty coal/1 loaded corn) down bound at MM 604.4 OHR when the tow rubbed the protection cells at the L & I Bridge.  The empty hopper barge ING 1674 located in the starboard string, third row rubbed along the protection cells for the bridge. The crew visually inspected the barges in the tow and protection cell and reported no damage.

UTV COOPERATIVE VENTURE was up bound when the barge ART 35497B allided with the right descending bank protection cell of the Pekin Railroad Bridge (Chicago & Northwestern RR Bridge). Wind was reported to be the cause of the incident. The UTV COOPERATIVE VENTURE was pushing 15 empty barges (6 dry cargo, 9 ethanol red flags). Completed deck walk and spot checked the voids on the T/B ART 948B. This barge was reported to have possibly rubbed the bridge but there was no evidence of damage.  While barges, ART 9024, & ART 945B were not directly involved in the allision they were adjacent to the Freight Barge ART 35497B and were checked for any possible damage.  No damage, pollution, or injuries were reported due to this incident. Vessel safely continued its transit.

The UTV JOHN R INGRAM while pushing 38 loaded and 2 empty barges allided with Hernando DeSoto I-40 bridge with its coal barge IN 107067.  The strike did not cause a breakaway and the barge IN 107067 has a 2" by 1/2" fracture in bow void bottom knuckle.  Allision was caused by the posting pilot not used to the currents.  Posting pilot tried to compensate but failed which caused damage to coal barge IN 107067.

SECTOR NEW ORLEANS received a report from MSU MORGAN CITY CDO of an Allision between M/V MARIE M. MORGAN and Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge.  CDO stated that the MARIE M. MORGAN was heading Northbound when the bridge tender ordered the vessel to back down.  It has been reported that the vsl did not back down, resulting in the allision.  No significant damage has been reported.  Investigators are enroute.  Current BNM exists on Bayou Boeuf RR bridge instructing vessels to check in with MSU MC or RR bridge tender due to restricted vsl traffic during construction.

On February 20, 2012 MSU Morgan City notified that THE UTV OLIVIA ROSE (O.N. 241248), PUSHING ONE EMPTY UNINSPECTED BARGE, THE USL458, ALLIDED WITH THE BAYOU BOEUF RR BRIDGE. DAMAGE TO THE BRIDGE WAS SOME BENT BEAMS AND A GEAR BOX, CAUSING THE BRIDGE TO BE INCAPABLE OF SWINGING SHUT, AND BACKING UP RAIL TRAFFIC. THERE WAS A REPORT OF OIL LEAKING FROM THE GEAR BOX ONTO THE PIER, BUT NO POLLUTION REPORTED TO THE WATERWAY. THE BRIDGE TENDER IS SENDING A TEAM OUT TO ASSESS THE FULL DAMAGE AND ETR TO THE BRIDGE. THERE WAS NO DAMAGE REPORTED TO THE BARGE. BARGE IS ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE BAYOU BOEUF LOCKS, WAITING FOR DUTY TEAM OF DMI, DINV, AND JMI. NO POLLUTION OR INJURIES WERE REPORTED. CAUSE OF THE ALLISION WAS REPORTED THAT THE WIND PUSHED THE BARGE INTO THE BRIDGE.

On October 26, 2011, the tug G.E.M. (official number 961681) was pushing ahead an unnamed crane barge through the opening of the Niantic Railroad Bridge.  The port stern of the barge allided with the bridge fender system.  There was no damage to the barge or the bridge.  The G.E.M. continued on its way, travelling south to north up the Niantic River, without notifying the Coast Guard of the bridge allision, and also without responding to numerous call-outs on the VHF radio by the bridge operator.  The Master of the tug and the company were later contacted by the Coast Guard Investigator and instructed to submit a CG-2692.

On February 27, 2012, the Sector San Francisco Command Center (SCC) received notification from Golden Gate Ferry company that a passenger sustained an injury on the MV MARIN on February 20, 2012.  At the time of the incident, MV MARIN was moored alongside the dock with a fixed gangway placed on the vessel's brow. It is reported that a female passenger was exiting the MV MARIN and slipped on a fixed gangway at the San Francisco Ferry Terminal.  At the time of the slip, the passenger was carrying her baby son. The passenger was the last to exit the MARIN.  The company reported that the incident was not witnessed by any crew members or employees. The passenger did not report the incident or request first aid from any employee of the Golden Gate. The incident was reported via telephone to the San Francisco Ferry Terminal on February 21, 2012.  The report was verified by the Golden Gate staff on February 24, 2012.  Because of the delayed report, chemical testing was not performed.

No Enforcement Action (EA) is recommended.

The M/V CHARLIE EVERHART (534782, Ingram Barge Co) while pushing 4 empty open hopper barges down bound at MM 190.4 CMB the tow got set by high wind gusts and allided with the Louisville & Nashville RR Drawbridge (CSX, LLNR 3870) RDB pier. The pilot reports no damage to barge OR 5332 and the vessel is continuing to its final destination at MM 187 CMB. Pilot reports no injuries or pollution.

SOHV received a report from the M/V DAVID K. WILSON (534110, Ingram Barge Co) while pushing 6 empty open hopper barges down bound at MM 190.4 CMB the tow got set by high wind gust and allided with the Louisville & Nashville RR Drawbridge (CSX, LLNR 3870) RDB pier. The vessel is tied off at MM 189 and reports no damage, injury, or pollution.

Master of UTV KYOVA reported collission with T/B USL 131 while assisting the UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY with fleeting at Marathon Lower South Point Fleet at Ohio River MM319.  The UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY was faced up to the T/B USL 131.  The port tow knee of the UTV KYOVA impacted the T/B USL 131 at the forward bulkhead of the #1 port wing void causing a 21" vertical crack in the hull plating at the deck sheer.  The crack was approximately 18" above the waterline.  T/B USL 131 was loaded with Propylene Oxide.  No pollution was reported.  Marine Inspectors from MSU Huntington responded to the incident.  T/B USL 131 received a  temporary repair of an epoxy patch and continued to Kenova River MM 48 for offload.  A PTP was issued for vessel to transit to Southwest Shipyard in Houston, TX for permanent repair.  The UTVs KYOVA and BRIDGET CAULLEY were both undamaged.

24MAY11 - The pilot on the UTV John R Ingram reported his vessel allided with the Railroad Bridge in Vicksburg, MS at MM 435.9. Striking the bridge with his port side while North Bound on the Lower Mississippi River. His tow consisted of 20 dry cargo barges, 4 empties, and no red flags. Minor damage to 4th barge back on port string (tow was 7 long).Tow remained intact, though 7 support wires were snapped, no barges adrift. No assistance requested or required. River current excessive due record flood stage. River level was approx. 55.9 ft; 13 feet above flood level.

No pollution or further damage reported.

Drugs and/or alcohol due not appear to be a factor in this case.
Sector New York received a report from a 911 dispatch that a crane onboard a barge  being towed by a towing vessel , struck the scaffolding center span on east side of the Brooklyn Bridge.

On 18MAR12 at approx. 0415 (all times local) the UTV YVONNE CONWAY, pushing 15 loaded barges (2 coal, 13 rock) upbound at the approach to R.C. Byrd L&D at MM 279 OHR, allided with the bullnose.  A strong eddy, due to high water conditions, set the head of the tow out toward the end of the long wall.  Pilot was unable to get the head of the tow to respond quickly enough to avoid hitting the bullnose on the long wall with the port lead corner of the tow (C-1135).

The C-1135 received damage to port lead corner and broke away from the tow but was quickly recovered and put back into the tow without further incident. Attending Coast Guard investigating officer confirmed no flooding of the voids on the damaged barge.  No other damage, injury, or pollution resulted. 

At approx 1030, Coast Guard investigation was completed, tow was re-configured, and vessel was permitted to resume northbound transit to MM35 OHR.

17MAR2012, 1415:  Barge FMT 2710, in tow of NB UTV BAXTER SOUTHERN, allides with (stbd side grazes) concrete pillar of Simmesport Bridge MM5 Atchafalaya River.  


No further injuries, damage or pollution.

M/V ROBERT T (969110, Luhr Bros.) pushing 12 empty flat deck barges at MM 980.4 OHR got set by high winds and allided with the center span pier (KY side) of the Cairo Bridge (LLNR 28370). Pilot reports broken wires, but no other damage, injury, or pollution. Pilot reports he sees no structural damage to the bridge pier.

The M/V Evey T down bound on the CMBR pushing 14 empty dry cargo barges when the lead port barge ING5578 allided with the Henry R. Lawrence Memorial Bridge (MM 63 CMR). due to high winds  Bridge did not sustain damage as a result of the allision.

On March 20, 2012, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City, Louisiana received a report that the Uninspected Towing Vessel UNCLE GEORGE pushing 02 empty freight barges, allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge. The bridge reported minor damage.  The UNCLE GEORGE reported no damage to the barges or tug. 

No pollution and no personnel injuries reported.

The Tug W.P. SCOTT with 4 POB and Tug REGINA Twith 2 POB, were southbound in the ICW near West Palm Beach, FL. They were towing 2 deck barges, MB 1213 (150ft.) and MB 523 (120 ft.). W.P. SCOTT was positioned at the stern and was faced up to barge MB 1213 with MB 523 hard wired ahead of it. Tug REGINA T was pulling with a short hawser to the bow of MB 523. They were set down by the wind and current and the starboard bow of MB 1213 (notch between both barges) contacted the NW side of the fendering system of the Southern Boulevard Bridge causing extensive damage.

Baldwin Bridge pinned up against fendering system. Spud Barge (Marland 120) was spudded when due to the weather conditions and current the barge pinned up against the fendering system. Currently no updates to if the fendering system was damaged. Sunrise towing has picked up the barge and is planning on taking the barge back to Central Boat Rentals in Berwick LA.

Subject vessel advised that while making the approach to the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Drawbridge, they were caught by an out-draft and allided with the right descending protection cell(s) of the drawbridge.  After the allision the barges in the tow broke free, the vessel was able to reconfigure the tow.  It was discovered that two barges had minor damage on the sterns.

RCVD report from the Captain O/B UTV JOE WARD pushing 6 barges (4 empty 2 loaded) made contact with a metal sheer fender on the North side of the Galveston Causeway Bridge. He stated that the STBD outside coupling on MEM 5182 hopper barge made contact and there was no damage to barge. Incident occurred at 0800 and is en-route Brownsville harbor MM682. No Pollution or injuries reported. Fendering system is part the old protective sheeting that is currently being replaced by new protective system. Tender was notified.

On 27 March, 2012, the tug THUBAN was towing the barge HYDRA 1200 on the east channel of the New Bedford bridge. The barge rubbed up against the rubber bridge fender arrangement. No damage occurred to the barge or bridge other than minor scratches to the bridge fender system.

On 14FEB2012, a southbound tug was pushing ahead two empty deck barges on the Intracoastal Waterway south of Fernandina, FL.  The tug was maneuvering through the navigational span of the Kingsley Creek Bridge (including the First Coast Railroad Bridge 43.20).  While transiting the span, the vessel's master claimed the current set the vessel to starboard and he was unable to overcome the current.  As a result, the aft barge made contact with the bridge fendering system.  The barge sustained no damage, but GWRR (operators of the bridge) produced documentation claiming fendering system was damaged during allision.  Vessel's master stated he was unable to determine extent of damage, if any, to the fendering system.  Professional engineer surveyed bridge and provided estimates of damage.  No injuries or pollution as a result of this incident.

The tip MF whip antenna on the allided with the Bayonne Bridge.  The antenna bent back on the first girdle, and when clear snapped forward and struck the second girdle, which caused the top foot of the antenna to snap off.

On April 3, 2012, at approximately 0630, the UTV EVELYN DORIS (O.N. 274942) was transiting southbound in the Elizabeth River while pushing the grain barge, EMI 4004 (O.N. 665818).  The operator of the UTV EVELYN DORIS had difficulty transiting through the bridge span due to a combination of the wheel wash from two tugs docking a ship in the vicinity of Elizabeth River Terminal and the river current, resulting in the barge EMI 4004 alliding with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge.  The UTV EVELYN DORIS and barge EMI 4004 did not sustain any damages.  The Gilmerton Bridge also did not sustain any damage.  No injuries or environmental damage.

On 5 April 2012 The UTV L P Wright was transiting up bound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) through the Merchant Railroad Drawbridge (mile marker 183.2 UMR) pushing a crane barge when the crane allided with the bottom of the bridge. The operator stated that the wake from another northbound vessel caused the barge to rise up enough so that the crane made contact with the bridge. There are several "X" bracings broken underneath the main span of the bridge. The L P Wright did not go all the way through the bridge. He is currently south of the bridge pulled off on the bank. There was no pollution or injuries but the operator is unable to tell what damage there is to the barge.

On April 8, 2012, at approximately 1140, the UTV NAVIGATOR (O.N. 641121) was transiting northbound in the Elizabeth River while pushing a grain barge, EMI 4001 (O.N. 651476). The operator of the UTV NAVIGATOR had problems transiting through the bridge span due to the river current, resulting in the barge EMI 4001 alliding with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge. The UTV NAVIGATOR and barge EMI 4001 did not suffer any damage.  The Gilmerton Bridge also did not suffer any damage.  No injuries or environmental damage.

Received call reporting a bridge allision between the UTV Kansas City (o.n. 543008) and the Sabula RR Bridge. No damage reported to either the bridge, its fendering, or the UTV/barges. No injuries or pollution reported.

UTV RAY A. ECKSTEIN had been backed in at mm 46.5 UMR RDB due to fog. When fog lifted they got underway. Their lead starboard barge hit a finger dike on the RDB causing the starboard string of 5 barges to break away. UTV was 6 wide and 5 long loaded with coal and grain. UTV COAL EXPRESS assisted with rounding up the break-aways. No P, D, or I with the exception of broken wires. ATON not a factor.

Offshore Supply Vessel RYAN CHOUEST did not sufficiently clear Bayou Sale Bridge located in Highway 317 at Intercoastal Waterway Mile Marker 115 and its mast scrapped the underside of the bridge. Vessel is fully operational except its mast light and there was no damage to bridge.

Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center received a report from the UTV HELEN MERRILL reporting an allision with the Chester Highway Bridge located at mile marker 109.9 on the Upper Mississippi River. The vessel was southbound pushing 03 Red Flag barges loaded with Ethanol prior to the allision. The master explained that the pilot aligned his approach to transit through the Northbound Span rather than the southbound span. The operator realized the error and attempted to correct his course and align with the southbound bridge span, but was unable to correct his course in time, causing barge number WCT 3007 (Ethanol) to lightly allide with the Chester Highway Bridge. A minor inset in the barge occurred, but there were no water integrity issues. No damage was reported for the bridge and no injuries or pollution resulted.

On April 15, 2012 at approximately 1900 local time the UTV RED FISH was transiting the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway when one of the barges it was pushing ahead, the HTCO 3003, made contact with the bridge ramp on the Caney Creek Swing Bridge. No damage, pollution or injuries occurred and the bridge remained operational.

On 17 April 2012, at approximately 2230, the Uninspected Fishing Vessel (UFV) OCEAN REVENGE (O.N. 553430) was transiting in the vicinity of the 2nd Island of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel Island with eight persons on board when the vessel grounded on the rocks during an ebb tide. The vessel waited for the flood tide. With the assistance from the UFV ASHLEY GAIL (O.N. 636187) the vessel successfully floated free with no observed damage to the vessel or injury to the crew. The vessel transisted to Newport News harbor and was pulled out to be inspected.

During the course of the investigation, it was determined that due to the nature of manning requirements on scallop fishing vessels, it is common for a single operator to be in control of the vessel for up to 16 hours per day during a fishing trip. Since the vessel is limited to 8 persons on board, operators usually man the vessel with members who will be conducting fishing operations. This could lead to fatigue of the operator at the helm.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the grounding of the vessel on the rocky seabed. This was followed by damage to the vessel's hull paint, indent on the keel, port & starboard sides, with damage to the engine keel cooler and kortz nozzle, rudder shoe, lower pintle bearing and propeller. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty were: (1) manning limitations in place and (2) fatigue of the operator.
UTV Craig E Phillip allided with the I-155 bridge at MM 838.7 LMR. Barges IN096018 and ING2096 were damaged.

On April 22, 2012, the M/V BAI CHAY BRIDGE (Flag; Panama) experienced a reduction in main engine propulsion while departing the port of Long Beach, CA.  The vessel's Master initially reported a Loss of Propulsion but the vessel never lost steerage and maintained 4-6 knots while maneuvering out of the traffic lanes for repairs.  The Induction Control Unit (ICU) malfunctioned on the #2 cylinder and the control system automatically reduced the vessels speed down to 6 knots, preventing damage to the main engine.  The vessel's crew replaced the ICU with a spare onboard.  The vessel proceeded to outside anchorage where the Classification Society Surveyor attested to the proper operation of the main engine.
While moving a fuel service pump to mount as a bulkhead spare, the 3rd Asst. Engineer strained the right side of the neck onboard the USNS BRIDGE.

UTV HELEN pushing 1 empty saltwater barge allided with a railroad bridge due to wind and current. No damage reported for UTV or barge. Railroad bridge sustained minor damage to the federing system timbers.

25APR12; 0300: UTV CITY OF NEW ORLEANS is NB at MM 4 Atchafalaya River with 4 loaded red flag barges. Inspected Barge KIRBY 28709 struck the Simmesport Railroad Bridge as the tug and tow passed beneath the bridge. No damage reported to bridge. Button came completely off of KIRBY 28709 and the KIRBY 28169 sustained an indentation of the port side approximately 360" X 55". Damage to barges detailed in Inspection Activities 4295126 and 4295200.

No further damage, pollution, or injuries reported.

On April 27, 2012  the UTV CORPUS CHRISTI pushing 4 red flag barges allied with the Morgan City Railroad Bridge.

Owner/Operator failed to submit CG-2692 within 5 days.  See EA:4308313.

04/29/2012 - The F/V Uncle Bayou was transiting inbound to the Old Brazos River when its outriggers struck the underside of the FM 1495 Bridge. The outriggers had been left upright in the stowed position. The impact bent and twisted both outriggers with damage extending from the halfway point out to the tips. 

CG STA FREEPORT received anonymous calls regarding the allision and dispatched personnel to check the bridge and attend the vessel at the pier. The bridge appeared unharmed which was later confirmed by the Texas DOT. The vessels was located but no personnel were present. The master of the vessel made no report of the allision. 

On 04/30/2012- A Team from MSU Texas City attended the vessel after it had a 1 outrigger fail and fold in half as it was transiting outbound. The vessel also violated a security zone while making temporary repairs. The vessel was escorted back to the pier where a 4100F and CFVSE were conducted. The results of the boardings combined with stability concerns due to the damaged outriggers lead to the issuance of COTP order. This order was cleared in 24 hours.

On April 27, 2012, at approximately 1210, the towing vessel LISA MORAN (O.N. 1199589), was maneuvering (backing out) the hopper barge M3100 (O.N. 651185) from pier 2 at Colonna's Shipyard when the starboard bow line parted. This caused the barge M 3100 to make contact with the north side of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge #5, located in the eastern branch of the Elizabeth River. No injuries, no pollution and no damage were sustained to the barge or bridge fendering system.

04/25/2012- The tow of the UTV COVE POINT (Official #1168245) allided with the bridge fendering system. The reported damage caused the north-eastern fendering unit to fold back. This fender has been damaged repeatedly in the past without permanent repair. No damage was found on the barge. 

05/29/2012- A damage estimate received from TX-DOT reports replacement cost to be $135,540.00 of which TX-DOT attributes one half to the vessel due to previous damage.

0100 CST 01MAY2012
MSU PORT ARTHUR COMMAND CENTER notified MSU LAKE CHARLES CDO that the Master of the UTV JASON LUHR (WDC2250) had called to report that a empty hopper barge he was pushing had an allision with the ELLENDER BRIDGE at MM 241.5 on the ICW IVO Lake Charles, LA heading east bound. 
the master stated that the tug-and-barge unit was at full stop when the wind pushed the barge against the bridge fendering at approx less than 1 KT. 
The master stated that a CG-2692 would be issued by the home office. 
No injuries, damage or pollution. 
0530 CST, 01MAY2012
Duty MI/IO was notified; responded at first light. 
D8 Bridges Branch was notified.

On May 3, 2012 at approximately 1940 local time, the UTV HARRY M (ON: 564341) was pushing the barge D.B. OLYMPIA (ON: 1027118) northbound in the Duwamish Waterway. The barge and tug were set to the west by the tidal current.  A derrick crane on board the barge struck the underside of the Duwamish Railroad bridge as it passed underneath.  The tug and barge proceeded out to Elliott Bay and anchored until daylight when a damage assessment could safely be conducted.

There was no damage to the tug and barge.  The crane luffing jib was damaged.  The Duwamish Railroad bridge suffered minor damage to the underside beams.  A damage assessment was completed and the bridge remained operational.

M/V HOLY ANGEL (261329, Excell Marine) reports they allided with the left descending main channel span of the I.C. Railroad bridge at MM 977.7 OHR. They have 14 barges in tow (No red flag barges), and report they had some broken wires due to the allision but no other D/P/I.

The UTV BRITNEY LEE allided with the Left Decending Bank (LDB) Side of the Sabula Rail Road Bridge ( Mile 535 Upper Misssissippi River)  protective barrier breaking 2 timbers. Mate had fenders in place, no damage to UTV.

10 May 2012, 0422: Rcvd a report from the Melville R/R Bridge that the southbound UTV FATHER PAT, pushing 6 loaded rock barges, allided with the center bridge pillar.  The bridge tender reported that the bridge is in good working order and no damage was reported. There was no damage reported to the barge, DIAMOND 200, that allided with the bridge.  

No further pollution, damages, or injury reported.

On 10MAY12 at approx 2345 (local time) the UTV D. A. GRIMM was making downbound approach to Parkersburg R/R bridge (OHR MM184) with 15 empty jumbo hopper barges.  The tow set too far to the left by swift current and allided (rubbed) with the left descending bridge pier.  The barge that allided was the second barge out from the UTV GRIMM in the port string.  3 broken wires with no further damage to rpt.  Bridge owner notified. MSU Huntington notified and investigating.

11MAY12 at 0430 MSU IO and UTV examiner boarded vessel at Prices Landing (OHR MM189) to conduct on scene investigation.  Visually inspected all port string barge voids to confirm no flooding.  Collected written statement from vessel pilot and released vessel to resume normal operations

11MAY12, 0045: The certificated tank barge STC2602, being pushed SB by UTV FRANK B TAMBLE allided with the Natchez Bridge at MM 363.3 LMR.  No damage to the bridge was reported.  

No further damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

Post casualty drug testing was performed. Separate notification created to alert MMLD see notification 529629.

SCC received call from the Surf City Swing Bridge Tender in regards to a 64ft TUG and 354 ftBARGE named NAVIGATOR stated Starboard side alliied with the fendering system of the bridge.
