Barge offloaded wheat in Wilmington and was empty at the time of the Incident. No damage observed by the Bridge Tender. TUG is currently en route to Norfolk, VA.

On June 4, 2012, the uninspected towing vessel CAPT WILLIE was pushing the derrick barge "SWING THOMPSON" eastbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway in the vicinity of the Bayou Dularge Bridge, mile marker 29.  The derrick barge allided with the south dolphin system casusing minor damage to the dolphin.  No vessel damage or pollution is associated with this incident.

On May 25, 2012, at approximately 1215 a.m., the uninspected towing vessel BETH WILSON, pushing two empty barges, west-bound through the West Port Arthur Bridge on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway allided with the northern bridge fender.  The winds were approximately 30 mph out of the south, off the vessel's port side. The winds pushed the vessel's tow into the fendering system, however there was no damage to the vessel or bridge. Immediately after the allision, the master of the BETH WILSON pushed the tow up against the bank of the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway and made the required notifications.

On 6JUN12, at approximately 1421 LT, Sector San Francisco's Command Center (SCC) received notification from the Marine Superintendant of Golden Gate Bridge, Highway Transportation District (GGB) that the M/V GOLDEN GATE (ferry) experienced a hydraulic control alarm. Alarm activation caused the Master to shut down the port outboard jet drive and its Main Diesel Engine (MDE) to troubleshoot the problem. The GOLDEN GATE was just leaving the dock at Pier 41 in San Francisco with 35 persons on board when the incident occurred.  
Investigation by TGGB's internal mechanical engineer diagnosed the problem and found it to be a loose fitting on a hydraulic hose. This loose fitting caused approximately 5 gallons of hydraulic oil to enter the water and forced the shutdown of the MDE and jet drive. The hydraulic hose is part of the hydraulic control for the jet drive and it is external to the hull of the vessel. It is unknown why the fitting became loose but, speculated that it was due to normal vibration and cavitations associated with the vessel. The company is working on corrective measures to prevent this in the future by means of preventive maintenance and or environmentally safe hydraulic fluid. Sector San Francisco's Duty Marine Inspector (DMI) verified that repairs were made, see activity #4336155. The GOLDEN GATE was able to safely disembark passengers at the Larkspur Terminal after making the transit using three engines and jet drives as per local protocol. No injuries or damage resulted from this casualty. Drug and alcohol testing was not conducted. On 06JUN12, Sector San Francisco Incident Management Division received a report that the ferry GOLDEN GATE discharged approximately 5 gallons of hydraulic oil into San Francisco Bay.

The M/V  with a reported air draft of 142 feet allided with the Bayonne Bridge.  The Bayonne Bridge air gap reading at the time of the allision was showing a reading of 149 feet.  The pilot reported that part of the mast struck the underside of the Bayonne Bridge.
At approximately 0615 on 01 JUN 2012 (local time) a Container Ship's INMARSAT antenna struck the bottom of the Bayonne Bridge.

A Coast Guard member working a security zone reported that he saw the Space Shuttle Enterprise, while being towed by the Tug Shelby, Weeks Marine Tug, struck the Beach Channel Cross Bay Blvd RR Bridge in Jamaica Bay.

On June 8, 2012 the Ferry Vessel M/V GOLDEN GATE was operating on its normal route between the San Francisco Ferry Building and the Larkspur Ferry Terminal.  At approximately 0805, the GOLDEN GATE was making her approach to the Larkspur Ferry Terminal with two licensed captains on the bridge.  At this moment, the Master in Charge (MIC), had to leave the bridge due to an intestinal disorder, leaving only one Master (Master in Navigational Command - MNC) on the bridge as the GOLDEN GATE was approaching its berth at Larkspur.  The MNC on the bridge elected to land the GOLDEN GATE by himself.  At approximately 0809, the GOLDEN GATE was approaching Berth 2 and the MNC attempted to shift conning control from the Pilot House operating station to the port bridge wing operating station unsuccessfully.  Subsequently, the MNC did not have time to regain positive control of the vessel before the GOLDEN GATE experienced an allision with the fendered piling and cement structure of the terminal near the point between Berths 1 and 2.  There were 14 passengers and 6 crew members on board at the time of the incident.  No injuries or pollution was reported as a result of the incident.  Damage estimates for the GOLDEN GATE as a result of the casualty are $10K.  The cause of the casualty was the failure of the MNC to ensure that control of the GOLDEN GATE had transferred from the Pilot House to the port bridge wing.

Recommend Enforcement Action (EA) against the MNC for Negligence leading to the allision.

UTV CITY OF NEW ORLEANS transitting westbound, ICWW MM393, with 4 empty red flag barges, allided with a privately owned pier at Bridge Harbor Yacht Club. Vessel Master stated that strong south west winds and strong outbound tide pushed vessel and tow towards the north bank causing the allision. Barge K30001T reportedly damaged 3 pillings. Barges under TBSIP and no damage reported.

On 21Jun12, at approximately 1630LT, the ferry M/V NAPA had to shut down the #2 Main Diesel Engine due to a low lube oil alarm on the bridge. This incident caused hydraulic fluid to enter San Francisco Bay, a navigable US waterway.

On June 10, 2012 at 1807L, Sector New Orleans received a report that the towing vessel BILL SEYMOUR allided with the Claiborne Avenue Bridge.  Damages sustained to the xxxxis a bent mast and shattered mast lights, but there are no damages sustained to the bridge.  There are no secondary casualties, pollution or injuries to report.

Received call from an Individual who works as a bridge operator at the Westlake Railroad Bridge. The individual stated that a towing vessel named SPOILER pushing one barge northbound allided with the fendering system on the Westlake Railroad Bridge on the southwest side. The vessel did not stop, but captain stated he would return in one hour to follow up with the damages. The fendering system appears to be severely damaged, however the infrastructure of the bridge itself was not damaged and is still fully operational. No injuries and no pollution reported at this time.

See IO statement for further information.

The Tug BISCAYNE(O.N. 292153), allided with the Dodge Island Railroad Bascule Bridge.The bridge is currently undergoing repairs and the information is posted in the Local Notice to Mariners (LNM). The North span of the Rail Road bridge was in the lowered position and the South span was raised. The Master noticed that the Road Bridge span that is parallel to the RR Bridge, was raised and did not see the lowered RR span until the last minute and had to back down. The pilot house upper railings, spotlights, fire monitor and radar tower were all damaged. The RR Bridge was not damaged except for minor scrapes.

It is the opinion of the IO and UTV Inspector that attended the vessel  that there was no negligence involved. The lowered span was hard to see with construction going on and the spans on both bridges were in different positions. This  incident was reported immediately, there was no damage to the bridge and minor damage to the tug. The Master of the vessel immediately completed alcohol and drug testing as per company policy.

18SEP12: A surveyor inspected the bridge and advised there was no damage except for some paint scratches.

On July 1, 2012 at approximately 0730 local time the UTV RANDY ECKSTEIN was travelling westbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway pushing six empty barges when the barges ACL 10137 and ACL 01700 made contact with the northeast fender system of the Caney Creek Swing Bridge. No damage, pollution or injuries occurred and the swing bridge remained operational.

On July 9,  2012,  The UTV RAY ME was pushing a crane barge under the Sakonnet river bridge when the extended crane on the barge allided with the bridge. The vessel was southbound traveling between Fall River, MA and Tiverton, RI. No damage was sustained on the bridge, a five foot end portion of the crane was damaged.

2012-07-12-WSW-Updated activity to reflect data from LA DOTcorrespondence and CG-2692.

Two loaded barges being towed by the UTV General Ellis (568367) allided with and damaged the Northwest Fender System of the Adeline Bridge in Adeline, LA.  Damages are estimated at $34,160.00.  The allision occured at 0940 on 10APR12 and did not interfere with marine or rail traffic.  As of 10JUL12 the damage is still in place.  It is unkown how many crewmembers were onboard the UTV General Ellis and the cargo is not known at this time.  The captain reported no damage to the bridge tender.  The bridge tender submitted a report to Coast Guard Bridge Administration.

9 July 2012:  Sector New Orleans received a notification of an allision between an UTV and the Lapalco Bridge.  The UTV sustained damage to its mast light.  The bridge is still open to vessel and vehicular traffic.  No further casualties to report.

Sector Long Island Sound Investigations Division received notification that a crew member on the ferry vessel P.T.BARNUM fell, injuring his left knee.  The crew member was directed to submit to post-casualty drug and alcohol testing.

USCG SECUMR rcvd a telephone call from the Sabula RR Drawbridge (535.0 UMR) stating the UTV Frank B Tamble allided with them while attempting to transit through the bridge. The bridge tender stated that he rubbed the protection cell and he did not see any damage to his bridge. SECUMR contacted the UTV who stated it was his first time transitting the bridge and he slightly rubbed the rub plate with his stbd barge (2 empty AA barges, side by side). There was no D/P/I and the rub was so slight they couldn't even find where it touched. They pushed in at 536.3 RDB and were ntfd to stby until cleared by MSD Quad Cities.  MSD QC IO and DPO attended vessel to verify report of no damage.  Slight rub was observed on stbd bow, no other damage.  Vessel cleared to continue transit.

UTV LAURA TAMBLE's port head barge allided with the fourth pier from the right descending bank of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge channel span located at Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282.1. The UTV was pushing 4 empty liquid fertilizer barges. No injuries, pollution or damage occurred to the vessel or the bridge.

On January 30, 2012, at approximately 1325 local time, the 154 foot, U. S. flagged passenger vessel M/V MARIN was being moored at the Ferry Terminal in Sausalito, California, when the starboard bridge wing throttle control station's port lever failed to respond to inputs by the crew.  The Master was able to regain control of the MARIN from the main control station and safely moor the vessel without further incident.

Subsequent investigation by the Golden Gate Ferry Port Engineer determined the problem to be a mechanically stuck V2 Control Valve.  The valve was replaced by the engineering crew and the system tested satisfactory for  the attending Coast Guard Marine Inspector (MI).  There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident.

No Enforcement Action (EA) is recommended.

On July 28, 2012, at 0630 the tank vessel SITEAM DISCOVERER was up bound on the Weymouth Fore River enroute to the CITGO facility in Braintree Massachusetts.  While passing through the Weymouth Fore River Bridge, the vessel was set to one side of the channel and the starboard side of the vessel made contact with the fendering system.  No damage to either the vessel or the bridge occurred.

On 23JUL12 at approx 1440 , while transiting northbound on the Minnesota River, the UTV MARY J pushing two barges struck the Savage Railroad swing bridge at MM 14.5 on the right descending side of the bridge with the lead barge (MTC 501) damaging the sheer fence above the turntable.  Two boards of the sheer fence are reported as broken.  No damage to the barge, pollution or injuries.  (Casualty was not immediately reported by involved party.  MSD St. Paul officially received CG-2692 on 31JUL12.)

M/V FAST RUNNER was conducting sea trials with Lafayette Marine Inspector when mast of vsl hit Bayou Dularge Bridge. Vsl mast head light broken and two support cables for mast damaged. No report of injury or pollution.

On August 8, 2012, at approximately 0900, the uninspected towing vessel HOSS (O.N. 290076) was transiting southbound in the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River with one empty barge in an alongside configuration. The HOSS had the mud scow 3001, secured to the port side of the tug, with the HOSS secured to the starboard side of the 3001. The intention of the transit was to shift the position of the 3001 from the #3 berth at Colonna's Shipyard to the gas free dock located south of the Bridge #5. While transiting through the bridge, the tug HOSS made contact with the fendering system of the bridge while trying to increase the clearance of the port side of the 3001. The tug HOSS had three large tires that served as fenders for the hull which broke free and sank in the vicinity of the navigational waterway. The bridge fendering system did not have any significant damage and no injuries were reported.

Sector Hampton Roads Waterways Branch was notified concerning the lost tires for further evaluation of waterway restriction or informational broadcast concerning the event and the tires.

Recommend closing this marine casualty case and referral for enforcement action.

Vessel was north bound coming through the triple bridge complex and rubbed the north east dolphin of the Morgan City RxR Bridge. Said he bumped the dolphin, stopped and came ahead.

15AUG2012-WSW IO opened enforcement activity 4411574.

At 1930Z on 13AUG2012, MSD Saipan received a report of a sheen at Saipan Harbor outer anchorage L-47, a U.S. navigable waterway.  The tug vessel CHAMORRO suffered a fuel leak from the towing line's engine on the main deck, discharging an estimated two gallons of hydraulic oil from the port side deck drain, creating a sheen upon the waterway.  Seabridge Inc. is the owner of the equipment and has been determined to be the Responsible Party.

After the UTV MR. Gilbert, D/B SWING THOMPSON pushed up onto the bank so that CG investigating department could conduct interviews after the group allided with two bridges before. The group got underway with 2 new assist tugs and lined up to proceed through the Homua Navigation Canal Bridge.
When the D/B SWING THOMPSON was entering the channel they called to one of the assist tugs to push them to the west despite being instructed to coordinate vessel movement with the lead tug. This caused the D/B SWING THOMPSON to hit the west wall of the Houma Navigational Bridge.

The commercial fishing vessel BOUNTY HUNTER was outbound on the Annisquam River and was the last of three vessels waiting for the Western Avenue Highway Bridge to open.  The bridge tender had received a call for a opening and had heard two vessels on his radio but due to an admitted blind spot created by darkness and a fully open near span on the river side, the tender did not see the BOUNTY HUNTER.  Two vessels passed through with no issues and the bridge closed as the BOUNTY HUNTER was passing under and the spans came into contact with the roof of the BOUNTY HUNTER.

The UTV MR. GILBERT pulling derrick barge DB SWING THOMPSON allided with the west side of the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge. MR. GILBERT was the lead tug towing the derrick barge with two assist tugs on the stern, UTV DEAN  and UTV LAYLA RENEE. As the vessel was transiting through the bridge, the lead tug mis-aligned it's approach causing the D/B SWING THOMPSON to allide with the bridge.
MSU Lake Charles received report that the UTV CREOLE BELL pushing one empty tank barge allided with the Grand Lake Bridge on the ICW MM 231.  No damage to the bridge or the vessels.

HOU2012/0287: Uninspected Towing Vessel Arabian pushing one empty barge under the San Jacinto Rail Road Bridge in Channelview came into contact with the lower steel girder of the bridge.  The PV vent protective cover on the barge was damaged. No Damage, pollution or injuries reported. District-8 and State Opcen notified. Vessel moored at Lyndel Channelview. No repairs were made to the barge vent; only small dent in the aluminum cap of the vent. Case closed.

August 26, 2012 approximately 0211 local time the UTV ROSS SALVAGGIO was traveling west bound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway (ICW) at MM 420 when the barge KIRBY 28706 allided with the north piling of the Caney Creek Bridge. No damage, pollution or injuries occurred.

On August 24, 2012 at 1510 approximately 30 minutes past high tide, an unnamed work-deck barge towed by the 59.2' UTV MISS JENNIFER (O.N. 531761) allided with the southern side of the Wappoo Cut Bridge fendering system at mile marker 470 on the Intracoastal Waterway near Charleston, South Carolina.  The weather was clear with NE winds 5-10kts.  The mate was the operator at the time of the incident and was also towing a second barge and approximately 1000' of dredge pipe behind the barges for a total tow length of 1185' from Wilmington, North Carolina to St. Augustine, Florida.  Two smaller escort tugs, the UTV MISS LEANNE (O.N. 1192522) and the UTV PROUD MARY (O.N. 1203287) were tending to the dredge pipe at the time of the incident.  The MISS JENNIFER entered Wappoo Creek at slack tide and maneuvered the tow beneath the southern side of the bridge.  The aft barge in tow struck the fendering system resulting in splintering of the wooden fenders and a split to the port bow of the barge hull.  No other damages or injuries were reported.

Pilot reports the mast of the vsl  "touched" the AK Bridge. No damage to the ship or bridge reported by pilot.
CG MBR's conducted on site investigation/inspection and found the ships mast to be bent back with the INMARSAT-C antenna broken off, dangling by its wires.

The UTV PAT WHITE was D/B in control of a six barge dry cargo tow (3x2 configuration) when the left,  stern,  aft, barge (CC-1196B)  allided with the Lower Pekin R/R Drawbridge (AKA Chicago and Northwestern RR Bridge) at MM 151.2 ILR.  The left stern corner of barge (CC-1196B) allided (rubbed) the LDB bridge protection cell wooden fender system. There was no damage, pollution or injuries. Tow safely continued transit. This bridge is a known obstruction bridge under the Truman-Hobbs Bridge Act.

MSD Victoria called Sector Corpus Christi Command Center (SCC) and reported that the Victoria Barge Canal railroad Bridge fender system was ran in to by the tug Cheryl Ann's empty barge. The tug was powering two barges, the D-B-5 and the D-B-3. While transiting inbound through the Victoria Barge Canal, the second barge in tow (D-B-5) allided with the fender system of the Railroad Bridge. MSD Victoria assessed damages and found damage to the bottom board of fendering system on starboard side of bridge. Upon inspection of tug and bage, MSD Victoria did not find damage to tug or barges.

18 SEP12; 2015: UTV CHAROLETTE is north bound on the MCPAAR/GIWW IVO MM58, pushing 2 loaded red flag barges. The tow allides with the Morley R/R Bridge along the west side fendering system.

No injuries, pollution, and no damages reported.

Sector Boston Command Center received notification from Anthony Cerulle at BOSTON DUCK TOURS that the LONGFELLOW BRIDGET became disabled in the CHARLES RIVER for unknown reasons. BOSTON DUCK TOURS dispatched a second duck boat to assist and tow LONGFELLOW BRIDGET out of the river. There were no reported injuries onboard the vessel. BOSTON DUCK TOURS reported the vessel will be inspected to determine the cause of incident. Sector Boston Command Center notified duty DMI and duty IO. DUTY DMI will follow up when cause of incident is known.

On September 22, 2012, at approximately 1745 local time, the passenger ferry MARIN observed a hydraulic fluid leak from the distribution block on the port main engine hydraulic pump while approaching the pier in Sausalito, CA.  After disembarking all passengers, the vessel shutdown the port main engine for the voyage from Sausalito to Larkspur, CA to conduct repairs.

On July 10, 2012, it was reported that one of the fishing vessel DAY STAR outriggers struck the Atlantic Beach Bridge as it was transiting through.  The Bridge Operator reported no obvious damage to the bridge but that the DAY STAR had bent their outrigger. 

The Bridge Operator made initial report to the Coast Guard. Vessel Operator did NOT make an immediate report to the Coast Guard. CG Investigating Officer contacted both the vessel operator (who admitted hitting the bridge) and the managing owner to advise that a CG-2692 must be filed within 5 days.  No report was ever recieved.

UTV MR GILBERT pulling the DB SWING THOMPSON allided with the Bayou Dularge bridge. MR. Gilbert was the lead tug towing the DB SWING THOMPSON with two assist tugs on the stern, UTV DEAN & UTV LAYLA RENEE. As the flotilla was transiting through the bridge the DB SWING THOMPSON allided with the south wall of the Dularge Bridge.

On October 1, 2012,  at approximately 1115 local time, the 127 foot passenger ferry NAPA was at the San Francisco Ferry Terminal dock being readied for afternoon runs, when the number three engine failed to start.  The vessel continued operating, with Coast Guard approval, with its remaining three engines.

At 020655Z Oct 12, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (Sec UMR CC) received a call from the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge (mile marker 535 UMR) stating that at 0605Z the passenger ship American Queen allided with the bridge causing minor damage to the bridge. The allision bent some hand rails and damaged some walkway gratings that are in use for construction. No other damage is being reported to the bridge at this time. The bridge tender also reported that twenty minutes prior to the allision, the American Queen called them and said they were have some trouble with their steering. Sector UMR CC called the American Queen on their cell phone to see if any type of assistance was needed. The pilot said there was no apparent damage and there is no danger. He stated that the bridge tender told him that his stern rubbed the lower end of the swing span.

Bridge tender was unable to provide an estimate of damage to the bridge and they do not intend to complete work on the affected area of the bridge at this time. According to the bridge tender they have no records of repairs completed to the affected area of the bridge. Damage to the bridge was so minor that they will not be conducting any repair work.

Steering Issues that were reported by the AMERICAN QUEEN were due to vessel operating with the use of Azimuth Pod (Z Drive), specifically listed on their COI as an auxiliary system, and did not affect the main steering system of the vessel.   Z Drive suffered casualty due to worn solenoid switch identified by IOs and Marine Inspectors.  Casualty does not meet the reporting requirements for informal investigation.

On 10/05/12 about 2130 the Coast Guard was notified by the M/V VANPORT (512604) they had allided with the Grand Lake Bridge fendering system near MM 231. No damage to the vessel or any barge, but the bridge pilings were knocked off their structure. Vessel is pushing 06 loaded barges (02 ACETONE, 1 SILICONE, 02 CAUSTIC HOT ASH, 01 CEMENT)

No injuries or pollution resulted.

At approximately 1330, F/V BAINBRIDGE struck F/V MARAUDER while she was dead in the water and hauling in nets.  The F/V BAINBRIDGE was traveling approximately 8 kts at the time of the collision.  F/V MARAUDER reported the incident to the Coast Guard.  The F/V BAINBRIDGE failed to report the incident until contacted later by STA Grays Harbor.

Received report from the bridge operator of the Grosse Tete span bridge that the UTV LADY LAUREN allided with the eastside fendering system while transiting south bound on the Morgan City/Port Allen route enroute to Houma, LA. No Injuries, pollution or damages reported.

On October 14, 2012, the tank vessel GREAT EASTERN was outbound on the Chelsea River.  The vessel was passing through the Mcardle Street Bridge when an allision occurred.  There was no damage to the bridge or the vessel.

On October 19, 2012, at approximately 0045 local time, the UTV ISLAND VENTURE (ON: 527409) was pushing the deck barge ITB 260(ON: 292626) loaded with sand and gravel.  The tug and barge were transiting from Dupont to Kenmore WA through the Portage Bay Reach when the port bow of the barge allided with the University Bridge.  The vessel returned to Lake Union and assessed the damage to the barge.  Damage to the barge was minimal and limited to the forward rake, port side at the deck edge.  The bridge fendering system sustained damage to the pilings and catwalk.

The initial estimated damage was over $200k but less than $500k.  The estimated cost of repairs provides for complete replacement in kind.

Sector Miami received a call from the tug NAVIGATOR's port captain in Jacksonville, FL notifying the Coast Guard that the NAVIGATOR had experienced a marine casualty.  Per the port captain, the NAVIGATOR left Jacksonville, FL and was enroute San Juan, PR with the barge JAX-SAN JUAN BRIDGE BARGE in tow when the tug began to get alarms for the starboard main engine's expansion tanks.  The vessel was 60NM offshore and 60NM east of Titusville, FL at the time of the casualty.

Crewmembers conducted a round and found that they were losing expansion tank water at a rate of approximately 25 gallons per hour.  The NAVIGATORS's crew immediately notified shore side support and began troubleshooting the equipment.  The engine was taken offline at approximately 1125 (not unintended loss) in order to determine if cooling water had entered the engine.  

the Port Captain indicated that they would like the vessel to divert from their course and anchor off of Fort Pierce, FL where a technician could attend the vessel and conduct repairs.  

While Sector Miami was determining a proper course of action and whether operational controls would be necessary, the Port Captain called back and indicated that the ship's crew determined that the cause of the equipment problem was a  jumper line on one of the heads on the engine had failed.  Line was replaced and engine was put back online at 1255.  Engine tested satisfactorily.  Tug and barge resumed their transit to  (San Juan, PR.

** Level of investigative effort: Per MSM Vol V, Part A, Chapter .F.2: The casualty occurred on an uninspected tug vessel that is over 100 GT, however it was not within U.S navigable waters.  Thus, this is being investigated at a data collection level.**

The Caney Creek Chief Bridge Tender reported that at 0210R 25OCT12, the M/V SEVERN pushing 2 barges (HTCO 3004/ MMI 3057) allided with the north fender system of the Caney Creek Bridge while transiting westbound.  Bridge tender reported that the bridge's front compartment suffered a minor leak that was secured. The bridge was closed to highway traffic until 1330R, 25OCT12. Owner/operator of the tug reports that the vessel was told the bridge did not suffer any damage at the time of the incident and was cleared to continue its transit to Victoria, TX. Post casualty survey identified that brushing of barge against the severely worn corner of the bridge caused a small hole.

SECUMR CC received a report of an allision of the UTV Bruce R. Birmingham with the Lacrosse R/R D/B at UMR MM 699.8 LDB. The UTV was heading upbound to St. Paul, MN with 8 barges (1 iron, 4 cement, 3 empty) in tow drafting 8' 8". Barge ING5902 made contact with the left descending protection cell and damaged the entire timber fence in front of the protection cell. No damages were reported to the tug or tow. No injuries or pollution were reported and the waterway is not affected by this incident.

On November 9, 2012, the Tug NAVIGATOR (O.N. 641121) was engaged in towing operations with the barge S.J. 215 (O.N. 665836). The barge was an empty hopper barge and was being pushed ahead by the tug. When the tug and barge were approaching the Eltham Bridge (Hwy 30) across the Pamunky River in West Point, VA, the mate on watch positioned two persons on the barge to assist in transiting through the Rte. 30 bridge fendering system.  Despite the effort of the crew the barge allided with the fendering system, this resulted in substantial damage to components of the system and required repair.  A survey was conducted by a certified marine surveyor to identify the structural integrity of the fendering system, as well as the required repair. There was no damage to the tug and barge. 

Recommend enforcement action and case be closed.
On November 12, 2012 at approximately 1514 local time the T/V BRUSSELS BRIDGE encountered a loss of propulsion while it was transiting in the port of San Francisco to berth 55 in Oakland, CA.

Sector Upper Missisippi River received a telephone call from the UTV Crimson Glory reporting that their tow allided with the La Crosse Railroad Drawbridge located in the vicinity of mile marker 699.8 on the Upper Mississippi River. Prior to the allision occuring the UTV Crimson Glory was heading southbound pushing 15 barges (Dry Cargo) to St. Louis, MO. While transiting the span furthest from the right descedning bank "Outside Span", The UTV Crimson Glory's tow drifted towards the left descedning bank and barge numner ART 428 (Port Lead - Soybeans) made contact with the sheer fence. The Sheer fence on the left descending bank was damaged and completely torn off. No Damages, injuries, or pollution was reported for UTV Crimson Glory or ART 428.

On 16-Nov-2012, Sector NOLA received a report that the UTV MR. KEVIN pushing ahead three non-red flagged barges had one of its barges allide a Rigolets Railroad Bridge fender.  No damage to bridge and only minor damage to barge and bridge fender system reported.

On December 5, 2012, the towing vessel UNCLE GEORGE was pushing one empty saltwater barge through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge, southbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway.  The Captain reports being caught by the wind  which caused his barge to hit the bridge span.  As a result, a bridge ladder was crushed hence cutting a wire that supplied electricity to the Navigation Lights on the bridge.  All lights were subsequently extinguished on the bridge.  The Bridge Operators reported broken timbers and broken gearbox as a result of the allision. No damage reported to the barge.

On 22Oct12 at 1515L, the UTV James F. Neal was southbound on the Upper Mississippi River, favoring the left decending bank, pushing 13 grain and 2 empty caustic soda barges when the lead port barge allided with the Lacrosse Rail Road bridge. Four timbers were cracked due to the allision.

On December 9, 2012, at approximately 0615 local time, the UTV BERNICE LIND was pushing the deck barge JS200, loaded with sand, through the Mare Island Straight when it allided with the wooden fender of the Mare Island Causeway Lift Bridge.  There was no damage to the barge.  The wooden fender of the bridge sustained damage.

At approximately 12:15 a.m., the uninspected towing vessel DOROTHY J, O.N. 644763 and it's tow allided with the Atlantic Beach Bridge in the vicinity of Reynolds Channel in East Rockaway, Long Island, NY.  The DOROTHY J had the empty hopper barge KELLY, O.N. 651511, in a short stern tow; the bow of the barge was approximately 50 feet from the stern of the tug.  At 11:30 p.m., the DOROTHY J requested the bridge opening as they passed the East Rockaway Sea Buoy, and told the Bridge Tender that they would be at the bridge in approximately 45 minutes.  At approximately 12:10 a.m., the DOROTHY J/KELLY was lining up approaching the bridge and noted it had not opened.  The Bridge Tender called out to the DOROTHY J and requested they hold up because there was a delay in the opening.  The DOROTHY J shortened the tow on the KELLY bringing it right up on the stern of the DOROTHY J, and began to slow down, but the currents turned the barge, resulting in the stern port quarter of the barge making contact with the northwest fender of the bridge.  The barge sustained no damage; there was damage to the bridge fender system.  No pollution or injuries were reported.  Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was directed and conducted.

The tug SHELBY (O.N. 593220) towing alongside the hopper barge MJS107 (O.N. 651488) allided with the north fender wall of the Atlantic Beach Bridge.  There was no damage to the tug/barge and no damage to the bridge or the fender system.

Received notification that the subject towing vessel suffered a breakaway and allision while pushing 2 loaded coal barges up-bound at mile marker 787 Ohio River. The operator over-steered on the tow and broke the facing wires causing barges to breakaway and drift down river. The barges did not hit the bridge. The starboard side  of the towing vessel landed on the U.S. 41 Dual Highway bridge up-bound bridge pier on the left descending bank side. The pilot reports no damage to barges, vessel or bridge. Subject vessel has collected the break-aways and is continuing to its final destination at MM MM 1 Green River.

Freight Barge ART 1012, under the control of the UTV New Dawn, allided with the right descending Pekin Rail Road Bridge fendering system at MM 151.2 ILR .  Master stated he was making a controlled landing and rubbed up against the bridge however, he failed to contact the bridge prior to making contact.  No damage, pollution, or injuries resulted from this incident.

On December 12, 2012, at approximately 1300 local time, the passenger ferry GOLDEN GATE experienced a partial loss of steering while transiting from Larkspur to San Francisco, California.  As a result of a failed component on the vessels steering system, approximately five gallons of hydraulic was discharged into San Francisco Bay.

On December 17, 2012, at approximately 1800 local time, a hydraulic hose ruptured on the passenger ferry GOLDEN GATE's starboard jet drive.  The jetdrive wasn't steerable after that.  The ruptured hose allowed approximately five gallons of hydraulic fluid to leak into the water.  The vessel was transiting from Larkspur, CA, to San Francisco, CA at the time of the casualty.

On 5 December 2012, at approximately 0030, the F/V AMANDA TARA allided with the Wreck Lead Railroad Bridge located in Reynolds Channel, NY. The vessel was inbound returning to its dock in Hog Channel. As vessel was attempting turn from Reynolds Channel into Hog Channel, the vessel experienced a steering failure and was carried in to the south span of the Wreck Lead Railroad Bridge. Minor damage to the bridge and only minor cosmetic damage to the vessel. No injuries as a result of this incident.

On December 18, 2012, at approximately 0615 local time, the foreign cargo vessel BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE experienced a loss of propulsion due to damage to the main engine No. 4 cylinder while departing Oakland, CA.

On December 29, 2012 While transiting South bound pushing 12 empty hopper barges ahead the UTV MICHAEL D (ON 622808) allided with Ironton/Russell highway bridge at MM327. Barge ING5040 (ON 623213) made contact with right descending bridge support opening a 6' x 1/2" tear in the starboard bilge knuckle requiring 4 dewatering pumps to get the barge to Superior Mariner Ways for repair. Due to barges age the company made the decision to scrap the barge.

On 04 January 2013, M/V HERBERT C. JACKSON was transiting the Rouge River outbound when it allided with the fendering system on the north side of the Conrail R/R bridge.  There was no damage to the vessel or the bridge.  The marine employer ordered post-casualty chemical testing in accordance with company policy.

On January 7, 2013, at approximately 1118 local time, the aft starboard quarter of the 752 foot, foreign flagged tank vessel OVERSEAS REYMAR allided with the west side of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge's "Echo" pier.  The vessel was headed outbound for sea from San Francisco Bay's Anchorage 9.  The vessel's cargo holds were empty at the time of the allision.  No pollution or injuries occurred as a result of this casualty.  Both the vessel and the bridge tower's fender system sustained substantial damage.

The vessel's Pilot failed to notify the Coast Guard of a discrepant aid to navigation associated with the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge; however, no enforcement referral was initiated due to the circumstances of the casualty.

On December 26, 2012 at approx. 1850, the unmanned, crane barge DERRRICK 16 was anchored approximately 300 feet from the Townsends Inlet Bridge at Townsends Inlet, NJ. The barge broke both anchor wires in heavy weather and drifted into the bridge, damaging the bridge fendering system. The barge had minor sideshell damage.

On December 11, 2012, at approximately 1710 (local), the UTV VULCAN was Northbound on the Ohio River at MM 2.5 pushing 16 loaded coal barges with the UTV JANET MARIE assisting when current set the port stern barge (565) and the JANET MARIE onto the left descending pier of the OHIO CONN. RR Bridge.  No subsequent events occurred.

While transiting up the Tennesse river, the tow of the Uninspected Towing Vessel GLADYS FORD landed on the right descending bank pier of the George Rogers Clark Memorial Bridge. No damage, pollution or injury was reported as a result of this allision.
While transiting under the LEHIGH VALLEY Draw bridge with a flexi float spud barge the forward spud made contact with the bridge.
The M/V  radar mast hit the Bayonne Bridge while passing under the bridge in-bound for Port Newark and caused  damage to the S-band radar mast & antenna. No damage reported to the bridge.

Subject towing vessel pushing 4 loaded coal barges downbound on the Green River mile 8.3  when the tow was set by the current and struck the sheer fence of the Louisville & Nashville R/B Drawbridge AKA Spottsville R/R Bridge. The opeartor of the UTV contacted the bridge maintainer on channel 16 VHF-FM to report. The lead port barge of the tow, was damaged and the #1 and #2 wing voids were flooded.  The bridge was determined to be undamaged by owner's representative.  The damaged barge was offloaded and placed in drydock for repairs.

Subject towing vessel reports, while pushing 12 empty hopper barges down bound at MM 787 OHR, they allided with Kentucky & Indiana/ US 41 Highway bride. Vessel and tow were making the approach to the bridge pier when the wind caught his empty barges. No damage, pollution or injuries reported. ATON not a factor.

Subject towing vessel reports while pushing 4 loaded coal barges down bound at mile marker 8 on the Green River, they allided with a sheer fence on the Spotsville Railroad Bridge pier. The vessel was making the approach to the bridge pier and hit too hard during an intentional landing, breaking 2 wires and the fence punctured a hole in the port stern barge. 3 pumps are in the stern wing tank and not keeping up. The vessel  is waiting on an assist vessel with 1 hour ETA to bring more pumps. Mate (Pilot) reports no injuries or pollution.

While attempting to transit southbound through the Vicksburg Railroad Bridge at MM 434.5 on the Lower Mississippi River, the M/V NATURES WAY ENDEAVOR'S tow allided with the north face of the Vicksburg Railroad Bridge #4 Bridge Pier. The lead barge of the tow, the MOC 15, broke away after alliding with the bridge pier sustaining damage along the port side. The remaining barge of the two barge tow, the MOC 12, remained attached to the M/V NATURES WAY ENDEAVOR and allided with the #4 bridge pier head on causing significant damage to the barge and subsequently a discharge an estimated 7181 gallons of sweet crude oil that created a sheen on the Mississippi River, a navigable waterway of the US.  One minor injury was reported several hours after the incident.

On 24 January 2013 at Sector NOLA received a report that the UTV RUSTY ZELLER allied with the Belle Chase Highway Bridge on the Algiers Canal. The UTV RUSTY ZELLER reported damage to their port radar scanner and mast. The bridge did not noticed any damage and is operational.
UTV reported an allison with several barges moored at the TILCON CORP docks in Wappinger’s Falls, NY.

13 JAN 13 ; 1210: UTV CITY OF NEW ORLEANS is south bound on the Atchafalya River.  As they passed under the Melville Rail Bridge a storm producing 40 mph westerly winds pushed the lead barge of the UTV CITY OF NEW ORLEANS' tow into one of the bridge pilings. The lead tow and second barge in the tow broke away due to broken couplings. The barges were quickly recovered.  <25 K in damage. Damage verified as follows: scraped paint and scraped concrete were only visible damage.

No further damage, no pollution, no injuries reported.

The Melinda Brent was transiting inbound on the Indiana Harbor from Lake Michigan pushing the Kirby 28706 with deck personnel posted on the head of the barge as lookouts.  The Master contacted the NS5 Railroad Bridge tender and requested an opening. As the vessel made their approach the bridge was not lifting. The Master began backing down full astern. Unable to stop the forward momentum the barge allided with the Railroad Bridge.   The bridge span did not open fast enough due to icing conditions.  

Major damage was sustained by the RR bridge and it remains stuck in the closed position.  UTV Melinda Brent experienced no significant damage, only scraped paint.

No alcohol and drug testing was conducted due to it was not determined for several days after the incident that the property damage estimate exceeded 100,000.00.

On 31 January, 2013, when crewmembers were pulling the port and starboard anchors in preparation for shifting from the designated anchorage to a dock facility, they noticed the starboard anchor was missing.

13 AUG 12: USCG SECUMR rcvd a report from the UTV Dennis Delaney stating they made contact with the Ft Madison RR Bridge at UMR 383.9. There was no damage, injuries or pollution reported. The vessel was downbound with 15 empty dry cargo barges when the aft port (INO 96044, empty coal) made contact with the bridge.

On 17 Jan 2012, the UTV Mathis (ON 261152) was headed up bound, pushing 9 empty coal barges at MM 14 on the Monongahela River when it was set by high current/winds and allided with the McKeensport-Dusquene bridge (LLNR 28370).

14FEB13; 0715: UTV BIG JOE was transiting south bound Atchafalaya River with 03 rock barges in tow. Two of the barges allided with the Simmesport Railroad Bridge, all 3 barges broke away upon impact and were collected and reconfigured in the tow. 

No further damage, injuries, pollution reported.

At mile marker 88.2, on the ILR, the dry cargo barge ING-118524 was being loaded with grain when it broke free from its moorings due to the wake of the U/B UTV NEIL N DIEHL. The Illinois River was in a high water condition at that time and more horsepower was needed by the tow to make and maintain a safe headway.  The barge drifted down river where it was recovered by the UTV PIN OAK and returned to the Cargill Grain Elevator loading dock. During the recovery effort, the barge allided (slightly scraped) the Beardstown Highway Bridge. Barge was safely re-moored and no damage was reported to the barge, UTV or the bridge.

On February 16, 2013, at approximately 1608 local time, the 154 foot, passenger ferry SAN FRANCISCO and a 22 foot recreational power vessel collided in San Francisco Bay, California.  The operator of the recreational vessel was killed and the vessel's sole passenger was seriously injured as a result of the collision.  None of the ferry's crew or passengers were injured.  The recreational vessel suffered extensive damage and the ferry suffered minor cosmetic damage as a result of the collision.

UTV San Louis hit the Grand Lake Pontoon Bridge fendering system. Bridge had damage to the pivot arm and is closed to highway traffic. Pivot arm repaired and bridge open to all traffic. No pollution or injuries. No damage to vessel or barge. See correspondence for IO Statement

Uninspected Towing vessel DAN JAWORSKI (978046, American Commercial Lines) reported their mast head light allided with the underside of I 24 bridge while downbound at mile marker 940.8. They have 20 loaded coal barges, 10.5 ft draft, and they are currently at mile marker 948 Ohio River. There is no Personal injury, no Pollution and the only damage they know of is the mast is broke in half.

15 FEB 13; 0800: UTV VALDA was north bound enroute from Lake Charles, LA to Natchez, Mississippi. When the vessel passed under the Simmesport Railroad Bridge, the vessel and its tow were set by the current, and the last 20 feel of the stern barge, MM-88, made contact with the bridge.

No damage, no pollution, no injuries reported.

20FEB13, Vessel was drifting in Unimak pass to avoid heavy weather when the vessel attempted to start its main engine at approx 1150 (local time) it failed to start due to two failed cylinder control units. At approx 1300 (local time) vessel contacted company to arrange a tow. At approx 2030 (local time) third party contacted USCG office to request use of local Emergency Towing System (ETS) once MSD Dutch Harbor was notified by third party, Sector Anchorage contacted the vessel. First report from the vessels master was everything was fine and operational, after third contact the vessel stated they had an inoperable main engine. After drifting for approx 11 hours the Chief Engineer completed repairs and the vessel proceeded to Dutch Harbor as directed by Captain of the Port Order 03-13.

No further damage, injuries or pollution was reported

M/V DAVID K WILSON (534110, Ingram Barge) transiting down-bound at MM 190.4 CMB w/6 empty hoppers. A gust of wind caused the head of tow to swing to starboard towards CSX railroad pier (LLNR 3870).  Captain shifted engines to astern to swing head of tow away from pier and lost the starboard engine for approximately 10 seconds. Possibly due to swiftly changing from ahead propulsion to astern propulsion. Vsl and tow cleared the bridge and was unsure if it touched, but followed protocol and notified the CG as well as the Bridge Tender via Channel 13 VHF.  Bridge Tender also was unaware if the barge touched the railroad span, but notified CSX for protocol.  No damage to CSX railroad span or Barge reported with the exception of a 6-8" scrape on the barge and bridge span. No injuries or pollution reported.

ACTEUR received a report of an injury on board the USNS BRIDGE. A crew member was descending a ladder well and tripped. The crew member sustained injuries to the chest and back. No further information reported.

Medical examination identified no major /acute injuries other than multiple contusions through back and chest area; minor injuries.

FWC Survey aircraft 7CH reported seeing a debris field with 10 PFD's and pieces of what they believed was from a vessel. The reported debris field spaned 2NM.
One body was recovered from the debris field. It was believed that there were 04 persons on board the vessel when it departed its last known port.  The three other crewmembers were never recovered. 
Multiple pieces of debris (fender, life ring and small pieces of structure) were recovered with areas of red/brown colored paint on various parts.  A search was conducted utilizing AIS and other data to determine which large vessels were in the area that could have possibly come into contact with the ON THE WEIGH.  Paint samples were taken from those vessels.  The paint samples and debris were sent to the FBI Laboratory for analysis. Analysis did not show any correlation between the samples taken and paint on the debris. 
1 deceased crewmember was recovered, and 3 remain missing, the vessel was never recovered.
Initial reports from the FWC aircraft noted a possible sheen on the water

On 25 Feb 2013 the M/V CHRIS ARDEN (596450, MCGINNIS) ,transiting up bound at MM 1 Big Sandy River  allided with the center pier of the Chessie RR Bridge, causing a 2ft x 3ft whole above and below waterline on the port side of the stern box of barge (ACBL 01525, Empty Hopper). Barge towed to Superior for repairs.

The Uninspected towing vessel MARTHA DENTON while pushing 16 empty open hoppers down bound at mile marker 63.1 on the Cumberland River, allided with the right descending pier of the Henry R. Lawrence Memorial Bridge. The vessel was set by high winds and scraped the pier with the second barge in the starboard string. No damage to bridge or vessel reported.

On February 27, 2013 at approximately 1030 local time, Kiewit-General-Manson (KGM) a Joint Venture was conducting a test pull on an anchor system for the Washing State Route 520 floating bridge project using an uninspected barge GC 156 (O.N. 508468).  The barge hydraulic winch slipped and relieved tension on the cable allowing the barge to sling back and strike the 520 bridge.  During the incident, one crewmember was stuck by one of the mooring lines causing a laceration on the back of his leg that required four sutures.  The crewmember was release to light duty and returned to work within 48 hours. 

On February 28, 2013, WSDOT engineers inspected the bridge for damage and found small superficial concrete spall on the concrete bridge pontoon. Divers were also splashed by KGM and WSDOT as a precautionary measure and found no damages detected below the water.

On March 1, 2013, the marine surveyor reported no damages to barge GC 156.

On February 18, 2013, the M/V BAI CHAY BRIDGE was departing Long Beach Harbor when it experienced a damaged injection control unit (ICU).  The vessel was departing for Oakland, CA and while under pilot control, the vessel automatically slowed down and could not achieve the desired RPM. The vessel anchored and it was found that the #7 cylinder ICU was stuck wide open and fuel deposits built up.  The ICU was cleaned and the engine tested satisfactorily. The vessel again began to depart with another automatic shutdown. The #7 ICU was replaced with a spare onboard. Class attended the vessel witnessed a satisfactory test of the new ICU. The remaining piston ICU's will be examined in Oakland, CA. The manufacturer will attempt to determine the cause of the failure of the #7 ICU.  Vessel was cleared to depart.

STA LWI received report from PGA bridge tender that a vessel with a crane had allided with the bridge, preventing it from opening.  MSD Lake Worth Investigators and STA LWI boarding assessed vessel and found the vessel had broke free from it's moorings at Ellison Wilson Road in West Palm Beach FL.  The vessel was moored at a house at 1700 to begin dock building operations at a residence the next day.  Investigators noticed the vessel used spuds to moor the vessel and one of the spuds were inoperable, attributing to the poor mooring and subsequent break away.

MSD Lake Worth Investigators and STA LWI Boarding were able to free the vessel from the bridge.  No damage was noted on the vessel or the bridge due to the allision.  The vessel was towed to Waterway Cafe and tied up there for the remainder of the evening.  The vessel owner was contacted and made arrangements to move the vessel in the morning.

Ft Pierce Lady allided with the southeast fender on the A1A Bridge in Ft Pierce, FL. The port bow of the Ft Pierce Lady glanced off of the bridge structure, causing the vessel to ride up onto the bridge fender.  This resulted in substantial damage to the Ft Pierce Lady, causing planking in the affected area to separate below the rub rail. The impact caused no damage to the bridge.  No injuries or pollution reported.

The tug SHELBY (O.N. 593220) was towing astern on a short tow the light barge KELLY (O.N. 651511) when the starboard stern quarter of the KELLY allided with the south fender of the Atlantic Beach Bridge fender system.  The tug/barge were inbound from East Rockaway Inlet to Oceanside, NY.  There was no damage to the barge and no damage to the bridge fender system as reported by the Bridge Tender.  Post-casualty drug and alcohol tests were conducted for the Master and deckhand on watch.

14 MAR 13; 0945: BRIDGE ALLISION, UTV DELANE WAXLER (ON.8992493), DULARGE BRIDGE, MM 59.9, GIWW, WHL: While transiting westbound on the GIWW, the UTV Delane Waxler towing 2 empty red flag barges (last cargo of barges is #6 Oil), rubbed against the fendering system of the Dularge Bridge (MM 59.9 GIWW, WHL) with the STBD Bow of the Stern Barge. Capt. of the UTV, was unable to set up for the turn properly due to a large Ocean going Tug and Barge fueling at Oil States Facility on the GIWW and taking up more than half the channel.

At 180030L Mar 13, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (Sec UMR CC) received a call from the Florence Highway Drawbridge at mile marker 56.0 on the Illinois River stating that the UTV CITY OF LOUISVILLE allided with the bridges protection cells on the left descending pier. The CITY OF LOUISVILLE was pushing four empty barges. No pollution, damage, or injuries reported. Vessel stated that they are heading down bound to New Orleans, LA. They were pushed by the wind into the bridges protection cells on the left descending bank. The two port barges (Kirby 24014/Kirby24022) rubbed up against the cells without causing any apparent damage, pollution or injuries. The bridge tender stated that the bridge is currently under construction and is locked in the up position. Construction workers inspected the bridge for damage in the morning with negative results.  It was reported by the bridge tender that the allision did not look or sound like it caused any damage.

At 180353Z Mar 13, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (Sec UMR CC) received a call from the UTV City of Cassville stating that while heading up bound on the Upper Mississippi River at mile marker 282.1, they allided with the Louisiana Railroad Drawbridge pushing 16 barges (7 empty and 9 dry cargo) with a configuration of 5 long by 3 wide with one on his port hip. The pilot claimed that two of his port barges (the 2nd and 3rd barges in the port string) made contact with the bridge but caused no damage, pollution, or injuries to the barges or the bridge. The two barges that made contact are LTD12026 and LTD12026. The pilot stated the reason was that he was too far over to the side. Sec UMR CC made contact with the bridge immediately after receiving notification. The bridge tender stated that he is unable to assess any damage but the bridge is operational. The bridge tender stated that the UTV made contact with the center swing span pier and the eastern span.  No damage was found the next day to the bridge.

The UTV RICHARD GONSOULIN II's lead barge, Gonsoulin 201, rubbed up against the fender to the Highway 35 bridge over the Victoria Barge Canal. Master stated that there is no visible damage to the fender and his barge is only scratched. Preliminary investigation confirmed no reportable  damage.  No pollution or injuries reported.

The UTV MARY K. CAVARRA tow had allided with the Florence Highway Drawbridge protection cell. They were heading southbound pushing 10 barges (All Dry Cargo) to St. Louis, MO. While on approach to transit through the bridge span the current pushed the tow closer toward the right descending bank than what was anticipated by the operator and barge T13720 (Soybeans) allided with the protection cell. Damage and minor flooding occurred to barge T13270. Temporary repairs were completed and not damage to bridge occurred.

On 20MAR13 at approx. 1520 local time, the towing vessel MISS LIZZY, along with towing vessel HELENE MARIA, dredge RICHARD LAQUAY, and deck barges M 870 and BA 20 were underway and preparing to transit underneath the Brooks Bridge in Fort Walton Beach, FL.  The MISS LIZZY had just about passed/cleared the bridge when the boom on the crane barge, BA 20, allided with the Brooks Bridge.  The boom of crane barge BA 20 allided with the steel girders of the bridge at the center of the highest point on the bridge.  The boom on crane barge BA 20 was in turn pushed up into the concrete apron of the bridge and ruptured a water line that ran parallel with the bridge.  There was some concrete damage to the apron of the bridge and broken water line that was the extent of the damage to the Brooks Bridge.

On 21MAR13 Investigating Officers from MSD Panama City verified and confirmed the height of the Spud Gallows Tower to be at 46.5 feet, which was supposed to be the highest point of the tow throughout the voyage.  The HELENE MARIA traveled from West to East under the bridge and was verified to have 3-4 feet of clearance from their mast to the underside of the bridge.  The gauge on the East side of the bridge that shows clearance of the bridge was at 49.5 feet of vertical clearance (air gap) with the tide at approx. 1630 this date.  The MISS LIZZY and the rest of the tow configuration proceeded to get underway and passed under the Brooks Bridge without further incident.  A determination was made that somewhere between transiting under the Navarre Bridge but before reaching the Brooks Bridge the height of the boom on crane barge BA 20 was adjusted and raised, which led to the allision with the Brooks Bridge.

Received a call concerning the UTV Alicia McCord (DOC 289740) drifting away from mooring and alliding with the 22nd St. Causeway.

26MAR2013-CG Investigator spoke with a Health and Safety Manager with International Ship Repair, who stated that the vessel ALICIA MCCORD was moored to berth 200 and apparently broke away from its mooring when a mooring line broke.  The vessel drifted east toward the 22nd street bridge in McKay Bay and came to rest beneath the bridge.  There was no damage to the vessel.  Florida D.O.T. inspected the bridge and there was damage to the bridge.

On March 31, 2013, at approximately 0538 local time, the M/V BAI CHAY BRIDGE experienced a reduction of speed while transiting outbound from Long Beach Berth 232 en route to Oakland, CA.  The vessel was approximately 2 miles south of the Long Beach Sea Buoy when the Injection Control Unit (ICU) on cylinder #1 failed.  The failure resulted in a reduction of speed to only 4 knots (Slow Ahead).  The vessel returned to Long Beach Anchorage for repair.  A new ICU was installed and the Main Engine was tested satisfactorily in ahead and astern propulsion in the presence of the vessel's class surveyor.

Received notification from M/V Pere Marquette that the vessel, pushing 15 loaded dry cargo barges, allided with the Florence Highway Bridge protection cell (LDB) on the Illinois River, mile marker 56. Tow remained intact with six wires broken. Minor damage to barge DKS-301 was reported with no repairs intended.

05April13; 1430: UTV JOHN C TERRAL was south bound with 06 barges in tow, approaching Melville Railroad Bridge. Vessel experienced loss of steering causing barge to allide with bridge.

No further injuries, damage, or pollution reported.

On Friday, April 05, 2013, Coast Guard Sector New Orleans, Louisiana, received a report that Uninspected Towing Vessel MS. GABRIELLE ALAINNA was transiting northbound pushing one barge when the wind and current pushed the towing vessel into timber on the guide wall of the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge in Amelia, Louisiana.  

No damage to the towing vessel or barge and no injuries or pollution were reported. The Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge sustained minor damage that did not affect vessel traffic.

Barge ART 35103 allided with the Lower Pekin Rail Road Bridge protection cell at MM 151.2 ILR while transiting south bound under the control of the UTV COOPERATIVE AMBASSADOR with the assistance of UTV EDMUND L. Barge was located at starboard stern of a 12 barge tow. No damage or injuries occurred during this incident. The tow safely continued its transit.

Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities received notification from Coast Guard Sector Upper Mississippi River that the UTV Penny Eckstein Allided with Crescent Rail Road Bridge bridge at Mile Marker 481 on Upper Mississippi River while pushing  15 barges (All Dry Cargo Loads) was southbound to St. Louis, MO.  Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities conducted a preliminary investigation and determined that there was no damage to the Tow boat or barges. Bridge remained fuctional and damage estimate for the sheer fence was not provided to Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities.  CG-2692 collected from vessel.

On Apr 17, 2013, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (Sec UMR CC) received a call from the UTV Cooperative Vanguard stating that while heading down bound at mile marker 403.1 on the Upper Mississippi River they allided with the Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge. They were pushing 6 loaded dry cargo barges (3 wide x 2 long) and the starboard rear barge (ART35720B Loaded Soy Bean) rubbed up against the right descending bank protection pier. This cause the barge to break away. With the help of the assist tug Betsy Lynn they were able to recover the barge and are in the process of putting the tow back together. There is no damage to the barge or the bridge. Master stated that the high water and swift currents pushed him into the bridge cell.

18 Apr 13:  Sector Ohio Valley was notified that the M/V A.J. Morris (O.N. 550220) was pushing a crane barge and an empty hopper barge when the crane barge alllided with the Louisville and Nashville drawbridge at mm 126.5 Cumberland river. The M/V called the bridge contact and when they did not get a call they proceeded to transit under the bridge. While transiting under the bridge the crane barge's spud allided with the R/R bridge and bent it back 4 inches.  The bridge suffered no damage other than cosmetic.  No injuries or pollution reported.

EVEY T (Ingram, 558474) heading downbound pushing 24 barges (23 empty and 01 loaded pipe) allided with the Eggners Ferry Bridge (Mile 41.7 Tennessee River) on the right descending pier span. No damage was reported to the Eggners Ferry Bridge.

At 100350Z Apr 13, Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (Sec UMR CC) received a call from the UTV Cleva Lee stating that they bumped into the C P Railroad Drawbridge (Soo Line Bridge) at mile marker 1 on the Black River in vicinity of LaCross, WI. The vessel was heading up bound at the time of the allision. They were pushing 4 small deck barges and 1 empty hopper barge strung out. The lead barge (empty hopper barge NNF-103) allided with the bridge pier on the right descending bank. The vessel is already at their destination just up bound of the bridge. They inspected the barge and there was no damage. They also checked the bridge for damage and there was no apparent damage. Sec UMR CC contacted the bridge and confirmed with the operator that there was no damage. The UTV operator stated that low visibility, hail, and high winds were the cause of the allision.
The UTV, while pushing a barge, had a tire caught on a handrail of the fendering system located under the center span of the bridge.
Vessel was transiting under the Bayonne Bridge when an obsolete IMARSAT antenna struck the bottom of the bridge.

UTV JOHN PAUL ECKSTEIN allided with the I-155 Bridge while pushing 28 barges N/B at MM 839 LMR in Caruthersville, MO.  All barges broke loose, assist vessels captured all barges and tow was re-wired. Freight Barge LTD-612 sustained damage during the allision and a transit plan was approved, the vessel and tow continued its N/B journey with COTP approval.

On 16 April 2013 at approximately 1630 the UTV TKL BARRIOS (NO. 508347) was pushing 4 empty deck barges and allided with the CSX R/R Bridge fendering system in Bay Saint Louis, MS. The wind was reported to be approximately 20-25 knots E/SE setting the barge M 2022 into the bridge fendering system resulting in approximately $20,000 damage to fendering and no damage to the barge. Master stated that he notified employer about the allision and filled out a CG-2692.

On 17 April 2013 Licensed mariner provided post casualty urine sample.

On 24 April 2013 Licensed mariner completed a post casualty drug screen.

On 29 April 2013  A company representative was contacted and stated the the allision was not reported to the CG. A CSX bridge representative was contacted and he stated that he was aware of the allision and that he had pictures and a survey summary.

1 May 2013 - SECUMR CC received a report from the UTV Joseph Patrick Eckstein stating they allided with the Sabula Railroad Bridge at mile marker 535.0. They were down bound with 12 loaded grain barges when the third barge in port string bumped the upper bull nose, and pilot stated no damage to barge, bridge or boat and no injuries or pollution. Sector UMR contacted MSD Quad Cities duty personnel who performed a phone interview and determined an on scene investigation was unwarranted. MSD Quad Cities investigation team told the company they needed to submit a CG-2692.

SEC UMR CC received a report of an allision and breakaway from the UTV City of Cassville. The UTV City of Cassville was heading downbound to St. Louis, MO with 9 loaded corn barges in a 3x3 tow configuration drafting 9'5" at its deepest draft. The forward barge in the port string made contact with the RDB (IA side) protection cell and caused all 9 barges to breakaway and become adrift. Currently no damages, injuries or pollution have been reported by the tug or tow.

28APR13:  MSD QC Duty IO received phone call from SUMR CC at 0345 with report of M/V CITY OF CASSVILLE downbound on UMR, alliding with Burlington RR Bridge, near MM 403.  CITY OF CASSVILLE was pushing 9 grain barges, no red flags.  Recent heavy rains and thawing snow pack had contributed to this portion of the UMR as more than 3' above flood stage at the time of the incident, causing high water and fast currents.  Master stated that he had aligned with the starboard side of the bridge, as he usually does, but the high water forced his tow opposite the normal manner.  This caused the forward starboard barge to strike the bridge protection cell with enough force to break apart the tow. Upon speaking with master, he stated that all 9 barges had broken out of the tow, and he was in the process of collecting them.  He reported no damage to vessel, pollution, or injuries.  After this confirmation, IO directed master to complete recovery of all barges and report back any further damage or issues.  Master did not provide any further updates.  Master did complete alcohol and chemical testing with in required time frames. 

30APR13: IO Contacted master, requested updates, and reminded him of 2692 requirements.  Master indicated that there had been flooding and leaks in multiple voids on board 3 barges.  Master did not give indication of extent of flooding.

02 MAY13:  IO received CG-2692 from Claims Manager at Marquette Transportation.  Extent of damage as indicated on 2692 is greater than previously reported.  IO and Marine Inspector attended barge CC-95151 at Hall Towing, where it had been surveyed by US Inland Marine Surveying.  CG received preliminary report from surveyor.

02MAY13 - Received a call from the bridge tender from the Columbia Road Bridge Tender that a pair of work barges sunk in the Cuyahoga River to the east of the Columbus Road bridge. No equipment or cargo were on the work barges at the time of the sinking. Location of the work barges post sinking was just inside the northern edge of the regulated channel causing an obstruction to deep draft vessel traffic. Cuyahoga River was temporarily closed for salvage operations to extract the sunken barge.

SLM CC received a phone call from the operator of the M/V Beau Blessey stating the vessel hit the Brandon Road Bridge at MM 285.8 on the Illinios River by the Brandon Lock and Dam. The tug was pushing empty barges that previously contained asphalt.  Operator stated no injuries, pollution, or damage is associated with the allision.

SECUMR CC received a telephone call from the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge reporting that the UTV Lauren's tow had allided with the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge at mile marker 481.4 on the Upper Mississippi River. The drawbridge tender reports that UTV Lauren was pushing two barges prior to the incident occurring. No damage, Injuries, or pollution was reported by the drawbridge tender. The operator explained that low visibility, bad weather, and high water conditions were contributing factors in causing barge number WGB#1 (empty) to allide with the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge. The navigation channel is clear. UTV Lauren has a maximum horsepower of 1000 and allided with the bridge at approximately 2 miles per hour. No damage, injuries, or pollution were reported for the vessel or their tow. Investigation reveled High water and wind gust- While making approach in high water conditions (8 MPH current) southbound through Clinton rail road bridge, wind gusts  (15 to 20 mph sustained gust to 26) between midnight and 0300 altered his course, the tow boat tried to back down to adjust to the altered course but was unable to get back on course before the casualty occurred.

UTV David L. Griggs reported that their tow had allided with the Clinton R/R Drawbridge at mile marker 518.1 on the Upper Mississippi River. UTV David L. Griggs was pushing 16 Barges (4 MAP, 1 Urea, 11 Dry Cargo Empties) northbound to St. Paul, MN. The high water level, fast water current (5 MPH) and  wind  (15 MPH) caused tow to drift towards the bridge piers and cause barge number ESRT 202B (Empty) to allide with the Clinton R/R Drawbridge.There was no damage, Injuries, or Pollution.  The Clinton R/R Drawbridge has minor scrapings. Bridge is fully operational.

Towing Vessel JERRY MCNEIL (272258, Tennessee Valley Towing), pushing 13 barges (3 empty red flag) down bound at Mile 977.7 Ohio River, was set by the current and allided w/the 2nd pier from the KY side of the Illinois Central Railroad Bridge while slowing to drop barges at a fleet 500 yards below the bridge.

On 12 May 2013, at approx 0150, SS HERBERT C. JACKSON was upbound in the Rouge River and was cleared for transit through the Jefferson Ave. Drawbridge.  As the vessel aproached the bridge, the bridge tender unexpectedly lowered the bridge, the vessel was unable to halt its forward momentum, and allided with the bridge.  

The Wayne County Road Commission estimates the bridge damage approx $3M-$5M if the damage is only structural steel to upwards of $50M if the concrete foundation is damaged.  The vessel sustained a 3-4 inch puncture in the bow approximately 2 feet above the anchor pocket. Total cost of damage to the vessel was approximately $5K.  Rouge River PD responded.

Complete IO written summary of investigation has been scanned into Correspondence tab.

On 12 May 2013, at approximately 0315, the tow of the UTV SIERRA DAWN allided with a protection cell at the Florence Hwy Drawbridge at mile marker 56 on the Illinois River. The UTV SIERRA DAWN was pushing 13 grain barges, 2 Red Flag Alcohol barges, drafting 9'6" and southbound to St. Louis, MO. Two dry cargo barges located in the port string, made contact with left descending protection cell. These barges were the ATM 2017 and the GOPV 39B. The allision resulted in damage to the ATM 2017's port side #2 and #3 void causing both voids to flood to river level. The GOPV 39B suffered damage to the corner of the port side bow causing the bow void to flood to river level. The red flagged ART 941B tank barge, located in the center string suffered a broken timberhead on the bow, starboard side. The Florence Hwy bridge tender reported no damage to the bridge. No other damage or injuries were reported.

At approx 0715 , the UTV JL FLEMING allided with the Twin City & Western Railroad bridge located in Savage, MN travelling upbound on the Minnesota River at MM 14.  The UTV JL FLEMING was pushing two empty grain barges enroute to St. Paul, MN when it allided with the sheer fence of the railroad bridge.  The allision caused one of the vessels facing wires to part, but did not damage the bridge.  The operator indicated that his approach to the bridge was too fast and the stbd quarter of the barge struck the bridge.  There was no further damages,flooding or injuries.  The vessel continued to St. Paul without further incident.

the Motor Vessel JUDI was pushing 25 empty open hoppers down bound mile marker 980.4 Ohio River when strong winds caused the tow to allide with the right descending pier of the center span of the Cairo Highway Bridge.  No pollution or injuries noted.

On March 14, 2013, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City, Louisiana received a report that an Uninspected Towing Vessel HERBERT J PAISANCE's mast allided with the Perry Bridge on Vermillion River at Mile Marker 19, three miles south of Abbeville, Louisiana. No pollution or injuries reported.

Barge WEB 231 under the control of UTV CHARLES E MARTIN allided with the Pekin Railroad Bridge due to high water conditions (strong current) on the Illinois River. Barge WEB 231 sustained a fracture at the #2 void near the waterline as a result of the allision.  Temporary repairs were made and the barge safely resumed its transit.

SOHV received a report from the M/V BUCKEYE STATE (1214534, AEP) pushing 15 loaded coal barges at MM 000.6 KAN. The vessel was fleeting barges and the towboat allided w/the right descending pier of the Chessie R/R Bridge (LLNR 8870). Master reports it was a "controlled landing" and there is no damage to the tow boat or the bridge. ATON was not a factor.

I/O boarded vessel at incident site.  Found minimal damage to vessel.  Took owner/operators info and returned to base.  No further damaged reported.

On May 13, 2013, the tug QUANTICO CREEK was pushing ahead the empty tank barge DS-38 when the barge struck the south side draw of the Pleasure Beach Bridge in Bridgeport, CT.  The tug/barge was departing through Johnsons Creek from the Global Oil Terminal.  A construction crew on Pleasure Beach heard the allision and reported the incident to the Bridgeport Harbor Master.  They also secured floating timbers in the channel.  The allision caused minor damage to the bridge span and no damage to either the tug or barge.  The Pleasure Beach Bridge has been inoperable since 1996 when the bridge burned down.  It was never replaced and the swing bridge remains in the open position.

TUG Sarah Katlin Northbound in the ICW pushing a string of four barges. The draw bridge opened and the port side of barge N175 struck the left fendering system of the bridge. the contact forced the barge to starboard as it proceeded forward, and then struck the right hand fendering system.  No damage to barge or fendering system, no pollution, no injuries.

The Tug GULF COAST and a barge SJ 214 pushed ahead by the tug ISLAND FOX collided 2 miles Northeast of Smith Point.  The Barge SJ 214 made contact with the port bow of the tug GULF COAST creating a 4 to 6 foot crack on the hull 4 feet above the waterline and damaging the fenders in the area impacted.  No damage was sustained by the SJ 214 and the ISLAND FOX.

The Motor Vessel JANET JOHNSON with 6 empty coal barges in tow allided with the P&I "Metropolis" R/R bridge at mile marker 943.1 Ohio River.  Barge ING 906 sustained a crack in the port bilge knuckle in way of the number 4 and 5 voids.

While traveling south on the Intracoastal Waterway in West Palm Beach, FL, M/V ANGER MANAGEMENT pushing a drydock barge allided with the fender system at the Parker Bridge. The vessel continued south hitting the fender system at Flagler Memorial Bridge. M/V ANGER MANAGEMENT caused minor damage to both fender systems totaling an estimated $3000. M/V ANGER MANAGEMENT continued south without stopping and failed to contact USCG concerning the reportable marine casualty.

On May 25, 2013, received notification from the Centerville Turnpike Bridge tender that the barge NO 16 (O.N. 1198729) with the work boat DIDAPPER NO 8 (O.N 1179864) attached was adrift just north of the bridge. The barge was an unmanned, empty, inspected tank barge which was moored at the Norfolk Dredging Company Facility located on the Intracoastal Waterway.  The barge  grounded in the Intracoastal Waterway near the Centerville Marina approximately 200 yards west of the Centerville Turnpike Bridge.  There was no damage reported to the barge, work boat and the Centerville Turnpike Bridge.  

Case closed.  Recommend no enforcement action be taken.

On May 28, 2013 at 1130, the Uninspected Towing Vessel COLUMBIA was transiting southbound pushing the barge USL 458 when it allided with the Bayou Boeuf Bridge on the port bow of the barge while passing through the west span of the bridge. The captain briefly lost control on a turn slide and struck a work ladder on the bridge. There was no reported damage to the barge nor the bridge. Barge dimensions are: Length 236 ft. and Breadth 54 ft.

31 May 13; 0015: The UTV MISS ROSLYN was transiting south bound with 06 barges in tow when the port lead barge allided with the Bayou Sorrel Bridge.  1-2 timbers slightly damaged.

No futher damage, injuries, or pollution reported.

02 JUN 2013 UTV Cardinal Pride reporting that their flagpole allided with the EADs Bridge located in the vicinity of mile marker 180 on the Upper Mississippi River. The operator explained that prior to the incident the UTV Cardinal Pride was light boat transiting the St. Louis harbor upbound from mile marker 180 on the Upper Mississippi River to transit through the main channel span of the EADS Bridge. As the vessel was transiting underneath the span, the UTV Cardinal Pride's flagpole made contact with the EADS Bridge. The operator attributes high water (High river stage) as the contributing factor because the higher water has reduced the vertical clearance of the EADS Bridge. No damage, Injuries, or Pollution were reported for the tow boat or bridge. The navigation channel is clear.

04 June 13; 0330: UTV ORLEANIAN was transiting northbound with 03 styrene barges, when the lead barge allided with the Bayou Sorrel bridge pilings.

No further injuries, damage, or pollution reported.

American Commercial Lines is not accepting responsibility of damage to bridge piling. They do not believe that the vessel made contact with the bridge, therefore, are refusing to submit CG-2692.

On June 4, 2013, at approximately 1500 local time, the passenger ferry MARIN experienced a loss of propulsion of its starboard main engine.  The starboard throttle would not shift and the vessel was taken out of service.

On June 8, 2013 at 1240 EST, the barge SUGAR EXPRESS (O.N. 968402), allided with the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge #5. No damage or pollution was reported. The  Sector Hampton Roads Command Center was notified at approximately 1500 EST. Norfolk Southern was notified at approximately 1510 EST by the duty Investigating Officer and informed of the alllision. Norfolk Southern advised that they had allowed two trains to use this crossing without notification of the allision and were alarmed that they were unable to determine the status of the damage prior to the trains crossing the bridge.  A team was dispatched by Norfolk Southern and determined no damage occurred; however, Norfolk Southern expressed concerns on how this could have been unreported for several hours. The master indicated to the Command Center that his company had contacted Norfolk Southern; however, they had no record of the call.
