The Master also stated that it was Harbor Fest weekend and there was excessive traffic that prevented him from reporting earlier.

Recommend case is closed with no referral for enforcement.

While down bound and pushing 3 loaded cement barges at Mile Marker 43.7 on the Upper Mississippi River, the Motor Vessel Winchester lost control of the vessel due to a burnt clutch.  The vessel and it's tow were set adrift and allided with the Thebes RR Bridge.  Barge RCC 204 experienced an inset in its starboard side shell.

While south bound at Mile Marker 46.4 the Motor Vessel COOPERATIVE ENTERPRISE experienced a failure in their flanking rudder while attempting to flank Gray's Point.  Vessel grounded by its stern knocking it free from its tow.  Vessel's tow broke away and allided with the Thebes Railroad bridge.  Five barges damaged, no pollution or injuries reported.

On June 08, 2013, the Uninspected Towing Vessel STEVE GOLDING was pushing three tank barges loaded with naphtha through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge in Morgan City, Louisiana. The vessel struck the fendering system of the bridge. 

No injuries, pollution, or significant damage reported.

While south bound at Mile Marker 43.7 on the Upper Mississippi river, the Motor Vessel  ANDREW CARGILL MACMILLAN allided with the Thebes Railroad bridge when the master over flanked.  The vessel's tow broke away and were corralled by assist tugs. Four barges were damaged, no pollution or injuries reported.

11Jun2013; 0000: ALLSION, HOUMA NAV SWING BRIDGE AND UTV STEPHEN L (ON1217124); While headed southbound on the Houma Navigational Canal, the UTV Stephen L came up a little high on the swing bridge and rubbed against the fendering system approx midway down the barge. Stephen  L has 2 barges in tow, a deck barge and a crane barge in a side by side config. Both barges are carrying Cement Pads. Bridge Operator states he cannot see any damage to the bridge but will have to check again in the morning, bridge remains fully operational. UTV Stephen L reports no damage to barge. 2692 requested, DIO will follow up with UTV in the AM. NTFD: DIO, CO, SCC.

On 12 Jun 2013, the UTV C. MICHAEL REEVES was down bound on the Upper Mississippi River pushing 15 loaded, dry cargo barges drafting 9' 5". At approximately 1810, the tow of the UTV C. MICHAEL REEVES allided with the Louisiana Railroad Bridge at mile marker 282.1. The allision caused damage to two barges in the tow, the CC-9287 and the MTC-364. The damage to the CC-9287 caused the bow void to flood to river level. The damage to the MTC-364 caused the #4 and #5 port wing voids to also flood to river level. No damage to the bridge was reported. On 13 Jun, an empty dry cargo barge and crane were dispatched to the UTV C. MICHAEL REEVES to lighter the MTC-364. At approximately 1741, the MTC-364 was lightered, removed from the tow, and relocated to Louisiana, MO. The UTV C. MICHAEL REEVES continued its down bound voyage. No other damage or injuries were reported.

On June 15, 2013, the towing vessel MISS AIMEE was pushing the uninspected and empty saltwater barge USL 458 through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge in Amelia, LA.  The captain was unable to safely navigate the 53 foot wide barge through the 56 foot wide bridge.  The barge allided with the fendering system on the right descending bank causing minor damage to the fendering system timbers.

While transiting upbound, the UTV MIKE BIRD, pushing four empty red flag barges (previously loaded with decant oil) allided with the Jackson St bridge. There was no reported pollution, injuries, or damage to the bridge. Bridge tender reported a power outage which made radio communications with the vessel impossible as well as making the bridge unable to be raised. MSU attended vessel and issued 835 to have repairs to affected barge made.

On 17 June 2013 Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (SECUMR CC) received notification from Crescent Rail Road (R/R) Drawbridge reporting UTV Bobby Jones alliding with the north end of their bull nose causing 2 barges to breakaway and striking the bridge swing span on the Illinois side.  Bridge Tender reports UTV City of Buffalo assisting and corralled one barge while UTV Bobby Jones is in pursuit of second barge. Investigator from MSD Quad cities arrived on scene at 0700. Damage to barge was exceeding $100K ordered Drug and Alcohol testing be conducted to all involved parties. One crewmember was injured reporting of back and head problems. Local Fire removed him and admitted to local hospital. He was held for 1 day and given a CAT scan and MRI for any internal injuries. Injured crewmember was on the head of tow during the allision with the bridge. Investigation shows master was proceeding at a high rate of speed and may have missed the approach to the bridge. Then trying to correct the position on approach got pushed by current into the bridge and then bouncing off one bridge cell into the next

Sector Honolulu Command Center received a call from the manager of SEABRIDGE INC in Guam reporting the TUG CHAMORRO with the Barge 2011 in tow had grounded in the channel while inbound Wake Island.  The manager reports there is no apparent pollution and the crew is making a damage assessment of the barge.

M/V PILE BUCK is a 25.8 foot steel hull uninspected towing vessel used to push construction barges to work sites.  On the day of this incident, the M/V PILE BUCK was pushing two 40' barges with a crane on board. 

On 18 June 2013, while transiting Bear Creek, the M/V PILE BUCK allided with the Peninsula Expressway Bridge pier fendering system.  Damage resulting from the allision consisted of two broken timbers.   Master of the vessel stated that he misjudged his position and wind conditions when he started going under the bridge.

On June 24, 2013, Sector Hampton Roads received a call from Chesapeake Police Department that they observed two barges alongside the Jordan Bridge.  The barges were not under the control of a vessel and were adrift.  Barges were Identified as DMT4003 (O.N. 665826) and DMT 4005 (O.N. 647807). Two tugs responded to the location of the barges and were able to return the barges to the Perdue Facility where they had been previously moored. One aft line on the inboard barge had parted and no evidence of any other lines were identified as damaged or parted.

Video cameras at the Purdue facility captured the barges breaking away as a deep draft vessel passed and the wake and propeller discharge showed significant affect on moored barges. The vessel passing was identified as the LIBERTY ISLAND (O.N. 95209860).

Recommend case is closed with no referral for enforcement.

SECUMR CC received a telephone call from the UTV KATHERINE O'HARA reporting that a spudded construction barge broke loose from its moorings and allided with a railroad bridge just upstream of the route 370 highway bridge (mile marker 27 on the Missouri River). The operator explained that drift of debris caused the breakaway. The construction barge had a crane on it which tore down some power lines prior to alliding with the railroad bridge. The UTV KKATHERINE O"HARA and another tugboat were able to put a line on the construction barge after it allided with the railroad bridge. The construction barge was held in place by the tugboats at the railroad bridge. The route 370 highway bridge downstream of the railroad bridge had been shut down to vehicular traffic as a precaution. Walsh Construction Company notified the railroad drawbridge owner. Railway traffic has been shutdown on the railroad bridge.

Received notification from UTV Show Me State reporting an allision with the Illinois Central Railroad Drawbridge at MM 579.9 UMR while transiting south bound (S/B), destined for St. Louis, MO,  pushing 12 barges (11 Loads and 1 Empty Dry Cargo) (3 Wide X 4 Long configuration) drafting 9' at its deepest draft. The reporting source states that the port lead barge (CBT 301) rubbed up against the north end protection cell on the left descending bank. No damage, pollution, or injuries reported.
Integrated tug and barge DOROTHY ANN and PATHFINDER, while transiting Cuyahoga River IVO Marathon Bend, lost power to bow thruster and collided with work dock and response vessel.

On June 30, 2013 Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received notification that the Uninspected Towing Vessel MISS GABRIELLE ALAINA allided with the Bayou Boeuf Bridge.  The MISS GABRIELLE was pushing the CIB 551 southbound when the starboard bow of the barge allided with the western span of the bridge. There was no significant damage to the bridge nor the barge as determined by the crew of the vessel and the bridge operator.

On 29 Jun 2013, the UTV Jennifer W. allided with the Bayou DuLarge Bridge while transiting on the GIWW. the Utv was pushing 02 flat deck equipment barges when it hit a cable attached to a spud on the bridge. No injuries or pollution to report.

On June 27, 2013, at approximately 1435, the tug ALEXANDER DUFF, O.N. 633594, was pushing the double skinned barge NJB-22, O.N. 1222676, loaded with 17k gallons of JP5 while headed southbound to North Landing when the starboard bow of the barge allided with the Great Bridge fendering system as a result of bank suction.  There was no reported damage to the locks, but approximately $35,500 in damage was observed to the boards on the fendering system.  There were no injuries or pollution.  Alcohol and chemical drug use were ruled out as contributing factors to this casualty.         

Recommend this case be closed without a referral to enforcement.

01JUL13: At approx 0630, MSD QC Investigators received report from SUMR CC of the M/V DAVID L FIELDS alliding with the Burlington Santa Fe R/R Bridge at MM 403.1.  The vessel was upbound, destination St. Paul, with a 15 barge tow, one of which was red flag containing caustic soda.  Tow collided with the left descending pier at the second starboard barge from the bow, causing 8 of the barges to breakaway, including the red flag.  All eight barges laid up against the bridge, due to the downstream current.  The seven remaining barges were transferred to the DAVID L GRIGGS (nearby at the time) and transported to the Matson fleeting area (0.5 mi upstream).  
0930: MSD QC Investigators arrived on scene and conducted assessment of situation.  Met with company rep, master and vessel surveyor.  Investigators reminded company rep and master of 2692 requirement, as well as drug and alcohol testing requirements.  Remained on scene throughout recovery operation for all eight barges.  
02JUL13: Marquette Surveyor and CG Inspectors identified 3 barges with varying degrees of damage, including the red flag barge.  See Inspection Activity# 4639785 for details.

29JUN2013  UTV Kevin Michael allided with the Louisiana R/R bridge causing some damage to the bridge. Bridge supervisor is en route to conduct inspection. There is a train waiting to transit across bridge. 

SECUMR CC contacted UTV Kevin Michael, operator reports while transiting south bound (S/B) at Upper Mississippi River (UMR) mile marker (MM) 282.1, UTV allided with the Louisiana R/R D/B center pier. UTV Kevin Michael was pushing 12 barges (Loads of dry cargo, corn & beans) drafting 9'5" destined for St. Louis, MO. Operator states UTV Ponderosa was assisting when the allision occurred, the current was too strong and caused the port lead barge (LTD12022) to allide with the bridge, made a dent in the barge and broke some wires in tow, no pollution or injuries sustained. UTV Ponderosa did not sustain any damages. UTV Kevin Michael is presently holding position at MM 281 UMR to repair broken wires. SECUMR Duty I/O has been notified and conducting preliminary investigation.

Initial damage report was unknown do to the location of the damage being located below the surface of the water. Alcohol testing was not conducted.

01JUL2013 SECURM CC Received a telephone call from bridge tender with the Florence Highway Drawbridge (DB) at MM 56 ILR reporting that the UTV Jeff Boat allided with the north end protection cell of the bridge on the right descending bank. Bridge tender reports no damage, pollution, or injuries, bridge is operational and channel is clear. 

Received a telephone call from operator of UTV Jeff Boat reporting  an allision with the Florence Highway DB. Reporting source states that while transiting south bound (S/B) at MM 56 ILR pushing 15 barges (14 Loads dry cargo, 1 Empty Red Flag MEG) in a 3 wide by 5 long configuration, drafting 9' destined for Cairo, IL, the current and angle of approach caused his starboard stern barge (ACL 97001) to allide with north end protection cell of DB on the right descending bank. Reporting Source states no damage, pollution, or injuries to UTV or DB. The channel is clear and UTV continues to transit S/B toward Cairo, IL.
While transiting, small passenger vessel light fixture struck the bottom of the Broadway Bridge in the Harlem River.
UTV with crane barge briefly allided with bridge.

On July 12, 2013, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City, Louisiana, received a report that the Commercial  Fishing Vessel QUEEN MARY had a loss of steering and drifted into the Morgan City Railroad bridge. Nearby the Uninspected Towing Vessel MISS JUANITA assisted the QUEEN MARY back to the Morgan City dock for repairs. 

No pollution, damage to the bridge or vessel, or injuries were reported.

6/24/13 - M/V EVELYN DORIS allided with the Figure Eight Bridge. No reported damage to vessel or bridge.  Bridge tender will notify bridge maintenance in the morning.  Being a private bridge DOT does not need to be notified.

13JUL2013 UTV Joseph M. Hamilton (571622) allided with Florence Highway Drawbridge at ILR MM 56.0. Vessel was down bound to New Orleans with 4 loaded barges (2 crude oil, and 2 LCO) drafting 9' when the stbd stern (Crude oil) barge rubbed the protection cell of the bridge in a 'controlled landing.' The pilot had not stated his intentions to the CG or the bridge tender prior to contact. No report of any damage to the barge or the bridge.

SUMR Marine Inspector and Duty Investigator visited the vessel on 14JUL13 as it was taking on fuel at Wood River, IL  Marine Inspector could not find any damage and all voids were dry.

On June 28, 2013, at approximately 2335 local time, the tow vessel DECATUR (ON:1163416) was pushing the empty barge MMI 2808 (ON:1194448) when it allided with the East Roundbunch swing bridge on Cow Bayou. Several bridge pilings were crushed, and the bridge navigation lighting was disabled. The bridge's electrical system was damaged and later replaced.

On August 5, 2013, at approximately 0545, the uninspected passenger vessel SANDRA D (O.N. 1214557) left Pirate's Cove Marina with 03 crewmembers and 06 passengers aboard. The SANDRA D was underway on the Oregon Inlet Channel when the steering failed during a hard port turn while approaching the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge in Nags Head, NC. The operator stated that the rudder got stuck and he could not bring the vessel straight ahead causing the vessel to allided with the bridge support to the south side of the main navigation span at approximately 22 knots. The allision caused injuries to 02 passengers and 01 crewmember. After the allision, the operator (in an attempt to prevent a total loss of the vessel) backed off of the bridge and grounded the vessel on a nearby shoal. The passengers and crew were offloaded to the CG47258 and taken to the USCG Station Oregon Inlet. SEATOW refloated the SANDRA D and towed it to Wanchese, NC.

On August 09, 2013, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City, Louisiana received a report that the Uninspected Towing Vessel MAC ANDREW MCKINNEY was underway northbound in the Atchafalaya River transiting through the Morgan City Bridge Complex and pushing ahead 05 loaded tank barges.  The tank barges were being pushed in a 1-2-3-4-5 configuration.  Tank barge 1 was loaded with water repellent.  Tank barges 2,4, & 5 were loaded with lube oil.  Tank barge 3 was loaded with metaxylene.  The 5th barge rubbed the east fendering system on the Morgan City Rail Road Bridge.  The 3rd barge rubbed against the eastern piling of the Highway 90 bridge.  Master reports minor scrapes on the barges and no structural damage.  The wing tanks were checked after the incident and reported dry.

On June 3, 2013, while passing under the Washington Street Bridge, the deck-barge WEEKS 295 allided with the bridge fendering system.  There was minor damage to the fendering system.  The WEEKS 295 suffered no damage.

On 05 Aug 2013 at 0015 the M/V SEA DRIFT while heading west bound on the ICW allided with the West Port Arthur Bridge at mile marker 289 while pushing four empty tank barges including Kirby 29050.  The tank barge Kirby 29050 sustained damage: bent dog hatches on its port side.  The West Port Arthur Bridge sustained damage to its fendering system. No pollution, waterways obstruction or injuries. Post-marine casualty drug and alcohol testing was conducted on the vessel navigation watch. The alcohol testing was conducted outside the 8-hour required window reportedly because the vessel master and relief captain did not identify the incident as a marine casualty.

On August 21, 2013 at approximately 1300 hrs the passenger vessel STARDUST allided with the Astoria Megler Bridge. Damage to the vessel was estimated at $3,000.00 and the bridge had minor scratches. There were no injuries or pollution associated with this incident.

UTV Midland allided barge UBL 47 with I-30 highway bridge right descending protection cell.  After allision vessel was pushed to port and master steered hard to starboard to line up on the Presidential bridge and allided barge OR 5321 on left descending protection cell.  After allision to Presidential bridge, barges came apart and barges T 13621 and OR 5321 went adrift and grounded on revetment.

Investigation revealed Master misjudged strong currents in the area resulting him to lose control of the vessel and alliding with the bridge.

26AUG13 (1430): MSD Quad Cities received report from SUMR CC of the UTV ARCHIE WILSON had run aground the previous day and failed to report to the Coast Guard.  MSD QC IO's responded to the report, and met the vessel in Niota, IL, where the UTV was in the process of offloading the two ammonia anhydrous barges in the tow.  After complete inspection of the barges and UTV, no damage was found.  IO's spoke with the master, who stated that he had "touched bottom" just south of the Burlington RR Bridge at MM 403.1 on the UMR, while down bound, due to his alignment in the channel and moving the tow starboard to avoid colliding with a red channel marker buoy.  Witness Statements from Captain and crew were collected.

23 AUG 13 - 1700 Local - The UTV AMERICAN GIRL and BARGE19 were outbound from Round Lake, Charlevoix, MI.  Simultaneously, the SPV SUNSHINE II was inbound in the same narrow channel.  In spite of efforts by the Tug Master and Bridge Tender to notify the Master of the SUNSHINE II via VHF radio, the broadcasts went unanswered.  When the passenger vessel met the tug and tow at the bridge span, both attempted to stear clear of each other in effort to allow a port to port passage.  This effort caused the tug to tow the barge closely to the right side of the channel.  As a result, the barge allided with a pile at the bridge.  No damage to the bridge or barge were reported.

On August 13, 2013, at approximately 1900, the uninspected open hopper barge MRT 937 was loaded with limestone when it broke away from the Greer Limestone Company fleet at mile marker 98 on the Monongahela River. The barge drifted down river and allided with the right descending bank pier of the Star City Bridge.  No subsequent events occurred.

01 SEP 13; 1415: UTV ROBERT A. KNOKE is pushing (3) red flag barges loaded with light cycle oil allided with the Bayou Grosse Tete Swing Bridge near MM 47 on the MCPAAR.  The lead barge CHEM3243 struck the bridge and bent its vent pipe and broke off the pressure release valve.  The bridge did not sustain any reportable damage.  

Investigation revealed that the incident occured as a result of miscommunication between the Bridge Tender and the towing vessel Master.

No injuries or pollution reported.

On September 2, 2013, the M/V WEAVER ARROW was transiting inbound in the Sabine-Neches River to the Port of Beaumont when its SAT C antenna came into contact with the center span green navigation light on the Veterans Memorial Bridge, causing damage to both the bridge light and the ship's antenna. Antenna repairs were made on the vessel and the bridge light was later replaced.

On 12 September 2013, while transiting through the New Bedford swing bridge, the tug EDDIE R pushing the deck barge JOE VERROCHI experienced an equipment failure that resulted in the barge alliding with the bridge. 

No damage to the bridge or tug and barge was reported.

SUMR CC RCVD a report from Terminal Railway (Cross) of an allision between a crane barge in tow by the UTV Spirit and the 12th panel, near pier 1, of the MacArthur Train Bridge in STL Harbor.  Master of the UTV SPIRIT was backing down to reposition the crane barge further up on their dock.  Master forgot that the crane was up and when he drifted down below the MacArthur Bridge the crane gantry struck the underside of the bridge.  No damage to the bridge but the crane had extensive damage. Initial damage estimate was less than $100k. Master was drug and alcohol tested following the incident.

SLM CC received notification from the master of the Tug Ken Booth that they had struck a piling on the EJ&E bridge at MM 332 on the Calumet River in Chicago, IL. No pollution or injuries. Vessel sustained damage on the starboard, aft side and stern of the vessel.

The USNS 1st LT  HARRY L. MARTIN was being towed upstream in the St. Johns River, Jacksonville, FL.  The port side of the MARTIN's stern ramp struck the underside support beams of the Mathews Bridge.  The bridge was immediately shut down to vehicular traffic and the waterway underneath the bridge was closed to vessel traffic. 

The waterway was re-opened and the bridge remained closed to vehicular traffic for 33 days until repairs could be completed. No injuries or pollution resulted from the casualty.

On September 28, 2013, at approximately 0430, the fishing vessel MISS GEORGIE (O.N. 1137499) was underway on the Newport River transiting through the High Rise Bridge in Morehead City, NC when one of the outriggers that was in the up position allided with bridge.  The clearance sign showed 64 feet clearance which is the same clearance the operator has transited without incident in the past (when loaded with fuel, ice etc.). This time the MISS GEORGIE had an extra 2-3 feet draft due to low fuel, no ice, etc.  After the allision, the operator lowered the outriggers and proceeded through the bridge without further incident. The bridge suffered minor damage (indentation) and the MISS GEORGIE suffered damage to the outrigger on the starboard side.

On 28 Sep 2013, SCC received notification from Crescent City Pilot onboard the Tank Vessel TVERSKOY BRIDGE that the vessel had been aground at MM 87, Valero Mereaux Terminal.  The pilot used 3 tugs to maneuver the vessel out of the berth and the vessel was heading south bound to the nearest anchorage area.  No injuries, pollution or further casualties to report.  Drugs and alcohol are not suspected to have contributed to this incident.

On September 22, 2013, at approximately 1730 local time, the 126 foot passenger vessel DEL NORTE suffered a low oil alarm on the port outboard engine while moored at the San Francisco Ferry Building.  A National Response Center report was filed, with a potential release of 3-5 gallons of hydraulic fluid in San Francisco Bay.  No pollution was located.
SEC SCC received notification from Cashman Dredging that UTV allided with the route 4 bridge on the Hudson River in Schuylerville NY.

Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (SECUMR CC) received a notification via VHF Channel 16 from UTV Titletown USA reporting an allision with the McKinley Bridge at Mile Marker (MM) 182.5 Upper Mississippi River (UMR). UTV Titletown USA was transiting South bound (S/B) pushing 14 Loaded barges of Grain drafting 9'9" destined for St. Louis, MO, Reporting source states in an effort to clear Dredge America it caused them to allide with the IL side pier of the McKinley bridge. No damage, pollution, or injuries reported. The Channel is blocked. SECUMR CC issued a SMIB.

On October 10, 2013, the uninspected towing vessel ST. ANDREW was pushing a string of six barges west bound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway.  While transiting through the Bayou Blue Bridge the starboard stern  barge ACL 10119 allided with the bridge.  No damage to the barge or bridge occured as a result of the allision.

While a passenger was moving about the vessel she slipped, twisted her ankle and broke her foot. As the Ferry GRAND REPUBLIC was approaching the Port Jefferson, NY Ferry Terminal the announcement for passengers to return to their vehicles was made.  The passenger was egressing from 01 deck accommodation space down the ladder and toward the car ramp on the starboard side car flat. As the passenger stepped down from the car ramp deck to the parking deck she lost her balance and rolled her left ankle breaking her 5th. metatarsal bone. Passenger was moved to her POV by spouse and taken to an emergent care facility where she was diagnosed.

Received a call from Captain of the UTV CELESTE LOUISE stating that his vessel allided with the Dulac Bridge in Dulac Bayou.  The captain stated that he was going under the bridge and some deck lights from a shimping dock past the bridge was right in his eyes making it hard for him to see the starboard bow of his vessel, at that time his vessel allided with the bridge fendering system cracking some of the timbers of the fendering system.  The vessel was pushing 1 spud barge at the time, there is no damage reported to the vessel or its barge.

SLM CC received notification from xxxx M/V Magnolia, of one the vessel's barges rubbing against a bridge fender on the CSX Railroad bridge at MM254.0 over the Illinois River. Mr. Fields reports no damage to vessel, barges, or bridge.

On October 19, 2013, at approx 2345 hrs local the M/V ZEUS was underway northbound on the Ouachita River at MM 114 when vessel allided with the Columbia Rail Road Bridge.  MSD duty team conducted a field investigation and discovered that the Master was navigating northbound under the RR Bridge with two red flag barges loaded with ultra low sulfur diesel oil when thick fog set in which reduced visibility.  Tow was approximately half way through bridge when the stern barge, KIRBY 24706, allided with the left descending bridge pillar.  Master pushed tow in above bridge at MM 114.8 LDB.   No damage was noted on the bridge pillar by bridge attendant.  Damage to Kirby barge 24706 internals was visible through manhole on No. 2 port wing void with no indication of hull fractures or water ingress.  MSD issued a CG-835 for barge to off load cargo at Red River Terminal in Monroe, LA then proceed to shipyard for damage assessment and permanent repairs.  Upon completion of field investigation the M/V ZEUS was allowed to continue northbound transit.  

No pollution or other damage was reported or noted. 

Drugs and/or alcohol do not appear to be a factor in this case.

SLM CC received call from UTV MISS ALLIE advising that he allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge at MM 254.1 on the Illinois Waterway.  UTV was carrying 3 loaded barges with #6 black oil red-flagged. Master stated that the UTV hit the bridge pier, resulting in a 4.5 inch deep by 1 foot wide dent to the bridge support.  The GM-5002 tank barge sustained a 2.5 foot long by 1.5 foot deep indent to the port bow according to the Captain. The affected barge voids were sounded with negative results of water intrusion. The UTV had no injuries onboard.

On the morning of October 18, 2013, the towing vessel MISS YVETTE with the deck barge EXCALIBUR alongside was inbound in the Weymouth Fore River and was pushed into the fendering system of the Fore River Bridge by wind while transiting the draw.  The master was able to make a gentle landing and used the fender to avoid alliding with a barge combo that was blocking part of the draw.  There was no damage to either vessel or to the bridge or its fendering system.

On October 19, 2013, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received notification of an allision between an uninspected freight barge and the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge.  

The Uninspected Towing Vessel RIVER ROYAL was pushing 02 uninspected empty freight barges, transiting northbound on the Port Allen Landside route waterway.

The barges were arranged in a lead barge, second barge configuration, with the towing vessel pushing behind the second barge.  The starboard quarter of the second barge allided with the southeast corner of the bridge's fendering system.

No personnel injuries were reported.

The Investigating Officer asked about Drug & Alcohol testing.  It was not required and was being performed.

At 1715/22SEP13, Master of the Ferry PARK CITY notified the Sector Long Island Sound Command Center that a passenger fell and injured his left knee while departing the vessel at the Bridgeport Ferry Terminal.  The Ferry PARK CITY was moored to the Bridgeport Ferry Terminal, Bridgeport, Ct. disembarking passengers, at which time  a passenger was making his way down the gangway where he lost his balance at the transition of the gangway to the macadam parking lot and fell forward, striking his left knee on the pavement. Ambulance service was called and took the injured passenger to St. Vincent’s Hospital for follow on care. It was determined that the passenger ultimately required follow on surgery to relieve the associated swelling from his injury.

At approximately 0930 on 23 Oct 2013, the UTV JENNIE DEHMER was northbound on the Missouri River (MOR) pushing two 300' barges in tow, arranged in tandem. Just as the head of the lead barge began to pass under the Highway 67 Bridge, the captain of the UTV JENNIE DEHMER observed a workboat begin to cross the MOR from the right descending bank (RDB), heading directly into the path of the UTV's tow. The captain of the UTV JENNIE DEHMER put the engines full astern, blasted numerous danger signals, sounded the general alarm and attempted to turn the tow to avoid a collision. The workboat struck the corner of the port bow of the lead barge and immediately sank with the operator inside. The workboat was part of a construction crew that was working on the #2 and #4 piers of the Bellefontaine Railroad Bridge located at Mile Marker (MM) 8.2 on the MOR. The workboat was crossing from a work flat on the RDB to a work flat on the left descending bank (LDB). The UTV SIR DOLAN, a second vessel from the jobsite, assisted in the search for, and recovery of, the operator of the workboat. The UTV JOHANNA was transiting the area at the time of the incident and also assisted with search and recovery efforts. The workboat was salvaged after approximately 30 minutes, with the operator inside the cabin. The operator was pronounced dead at 0525 on October 24, 2013.

Barge GM 5010 under control of UTV Dave Anderson while down bound the port string allided with the Pekin Railroad Bridge, LDB, upper end protection cell at MM 151.3, ILR, causing wires to break in starboard string barge containing barge GM 5024 allowing barge to break free. Master of UTV Dave Anderson successfully retrieved GM 5024 and rewired barge into tow. No significant damage or injuries reported. Inspectors surveyed barges and UTV, confirmed damage to barge GM 5010 was minimal and did not affect the structural integrity or water tightness of vessel.

It was reported to Sector Long Island Sound on 23OCT13/1330 that on 22OCT13 at approximately 1300, while the Tug FRANKLIN REINAUER with the T/B RTC 26  pushing ahead was departing Johnson's Creek entering into Long Island Sound enroute New York City, it allided with the Pleasure Beach Bridge.   As the Mate at the helm rounded up the Tow on the bridge and started progressing down the channel running parallel to the bridge he got set by the wind down into the center span super structure and cribbing, the allision of the tow with the bridge structure caused extensive damage to the pedestrian walkway assembly and railing arrangements on the center span . The Tug and Tow was attended by Sector LIS Marine Inspector/Investigator upon its return Johnson's Creek on 24OCT13/0900, no damage was identified to the tug and or barge.

On October 31, 2013 at approximately 2030, UTV LARRY TILLEY (O.N. 511120) was transiting the Tombigbee River MM 173 when the wind caught the vessel and caused the lead barge to brush the Naheola Railroad Bridge. No damage was done to the vessel or bridge.

On 4NOV13 at approximately 1550, the UTV SARA KAITLIN (ON 293828) was transiting southbound on the AICW with two barges and dredge piping under astern tow. An assist tow, the UTV GRAHAM (ON 1215995), maneuvered off the stern of the second barge, directly controlling approximately sixty feet of dredge pipe as the vessels transited the AICW. During the approach to the Wappoo Cut Bridge, the Master of the SARA KAITLIN noticed a strong flood tide, setting the towing vessel to port. The Master compensated by setting up an approach on the starboard side of the channel and successfully passed the towing vessel through the bridge opening. Both barges remained on the starboard side of the channel, resulting in the starboard bow of the second barge alliding with the fender system of the bridge. The barge and the bridge fender sustained minimal damage and no injuries or pollution occurred.
UTV was underway and pushing ahead dredge, made up on port quarter.  Starboard bow of dredge made contact with fendering system of Morgan R/R Bridge over Cheesequake Creek, NJ.

On November 3, 2013 at approximately 2230, UTV GORDON A. KEENAN (O.N. 1242167) was pushing ahead 02 loaded tank barges transiting on the Tombigbee River MM 173.2. As the master approached the Naheola RR bridge, the current slid the stern barge of the tow into the bridge pillar. A dent was left on the aft side of the barge (15'X4'X8") in the monetary amount of $60,000. No damage was done to the bridge. Vessel continued to final destination where repairs were made. No further incidents.

While transiting the Victoria Barge Canal, the UTV Alex B's stern barge brushed the fenders on the starboard side. The UTV was pushing two empty deck barges. MSD Victoria conducted investigation. No damage to either the barge or the fenders of the bridge.

On 17 NOV 2013, Sector NOLA received report that the UTV JOEY JOHN allided with the CSX RR Bridge while transiting down the ICW at MM 35 EHL.  There is no damage to the UTV JOEY JOHN or barge and the damage to the CSX RR Bridge is a bent "I" Beam.  There were no additional casualties reported.

On 25-Oct-2013, Sector NOLA received a report that the UTV RAZORBACK pushing ahead a crane barge had the top of the crane barge hit the underside of the LaPalco Drawbridge damaging the bridge's catwalk.  The person operating the UTV RAZORBACK was unlicensed.

On November 18, 2013, the uninspected freight barge JOHN WAYNE allided with the Bayou Bouef Railraoad Bridge in Amelia, LA.  The barge was being pushed by the uninspected towing vessel MISS AIMEE southbound in Bayou Beouf.  The allision resulted in three fenders and a navigation light on the bridge being offset.  No damage to the JOHN WAYNE was identified.

The JOHN WAYNE is a 180 foot by 54 foot uninspected/undocumented contruction barge.  The Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge has a clearance of 56 feet.  Wind at the time of the incident 15 miles per hour out of the northeast.  

No injuries, pollution, or other marine casualty occured as a result of the allision.

20 NOV 13; 0720: UTV St. Charles is northbound on the Port Allen route turning at the Grosse Tete Bridge and allides with the guide wall breaking a timber with the lead barge KIRBY 29035 carrying 3,500 tons of pie gas.  Duty IO verified no damage to barge, and one timber broken on Grosse Tete Bridge guide wall.

No further injuries, damage or pollution reported.

On November 21, 2013, MSD Nags Head received a report from North Carolina Department of Transportation Bridge Division that the Alligator River Swing Bridge was struck around midnight on November 20, 2013. The bridge tender could not accurately report what vessel struck the bridge. Further investigation found that the Tug CAJUN (O.N. 589263) and the Tug POPS (O.N. 285160) were towing a crane barge and 450 feet of dredge pipeline through the bridge when the dredge pipeline allided with the fendering system causing extensive damage. No pollution, injuries or damages to the vessels were reported. Since the vessels and tow were unable to coordinate a location to moor in North Carolina, the CG Investigator allowed the vessels to continue to their next port in Charleston, SC. The Investigating Officers from Sector Charleston conducted the investigation.

08JUN2013; 1629; ALLISION, UTV REED DANOS (ON588434) AND HOUMA NAV SWING BRIDGE: Received notification from the Houma Nav Swing Bridge Operator that the UTV Reed Danos was pushing a barge and the tip of the barge hit the fendering system for the bridge. The bridge operator states that there was some rubber knocked off the first 3 federing pads. Bridge remains fully operational. Tried to hail UTV Reed Danos and call the cell phone given to the bridge operator with negres. Bridge had closed due to unexpected issues and traffice was backed up waiting to pass.

On November 27, 2013, the uninspected towing vessel BRIDGET CAULLEY was underway transiting on the Intracoastal Waterway in vicinity of Mile Marker 170.  

The vessel was pushing three empty tank barges.  The crew underestimated the power of the wind, and was swung perpendicular to the channel, causing the rear of the tug to strike the bank, causing rudder and tiller arm damage.  Once the wind abated slightly, the tug was able to get back underway.  02 assist tugs were dispatched, one to take the barges, and the other to assist the vessel to Elmwood Ship Repair in Gretna, LA.

No pollution or injuries were caused as a result of this incident.
Vessel fiberglass antenna made contact with bridge while underway.

On 26NOV13 at approximately 0823, it was reported via Fax Notification to the USCG Sector Long Island Sound Investigations Department that a passenger slipped on the stern car loading ramp for the P/V GRAND REPUBLIC on the evening of 24NOV13 at approximately 2200 while embarking the Ferry. The passenger while embarking the vessel used the stern car loading ramp in lieu of the passenger designated gangway. When instructed by ship's crew to turn around and use the gangway, she stopped abruptly, slipped and landed on her left knee, thus causing the reported laceration. The passenger recovered herself and made her way onboard the vessel, where she was provided with immediate care. She ultimately opted to ride the Ferry to Long Island, seeking out follow on care at Mather Hospital. Passenger released with multiple stitches and instructed to follow up with Personal Physician.

On December 3, 2013, at approximately 1044 local time, the passenger ferry GOLDEN GATE experienced an equipment failure while docked in San Francisco, California.  The internal seal on the port aft main engine high pressure fuel pump was leaking.  The engine remained operational; however, the vessel's owner chose to remove the vessel from service in order to rectify the problem while the engine was still under warranty.

SCC NOLA received a call from the agent of the MV SID MOLLER that struck the underside of the Bayou Delores bridge at MM60 ICW.  The MV SID MOLLER notified the bridge that he needed the bridge to be opened and by the time the MV SID MOLLER came around the bend, the bridge was not open.  Because of the distance from the turn to the bridge was so short, the MV could not stop.  The vessel then proceeded to transit under the bridge and bent its mast light.  The bridge tender stated that there was no damage done to the bridge.

SCC received a notification from a Maryland State Bridge Inspector of a barge allision with the Spa Creek draw bridge located in Annapolis, MD.  The Tug B&W MARINE was pushing a 150ft deck barge, when the barge struck the Spa Creek draw bridge.  The Tug POWERHOUSE from Central Marine was following the B&W MARINE at the time of the incident. The barge struck the bridge slightly off center, toward the near side of the bridge tenderhouse.  MD Bridge Inspector arrived on scene to conduct a damage assessment of the bridge.  The Damage assessment revealed 2 vertical boards on the bridge had been affected, both are cracked with a 4-6" indent.  The Bridge Inspector reported the bridge is not an imminent threat to vehicles or vessels and can continue to operate.  The Bridge Inspector reported there was no need to close the bridge.  All other bridge functions operate as intended and designed.

On December 7, 2013, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Houma received notification that the Uninspected Towing Vessel BAYOU LADY allided with the south side of the Bayou Blue Bridge while pushing 6 empty hopper barges en route to a scrap yard in Morgan City, Louisiana. 

The caller stated that the vessel lost steering while in the process of passing through the bridge. The minor damage to the barge is inconsequential as the barges are headed to a scrap yard. However, the caller reported significant damage to the bridge.

No pollution or personnel injuries were reported.

The Command Center recieved a phone call from the Houma Navigation Bridge, that the tug SEA MULE, lead tug, and the tug SUMERTIME, tail tug, had 01 deck barge allied with the fender wall. Was unable to get in touch with tugs at phone number, 985-688-xxxx, given by the bridge operator.

IO's investigated the incident and established a presumption of negligence due to the fact that an allision occurred.

10Jul13 @ 0240: UTV MELVIN L. KING was heading eastbound from Houston, TX to Demopolis, AL. The vsl was pushing ahead 6 empty hopper barges in Tandem. The barges usually carry concrete. At approx. 0240 the middle barge the BIG 996B caught the corner of the Black Bayou Pontoon Bridge, this caused the bridge to get pushed off the pivot post and the pivot arm was in the water. The barge suffered a hole located 7' above the waterline and measured (4"x12").  Alcohol tests were conducted with USCG aboard the vsl, Drug test to be administered during next 24 hrs. Conducted Post Casualty UTV examination with no deficiencies. Vsl cleared to continue voyage; no pollution, or injuries. See IO statement in correspondence for more details.

On 11 December 2013, UTV CHRIS ARDEN allided with Norfolk and Southern R/R Bridge at MM 315 OHR. While fleeting one tank barge (AI 529, #2 Diesel), wind and river current caused UTV and barge to be set toward right-descending R/R bridge. Pilot reported rake of barge contacted pier at low speed (.5kt). Pilot then corrected heading, causing stern of barge to contact pier closest to RDB. Aton was not a factor. Barge is currently in Marathon fleeting area and UTV has continued transit. Norfolk and Southern R/R Bridge manager notified and closed bridge to R/R traffic and river.  No damage to R/R bridge reported by bridge inspectors.  River and R/R bridge was opened to all traffic.  I/O inspected AI 529 for extent of damage and interviewed crew on UTV Chris Arden.  Damage survey to barge has been added to case.

On May 7, 2013, the uninspected towing vessel SIDNEY V was pushing a barge under the West Larose Bridge at mile marker 36 on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway.  The starboard side of the barge allided with the south side fender of the bridge causing minor damage to the fender.  The barge was not damaged.  No pollution or injuries were associated with this incident.

Reference notification #579633,  Case #635232, and IIA #4626969.

On December 17, 2013 the bulk carrier OCEANIS was underway in the Chelsea River, Massachusetts when the vessel allided with the McArdle Street Bridge fendering system. The vessel continued on to Eastern Minerals where it moored up. Sector Boston Marine Inspector and Investigator responded.

On December 15, 2013, the self-propelled barge PATRIOT was dislodged from where it was spudded down in the Merrimack River by current and ice.  The barge allided with the Rocks Village Bridge causing some damage to the barge's spuds and wells.

Received notification that a U.S.-flagged inspected tank barge under the direction and control of a 189 gross ton U.S.-flagged uninspected towing vessel unintentionally allided with the West Port Arthur Bridge which spanned the Intracoastal Waterway, a navigable waterway of the United States. The allision affected the northeast corner of the bridge fendering system.  There was no damage to the towing vessel or barge nor were there any injuries or pollution associated with this event.  

Monetary damage estimates to the bridge fendering system were not immediately attainable, were suspected to be above $25K but not initially guaged to be aboe $100K.  Accordingly, this incident was not judged to meet definition of Serious Marine Incident as outlined in 46 CFR 4.03-2.  However, iaw MSM Volume V.A.5.F.2., this bridge allision was assigned an Informal level of investigative effort.

24DEC13 - MV SYDNEY T was southbound on the Red River when it allided with the Jackson Street lift bridge at MM 88.5. Vessel had 06 empty hopper barges in tow.

Drugs and/or alcohol did not appear to be a factor in this case.

No further damage, pollution or injuries reported.

Subject towing vessel reported, while transiting upbound in vicinity of mile marker 602.9 OHR, the towing vessel's starboard stern rubbed against the left descending pier of the Big Four Railroad Bridge in Louisville, KY.

On November 04, 2013, at approximately 1330,  Southern Towing Company reported  that the UTV Richard Sides had a loss of steering casualty at mile marker (MM) 700 on the Upper Mississippi River.  The UTV operator stated that while they were pushing downbound towards the Lacrosse Railroad Bridge (MM 699.8 UMR) with their assist tug UTV Barbara B,  their steering ram came apart. They were pushing 04 empty non red flagged fertilizer barges. The UTV was drafting 9 feet. The operator stated that they were pushed against the LDB to start repairs. No damage, or  pollution noted, there was 08 crew onboard and no injuries reported.

On December 27, 2013, Marine Safety Unit Morgan City, Louisiana received a report that the Uninspected Towing Vessel MISS DIANA was pushing a deck barge and transiting through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge.  The deck barge got stuck while transiting underneath the bridge.  The operator backed down and was able to free the barge by pulling up tires on the sides of the barge which make up the fendering system.  The barge and tow were able to safely transit through the bridge system without any further incident.

No pollution, no injuries, and no damage was reported.

Drug and Alcohol testing was not conducted and not required by the company.

29 Dec13;1925: The UTV FREEDOM, UTV ANGELA RAE, and UTV MISS DOROTHY were south bound with barge  FSP 101 in tow. Upon approaching Sunshine Bridge UTV MISS DOROTHY experienced engine problems, which caused a drag in the tow and moved the UTV ANGELA RAE from their sail line. The UTV MISS DOROTHY allided with the Sunshine Bridge's fendering system, causing a 2 foot inset along the starboard hull. The vessel began taking on water and was able to push up on the west bank at MM 167 LMR. A deckhand on the UTV MISS DOROTHY was injured with a broken leg and taken to the hospital.

Injured crewmember was not drug & alcohol tested while at the hospital as their employer expected.  All other drug & alcohol tests were conducted for involved crew members. 

07Jan14- Western Rivers Rep. confirms that repairs will not be made, vessel will be a total loss.

The bridge operator at Grosse Ile Toll Bridge reported that the starboard stern of the M/V MANISTEE made contact with the north bridge pier in the Trenton Channel.  The vessel did not make contact with the bridge itself and the bridge is fully operational.  Sector Detroit's Marine Casualty Investigator found no damage to the M/V MANISTEE.  The bridge owner claims that there is significant damage to the bridge pier, however he is unable to have the structure properly inspected due to river icing conditions.  He stated that the bridge pier will be inspected by a naval architect to obtain an estimated cost to repair damages in the spring of 2014.  Causal analysis tab is bold because the initial data indicated that there would be damage estimates forthcoming in excess of $25k.  However, damage estimates were requested on several occasions and never reported or provided. Causal analysis not completed.
Coast Guard received a report that the UTV HMS LIBERTY allided with the AK Railroad Bridge on the Arthur Kill River in the port of NY/NJ.

The motor vessel JAMES H. HUNTER allided with the Canton Rd Hwy 80 / 60 bridge at mile marker 63.1 of the Cumberland River. While transiting down bound a strong crosswind forced the barge second from the lead on its starboard string to land against the bridge pier. No damage, pollution or injuries.

On 01.05.14 at approximately 0920PST the WSF WENATCHEE (ON 1063109) #1 end battery charger, for the propulsion control system, defaulted.  Crewman immediately switched to the #2 end charger system.  The crewman allowed the #1 end battery charger to cool and electricians' trouble shot the system and could not duplicate the issue/shutdown.  The #1 end battery charging system was reset and the vessel continued to run without further incident.

The M/V BILL RODGERS was pushing 8 empty hopper barges at MM 118.5 on the Arkansas River in the vicinity of the I-30 Bridge when its starboard stern barge PB 9606 allided with the bridge protection cell.  No damage to cell or barge.

On January 11, 2014, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received notification of an allision between the Uninspected Towing Vessel FRED A SETTOON and the Bayou Beouf Railroad Bridge in Louisiana.  

The RIVER ROYAL was pushing 02 empty freight barges, transiting northbound on the Port Allen Landside route waterway.

The barges were arranged in a line, in a lead barge, second barge configuration, with the towing vessel pushing behind the second barge.  The lead barge made contact with the bridge's fendering system causing minor cosmetic damage. 

No pollution or personnel injuries were reported.

Motor vessel MISS KATHY down bound on the Ohio River mile marker 940.8 pushing 4 empty red flag barges in a 2 by 2 configuration drafting 2 ft. Master reports the wind caught the barges and they made contact with the right descending bank I-24 bridge pier. No damage to bridge pier, minor damage to starboard stern of the 2nd barge back on starboard string. No other damage, pollution or injuries. Vessel was allowed to continue to Cario fleeting area.

M/V JEFFBOAT collided with the Illinois Central Railroad Bridge at MM 977.7 OHR. Tow broke apart upon impact and damage was reported on the vessel as well as two barges.  No damage to bridge, pollution or injuries.

On January 16, 2014, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received a report that Mobile Offshore Drilling Unit (MODU) COASTAL RIG 20's port bow allided into the Patout Swing Span Bridge's guide timbers at Weeks Bayou in Vermillion Bay, Louisiana.  The COASTAL RIG 20 was being towed by the Uninspected Towing Vessels MISS LAURIE, MR. THOMAS, and MR. SCOTT at the time of the incident. 

There were no damage, injuries, or pollution reported.
On January 17, 2014, the commercial fishing vessel (CFV) SKOAL allided with the swinging Southport Bridge as it was closing.  No injuries. Only property damage to vessel.

On 21 January 2014, at approximately 0830, the towing vessel JACK HOLLAND (O.N. 669003) , pushing ahead one empty hopper barge, allided with the Centerville Turnpike Swing Bridge while transiting the intercoastal waterway in the Albemarle and Chesapeake Canal.  The incident was immediately reported by the vessel's Captain to the bridge tender and the Coast Guard.  Upon inspection of the bridge by the bridge supervisor, it was determined that no damages were sustained to the bridge or fendering system.  There was no damage to the towing vessel or barge and no injuries sustained by the vessel's crew.

Towing vessel LARRY TILLEY pushing 14 loaded rock barges downbound at mile 2.5 Cumberland River allided with the Lucy Jefferson Lewis Memorial Bridge (I-60) on the right descending pier. No damage, pollution, injuries to the tow. 2'X2' rub mark observed on the bridge pier.  Kentucky DOT completed bridge inspection noting no damage.

Received notification that a foreign-flagged tank vessel transiting under the Martin Luther King Jr. Bridge spanning the Sabine-Neches Canal, a navigable waterway of the United States, created a wake which impacted construction scaffolding around a fendering cell and resulted in its collapse into the waterway.  

Early monetary estimates of the material damages were initially judged to be at or below $100K.  Upon further review and discussion with the bridge construction manager it was discovered that final damages would exceed $100K and approach $500K.  However, the initial estimates were the figures used and accordingly this incident was assigned a data collection level of investigative effort iaw MSM Volume V, Part A. Chapter 5.F.2 (Property Damage paragraph).  Additionally, this incident was not judged to meet the Major Marine Casualty criteria outlined in 46 CFR 4.40-5((d).

25 JAN 14; 1100: SEC NOLA received notification that two different vessels allided with the Simmesport RR bridge and broke apart their tows. Witness lives nearby and witnessed the event. The only name of the vessel noticed was DANA ROBYN. The other vessel's name was undetermined at the time of the incident. Reporting source believed same company owns both vessels. Both looked to be pushing a dredge barge and transiting south bound. Neither vessel reported the allisions to the Coast Guard. MSU DIO called Melville Bridge to get names of south bound vessels. The UTVs DANA ROBYN and LINDA FISHER confirmed that they were towing dredging equipment south bound to their homeport of Port Lavaca, Texas & came in contact with the Simmesport Railroad bridge.  One of the anchor barges in the LINDA FISHER's tow broke out of the tow at the time of the allision. Both vessels are owned by the same company and both just completed a dredging operation for the US ACOE.
Subsequently the dredging equipment in the UTV DANA ROBYN's tow came in contact with the Melville Bridge as they transited through the area. No damage reported to either bridge. No damage reported to dredging equipment on either of the towing vessel's tows.
Both towing vessels were restricted on the Atchafalaya River until the size of their tows could be reduced to less than 800 feet. Both tows were over 800 feet prior to restriction and were having communication problems with the dredge tender vessels that were assisting the tows through the bridges.

On 27JAN14 at approximately 2000, the Ferry PARK CITY had a catastrophic failure of an O ring seal on the port main diesel engine lube oil line that connects the lube oil heat exchanger to the lube oil duplex filter assembly, at the filter assembly.  Chief Engineer notified the bridge and ordered the engine secured. Vessel continued onto Port Jefferson, NY to effect permanent repairs. Repairs could not be completed due to a lackof resources. Vessel was authorized to return to Bridgeport, CT.  Upon conducting final repairs to the lube oil line and bringing the engine back into service it was identified that the reduction gear clutch pack had catastrophically failed due to a lack of lubrication while enroute homeport because it was fanning while underway. After repairs were made and sea trials conducted it was identified that the port main diesel engine had metal shavings in it's lube oil filters due to the common lubrication system transporting shavings from the reduction gear up to the engine. O/O elected to take vessel out of service for emergency dry dock to replace port main diesel engine.

This incident is considered a Major Marine Casualty based on the cost of the clutch pack work, purchasing, transporting, and installing a new main diesel engine.

25JAN14 Sector Upper Mississippi River received a report from Kirby Inland Marine stating that their vessel, the UTV Challenge ran aground at MM 143.9 UMR. He was headed upbound pushing 02 loaded dry cargo barges of non-regulated fertilizer with a 9 foot draft. Vessel was off ground by 0630 CST with no damage, pollution, or injuries noted.

On 05 February 2014, at approximately 1100 local time, Sector Hampton Roads received notification from the Virginia Marine Police that the CFV STORM was operating in the vicinity of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel (C.B.B.T.) when it allided with the bridge around 0130 on 05 February 2014 after the Mate-on-watch fell asleep at the helm.  Sector Hampton Roads was not notified until approximately nine hours after the allision occurred when Virginia Marine Police was conducting fishery examinations at the Newport News, VA Small Boat Harbor.  No immediate notifications were provided by the Master of the vessel or the Owning or Operating Company.  Sector Hampton Roads Investigators attended the vessel and conducted a joint preliminary investigation with Virginia Marine Police, noting substantial damage to the vessel's main boom, port and starboard rigging.

On February 12, 2014, at approximately 1630, the towing vessel JOHN PARRISH (O.N. 543973) was the lead vessel towing astern the dredge HAMPTON ROADS (O.N. 521346), the crane barge JOHN (O.N. 644022) and an A frame anchor barge MB50.  During the towing evolution, there were two other assist tugs the M/V KELLY ANNE (O.N. 1075488), which was positioned on the starboard side of the dredge HAMPTON ROADS, and the M/V ETHEL G (O.N. 1132925), which was positioned on the port side of the tow between the JOHN and the MB50.

The tow was transiting southbound on the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway in the vicinity of Holden Beach, NC.  While transiting through the Holden Beach Bridge the port side of the tow, the dredge HAMPTON ROADS, struck the east side of the bridge's fendering system causing significant damage. After the allision, the master of the JOHN PARRISH contacted the USCG and continued transiting to Charleston, SC.

On February 12, 2014, at approximately 0645 local time, the 874 foot long, Panamanian-flagged container ship, BRUSSELS BRIDGE was outbound from Oakland, California, en route Japan, when the vessel experienced an unexpected reduction in propulsion.  The vessel's main engine was not capable of running at full RPM, however, it was capable of half-ahead.  The vessel returned to San Francisco Bay Anchorage 7 to perform repairs.

Sector Lake Michigan received a call from the UTV Gretchen C stating they had allided with the Chessie Railroad bridge at MM254.1 on the Illinois River. The tank barge HTCO 3077 struck the protection cell of the bridge on the port side amidships, causing a 3 inch by 2 foot long indent near the waterline.  The impact caused the tow to be pushed to the opposite bridge pier where the tank barge HTCO 3076 struck on the starboard bow knuckle of the barge.  No damage occurred to the HTCO 3076.  The starboard side face wire was severed during the incident.  Both barges were empty gasoline CBOB red flag barges. No pollution or injuries were reported. The tow was transiting from Chicago, IL to Houston, TX.  MSU Chicago Investigators responded to the incident and issued a CG-835 for the damage to HTCO 3077 barge.

On February 23, 2014 at approximately 1230 hours, the M/V RIVER QUEEN allided with the Purple People Bridge while on an excursion cruise with 40 passengers on board.  The vessels stacks were hung up on a section of the lower under hang of the bridge. The ornamental crown on the starboard side was completely sheared off and the port side crown was bent and buckled.

As a result of this incident, there was no pollution or injuries reported.
SECTOR OHIO VALLEY received notification from Lock and Dam 52 that UTV ROBERT GREENE (619977,  6250HP, ACL) had allided with the I-24 bridge at MM 940.8.

UTV PERE MARQUETTE reporting an allision with the Florence Highway Drawbridge at mile marker (MM) 56.0 Illinois River (ILR). Pilot of the towing vessel stated that he was heading down bound (D/B) destined for St. Louis, MO pushing 12 loaded dry cargo barges drafting 9'6". R/P further states the cause was due to the current pushing him to port, he over corrected to starboard resulting in the lead starboard barge (CC 9218) to allide with the protection cell on the right descending side. The barge sustained a broken strand on a wire and the second barge on the starboard side sustained a hairline fracture above the waterline, (not taking on water). Fractures are located on the box end at the upper knuckle and a small vertical fracture immediately below that one. Both are above the waterline.  No other damage to either barge was found. Vessel will be transiting to St Louis where the barge will be unloaded and repaired.  No noticeable damage to the protection cell was reported by the UTV or the bridge tender. Bridge tender reports will conduct a more thorough inspection during daylight hours. No further damage, pollution, or injuries were reported. Duty I/O requested CG2692.

04 March 14; 1800:  UTV NATALIE ALEXANDER was northbound with 3 red flag barges in tow and intended on transiting through Simmesport Railroad Bridge when the lead barge allided with the west span. No damage to barge other than some scratches. No damage to Simmesport railroad bridge reported.

No further injuries, pollution, or damage reported.

On 21 February 2014 the UTV CHARLES HUAN was underway on the Tombigbee River at MM173.6 near Naeola Bridge. The UTV CHARLES HUAN was carrying coal. The UTV allided with the east pillar of the Naheola bridge. There was no damage reported for the barge or the bridge pillar, phone call with the Bridge tender confirmed no damage.

MV JOSEPH L BLOCK was entering Sturgeon Bay, WI, from Lake Michigan en route to Bay Ship.  Ice Build up on the port quarter and starboard bow of the vessel slowed the swing of the vessel to starboard, causing the port bow to strike the SE fender of the Michigan Street Bridge.  Caused damage to two rubber fenders on the east end of the bridge.

At 0530 local time the tank vessel (T/V) SEAPRIDE was outbound on the Piscataqua River. While going through the Memorial Bridge the SEAPRIDE allided with the fendering system, resulting in the loss of 01 fender and scrape marks down side of the hull. Initial contact was made to the port side # 1 wing ballast tank.  Follow up inspection of the void revealed that the hull was not breached as no water entered the hull.
Motor vessel MOUNTAIN STATE was upbound on the Ohio River at mile marker when the top of the radar and flag pole had struck the I-24 bridge. No other damage, pollution, or injuries reported.

On March 14, 2014, the UTV JAMES H (C&B Marine, 1200HP, 501747) allided with the Taylor-Southgate Bridge (US 27) at MM 469.9 OHR. UTV JAMES H was headed upbound pushing 6 empty hopper barges (3x3 configuration), when the master reported that the wind caught the tow and pushed the UTV toward the pier near the RDB, causing the port stern barge to allide with the pier. The crew immediately conducted a visual inspection and took soundings. No damage, pollution, or injuries were noted. ATON was not a factor. Kentucky Transportation Cabinet responded and conducted a bridge assessment. No damage noted.

Captain of ATB DOROTHY ANN/PATHFINDER contacted MSU Cleveland Duty Marine Inspector to notify of allision with the River Terminal Rail Road Bridge (Arcelor Mittal Rail Road Bridge) over the Cuyahoga River at Mile Marker 5.42. While backing down, barge PATHFINDER allided with the bridge's fender system on the portside slightly forward of amidships. No damage to the vessel or the bridge was found upon investigation by the vessel's captain and bridge tender. No injuries, no pollution reported. The bridge continued to operate at full capacity. 

Captain reported that he was too late to make a course correction using starboard bow thruster before the vessel allided with the bridge. Personnel were stationed on deck to make distance call outs to the bridge via hand held radio. Deck personnel notified captain immediately that vessel had made contact with the fendering system. Captain of the DOROTHY ANN/PATHFINDER immediately notified CG Duty personnel and the rail road bridge tender.

On March 13, 2014, the Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received a report that the barge HUNTER S, being pushed by an uninspected towing vessel MS. MONIQUE, allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge in Amelia, Louisiana.  No damage  to either vessel or the bridge occurred as a result of this incident.  

No other casualties associated with this incident.

The UTV NAVIGATOR (562688), was at sea towing the U.S. inspected barge SAN JUAN-JAX BRIDGE (667317) from Jacksonville, FL to San Juan, PR. The engine alarm on the PMDE sounded and reported the water pump had failed. The engineer secured the Port MDE and replaced the water pump. All tests were satisfactory and the NAVIGATOR continued towards San Juan.

USCG Sector Upper Mississippi River rcvd a telephone call from the bridge operator at the Florence Highway Bridge at ILR MM 56.0 stating the UTV ARDYCE RANDALL allided with the bridge protection cell while transiting beneath the structure. Notification of intentions to allide were not made to the bridge tender or the CG. The UTV ARDYCE RANDALL was southbound to St Louis, MO with twelve dry cargo barges drafting 9'6" when the incident occurred. The second barge in starboard string (ART-440360) is currently taking on water, and pumps are being deployed to the #5 void. Amount and rate of water is unknown but pumps kept the flooding in check.  Two broken wires were also reported by the tow. Bridge tender was unable to tell if there was any damage due to low light. SECUMR made recommendations to bridge operator to contact the owner of the bridge as well as ILDOT.

During downbound transit to Green River MM 1, subject vessel with 4 loaded coal barges, temporarily lost maneuverability due to a steering failure. This loss of maneuverability caused the stbd aft barge to make contact with the right descending pier of the Spotsville Railroad bridge.  The impact from the contact broke some rigging wires causing a two barges to break free from the tow.  Quick action by the crew rebuilt the tow and inspected all vessels.  There was no damage other than the broken wires.

The vessel was placed in the GRN MM 1 fleeting area while engineers from the vessel owner completed a diagnosis and repairs to the steering system.  A bare wire within the control pod was grounding on panel.  This caused temporary intermitent failure of the steering system.  Corrective and preventative actions were taken on all associated wiring.  Vessel operational after proper testing of all steering and navigation equipment.

On March 27, 2014, Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the uninspected towing vessel DISCOVERY was pushing 2 empty barges north through the BAYOU BOUEF RAILROAD BRIDGE in Amelia, Louisiana, when it struck the bridge with one of its barges while the master was at the helm. The vessel itself is 57.7 feet long.  The barge 06-2B is 45 feet wide and 160 feet long, and is the same size and length of as the other barge.  The forward barge that struck the bridge with its forward port corner, the 06-2B, was an unregistered barge.  Neither the vessel nor the barges were damaged, but the bridge had 5 timbers broken.  The structural integrity of the bridge remained intact, and it was able to continue operations. 

No pollution or injuries resulted from this incident.
M/V hit the Bayonne Bridge while inbound on the Kill Van Kull in the Port of New York and New Jersey.

On 18FEB14 at approximately 0940 the tug AMY MORAN with the barge BRIDGEPORT in a pushing ahead configuration, while backing down to tie up port side to the M/V BARKALD, anchored in the Bridgeport Anchorage, Long Island Sound, Ct., conducting dry cargo off loading operations from the M/V DARYA MOTI, allided with the port aft quarter of the M/V BARKALD. The barge BRIDGEPORT's starboard forward quarter at the aft foremost set of bits struck the M/V BARKALD in way of frame 17 at longitudinal #2 from the deck turn creating an inset approximately 1 inch deep that extends to frame 15. A second allision occurred when the same set of bits struck in way of frame 12 at longitudinal #2 from the deck turn creating an inset approximately 4 inches deep that extends to frame 10. Also internally where the allisions took place were multiple deflected and tripped up webbing, bracing and bracketing arrangements in way of the intersections of the associated transverse and longitudinal framing.

4 Apr 14:  Received a call from Chad Comeaux stating that the MV CINDY T SETTOON pushing the SMI 30029, and SMI 30030 loaded with crude oil allided with the Claiborne Bridge.  At the time of the report there was no damage reported from the bridge and is still open for traffic at this time.  No injuries, pollution or further casualties to report.  Drug and alcohol testing was conducted on the vessel Master.

At approximately 1400 on 08APR14, MSD QC IO received call from SUMR CC reporting a bridge allision between the M/V WISCONSIN and the Sabula Railroad Bridge, in Sabula, IA.  The M/V WISCONSIN was pushing 15 loaded barges at the time, all dry cargo, no red flags.  Upon arrival in Sabula, IOs witness extent of damage to R/R bridge, which included the complete destruction of the down bound protection cell in the center of the swing bridge.  When IO's got onboard the M/V WISCONSIN, spoke with Master and Pilot.  Pilot was on watch at the time, reports losing port steering pump and reduction in maneuverability of vessel.  This led to striking the bridge.  Port lead barge was damaged only on the fiberglass covers, no structural damage as indicated by conducting inspection of voids and inspecting all sides of the barge from waterside asset.  Pilot conducted post casualty alcohol testing, and Master indicated that company had been informed and was sending a representative to conduct post casualty drug testing. 

Spoke with Marine Surveyor who inspected the damage to the bridge, and estimated offhand the damages to be in excess of $400,000.  Canadian Pacific Rail personnel were on scene conducting testing of the railway to determine functionality.  Functional tests were completed satisfactorily, but the waterway is closed to traffic at this time.  Temporary repairs are being planned, as well as planning for re-opening waterway.

Sector Upper Mississippi River Command Center (SCC) rcvd ntfn via vhf ch 16 from UTV GABRIEL J reporting a 4 barge breakaway at Missouri River (MOR) Mile Marker (MM) 43.9. The barges consist of  1 sand barge, 1 construction barge and 2 crane barges which were moored up river and broke free from their moorings. The cause of the breakaway is believed to be either the rapid rise (10ft) of the MOR or foul weather over night. SCC contacted Missouri Highway Patrol (MHP) and requested Missouri Department of Transportation on scene to evaluate bridge damage and close bridge if needed. UTV GABRIEL J is attempting to move the sand barge and the construction barge, but is restricted by horsepower. Gateway Dredging has been contacted by barge owner (Walsh Construction) and will be sending 2 UTV's to assist; ETA 1200L. All ntfn's made in accordance with the SCC ntfn's matrix.

SEC NOLA received a call from the EMS Express stating that he was trying to pass under the Dularge bridge in Houma, when he got himself twisted and allided with the bridge damaging a RED FLAG Barge; the KIM 3200, breaking a coupling, which he needs to fix.  There was no damage to the bridge or barge.  He was told to move out from under the bridge to not block traffic on the ICW

15 APR 14; 1015: UTV JASON LUHR is south bound on the Atchafalaya River near MM 30 pushing six loaded rock barges. Master reports that the barge L989 came in contact with the Melville Bridge. No damage to bridge confirmed by Melville Bridge tender. 

No damage, no pollution, no injuries reported.

On 16JAPR14 MSU Lake Charles duty Inspector received a phone call stating that the the first engineer of the Uninspected Towing Vessel suffered an injury to his cheek. The injury occurred when he was transporting two fire technicians from the towing vessel to the shore. While underway  the crew member maneuver the small boat to transit near the Black Bayou Bridge where a hook was dangling from the side of the bridge.  As the boat travel next to the bridge the fishing hook pierced his left cheek. The injury crewmember was taken to for medical treatment. Drug test was conducted in accordance with DOT regulations. No pollution, damage or hazard to navigation resulted from this incident,  Crewmember return to work the same day fit for full duty.

F/B IMT106 (Coal), under the control of the M/V LAINEY JONES, allided with the upper left descending protection cell of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Drawbridge (Also Known as the Lower Pekin Railroad Drawbridge) at mile marker 151.2 on the Illinois River. The M/V LAINEY JONES was heading south bound to Baton Rouge, LA pushing 11 barges (all loaded dry cargo) with the deepest draft in tow of 9ft. Operator attempted to make a controlled landing (however bridge tender was not notified of controlled landing) when F/B IMT-106 (Coal) allided with the protection cell harder than expected. No damage to bridge protection cell reported, however, F/B IMT- 106 sustained damage to the bow rake & #1 port wing tank and was taking on water.  Vessel crew able to dewater void and maintain void integrity using one pump and was transported to Logsdon fleet services, ILR MM 88.2, to conduct temporary repairs.  No pollution or injuries report.

At 1648Z UTV ROBERT FRANE went aground and subsequently broke up her tow causing an allision with the Harrahan Bridge at MM 734.8 LMR.  UTV reports 05 barges broke loose   The barges breaking loose allided with the Harahan R/R Bridge.

SLM CC received notification from Jeff Stabbler (fleet captain of Great lakes Towing)), that the inbound Freight Ship LUBIE made contact with a low hanging line from the scaffolding on the I-794 bridge (HOAN BRIDGE). Damage was sustained to the mast on board the LUBIE but no injuries or casualties were reported. No one was working on the scaffolding of the I-794 bridge involved in the marine casualty. The LUBIE was in ballast inbound to load grain.

On 3 April 2014 at approximately 1730 the UTV MISS LIS (O.N. 647237), pushing the deck barge CHICAGO BRIDGE in ballast condition, got its tow hawser wrapped in the starboard screw while reconfiguring the tow for entry into Mobile Bay. The entanglement of the screw caused the starboard engine to stall. The vessel anchored in location and awaited the assist vessel UTV HAWK (O.N. 1033239) to transfer the tow. The UTV MISS LIS continued to Mobile, AL for repairs after the transfer of their tow.

UTV Kelly Rae Erickson (Marquette Transportation, twin screws, 6200 HP)  transiting up bound with 28 dry cargo barges (no red flag) in tow, allided with the left descending pier of the Harahan R/R at MM 734. 6 LMR.  No damage/pollution/injuries reported.

On September 22, 2013 the UTV JONATHAN ERICKSON was pushing 15 loaded grain barges northbound on the Upper Mississippi River at mile marker 182.5 when the tow grounded resulting in broken tow wires and 15 adrift were barges. The 4 adrift barges allided with the McKinley Bridge.  No pollution or injuries occurred.

On April 27, 2014, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received a report from the Offshore Supply Vessel MATTHEW D MCRAE of a bridge allision. The vessel was traveling northbound approaching the Morgan City Bridges on the Atchafalaya River.  The mast of the vessel impacted the bottom of the bridge.  The mast of the vessel sustained damage, the bridge was undamaged. 

No pollution and no injuries were reported

Subject Name Vessel (SNV) reported that while transiting out of Dam # 1 on the Green River, they allided with the Spotsville Railroad Bridge located MM 8.3. SNV was pushing four loaded coal barges, no red flags. SNV ALLIDED with the RDB span of the bridge resulting in all four barges breaking away. Two barges are laying on the RDB, one on the LDB up against the bridge and one floated down river.  The two lead barges sustained damage that resulted in flooding of the bow on C 1244 and void # 4 on the C 807.  Both have been pumped out.  The tow has been made up and the vessel is transiting 6 miles downriver to the fleeting facility to off load and repair barges.

07 May 14; 2220:  UTV BRIAN O'DANIELS is transiting southbound with 02 red flag barges in tow loaded with crude oil. The port face wire on the barge broke approximately 800 feet from Melville Bridge while making a hard turn to port. The starboard side of barges FMT 3190 and FMT 3061 allided with the east span of the bridge. FMT 3190 sustained damage to the #5 port wing void. Barge FMT 3061 sustained damage to the starboard stern corner.

Inspection activity numbers: 4853524 and 4853609


No further injuries, damage, or pollution reported.  Case closed.

On April 22, 2014, the M/V BALTIMORE BRIDGE was transiting outbound from Long Beach Harbor when it experienced a loss of propulsion.  The vessel was towed to anchorage where the cause was determined to be water in the storage service tank.  Fuel was transferred from the starboard storage tank to generator service tank and the water in storage tank resulted in failure of #1,3,4 generators.   The crew stripped storage and service tanks of water and conducted satisfactory tests of all 4 generators with class in attendance.

The UTV BILL MILLER was south bound with 03 empty red flag barges at mile marker 46 on the Port Allen Route when the lead barge, the KIRBY 30407 allided with the Grosse Tete Bridge fender system; damaged 02 timbers on the fender system and bent walkway.  DIO and DMI attended vessel and discovered that additionally, once the vessel passed the bridge, it grounded near the Grosse Tete Canal; damaged its tiller arm for the starboard main steering.  Vessel was assisted to and repaired at Verret's Shipyard.   There were no damages to any of the barges.

No injuries or pollution reported.

Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities received notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River of UTV Lee Ann Ingram Allison with Sabula Rail Road bridge at Mile Marker 535 on Upper Mississippi River while pushing  15 barges (12 Dry Cargo Loads, 3 Red Flag Loads Caustic Soda) was northbound to St. Paul, MN.   Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities conducted a preliminary investigation and determined that there was no damage to the Tow boat and Barge Number ING-5824 made contact with 2 hand rail posts on the bridge pier which resulted in the hand rail posts being uprooted from the concrete.
