MSD QC recieved notification from SUMR CC of M/V C. MICHAEL REEVES alliding with Sabula RR bridge at mm 535 on UMR.   C. MICHAEL REEVES was upbound with 15 loaded coal barges when the winds pushed his stbd lead barge into the protection cell, damaging fence boards and piling. Bridge tender stated they will be sending people down at first light for further inspection. There is no reported D/P/I to the tow, and pilot stated he had ntfd bridge of possible controlled landing prior to transitting. MSD Quad Cities was ntfd for follow up phonecon.  MSD QC IO followed up and verified the condition of the vessel and bridge.  All sat.

Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities received notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River of M/V Capt H. R. Kirtley Allison with Sabula Rail Road bridge at Mile Marker 535 on Upper Mississippi River.   Capt H. R. Kirtley was down bound with 4 loaded liquid cargo barges when they rubbed against the bridge. Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities conducted a preliminary investigation and determined that there was no damage to vessel and bridge.

19MAY14: MSD Quad Cities Duty Petty Officer recieved call from UTV M/V WASHINGTON, who stated they rubbed the sheer fence of the Sabula Railroad Bridge while transiting Southbound with 6 loaded grain barges.  The vessel was using the assist tug WILLIAM E. LAWSON IAW the current MSIB.  No damage reported by the bridge or the vessel. Duty IO responded on scene to verify condition of RR Bridge and vessel.

06JUN14: M/V C. MICHAEL REEVES transiting southbound with 12 loaded dry cargo barges from St. Paul, MN to St. Louis, MO.  While transiting the Sabula RR Bridge, vessel made contact with the upper shear fence of the bridge with the third barge in the starboard string.  No damages reported by vessel or bridge, vessel continued on voyage.  Vessel was in compliance with current BNM issued for the area.  No d/p/i.  Phone investigation conducted by MSD QC IO, requested 2692 within 5 days.

On May 06, 2014 at approximately 0600, the 64ft, steel hulled UTV WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE (O.N. 638901) struck the Little River Swing Bridge located on the Intracoastal Waterway (ICW) in Little River, SC. The UTV WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE destroyed the fender system located on the Northbound (East) side of the ICW. UTV WILIAM BRECKENRIDGE was pushing ahead 3 barges from Charleston, SC to Norfolk, VA. The South Carolina Department of Transportation was notified by the Little River Swing Bridge attendant, and DDO Myrtle Beach was notified by the Sector Charleston Command Center.

Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities received notification from Coast Guard Sector Upper Mississippi River that the UTV Jonathan Erickson lost steering and subsequently allided with Canadian National Railroad Bridge at Mile Marker 579.9 on Upper Mississippi River while pushing 9 barges northbound.  Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities conducted a preliminary investigation and subsequent on scene response. It was determined that there was no reportable property damage to the Tow boat or the barges. The Canadian National Railroad Bridge remained functional and a property damage estimate was provided to Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities.
17JUN2014 - Tug ANGER MANAGEMENT pushing empty deck barge 226 ZITO allided with the South Causeway Bridge in Ft. Pierce, FL.

Sector received a report of the Towing Vessel Inland Cardinal struck the piling on the north side westbound just before the fendering system of the Highway 98 bridge ( Fort Walton Beach Bridge ).  The vessel sustained no significant damage the dredge pipe being towed caused the damage to the bridge fendering system that was estimated to be 30k. No injuries and no pollution reported.

On June 24, 2014, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Houma received notification that the Uninspected Towing Vessel DARI LYNN allided with the West Larose Bridge.  The DARI LYNN was pushing 05 uninspected hopper barges transiting northbound near mile-marker 35 on Intra-coastal Waterway at time of the incident.

No damage was reported to the vessels or bridge.

No pollution or personnel injuries were reported.

On June 26, 2014, the M/V CHICAGO BRIDGE was inbound to the Port of Long Beach when the vessel experienced a loss of propulsion.  The ship was operating on auxiliary generators #1 and #2 with an approximate load of 1000KW.  In preparation for Pilot maneuvering and the added electrical demand from the bow thruster (2000KW), auxiliary generator #4 was brought online.  During the start up of auxiliary generator #4 the 3rd engineer failed to follow procedure by not opening the fuel valve.  Subsequently, the #4 generator failed and the added load of the bow thruster caused the #1 and #2 generator's circuit breaker to trip and the vessel to be without power for approximately 4 minutes.  The fuel valve was closed and power was restored.  The vessel continued its transit and moored up safely.

MSU Pittsburgh received a report that the M/V PRINCESS (668036) had lost propulsion with 171 persons onboard. The vessel was transiting upbound the Allegheny River near the Veterans Bridge. While adrift the crew attempted to anchor the vessel but at the same time allided with the Veterans Bridge. Minor injuries were reported to a few passengers and Pittsburgh River Rescue went onboard to provide treatment. The vessel was towed back to the dock by the M/V Duchess without further incidents. The incident was due to a loss of air pressure for the control system. The main air compressor pump overheated and failed to turn on. When the secondary air compressor was insufficient in size and unable to replenish the lost air to allow the vessel to continue to operate.

22 JUL 2014 The UTV GOLDEN EAGLE was downbound with 15 loaded dry cargo barges. The starboard facing wires broke while making the approach to the Louisiana Railroad Bridge, Mile Marker 282.1. The Captain attempted to back down and stop barges from breaking away. The tow swung toward the left descending bank and allided with the bridge protection cells. Multiple barges got stuck under the bridge and along the northern side of the bridge. The swing bridge is unable to close because of the barges. Multiple vessels are enroute to assist with the removal. Damage to multiple barges has been reported.
UTV, while underway with no cargo, allided with the Arthur Kill Railroad bridge within the Port of New York & New Jersey.

The M/V ALL SWELL (O.N. 1052208) was towing a banana boat with 10 passengers on the vessel and 10 on the banana boat.  The Captain of the vessel turned his vessel to starboard, making the banana boat turn to port and onto the vessel's wake.  Due to the speed the wake made the banana boat eject the passengers and two female subjects on board the banana boat sustained injuries when they collided with each other. The two females were taken to the hospital.  One female suffered a laceration to her face requiring 53 stitches and the other a head concussion, and neck and back pain. No other incidents were reported to the USCG.

On 13Aug2014, at approximately 2354, the UTV CORY MICHAEL pushing crane barge BBCCI 901.012 allided with the Florida Ave lift bridge at mile seven on the Inner Harbor Navigational Canal.  As the CORY MICHAEL was attempting to pass under the bridge, the mast boom of the crane aboard the barge made contact with the center portion of the bridge causing the collapse of the working boom onto the elevated wheel house of the UTV CORY MICHAEL where the master was operating the vessel. The allision resulted in the death of the master, $55K in damage to the vessel $2.3M in damage to the crane and the loss of nearly 322,000 lbs of steel crane counterweight into the canal beneath the bridge. This casualty meets the criteria for a Major Marine Casualty and CG-INV was notified. NTSB participated in this investigation.

As a result of our investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this incident was negligent operations by bridge tender and by the master. There were several subsequent events including drug use and inadequate oversight of the bridge. A Report of Investigation was completed and is attached as Correspondence.
UTV JEFFREY G pushing 25 loaded hoppers down bound at MM 43.7 UMR when the tow struck the right descending pier of the Thebes R/R Bridge causing barges to break away.

On 17 September 2014, at approximately 1824, the FORT MACON (O.N. 574395) was pushing the SWB 2 (O.N. 1224918) when the SWB 2 began taking on water prior to partially sinking and grounding outside of the main navigation channel on the Elizabeth River.  Further investigation revealed that the SWB 2 was a former Navy Warping Tug that the marine employer was utilizing as a deck barge to transfer equipment to and from a worksite.  At the time of flooding and sinking, the SWB 2 was being pushed stern first, which sits lower in the water than the SWB 2's bow due to the placement of twin jet-drive engines.  In addition to the SWB 2 being pushed stern first, the SWB 2's deck plate/hatch covers were not secured or appropriately dogged down in place.  While the covers were closed, they were not sealed tight and allowed water that was washing over the vessel's deck to enter the void and engine spaces.  The SWB 2 was successfully refloated and underwent repairs at the McLean contracting yard in Chesapeake, Virginia.  

It is recommended that this activity be closed and referred to enforcement.
On 01 OCT 2014 UTV THE DELTA, towing Barge CRIMSON CLOVER, allided with the fender system of the Chickasaw Railroad Bridge. No damage was reported to the bridge or vessel.

On September 25th, 2014, MSU Houma CDO received a notification via cell phone call from Terrebonne Parish Sheriff's department water patrol officer.  He reported an allision involving M/V MR. ALAN (ON: 1040047) and Dulac Pontoon bridge on the Houma Navigation Canal, MM 23.1.

No personnel injuries, no pollution, no damage to the vessel. The Dulac Pontoon Bridge was unable to open for approximately 2 hours due to repairs being completed.  The bridge was also unable to allow vehicle traffic over the bridge during this time.

The motor vessel ALAMO (1247382, 2000hp, Harley Marine) pushing 2 red flag barges (2x1 config, ultra low sulfur diesel) heading down bound mile marker 1.3 Upper Mississippi River struck the 2nd pier from the right descending bank of the Cairo Bridge (LLNR 17665) due to loss of steering. The lead barge Professor Karen Ann Brown (1252855) suffered a 2.5-3' dent on the stbd stern quarter from hitting the bridge.The aft barge Kolachi (1251936) sustained damage to the stern void from hitting the bridge, the damage is not visible, it is below the water line.  No pollution or injuries.

At approximately 0147 EST on November 19, 2014, the uninspected towing vessel WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE (638901) was underway on the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway while towing astern the barge ENDEAVOR and 500 feet of dredge pipes with the assist of the tug HILTON HEAD (attached to the tail end of the pipes). The WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE was transiting through the Onslow Beach Swing Bridge when the port quarter of the barge ENDEAVOR allided with the fendering system of the bridge. The allision caused the barge to bounce from the fendering system and the dredge pipes (that were on a series of pontoons) continued heading towards the fendering system. The port pontoon ended up alliding with the fendering system which caused the hawser to snap on the leading edge of the dredge pipe. The master of the WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE was notified about the allision by the bridge tender, who immediately informed the master of the HILTON HEAD. The HILTON HEAD broke loose from the tail end of the dredge pipes and proceeded towards the front of the dredge pipes. Subsequently, the HILTON HEAD reattached a tow line to the dredge pipes and pulled them away from the fendering system and through the bridge. The WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE waited south of the bridge for the HILTON HEAD to bring the dredge pipes and reattached to the barge ENDEAVOR. The WILLIAM BRECKENRIDGE and tow continued with its route towards New River Inlet without further incidents. There were no damages to the barge ENDEAVOR and pontoons; however there were damages to the walkway and fendering system of the bridge. The official report from a Project Analyst from Camp Lejeune informed that the repairs were estimated at approximately $41,000.

Sector Honolulu received notification that an elderly passenger with pre-existing medical conditions onboard the STAR PRINCESS had died as a result of cardiac arrest.

This investigation was downgraded to data collection in accordance with the Marine Safety Manual, volume 5, section B.7.A.2.b (natural cause).

On December 11, 2014, the M/V BELLE OF CINCINNATI was towing the USS NIGHTMARE (Craft Routinely Operated Dockside), the WHITE BARGE (Craft Routinely Operated Dockside) and the P/B NO. 4 to the McGinnis Mooring cells at mile marker 480 on the Ohio River. B B Riverboats intended to moor the USS NIGHTMARE and the WHITE BARGE at the mooring cells in a care taker status until the next seasonal operation of the craft in the fall of 2015. The UTV SHIRLEY B was assisting in the tow.  As the tow package approached the Cincinnati Southern Railroad Bridge on the Ohio River, mile marker 472.3, the M/V BELLE OF CINCINNATI was caught by the wind and current and subsequently was set on the Ohio bridge pier. The WHITE BARGE allided with the Ohio side bridge pier on the starboard side bow. The impact caused the tow package to split in two with the M/V BELLE OF CINCINNATI and the USS NIGHTMARE drifting towards the left descending bank (Kentucky Side) and the UTV SHIRLEY B and WHITE BARGE drifting towards the right descending bank (Ohio Side).  Upon impact, the P/B NO. 4 broke away and was set adrift.  The UTV MAC MCGINNIS was transiting the area, saw the allision and rendered assistance. The UTV MAC MCGINNIS secured the P/B NO. 4 and assisted the UTV SHIRLEY B, P/B NO. 4 and the WHITE BARGE back to B B Riverboat's docks located in Newport, KY.

On 06 January 2015 at approximately 0845 the UTV Cooper Devall (O.N. 1254288) was pushing two red flagged barges containing the product Adiponitrile (ADN) southbound on the Tombigbee River at Mile Marker 174 with the river running high. The PILOT was preparing to navigate the tow pass the Naheolaa RR Bridge. The PILOT approached approximately 200 feet above the bridge but the current shoved the lead barge EIDC 70 (CG 000322) stern into the west pillar of the RR Bridge. The PILOT attempted to throttle up but the current impeded the attempt.  The crew checked the barge and noted flooding in the #3 starboard voids. The crew controlled the flooding with a pump and the company dispatched additional pumps to assist. Damaged assessed to the EIDC 70 was located in the starboard #2 wingtank aft bulkhead with adjacent bottom and deck plating distorted. Additionally the #3 wingtank had numerous fractures. Company had the barge EIDC 70 repaired at James Marine (see Activity 5066124). Estimated repair costs  to barge were $95,000.00.  Divers checked the Bridge and noted no damage from the allision. Drug and Alcohol tests were administered.

SLM CC received notification from operator of UTV Windy City (ON 61279), stating that at 0230 CST, the vessel was transiting under the Conrail Eight Track Railroad Bridge, when the radar touched the cross beam on the bridge, causing a small dent in the radar receiver, not requiring repair.  The company had a technician come out to the vessel and verified the radar functioned correctly.

23 JAN 15; 0125: The UTV MARI LAMPTON is S/B on the MCPAAR/GIWW pushing (3) loaded asphalt barges, when the master receives a call from the Bayou Sorrel Swing Bridge Tender, notifying him that the tow made contact with the fendering system.

While transiting down bound with six empty barges, the UTV David L Fields tow lightly struck the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Bridge at MM287.5 on the Illinois River.  The cause of the incident was wind gusts that affected the handling of the tow. Neither the barge, AGS-818, or the bridge protection cell sustained any damage.

ACTEUR received notification that at 0549 on 22 February 2015 the outbound U.S. Flagged ST LOUIS EXPRESS and the inbound Panama Flagged HAMMERSMITH BRIDGE collided while transiting the Westerschelde river in the vicinity of Hansweert, Netherlands. The HAMMERSMITH BRIDGE sustained damage to her port side and the ST LOUIS EXPRESS sustained damage to her port quarter. Chemical tests were administered for all mariners. After viewing the VTS video, the HAMMERSMITH BRIDGE pilot recognized his error and admitted to being in the middle of the channel. During certan tidal conditionsspring, a river condition exists creating a clockwise current located at the intersection of the Zuider Gat and the Schaar Van Valkenisse. This coincides with a particularly dangerous bend in the river and subsequently where the collision occurred. It is important to note, at no time before, during, or after the collision did either pilot communicate with the other. Although there was communication with the vessel traffic serivce, this service did not direct either vessel to make navigational corrections before the accident.

On the afternoon of March 04, 2015, the ice flow damn on the Youghiogheny River broke free sending a mass of ice and other debris down the Monongahela River. The river current also increased dramatically as the excess water on the Youghiogheny flowed into the Monongahela.  At approximately 1745 the mass of ice struck the Duquesne Coal Dock barge fleeting area, left descending bank MM 11.65, Monongahela River, causing 18 empty coal barges to break away from their mooring cells. 17 of the barges allided with the Conrail Railroad Bridge and 01 barges allided with the lower fleeting area pushing against the loaded coal barge fleet. The one barge that allided with the lower fleeting area was secured undamaged without further incident. Barge MRT 1923, owned by Murray American River Towing, was in the back left row of the 17 barges when they allided with the Conrail Railroad Bridge. The barge bent partially around the bridge pier causing significant structural damage to the barge.  Barge MRT 1923 sank while wedged between the bridge pier and the rest of the barges. Murray American Towing stated that the barge will be scrapped. Barge MRT 1966, also owned by Murray American Towing, was next to barge MRT 1923 and sustained hull damage from rubbing against the sunken MRT 1923. The barges were secured together in 2 rows of 8 and 1 barge secured off the left row heading down river when the allision occurred. No other barges were reported damaged during this incident.

On 09MAR15, at approximately 0350, the UTV Cailey Moore was repositioning 15 jumbo loaded coal barges within the Murray West Elizabeth barge fleeting facility when the current broke the barges away fom the # 4 mooring cell. The barges were secured together in 3 rows of 5. The barges floated to the opposite side of the river  hitting the right decending bank.The barges floated back to the left decending bank alliding with the facilities empty barge fleeting area. This broke 2 empty hopper barges free from the fleet which were recovered by another towing vessel without incident. The remaining barges then floated down river alliding with the Route 51 Bridge's right decending pier. No damage was caused to the bridge. The group of barges continued to swing around and allided with the empty fleeted barges again. Between alliding with the bridge and alliding with the fleeted barges the group started to break in half. 3 barges broke away from the group and were shoved to the left descending pier below the bridge. A single barge that broke from the group allided with with three barges causing them to all break free. Two of them were secured quickly and the other two continued down river to strike the lower empty fleet causing a jumbo empty barge to break free. The barges were later secured by an assisting vessel with out incident. The remaining barges were all gathered and secured without incident.

Received phone call from representative for the TUG Navigator. Initial report was that TUG NAVIGATOR experienced temporary steering casualty which caused the barge in tow SAN JUAN JAX BRIDGE to jack-knife causing the 2nd mate on board to cut his lip and suffer from a bruised thigh. Another injury was also suffered by the A/B seaman who was in the mess deck who suffered a bruise hip/thigh.

On March 20, 2015, at approximately 1100, the towing vessel DAUNTLESS II (O.N. 266552) was transiting southbound on the Elizabeth River while pushing an undocumented crane barge.  When the Captain attempted to  navigate the vessels under the Interstate 64 High Rise Bridge, the top of the barge's forward spud, which was approximately 80 feet high, allided with the bottom of the bridge, which has a vertical clearance of 65 feet.  There was no damage to the tug or barge, and the bridge sustained only superficial damage.  There were no injuries or pollution.

At approximately 0430 EST on March 22, 2015, the fishing vessel REELS OF FORTUNE (O.N. 924655) was transiting outbound on the Oregon Inlet when the starboard side of the vessel allided with a support column of the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge. The incident occurred as the operator maneuvered the vessel away from the main span of the bridge (due to shoaling) and decided to transit on deeper water through a different span of the bridge (around 11-14 span), however a strong current took the vessel closer to a support column. The operator continued with its voyage without further incidents. There were no injuries or pollution found during this investigation. The vessel suffered minor superficial damage (scratches) on the starboard side. 

During the course of the investigation it was found that on August 15, 2014, the operator, who holds a merchant mariner's credential, had been convicted of an offense that would prevent the issuance of a credential (DWI-Motor Boat/Vessel). CG Investigating Officer referred case to enforcement.

On April 1, 2015, at approximately 0540, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received notification of an allision between a barge being pushed by the Uninspected Towing Vessel Capt Pete and the Morgan City Railroad Bridge in Morgan City, LA.  The barge, HTCO 3086, is reported to have minor damage to the #4 and #5 port voids.  

No injuries or pollution was reported.

UTV JAMES J. PERERA allided with the I 155 Bridge in Caruthersville at MM 838.8 LMR while heading downbound pushing 3 loads of crude oil (red flags). The investigation revealed that the pilot was being set to the right descending pier, so he began steering toward the left descending back.  However, his attempt was not successful as he stuck the starboard pilling of the bridge.  There was damage to all 3 barges.

STA Atlantic City received a call from the operator of the Margate bridge that a crane cable snagged on the bridge while the trident marine pushboat and uninspected barge was transiting under the bridge.  There was damage to the crane and no damage to the bridge.  The pushboat and barge completed its transit and safely moored.  There were no personnel injuries or pollution.

On 8 April 2015, the uninspected hopper barge ART 35179 (VIN 1225264), towed by the UTV ALEX D (VIN 1231404), hit a fender at the Dularge Bridge at ICW MM 59.9. The ART 35179 was carrying aluminum sulfate, no release of contents.

The UTV  approached the Arthur Kill Bridge and seeing the bridge closed to vessel traffic, remained on the north side of the bridge to lower its antennas.  After waiting for several minutes and with the bridge still closed, the vessel transited under the bridge, however, the fiberglass VHF antenna that had remained in the up position struck the underside of the bridge.  No damage was reported and there were no injuries.

On May 3, 2015, Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Houma received notification that the UTV MISS ELIZABETH was towing a derrick barge, the DB RAFORD, astern and allided with the Houma Navigation Bridge.  Master claimed the current pushed the barge into the west fender of the bridge.

On May 12, 2015 at approximately 0635, the UTV BIG EDDIE was underway from MM 8 on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway (GIWW) northbound enroute to MM 2.8 GIWW when the vessel allided with the Lapalco Bridge at MM 3.0 GIWW. The UTV BIG EDDIE was a 66 foot in length towing vessel managed by Crosby Marine Transportation, LLC equipped with a hydraulic wheelhouse. When the hydraulic wheelhouse was fully retracted with the mast down, the vertical height of the vessel was 42 feet and 4 inches. The deckhand onboard the UTV BIG EDDIE extended the hydraulic wheelhouse approximately 6 feet on May 11, 2015 to paint the deck of the lower wheelhouse. The hydraulic wheelhouse was left extended overnight to allow the paint to dry. The master failed to verify the hydraulic wheelhouse was fully retracted prior to getting underway the morning of May 12, 2015. The approximate vertical height of the UTV BIG EDDIE at the time of the incident was 48 feet and 4 inches. The Lapalco Bridge was a bascule bridge manned by a tender 24 hours a day 7 days a week. The vertical clearance beneath the Lapalco Bridge the morning of the incident was 45 feet. The UTV BIG EDDIE's hydraulic wheelhouse allided with the Lapalco Bridge when the vessel attempted to pass beneath bridge.

The Lapalco Bridge sustained damage to the navigational lights and grated catwalk on the south side of the bridge. The hydraulic system and stanchions for the UTV BIG EDDIE's hydraulic wheelhouse were significantly damaged and placed the vessel out of service until adequate repairs could be completed. No Lapalco Bridge employees, UTV BIG EDDIE crewmembers or other personnel were injured as a result of this casualty.

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that this incident was a result of human error and inaction on the part of multiple parties. It was deemed that the inactions of both the Lapalco Bridge tender and vessel operator were causal factors in this incident.

Ellender Bridge HWY 27:
 MSU Lake Charles received a report that the outriggers on the F/V DORA MAY allided with the Ellender Bridge while heading Westbound. Fishing Vessel was reported to be listing to one side. No reported damage to bridge.

Following the report of the DORA MAE (O/N: 5955875) alliding with the Ellender Bridge on Highway 27, MSU Lake Charles contacted the USCG Fishing Vessel Examiner from MSU Port Arthur to request assistance since the vessel was west bound and transiting into the MSU Port Arthur area of responsibility.  The MSU Port Arthur Fishing Vessel Examiner and a MSU Port Arthur Marine Casualty Investigator visited the vessel and conducted a post-casualty investigation and a fishing vessel exam. During the investigation portion the Captain of the DORA MAE denied hitting the Ellender Bridge and stated that any damage to the vessel occurred as a result of normal operations and the rigors of fishing. Although the Marine Casualty Investigator took pictures of the damage it could not be articulated/proven that the damage was the result of alliding with the bridge (no viable evidence to prove the allision actually occurred).  

Additionally, during the fishing vessel exam the MSU Port Arthur Fishing Vessel Examiner discovered 14 safety deficiencies onboard the DORA MAE; this resulted in the issuance of COTP Order 2015-109 (see MISLE Activity #: 5130577) directing the vessel to remain moored until all deficiencies were corrected.

Utilizing the information provided by MSU Port Arthur, MSU Lake Charles marine casualty investigators continued the investigation but were unable to find evidence (other than the initial report) to prove that the DORA MAE allided with the Ellender Bridge.

Sector Saint Petersburg received notification from the master of the uninspected towing vessel MISS KRISSY concerning a bridge allision with the Cortez Bridge.  The master reported the MISS KRISSY, pushing the barge M-1403, became offset while transiting under the Cortez Bridge resulting in the port quarter of the M-1403 contacting the Cortez Bridge fender system.  The fender system walkway sustained displaced sections of wood resulting from the allision; there was no structural damage to the fender system or barge. The walkway was subsequently nailed back into place. No injuries, pollution or waterway obstructions were attributed to this marine casualty.

On 13 May 2015 at approximately 0145 the UTV HERITAGE (O.N. 240322) was transiting W/B in the ICWW near mile marker 188 pushing ahead four empty barges and one loaded barge. The Master stated he had experienced a heavy wind causing the forward left barge, PEN 119 (O.N. 955959) to allide with the Bob Sykes Bridge's wooden fendering system. The Master stated the Range Lights on the bridge were also out. The Master and crew were able to free the port rake on the bow from the bridge's fendering system and secure the tow. The initial call came from a witness to the allision and USCG Station Pensacola was dispatched to check the damage. USCG Station Pensacola arrived on scene to confirm damage and noted the only vessel in the area was the UTV HERITAGE. USCG personnel conducted a 4100 Boarding and field sobriety tests on the crew of the UTV HERITAGE. The Pilot (Relief Captain) on board did not pass the field sobriety test (had not reported to scheduled watch on time so not on bridge at time of incident). Another crewmember had an outstanding warrant and was transferred to the local Police Department. The UTV HERITAGE was allowed to dock at the Port of Pensacola after the COTP terminated voyage (reference Activity Number 5124821). Owners of barges arranged to have another company transport. Damage to the barge PEN 119 estimated to be $30,000 and $20, 000 estimated to repair the fendering system on the Bob Sykes Bridge. Bridge was examined by FLDOT and was found to be structurally sound with no damage noted.

The UTV JILL HARVEY was downbound with 3 loaded dry cargo barges. The lead barge lightly allided with the right fendering system on the Florence highway bridge. No damage reported from the bridge or the barge.

On June 02, 2015, at approximately 0335, the commercial fishing vessel (CFV) HANNAH BODEN (O.N. 661284) was transiting outside of the north auxiliary channel of the Thimble Shoals Channel in the vicinity of Lighted Gong Buoy No. 8 (FI R 2.5s) (LLRN #9240) by the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel.  The vessel's recorded draft was 6.5 feet forward, 13.1 feet midship and 10 feet aft.   While approaching the second island of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel, the starboard midship side of the vessel ran aground on the protective rocks surrounding the island in a charted depth of 6 feet.  The vessel was refloated at approximately 0600.   No injuries, structural damage, flooding, or pollution resulted from this marine casualty  Drug and alcohol testing were conducted.

On the evening of July 4, 2015 at approximately 2126 Eastern Daylight Savings Time, a rented 24 foot pontoon boat (GERALD, KY0704UG) was traveling down-river with nine persons on board.  The vessel was transiting the area near the I-65 northbound bridge construction project, Ohio River mile marker (MM) 603; it was between the Big Four Pedestrian Bridge and the I-65/Kennedy Bridge.  The operator attempted to make a turn near tower #5 of the bridge construction project, when he attempted this maneuver the vessel allided (a collision with a fixed object) with the bridge pier footer.  The allision involved the port side of the vessel and the up-river side of the pier footer.  The current caused the vessel to become pinned against the bridge pier footer.  The operator asked his passengers to assist in freeing the vessel by pushing the vessel away from the bridge pier footer.  The vessel then slid astern by-way of propulsion or river current and allided with a moored spud barge, KS 395 (CG1355250).  When the vessel allided with the barge, the port stern became wedged under the raked bow of the barge, the vessel then capsized.  The operator directed the adult passengers to get all the children off onto the barge; three children were able to board the barge, six other passengers went into the water.  One adult male was able to climb onto the barge while the other five persons were missing, of those five other persons there were two children and three adults.  When the vessel began its voyage and departed the marina, it was stocked with personal floatation devices (life jackets).  Two passengers, children under the age of 12, were wearing personal floatation devices in accordance with state and federal regulations.  It cannot be confirmed if the personal floatation devices were correctly fastened or the proper size.  All victims were recovered over a three day period; none were recovered with personal floatation devices on their person and all were deceased.  One of the recovered victims was under the age of 12; all of the recovered personal floatation devices were CG approved TYPE II (adult) and TYPE III (children).

As a result of this investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the I-65 northbound bridge pier footer known as tower #5, caused by the operator's decision to make a turn to port instead of starboard.  This was followed by the allision with a moored work barge and eventual capsizing of the vessel.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include; (1) the river state, (2) the experience of the operator, (3) the vessels load and engine size, and (4) personal protective equipment.

UTV GOLDEN EAGLE while transiting down bound pushing 24 loaded dry cargo and 1 empty red flag in a 5L by 5W configuration with a deep draft of 10ft. Pilot was making the approach to the Thebes RR Bridge bridge span when he was set by the 5 mph river currents at MM 43.7 UMR. Pilot misjudged the speed of the set and became misaligned with the main channel span. The pilot attempted to correct the set but the stbd stern barge CC -9920 allided with the RDB pier, causing connecting tow wires to part and set a block of 20 barges adrift.  The allision also caused damage to the stern void of the CC-9920, allowing flooding of the void.  The flooding caused the stern of the CC-9920 to partially sink outside the main channel with the bow visible above the waterline.  The remaining barges were corraled and returned to tow.  

Coast Guard investigation determined the initiating event to be the allision with the RDB pier of the Thebes RR bridge located at MM 43.7 Upper Mississippi River. Contributing factor include 1) Swift river current in excess of 4-5 mph at MM 43.7 UMR; and 2) Pilot error, misjudging the speed and set of the river current.

Incident did not exceed the criteria ($200,000 in property damage) in the D8 Mission Prioritization Guidance.  The level of investigation was descoped to a data collection level due to manpower constraints, lack of qualified investigators and competing mission priorities.

On June 30, 2015, at approximately 2020, SANDY DRAKE pushing ten open hopper barges, each carrying coal departed Markland Lock and Dam at MM 531.5 on the Ohio River on an upbound transit to MM 444 on the Ohio River. Barge C 466 was the #2 port barge in a 2 wide by 5 long tow arrangement, measuring 1068 feet combined with the towboat. The seven member crew of the SANDY DRAKE was made up of two USCG licensed Masters of Towing Vessels, and five non-credential Deckhands. 

On July 1, 2015, the Ohio River was 10 feet above the projected pool 27ft and a river current of 5 mph. At approximately 1340 at MM 493.3 the SANDY DRAKE approached the I- 275 Bridge from along the left descending bank of the Ohio River, the master conducted an assessment of present navigational hazardous and environment conditions before transiting the I-275 Bridge. The master executed a plan based on experience to transit the narrower horizontal span (outer span) of the bridge. The master plotted the head of the tow to pass through the outer span of the bridge.   

At approximately 1410, the #2 port barge allided with the Kentucky span's pier of the I-275 Bridge, at MM 491.6 on the Ohio River. Barge C 466 sustained minor cosmetic damage on the portside rub rail. The allision resulted in estimated vessel damage of $2100. The Kentucky Transportation Cabinet (bridge administration) reported no damage to the bridge.

As a result of its investigation, Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was vessel navigation error. This was followed by the subsequent allision of C 466 with the Kentucky span pier of the I-275 Bridge.

SLM CC received notification from the master; UTV William C pushing 01 scrap metal barge experienced loss of steering due to a ruptured hydraulic hose.  The tug and barge drifted over to dock near the Amtrak Railroad Bridge. There was minor damage to the dock and hydraulic oil had spilled into the Chicago River South Branch but was a small amount.

The foreign vessel bound for berth  reported to have struck the Arthur Kill Railroad Bridge with its Inmarsat C Antenna.  There was no damage to the bridge, no injuries no pollution but there was damage to the vessel's Inmarsat C Antenna.

On 15 JULY2015 the UTV LEONARD WHITTINGTON was heading northbound through the LOUISANA RR Bridge and rubbed the protection fence with barge RF809B which was the 3rd barge from the UTV portside. No damage reported to bridge or barge.

UTV GEORGE W JONES underway pushing 9 empty hoppers upbound at MM 57.7 KAN when the port stern barge made contact with the right descending pier of the I-64 Fort Hill Bridge. UTV GEORGE W JONES reports no damage, injury or pollution. WV Dept of Highways inspected bridge and found no damage.

UTV SARAH HUNTER (Hunter Marine, 602461, 3600HP) reported while departing the fleeting area MM 787 OHR LDB pushing 15 loaded coal barges (3X5 config) the UTVs 2nd barge in the port string (Crounse 799) allided with the LDB land pier of the US 41 upper bridge (LLNR 27505) MM 786.8 OHR LDB. The allision caused wire damage; no injuries, further damage or pollution reported.

The UTV WAYNE P LAGRANGE was downbound pushing a 12 barge loaded tow (all dry cargo). While still above the Beardstown RR Bridge, at approximately MM 92, the Pilot (relief captain) requested, via VHF channel 16, an opening of the bridge. The bridge is located at MM 88.9 on the Illinois River and has a single horizontal channel lift span. The bridge cannot be visually observed from the Bridge Tender's office, approximately a mile away. The Bridge Tender’s Office has two desks: one containing the bridge control console (containing the bridge control box, VHF radio, video feed, and RADAR) and one containing all of the Internal Yard Train and Maintenance Controller equipment for carrying out those responsibilities. While sitting at one desk, the Bridge Tender has his or her back to the other desk.

The Bridge Tender flipped the bridge opening switch on the bridge control console (also called the bridge control box) to the "open" position and radioed the vessel that "the bridge was on the way up". The bridge’s channel lift span did not completely open, it only opened approx ¾ of the way. The Bridge Tender never verified (via the video monitor or the bridge control console lights) that the bridge’s channel lift span actually opened all the way.

When the UTV WAYNE P LAGRANGE got closer to the bridge, the Pilot realized that the bridge was not fully open but was unable to stop the vessel’s forwarded momentum (due to the strong river current and the vessel's speed) and it allided with the bridge’s channel lift span.  All of the vessel's navigational, lighting, and electronic equipment atop the vessel's pilothouse was sheared off.

The reason the bridge only partially opened was due to the tripping of a bridge seat electrical relay which is located on the bridge itself and senses that the bridge is fully open (seated).  After the allision, the bridge seat relay was reset and the bridge functioned normally. The cause of the bridge seat relay failure (tripping) was never determined. The vessel pushed in below the bridge, and after temporary repairs were made, was allowed to continue its transit.

On 16 JUL 2015, at approximately 1500, the UTV DANNY BRADFORD was underway down bound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) near mile marker 180.  While pushing two loaded hopper barges, the upper pilothouse of the DANNY BRADFORD struck worker occupied scaffolding located underneath the center span of the Eads Bridge.  Weather conditions at the time of the allision consisted of overcast skies with winds at 7 knots, gusting to 11 knots, from the south/southwest.  The UMR in the area of St. Louis, MO was in extreme high water  with the UMR St. Louis gauge, located at the Eads Bridge, reading approximately 33 feet and falling.  

The Eads Bridge was completed in July 1874 and was designed with a center span width of 517 feet between bridge piers. This center span serves as the primary channel for river traffic.  The vertical clearance at the center of the main span is normally 88.6 feet minus the reading of the UMR St. Louis gauge. Due to the curved design, a decreasing vertical clearance away from the center follows the supporting steelwork as it curves downward towards each supporting bridge pier.  Due to extreme high water on 16 JUL 2015, and with the presence of scaffolding added under the bridge, the vertical clearance at the center of the main arch was approximately 54.8 feet decreasing to about one foot at the bridge piers.  

Undergoing a long term maintenance project that began in 2012, this project involved worker occupied enclosed scaffolding that extended downward under the bridge.  The project site was an Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulated workplace, while navigation safety issues specific to the bridge maintenance project were regulated by the Eighth Coast Guard District Western Rivers Bridge Branch.  The intent of the conditions issued by the Eighth District Western Rivers Bridge Branch was to limit vessel traffic horizontally on the water whereby traffic would remain centered in the middle 300 feet of the center span.  

On 16 JUL 2015, at approximately 1400, the DANNY BRADFORD with two hopper barges loaded with petroleum coke, departed Beelman River Terminal located at mile 182.3 UMR left descending bank (LDB), heading southbound to Buzzi St. Louis Dock at mile 176 UMR right descending bank (RDB).  Approximately 2000 feet upbound of the Eads Bridge, the master of the DANNY BRADFORD realized the vessel and barges were not lined up correctly to pass under the middle 300 feet of the center span and began backing and steering to try to correct the approach but without success.  As a result, the vessel passed under the Eads Bridge outside of the middle 300 foot navigational opening intended for vessel traffic.  As there was not enough vertical clearance to pass under the bridge outside of this window, the pilothouse of the DANNY BRADFORD struck the scaffolding at the same spot a bridge maintenance worker was located resulting in immediate death to the worker.

On 17 July 2015 at approx. 16:30 the UTV CARL CANNON was southbound on the Illinois River mile 56 when the hopper barge ACL 9728 B struck the right descending protection cell of the Florence Hwy Bridge.  The hopper barge ACL 9728 B was slightly damaged.  the was no damage to the bridge.

While transiting north bound on the Upper Mississippi River, a UTV caring 4 barges loaded with UAM allided with the La Crosse Rail Road Bridge.  The allision resulted in minor scrapes to the barge and possible splintering to the protection cell of the bridge.  USCG inspectors were on scene the next day and observed minor scrapes to the barge and no flooding, pollution or internal damage to the barge.

On July 29, 2015 at approximately 2015 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel NEPTUNE (O.N. 981971) was towing astern the loaded deck barges JMC 46 (O.N. 1064243) and WEEKS 294 (O.N. 1037414). The vessels were transiting outbound on the Chesapeake Bay, in the vicinity of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel, enroute to Bayonne, New Jersey. While enroute the JMC 46 allided with the bridge’s highrise fendering wall resulting in approximately $300,000 in damage to the fendering system.

As a result of its investigation, The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the movement and crossing of the barges’ tow wires as it made its approach towards the bridge span, which negatively impacted the vessel’s positioning between the fendering systems under the bridge. The subsequent events to this casualty were: (1) the barge’s allision with the bridge’s fendering wall and (2) the material damage to the fendering wall. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the environmental conditions at the time of the incident specifically the current, (2) the master’s lack of experience transiting through the bridge span, and (3) the inadequacy of the master’s voyage planning, which failed to account for the tow configuration/size, and bridge span clearances.

Recommend a DAPI audit of the vessel's operator, Dann Ocean Towing.

Recommend this incident investigation activity be closed with a referral to enforcement.

On Thursday August 6, 2015, at approximately 1610, the UTV RITA, pushing ahead 6 empty hopper barges allided with the Morgan City Rail Road Bridge. While the vessel was on a southbound heading making their approach to cross the bridge at an angle due to the strong current, the lead starboard barge allided with the bridge's northwestern fender causing damage to the barge and subsequently breaking the 3x2 towing configuration. 

Following the allision, the row of three port barges broke loose and were recovered by an assist tug. The remaining three starboard barges remained connected to the vessel. The lead starboard barge ING 5728 received damage to the starboard bow with a penetration approximately 6-8 feet square. It was reported that the fendering system received minor damage. 


As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the bridge. This was followed by the subsequent injury and the barges going adrift. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty were 1) the environment, 2) communications between the UTV RITA and the MISS EDMAY, 3)the routine performance of duties from the pilot, and 4) poor voyage planning.

UTV JEFFREY  G. STOVER was transiting up bound MM 2.2 UMR and pushing 5 empty hoppers and 14 dry cargo barges when a coupling failed and three barges broke free and were set adrift. Two barges allided with the left descending pier of the channel span on the CAIRO HWY BRIDGE MM 1.3 UMR and have sustained minor damage. No damage to the bridge reported. Three barges grounded and one barge sustained minor inset from the grounding that did not need repairs. Several tow wires were broken in the indicent. All barges were retrieved and placed back in tow.

Coast Guard investigation determined the the intiating event was the material failure of the barge coupling in the tow.  Contributing factor include strong currents pushing against the tow as the vessel was headed upbound against the river flow.

Incident did not exceed the criteria in the D8 Mission Prioritization Guidance.  The level of investigation was descoped to a data collection level due to manpower constraints, lack of qualified investigators and competing mission priorities.

SCC rcvd calls from the LaCrosse R/R Bridge tender and the UTV Kim Nowell reporting an allision on the outside span (up river).  

MSD St. Paul duty investigator discovered the UTV Kim Nowell was heading down bound with 12 dry cargo barges when it made its approach to the easterly LaCrosse swing bridge opening at about 0430 on 07SEP15.  The port bow of the port lead barge struck the east rest wood protection pier of the LaCrosee swing bridge.  No pollution or injuries but the barge struck the wood protection resulting in damage to about 35' of timbers.  When the bridge surveyor arrived on scene, it was estimated that the cost of damage would be approximately $135,000-$145,000 to the structure.  Bridge inspectors were called in by the Rail Road to survey the damage at first light and a marine surveyor was on scene in LaCrosse to survey the barge for damage.  Initially due to the time of late night/early morning, the extent of the damage was not visible until first light.  Once the extensive damage was observed, it was reported and relayed back to vessel which stopped its transit for proper protocols.

It was determined that miscommunication of approach distance between the bow lookout and the UTV operator led to the barge getting to close to east rest pier wood protection which ultimately resulted in the allision.

On September 12, 2015, Sector Baltimore Command Center received a phone call from the Master of Passenger Vessel Odyssey III. The Master stated that as the vessel was transiting under the 14th Street railroad bridge in the Potomac River, the stern mast light scraped the bridge at center span and the navigation light broke off.  

The stern navigation light is attached to a retractable mast/flag pole and crewmembers lower the mast prior to transiting underneath the bridge. There is approximately a foot of clearance for the Odyssey III to transit through, which is a routine occurrence. There was no damage to the bridge, no further vessel damage and no personnel injuries. DC Fireboat 2 was transiting behind the Odyssey III and witnessed the incident. Vessel returned to home pier at Southwest Waterfront in Washington, D.C. to conduct repairs.

On September 12, 2015, Coast Guard investigator and inspector visited the Odyssey III and tested the stern flag pole. It was found the retraceable flag pole was not resting completely when lowered and there could possibly be water in the hydraulic line. A technician was recommended to conduct repairs for proper hydraulic operation. In the mean time, a temporary repair was accepted where in the event of transit under the bridge; the flag pole would be lowered and lashed with a line to keep it in a full resting position.  

On September 14, 2015, a technician from Baltimore Hydraulics, Inc. inspected and exercised the aft mast hydraulic system and did not find any issues. Crewmembers replaced the broken mast light and renewed the base for the anchor light and the lower masthead light.

On 11SEP15 at approximately 1655, it was reported that the P/V PARK CITY had a loss of primary steering while enroute to Bridgeport, Ct.  The vessel had departed Port Jefferson, NY and entered Long Island Sound when the Master observed that the #1 steering pump remote alarm and indicator actuated.  The Master immediately started the #2 pump and continued the enroute voyage while making notifications. Vessel entered the Port of Bridgeport, Ct and moored to the Ferry Terminal to effect repairs.  It was identified by the Chief Engineer that #1 pump was continually blowing fuses.  O/O via Master made request for a one time transit with passengers back to Port Jefferson, NY., voyage was authorized.  While underway enroute Port Jefferson, NY. Chief Engineer identified that normal ships power was being fed through the Emergency Bus to the #1 steering pump.  Chief Engineer secured power to the #1 pump at the Emergency Bus and reinstalled a fuse, circuit was energized at the Emergency Bus and locally, no failure reported. Vessel continued voyage to Port Jefferson, NY under #2 pump, upon arrival MSD Coram Duty MI attended the vessel.  Operational readiness of #1 steering gear assembly was demonstrated.  It is believed that initially the fuse had vibrated loose and shorted, upon reinstalling new fuses this process reoccurred at least twice due to the power not being properly secured prior to attempting to effect the repair.

It was reported to Marine Safety Unit Morgan City the Uninspected Towing Vessel ENDEAVOR allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge fender system.  The ENDEAVOR was pushing two red flag barges when it allided with the bridge fender system.  The bridge reported a non-structural member was broken and fell into the water.  The bridge operator stated that there were no issues with the operation of the bridge.

On 19 August 2015 HONEST BOB departed Tuscaloosa heading South bound on the Black Warrior River, pushing ahead 6 empty barges; barge configuration was 3 wide and 2 long. On 20 August 2015 at approximately 0200 the HONEST BOB approached the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge at Mile Marker 268, visibility was clear and there was no wind at the time. As it neared a bend in the river the Master slowed the tow down then aligned the tow with the head on the point. As the vessel passed under the bridge the master noticed the tow was sliding more than anticipated. The mate engaged the engines in reverse to stop the headway motion; this caused the starboard rear barge, BKM4510B, to allide with the west pillar on the bridge. 

After the allision, the Mate engaged the engines in order to clear the bridge. After clearing the bridge the Mate alerted the bridge tender of the allision. The vessels crew inspected the barge for damage and found it sustained only minor cosmetic damage to its starboard rear not needing repair. The barge tender did an initial inspection of the bridge with no noted damage. The Norfolk Southern railroad supervisor arrived on scene at approximately 0440, inspected the bridge and found that the bridge sustained no visible or structural damage. The HONEST BOB continued on to Demopolis with no other incident.

At approximately 0015 CST on September 09, 2015, the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) CROSBY COMMANDER (O.N. 1163372) allided barge OCEANUS (O.N. 1233982) with the Houma Navigation Canal Bridge in Houma, LA. At the time of the allision, the UTV CROSBY COMMANDER (O.N. 592410) was moored on the centerline stern of the barge, acting as a guide vessel. UTV MISS STACIE (O.N. 622585) was not moored to the barge but forward of the tow acting as a scout vessel.
 
While transiting southbound in the GICW, the tow became misaligned as it passed through the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge. The Master of UTV CROSBY COMMANDER tried to correct the mistake but was too late and the OCEANUS struck the northwest side of the fenders.  The Master of UTV CROSBY COMMANDER then tried to compensate for the allision and struck the northeast side of the fenders. The barge sustained $16,000 in damage and the bridge sustained $85,000 in damage totaling $101,000 in damages.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was an allision from OCEANUS, which was pulled in tow by CROSBY COMMANDER, with the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge. The subsequent event was damage to the port side of OCEANUS and damage to the northeast side of the bridge. CROSBY CARRIER attempted to realign the tug and tow but overcompensated resulting in the second subsequent event of an allision with the northwest side of the bridge. The starboard side of the barge was undamaged but the bridge sustained damage to its northwest fender system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) mismatch between the Captain and the environment of a large tow through a narrow bridge channel, (2) execution error-attention failure of the misaligned tug and tow through the bridge, and (3) inadequate shiphanding of a tug with a large tow.

On 9/15/2015 at approx 1500, the UTV HOWARD CORSE, pushing 9 loaded hopper barges travelling N/B on the Cumberland River, was set by the outflow from Barkley Lock. The set from the outflow caused the center lead barge to allide with the right descending pier of the Eureka Bridge locate at MM 29.9 CBR. No damage occurred to the bridge pier or barge. The investigation revealed that the strong flow from Barkley Lock impacted the 1800 hp vessel's ability to maneuver.

At approximately 0318 EDT on October 09, 2015, the tank vessel QI LIN ZUO was transiting the Arther Kill in the Port of New York and New Jersey, when her INMARSAT C antenna mast struck the Arther Kill Rail Bridge. 

The allision bent the steel mast backwards and removed the INMARSAT C antenna. The bridge was surveyed after the allision and was found undamaged. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that an inaccurate air draft measurement was reported to the pilot prior to transit. This discrepency was a result of the vessel operator's failure to account for the full height of the INMARSAT C antenna mast. The mast is designed to retract downwards if needed. The air draft measurement provided to the pilot was correct only if the mast was retracted. On this transit, the mast was not retracted, consequently the air draft reported to the pilot was incorrect, and the mast struck the bridge.

On October 9, 2015 at approximately 0645 local time the Tug CAPT JOHNNY (O.N. 299649) was pushing the gravel barge DMT 4005 (O.N. 665826) ahead when it allided with the fendering system to the South Norfolk Jordan Bridge.  The tug reportedly had to unexpectedly slow down due to a recreational sailing vessel that was transiting in front of the tow.  The tug utilized its horn in an attempt to hail the sailing vessel after the vessel failed to respond to VHF communications.  The tug’s horn became stuck in the actuated position, leading to a loss of control air and throttle control.  This equipment failure influenced the tug's ability to maneuver in the prevailing sea conditions (currents), resulting in the starboard bow of the barge alliding with seven eight foot wooden planks on the bridge’s fendering system.  The initiating event identified in conjunction with this incident was failure of the actuating valve for the vessel's air horn, which became stuck in the open position resulting in the subsequent loss of control air necessary for throttle control.  This ultimately led to a reduction in maneuverability event followed by the allision with the South Norfolk Jordan Bridge fendering system.

It is recommended that this investigation activity be closed without a referral to enforcement.

On 11OCT2015 the open hopper barge SG-553B broke free from the fleeting area and travelled north on the Illinois River where it allided with the Tazewell and Peoria Railroad Bridge at MM 160.7. The empty SG-553B was part of a southbound tow that was being wired in and secured on winch wires with downriver leads only.  Strong winds blowing north caused the barge to slip out of the downriver leads and was blown upriver against the current.  The barge was retrieved by the UTV PRARIE LAND and resecured in the fleet.  There was no damage to the barge or the bridge.

On October 27, 2015 at approximately 1215 CST, the Uninspected Towing Vessel MISS EDMAY, pushing ahead two barges, allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge fendering system. The allision occurred as the MISS EDMAY was heading southbound on Bayou Boeuf, while pushing ahead two loaded barges, the lead barge 2015 (35 ft wide) and the SMI-59 (40 ft wide). As the vessel began to transit through the railroad bridge, the lead barge cleared the bridge. As the second barge approached the starboard bridge dolphin (fendering system), the starboard bow of the second barge allided with the fendering system.  Due to the difference in size of the two barges, a corner was created where the two barges meet and upon going through the bridge, the barge got pushed to the starboard side by the current and the starboard corner of the aft barge (SMI-59) allided with the bridge fender. Upon impact, the port side wires connecting the two barges parted, but safety ropes prevented the barges from swinging out of control.

The Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge fendering system received minor damage. The operation of the bridge was not affected. Neither the barges, nor the vessel received any damage.

Vessel Master contacted Sector Guam reporting a ruptured lube oil hose ruptured on the Towing Vessel TAMARAW requiring the main engine to be shut-down for repairs.  The Tug TAMARAW maneuvered using their bow-thruster and completed repairs in approximately 1.5 hours. The Tug was offshore and in transit to Kwajalein when this occurred. No injuries, no pollution, and no drug/alcohol testing was required.

On 27 Oct 2015 at 0650 M/V BRIDGETT CAULLEY was pushing 3 loaded red flag barges up bound LMR at MM 340 when the lead barge ran aground in the marked channel. The vessel was able to break down its tow and get the barge free from ground with no damage. Vessel them assembled the tow and got back underway.

On November 3, 2015, at approximately 1000 local mean time (LMT), the US Coast Guard Certificated Army Corps of Engineer Dredge Barge MURDEN (O.N. 1235517) was transiting southbound in the Virginia Intercoastal Waterway (ICW) en route to Wanchees, NC. The Captain had assumed the first navigational watch after the vessel got underway from Fort Norfolk, VA.  The Mate was also on the bridge serving as lookout and assistant to the Captain while transiting in the southern branch of the Elizabeth River, an area of high traffic congestion and bridges.  The mate stayed on the bridge as the MURDEN transitioned into the Virginia Intracoastal Waterway (ICW).  At approximately 1/2 mile south of the Centerville Bridge, in the VA ICW, the vessel struck an unknown submerged object.  The object damaged the starboard side hydraulic motor on the azimuth drive unit.  The motor leaked approximately 2-5 gallons of hydraulic fluid into the ICW.  The starboard side azimuth drive was secured and the Captain of the MURDEN made the decision to continue towards Wanchees, NC using only the port engine and bow thrusters.  This decision was made out of concern that it would be safer to transit in an area of less traffic congestion then turning around and heading back into Norfolk.  The Captain originally estimated that the cost of labor and material to repair the starboard motor would be approximately $50,000.

The dredge barge made it safely to Wanchees, NC where it was hauled out for dry dock.  It was discovered that the steering pump had broken loose from the outdrive unit.  The damaged unit was replaced by a fully operational spare unit.  The total cost of repairs was $70,000.00 and were affected by members of the Army Corps of Engineers repair yard.  These repairs were monitored by Coast Guard marine inspectors assigned to Nags Head, VA.  

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the unknown submerged object in the VA ICW.  Subsequently, this damaged the starboard Azimuth drive unit beyond operation.  This negatively impacted the maneuverability of the vessel and it was forced to continue on its voyage to Wanchees, NC for repairs on one engine. The main causal factor in this incident is the heavy industrial activity on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River, NC that creates much debris being flushed from the banks into the water. This debris is often submerged and not within the visibility limitations of operators. 

In accordance with the memorandum of understanding between the US Coast Guard (USCG) and the Army Corp of Engineers (ACOE), requesting their ACOE vessels to be certificated and subsequent marine casualties investigated by the USCG, this incident was investigated by the USCG and it is recommended that this case be closed without a referral for enforcement.

UTV MAP RUNNER (O.N. 1121215, MARATHON PETROLEUM, 1400HP, 9'6 barge draft) reported barge MPC 913 (loaded with crude oil) allided with the center pier of the Chessie R/R Bridge while transiting upbound at MM 01 Big Sandy River, pushing ahead stern-side forward. UTV was only pushing one barge, moving it from the fleet to the facility to be discharged. Allision was due to dense fog that came on during transit and the captain reported the center span lights of the bridge were extinguished. Captain of UTV had posted two lookouts on the tow, who afterwards reported only seeing the green light of the alternate span during transit.  UTV continued to destination Marathon Refinery after completing a visual inspection of the bridge and barge. The barge sustained a 02" wide, 04" deep inset on the port stern running the entire height of the barge, as well as bent K-beams and frames. The bridge is owned by CSX, who inspected the bridge and reported no damage.

At approximately 1048 CST on November 11, 2015, the towing vessel Sarah Andrie was pushing (9)barges and the the barge A-390 was the lead barge in a "strung-out" formation. The allision ocurred as the Sarah Andrie was passing the western bridge protection cell, the starboard bow of the A-390 made contact with the cell pushing the barge into the eastern cell. The port bow of the A-340 made contact with the cell at a speed of 5 kts. The damage to the A-390 was a dent 4 ft by 5 ft in the port bow. At the time of the allision the A-390 was empty of any product. The damage was forward of the collision bulkhead. 

The master and crew stated that the wind was blowing from the SW 10-15 kts. The master said that the combination of the wind and tight clearance between the cells (1 ft either side) effected his steering and blew him onto the cells causing damage to the A390. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a combination to the 10-15 kt wind effect on the barges along with the extremely tight passage between the protection cells. The causal factors that contributed to the casualty include: (1) excessive winds in the vicinity of the tow as it entered the bridge cells, (2) The master misjudging his speed as he entered the protection cell area, (3) Loss of sitional awareness of the master when he stated that "he usually piviots off of the eastern cell into the cell area and swings into the protection area". He mis-judged the wind, his speed of his tow and the piviot point on the head barge A-390 causing the allision.

On October 22, 2015 at approximately 0700, an unnamed and unmanned work barge broke free from its mooring on the ICW and allided with the Little River Swing Bridge. The barge drifted with the tide until it allided and became stuck under the bridge. The allision resulted in damage to the bridge's fendering system but did not cause damage to the barge.

The cause of the casualty was determined to be the barge's mooring lines were not properly secured, allowing the barge to break free.

ON November 20, 2015 at approximately 1955 hrs the M/V  W.T. TOUTANT (ACL, 637070, 6200HP)  pushing 18 loaded barges (soybean, corn, pellets & 4 ethyl alcohol), 4 X 5 with a notch in the port string, down bound at MM 43.7 UMR when the starboard screw caught some drift in the wheel  and the engine shut down. The starboard stern barge (soybean) struck the right descending pier of the Thebes R/R Bridge (LLNR 17425). The ACL 119 barge began taking on water in the starboard stern voids 2 and 3 and was dewatered using pumps. All of the red flag barges are in the port string with no damage.  No other damage, injury or pollution reported. Vessel and tow released to proceed to final destination in Louisiana after temporary repairs were effected  Railroad bridge was inspected by owners and no damage was found.

On 03 December, 2015 at approximately 0655 hrs  the M/V CRIMSON DUKE while transiting downbound at mile 44 upper Mississippi River pushing 36 loaded barges, the STBD stern barge allided with the right descending pier of the Thebes Railroad Bridge. 16 barges subsequently broke away, including 4 red flags.  Barges were retrieved with the help of assist vessels with 2 grounding on dikes.  The two grounded barges (ART 35716 AND RRS 7970) were  found to be damaged as a result of the allision.  Temporary repairs were conducted and the ART 35716 was partially offloaded conduct repairs.  Barges were placed back in tow for transit to repair facility.  Investigation revealed the 7+ mph current to be a causal factor in the allision.

The STEPHEN L. COLBY was up bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282 when the tow allided with the turntable of the Louisiana railroad bridge. No damage occurred to the bridge or the barge. The Master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

At approximately 0915 CST on December 7, 2015, the offshore supply vessel SARAH BORDELON allided with the BAYOU DULARGE BRIDGE, located near MM 59.9 of the Gulf Intracoastal Water Way. The allision occurred as the SARAH BORDELON was headed west bound en route to ABL Fabricators in Amelia, Louisiana. 

The BAYOU DULARGE BRIDGE was struck on its east facing side by mast of SARAH BORDELON. The bridge reported no damage, while the SARAH BORDELON sustained a bent mast and broken navigation lights.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of SARAH BORDELON's mast with the BAYOU DULARGE BRIDGE. This was followed by damage to SARAH BORDELON's mast and navigation lights. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) lack of familiarity and misjudgement, on the part of the helmsman, with the height of the bridge and (2) failure of the helmsman to request an opening of the bridge prior to passing through.

On 02 December 2015 the towing vessel LAVACA (Official Number 626298)was transiting northbound on the Atchafalaya River at approximately 0015 hours. While northbound the towing vessel LAVACA allided with the northeastern bridge fender of the Morgan City Railroad bridge. The master of the vessel stated that he misjudged the water current and the turn. By the time he realized that he was not going to make the turn he tried to minimize the impact and managed to allide with the bridge fender. The cause of the allision was due to the master misjudging the water current which lead him to allide with the bridge.

At approximately 1130 PST on December 9, 2015 the tug vessel HENRY FOSS was transiting the Hylebos Waterway in Tacoma, WA shifting a derrick barge from the vicinity of General Construction to American Construction.  The transit required the HENRY FOSS to pass beneath the Hylebos Bridge (11th Street Bridge).  The master tried to abort his approach to the bridge but was unable to stop the vessels before sticking the bridge with the starboard bow of the HENRY FOSS.  The impact occurred at nearly dead stop so damage was only cosmetic in nature to the vessel and bridge.

Cause of the allision was a result of the tug operator misjudging his approach angle through the bridge.  Once the error was recognized the operator was unable to fully correct the situation prior to striking the bridge.

At approximately 1255 on December 4, 2015, BARGE CC 97149, loaded with salt, while U/B under the control of the UTV DAVID L FIELDS allided with the upper protection cell on the right descending bank of the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RAILROAD BRIDGE (AKA Lower Pekin Railroad), on the Illinois River, Mile Marker 151.2. UTV DAVID L FIELDS was pushing a 13 barge tow and BARGE CC 97149 was the second barge in the port string.  Master stated he intentionally laid up on protection cell for a controlled landing but did not notify the bridge in advance.

The allision resulted with BARGE CC 97149 taking on water in its bow void. No damage to the bridge was reported by the bridge tender. UTV DAVID L FIELDS deployed two 3 inch pumps and two 2 inch pumps to control the flooding. At approximately 2140, December 4, 2015, divers arrived on scene to conduct a damage survey and repairs.  At approximately 0052, December 5, 2015 divers completed temporary repairs using shingles on 7 fractures, the largest approximately 1 ft. long by 1 inch wide.  The fractures were located by the 4th, 5th, 6th, 8th and 9th knuckle gussets forward from bulkhead all on the portside.  The void space was dewatered and vessel was allowed to continue its transit.

At approximately 0429 CST on December 12, 2015, the uninspected towing vessel (UTV) MISS LIS pushing the barge MARMAC 27 allided with the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge. At the time of the allision, the MARMAC 27 was empty. The UTV MISS LIS pushing MARMAC 27 had departed Port Fourchon, LA at approximately 1800 on December 11, 2015 and was heading to Gibson, LA to deliver MARMAC 27.

The starboard bow of MARMAC 27 struck the southeast fender of the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge.  There was no damage to the bridge or the barge.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the misalignment of the UTV MISS LIS pushing MARMAC 27 through the Houma Navigational Canal Bridge. There were three (03) barges moored on the side of the ICW that could have potentially impacted the navigation of the towing vessel and barges transit. It is the responsibility of the operator to ensure safe navigation of the vessel.

At approximately 0135 on December 14, 2015 the towing vessel MARK C was pushing 6 empty salt barges southbound through the Bayou Sorrel Bridge when the port stern barge (IN015455) in the tow allided with the northeast fendering system of the bridge.  

The IN015455 was not damaged, but the navigation light on the end pylon of the fendering system was knocked off. The bridge was undamaged and fully operational after the allision.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initating event for this casualty was the allision between the barge and the fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the Captain's choice to favor the east bank with a following current and wind coming from the southwest.

On 13DEC2015 at approximately 1825 hrs the M/V  JINX P. SMITH (ON# 569720, 3800HP, YAZOO RIVER TOWING)  allided with the left descending pier of the Henry R. Lawrence Memorial bridge at MM 63 Cumberland River while transiting down bound with 04 empty barges (2X2 configuration, previously loaded with liquid fertilizer less than 2%) due to high wind. The port lead barge (VPF-403B) rubbed against the bridge causing no damage to the vessel or barge. The Bridge was inspected and no damage was found to the bridge. The M/V was released to continue transiting towards Vicksburg, MS to disembark barges and their final destination is New Orleans, LA. No other damage, pollution or injuries reported.

On December 14, 2015, at approximately 1715 LMT, the tug JACK HOLLAND (ON# 669003) was pushing the empty freight barge NTC-50 (ON# 531237) northbound on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River, transiting through the Gilmerton Bridge Span.  During the transit through the bridge span the barge allided with the eastern side of the fendering system.  The Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River north of the Gilmerton Bridge is a known problem area due to a sharp almost 90 degree bend in the river that exists . The mate-on-watch attempted to navigate closer to the port side of the channel due to two reasons, the first being the sharp bend in the channel immediately following the bridge and second, because the weather and waterway conditions was pushing the tug and barge to the starboard side of the channel. At the time of the casualty the current was ebbing, and the wind was gusting to the east at approximately 10-15 knots.  Also, the 324 foot NTC-50 was empty which caused the barge to have a very large sail area.  The wind gusts combined with the increased sail area of the empty barge set the vessels to the starboard side of the channel as the mate-on-watch was approaching the bridge span.  Once the mate-on-watch realized that an allision was inevitable, he made evasive maneuvers to ensure the barge made a controlled landing on the easterly side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system. The barge slid down the side of the fendering system and exited the bridge span. The tug did not make contact with the bridge fendering system.  No damage was reported to the bridge, fendering system or tug and barge.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a lack of vessel maneuverability, which resulted from a combination of weather factors of an ebb tide and strong gusting wind, the large sail area from the unloaded barge, and the significantly reduced navigational channel at the Gilmerton Bridge Span.  This combination negatively impacted the mate's approach, which resulted in an allision with the fendering system.

On 02 January 2016 at approximately 1125, the uninspected towing vessel XENA (O.N. 1121166) was pushing ahead 1 empty pressure barge which normally carries Butane, the EMS 402 (O.N. 1231305). While transitting southbound on the Escambia River, the starboard bow of the EMS 402 allided with the northside, along the right descending bank, of the Escambia River Highway 90 Bridge causing damgage to the fender system of the bridge and the walkway under the bridge. Also present during the casualty was the towing vessel WALTER (O.N. 1033116), who was on the south side of the bridge, helping to guide the XENA through the bridge.

The EMS 402 was undamaged, except for minor paint scrapes and a slight indent on the starboard bow knuckle just below the deckline. Nothing of concern in regards to the steel of the barge was found. The damage to the Escambia River Highway 90 bridge was estimated at $410,000 and included damage to the wooden fendering system and walkway under and along the side of the bridge.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating/sole event for this casualty was the allision with the Escambia River Highway 90 Bridge which caused subsequent damage to the bridge. The causual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) Misuse of reverse in strong current and (2) Miscommunication between the XENA and the WALTER.

The containership AKINADA BRIDGE (O.N. 92224532) was inbound from the pilot station to Pier 3 in Tacoma, WA.  As the vessel approached the "SA" buoy at approximately 1815, the vessel experienced a loss of power throughout the ship.  The vessel was adrift for approximately three minutes before steering system power supply was restored.  At approximately 1824, the vessel restored full power.

After further investigation, the source of the vessel black-out condition was due to a sensor failure of the No. 3 diesel generator.  The faulty sensor activated the air-supply for the No.3 diesel generator turbo charger which caused the generator to trip on over-speed condition.  Immediately following the blackout, the onboard electrician replaced the faulty sensor and normal power was restored. The vessel safely transited to Pier 3 in Tacoma, WA with no further issues.

On Dec 30, 2015 at 1115 the F/V JUSTICE allided with the Rt 6 bridge which spans between Fairhaven, MA and New Bedford, MA. While backing into their dock slip at Fish Island the operator was shifting his location from the forward operating station to the aft operating station, a routine operation for this vessel.
