Once the operator attempted to maneuver the vessel from the aft operating station, the vessel did not respond to commands which allowed the vessel's bow to drift into the channel divider under the bridge at a slow speed. The vessel operator quickly moved back to the forward station gained control of the vessel and satisfactorily backed the vessel into the slip. There was minimal damage to the fendering system of the channel divider and no damage to the vessel.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the casualty was an electrical failure at the aft steering station. The lack of response from the aft station allowed the vessel to drift into the channel barrier. The operator was able to gain control of the vessel once he returned to the forward operating station. The casual factors that contributed to the allision include: (1) the wind and tides that pushed the vessel's bow into the barrier (2) electrical failure of the aft control station.

Sector St Petersburg received a report of a commercial fishing vessel alliding with the Matanzass Pass Bridge.  The vessel was underway with 03 crew on board.  Investigating Officer spoke with company representative and determined that the vessel received damage to the outrigger.  The bridge also sustained some damage. No injuries, pollution or waterway obstruction.

On December 30, 2015, at approximately 0930 CST, three River Construction employees boarded the moored MV PINTAIL at the Magnolia Fleet dock barge on the right descending bank of the Lower Mississippi River at mile marker (MM) 122. After receiving task direction from the shift supervisor, the River Construction crew got underway from the inboard side of the Magnolia fleet dock barge. Two crewmembers were inside the cabin and one remained on the aft boat deck. 

As the MV PINTAIL departed the Magnolia Fleet dock barge, the uninspected towing vessel CAPT GEORGE BRUMLEY and tow of one sludge barge was positioned off the outboard side of the Magnolia Fleet dock barge with its engines engaged and propeller turning. There was a gap of approximately 30 feet between the stern of the UTV CAPT GEORGE BRUMLEY and the bow of the Carline dock barge immediately down river from the Magnolia Fleet dock barge. 
   
The MV PINTAILs outboard engine stalled as the vessel passed behind the UTV CAPT GEORGE BRUMLEY. Without propulsion, the MV PINTAIL drifted down river with the river current and propeller wash until alliding with the bow of the Carline dock barge. Pinned against the dock barge, the MV PINTAIL started listing to the port side. As the vessel rolled, the crewmember on the aft boat deck jumped off the port side of the vessel and began swimming. Moments later, the MV PINTAIL capsized with two crewmembers inside the vessels cabin. 

The MV PINTAIL drifted down river with its bow submerged and stern raised vertical out of the water. The two crewmembers escaped from the MV PINTAILs cabin and clung to the vessels hull.  The crewmember that had jumped off the vessel drifted with the river current and was last seen swimming towards the river bank in between the stern of the Carline dock barge and the bow of a Bisso dock barge immediately down river. The MV PINTAIL drifted alongside the UTV BOBCAT moored to the Bisso dock barge, and two crewmembers climbed out of the water on to the UTV BOBCAT. A crew member from the UTV BOBCAT secured mooring lines to the MV PINTAIL and prevented it from drifting further downriver.  

The U.S. Coast Guard, St. Charles Parish Sheriff’s office, Port of South Louisiana, and multiple Good Samaritans conducted search and rescue operations for the other crewmember. The Coast Guard search and rescue operations were suspended on December 31st 2015. On January 24, 2016 the body of a deceased individual was discovered near Mile Marker 100 on the Lower Mississippi River. The body was later identified as the missing crewmember.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event to be the MV PINTAIL losing propulsion. Causal factors for this casualty were: 1) Inadequate Training 2) Personnel Actions / Judgment 3) Environment- High-water River Conditions. 

This incident met criteria for a reportable marine casualty and a serious marine incident. The level of investigative efforts met the requirements of an Informal Investigation as it resulted in loss of life.

On 29 December, 2015 at approximately 2330 hrs the M/V TENNESSEE HUNTER (Hunter Marine, 625977, 4200HP) pushing 15 empty hoppers (3X5) down bound at MM 5.3 TNR when the tow was set by strong currents and struck the left descending pier of the George Rogers Clark Replacement Bridge MM 5.6 Tennessee River. When the 6 lead barges broke away, but were quickly recovered by the UTV NIXON and UTV TOM BUSSLER. Two of the barges had damage to them. No flooding, injury or pollution reported. The tow was rebuild and released to continue its voyage.  Coast Guard investigation revealed a causal factor to be the master had misjudged the strength and set of current and got out of shape to properly transit the bridge span.

AT 1019L SEC MIAMI received a report from STAFTP concerning an allision between tug LADY THEO and its tow barge DD60 with the FTP NORTH CAUSEWAY BRIDGE.  Upon preliminary investigation, it was determined that the dredge pipes, also towed by LADY THEO, contacted the bridge's fender system and a concrete pillar.  FTP CG45631 conducted a boarding, along with MSD Lake Worth IO. No damage to either the tug or barge was noted during the boarding.  And only minor damage to the bridge fendering system was noted.

At approximately 1000 CST on December 28,2015, the uninspected towing vessel J. A. WARD pushing ahead 6 barges (5 empty open hoppers; 1 spud barge) (tow dimensions were 2 barges wide by 3 barges long) had its stern port barge, RM 3351, lightly rub the Bayou Dularge Bridge Fender System.  The allision occurred while the J.A. WARD was headed west bound along the GIWW toward the Atchafalaya River just north of Morgan City to Hot Springs, Louisiana.

The bridge fender system was lightly rubbed on its south fender causing no damage to either the barge or the fender system. The tow's forward speed was approximately 0.7 mph when it lightly allided the fender works.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event was the allision of the tow's port stern corner of barge, RM 3351, with the south bridge fender works. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:  1) Tow's forward speed was not enough to offset strong sudden southerly wind gusts near 25 mph that pushed the tow's stern port corner onto the bridge's south fender works; 2) Bridge span width was 125 feet and the tow's dimensions were 70 feet wide by near 600 feet long. This allowed little room to compensate for sudden changes in weather conditions, which occurred in this instance; 3) Vessel master just got underway about a quarter mile east from the bridge fender system after navigational curfew ended. This caused the vessel to not have enough forward speed or headway to counter the sudden strong wind gusts as the vessel entered the bridge fender opening.

08JAN2016: M/V CMA CGM ALMAVIVA was transiting outbound through the Arthur Kills and under the Bayonne Bridge when the port inmarsat c antenna #2 made contact with the construction net of the Bayonne Bridge. The contact was enough to pull down the antenna, shattering the antenna cone when it fell to the deck of the vessel.  Vessel was directed to anchor in Gravesend Bay with IO and MI dispatched to investigate. Airdraft of the vessel was 148.7 ft and the airdraft for the bridge at the time of incident was 152.2 ft. giving the vessel a clearance of 3.5 ft. However, after reviewing witness statement from the Master of the vessel, VTS track and video of the vessel transiting under the bridge, it was determined that the Pilot had cut the corner of the outbound turn in the Newark Basin and had the vessel transiting under the northern part of the bridge instead of going directly under the high point Pilot Flag. This subsequently dropped the air draft clearance by approximately 3 ft. and had the vessel with 1/2 foot of clearance. Furthermore, the video captures that the vessel was turning hard to port and subsequently listing to starboard which would have made up the clearance distance resulting in the portside inmarsat c antenna #2 making contact with the construction net of the Bayonne bridge. No damage to the bridge was sustained as per the Bayonne Bridge Port Authority and Form B was issued to the vessel for repair of the inmarsat c antenna.

As the vessel was north of the mid-channel by approximately 30 yards, it should have been calculated that this maneuver would reduce air clearance and this should have been taken into account by the Pilot. At the time of the incident, there was no precise method of computing the true height of the Bayonne Bridge and its suspended hazards. Subsequent meetings and conversations since incident between all parties should help mitigate the hazards of bridge strike allisions while the bridge undergoes re-construction.

At 1014U on 07 January 2016, Sector Puget Sound received report from the regional manager of Foss Maritime that at 0810U the AMERICAN TRADER allided with the Hylebos Bridge. At the time of the incident, the AMERICAN TRADER was being towed by the WEDELL FOSS and HENRY FOSS from the West Hylebos moorings to American Construction facility. The WEDELL FOSS was on the port bow of the AMERICAN TRADER and the HENRY FOSS was on the stern on a single line moving port/starboard. At approximately 30 to 40 feet in to the crossing, the mate onboard the WEDELL FOSS noticed that the AMERICAN TRADER was not square in the horizontal clearance (150 feet).  The mate gave the order to check the stern to starboard, but did not catch the swing soon enough.  The AMERICAN TRADER's starboard forward ladder which extends about a foot off the hull allided with the Hylebos Bridge shear wall. The Hylebos bridge tender conducted inspection and discovered only minor damage to the west side protective wall. The Hylebos Bridge remains fully operational. There was no damage to the AMERICAN TRADER.

At approximately 1130 CST, on January 7, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel KAREN KOBY (O.N. 1230122) allided with the Morgan City LA 182 bridge on the Atchafalaya River. The vessel was transiting northbound and cleared both the Morgan City Rail Road Bridge, which was lifted, and the Highway 90 bridge. 

Upon allision, the aluminum mast snapped off at the swivel point, approximately 15 feet below the mast head light, and landed of the aft top deck. The section of the mast that snapped off contained all the towing lights. Additionally, the Louisiana Department of Transportation was notified and they sent out a bridge inspector to assess damages. The bridge had no apparant damage.

As a result of the investigation it was identified that the master failed to properly assess the situation and failed to lower the mast prior to crossing the bridge. The air draft of the vessel (62 ft) was higher than the vertical clearance of the bridge (50 ft).

On January 4, 2016 the M/V JAMES PAUL AYERS (507944, Ingram, 4000HP) pushing 15 empty hoppers (3x5) down bound at MM 787 OHR when the tow was set by strong current and winds, and struck the left descending pier on the U.S. 41 Dual Bridges (LLNR 27505). No damage to the barges or M/V.
As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the high winds and higher than normal water causing strong current in the river.  KDOT Engineers determined no damage to bridge.

At approximately 0500 on 9 AUG 2015, the UTV HERITAGE (240322) allided with the Popps Ferry Bridge. The vessel was pushing 5 barges east bound through the Big Lake from Gulfport, MS to Moss Point, MS. After clearing the bridge, the tug reversed and reposition in order to navigate the waterway properly, and the stern starboard barge pushed against the bridge dolphin piling which resulted in the dolphin being damaged and pushed over. The barge sustained no damage.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) winds out of the northeast at 15-20 knots, (2) flooding tide at 3-5 knots, and (3) a difficult waterway to maneuver as vessel's were forced to make an "S" turn, first to port then starboard quickly.

On 12JAN15 at approximately 0400, the UTV HORTENSE B INGRAM was pushing 10 open hopper barges southbound near MM 106, LMR. Upon passing the turn near MM 109, the UTV attempted to get back towards the center of the channel to pass beneath the Huey P. Long Bridge. Due to the high river stage and the current pushing towards the eastbank of the river, the UTV's bow began angling towards the eastbank putting the whole tow diagonal in the river. The Pilot attempted to maneuver the vessel so it was centered up prior to passing under the bridge but was unsuccessful. As the tow passed beneath the bridge, the port stern barge in the tow (IN 155417 loaded with coal), allided with the bridge. The Pilot called for assistance following the allision, 05 tugs responded and helped the UTV HORTENSE B INGRAM push up against the westbank of the river. The IN 155417 sustained damage beneath the waterline which divers estimated to be a 1 foot crack in the lap of the bilge knuckle, which affected both the #2 and #3 port voids. Damage estimate reported on CG 2692 was recorded as $100k, however, $20k of those costs were attributed to drydocking, salvage.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the strong current pushing the vessel off track from its intended course. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include the fact that the pilot made a turn just prior to getting off course. While navigating this turn in the river, the pilot tried to maintain a position close to the westbank, however, the current was pushing strongly to the eastbank. As a result, when the pilot cleared the turn in the river he was already too far towards the eastbank and did not have sufficient time to center up in the channel before passing beneath the bridge.

On 10 January 2016 at approx. 09:30 the JAMES F. NEAL was south bound on the Illinois River Mile Marker 56 pushing 12 loaded dry cargo hopper barges.  The master attempted to maneuver the tow through the Florence Highway Bridge middle raised span, but the tow started to miss align. The master placed throttles full astern in efforts to correct the tow and the port lead barge allided with the left descending bank protection cell of Florence Highway Bridge. As a result of the bridge allision 4 barges were damaged and 9 barges broke loose and drifted downstream from the bridge. The Illinois River IVO of the Florence Highway Bridge was in major flood stage and the Master of the vessel misjudged the affects of the extra strong current associated with major flooding. The breakaway barges were collected by the Master of the JAMES F. NEAL with assistance from nearby vessels.

On 9 January 2016 at approximately 0155 the UTV ST JOHN was heading South in the Biloxi Channel pushing 3 empty scrap barges when it allided with the piling cluster of the fendering system for the Pops Ferry Bridge. As the master manuevered his tow through the bridge a strong ebb tide began to set him to the starboard side of the channel. Sensing this, the master requested the bridge tender lift the bridge again for him to back down and reset his tow into the channel on a better heading. However, he was unable to make the correction prior to alliding the starboard stern of his starboard barge, MTC 0016, with the piling cluster in front of the fendering system. As a result of the allision, the piling cluster was knocked slighlty over from its original position but no damage was done to the barge and no other incidents resulted from this casualty.

Downbound en route New Orleans, the CYNTHIA G ESPER struck the left channel span of the Hwy 49 Bridge at Helena, AR, mile marker 661.7 on the LMR.  The tow of 4 loaded denatured ethanol barges (red flag), broke up and went adrift down river.  The CYNTHIA was able to retain one barge (STC 3015), with minimal damage and regain control.  Assist vessels were able to recover the other barges.  Two barges sustained leaks to cargo tanks into the wing voids (SCF 1204 and WTC 3010).  The SCF 1204 became partially sunk after the vessels pushed it as far up the left descending bank as possible to secure it at mile marker 664.   Testimony and evidence gathered show that the master misjudged strength of current after backing down resulting in an allision of the left channel span.

At approximately 1043am on January 10, 2016 the M/V Park City experienced an electrical fire in the galley. The fire was contained inside a distribution panel on the starboard side of the galley. Once galley workers noticed fire and smoke coming out of the panel they notified crewmembers.  The Chief Engineer turned off power to the galley and a crewmember came and used CO2 to extinguish the fire and stayed for fire watch. He was relieved by the mate, and the fire reflashed two more times, finally being extingushed at approximately 1048am. The cause of the fire was found to be holes in the top of the distribution panel that allowed water intrusion into the panel. The water intrusion was caused by a hole on the upper deck which dripped water down onto the electrical wiring, which then dripped thru the top of the panel. The entire panel was replaced and the hole on the upper deck was repaired.

At approximately 0921 CST on January 16, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel GOSPEL LIGHT (O.N. 570130) pushing six open hopper barges lost steering and then subsequently allided with the West Larose Bridge. The GOSPEL LIGHT departed from Lake Charles on January 15, 2016 and was heading east enroute to American Commercial Lines in Harahan, LA.

The West Larose Bridge sustained damage to the fendering system and the red navigation light. A damage estimate was not given because the West Larose Bridge is currently undergoing a $25M overhaul. The tug and barge did not sustain any damage.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the material failure of the wiring for the steering breaker which subsequently caused GOSPEL LIGHT to lose steering.  The next subsequent event was the allision with the West Larose Bridge which subsequently caused damage to the bridge.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the communication error in which the oncoming, new operator was unaware of previous trips from the breaker that caused the vessel to lose steering, (2) the routine (adaptation) planning error in which the crew continued to operate the vessel without properly repairing the tripped breaker after the first malfunction, and (3) the maintenance/repair plan for ensuring the vessel's safety after a marine casualty occurs.

Barge MEM 5085 and ACL 9973 broke free from Southern IL Transfer fleeting area at Mile Marker(MM) 122 Upper Mississippi River (UMR). MEM 5085 struck the Chester Bridge, UMR MM 109.9. ACL 9973 ran aground at at UMR MM 105.

On January 12, 2016 at approximately 1447 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel LA COMMANDER (O.N. 548364) was towing astern the unloaded container barge COLUMBIA BALTIMORE (O.N. 1049400). Serving as the assist vessel, the uninspected towing vessel STEPHANIE DANN (O.N. 600517) was positioned off the port stern of the barge. The vessels were transiting eastbound on the Elizabeth River enroute to Colonna’s Shipyard, Norfolk, Virginia. While making the voyage the barge allided with the west fendering wall of the Berkley Bridge, resulting in approximately $100,000 in damage to the fendering wall.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the yaw movement of the barge as the bow exited from under the Berkley Bridge, which negatively impacted the vessel’s positioning between the fendering systems under the bridge. The subsequent event to this marine casualty included: (1) the barge’s allision with the bridge’s west fendering wall. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the environmental conditions at the time of the incident, specifically the strong winds, (2) the lack of a company policy, which addressed operating in high wind conditions, (3) the mate on watch’s unfamiliarity with the waterway, and (4) the inadequacy of the mate on watch’s voyage planning, which failed to account for the prevalent weather conditions.

It is recommended that this incident investigation activity be closed with a referral to enforcement.

M/V AMY FRANCES (Magnolia Marine Transportation) was underway Southbound near Natchez Bridge pushing 06 Red Flag barges (04 loaded, 02 empty).  While lining up for Natchez Bridge the captain could not get the tow set in the correct position due to high river level and increased currents.  Head of tow could not be brought around and barge MM 46 allided with Natchez Bridge.  Due to collision, extensive damage was done to barge MM 46 compromising cargo tanks and causing product (CCFB / Slurry Oil) to discharge into the water near MM 361 LMR, creating a sheen.  Vessel pushed in at MM 361 LMR on the LDB.  Due to the product having a high specific gravity, it sank below the surface of the water quickly leaving only a light sheen on the surface of the water.

MSD Vicksburg responded to incident and conducted initial investigation.  Unified command established to mitigate environmental damage.  Responsible Party contacted OSRO to contain and clean up oil pollution.  Due to environmental (high water - increased currents) / safety concerns (night time) initial containment and clean up was postponed til the following morning.  USCG Gulf Strike Team personnel and IMAT incident commander were sent to assist in operations.  Incident Command was set in place mitigating spill response from 22JAN16 - 25JAN16.

Shoreline Assessment survey was completed 01FEB2016 by MSD Vicksburg and E3 (OSRO) personnel.  River had fallen 8 feet since the initial incident took place.  Area was reported to have patchy areas of oil up to 100 yards inland through brush and around trees.  Some large puddles of oil were reported (3-4 feet long, 1-2 feet wide, 2-4 inches deep).  Light sheen was seen along waterline for approx. 200 yards.

Investigation revealed due to high water and faster than normal currents the Master was unable to position the tow correctly to navigate safely through the bridge.

On September 5, 2015 the Tug MISS YVETTE was underway pushing ahead the barge WEEKS 241 on the Acushnet River in New Bedford, MA. While making passage through the Route 6 Swing Bridge, the WEEKS 241 was involved in an allision when the swing bridge was prematurely closed, striking the WEEKS 241 and causing minor damage to the port bow of the barge and no obvious damage to the swing bridge.

As a result of the investigation the Coast Guard determined that the cause of the incident was inattention by the swing bridge operator resulting in premature closure of the bridge prior to all traffic passing safely.

The motor vessel WAYNE P LAGRANGE (ACL, 626849, 6250HP) was pushing 24 empty hoppers (6 X 4) down bound at mile marker 980.4 of the Ohio River when the tow was set by high wind (30mph) and the port lead barge struck the left descending channel pier of the Cairo Bridge. The motor vessel SHARON K assisted the WAYNE P LAGRANGE in putting damaged barge in fleet at mile marker 981 on the Ohio River. 

The port lead barge sustained significant damage to the bow rake. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the bridge allsion. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) high wind gusts, (2) master pushing 24 empty barges in high wind.

On 21 JAN 2016 at around 1415 local time the M/V THOMAS K. was south bound MM 432.8 LMR with 19 barges 1 red flag (ethanol) and the rest were dry cargo hopper barges. When the vessel was transiting under the bridge the cross current above the bridge set the vessel over to the left descending bank. Under these conditions the vessel was unable to complete the bridge transit without rubbing down the port side of the last barge in tow (WTC 3011 Ethanol). The barge was facing aft in the tow with damage to its STBD side, no damage to the cargo tanks and no product was released.

On January 31, 2016 at approx. 0915, the boom of the crane barge BC-6185 struck the Douglas MacArthur Railroad Bridge located at mile marker 179 on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR). The crane barge was being shifted down river by the towing vessel LYNDA J and was conducting fleet operations at the Peabody Fleet. This fleet extends above and below the bridge. The crane is used to lift and move cargo covers for hopper barges and was not lowered enough by the crane operator for the crane barge to pass under the bridge.  The vertical clearance of the Douglass MacArthur Bridge is 103.5 feet minus the UMR St. Louis gauge.  The UMR St. Louis gauge was at 15 feet the morning of the allision, so the vertical clearance was 88.5 feet.  There was no damage to the bridge but the boom of the crane was severely damaged

The UTV W.W. CRUM was DB at ILR MM 151 pushing two red flag barges (MM 20, empty) and (MM 95, loaded)) when the UTV attempted to make a controlled landing on the Union Pacific Railroad Bridge (aka Pekin Railroad Bridge). This is a documented, known, obstructive bridge under the TRUMAN-HOBBS Act. There was a strong current with flowing river ice. The barges were breasted with MM-95 on the stbd side. The stbd bow corner of barge MM-95 glanced off of the RDB fending system causing no damage; however, the impact caused the tow to veer to the left and the port bow of barge MM-20 to allid with the LDB shear fencing. This allision resulted in multiple broken wooden fencing timbers and pilings. The UTV was authorized to proceed southbound to Havana, IL where IO’s could safely board the vessel.  No damage was sustained to the barges. This vessel operates on a semi-dedicated route and the Pilot stated that he had probably transited the bridge 30 times in 2015 and was familiar with the intricacies of this bridge. The wooden bridge fendering system was damaged; estimated cost of repair is currently $300,000. Primary cause appears to be the Pilot's inability to accurately determine and/or anticipate the tows set and drift do to the current. This was a SMI, drug and alcohol testing was conducted.

On February 2, 2016 at approximately 1100, the deck barge JOHN WAYNE, being pushed by the Uninspected Towing Vessel MAMA ROSIE, allided with the Bayou Boeuf Rail Road Bridge fender wall while on a southbound transit. The allision led to a 6 ft. timber from the fender wall to become dislodged into the channel. 

At the time of the casualty, the UTV MAMA ROSIE was pushing the JOHN WAYNE on the port aft section of the barge, giving the UTV less than 50 percent field of vision ahead due to the spuds, crane and equipment on deck located on the barge. Additionally, the barge only had a 1 foot clearance on each side of the bridge due to the barge being 54 ft. wide and the bridge horizontal clearance being 56 ft. 
During the preliminary investigation it was discovered that the  Vessel's forwared visibility was reduced, so a decision was made to launch a Coast Guard Small Boat along with an Investigating Officer to board the vessel in the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway. Upon arrival, it was discovered that the vessel seemed to be "tacking" along the waterway, and it was further confirmed that the reason for "tacking" was due to the restricted visibility, so the vessel has to zig zag along the Intracoastal Waterway to ensure a full field of view. Also during the investigation it was discovered that there was only one deckhand onboard who was being used randomly to post a lookout, even thought the vessel had a constant reduction in visibility.

M/V WALLY ROLLER (American Commercial Lines) was underway Southbound near MM 437 LMR pushing 06 Barges (02 Soybean, 01 Corn, 01 Styrene (Red Flag), and 02 Empty Molasses).  While setting up for Vicksburg Bridge the vessel Captain was unable to get proper course set due to etremely high currents caused by high water.  Center barge in the starboard string (PML 1348B) allided with Pier #4 of the Vicksburg Bridge causing damage and taking on water.  Impact caused vessel tow to split up and barge ACL 11142 allided headon causing extensive damage to the barge.  MSD Vicksburg personnel conducted investigation aboard vessel.  02 damage barges were lightered and moved into Vicksburg Harbor.

On February 8, 2016 at approximately 0530 EST the F/V OCEAN ONE, 75' 139 gross ton commercial fishing vessel, allided with the Brielle Railroad Bridge in Point Plesant, NJ on the Manasquan River.  The OCEAN ONE was anchored in the Manasquan River and unattended at the time of the incident.  The OCEAN ONE allided with the bridge on its starboard side and suffered no damage.  The Brielle Railroad Bridge had damage to several handrails and had several severed electrical supply cables.

As a result of it's investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the vessel dragging anchor due to the anchoring arrangement, high winds and flood tide.

On February 11, 2016 Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the Uninspected Towing Vessel RONNIE ROGERS was pushing six (06) loaded uninspected rock barges headed south on the Atchafalaya River in Morgan City, LA when the tow allided with the Morgan City Railroad Bridge fender system.  The vessel and its tow did not receive damage.  The bridge was not damaged and is fully operational.

On Feburary 13, 2016, the motor vessel BRIAN A. NAPACK (640349, 6100HP, Ingram Barge Co.) was down bound at mile marker 940.8 on the Ohio River. The tow was in a 2X5 configuration with an additional on the port head. While navigating thru the I-24 highway bridge the vessel was set by current and the starboard stern barge allided with the center right descending pier.  After alliding with the bridge, the tow broke apart and drifted down river. The motor vessel ROBERT C. LOEDDING assisted with recovering the barges. After inspection there was no damage to the bridge however 3 barges sustained damage. The Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was that the master did not make appropiate adjustments in navigating the vessel and was set into the bridge.

On 14 February, 2016 at 1050 hours the M/V JAMES H. HUNTER (1199294, 3600HP, Hunter Marine) was transiting down bound MM 63 CMB in a 3X2 configuration  when their stern barge (empty, hopper) in the port string allided with the left descending pier of the Henry R. Lawrence Memorial. No damage, pollution, or injuries reported. KDOT/Bridge Inspectors inspected the bridge and no damage was reported.  Coast Guard investigation revealed that causal factor in the casualty was the high cross winds around the bridge at the time of the allision.

On February 8, 2016, at approximately 1450 local time, the U.S.-flagged passenger ferry SONOMA lost steering while backing away from the San Francisco Ferry Terminal in San Francisco, California, when the rudder became stuck hard to starboard.  The SONOMA moored safely without injuring passengers, damaging the facility or the vessel.

The primary cause of the loss of steering was a broken steering stop on the port steering cylinder that permited the cylinder ram to extend out pass its limit.  When fully extended, the rod end of the cylinder was pressed up against the rudder arm causing the rod to bend and finally fracture.

On 06 February 2016 at approx. 20:17, the UTV PAT PICKETT tow allided with the Florence Highway Bridge located on the ILR MM 56. The starboard lead barge, BASH 1 was the barge that sruck the protection cell of the bridge.  The tow slid over to starboard while on approach to the bridge. No damage occurred to the bridge or barge.

On 17 February, the MSC LAURA allided with the Bayonne Bridge while passing beneath it.  There was no damage to the vessel or crew.  The vessel's master began experiencing medical complications shortly after the allision and had to be removed from the vessel and taken to the hospital for evaluation.
While passing beneath the Bayonne Bridge, the HF/MF "whip" antenna made contact with the Bayonne Bridge which is currently under construction.  There were no injuries or damages associated with this allision.

The Coast Guard investigation concluded that the antenna was mistakenly left in the upright position after a test of radios, without the knowledge of the Master, Chief Officer or Pilots.  The pilot card indicated that the vessel's air draft was approximately 146.5 feet when in fact it was approximately 159.1 feet and the air gap at the Bayonne Bridge was approximately 156.6 feet.  The  Master's medical emergency was not an injury related to this incident.  
This incident was referred for enforcement action.

At approximately 2345 on February 12, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel SANDY DRAKE was down-bound at approximate mile 327 on the Ohio River, pushing 15 coal barges.  As the vessel passed underneath the Ironton-Russell Highway Bridge, the vessel got caught in a strong wind and the tow allided with the right bridge pier. 

Coal barge C544 struck the right bridge pier of the bridge and suffered three broken barge wires. The wires were replaced without further incident.  

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between barge C544 and the Ironton-Russell Highway Bridge. The casual factor that contributed to this casualty was the master of the vessel failing to correctly manipulate the vessel under the on-scene weather conditions. The vessel got caught in the wind and the master was unable to recover control prior to striking the bridge.

On 18 February , 2016 at 0310 hours the M/V MARK DOUGHERTY (ACBL, 1075882, 4200HP, 10'1" Draft) was pushing 14 barges down bound at MM 940.8 OHR when the tow was set by strong current, causing the tow to be set and strike the bridge pier on the KY span of the I-24 HWY Bridge. Nine barges broke away they were immediately placed back in the tow. Three barges sustained damage. Drug and Alcohol testing was preformed.  A causal factor in the allision was the strong currents due to high water conditions on the Ohio River.

On 20 FEB 2016 at approximately 2220, the UTV MOBILE was transitting west in the GICWW pushing 2 empty red-flagged barges ahead when it grounded and subsequently allided with the Dauphin Island Bridge with the starboard side of the KIRBY 30004T. As the master was setting up the stacked tow to go under the Bridge, the stern of the MOBILE grounded in the vicinity of Buoy #6. The master then attempted to free the MOBILE from ground and while manuevering the tow, the starboard side of the KIRBY 30004T allided with the east-side North fender of the Bridge. No damage was sustained to either the Bridge or the barge and the vessel was cleared to proceed on its' voyage.

At approximately 1235 CST on Feb 20, 2016 the towing vessel ELIZABETH M. ROBINSON (O.N. 1257752) was heading northbound on the Des Plaines river pushing 2 barges (GM 1011 & GM 3000) when the GM 1011 made contact with the McDonough St. bridge protective cell. The starboard side mid-ships of the GM 1011 made contact. The master stated that winds were sustaining at 15 kts and gusting to 23 at the time of the allision. He said the wind caught him on the port side and blew the tow on to the protective cell. The cell sustained cosmetic damage to the lower rubber portion and the barge did not sustain any damage.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the gusty winds in the vicinity of the McDonough St. bridge.

On March 1, 2016, the empty jumbo hopper barge SJ-199 (O.N. 665820) allided with a charted mooring dolphin at the NuStar Energy facility in Chesapeake, VA and the North Landing Bridge at 0317 and 0322 LMT, respectively.  The allisions occurred while the tug KODIAK (O.N. 637055) was pushing the SJ-199 under the control of the Mate.  The tug and barge were underway on the North Landing River headed north bound from Edenton, NC to Baltimore, MD at a speed of approximately 3.5 knots.  The Mate was operating from the lower wheelhouse during both allisions, with minimal visibility beyond the bow of the barge due to its size.  There was no lookout posted on the barge.  The Mate did not report the marine casualties to the Coast Guard and continued transiting northbound following the allisions.

The allisions resulted in the North Landing Bridge operating on a limited opening schedule, and damage to the mooring dolphin.  The initial damaged estimate was $500,000; however, the most recent repair estimate for the Bridge and the mooring dolphin is approximately $277,322 as of December 13, 2016.  The SJ-199 was also damaged as a result of the allision with the bridge, and was repaired at a cost of $30,996.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the SJ-199 alliding with the mooring dolphin at the NuStar Energy facility mooring dolphin. This was followed by a second allision with the North Landing Bridge.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the lack of training for the Mate, (2) the Mate’s failure to post a proper lookout (3) the lack of recent experience operating as a Mate, (4) the Mate’s failure to operate from the upper wheelhouse, (5) the marine employer’s failure to verify the Mate’s employment history upon hiring him, (6) and the National Maritime Center’s failure to verify the Mate’s sea time upon submission for an increased endorsement as a Mate in charge of a towing vessel.  Fatigue, weather, and equipment failure were all considered in the course of this investigation, but were not found to be causal factors.

At approximately 1118 on February 19, 2016, a crane collapsed aboard RINGER SPUD BARGE #1 at the construction site of the I-265 East End Bridge Project at Ohio River mile marker 595.1, near the Kentucky shore. At the time of the collapse, construction workers were attempting to swing the crane into position for a lift and four persons were aboard RINGER SPUD BARGE #1. One person jumped from the barge into the river and swam ashore.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard (CG) has determined the initiating event was the operation of the crane in high wind conditions. The CG level of investigation is data collections and defers to the OSHA investigation regarding compliance with Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations Parts 1918-1919 and the operations of the crane aboard this uninspected vessel.

At approximately 1500CST on February 28, 2016, the UTV JOE B WARD allided with the west Larose bridge. The allision occurred as the JOE B WARD was making the turn in the channel and the captain hugged the north side of the channel due to construction being conducted on the south side. The wind caught the empty barges and scraped the AEP 7569 STBD last barge on the bridge. At the time of the allision JOE B WARD was PUSHING 6 empty hopper salt barges

The barge AEP 7569 rubbed the bridge on STBD stern and sustained no damage. The west Larose bridge sustained no damage.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was that construction in the area of the bridge makes a choke point in the river and vessels need to move closer to the north side shore which can cause shore suction. This suction will pull the vessel toward the shore.

On February 24th 2016, the M/V MARY ARTIE BRANNON (1044132, Kirby, 3000HP) pushing 15 empty hoppers (3x5) down bound at MM 745.6 OHR when the tow was set by strong current and winds, and struck the left descending bridge pier on the Kentucky bridge support, U.S. 231 Bridges.  Kentucky DOT Engineers determined no damage to bridge and the hopper barge C1143 sustained minor scraps, inset, and broken wires.
As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was unanticipated high winds and higher than normal water levels causing strong current in the river.

At approximately 1235 CST on Feb 20, 2016, the towing vessel Elizabeth M. Robinson was pushing 2 barges (GM 3000 and GM 1011) north bound on the Illinois river. At mile marker 287, the McDonough street Bridge, the starboard side mid-ships made contact with the bridge fendering system. The master stated that the wind was blowing off of his starboard side 15-23 kts. The wind pushed the tow on to the fender. The barge was not damaged; the fender system had cosmetic damage only.

As a result of its investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the casualty was the wind blowing at a speed of 15 gusting to 23 kts. The wind pushed the tow on to the protective cell causing the allision.

Subject vessel underway with 15 empty barges in a 3x5 configuration, downbound on the Ohio River near mile marker 603, traveling at approximately 5.5 MPH.  Subject mariner in command and control of the vessel and her tow.  As the vessel approached the Big 4 pedestrain bridge the subject mariner was battling wind gusts of approximately 29 MPH and the wind sail surface from the empty barges.  Realizing he was too close to the bridge he took actions to avoid an allision.  Unable to prevent an allision the mariner landed (uncontrolled) the starboard string of barges onto the starboard (Right) piling/pier of the channel span of the bridge.  The starboard side of the starboard string scraped the bridge piling/pier.

The investigation into this incident has determined the causal factors to be operator error in navigation with prevailing winds and current conditions of the environment.

On March 9, 2016, at approximately 2240 hrs local the M/V BILL ROGERS (O.N 649344) allided with the left descending bridge pier of highway 6 bridge at Red River MM 152.1 while pushing 6  empty rock barges.  Master was flanking tow south bound at MM 152.5 when current set the tow towards the right descending bank.  The towing vessel (drafting 6 foot) then grounded on a submerged dike along the right descending edge of channel.  The head of tow then set to starboard.  The master unsuccessfully attempted to back down hard astern.  The starboard lead barge then allided with the bridge pier which resulted in the breaking away of the port string.  The M/V BILL ROGERS transited down river and retrieved the three adrift barges at MM 150.5.  The allision resulted in damage to the starboard lead barge’s head log not affecting watertight integrity.  MSD confirmed from the LA DOT that no structural/significant damage to bridge.  Excessive cross current from the old bend way channel above the bridge combined with higher river levels were determined to be contributing factors in this marine casualty.

On February 15, 2016 Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the Uninspected Tow Vessel (UTV) CAPTAIN THOMAS made contact with the fender system of the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge in Amelia, LA. The UTV CAPTAIN THOMAS was pushing two uninspected deck barges at the time of the allision.  The master reported no damages to the barge and minimal damage to the rub rail on the fender system of the bridge.  The bridge is and remains fully operational.

During the Coast Guard Investigation, it was determined that root cause of the allision was poor navigation by the master, and failure to properly account for wind and current.

No injuries or pollution reported.

On March 1, 2016 at approximately 1515 CST, the UTV Lemont Trader was northbound pushing 05 barges (four empty red flag barges, one empty hopper) and transiting under the Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge. A reported cross wind gusted and set the tow towards the right descending protection cell. The starboard lead barge, Tank Barge CBC 373 made contact with the railroad bridge protection cell. The master reported no damage to the CBC 373 or the bridge protection cell. MSU Chicago contacted the bridge owner to alert them of the casualty. The CBC 373 was dropped off at the IMT Channahon fleet where inspectors verified no damage. No damage was observed on the bridge, no injuries, and no pollution resulted from the casualty.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that strong winds and the masters inability to correct course in time were the causal factors for this casualty.

On 12Feb16 @ approximately 1425L, the UTV JACOB MICHAEL ECKSTEIN was transiting the McDonough Street bridge on the Illinois River and pushing the barge MTC 1418B. The operator reported that he was beset by wind and the starboard stern side of the barge landed on the left descending pier (protection cell) of the bridge. No damage to the bridge or barge was reported.  A bridge inspection confirmed no damage. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has concluded that heavy wind was the initiating event for this casualty which resulted in the operator losing control of the vessel.

On 16 March 2016 at approximately 2015, the uninspected towing vessel SUSAN ELIZABETH (O.N. 967990) pushing ahead two barges allided the aft barge, KIRBY 30412 (O.N. 999813), with the starboard fendering system of the Jackson Railroad Bridge in Jackson, Alabama near mile marker 90 on the Tombigbee River. Both barges were loaded with Acrylonitrile (UN 1093).

Damage to KIRBY 30412 includes a 0"-6" by 3 foot vertical fracture to the #2 starboard wing void side shell costing approximately $57,500 in repairs. Damage to Jackson Railroad bridge includes bent and dismantled railing which runs along the outside of the fendering system of bridge. No damage occurred to the SUSAN ELIZABETH or the other barge, KIRBY 28114 (O.N. 1220961). No pollution or injuries resulted.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of KIRBY 30412 with the Jackson Railroad bridge which led to the fracture in the #2 starboard wing void side shell. The casual factor that contributed to this casualty was an error by the Captain in accounting for the effects of the current. There was no causal factor for the fracture of the side shell since it acted as intended to protect the containment of the cargo.

At approximately 1700 CST on March 20, 2016, the UTV Julie White was pushing 8 barges heading north bound at mile marker 287.3 at the McDonough Street bridge. The lead starboard barge made contact with the McDonough Street bridge fender cell. The contact was very slight and a small amount of paint transferred from the barge at the waterline on to the fender rub rail. The crew on the barge could not see any damage to the barge and the bride tender confirmed the small paint transfer.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the loss of situational awareness of the master of his starboard lead barge (ART 965). He stated that he could not see where the barge was in reference to the bridge fender and was un-aware that the barge made contact.

UTV SANDY DRAKE (571855, Crounce Corp, 1800HP) reported while departing Mcalpine L/D down bound, MM 606.8 OHR while pushing 9 barges (3 loaded coal, 6 empty) was set off course by the eddies that are prominent in the area.  The master realized he was not going to clear the Kentucky & Inidian RR bridge (LLNR 26805), MM 607.4 OHR and stopped its way but could not gain astern momentum in time to prevent the allision; the lead starboard barge (empty hopper) came to rest on the bridge pilling.  The lead barge had a scrap on the stbd bow, no inset or puncture. Bridge inspection completed by Norfolk Southern with no report of damage. Vessel continued on it's voyage.

The investigation into this incident has determined the causal factors to be the Master's failure to navigate the vessel with known environmental factors in this area.

On March 6, 2016, a plastic antenna on the top mast of the foreign flagged tank ship SITEAM ANJA struck the Castleton-On-Hudson Highway bridge while the vessel was transiting Northbound on the Hudson River. No damage to the bridge was reported, while the plastic dome on the vessel’s INMARSAT C antenna was broken off by the contact. There were no injuries, pollution, or other damages as a result of this casualty.

Investigating Officers from Sector New York attended the bridge, and verified that there were no obstructions hanging from the bridge or reducing the charted air clearance. The bridge is midway through a wo year painting project, and the navigation channel has been reduced in width from 360 feet to 210 feet. This reduction has been promulgated in the Local Notice to Mariners, and was current as of the NTM issued for week 9 of 2016. Within the reduced-width channel, there is no charted reduction in air clearance below the bridge. This was verified on scene, with all scaffolding and equipment in place higher than the bottom structures of the bridge within the reduced channel. The vessel’s Master and Pilot were aware of the reduced-width channel under the bridge, and navigated the vessel within this channel. 

Investigators also attended the vessel pierside in Albany, NY. Documentation onboard indicated that the INMARSAT C antenna was included in the keel-to-masthead measurement used to calculate air draft. Based on this measurement and the vessel’s ballasting arrangement, the pilot calculated the vessel’s air draft at 132.3 feet, and used this measurement for bridge clearance measurements.

The air clearance under the Castleton-on-Hudson bridge is charted at 135 feet from Mean High Water. There is no NOAA water level measurement available for this location, however NOAA does promulgate tide predictions for Hudson, NY, which is just upstream of the bridge. According to the tide prediction, on March 6, 2016 there was a high tide at approximately 1346. Review of the tide prediction table indicates that the water level at the time of the allision (1444), was approximately 5 feet higher than Mean Lower Low Water. Using these numbers, it was established that the vessel transited under the bridge anticipating approximately 2.9 feet of clearance between the highest mast and the bridge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that it is most likely that the actual water level at the time of the allision was higher than the predicted level. In the absence of actual measurements, the actual water level cannot be verified. However, there is no evidence that the measurements that the vessel provided for the air draft calculation were inaccurate. As a result, no enforcement action was taken against the vessel. Ideally, the Pilot and Master would wait until a lower water level to transit under a bridge. Unfortunately, the Hudson River transit has many points where there are restrictions on draft and/or air draft. Although vessels can speed up or slow down to change the time that they encounter a restriction, large seagoing vessels cannot stop and wait at most points in the transit, since the navigable waterway is too narrow to swing at anchor. With a vessel this large operating with such small margins for error, even a relatively minor deviation from the predicted water level would have been enough to result in the antenna contacting the bridge. By process of elimination, higher than predicted water level is the most likely pre-condition that led to this casualty.

On 24MAR16 at approximately 0330, the T/B SEA CREST was tied to the UTV PACIFIC DAWN's port side and they were approaching the Huey P. Long Bridge. The UTV PACIFIC DAWN reported another UTV, STEPHEN R WARDEN, heading in the opposite direction came within 50 ft. of the UTV PACIFIC DAWN. The wake created by the UTV STEPHEN R WARDEN caused water wash on the deck of the UTV PACIFIC DAWN and the forward line affixed to the T/B SEA CREST to part. Once the forward line parted, the bow began to veer away from the UTV PACIFIC DAWN and the remaining two lines parted. Shortly after the lines parted the port side of the barge struck the center piling of the Huey P. Long bridge. The barge was collected by the UTV PACIFIC DAWN and brought to Buck Kreihs facility where surveyors found a 2 inch hole in the bilge knuckle of the #7 void which allowed water ingress.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the parting of the three tow lines between the UTV PACIFIC DAWN and TB SEA CREST.

On March 25th, 2016 the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) LADY LAUREN was transiting through the Morgan City Railroad bridge on the Atchafalaya River, Morgan City, LA. The UTV captain was set by the wind with reported gusts up to 22mph. The lead starboard barge brushed up against the hydro cushion of the Morgan City Railroad bridge. The vessel backed down, adjusted position and successfully transited through with no notable damage to the vessel or bridge.

On March 25, 2016, TENNESSEE HUNTER (625977, 4300HP, Hunter Marine) was down bound at mile marker 63.1 on the Tennessee river pushing 15 empty dry cargo barges in a 3 x 5 configuration. While navigating thru the Henry R Lawrence bridge the starboard lead barge allided with the construction work platforms. There was no damage to the barge, however there was damage to the construction platforms. The master stated he was set into the platform by wind. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the master's loss of situational awareness navigating a tow of 15 empty barges in high winds. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) high winds, (2) high wind sail on empty barges (3) loss of situational awareness by the master

At approximately 0504 EST on April 04, 2016, the container ship CSCL AFRICA allided with the Bayonne Bridge, while entering Kill Van Kull. At the time of the allision, the CSCL AFRICA was loaded with various containers. 

The Bayonne Bridge was struck in the center region at the lower part of the bridge by the AM Radio Whip antenna of the vessel.  This antenna is located just starboard of midships atop the vessel’s superstructure.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined, navigating toward the bridge with the AM antenna in the upright position, caused this event.  This was due to the miscalculation of the airdraft.

On 06 April, 2016 at 0330 hrs the M/V MICHAEL G MORRIS (1078466, ACBL, 8000HP) was pushing 30 loaded grain barges (6 X 5) down bound at MM 43.7 UMR. The river stage was at 26.96 on the Cape G gauge. Reported weather was 42 degrees with 9 miles of visibility and winds were 13 MPH WSW with gust up to 29. The current was flowing at 3 to 4 mph. The vessel was traveling at 8 mph. The Pilot was on watch when he attempted to navigate a 110 degree turn and then attempted to pass through the Thebes Railroad bridge span. The Pilot was flanking the bend, then began pushing ahead to give headway.  To counteract the slide, he pointed the head of the tow towards the left hand pier. His speed over ground was 8 mph. The head of the tow became hung up in slack water under the point so he started to back down hard on the starboard MDE but the head of the tow continued to hang up in slack water and began to swing to port.  The vessel and tow continued down bound when the port side of the tow struck the left hand pier of the Thebes R/R Bridge span causing all 30 barges to be set adrift.  The barge AEP 3117 sank on the bridge pier and barge LF 114 sank in the middle of the channel at MM 42 and eventually recovered.  The other 28 barges grounded further down river, with 16 total barges sustaining minor damaged. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the allision with the bridge pier at Thebes Railroad Bridge located at mm 43.7 Upper Mississippi River. Casual factors include 1) Human error exacerbated by pilot's unfamiliarity with the vessel. Pilot was not familiar with the vessels turn rate and mistimed his approach by allowing the head of the tow to get in slack water which did not allow for the head to swing at a faster rate; 2) Waterway condition.  Pilot did not account properly for the decrease turn rate from slack water.  River stage was 26.96 ft with 9 miles of visibility and winds were 13 MPH WSW.

M/V FRED LEE was north bound RED River MM 84 at the KANSAS SOUTHERN RR Bridge pushing a crane barge BG 9502 with the spuds up and hit the bottom of the bridge. The Army Corp contacted the RR who sent out inspectors and the bridge was open for RR traffic. The Barge suffered bent spuds as a result.

On March 18, 2016 at approximately 0020, the UTV SHERRYL B REEVES allided with the Sabula Railroad Bridge while transiting through the bridge. The UTV SHERRYL B REEVES made contact with the upper protection cell of the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barges, or barge. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On April 7, 2016 at approximately 0112, the UTV CITY OF CASSVILLE allided with the Dubuque Railroad Bridge while transiting southbound on the Upper Mississippi River. The UTV CITY OF CASSVILLE tow made contact with the right descending pier of the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barges, or barge.

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

At approximately 1525 CST on April 13, 2016, the UTV harvest Run was pushing 5 barges, 2 open hopper and 3 red flag heading south bound on the Illinois river. At mile marker 254.1 as the tow passed under the Chessie Rail Road Bridge the starboard forward open hopper barge (ING 493) made contact with the bridges right protection cell. The master stated that the wind was blowing 8-10 kts off his port side and the wind pushed his tow on to the protection cell. No damage was reported to the cell or the barge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event for this casualty was the master was unable to control the tow in the prevailing wind conditions as he passed under the bridge.

On March 18, 2016 at approximately 0020, the UTV SHOW ME STATE allided with the KEOKUK HWY BRIDGE while transiting northbound. The UTV SHOW ME STATE made contact with the protection cell of the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barge or barge. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On March 18, 2016 at approximately 0045, the UTV PENNY ECKSTEIN allided with the Clinton Iowa Railroad Bridge while transiting through the bridge. The UTV PENNY ECKSTEIN made contact with the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barges, or barge. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On March 8, 2016, the towing vessel TAURUS, pushing ahead the loaded tank barge DBL 22, ran aground as it was transiting through the Pleasure Beach Bridge south span in Bridgeport, CT.  The grounding of the tug caused the barge to swing and allide with the center span of the bridge, causing damage to a fixed navigation light on the bridge and the destruction of several fender timbers.  The bridge is not operational and has been out of service for many years.  Surveys were condicted on both vessels: there was no damage to either the tug or the barge outside of paint scrapes to the hull of the barge.  The tug was able to work free from the grounding and safely transit with the barge to the Global fuel facility on Johnson's Creek.  It was high tide at the time of the transit.  

CG Sector Long Island Sound has a Safety Zone in place for transits through the Pleasure Beach Bridge due to the condition of the center span of the bridge, and the narrow openings.  There have been fewer tug/barge transits within the last 30-60 days, which could have resulted in shifting sandbars not being effected by vessel movements.  The TAURUS and DBL 22 were making a good approach through the bridge, and the grounding was most likely caused by shifting sandbars in the area.

On April 21, 2016 at approximately 1655, The UTV MARY K CAVARRA  allided with the Sabula Railroad Bridge while transiting up bound. The UTV MARY K CAVARRA made contact with the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barges, or barge. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On March 21, 2016 at approximately 2330, while transiting down bound on the Upper Mississippi River, UTV THOMAS K allided with the ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD DRAWBRIDGE (DUBUQUE)at MM 579.9. THOMAS K was pushing 9 loaded grain barges when the middle barge on the starboard string made contact with the bridge causing damage to the bottom of the bow rake that was deemed under the reportable property damage threshold and did not affect the barges fitness for service. Voyage was continued and no pollution or injuries occurred.
The ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD DRAWBRIDGE (DUBUQUE) remained functional and damage estimate for the property damage to the bridge was not provided to Coast Guard Marine Safety Detachment Quad Cities.

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On April 18, 2016 at approximately 1100 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel SHARPS ISLAND (O.N. 296459) was transiting Southbound on the Elizabeth River, Virginia enroute to Chesapeake Grain in Chesapeake, Virginia. The vessel was towing astern the dredge TANGIER  SOUND (O.N. 297588), which had a small undocumented work barge and work tug MISS ASHLEY (O.N. 1268569) tied off to its starboard side. The uninspected towing vessel MAVERICK (O.N. 510611) was positioned off the TANGIER SOUND’s port stern to serve as an assist vessel as directed by the master of the SHARPS ISLAND. While making the voyage the small work barge allided with the west fendering wall of Gilmerton Bridge resulting in approximately $23,000 in damage to the fendering wall and MAVERICK. 

The small work barge struck a section of rubber fender on the lower portion of the west fender wall, resulting in approximately $5,000 in damage to the fender system. There was no damage to the small work barge or the small work tug MISS ASHLEY.  Following the allision, the small work barge and the TANGIER SOUND ricocheted towards the eastern fender wall and the cutter head of the dredge collided with the upper deck of the MAVERICK resulting in approximately $18,000 in damage to the vessel. 

As a result of its investigation, The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the west fender wall as the vessel proceeded through the bridge, which negatively impacted the vessel’s positioning between the fendering systems. The subsequent event to this was the collision between the cutterhead of the dredge and the upper deck of the MAVERICK after ricocheting off of the fendering wall due to the allision. During the course of the investigation, fatigue and distraction by use of electronic devices were not determined to be causal factors in this marine casualty. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) The master’s failure to properly align the tow prior to transiting between the fendering system (2) the master’s lack of recent experience operating on the Elizabeth River, and (3) the lack of communication between both masters regarding the roles and positioning during the transit.

At approximately, 1800 CST on April 19, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel CARLY MICHELLE allided with the Dulac Pontoon Bridge fendering system. CARLY MICHELLE (O.N. 633211) was towing a new construction/non-certificated lift boat, WHISKEY STAR XIX, astern, headed south bound on the Houma Navigation Canal with the MR. ROLAND, an assist tug following behind. The collision occurred as the CARLY MICHELLE was transiting through the Dulac Pontoon Bridge. 

The WHISKEY STAR XIX is 110' wide, the channel width is 179' wide and the bridge fendering system reduces channel clearance to approximately 135'. The CARLY MICHELLE was transiting at 2.8 mph and there was a 15kt East wind. While transiting through the Dulac Pontoon Bridge, the wind set the starboard bow of the WHISKY STAR XIX onto the northwest fender system causing damages to the timbers and pilings of the fender system and minor damages to the WHISKY STAR XIX. The total reportable damages to the bridge totaled, $58,600, which does not meet the criteria for a Serious Marine Incident. 

The causes of the allision were 1) a mismatch between the Master and the environment. The 15 kt winds pushed the tow into the bridge fendering system. 2) A planning error. The Master applied a general rule of thumb and transited through the bridge at 2.8 kts. The large size of the tow, wind speed and navigable width should have been factors for the Master to adjust speed or other factor of ship handling.

At approximately 0320 CST on April 28, 2016, the UTV W. Stanley James was unable to make headway due to the strong current as they approached the Jackson St bridge (MM 288.3) on the Illinois River. As they passed under the bridge, the current set the tow to starboard. The head starboard barge (ACBL 3296) made contact on the starboard side midships of the barge with the fender of the bridge. No damage was noted to the bridge or the barge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the current pushing the tow to starboard onto the bridge protection cell.

On April 11, 2016 at approx. 21:00 the UTV LINDSEY ANN ERICKSON was transitting northbound under the Louisiana RR Bridge on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) MM 282.1 when the port barge third row, (AEP 7236), rubbed the sheer fence on the bridge.

At approximately 1800 EST on April 12, 2016, the fishing vessel JANE CAROLYN (1041448) was transiting southbound on Bogue Sound when the vessel allided with the fendering system of the Morehead City High Rise Bridge. The incident occurred as the vessel was preparing to transit under the bridge, the operator of the vessel lowered the outriggers in order to clear the air gap of the bridge. As the vessel was transiting through the fendering system, the operator did not realize that the vessel was getting too close to the west side fendering syatem when the cabling for the vessels rigging became entangled on the fendering system. The allision caused the trawl door to fell overboard. The vessel cleared the bridge and lowered the outriggers to recover/reel in the trawl door. The trawl door was recovered and the vessel continued with its voyage without further incidents. There were no damages to the vessel and/or the bridge’s fendering system.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the fendering system which caused the vessel to get tangled up with the fendering system. The weather was not a contributing factor in this casualty. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty were: (1) the operator misjudged the distance of the vessel with the fendering system while transiting through the bridge, and (2) complacency, since the operator has transited through the same bridge/fendering system many times in the past.

On 05 May, 2016, Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) ST PAUL (O.N. 1239322) was traveling northbound on the Atchafalaya River pushing four red flagged barges when it experienced an equipment failure on the port side tow wires resulting in an unsecured barge, which caused a bridge allision. The barges were secured by an assist tug and the parted wires were replaced in kind.

There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident.

On 5 MAY 2016 at approximately 1800 CST, the towing vessel INLAND CARDINAL (O.N. 579633), pushing ahead 2 loaded hopper barges, 2 loaded utility barges, and the dredge KELLY L (O.N. 270737), allided with the Bob Sykes Bridge in Pensacola, FL on the GICWW MM 189. Vessel was headed west from Port St. Joe, FL to Mobile, AL when the port facing wire connecting the INLAND CARDINAL with its' tow snapped while transiting through the Bridge. This caused the master to be unable to fully maneuver the tow through the bridge and the starboard stern of the KELLY L, on the port side of the tow, to allide with the south port fendering system damaging both the fendering system and the dredge. Estimated damage cost to barge was $8,000 to repair and to repair the bridge fender system $21,740. No further incident to report.

The Coast Guard investigation determined the initiating event of the allision was the port facing wire connecting to the KELLY L breaking while the tow was being navigated through the bridge. The casual factors that contributed were the condition on the port facing wire and location when wire broke.

On 10MAR2016, MSD Lake Worth Received a phone call from Beyel Bros reporting an allision between the Tug vessel Brittany Beyel (and barge JMC-140)with the Roosevelt Railway Bridge in Stuart, FL. The initial report was no damage to the actual bridge and only minor damage to southeaster side of the fendering system. Additionally, there is no damage to the tug or barge and no personnel injuries.
The Tug was getting ready to transit the narrow bridge channel when weather conditions shifted and the barge contacted the fendering system. The channel is 45 ft wide and the barge is 40 ft wide which leaves very little room to maneuver.

UTV STONE STRAIT while transiting downbound pushing 20 barge at mm 109.9 upper mississippi river allided with left descending bank pier of the Chester Highway bridge channel span due to reported river conditions. Minor damage to port stern barge; no pollution or injuries reported.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the allision with the bridge.  Contributing factors include 1) High water conditions on the upper mississippi river; 2) Master situational awareness determining the speed and strength of the set; and 3) Potential overconfidence as master was used to bigger tows and had less barges this transit.

Pilot is well seasoned with near two decades of experience as a pilot and is an experienced heavy tow pilot on the Mississippi River.  Investigation complete with no further action anticipated.

At approximately 1230 CDT on May 11, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel FRED A SETTOON pushing ahead a deck barge loaded with scrap metal, allided with the northwest section of the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge fendering system, causing minor damage to one of the wooden stringers.

The vessel was on a southbound transit making approximately .5 knots, transiting through the bridge opening when she allided with the bridge. The width of the barge was 54 feet, with an additional 8 inches for tire fenders on each side of the barge. The horizontal clearance of the bridge opening was 56 feet in length. 

As a result of the investigation, it was identified that due to the size of the barge compared to the size of the horizontal clearance, the probability of not rubbing against the fendering system is improbable and was expected by the master as there are only 4 inches of clearance on each side of the barge as it transits through the bridge opening.

There was no report of vessel damage or reported injuries.

On April 25,2016, the CAROLINE N (O.N. 546688) was up bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282 pushing 16 empty hopper barges, when the port stern barge ACL 33246 (O.N. 1252632) allided with the left descending side of the turntable bridge.

On May 9, 2016 @ approximately 1030L, SLM CC received notification that the empty T/B KIRBY 27722 allided with the 92nd Street Bridge, MM332.4 on the Calumet River, while en route to BP Whiting Facility, IN and being pushed by the UTV MELINDA BRENT. The operator stated that "the wind was blowing steadily", so they "backed down the engines and let the wind push them into the bridge." There were no initial reported injuries, pollution, or damage. Notifications were made to the 92nd Street Bridge Tender of the allision. The 92nd Street Bridge stated they would not be able to open until their inspectors came out to survey the bridge. MSU Chicago CDO conducted telephone interview and directed the vessel to redirect to fleeting facility in Blue Island, IL. 

MSU Chicago Marine Inspectors attended barge with the Captain while moored starboard side along the long wall at T.J. O'Brien Lock and Dam in Chicago, IL to conduct damage survey. 
Examined barge from waterline on starboard side and bow from the long wall at the lock and dam. Visually inspected voids from open deck level. Noted 12" scrapes on portside bow rake wrapper with no apparent damage. Noted 6' x 3' deep scrape located on the portside at the #6 port void between 8' and 10' draft line. Unable to determine extent of damage from exterior inspection. Issued CG-835 requesting gas free certificate for the void to allow entry and verification of possible damage to sideshell.

10MAY16: Received notification from a representative from Kirby Marine that barge will be gas free and available for inspection at Full Circle Marine. Marine Inspector attended barge with Kirby Representative at Full Circle Marine. Verified Marine Chemist Certificate for #6 portside void. Upon entry, 1 side chord twisted and 2 angles tripped. No repair required; instructed to complete repairs at next ISE. Cleared CG-835. Because repairs were not required until next ISE, vessel damage dollar amount was not assessed.  

As a result of its investigation, the CG has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the wind that beset the tug and tow into the bridge fendering system.  This resulted in the barge sustaining damage to the #6 portside void.

Commercial fishing vessel MISS RITA's antenna struck the John's Pass Bridge during it's inbound transit.  The bridge is a 4 leaf draw bridge, and only 1 leaf was up at the time of the incident.  The MISS RITA called ahead to report it's inbound transit.  When the bridge operator went to raise the bridge, a breaker tripped resulting in the bridge not raising in time for the MISS RITA to transit under.  The MISS RITA attempted to back down, but could not stop forward momentum by that time.  The MISS RITA's antenna hit the bottom of the bridge and broke off as a result.  There was no damage to the bridge.  There was no pollution, injuries, or waterway restrictions.

At approximately 1820 CST on May 19, 2016 the UTV Eileen C was pushing three empty dry cargo barges south bound on the Des Plaines River at MM 288.7. The pilot reported, as the tow passed under the Cass Street Bridge the lead barge NB 1741B starboard side made contact with the protection cell, due to a gust of wind.

No damage was reported to either the barge, or the protection cell. No report of any pollution or injuries.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was wind conditions. The subsequent event was the barge alliding with the protection cell.

At approximately 2100 CST on May 28, 2016 the SPV Star of Chicago was heading south bound on the Chicago River, senior deckhand at the helm with 31 passengers on board. As they approached the Adams St Bridge MM 325.1, the Senior Deck hand cautioned the master who was standing on the starboard side of the bridge that they were set towards the starboard side of the channel. The deckhand steered to starboard because of a construction barge on the left side of the channel. The deckhand stated that the master did not say anything in response. A short time later the master responded, stating that they were going to hit the bridge. The aft frame on the starboard side canopy made contact with the bridge and then became dislodged hitting to passengers, a male involved party on the top of his head and a female in the forehead. The involved party's parents refused medical treatment and the involved party was taken to the hospital for treatment of a laceration to her forehead. The Master took the helm and returned the vessel back to it's mooring at Ogden Slip. EMS arrived on scene and took the injured passenger to Northwestern Hospital.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the Master not maintaining direction and control of the vessel. This was followed by the eventual bridge allision and passenger injury.

UTV RAYMOND GRANT ECKSTEIN was transiting south bound pushing 15 empty dry cargo barges when the 2nd barge in the port string allided with the Centennial Hwy Bridge. Wind caused the tow to bump into the upriver right descending pier of the bridge. The allision caused the barge BUNGE 736 to ground on the Iowa side of the river. UTV CLEVA LEE assisted and pulled BUNGE 736 off ground. Tow was rewired and all barges were looked over. No damage, pollution, or injuries were discovered. After replacing coupling and looking over the barges, vessel was cleared to continue its voyage. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the winds the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

On June 1, 2016 at approximately 2315, the UTV SIERRA DAWN allided with the Clinton Railroad Bridge while transiting southbound on the Upper Mississippi River. The UTV SIERRA DAWN made contact with the bridge with no reportable property damage reported to the tow boat, barges, or barge. 

This investigation determined that the master mistimed the passing through the bridge and made a minor contact.

At approximately 1600 CST on March 9, 2016, uninspected towing vessel CSS TEXAS was transiting southbound on the Lower Mississippi River, when it experienced an allision with the Huey P. Long Bridge at MM 104, causing damage to the fendering system of the bridge pier, and minor damage to 1 loaded dry cargo barge.

The CSS TEXAS was transiting downbound, piloted by the Relief Captain and pushing 4 barges total: 2 dry cargo barges (MTC 711 and JKM 6410) loaded with petroleum coke as her port string of barges, and 2 empty chemical barges (CDC 34 and RCT 9) on her starboard string.  The Relief Captain put the vessel on a similar track line as in the past to set up the tow and vessel to navigate through the main navigational span of the Huey P. Long Bridge, and was flanking the turn as he set up to transit the bridge.  The wind was gusting intermittently up to 50 knots from the east to the west.  One such gust caught the vessel and its tow and set the vessel sliding toward the Left Descending Bank of the river, and towards Pier II of the bridge.
