The Relief Captain attempted to steer out of the situation, and put the vessel hard to starboard, full ahead.  The sustained gust of wind kept setting the vessel to port, and the port string of barges struck the rubber fendering/bumpering system of Pier II, causing damage both above and below the waterline. Repairs were effected at a cost of $12,947. Damage to the barge JKM 6410 in way of the #4 wing void, and on the bilge knuckle in way of the #3 and #4 wing voids estimated at $5,000.

Note: Pier II was struck and damaged 1 time prior to this allision, on January 12, 2016, and once after on March 24, 2016. New Orleans Public Belt Railroad is responsible for the upkeep and repairs of the bridge, and was waiting for the high water conditions that have prevailed since early January to subside before making a full assessment of the damages and making repairs to the bridge, thus why damage was compounding on top of damage.  Though an initial assessment was made of the total bridge damages (dated March 11, 2016) and a total cost estimate was provided for the allisions occurring prior to the one on March 24, 2016, the final assessment was successfully made in May.  Each allisions’ damage cost was itemized to show each incident cost as though repairs would have been affected totally separate from each other on each occasion.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating even for this casualty was the allision. Contributing factors to the allision included 1) the gusting wind conditions that set the CSS TEXAS sideways unexpectedly, 2) the Relief Captain underestimating the strength and sustainability of the gusting wind, and 3) the Relief Captain not leaving extra room to account for the unpredictability of the prevailing conditions.

This incident met the criteria for a reportable marine casualty & an Informal Investigation/Data Collection was conducted.

On 03JUN16 the UTV BRUCE L. HAHN was navigating up-bound UMR around MM 699.8. Vessel was pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges, while transiting through the LaCrosse Railroad Swing Bridge, the port stern barge, LTD 14174B, allided with a man-walkway handrail and rubbed against the protective sheer fencing below the man-walkway, damaging the man-walkway handrail at approximately 1644.  Voyage continued with a scratch in paint on port side of barge LTD 14174B and no other damage, pollution, or injuries.  Draft is reported as 9'.

At approximately 1430 EST on May 21, 2016, the Commercial Fishing Vessel JAIME MAE allided with the Middle Thorofare Bridge locally known as the Two Mile Bridge. The JAIME MAE was returning to port following a fishing trip.

The JAIME MAE's stbd outrigger was bent when it struck the bridge. This caused the forward stay to part and the cables associated snap back caused the cable to strike and damage the open array radar antenna. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the vessel's outrigger striking the bottom of the bridge. The causal factor that contributed to this was oil leaking from the bridge's motor contaminating the brake drum allowing the bridge to unintentionally drift downward.

SPV PALM BREEZE allided with the Haven M. Ashe Bridge (aka. Boca Inlet Bridge) while transiting back to Boca Raton Resort & Club.  According to all parties involved, the SPV PALM BREEZE and ISLAND BREEZE were coming back after a day of sailing and the bridge tender acknowledged the request for bridge opening only after asked again by the SPV PALM BREEZE.  The SPV ISLAND BREEZE had requested the bridge opening prior to the SPV ISLAND BREEZE yet was not acknowledged by the tender.  Apparently the bridge tender started the bridge closure after the SPV ISLAND BREEZE has passed not allowing the SPV PALM BREEZE to clear the bridge thus being the cause of the allision.

On June 04, 2016 at approximately 1631 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel PAMLICO (O.N. 504262) was transiting Northbound on the North Landing River enroute to Colonna’s Shipyard, Norfolk, Virginia. While making the voyage the barge allided with the North Span fendering wall and South Span of the North Landing Bridge, resulting in approximately $13,200 in damage to the fendering wall and vessel. The allision occurred as the vessel was making its way through the bridge, which only had one span open at the time of the casualty. 

The vessel struck the right corner of the South Bridge Span at the vessel Port beam bulwarks, resulting an approximately 18” by 2” inset and a puncture of approximately 2 inches of the bulwarks resulting in $3,200 in damage.  As a result of the allision with the South Span, the bridge sustained approximately $10,000 in damage. 

As a result of its investigation, The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the North Span fendering wall as the vessel proceeded through the North Landing Bridge, which negatively impacted the vessel’s positioning between the fendering system and South Span of the bridge. The subsequent events to this were the vessel’s allision with the bridge’s South Span and subsequent damage to both the vessel and bridge span. During the course of the investigation, fatigue and distraction by use of electronic devices were not determined to be casual factors in this marine casualty. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) Inadequate pre-voyage planning which failed to take into account encountered bridges and their operating conditions and parameters for the upcoming voyage (2) The master’s failure to review the most recent Local Notice to Mariners prior to commencing the voyage, and (3) the mate on watch’s decision to proceed through the single span opening.

Recommend this incident investigation activity be closed with a referal to an enforcement activity.

On June 13, 2016, at approximately 1250, the UTV KIM W NOWELL (O.N. 503877) was underway south bound on the Upper Mississippi River when it allided with the CLINTON R/R BRIDGE at MM 518.  Vessel was pushing 06 barges in a 2X3 configuration, when the starboard stern barge allided with the CLINTON R/R BRIDGE. The Master was on watch in command and control of the vessel at the time of the allision. 

The allision caused a hole in the #4 wing tank of the IN 995465 barge resulting the void taking on water. Vessel deployed 04 dewatering pumps to combat flooding. No other damage to the remaining barges, equipment or bridge was discovered. Damage to the IN 995465 barge was estimated at 30,000.00.  As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the allision was a caused due to the vessel master's miscalculation of his approach through the Clinton Railroad Bridge.

On June 9, 2016, the uninspected towing vessel Mister T was transiting southbound in the Hutchinson River when her mast struck the Hutchinson River Parkway Bridge. There was no damage to the bridge as a result of the allision, onboard the vessel the aluminum mast snapped near the base and required repairs. There were no injuries, pollution, or other damage as a result of the incident.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the allision was caused by the Mate on watch’s decision to raise the retractable mast before the vessel passed under the bridge.

On 23 June 2016, at approximately 1500 the LADY LAUREN (O.N.1217499) departed Biloxi, MS. South bound in the Biloxi Bay en-route New Orleans, La, pushing ahead four unloaded barges; barge configuration was 2 wide by 2 long, previously loaded with lime stone. Approximately 20 minutes into their transit they approached the Biloxi Bay Bridge, visibility was clear and wind was out of the South-South/West at 15-20 knots. The Captain lined up his approach south bound with both engines engauged ahead at 1.5 knots and the bridge off his starboard bow. As the Captain attempted to maneuver the vessel through the bridge the wind speed started to pick up and there was a gust of wind approximately 20 knots that caused the stern port barge MTC227B (O.N. 982867) to contact the fendering system midway down the barge's port side. 
After the allision the Captain of the LADY LAUREN maneuvered the barges and the tug through the remainder of the bridge. The vessel's crew inspected the barge for damage and found none and the Bridge tender reported only minor scrapping to the pier protection fence. The LADY LAUREN continued on to New Orleans with no further incidents.

On June 27, 2016 at 0911L, SCC MD-NCR received a report that M/V The Osprey allided with the north fender system of the 14th Street Bridge in Washington DC. 

The Osprey’s forward portside railing was bent, forward light was broken and knee brace was damaged. 

The Master and the deckhand, also his son, were onboard without passengers. They sustained bruises from the allision and there were no serious injuries. 

A vessel alliding with a bridge in a navigable channel is a reportable marine casualty as stated in 46 CFR. Instead of notifying the Coast Guard after the Master arrived at the pier and all safety concerns were addressed, he waited until the next morning to notify the Coast Guard. 

DC Department of Training Asset Management who is responsible for the bridge was contacted. 

On June 29, 2016, a welder conducted repairs to the port side front corner of The Osprey and vessel is fully operational.

On May 22, 2016, the UTV CORAL DAWN (O.N. 512092) was northbound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282.1 pushing 15 empty dry cargo hopper barges. The master did not contact the LOUISIANA R/R BRIDGE prior to transiting through the bridge span that the vessel was going to conduct a controlled landing. The port stern barge of the tow rubbed the turntable protection cell.

On June 17, 2016, the UTV LEE ANN INGRAM was northbound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282.2 pushing 16 barges tow. The vessel was transiting through the bridge span when the port stern barge, (IN075174) located on the hip of the towing vessel landed on the protection pier of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge.

On June 27, 2016, at approximately 0710 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel ALEXANDER DUFF (O.N. 633594) was pushing the deck barge DOUBLE SKIN 14 (O.N. 541136) while transiting northbound on the Elizabeth River to Sewell’s Point Anchorage. The on scene weather conditions consisted of an air temperature of 76 degrees Fahrenheit with fog. The Elizabeth River was at ebb tide with a current speed of 0.5 knots. While transiting through the Old Virginia Railroad Bridge, the barge’s starboard quarter allided with the eastern side of the bridge’s wooden fendering system, resulting in no damage to the bridge’s fendering system or the barge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the vessel's turn to port approximately 600 feet away from the Old Virginia Railroad Bridge, causing the vessel to line up east of its intended track for transiting through the Old Virginia Railroad Bridge. The subsequent event to this was the barge’s allision with the bridge’s fendering system. During the course of the investigation, fatigue and distraction by use of electronic devises were not determined to be causal factors in this marine casualty. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the restricted visibility due to fog and (2) the impact of the ebb current on the ALEXANDER DUFF’s tow.

On June 30, 2016 at approximately 0025, the UTV DENISE T DELANEY (O.N. 536790) was underway south bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 481.4, pushing 15 barges in a 3X5 configuration, when the stbd #2 barge allided with the crescent rail road bridge. The pilot was on watch in command and control of the vessel at the time of the grounding. 

The ING7751 (O.N. 1074478) was the barge that allided with the crescent rail road bridge. The ING7751 allided causing a 10" fracture in the barge below the waterline, which resulted in a $2500 repair. The barge was temporarily repaired utilizing shingles.

On June 18, 2016, the M/V ARABELLA was in transit on the Corpus Christi Channel to Interstate Grain Dock in the inner harbor.  When the Pilot came onboard at anchor the vessel’s air draft was discussed and it was determined the vessel had to take on ballast to get an adequate draft to pass under the Corpus Christi Harbor Bridge.  The Captain did not want to go to anchor so he instead chose to proceed inbound and take on ballast while in transit.  The Pilot agreed and the vessel was cleared for entry.  

To increase the vessel’s draft, ballast was placed in the #3 aft peak tank.  Assist tugs standing by provided draft readings as the vessel approached the bridge and gave a final draft that seemed adequate for clearance.  While passing underneath the bridge, the vessel’s INMARSAT antenna struck the span.  The antenna broke off of its pole and fell to the deck below.  The vessel maintained all navigational capabilities and proceeded to dock without any further issues.  There were no injuries, pollution, or other damage.  A technician was able to replace the antenna and restore all INMARSAT functions.  The bridge was not damaged.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the Captain to ensure adequate air draft with the known bridge height.  Prior to entering anchorage, the vessel had cleaned all cargo tanks in preparation of loading operations.  The Captain did not want to place ballast in a cargo tank and have to re-clean.  Instead, he chose to take on ballast in a limited time frame after the Pilot insisted.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:

1) The Captain failed to adequately prepare his vessel for entry into port to account for all known situations.  The Captain did not use all available information to ensure safe passage.  Only until the Pilot insisted the vessel take on ballast did the Captain consider the proper air draft.

2)  The Captain did not want to delay entry into port by staying at anchorage and take on adequate ballast for acceptable vessel draft.  Instead, he chose to take on ballast while in transit.  This reduced the ability of the assist tugs to provide accurate draft readings.

On May 17, 2016,the UTV DENNIS T DELANEY was upbound at approx. mile 281.1 on the UMR transiting under the Louisiana R/R Bridge pushing 12 empty and 3 loaded dry cargo hopper barges when the port stern barge of the tow landed on the sheer fence of the Louisiana R/R Bridge.  There was no damage to the barge or sheer fence of the bridge.

On 12JUL16 the UTV CALVIN J STEWART was navigating down bound UMR around MM 835. Vessel was pushing 07 empty dry cargo barges, while transiting through the Pigs Eye Railroad Bridge, the starboard stern barge allided with and rubbed against the protective sheer fencing, the wind and current pushed the tow off the intended route.  Voyage continued with no damage, pollution, or injuries.  Draft is reported as 7'.

On 15 July, 2016 at approximately 1625 LT the UTV KODIAK with 3 barges in tow made its approach through the fendering system of the Bridge of Lions in St. Augustine, FL headed southbound in the ICW for Tampa, FL. The UTV KODIAK was the lead tug with the UTV COASTAL TRADER as the stern assist tug. THE UTV KODIAK approached the bridge at about 1.5 kts holding high towards the port fendering system as the SW wind was setting the vessel and barges to the starboard. The Captain of the UTV KODIAK attempted to adjust the vessel and tug but the wind continued to set the vessel towards the fendering system, causing the first barge to allide with the NE (port) fendering system. The second barge shifted to port and caught the corner of the port fender system with the bow. Post-casualty drug and alcohol testing was conducted with negative results.
Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that wind was a causal factor for the vessel/barges alliding with the bridge fendering system.

On June 22, 2015, Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) Dickie Gonsoulin (O.N. 1245164) was pushing two loaded barges through Morgan City, LA, when the starboard quarter of the UTV allided with the Morgan City Railroad Bridge and resulted in the parting of a face wire. 

There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident. The bridge was also undamaged.

081909Z JUL 16: UTV ARTHUR E SNYDER (272142, 3200HP, Excell Marine) reported while transiting down bound MM 41.7 TNR in a 3X5 configuration (15 empties) when they became set by the wind causing their starboard string to allide with the old Eggners Ferry Bridge right descending pier. UTV reported the allision occurred at the coupling causing wires in the tow to break. No other damage, pollution, or injuries were reported. SCC contacted KYDOT. Due to bridge no longer in service no inspector will be sent. MSU Paducah MDO is conducting phone investigation to further evaluate the situation.

On 27JUN16 at approximately 1515 the UTV BILL STEGBAUER was navigating up-bound the UMR around MM 699.8. Vessel was pushing 15 empty dry cargo barges, while transiting through the LaCrosse Railroad Swing Bridge, the port stern barge, MTC 332, allided and rubbed against the protective sheer fencing.  The UTV STEGBAUER incured approximately $8,500 damage to a port rolling chalk for a tow wire, the crew replaced the rolling chalk with a spare and continued with a no further damage, pollution, or injuries.  Draft is reported as 1'.

On 13 June 2016 at approximately 1445, the towing vessel, KEN WEWA STRICKLAND, allided with the Judge Perez Bridge (Belle Chasse) on the Algiers Canal. While traveling east bound on the Algiers Canal pushing one loaded hopper barge, the mast of the UTV KEN WEWA STRICKLAND allided with the bottom of the Judge Perez Bridge. The air gap from the water level to the bridge was 40 feet and the height of the vessel was 45 feet. The vessel was making approximately 3 nautical miles with clear weather and good visibility.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event was the mast gear of the UTV KEN WEWA STRICKLAND alliding with the Judge Perez Bridge. The factors that contributed to this casualty were (1) Human Error:  Communications between the bridge tender and the vessel Master. (2) Human Error: the Master maneuvering to close to the Judge Perez Bridge prior to the bridge executing a full opening. (3) Human Error: The bridge tender not executing a full opening. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the bridge was fully operational before and after the allision. A Department of Transportation conducted a post casualty damage survey of the bridge, however no monetary damage estimate was issued. The UTV KEN WEWA STRICKLAND sustained minor damage totaling approximately $10K. This incident met the criteria of a reportable marine casualty a per 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1), unintended allision with a bridge. The level of investigative effort met the requirements of data collection activity as the property damage did not exceed $25K.

ON 20JUL2015 at approximately 1200 the UTV RIVER ADDYSON (Western Rivers Boat Mgmt, 275952, 7200HP) pushing 30 loaded rock barges (5X6) down bound at MM 977.7 OHR when the port lead barge, and the second barge in the port string, struck the left descending pier (Illinois Span) of the Illinois Central R/R Bridge in Cairo, IL. The port lead barge is partially sunk and remains in tow. The second barge is completely sunk approximately 100' off the RDB at MM 978.5 OHR. The UTV topped around and pushed the partially sunken barge into the RDB at MM 978.4.Investigation revealed that human error was the causal factor.

During an outbound transit, the vessel allided with the CSX rail bridge in ST. Joseph, MI.  After unloading cargo, the vessel attempted to depart stern first from the Consumer Asphalt dock, in the ST Joseph River. While passing the CSX rail bridge, the vessel rubbed against a wooden pilling that makes up part of the bridge protection system.   The vessel did not receive hull damage other than paint scrapes.  The wooden pilings received minor damage and the bridge owner elected to not perform repairs.  The stern first transit reduced maneuverability and the high winds (gusting to 15 knots) made the vessel difficult to control, causing it to rub against the wooden pilings on the rail bridge.

270416Z JUL: UTV GREGORY DAVID (Steel City Marine, 552069, 6000HP, 11' Draft) pushing 25 loaded dry cargo barges (5X5) down bound at MM 2 UMR when the port lead barge grounded on the LDB resulting in all 25 barges breaking away in 4 blocks.  Two barges,PGM 224B and JEM 366 allided with the Cairo Highway Bridge while floating down.  

SCC issued SMIB.

SCC contacted Cairo Bridge (LLNR 17665) MM 1.3 UMR and reported the break away. The bridge maintainer reports inspectors will not respond unless there is confirmation that the bridge was struck. SCC unable to confirm.

MSU Paducah MDO reports that UTV GREGORY DAVID aground LDB MM 1.8 UMR. 22 barges have been recovered by the assist vessels. Master of the UTV GREGORY DAVID suspects that the remaining 3 barges are aground IVO MM 2.

MSU Paducah MDO is monitoring the case and awaiting damage reports from the port captain.

MSU Paducah MDO reports that all barges have been accounted for, there is no apparent damage to the UTV GREGORY DAVID. The assist tugs are working to get the barges back into configuration, a marine surveyor is en route ETA unknown.

On 28 July 2016 at approximately 0020, the towing vessel JOE CAIN (O.N. 657662) pushing ahead eight barges allided the port quarter of the aft-most port barge, R 9014 (O.N. 957142), with the fendering system on the eastern side of the Jackson Railroad Bridge in Jackson, Alabama near mile marker 90 on the Tombigbee River. All eight barges, uninspected, were loaded with stone and were being transported southbound from Decatur, Alabama to Mobile, Alabama. 

No damage was found on barge R 9014, on any of the other barges, or on the JOE CAIN. The Jackson Railroad Bridge suffered a minor scrape which did not require any repairs. No injuries or pollution resulted from this casualty.

At approximately 1050 CST on July 28, 2016, the M/V Evey T was heading northbound on the Illinois River at mile marker 238 (Ottawa Rail Bridge). The tow boat was pushing 15 barges when the head barge (INO 05448) made contact with the Ottawa Railroad Bridge protection cell. The INO 05448 was an open hopper barge, sustained a 1.5 ft by 1.5 ft dent on the port bow knuckle. The protection cell sustained a broken timber.

As a result of its investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was when the current pushed the tow towards the protection cell.

On 05 AUG 2016, Marine Safety Unit Morgan City was notified that the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) LADY OF GUADALUPE (O.N. 1206755) had an allision with the Route 182 Highway Bridge in Morgan City, LA, on August 4. Through its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the misjudgment by the master. Factors that contributed to this event were: (1) the length of tow, (2) the strong southbound current, and (3) the narrow margin for error while passing through the triple bridge complex in Morgan City, LA.

On 07 August 2016 at approximately 0115, the PARACLETE (O.N. 1050052) was pushing ahead four loaded coal barges transiting under the Pensacola Bay Bridge en-route to the Crisp Plant on the Escambia River. The current caused the vessel and tow to set to the west of the channel. The Pilot then engaged the port rudder which caused the forward starboard lead barge to overcorrect and contact the fender pylons on the east side of the bridge. No damage was noted to the MTC 0174. The PARACLETE completed transit to Crisp Plant with no further issues. The contractor that maintains the bridge was notified and sent out an electrician to fix the lights that were impacted and during daylight hours a crew went out to place warning buoys around the damaged fender. A safety broadcast (DTG: 071535ZAug16) concerning the damaged fender and potential debris was sent out. The bridge crew estimated to replace the entire fender system near the affected area would cost $500,000.000. The damaged area to be repaired was substantially less $85,000 therefore subsequent drug and alcohol testing was not required.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the bridge fendering pylon. The causal factor that contributed to this casualty include: (1) Failure of the Pilot to identify the current running through the channel at that time and overcorrecting causing the barge to allide with the bridge.

On 03 August 2016 at approximately 0415, the towing vessel CHANDY N, while pushing 2 red flag barges, allided with the Bayou DeLarge Bridge at MM 59.9, west of the Harvey lock, on the Intracoastal Waterway (ICW). The towing vessel was underway and transiting westbound enroute to Washburn Marine, MM131 ICW. The barges were configured with a bow to stern tow, with a total length of 668 feet and width of 54 feet. The CHANDY N was pushing from behind. 

The vessel was making approximately 3.1 knots westbound with clear weather and good visibility. When making the approach to the bridge, the pilot was being set by the cross current and he was unable to correct the drift. The   aft barge, ATC 3523 struck the southeastern pier fendering system. There was no damage observed on the bridge fendering system. The allusion resulted in a 5 foot inset on the port quarter, above the waterline of the barge. The cargo envelop was not breached. The other barge in the tow (ATC 3424) was undamaged.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event was the speed of the UTV and the cross current between the ICW and Bayou DuLarge. As corrective action, the company is considering having crewmembers standing looking while transiting under the Bayou DeLarge bridge and decreasing speed.

On July 31, 2016 vessel while transiting up bound to St. Paul was pushed against the Dubuque Rail Road bridge where the barge touched. Bridge reported there was no damage to the bridge and vessel reported no DPI. Crew checked voids and tow wiring and found all in good order. Vessel proceeded to final destination.

At approximately 0350 the T/B KIRBY 11519, under control of UTV CITY OF PADUCAH while transiting south bound,  allided with the Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Bridge (AKA Pekin Railroad Bridge) protection cell at MM 151.2, ILR. The allision caused the T/B KIRBY 11519 to break free from the tow and become adrift.   The UTV was pushing 06 empty red flag barges.  The UTV SHIRLEY ANN was serving as a helper boat and assisted in returning the barge back to the tow.  The crew’s survey of the barge revealed no damage and no damage to the bridge was confirmed by bridge tender.  The UTV CITY OF PADUCAH safely resumed its transit after re-building the tow.  The Chicago & Northwestern Railroad Bridge is a known obstructive bridge under the Truman-Hobbs Bridge Act. 

Conducted descoped investigation of vessel bridge allision due to lack of personnel resources IAW CG Sector Upper Mississippi River memo 16700 "MSD Peoria Investigations Mission De-scoping Intentions" dated 20MAY2016.

20AUG2016-Received call from SECTOR Mobile Command Center reporting that the empty barge CRIMSON CLOVER (O.N. 1069744), a 259' 3289GT U.S. flagged freight barge had allided with the Chickasaw River CSX Railroad swing bridge near the entrance of the Chickasaw River on the Mobile River just north of the Cochrane Bridge in Mobile, AL.  The CRIMSON CLOVER was underway with the tugs THE DELTA (O.N. 586904), a 53.5' 1050HP uninspected towing vessel (UTV) which was pushing from astern and the JUDSON B, (O.N. 611533), a 56.6', 91GT, 800HP uninspected towing vessel, assisting from port bow of the CRIMSON CLOVER.

The CRIMSON CLOVER's last port of call was Domincan Republic and the vessel was towed on a registry voyage by the towing vessel ANN T. CHERAMIE. A Mobile Bay Bar Pilot navigated the ANN T. CHARAMIE and CRIMSON CLOVER into Mobile Bay to approximately the State Docks.

On 20AUG2016 at approximately 1500 local, the CRIMSON CLOVER was inbound Mobile Bay/Mobile River near Arlington channel with Mobile Bay Bar Pilot on board.  UTV THE DELTA met the vessel at approximately Arlington Channel and attached to the stern of the CRIMSON CLOVER on the stern with a double wire pushing arrangment.  The JUDSON B picked up Harbor Pilot Bernie Scott and dropped him off on board the CRIMSON CLOVER, then disembarked the Bar Pilot off the ANN T. CHARAMIE and returned the Bar Pilot to the State Docks. When the towing arrangement was just south of the Cochrane Bridge on the Mobile River, the ANN T. CHARAMIE discontinued towing the CRIMSON CLOVER and proceeded to the port side of the CRIMSON CLOVER to disconnect from the tow.  At this time THE DELTA was on the stern of the CRIMSON CLOVER and the JUDSON B, had taken station on the starboard of the CRIMSON CLOVER.  As the vessel continued under the Cochrane Bridge, the pilot had taken station on the starboard bow of the CRIMSON TIDE and the JUDSON B had moved to the port beam of the barge with a cable attached.  The three vessels were communicating on VHF-67 with the pilot giving instruction to the JUDSON B and THE DELTA.  The master of THE DELTA stated that he had no forward visibility because of the barges high structure.  

As the vessel appoached the open CSX Chickasaw railroad swing bridge, the harbor pilot stated that he was lining up the 70' wide CRIMSON CLOVER to pass through the 135' opening with himself on the starboard bow of the CRIMSON CLOVER and the JUDSON B on the port beam with a wire over.  THE DELTA was pushing ahead from the rear of the CRIMSON CLOVER.  As the vessel came closer to the open bridge, the harbor pilot gave a command for the JUDSON B to pull to correct the heading to port.  The pilot of the JUDSON B stated that he pulled then disconnected because he was approaching the fendering system and needed to disconnect to avoid striking the southern fendering system.  When the JUDSON B pulled it caused the CRIMSON CLOVER heading to move rapidly toward the southern extention of the bridge.  The JUDSON B's pull also caused the starboard stern to swing toward the northern fender.  CRIMSON CLOVER's starboard aft beam struck the large northern fender on the eastern side of the bridge.  Immediatly the port bow struck the railroad bridge piling causing damage to the cement and railing system on the southern connection of the bridge. After striking the bridge, the harbor pilot, realligned the arrangement and proceeded up Chickasaw River to Crimson dock. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for the casualty to be the mis-communication/working experience between the operator of the JUDSON B and the pilot on board the CRIMSON CLOVER. The pilot expected the master of the JUDSON B to pull the CRIMSON CLOVER to port then check/stop the swing which the JUDSON B did not, just before passing in between the open bridge.  

Drug testing was administered to the vessel operators. For unknown reasons the master of THE DELTA had a non-DOT test admininstered.  Recommended training be given to master for DOT compliance post casualty.  Coast Guard Investigators directed master of JUDSON B to have drug testing as well.  Testing for JUDSON B was beyond 32 hour requirement.   CRIMSON CLOVER sustained damage to port bow just above the water line.  Structural damage sustained.

At approximately 1209 EST on Sept 3, 2016, the small passenger vessel LONGFELLOW BRIDGET was underway in the Charles River, MA, on a commercial sightseeing tour when it sustained a material failure to its main propeller shaft. The vessel lost propulsion and maneuverability and was towed back to the dock for repair.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the material failure of the propeller shaft where it sheared off in the vicinity of the set screw, which rendered the vessel unable to maneuver.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) three welds applied to the shaft and collar coupling to prevent shaft slippage were fractured, and (2) an installation flaw in the propeller shaft and coupling (in way of the welds and set screw) weakened the shaft, making it more prone to breaking.

At approximately 1840 EDT on August 29, 2016 the commercial fishing vessel FLICKA allided with the Two Mile Bridge in Cape May, New Jersey. The FLICKA had just been purchased by a new owner and was being taken from Cape May, NJ to Anacortes, WA by a delivery captain and crew.

The FLICKA struck the bridge with its port bow causing moderate non-structural damage to the vessel's bulwarks in the port bow area. The deflection of the bulwarks caused the deck-to-hull joint to separate and create a 3' long x 6" opening in the generator space approximately 20' above the waterline. The deck, hull plating, and associated structural members were also deflected in the immediate area of the impact. The only damage suffered by the bridge was concrete damage to a small house that contains some mechanical equipment. The structure of the bridge itself was unaffected. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the FLICKA alliding with the bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:(1) the masters failure to follow the route recommended by the previous owner, (2) excess speed which left the bow thruster ineffective and (3) the master's unfamiliarity with the engine operating characteristics as the electronic engine controls failed to respond immediately, as anticipated by the master, to a full astern command.

On 3 Sept, 2016, the ST PEREGRINE (O.N. 112132) allided with the 399 Pensacola Bridge while transiting west in the Gulf Intercoastal Waterway en route to McDuffie Terminal in Mobile, AL, with four empty coal barges in tow near mile marker 190. As the vessel was nearing the bridge, wind gusts increased to 20-22 mph. The captain attempted to navigate the vessel successfully through the bridge by slowing it down and making turns to correct its direction. The vessel slowed, but allided with the bridge fender system, then corrected it's position, and continued under the bridge. No damages were reported to the barges. An inspector attended the bridge and found no critical damage, but the bridge fender system suffered minimal damages and the red navigation light was broken. Temporary repairs were made to the fendering system, and the light was replaced.

Received notification from command center of UTV PACESETTER (ON: 991123) having an allision with the DOW rail road bridge. The UTV PACESETTER is a retractable pilot house towing vessel that regularly pushes barges under the DOW rail road bridge. UTV was outbound in the DOW canal in a lite boat condition when the radar array struck the underside of the bridge due to the radar being in the raised position.

On September 09, 2016, at approx 20:00 the UTV EILEEN BIGELOW was south bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 281.1 pushing 12 dry cargo hopper barge. While using an assist vessel to transit through the Louisiana Railroad Bridge the barge ING 4775 located in the port string of the tow rubbed the upstream protection cell of the bridge.

At approximately 1325 CST on September 15, 2016, the UTV SARAH ANDRIE (ON# 519910, Flag: US, Owner: Andrie INC) was transiting the Indiana Harbor Ship Canal @ MM 1.89 and pushing the empty tank barge A390 (ON# 649264, US, Owner Andrie Leasing LLC). As the vessel approached the EJ & E Railroad Bridge, the operator was notified that the bridge was "stuck in position, almost all the way open". Despite this warning, the vessel informed the bridge tender that it would transit through. With three crewmembers on lookout, the "king post" of the barge's port cargo boom allided with a steel stringer under the bridge, resulting in approximately $112,000.00 in damage. 

As a result of the investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the casualty was inattention and miscalculation of the airdraft related to the barge (highest point to its waterline) and vertical clearance (distance between vessel and under bridge) to ensure a safe passage. 

The master focused his attention on the UTV mast clearance by assigning all three crewmembers to the head of the barge to monitor the mast, prior to and during the transit through the bridge. No one was assigned to monitor the clearance of the barge.Prom

M/V BRIDGET CAULLEY (565797, Kirby) experienced a loss of steering while exiting at Lock 52, OHR MM 938, transiting u/b with 3 loaded styrene barges. UTV SUSAN KOSSOW (641018, Ingram) took the tow and put BRIDGET CAULLEY on the hip. Barges were secured in McGinnis fleet and BRIDGET CAULLEY was taken to James Marine Paducah for repairs. Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be loss of steering. Contributing cause was determined to be broken rudder bushings from drift getting into the rudders, and the loss of the stbd propeller.

Level of Investigation was descoped to a data collection as per "D8 Operational Flexibility and Mission Prioritization Guidance; Deferring and Descoping Inspection and Investigation Activities" due to lack of trained, qualified IOs and responding personnel and competing mission requirements.

At approximately 2208 CST On 22-JUL-2016, the UTV SAFETY TEAM, pushing 7 loaded coke barges was transiting northbound destined for the Burnside Fleet immediately south of the Sunshine Bridge and was at approximately mm 165.3 when a collision with The UTV DENNIS ROSS pushing two empty red flag barges southbound for mm 144 occured. 

The allision resulted in damage to one barge, the mm 98, pushed by the DENNIS ROSS, above the waterline with no damage to any other vessels involved in the operation.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the collision between the two vessels. The causal factors that contributed to the casualty include: (1) The absence of daylight and the presence of the Sunshine Bridge serving to reduce visibility (2) The master of the UTV SAFETY TEAM's lack of attention to the oncoming traffic during preparation for arrival at Burnside Fleet. (3) the master of the UTV SAFETY TEAM not effectively using VHF communications to avoid the risk of collision.

On September 11, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received a notification from the sector command center of an allision between the BILL STEGBAUER (568965) and the Central Illinois Drawbridge (Dubuque). The Dubuque Railroad Bridge is on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 580. The vessel was pushing four empty barges southbound towards Greenville, Mississippi. The allision did not cause damage to the bridge, however damage was done to barge (MMI 603) resulting in a 2 foot by 3 inch gash on the bow underneath the headlog and 8 feet above the waterline. After damage was assessed, BILL STEGBAUER continued southbound where the MMI 603 barge will undergo dry dock repairs in Greenville, Mississippi. No further damage, injuries, or pollution.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot error/lack of local area knowledge.

On September 02, 2016 at approx. 23:30 the towing vessel SHERRYL B REEVES (505721) allided with the Burlington Railroad Bridge. The bridge is on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 403. The vessel was pushing 15 dry cargo grain and bean barges southbound towards St. Louis. The allsion caused damage to the timbers on the protection cell but did not affect the structural stability of the bridge. A bridge foreman assessed the damage the next morning. 4 barges were damaged and 12 of the 15 barges broke away as a result of the allision.  The vessel then received assistance from the BURLINGTON, DONNA RAE, DENISE RAE, JACOB MICHAEL ECKSTEIN and JAMES L in recovering the 12 remaining barges. 14 barges were gathered and 1 one grounded on a wing dam. This barge (MEM 2365)took on water in multiple void spaces and the cargo was transfered to another barge. The SHERRYL B REEVES reported no other damage, pollution, or injuries. The SHERRYL B REEVES continued southbound with 14 of the 15 barges towards St. Louis. After the lightering operation was complete, 2 of the damaged barges were taken to a fleeting area in Fort Madison to complete temporary repairs. The result of all damages due to the incident is was $284,500.00. Drug testing was conducted.

On September 15, 2016, the JONATHAN ERICKSON (O.N. 500995) was south bound on the ILLINOIS River Mile Marker 56 pushing 5 loaded dry cargo hopper barges. The vessel and tow was passing through the Florence HWY Bridge span when the current set the starboard lead barge onto the right descending channel protection cell of the bridge, damaging the MTC 722 and SCF 22006 and causing the MTC 722 to break free from the tow.

At approximately 1345 on September 29, 2016, a VHF whip antenna on the Liberia flagged container ship NORTHERN JUBILEE made contact with the underside of the Bayonne Bridge main span. There was no damage identified on either the bridge or the vessel. The air gap at time (distance from bottom of bridge deck to water) was 154.4 feet. The vessel's air draft (distance from vessel's waterline to highest point) reported to the pilot and vessel traffic service was 151.6 feet. It was confirmed that the vessel's highest point was a steel mast, which cleared the bridge. The contact was observed by the vessel's pilot and crew, who observed cables hanging approximately 3 feet below the bridge deck. It was determined that the antenna made contact with the hanging cables rather than with the bridge deck itself.

On September 29, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received notification of a bridge allision between M/V LG SULLIVAN and Burlington Railroad Drawbridge. The vessel was pushing 16 barges loaded with grain, corn, soybean, and slag metal northbound on the Mississippi River when it allided with the bridge. The allision caused tow wires to break. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot overcorrecting to account for current resulting in an allision with no monetary damage.

At approximately 0500 CST on September 29, 2016, the UTV Madeline (owner Enterprise Marine Services, U.S. Flag, O.N. 1209145) was pushing 2 empty tank barges down bound on the Illinois River @ MM 254. As the tow was transiting the CSX Seneca Railroad Bridge, the starboard side aft of the barge EMS 389 allided with the bridge fender. There was no visible damage to the the barge or bridge fender. No report of any pollution or injuries. Bridge personnel were notified and the bridge was inspected.

The master reported that as the tow passed by the right descending bank protection cell, he was set over by the the current which pushed him into the fender.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this incident was the water current condition near the bridge fender.

The UTV J. A. WARD while transiting upbound pushing 18 barges, allided with the I-155 bridge with an extended crane boom onboard an uninspected crane barge.  The barge and I-155 bridge were found to be undamaged.  The crane boom was bent after contacting the bridge.  The allision occurred due to the vessel crew misjudging the height of the crane in relation to the river stage and bridge clearance.  Damage to crane estimated at $10000.

24JUN2016: M/V SUANNE (O.N. 296186) was faced up on the crane barge while the crane barge (with 3 spuds down) was faced up on the equipment flat (with 2 spuds down); all were moored at the middle landing at MM 53 Kanawha River (Dock #2) having a total of 5 spuds down.  Due to hard rain, the river rose very rapidly through the night.  The increased current pushed the 2 flats and the SUANNE down river.  The breakaway group allided with a moored group of six (6) open hopper Crounse barges (empty), causing four (4) to break free from the tri-ties.
  The original breakaway group (SUANNE and 2 deck barges) were retrieved by the M/V ALABAMA. Three (3) of the open hopper barges were retrieved by the M/V CAPT ED HARRIS.
  The remaining empty hopper barge allided with a marina and a bridge before coming to rest under the Dick Henderson Memorial Bridge (St. Albans-Nitro Bridge).

The investigation revealed that the breakaway occurred due to a rapid increase of the water level in the Kanawha River.  The breakaway would likely have been avoided if the operator would not have relied on the use of spuds on the barges as the only means of securing the vessels at dock #2.

On September 25, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received notification that the M/V DENISE T DELANEY allided with the Dubuque RR Bridge. The vessel was southbound on the Mississippi River at MM 579.3 with 12 dry cargo barges. The M/V DENISE T DELANEY was being assisted through the bridge by the M/V SCARLET RIVER. The M/V DENISE T DELANEY was just finishing passing under the bridge, the M/V SCARLET RIVER was complete with it's assist when it backed off and caused the M/V DENISE T DELANEY to allide with the bridge. The bridge also reported no damage pollution or injuries. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a combination of the M/V SCARLET RIVER backing off from the M/V DENISE T DELANEY and tow and abnormal current conditions to a high water event.

On 15Sep16 @ approximately 0005L, the UTV MIKE NADICKSBERND was pushing ahead 11, uninspected grain and 1 empty red-flag barges IVO MM 254 of the Illinois River. While transiting the Chessie RR drawbridge, the port string barge, MEM 2419, made contact with the left descending bridge protection cell with its port bow corner. The bridge protection cell suffered cosmetic damage while the barge suffered damage to the port, bow corner deck and upper knuckle. The Illinois Dept of Transportation was notified and the bridge was inspected. As of 06Oct16, repairs have not been made to the barge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has concluded that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error. There were no subsequent events resulting from this casualty.

On September 27, 2016, at approximately 1809 local time, the Portuguese flagged container ship KACHIDOKI BRIDGE was on the final approach for mooring starboard side to Oakland Berth 32 when the ship experienced a failure of the starboard bridge wing main engine control telegraph.  The pilot had switched ship propulsion control from the center bridge main engine control telegraph to the starboard bridge wing telegraph.  Upon arriving at the starboard wing telegraph the pilot ordered a slow astern bell with no response.  The pilot immediately dropped the port anchor for safety reasons to slow the ship due to another ship moored dead ahead and switched control of the ship back to the center bridge telegraph.  The pilot regained control of the propulsion plant and safely moored the ship to Oakland Berth 32.  The starboard bridge wing telegraph was electrically isolated and the ship's electrician investigated the cause of the failure. 

The primary causal factor for this casualty, which resulted in the loss of propulsion event, was the telegraph handle not being placed in the proper "stop" position for transfer of bridge control resulting in "follow up" failure of the starboard bridge wing main engine control telegraph, the bridge crew's lack of training on the telegraphs alarms, and the steps required to clear them. Due to this reason the main engine could not be started from the starboard bridge wing telegraph.

The Captain of the SPV "THE OSPREY II" reported to the Domestics Inspectors via email that, while traveling westbound to pick up passengers for a tour in the vicinity of Buffalo Bayou in the Houston Ship Channel, the Master bent over to retrieve his cell phone which had fallen behind the captain's chair and experienced dizziness when he stood back up. He subsequently sat back down in the chair and experienced a temporary loss of consciousness. He remembered hitting the abutment (south side) of the Beltway 8 Bridge near Buffalo Bayou. This did not occur during a tour and there was no one else on board. After safely mooring the vessel, the Captain visited an emergency care facility and had a complete medical check up to determine cause of dizziness. Everything checked out with the exception of aparent symptoms of dehydration.

The vessel expeerienced a sharp 12" deep inset on the forward barrel portion of the starboard pontoon. There was no damage reported to the bridge. 

The probable cause of this incident was heat exhaustion. No further damage, pollution or injuries were reported.

While loading corn at CGB Birds Point, ACL 9274 parted moving wires and drifted into the river, floated down river and allided with the Cairo Hwy 62 Bridge. No damage reported to the bridge.  Vessel sustained hull damage.  Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be an equipment failure when the moving lines broke.  Contributing factor was determined to be a build up of drift on the head of the barge placing heavy strain on the wires.

Level of Investigation was descoped to a data collection as per "D8 Operational Flexibility and Mission Prioritization Guidance; Deferring and Descoping Inspection and Investigation Activities" due to lack of trained, qualified IOs and responding personnel and competing mission requirements.

On 18 July 2016, the foreign, Motor Vessel GLEN CANYON BRIDGE (O.N. 9302097) allided with the domestic, Hopper Barge LITTLE WILLIE, causing structural damage to the LITTLE WILLIE (O.N. 651509).
The GLEN CANYON BRIDGE was moored at Maher Container Terminal, Newark, NJ when an extraordinary gust of wind from the South pushed the vessel on its starboard side, causing the vessel to break away from its moorings.  The vessel was then pushed across the basin where it allided with the moored Hopper Barge LITTLE WILLIE. The GLEN CANYON BRIDGE sustained only cosmetic damage while the LITTLE WILLIE sustained significant structural damage in access of $100,000.  The GLEN CANYON  BRIDGE was assisted back to its mooring by some nearby towing vessels.  There were no injuries or other property damage associated with this incident.  
The Coast Guard's investigation concluded that this incident occurred from a sporadic storm that generated strong gusts of wind that was recorded by the weather service and also caused another similar vessel in the vicinity to break away from its mooring as well.

On 17 October 2016 at approximately 1440, the commercial fishing vessel H & R allided with the underside of the FM 1495 Bridge in Brazosport, TX.  The vessel was transiting inbound on the old Brazos River, enroute to the formerly known Western Seafood dock. The Master had not conducted this transit in approximately 17 years.  As the vessel made its way up the waterway, the 55ft outriggers were fully hoisted up. Additionally, there was a 6'9" stabilizer extension installed at the end of the port outrigger.  The starboard stabilizer extension had previously detached from the starboard outrigger and was being store onboard the vessel.  Prior to reaching the FM 1495 bridge, the Master directed the two crewmembers onboard to lower the outriggers about 35 degrees in order to pass freely under the bridge; this was his normal practice from previous transits in the past.  He also declutched the main engine out of gear and allowed the vessel to drift towards the bridge at approximately 2 knots with the inbound flood current.  The Master observed the vessel begin to roll just before crossing under the bridge due to the wake of a nearby small recreational vessel.  

When the H & R was transiting underneath the FM 1495 bridge, the port outrigger struck the underside of the bridge.  There was no apparent damage sustained on the bridge; however, the force of the allision caused the port stabilizer extension to break at the base weld on the outrigger.  Consequently, the extension fell off and became entangled in the lines overheard the vessel's deck.  It was later safely lowered to the deck by the crew.  The Master had no intentions to repair/replace the stabilizer extension, since he did not feel it to be useful or necessary for fishing operations.  The vessel proceeded to the nearby dock without further incident.

On September 25, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received notification of a bridge allision between the M/V SHOW ME STATE (614262) and the Sabula Railroad Bridge. The vessel was northbound pushing 15 empties when it allided with the bridge. There was no damage to the barge, UTV, or bridge as a result of the allision. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was unusual currents and river conditions due to a high water event that resulted in the master on watch misjudging the set for his transit under the bridge.

On August 20, 2016, at approximately 0043, the UTV JILL P HARVEY (O.N. 1152898) allided with the Judge Perez (Belle Chasse) bridge. While transiting west bound at approximately 2.2 nautical miles per hour on the Algiers Canal, the UTV JILL P HARVEYs aluminum mast pole and attached #1 and #2 navigation lights made contact with the bottom of the Judge Perez Bridge. The vessel is outfitted with a switch that lowers the vessel’s antennas and mast pole with attached navigation lights. When the Master operated the switch, the vessel’s antennas lowered but the mast pole did not. The pole made contact with the bridge, resulting in the aluminum poll bending and the #1 and #2 navigation lights becoming disconnected from the pole. The Judge Perez bridge did not sustain any damage as a result of the allision. 
 
As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the allision was initiate by a failure of the lowering ram for the mast pole. A contributing factor to this casualty was human error, attention failure. 

As per 46 CFR 4.05-1 (a) (1), this incident met the criteria of a reportable marine casualty, as it involved an unintended allision with a bridge. The level of investigative effort met the requirements for a Data Collection.

On August 18, 2016, the LADY OF FATIMA was transiting southbound on the Charenton Canal approaching the Baldwin Railroad bridge when the tug and tow were set by the current and the starboard stern of the barge pushed up against the bridge fender. The railroad bridge company confirmed that there was no damage associated with the LADY OF FATIMA and the bridge. There was a very strong current at the time due to the heavy rain fall recently. 

No damages, injuries or pollution reported.

On September 27, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received notification that the M/V BAXTER SOUTHERN allided with the Fort Madison Drawbridge. The vessel was northbound on the Mississippi River pushing 4 Ammonium Nitrate Urea Solution (water based) barges. The tow was properly aligned to cross the bridge when a strong current shifted the vessel and tow off course alliding with the bridge. The barge (STC 180B) that allided with the bridge was damaged and taking on water in their forward starboard void space. During the allision the tow's forward 3 barges broke away from the tow and were immediately recovered. The vessel and tow were pushed a half mile upriver and pushed off to the right descending bank. The vessel deployed 1 3-inch pump and 2 2-inch pump's to stay ahead of the flooding. The vessel later added 2 more 2-inch pumps to assist. Divers made temporary repairs until permanent repairs could be made. The product was transferred from STC 180B to STC 606. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a abnormally current.

On 10 August 2016 at approximately 1745 CST, the underway UTV (Uninspected Towing Vessel) SLYE JOSPEH, while pushing 02 uninspected deck barges, allided with the North East guide-wall of the Barataria Bridge IVO mile-marker 13 on the Intracoastal Waterway (ICW). The UTV SLYE JOSPEH was transiting southbound on the ICW and was attempting to navigate through the Barataria Bridge (swing).  As a result of the allision, three 12” guide-wall pile clusters and guide-wall navigation lighting was damaged. The bridge remained fully operational and the final damage estimate to the guide-wall was $37,514.31

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event was the vessel losing maneuverability likely attributed to unexpected high winds as the Master was attempting to transit through the Barataria Bridge. According to the Bridge Tender and the Master of the UTV SLYE JOSPEH, winds were blowing out of the West/North west at 10 mph. The nearest National Weather Service station in Galliano, LA (approximately 20 miles to the south west) recorded max wind speeds of 17 mph with gusts up to 28 mph out of the West that day. Although the winds in Galliano may not have been the same IVO of the Barataria Bridge at the time of the incident, the winds do give some indication that there were likely high winds in the vicinity of the Barataria Bridge at the time of the incident. 

IAW 46 CFR 4.05-1, this incident was a reportable marine casualty as the allision resulted in property damage greater than $25K. The level of investigation effort meets the requirements of an Informal Investigation.

On October 15, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received notification that the UTV J ANDREW ECKSTEIN (581143) allided with the Fort Madison Drawbridge. The UTV was pushing 15 barges southbound on the Mississippi River at MM 383.8. There was minor damage to vessel and none to the bridge, far below any monetary thresholds. The master of the M/V J ANDREW ECKSTEIN was approaching the bridge and miscalculated his approach. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error in miscalculating his approach to the bridge.

081430Z OCT 16: Received a call from a Good Samaritan reporting that at MM 327 OHR (Russell, KY) one barge (TB704, empty hopper) broke away from its fleeting area and was being blown upriver towards the New Ironton-Russell Bridge due to heavy winds.  Barge TB704 did allide with the Oakley C. Collins Memorial Bridge: no damage discovered.  KYDOT, OHDOT and CG Bridge Branch (ST. Louis, MO) were notified of the allision.

Note:  The barge broke away due to an inadequate mooring line arrangement (1 four-part line, 1 two-part line) that didn’t factor in strong wind or slow-flowing river water situations.

At approximately 1135 CST on October 19, 2016 the UTV LEMONT TRADER (O/N 559046) was transiting down bound on the ILR @ MM 254 and pushing 09 barges (3 empty red flag, 1 scrap metal, 5 petroleum coke). While transiting the Chessie Railroad Drawbridge, the dry cargo barge ING 2133 allided with the bridge protection cell. There was no report of damage to the vessel or bridge.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this incident was the master not maintaining enough headway to control steerage in an area of restricted maneuverability. This was followed by the barge alliding with the bridge.

At approximately 1520 LMT on October 23, 2016, the MISS CATE (O.N. 669637), an uninspected towing vessel, pushing ahead the dredge VIRGINIAN (O.N. 663156), was underway, making way at approximately 1.4 knots southbound on the Elizabeth River enroute to Norfolk Dredge Dock in Chesapeake, VA when the port side of the dredge allided with the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system.  

The weather was clear visibility, 0.7 flood current, and 15-20 knot NNW winds with 25 knot gusts.  The MISS CATE was underway, making way southbound on the southern branch of the Elizabeth River pushing ahead the dredge VIRGINIAN enroute to Norfolk Dredge Dock in Chesapeake, VA.  The tow and dredge were approaching the Gilmerton Bridge when the Master misaligned the tow and dredge to transit between the Gilmerton Bridge's fendering system.  He incorrectly factored in the wind, current, width of bridge span, and dimensions of the dredge to safely transit through the span without an allision.  Once the Master anticipated an allision, he quickly took all three engines out of gear to reduce the impact.  The portside of the VIRGINIAN allided with the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system, but the tow, dredge, and bridge were not damaged as a result of the allision.  The Master notified the Coast Guard immediately following the marine casualty and although the incident did not reach the threshold for a Serious Marine Incident, he conducted post casualty alcohol and drug testing.   

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the inadequate vessel maneuvering of the MISS CATE to transit between the bridge fendering system, the subsequent event was the VIRGINIAN allision with the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) execution error/attention failure: mariner failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the bridge fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the wind, current, width of bridge span, and dimensions of the dredge to safely transit through without an allision, (2) environmental complexity:  the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River has a bend on the north end of the Gilmerton Bridge. The natural bend in the river in conjunction with a narrow channel between the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system makes navigating this waterway complex and provides little room for navigational error for vessel's with larger breaths and widths, and (3) failure to use an assist tug:  other operators use an assist tug to aid with wide tows that transit through the Gilmerton Bridge but this vessel did not and could have prevented this allision.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral for enforcement.

MSD Quad Cities recieved a report of the M/V ARDYCE MARINER alliding with the Crescent Railroad Bridge at MM 481.4. Allision was caused by high water conditions. No damage to bridge or vessel. As a result of the investigation, the US Coast Guard determined the cause of the casualty was due to high water conditions causing the master miscalculate vessel manuever underbridge.

On November 03, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received a notification from the sector command center of an allision between the DENNIS T DELANEY (536790) and the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge. The Sabula Railroad Drawbridge is on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 535. The vessel was pushing twelve dry cargo barges southbound towards St. Louis, Missouri. As the vessel approached the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge, the stern was out too wide allowing the current to off set it. The master attempted to correct the set but was not successful. The starboard center barge (IN135419)rubbed against the upper protection cell as the vessel was transiting the right descending span of the bridge. The allision did not cause damage to the bridge or the barges.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot error.

On October 16, 2016, MSD Quad Cities was conducted a ride along with the BETTENDORF CAPRI while they were conducting sea trials from their moorings in Bettendorf to Lock and Dam 16. While transiting southbound the vessel allided with the I-280 Bridge. Before transiting under the bridge the vessel ensured it had the proper clearance, however the lights on the bottom of the bridge were not included in this clearance height. The vessel made contact with the light and caused minor damage to the temporary wheelhouse. The light was not damaged on the bridge. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was an incorrect vertical clearance listed which caused the BETTENDORF CAPRI to misjudge the actual clearance.

On October 17th, 2016, MSD Quad Cities recieved notification that the SAMUEL B. RICHMOND allided with the Dubuque Railroad Bridge. The vessel was transiting Southbound on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 579.9 pushing 12 soybean barges. The vessel was making it's approach too wide due and attempted to correct. The correction was not made in enough time and the second barge back in the starboard string (ING7926) made contact with the bridges protection cell. There was no damage to the barge or bridge. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was an incorrect vessel manuever on approach to the bridge due to operator error.

On or about 210700K SEP2016, Captain on board towing vessel CARDINAL (O.N. 1209747), reported that the vessel's port side engine shutdown unexpectedly resulting in partial loss of propulsion during towing evolution with barge S-2011, while coming alongside the pier at Tinian Harbor. Both towing vessel and barge are alongside at the pier in Tinian.  No report of pollution, damage to the vessel, barge, cargo and no injuries.  Briefed SIO and informed Captain of CARDINAL to submit CG2692.

At approximately 0200L on November 9, 2016, the Canadian Freight Vessel BAIE ST PAUL (IMO#9601027) was transiting the Chicago Skyway Bridge on the Calumet River at MM 332 when the vessel mast allided with a hanging wire. The wire ripped off the anchor light and anemometer.

During the investigation, the IO learned that on May 19, 2015, Coast Guard District Nine (D9) Bridge Branch approved the temporary installation of scaffolding underneath the Chicago Skyway Bridge from May 20, 2015 thru December 31, 2015 for general maintenance (blasting and painting). This reduced the vertical clearance from 125' to approx. 110'. Upon completion of work or prior to December 31, 2015, the contractor was required to remove the scaffolding and any other equipment to restore the bridge to the charted vertical clearance. 

As the investigation continued, it was discovered that the scaffolding and equipment was not removed and was in place for 11 months. D9 Bridge Branch directed the contractor to immediately remove all equipment and restore the bridge clearance to 125'.

On November 10, 2016, the contractor increased the vertical clearance to 122' which allowed for the vessel's safe departure.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the scaffolding and associated equipment remaining in place and not being removed after completion of work by bridge contractors. The vessel Master was not aware that the bridge vertical clearance was reduced, and was less than what was noted on the navigation chart. This was followed by damage suffered to the vessel navigation system.

On November 25th 2016 at approx 1900 the American Star allided into the Main Street Bridge located in the vicinity of downtown Jacksonville, Florida within Sector Jacksonville AOR. The vessel was operating east of the main street bridge attempting to tie up port side to at a local hotel. The vessel's approach was not to the master's satisfaction and the vessel began stern propulsion with a starboard turn. The vessel was pulled by the current and did not have enough immediate propulsion to correct the action of the current. The vessel was pulled by the current port side into the Main Street Bridge. Tidal changes allowed the vessel to free itself and transit to the North Florida Shipyard.

On November 16, 2016 at approximately 1715 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel JACK HOLLAND (O.N. 669003) was transiting northbound on the Elizabeth River, Virginia enroute to Norfolk Tug, Norfolk, Virginia. The vessel was pushing the empty deck barge NTC 50 (O.N. 531237). While making way under the Gilmerton Bridge the starboard midship section of the barge made contact with the eastern side of the Gilmerton’s fendering system. The allision did not result in any property damage to the barge or fendering system. There were no injuries to personnel and the Gilmerton Bridge was determined to be fully operational. Alcohol and drug testing was conducted under company policy.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the vessel's misalignment on approach to transit the Gilmerton Bridge, the subsequent event was the allision of the NTC 50 with the east fender wall as the tow proceeded through the bridge. During the course of the investigation, fatigue and distraction by use of electronic devices were not determined to be causal factors in this marine casualty. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) The master’s failure to properly align the tow prior to transiting between the fendering system. (2) The Gilmerton Bridge transit is known as having a small room of error when transiting without the use of an assist tug. (3) This was the first time the Mate on watch was operating the vessel and pushing the barge. (4) The waterway condition, which consisted of an ebbing and tide and a strong current.

At approximately 0810 LMT on November 19, 2016, the towing vessel SIGNET INTRUDER (O.N. 1106764) was moored in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic with the barge CHICAGO BRIDGE (O.N. 1059124) attached when the Pilot suffered an injury to his back.  After mooring operations were complete, the pilot came back onboard the vessel to complete his paperwork and attempted to climb over the tow line across the back deck when he tripped and fell, landing on his back. The paramedics were called and transferred the pilot to the hospital.  

The pilot suffered an injury to his back and underwent surgery which required 10 days of hospitalization. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the pilot falling on his back on the deck of the towing vessel. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the inadequate walkway across the deck when barge attached, (2) the pilot’s failure to take the appropriate thruway across the tow deck, and (3) failure to maintain awareness while moving about tow deck.

On 06NOV2016 at approximately 0740, the UTV MISS CALLIE CATE was passing under the Highway 90 Chef Menteur Bridge heading West towards Bayou Sauvage pulling 03 deck barges loaded with various sized piping. As the trailing barge, the DBN08, was approaching the bridge fender system a pipe that it was carrying made contact with the south side fender. The pipe extended approximately 5 feet over the deck on the port side of the barge. The pipe did leave a rub mark to the fender, but no other damage was reported by the Master or the bridge tender. The Master immediately made a correction to its course to avoid any further damage. Once the UTV MISS CALLIE CATE safely passed through the bridge, the Master made contact with the bridge tender and stayed on scene until released. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that due to the minimal damage suffered to the fender system only, that it was best to capture the incident as a data collection.

On November 30, 2016, at approximately 1100 LMT, the tug JENNIFER TURECAMO (O.N. 557188) was underway pushing the barge PORTLAND (O.N. 911886) in the notch with the tug JACK T MORAN (O.N. 1268013) secured bow to bow to the barge PORTLAND operating in astern propulsion. All three vessels were traveling southbound on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River approaching the Gilmerton Bridge. While transiting under the Gilmerton Bridge, winds began to increase and beset the bow of the barge to the east, posing a risk of alliding with the east fendering system. The Docking Pilot ordered the tug JACK T MORAN to pull the bow of the barge to the west in an attempt to prevent the allision. The tug over compensated the corrective maneuver, which resulted in the starboard side of the barge alliding with the west side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system.

There was no monetary damage to the bridge or vessels involved in the allision. However, several man hours were dedicated to assess the potential for damages by bridge personnel. A small boat was used with several employees of the Gilmerton Bridge to inspect the fendering system of the bridge to ensure the bridge and the fendering system were not structurally damaged.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge PORTLAND alliding with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge. Causal factors that contribute to this casualty include: (1) south south-west winds had been sustained at 15 KTS and gusts exceeding 30 KTS; (2) single pendant vice a bridle did not maximize control of the barges swing of the bow when maneuvering; (3) the Masters limited exposure to the complex navigational challenges posed by the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River in the vicinity of the Gilmerton Bridge; (4) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement.

At approximately 0622 CST on November 19, 2106, the towing vessels SIGNET WARHORSE I (O.N. 1131547) and SIGNET WARHORSE II (O.N. 1206581) broke free of their moorings at Signet Shipbuilding and Repair, floated down river and the SIGNET WARHORSE II allided with the Pascagoula CSX Bridge. At the time of the break away, the SIGNET WARHORSE I was not operational and moored to the facility, and the SIGNET WARHORSE II was tied up to the SIGNET WARHORSE I. There was heavy weather in the area, including wind gusts in excess of 40 mph, and a strong current, which caused the SIGNET WARHORSE I's stern mooring lines to break first, then bow lines broke allowing both vessels to float free. The Pascagoula CSX Bridge is approximately 100 feet away from the Signet Ship Buliding and Repair facility. As the vessels floated down river the SIGNET WARHORSE II was downstream, and allided into the bridge causing approximately $5,000 in damage to the bridge concrete walkway and hand railing. The bridge was already closed to vessel traffic since winds were in excess of 30 mph. The allision damage caused the bridge to shut down train traffic for an hour, but was reopened after an inspection was conducted and deemed the bridge safe for train traffic due to no structural damage. The SIGNET WARHORSE II suffered minimal cosmetic damage, estimated at $500. Signet vessels were dispatched to retrieve the free floating vessels, and returned them to the facility where they were moored separately.

At approximately 0015 CST on November 28, 2016, the empty barge B0769 broke free from the Ozinga Cement facility (Joliet IL) on the Illinois river IVO MM 287. The barge drifted up river and allided with the McDonnough St Bridge on the right descending side. The bridge sustained damage to the underside fascia beam in the vicinity of the southwest quadrant, west of the protection cell. The UTV ALIVIA FAITH recovered the barge and took it back to its mooring at the Ozinga Cement facility. The bridge was inspected by Illinois DOT and remained fully operational. The barge company was contacted by MSU Chicago IO and stated that the barge did not sustain any damage. 

According to the bridge technician and because the nature of the damage, no immediate repairs will be made. Repairs may be made in Spring 2017 and costs may be reduced based on repair contract. 

As a result if its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge breakaway from its moorings at the Ozinga Cement facility, resulting in an allision with the McDonough St Bridge.

On December 02, 2016, MSD Quad Cities received a notification from the sector command center of an allision between the CRIMSON GLORY (515916) and the Sabula Railroad Drawbridge. The Sabula Railroad Drawbridge is on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 535. The vessel was pushing fifteen dry cargo barges southbound towards St. Louis, Missouri. As the vessel approached the drawbridge, stern was being carried to the port side. The master attempted to correct the approach, but was not successful. The port center barge (ART 35312) rubbed against the upper protection cell as the vessel was transiting the right descending span of the bridge. The allision did not cause damage to the bridge or the barges.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot error.

On December 4th, 2016, at approximately 0800, the vessel PAUL RUSS was underway southbound on the Hudson River when the vessel allided with the Castleton (Castleton-on-the-Hudson) Bridge. An all round white light struck the bridge, and was bent back at about a 45 degree angle. The damage was estimated to be around $500. The causal factors for the incident were inaccurate air draft calculations and incorrect ship particulars, all of which were provided to the pilot who was navigating the vessel at the time of the allision. No subsequent events occurred.

At approximately 1912 EST on October 12, 2016, the cruise ship VIKING STAR was underway from Boston, MA to New York, NY with 1374 persons on board.  While transiting the Cape Cod Canal with a Federal Pilot on board, the aft mast of the VIKING STAR struck the Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge (under the lift span of the bridge).  As a result of the allision with the bridge, the aft top mast was broken and the aft masthead light was extinguished.  The Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge did not sustain any damage as a result of the allision. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the aft mast striking the railroad bridge lift span. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the pilot card for the VIKING STAR not indicating if the air draft condition is for masts up or masts down condition and (2) failure of the bridge team of the VIKING STAR to adhere to vessel rules as set forth in the Bridge Procedures Manual of the VIKING STAR, which mandates a safety margin for air draft clearance situations of at least 2 meters.

On November 14, 2016, at approximately 0950, the 201 dredge barge the uninspected towing vessel BARBARA LIND was pushing ahead allided with the Black Point Railroad Bridge at the entrance to the Petaluma River in Marin, California.  There was restricted visibility that morning due to fog in the area.  The BARBARA LIND maneuvered to avoid collision with a pleasure craft that was in the channel and in doing so the 201 dredge barge made contact with the lower channel side of the fender works.  There was no apparent damage to the 201 dredge barge or the fender system of the bridge.
