On 11 December 2016, the Towing Vessel CURTIS REINAUER (O.N. 1243220) allided with the LEHIGH VALLEY DRAW BRIDGE, causing damage to the CURTIS REINAUER's navigational light mast.
The CURTIS REINAUER was transiting south towards the LEHIGH VALLEY DRAWBRIDGE when it requested a bridge raising for safe passage.  After the bridge went up and stopped, the CURTIS REINAUER passed under the bridge and its mast struck the bottom of the bridge.  

The investigation revealed that the bridge was not up the whole way and the indication lights were inoperable.  Because the lights were inoperable, the Master of the CURTIS REINAUER had no way of realizing that the bridge was not up the whole way.  The USCG District 1 Bridges Branch investigated the incident as well with findings against the bridge operator. No damage to the bridge was reported and damage to the vessel was less than $25K. There were no injuries associated with this case.

12Dec16:  While crossing under the Lehigh Valley Drawbridge the Tug JENNIFER TURECAMO,pushing the barge PORTLAND, struck the fendering system on the eastern side of the bridge.  A case was opened initially with the thinking that the monetary amount for damage may possibly be over the $25K threshold but estimates put the damage at less than 25k, therefore this is not a reportable marine casualty under 46 CFR part 4.

The tug SARA K was pushing loaded (octane) tank barge (T/B) FMT 1062  near the I-10 bridge in the Houston Ship Channel, when the FMT 1062’s vapor vertical pipe stack allided with the underside of the I-10 bridge. The allision resulted in minimal damage to the T/B’s vapor stack. No injuries or pollution were reported. 

The tug SARA K was traveling outbound with only the loaded T/B FMT 1062 under ahead tow. As the tug and barge made their way underneath the I-10 Bridge, the Master miscalculated the vertical clearance required to safely navigate the barge underneath the bridge. Specifically, the Master did not take into consideration the height of the vapor vertical pipe stack on the FMT 1062. As a result, the vent stack struck the underside of the I-10 Bridge. The stack bended forward approximately 15 degrees creating a distortion of the vapor stack’s rain shield; there was no damage to the bridge. 

This marine casualty was the result of the Master’s inattention to details to include tide, currents, draft but specifically the vertical clearance required to safely navigate underneath the bridge.

On December 16, 2016 at approximately 0750, the towing vessel JINCY was pushing 15 empty coal barges, down bound at Ohio River near mile 803. As the vessel made their approach to the CSX railroad bridge the second barge from the front of the tow on the starboard side, allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge at mile marker 803.7 on the Ohio River, Henderson, KY.

The crew conducted a visual inspection and reported no damage to either the bridge or the barge.  They also reported no pollution or injuries.  The vessel master notified the NRC.  Sector Ohio Valley notified CSX railroad and a inspector was dispatched to survey the bridge.  

During the initial inquiry and investigation the vessel master reported that a gust of wind  caused him to allide with the bridge pier.  A review of local weather data at the time of the incident supported this report.

On December 01, 2016, at approximately 2024, the uninspected towing vessel BROWN EAGLE was transiting north on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway pushing 02 deck barges when overhanging equipment on the barges allied with the port side of the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge. The master of the BROWN EAGLE stated he could not see over the equipment in the back causing a blind spot which resulted in improper navigation of the tow and bridge allision. 

The Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge was hit on the fenders of the bridge causing cracks, bends in timbers. There were also parts of timbers pulled out of fender. Estimated cost of damage to the bridge was $6,337. No damage to the vessel was reported. No pollution or injuries reported. 

As a result of the investigation the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the improper placement of equipment on the deck barges, which negatively impacted navigation resulting in the allision of the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge.

At approximately 1625 AST on November 18, 2016, the tug SIGNET LIGHTNING (O.N. 8969305) was underway from Jacksonville, Florida en route to San Juan, Puerto Rico with Barge JAX-SAN JUAN BRIDGE (O.N. 667879) in tow when the vessel experienced a loss of steering.  The Chief Engineer discovered a malfunctioned battery charger and drained battery bank that supplies power to both auxiliary generators. The dead batteries were replaced and the generator was successfully restarted. At approximately 1730 AST, electrical power and steering was restored and the vessel continued on their intended voyage to San Juan, Puerto Rico.

The SIGNET LIGHTING lost steering with limited maneuverability in international waters near the Bahamas for approximately 65 minutes.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the Marine Battery Charger. This was followed by the draining of the batteries which led to a loss of electrical power and the eventual loss of steering of the vessel.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the faulty sensor on the Marine Battery charger, (2) the lack of failure detection devices/alarms, and (3) inadequate intervals of engine room rounds.

At approximately 1400 on June 6, 2016, the self-propelled barge BEANTOWN's starboard side spud allided with the underside of the Shinnecock Canal rail road bridge while traveling Southbound. 

No damage was sustained to either the BEANTOWN or the railroad bridge as a result of the allision.  The cause of the allision was the operator's failure to maintain situation awareness as it related to the height of the spud and clearance necessary to pass under the railroad bridge.

On October 21, 2016, at approximately 1850, the towing vessel CREOLE SUE's barge, allided with the Baldwin railroad bridge. The CREOLE SUE was traveling southbound through the Baldwin Railroad bridge. The CREOLE SUE's barge rubbed the west end of the bridge's fender system.

There were no damages reported. The casual factor that contributed to this event was due to the current being faster than normal.

On October 23, 2015, at approximately 2030, the towing MISS LAUREN ELIZABETH (O.N. 522677) was transitting southbound pushing 6 rock barges when it allided with the center span of the Simmesport Railroad swing bridge on the Atchafalaya River at mile marker 4.5.

The barge SL36 sustained an inset to the starboard bow void area approximately 4 feet long by 2 inches deep. The bridge fendering system sustained superficial damages.

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the causal factor contributing to this event was the master's misjudgement of the approach to the bridge.

On January 25, 2017, at approximately 0820, the Tug LIBERTY was outbound Chelsea Creek towing the CLS SPIRIT.  As the LIBERTY passed through the McArdle Street Bridge opening, the ship swung its rudder hard right and increased its power pushing the LIBERTY towards the North side of the opening.  The LIBERTY's starboard quarter fendering made light contact with the bridge fendering and slid along the bridge fendering for approximately 5 feet.  The master of LIBERTY assessed no damage to the LIBERTY or the bridge itself and notified his company of the situation, which then notified the Coast Guard.  

The Coast Guard instructed the company that this was a reportable marine casualty and to notify the bridge tender.

At approximately 1030 CST on January 26, 2017 the UTV JOHN D NUGENT was heading south bound on the Illinois River in the vicinity of mile marker 254 (Seneca Bridge). The vessel was pushing six, open hopper barges loaded with corn in a 3 x 2 deep configuration. During the transit, the starboard stern of barge (PML 1327B) made contact with the bridge fender system. No damage to the bridge or barge was reported. The duty IO made contact with D8 Bridge Branch who confirmed there was no damage, as reported by CSX railroad.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error. The configuration of the barges (rake barge on the port side and 2 box ends of the barges in the middle of the tow) made it difficult for the operator to control through this area of the river. The tow unexpectedly slid to starboard which resulted in the allision.

On January 24, 2017, at approximately 2130, the uninspected towing vessel MR. DEVIN pushing two barges rubbed against the west fender wall of the Bayou Boeuf railroad bridge. MR. DEVIN's crew reported no damage to the bridge and the bridge tender also reported no damage to the bridge. Coast Guard Marine Safety Unit Morgan City received an email confirmation from the Bridge Management Specialist at the 8th Coast Guard District office confirming the damage assessement.
As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was when the MR.DEVIN allided with the Bayou Beouf railroad bridge.

On January 31, 2017, at approximately 14:30, the container ship HUMEN BRIDGE, IMO# 9302164, experienced a reduction in propulsion while enroute from Long Beach, CA to Oakland, CA.  The vessel encountered an RPM slowdown on their main diesel engine when operating above a dead slow ahead bell.  The vessel tested local, pilothouse and engine room control and experienced the same RPM slowdown.  The vessel was able to maintain steerage and a safe speed by operating at a dead slow ahead bell.

Upon investigation by the crew it was determined that there was a loose cable connection between the circuit control unit and the ELVA/FIVA hydraulic control system.  The engine was stopped to reconnect the loose wires and the system was reset.  The main diesel engine was restarted and found to be in normal operation.

UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY experienced a starboard engine failure while transiting northbound at MM 719. VSL was pushing 03 loaded styrene barges. The engine failure resulted in a flash fire in the engine room which extinguished itself once the engine was shut down. Investigation revealed the engine failed due to a dropped valve in the engine.  The fire extinguished itself when the captain secured the engine.

At approximately 1830 CST on Feb 1, 2017, the UTV WINDY CITY (O.N.612974) was transiting south bound on the ILR@MM 254 pushing 6 dry cargo barges. As the head of the tow cleared the left descending bank and the pilot pulled the throttle back a gust of wind (20-25 MPH) pushed the tow to starboard onto the bridge protection cell. The starboard lead barge MML 0906 (O.N.1217916) made contact with the protection cell timbers. D8 bridges contacted CSX and they said they did not find any damage to the protection cells.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the high winds gusting off the port side of the tow, causing the tow to go off course. This was followed by the barge alliding with the protection cell.

At approximately 1021 Eastern Standard Time (EST) on February 10, 2017, the towing vessel DONNA YORK was pushing twelve empty hopper barges in a 3x4 configuration down bound.  As the vessel made their approach on the Owensboro Highway Bridge (SR 2262) the first two barges in the starboard string C1099 & C1073, allided with the bridge pier near Ohio River mile 756, Owensboro, KY. The crew conducted a visual inspection and reported nine broken wires within the tow and a deck winch torn from the deck of the C139. 

The Coast Guard's investigation found the initiating event was the allision and gusty winds contributed to the tow's allision with the bridge, as the 1800 horsepower towing vessel attempted to transited the bridge with the 12-empty barges.

At approximately 1758 CST on February 13, 2017, the UTV DELTA LADY allided the West Larose Lift Bridge at MM 35.6, Gulf Intracoastal Waterway (ICW) in Larose, Louisiana.  A new crow's nest wheelhouse was just added to the top of the vessel by a shipyard in Lake Charles, Louisiana.  The allision occurred as the UTV DELTA LADY was underway light boat from Lake Charles heading to Belle Chasse, Louisiana for a job.

The vessel's newly installed crow's nest wheelhouse hit the bridge and fell into the ICW.  The bridge representative reported no damage.  However, the waterway was closed to all marine traffic for 7 hours until the vessel's crow's nest wheelhouse was recovered from the waterway.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event for this casualty was the bridge allision.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:  (1) The vessel's master forgot about the newly installed crow's nest wheelhouse.  (2) With the newly installed crow's nest wheel house, the UTV DELTA LADY’s height was 49 feet.  (3) The West Larose Bridge height in the down position is 37 feet.  (4) In the raised position, the bridge’s height is 72 feet.  (5) The vessel's captain simply did not ask the bridge tender to lift the bridge.

By 0100 on 14-Feb-2017, the UTV TAMPA BAY brought a crane barge on location and a diver was able to retrieve the crow's nest wheel house from the bottom of the ICW..  The UTV DELTA LADY was restricted to daytime transit only as the vessel’s mast light was out.  The vessel proceeded to Belle Chasse for repair.  The crew was drug/alco tested.  DIO and Port State/UTV inspector obtained witness statements and attended vessel, checked credentials and the bridge remained operational.

At approximately 0753 CST on February 12, 2017, the UTV PASS CHRISTIAN pushing ahead 2 red flagged barges had its mast and antennas damaged when the West Larose Bridge Tender lowered the lift bridge onto the vessel before the tow cleared the bridge opening.  DIO called the bridge operator and no clear explanation was given as to why the lift bridge was lowered before the tow cleared the bridge, except that it was a mistake or misunderstanding.  The bridge is located along the Inter Coastal Waterway at mile marker 35.6 west of the Harvey Locks.  It is a Louisiana state bridge operated by state employees.

The vessel's mast light near the Furuno Radar Scopes was impacted straight down from above by the lowering bridge.  The rear flag pole was bent by the lowing bridge.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the bridge operator lowing the bridge before the tow cleared the bridge span causing the bridge to hit the UTV PASS CHRISTIEN.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:  (1) The UTV PASS CHRISTIAN had an air space or height of 46.5 feet from the waterline to the very top of the highest antenna.  (2) The West Larose Lift Bridge height is 37 feet above the water's surface in the down position and in the raised position is 72 feet above the water's surface.  (3) The bridge was opened all the way when the tow was ¼ mile from the bridge span.  (4) After both leading barges cleared the span, but just before the UTV PASS CHRISTIAN was immediately under the span, the bridge tinder lowered the bridge onto the UTV PASS CHRISTIAN causing the incident.  (5) As the vessel’s wheelhouse was directly below the lowering bridge, from the master's view, the master could not tell that the bridge was lowering on him until he felt the first hit from above.  Then, he frantically called the bridge operator on channel 13 to open up.  

Had the bridge operator started to lower the bridge 10 seconds earlier or if the tow was moving a ¼ mile slower, the wheel house could have been impacted and this near miss casualty could have been a lot worse.  Two people were in the wheel house at time of impact.  Due to restricted overhead view from the wheelhouse, neither noticed the bridge lowering until the first impact.

To prevent a reoccurrence, it is suggested vessels designate lift bridge lookouts to notify the master immediately if the bridge is being mistakenly lowered on the wheel house.

At approximately 0800 EST on January 13, 2017, the fishing vessel CAPT GARLAND allided with the north fender system of the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge in Oregon Inlet, NC. The allision occurred as the CAPT GARLAND was inbound from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pamlico Sound en route to offload shrimp at Hobo Seafood in Swan Quarter, NC.

The CAPT GARLAND struck the fender system with her bow sustaining minor damage (a broken wire stay in the rigging for the starboard outrigger and paint damage to the starboard hull). However, the fender system sustained damages to the vertical boards and horizontal walers which was estimated at $49,000. After the allision, the CAPT GARLAND continued with its voyage and shortly after CG Station Oregon Inlet boarding team conducted a safety boarding in the vicinity of the Old House Channel. The CAPT GARLAND had a current CFVS decal (No. 208405) expiring at the end of January 2017 and the boarding team found no discrepancies. The boarding officer also conducted a breathalyzer analysis on all 03 persons aboard the CAPT GARLAND;After the boarding, the CAPT GARLAND headed to homeport in Swan Quarter, NC.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the inability of the vessel to sufficiently respond to the operator's attempted turn to port, due to the direction and speed of the water current in Oregon Inlet. This was followed by the operator's failed attempt to maneuver the vessel away from the fender system and eventual allision with the north fender system. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the unpredictable current conditions of the Oregon Inlet, (2) narrow channel beneath the bridge, (3) the operator's decision to rely on poorly communicated radio recommendations, and (4) the vessel having one engine and shaft which could limit maneuverability.

At approximately 0150 EST on February 15, 2017, the small passenger vessel SWIFT RUNNER allided with the Townsend Inlet bridge. The allision occurred as the vessel was transporting crew from Avalon Marine Center in Avalon, New Jersey to the dredge TEXAS off of Cape May.

The port side of the SWIFT RUNNER struck the North side of the bridge's fendering system. The bridge was inspected the following morning by the county bridge comission with no damage reported. The SWIFT RUNNER was attended by a Sector Delaware Bay Marine Inspector. The deck port side amidships had a minor kink. It was determined that the deck did not require immediate corrective action. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the Townsends Inlet bridge. The causal factor that contributed to this casualty include the masters failure to account for the current as he maneuvered through the Townsend Inlet bridge.

At approximately 1830 CST on February 18th, 2017, the UTV ALBERT C allided with the Lemont Railroad Bridge at mile marker 300.6 on the Chicago Sanitary Ship Canal.  The ALBERT C was conducting fleeting operations at the time of the incident with one empty dry hopper barge (CBX 203).  The ALBERT C picked up the CBX 203 and was backing down in close proximity of the bridge.  While the Master of the ALBERT C was backing down, the vessel struck the railroad bridge causing damage to the port side, aft pilothouse of the ALBERT C as well as a small inset and paint scrapes on southside of the bridge.  The allision was unintended and as such, the incident was deemed a reportable marine casualty.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error, during the maneuvering of the ALBERT C and tow as the vessel was backing down towards the Lemont Railroad Bridge.  This was followed by the ALBERT C alliding with the bridge.  

Although this incident did not reach the threshold of an informal investigation, MSU Chicago upgraded the level of investigation based on facts discovered during the preliminary investigation.  These facts included that a licensed mariner failed to ensure the vessel wheelhouse was fully retracted before approaching a bridge and failed to maintain communication with the lookout. By upgrading the incident, MSU Chicago will be able to document causal analysis, draw conclusions about the incident to share with industry, and ultimately prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. Further, this activity will be referred for enforcement.

On February 18, 2017, at approximately 0500 local time, the Marshall Islands flagged cargo vessel SEA PROTEUS allided with the Union Pacifc Railroad Bridge as it was transiting inbound to Pittsburg Terminal #3, Suisun Bay, California. Calculations by both the master and pilot afforded the vessel a 4ft clearance between the vessel and the bridge. However, the vessel's INMARSAT Antenna was over 4ft higher than the vessel's schematic and was subsequently knocked down. No damage reported to the bridge.

As a result of the investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined that the initiating event leading up to the casualty was an inaccurate vessel schematic. This gave both the master and the pilot the false impression that the vessel had a 4ft air gap clearance.

At approximately 1630 Eastern Standard Time (EST) on February 25, 2017, the towing vessel BRIDGET CAULLEY was pushing four empty red flagged barges in a 2x2 configuration down bound. As the vessel and tow approached the Cannelton Lock and Dam the lead starboard barge, HFL406, allided with the long wall while entering the lock at mile marker 720 on the Ohio River.  The HFL406's last cargo was styrene.  

The crew conducted a visual inspection of the tow and found only damage to the HFL406 barge, no injury or pollution. The barge had a smooth inset on the outer vertical shell plate and rub bar of the #1 starboard void. The inset was approximately 8 feet long, beginning at the deck level extending down approximately 12 feet with a 3 inch inset. At approximately 2149 EST the Kirby dispatch notified the Coast Guard of the marine casualty.

The Coast Guard's investigation found the initiating event was a navigation error while operating in 25 mph winds.  The Pilot got the head of the tow into the lock but could not align the stern. The Pilot tried to back down the barges to avoid the allison but failed. The wind combined with the execution error contributed to the allison of the HFL406 barge with the lock wall as the BRIDGET CAULLEY proceeded to push her tow into the Cannelton Lock and Dam.

On March 04, 2017, at approximately 0825, the Panamanian flagged container ship BAI CHAY BRIDGE had a degradation in propulsion while maneuvering to its berth approximately 750ft southwest of Yerba Buena Lighthouse in San Francisco Bay, California.  The pilot ordered a slow and then half ahead bell but did not get an engine response for either command.  The engineers received an alarm for the #6 cylinder for the main diesel engine that triggers an automatic slow down.  The engineers reset the alarm which enabled the engine to answer the pilot's engine order.  Afterwards, the vessel was able to safely manuever to its berth in the Port of Oakland without incident.

Upon investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined the initiating event for the marine casualty was the failure of the injection control unit (ICU) for the #6 cylinder on the main diesel engine.  A subsequent event was the loss of propulsion.  The primary causal factor identified was the faulty condition of the injection control unit.  The defective ICU was eventually replaced, thereby rectifying the propulsion issues.

On 09 Feb 2017 at approximately 2:55 a.m., the foreign bulk carrier FEDERAL COLUMBIA allided with the Delair Railroad Bridge’s fendering system on the Pennsylvania side of the bridge.  The FEDERAL COLUMBIA struck the Delair Railroad Bridge’s fenders on its port side, near holds 3 and 4, with minor damage sustained to the bridge and vessel.  The FEDERAL COLUMBIA’s allision occurred as the vessel was transiting outbound of the Delaware River enroute to sea. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was an evasive vessel maneuver, releasing of the starboard anchor to prevent the FEDERAL COLUMBIA from grounding or alliding with the Delair Railroad Bridge.  This was followed by the eventual allision with the Delair Railroad Bridge’s fendering system.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) lack of reference materials or policies for the bridge tender, (2) poor communications between the pilot and bridge tender, (3) the pilot’s decision to proceed toward the bridge without establishing a proper signal, (4) the bridge tender’s lack of monitoring the radio, and (5) the pilot’s inability to adhere to 33 CFR 117.5.

On March 11, 2017, at approximately 09:21L the tow vessel STEVE PLUMMER departed from mile 184 (Upper Dundee Loaded Fleet) with a single string of 03 loaded sand barges in tow; HMT 301, H418B, and HMT 316.  The tow vessel was transiting up bound on the Cumberland River from 184 to 192.5 (Hollywood Fleet) to drop the loaded sand barges.  The STEVE PLUMMER was attempting to pass through the CSX bridge span closest to the right descending bank and center span.  The operator onboard noted the tow was being set into the CSX guard pier located on the upstream side of the bridge.  The guard pier was located approximately 134 feet up river from the main span.  The operator of then commenced collision avoidance maneuvers by jockeying the throttles and rudders.  At approximately 11:20L, the H418B, the second barge in the tow H418B, struck the upper guard pier and dislodged at least 3 stones which landed in the water and on the deck.  Moments later the third barge in the tow, HMT 316, struck the guard pier near its port stern void, causing it to collapse towards the center of the channel.  The tug and tow passed through the bridge, but due to the allision and collision avoidance maneuvering, an immense amount of strain was placed on the tow lines and all the lines parted.  The barges drifted with the current and laid against the upstream side of the bridge.  The allision caused the number 5 starboard void to the barge H418B be set in as much as 10 inches and the entire cargo combing above the number 5 starboard to be set-in approximately 12 inches.  The barge HMT 316 experienced a 3 feet by 5 feet hole in the side plating.  The estimated damage amount for the bridge guard pier and the barges was approximately $1.7 million dollars.

This investigation involving the allision between the tow of the STEVE PLUMMER and the CSX Railroad Bridge, which ultimately resulted in the collapse of the upstream guard pier and damage to two barges on March 11, 2017, was determined to be a Major Marine Casualty as defined in Title 46, Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 4.  As a result, this investigation was jointly investigation with the National Transportation Safety Board (NTS).  The rules that governed the fact-finding portion of the investigation was conducted in accordance with 46 CFR Part 4.  The NTSB completed their analysis and conclusions and issued a Marine Accident Brief.

The Coast Guard investigation activity identified causal factors; non-existent or complacent company policy guidance to vessel operators and limited manueverability of the towing vessel at the time of the allision, due to the prevailing waterway conditons. A single referral was made for further investigation in accordance with 46 CFR Part 5 for possible enforcement action(s).

On January 4, 2017, at approximately 1638, the bulk freight ship EMERALD BAISHA experienced an allision with the Huey P. Long Bridge at mile marker 126 of the Lower Mississippi River. While transiting upbound the LMR and passing underneath the center span of the Huey P. Long Bridge at approximately 10 nautical miles per hour, the whip antenna of the EMERALD BAISHA struck the bridge. COTP order 0010-17 restricted the vessels operations to the Lower Mississippi River pending a survey by the classification society. The EMERALD BAISHA did not sustain damages. The Huey P. Long Bridge did not sustain damages. 

As a result of its investigation the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event of this casualty was the whip antenna alliding with the Huey P. Long Bridge. Contributing factors to this incident was (1) Software Factors: Pilot Card Air gap Discrepancy. As a result of this incident the Pilot card was updated to reflect the correct air gap data. 

This incident met the criteria of a reportable marine casualty as per 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1) as the incident consisted of an unintended allision with a bridge. The level of investigative effort meets the requirement of a Data Collection as the incident did not result in damages exceeding $25K.

At approximately 0100 EST on March 10, 2017, the freight barge MSJ 111 allided with the fender system of the William B. Umstead Bridge while being pushed ahead by the towing vessel EVELYN DORIS. The allision occurred as the tow was transiting northbound in the Croatan Sound en route to Norfolk, VA. At the time of the allision, the MSJ 111 was empty. 

Initially, the starboard side of the MSJ 111 allided broadside with the eastern bridge fender which caused no damage to the vessel or the bridge. The spring-like force of the initial impact, however, pushed the MSJ 111 in the opposite direction causing the barge's port bow to allide with the northwest portion of the fender system. The MSJ 111 was undamaged. The northwest fender system of the bridge sustained significant damage. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of the MSJ 111 with the eastern fender of the William B. Umstead Bridge, which pushed the tow toward the opposite fender. This was followed by a second allision of the MSJ 111 with the northwest portion of the fender, resulting in significant damage to the structure. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the southwest winds which pushed the tow out of alignment while passing through the bridge, (2) the failure of the vessel operator to properly account for the force of the wind while passing through the bridge, and (3) the experience level of the vessel operator working in the Mate position.

On March 08, 2017 at approx. 20:10 the towing vessel COOPERATIVE VENTURE was pushing a tow of 15 loaded grain barges downbound through the Florence Highway Bridge on the ILR Mile Marker 56 when the starboard barge in the 3rd row struck the bridge protection cell on the right descending bank (RDB) side of the open span.  The Master of the COOPERATIVE VENTURE overcompensated to starboard after the tow drifted to port.   The hopper barge TRI 23 was holed in the #1 and #2 voids and both voids flooded. The bridge tender reported no damage to the protection cell.  The crew of the COOPERATIVE VENTURE successfully dewatered void #2 of the barge TRI 23 but was unsuccessful in their attempt to dewater void #1.  The barge was allowed to proceed to St. Louis to be offloaded and permanently repaired.

Vessel was transiting southbound by the LaCrosse RR Bridge at MM 699.8 when they were caught by the current and pushed into the protection cell. Starboard stern barge allided with the LaCrosse Rail Road bridge, causing $75,000 worth of damage to the protection cell. No damage to the barge was reported.

On 20 march 2017 at approximately 1322 hrs the M/V BILL ATKINSON (Pine Bluff Sand and Gravel Co, 1225191, 6000HP) while transiting down bound at MM 2.3 Cumberland River (Smithland, KY) pushing 15 loaded barges (rock) when the port lead barge allided the Lucy Jefferson Lewis Highway Bridge (US HWY 60).The port lead barge (PB 2223) reported minor damage in the amount of 3,000.00, Kentucky Department of Transportation reported only rub marks no significant damage.
Coast Guard investigation determined the initiating event was the barge PB 2223 alliding with the  left descending pier of the Lucy Jefferson Lewis Highway Bridge.  Contributing factors were Pilot misjudged the speed and set of the current.

At approximately 0325 Central Standard time (CST) on March 11, 2017 the ARTHUR J. CARSON (Ingram Barge Co., 556145, 2800HP) pushing 15 empty hopper barges (12 wood chip, 3 grain) barges (3X4+3) down bound at MM 787 OHR (Henderson, KY) when the tow's port lead barge (IN155460) allided with the Highway 41 (twin-span) bridge pier, near the Ohio River's left descending bank. The tow broke into three sections and the towing vessel was able to rebuild tow with the assistance of the LOIS ELAINE (ON: 612998), the A.W. BAYER (ON: 613084) and the JOSHUA (ON: 626286). The subject towing vessel reports a 1 foot inset above the water line on the port lead barge (IN155460) approximately 5ft aft of the port bow and no damage to the bridge, estimated damages totaled $96,400. 

As a result of the investigation, Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the loss of maneuverability when the ARTHUR J CARSON was unable to direct the tow away from the bridge pier, as it was set onto the bridge pier by river currents and wind, while transiting. This was followed by the subsequent allision of IN 155469 with the bridge pier, rigging failure, and tow breakaway.

On 11 March 2017 at approximately 1230 local time, the UTV JA WARD, while maneuvering six empty hopper barges in a typical 2 x 3 arrangement at the Belle Chasse Bridge IVO mile-marker 4.2, Intercoastal Waterway allided with the fender system of the Belle Chasse Highway 23 bridge.  Two of the empty hopper barges, middle and aft starboard, rubbed against the bridge fender system while the UTV JA WARD proceeded past the bridge. There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this incident. No damage was reported by the UTV JA WARD or the Belle Chasse Bridge.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the allision occurred due to South Easterly winds of approximately 10-15 mph causing the UTV JA WARD to turn to starboard while passing through the bridge; pushing the starboard side of the hopper barges into the fender system. 

The hopper barges were deemed fully operational & returned to service. This incident met the criteria of a reportable marine casualty as per 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(1) as the incident consisted of an unintended allision with a bridge. The level of investigative effort meets the requirement of a Data Collection as the incident did not result in damages exceeding $25K.

On 18 MAR 2017, the starboard lead barge MTC 0123 (O.N. 1186524), being pushed by the tug vessel CRISTO SANTO (O.N. 1102180), allided with the Pensacola Bay Bridge fendering system, causing damage to the wood pilings and wiring. At the time of the allision the vessel was north bound in the Pensacola Pass, transiting from McDuffy Terminal in Mobile, Al to Escambia Power Plant in Pensacola, FL towing 4 loaded coal barges, pushing 2 ahead and with 2 on the stern. The operator was setting up to approach the Pensacola Bay Bridge and had to slow the vessel's speed to account for pleasure crafts in the vicinity of the bridge. His slow speed and the tide caused the tug and barges to get set onto the bridge. The bow rake of the MTC 0123 struck the south west bull nose of the bridge fender. The rake suffered a small inset, and the fender suffered damage to the wood planks and metal wiring. The tug and barges continued to the power plant and the fender system was repaired. There were no personnel injuries and no pollution. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge alliding with the bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the impact of the tide pushing on the vessel and tow, (2) the disruption of bridge traffic by pleasure craft in the vicinity, causing the operator to slow the vessel's speed, and (3) the failure of the operator to approach the bridge correctly for passing, accounting for speed and tide movement.

On 08 February 2017, at approximately 1900 local time, the uninspected towing vessel (UTV) WINCHESTER reported a bridge allision between its tow and the Almonaster Avenue Bridge (L&M Railroad bridge) in the Industrial Canal at mile marker 9 in New Orleans, LA. The WINCHESTER was pushing the CITY OF NEW ORLEANS, a decommissioned casino vessel, in the Industrial Canal enroute to Morrison Yard Dock located approximately 1.5 miles north of the Almonaster Avenue Bridge. When the WINCHESTER was exiting the underside of the Almonaster Avenue Bridge, the wind turned the CITY OF NEW ORLEANS sideways in the canal. The CITY OF NEW ORLEANS’ starboard stern got caught in the wind and its port bow touched the bridge’s fendering system and guide wall. Damage to the CITY OF NEW ORLEANS was not availible due to the company’s complete renovation of the entire vessel. Damage to the bridge fendering system was estimated at $629,720. 

As a result of its preliminary investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the incident was a reportable marine casualty as defined in 46 CFR 4.05-1. The level of investigative effort was an informal investigation as the vessel allided with a bridge’s fendering system and the final damage estimates totaled more than $200k.

The Coast Guard determined the initiating event for this casualty was the allision; the causal factor for the allision was an unexpected environmental condition—a gust of wind.

On March 30, 2017, at approximately 1112 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel ANNE JARRETT (ON: 1182572) was underway making way at approximately .5 knots towing alongside the 300 foot, hopper dredge barge  6002 (O.N. 1152195) when the 6002’s starboard bow allided with the north fender of the Berkley Bridge’s fendering system.

Prior to the allision, the ANNE JARRETT and 6002 were heading west on the Eastern Branch of the Elizabeth River approaching the Berkley Bridge with an assist tug, AMERICAN EAGLE (ON:507165). Once the ANNE JARRETT and 6002 were aligned within the channel, the master released the assist tug to head first through the draw and assist as the bow of the 6002 crossed the draw. As the ANNE JARRETT and 6002 transited through the draw, the 6002’s starboard bow allided with the north fender of the Berkley Bridge’s fendering system. The monetary damage to the fendering system was approximately $9,763. The 6002 did not sustain any damage as a result of the allision. Drug and alcohol testing were conducted for the involved parties under the direction of company policy.  Results were negative.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the 6002’s allision with the Berkley Bridge’s fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) execution error as the master failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the bridge’s fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the wind and current, width of bridge span, and dimensions of the barge to safely transit through without an allision and (2) weather conditions. The Coast Guard evaluated distraction through the use of electronic devices, fatigue, and towing vessel equipment failures but were not contributing factors to this marine casualty.

On March 05, 2017, MSD Quad Cities received notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River of an allision between UTV CHERYL STEGBAUER (568268) and the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge at approximately 0415. The vessel was southbound pushing three empty UAN tank barges at MM 403. As the vessel was making the approach to pass underneath the Burlington Railroad Drawbridge, the vessel got caught up in the strong winds (21-22 mph) and quick current (181,145cfs) and rubbed the leading barge (STC3006) against the protection cell of the bridge. The vessel reported no damage, pollution, or injuries. The bridge tender confirmed strong winds and quick current in the area and reported three damaged timbers, but no other damage, pollution, or injuries. Bridge was still fully operational.

As a result of the investigation, the coast guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was due to strong winds and current.

Sector Upper Mississippi River (SUMR) received report from the bridge tender at the LaCrosse R/R Bridge on UMR MM 699.8 that the UTV CHRISTOPHER MYSKOWSKI rudded along the protection cell, causing damage to some of the timbers when trying to line up the passage under the bridge during swift current conditions. The bridge tender reports they are unsure if the damage is new or from a previous allision a week prior.  MSD St. Paul duty IO discussed past incidents with the Bridge maintenance manager and determined the damage was not pre-existing.  After contractors were hired to assess the total damage, it was determined that 12 timbers will have to replaced.  The timbers are for the sheer fence and is not a structural member of the bridge.  The incident did not result in any other damage, pollution, or injuries.

04MAR2017-While underway near mile marker 90 on the Tombigbee River, the UTV RANDY BAYGENTS did cause the barge PTC 549 to allide with the Jackson RailRoad Bridge fendering system.  The pilot of the vessel stated that he misalligned his approach to the open bridge and the barge contacted the north east fender on the port side.  The allision was reported by the tender and the vessel personnel to caused minimal damage to both the barge and the fender.  In an interview with CG investigators, the pilot of the UTV RANDY BAYGENTS stated that he was piloting 8 coal barges south bound in an "H" formation and missalligned the tow for the entrance into the open bridge.  When the port leading barge allided with the fendering system, it caused 5 wires from the tow configuration to part.  The pilot was able to re-allign the tow and safely navigate through the open bridge and replace the broken tow wires.  Wires were replaced, barges were inspected, only surface damage (paint) occured.

On April 15, 2017, at approximately 0830 local time, the Panamanian flagged cargo vessel HUMEN BRIDGE lost propulsion as it was transiting inbound to the Oakland Terminals, Berth 30. Two tugs were already tied up alongside and assisted the vessel in slowing its forward momentum as the vessel approached the pier at 2-2.5kts. The ship's crew quickly detected the cause of the casualty and brought the main engine online within 2 minutes. The vessel safely moored under its own power and tug assist. 

As a result of the investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined that the initiating event leading up to the casualty was a loose wiring connection on the remote mode high pressure L/O pump system. This lack of electrical signal caused the main engine's automation system to falsely believe the high pressure L/O pump had shut down, and thus, secured to the main engine to prevent mechanical damage.  The subsequent event was the loss of propulsion from the main engine shutting down.

On 14APR at approximately 1630, the M/V TENNESSEE HUNTER (625977, Hunter Marine, 4200 HP) was transiting downbound on the CUMBR at MM 63 pushing 13 empty hopper barges and 1 crane barge in a 3x5 configuration. As the pilot steered around the corner at MM 64, he anticipated continued winds of 5-10 knts coming from the west.  As he cleared the bend, the wind died and caused more slide than anticipated.  The pilot  then began backing down to reduce headway and trying to pull the head of his tow to stbd.  At approximately 1635 the port lead barge (PBM 130) allided with the center pier of the Henry W. Lawrence Memorial Highway Bridge.  A visual inspection of the barge was made with no damage reported.  KYDOT conducted inspection of the bridge and reported no damage.

CG investigation determined the initiating event was the allision between the port lead barge of the tow and the Henry W. Lawrence Memorial Highway Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Sudden change in environmental factors (i.e. wind speed). 2) Pilots inability to completely stop the tow.

On April 06, 2017, MSD Quad Cities recieved a notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River of an allision between UTV CITY OF LOUISVILLE (287746) and FT Madison Railroad Brawbridge. UTV LOUISVILLE was southbound at approximately 1200 pushing 04 empty UAN tank barges at MM 384. As the vessel was making the approach to pass underneath the FT Madision Railroad Drawbridge, wind gusts were up to 25 mph from the northwest bringing the lead port barge (KIRBY 3304) to rub against the protection cell causing rub marks. The vessel did not report any damage, pollution, or injuries. The bridge tender confirmed bridge was fully operational with no further damage.

As a result of the investigation, the coast guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was due to strong winds.

On April 11, 2017, MSD Quad Cities received a report from Sector Upper Mississippi River of an allision between UTV DEANA ANN (624968) and the Crescent Railroad Drawbridge. The UTV DEANA ANN was northbound on the Mississippi River pushing 16 empty dry cargo barges towards Winona, MN. As the vessel was making its approach to pass through the bridge, the force of strong winds from the southwest pushed on the starboard quarter of the vessel (DEANA ANN) causing the starboard leading barge (SCF 2218) to allide with the bridge protection system. The allision caused 8-wires on the tow to break. The DEANA ANN pushed up at MM 481 to re-connect the wires. No further damage, pollution, or injuries. The minor damages to both the Crescent Railroad bridge protection system and the SCF 2218 barge were insignificant so no repair or damage costs were incurred.

As a result of the investigation, the coast guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was due to strong winds.

At approximately 0745 EST on April 15, 2017, the tug CAPTAIN SAM was towing a 800' long pipe raft consisting of 18" diameter steel dredge pipe which allided with the Absecon Inlet (RT 87) bridge in Atlantic City, NJ. The dredge pipe was being transported from South Carolina to Atlantic City, NJ.

The vertical and horizontal wooden posts on pier number 6 Northeast corner (North side of channel, East side of bridge) of the bridge fendering system were damaged. There was no damage reported to the dredge pipe.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the tow's allision with the fendering system. The causal factor that contributed to this casualty was the absence of a tow plan that took the effects of set and drift on the tow into account.

UTV DARLANE B (Industry Terminal & Salvage Co., 569124, 1500HP) was pushing 9 barges (6 loaded & 3 empty) in a 4X2 configuration w/one empty on the port head, down bound at MM 940.8 OHR. The tow got set by the current and drifted sideways into the right descending pier of the KY span of the I-24 Highway Bridge (LLNR 28220). A loaded grain barge (ART 1430,) 3rd barge from the head on the starboard string, struck the pier on the port stern and flooded the stern void.

Coast Guard investigation determined the initiating event was the barge ART 1430 alliding with the I-24 Highway bridge.  Contributing factors include 1) High water conditions existing on the Ohio river; 2) turbulance around the nav pass due to a 2ft drop across the weir dams; 3) Tows requiring to transition from the Illinois side of the Ohio river to the Kentucky side in a limited area; 4) Pilot's inexperience in transitting the area and at night time in the last 8 years.

On the morning of March 21, 2017 the 66 foot 92 gross ton uninspected towing vessel DELTA FOX (O.N.626842) was underway with barge NALLY (O.N.1084906) on the hip, transiting southbound through the starboard passage of the Route 6 swing bridge in New Bedford, MA. As the vessel and it's tow passed through the opened bridge, current and wind began to set the tug and barge to the east, causing the last 20 feet of the barge to make contact with the fendering system for the bridge. The fendering system is of wood construction and not integral to the bridge. The operator of the DELTA FOX reported no damage to the barge, visual inspection of the fendering system by the bridge operator and personnel from the U.S. Coast Guard revealed light damage to the fendering system. The bridge remained operational and at no time was shutdown as a result of the allision. The tug DELTA FOX continued on its intended voyage without further incident. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge unintentionally making contact with the bridge fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include (1) winds and (2) currents setting the tug and barge onto the fendering system as it transited the bridge passage.

At approximately 0445 EST on April 27, 2017, the towing vessel EARL JONES was downbound at mile marker 604.9 of the Ohio River pushing 11 red flag barges (10 empty, 1 loaded with 8,000 bbls of gasoline). As the tow approached the L & I  Railroad Bridge it was set by the south wind and current flow through the vane dike to the point where navigating under the bridge was no longer possible, forcing the pilot on watch to lay up on the three protection cells just upbound of the bridge.

Upon striking the protection cell, a 3 foot by 2 inch tear occurred in the #5 starboard void on the tankbarge KIRBY 11521. The crack was about 8 feet above the waterline.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the KIRBY 11521 and the protection cell. This created a tear in the #5 starboard void.

On 14Apr17 @ approximately 1515L, the UTV KATHY AZLIN was underway SB on the Illinois River IVO MM 225 and pushing ahead three loaded tank barges (vacuum gas oil) strung out with an overall length of 1,010'x 54' wide. According to the vessel's operator, as he was approaching the LaSalle Railroad Bridge the vessel was set by the current to the starboard side and the lead barge made contact with a bridge protection cell. After the allision, the rear barge grounded on its starboard side. 

The lead barge suffered an approximate 4-5" inset, approximately 4' above the waterline to the bow corner. The vessel was grounded for approximately three hours before it was freed with assistance. With the permission of the Duty IO, the vessel moved to a safe location to await a CG duty team.  Upon arrival, the duty IO inspected the ballast tanks of the grounded barge and did not find any visible ingress of water. The operator indicated he had 20 years experience transiting the route. His MMC was inspected and was valid. He also had a medical waiver for insulin and peripheral vascular disease. After the duty team was satisfied that the barge was safe to transit, the vessel continued on its journey. 

On 03May17 MSU Chicago IO contacted the owner of the bridge and confirmed that a bridge surveyor conducted an assessment; the bridge protection cell suffered cosmetic damage and will not be repaired. 

As a result of its investigation, the CG has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a navigation error by the operator. The operator did not compensate for the current and allided with the bridge protection cell. The subsequent event was the grounding.

At Approximately 1625 on April 14, 2017 the barge, JB 60 (empty hopper barge) allided with the Tazewell and Peoria Railroad Bridge after the stern of the barge broke away from the J & L dock. The barge’s stern line parted causing the empty barge to swing out from the dock and the now unsecured stern corner of the barge, allided with bridge. There was no damage to the barge JB 60 or the Railroad Bridge. The UTV Prairie Land assisted the J & L Dock in re-securing the barge JB 60. The barge’s bow line remained intact during the entire incident, only the barge's stern floated away (swung out) and allided with the bridge.

On May 1, 2017, CG Sector MD-NCR received notification from the Pilot that M/V Tysla allided into the Dundalk Marine terminal Pier in Colgate Creek, Maryland.

Vessel was shifting berths during windy conditions. A gust of wind pushed Vessel Carrier Tysla’s starboard stern towards the Pier and subsequently allided into Berth 6. 

Tysla’s starboard aft shell was indented and internal structure was buckled. The damaged area is a void space extending from the steering flat and high above the water line. Examination confirmed there was no water ingress and surveyor postponed repairs to next scheduled dry dock date.  Approximately, 6 feet section of the Pier’s edge had crumbled and engineers determined repairs would be needed. 

There was no pollution or injuries and vessel was allowed to proceed to the next port. 

The Pilot was administered a Drug and Alcohol Test.

At approximately 1416 CST on April 21, 2017, the UTV MARGARET ANN was transiting south bound on the Chicago Sanitary Ship Canal (CSSC) and pushing two empty tank barges when the thermal fluid heater on the lead barge (MM 92) allided with the Belt Railroad Bridge at MM 317.6.  As a result, the thermal fluid heater broke off of its mounting. The barge did not sustain any structural damage and there was no report of  injuries or pollution. The duty CDO confirmed that the bridge was not damaged and a survey was conducted. 

Before the vessel departed the Ameropan Facility on the CSSC at MM 319, no ballasting operations were conducted. The operator made the determination that he had sufficient clearance for the upcoming Belt Railroad Bridge by contacting the UTV CHICAGO TRADER who had just cleared the bridge while pushing a sister barge (MM90).

Upon arrival, the duty IO inspected the wing voids and did not find any visible water ingress. The operator indicated he was "very familiar" having 13 years experience as a towing master of which nine years of operation on the CSSC. The last time he operated in the area was approximately six months prior. After the duty team was satisfied that the thermal fluid heater was properly secured, the barge was granted permission for transit to Greenville, MS for permanent repairs.

To ensure this casualty would not occur again, a fleet-wide post incident safety alert was released. Additionally, a new air draft policy was drafted and a safety stand-down was held throughout the fleet. Further, both captains onboard the vessel were demoted by the company. 

Drug and alcohol testing was conducted with negative results.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the operator's failure to calculate the vessel's clearance prior to transit.

On April 15, 2017, at approximately 1300 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel LORRETTE (ON: 669001) was underway, making way at approximately .3 knots pushing ahead the deck barge NTC 50 (ON: 531237) when the NTC 50 was set onto the east fender of the Gilmerton Bridge.

Prior to the allision, the LORRETTE and NTC 50 were northbound approaching the Gilmerton Bridge where an assist tug, the TAFT BEACH (ON: 647773), was standing by.  The TAFT BEACH was directed to wait on the northeastern side of the bridge and assist when the bow of the NTC 50 crossed the bridge span.  As the Mate aligned his tow to cross the span the port side of NTC 50 was exposed to wind gusts of approximately 26 mph which set the barge to the eastern side of the span. The Mate reduced his speed to approximately .3 knots and let the wind set him to the eastern side of the fendering system.  The TAFT BEACH assisted the NTC 50 once the bow crossed the span. The TAFT BEACH was positioned on the NTC 50's starboard bow and helped guide/align the NTC 50 as is crossed the bridge span.

There was minor damage to the Gilmerton Bridge’s fender wear plate and hardware, but the bridge was fully operational. The damage was estimated at approximately $5,556. The NTC 50 was not damaged. Non-DOT drug testing was conducted for the involved parties under company policy. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the Gilmerton Bridge’s fendering system.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) execution error/attention failure: the mate failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the bridge’s fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the current, width of bridge span, and dimensions of the barge to safely transit through without an allision, (2) weather, (3) environmental complexity:  the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River has multiple bends when approaching from the north of the Gilmerton Bridge. These angles and natural bends in the river make navigating this bridge and waterway complex, and (4) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

Recommend closing this Incident Investigation Activity with a referral to Enforcement.

M/V COOPERATIVE ENTERPRISE (ARTCO) was underway near MM 437 LMR pushing 49 empty (Dry Cargo) barges.  While transiting through the Vicksburg Bridges between Pier #6 and Pier #7 the starboard string made contact with the Vicksburg Railroad Bridge.  Incident was due to pilot error while steering through the bridges.  No Damage, pollution or injuries were reported for the vessel or bridge.  Vessel was permitted to continue normal operations.

On 05MAY17 at approximately 1934 the T/V MISS DOROTHY was northbound underway from the fleeting area at MM 733 on the Lower Mississippi River with 15 empty barges, 8 deck barges and 7 hopper barges.  While passing the Harrahan Railroad Bridge, the Master noticed a reduction in the port main RPMs.  The RPMs recovered, however, a few seconds later the port main shutdown.  The MISS DOROTHY was mostly through the bridge crossing and the current pushed the tow arrangement to starboard.  The vessel was traveling at approximately 1 knot at the time. As the tow arrangement swung towards the left descending bank the Master backed down hard on the starboard main to reduce the swing. The barges allided with the bridge pilings in the main channel and rested span to span. All 15 barges rested on the bridge pilings. The CPD 9709 broke away and was placed in the fleeting area.  All other barges remained intact and recovery was successful at first light. 

Due to the allision, four barges were damaged with insets, a damaged bit and minimal fracturing. No apparent damage to the bridge occurred. TDOT conducted a survey for damage.  

Investigation revealed the reduced RPM on the main and the subsequent loss of the port main was due to river debris lodging in the port nozzle.  The debris was washed out successfully during a washout procedure after the port main was restarted and propulsion tests were conducted satisfactory.

At approximately 0430 CST on 7 May 2107, the UTV J.W. HUNTER was heading south bound on the Illinois River and pushing six loaded hopper barges IVO MM 254.1, when the port lead barge made contact with the CSX Seneca rail road bridge protection cell on its starboard side. The barge sustained a 6 inch crack on the starboard hull below the waterline between the number 2 and 3 wing voids. It also sustained a 6 ft X 10 ft X 8 inch inset to the hull. The barge began taking on water at which time four pumps were deployed, but could not keep up with the water ingress. 

A CG marine inspector and investigator responded to the scene and made the recommendation that the vessel stay on station until temporary repairs could be made. The crew managed to get the water level down when they added a fifth pump. They inserted shingles in the cracks and were able to get the barge stable enough to transit to St Louis for repairs.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error, when the pilot misjudged the speed of the current as he approached the bridge. This resulted in the tow allliding with the bridge fendering cell which caused damage to the barge.

At approximately 2350, 08 May 17, the M/V BIG J.O. (1252860, 4300 HP, Yazoo River Company) was upbound at MM 977.7 OHR pushing five loaded fertilizer barges when it allided with the I.C Railroad bridge. As a result, the vessel sustained damage to the VHF antenna's, mast head light and the radar scanner. The pilot onboard was a trip pilot and had only been on the vessel for two weeks.  He was unfamiliar with the vessel characteristics including her air draft.  The Ohio River at Cairo, IL was in moderate flood stage with a gauge reading of 52.12 ft at 2300, and had been in flood stage for several days. The pilot stated he thought he could clear the bridge as there were no marks indicating the heighth of the channel span. After striking the bridge while transitting underneath, the pilot did not report the allision to the company or the Coast Guard.  The following morning, the engineer onboard submitted a damage report to the vessel's port captain listing the damage to the vessel and requesting repairs. The port captain immediately emailed the vessel requesting to know the source of the damage, since he had not received any reports that the vessel had been in an incident and sustained damage. After confirming the bridge allision with the pilot, the port captain notified the Coast Guard of the incident.

Copast Guard investigation determined the initiating event was the top of the towing vessel BIG J.O. alliding with the bottom of the span of the IC railroad bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Pilot's lack of knowledge of operating area; 2) Pilot's lack of awareness of the airdraft of his vessel; 3) Pilot's lack of wareness of the bridge clearance height at the current gage water levels; 4) Higher water levels on the Ohio river ar Cairo

On May 04, 2017 MSD Quad Cities received a notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River of an allision between UTV DOTTIE STRAIT (272085) and the Sabula Railroad Bridge. At approximately 2330 UTV DOTTIE STRAIT was southbound on the Mississippi River at MM 535 pushing 04 loaded grain barges which drafted 9'6". As the vessel was making its approach to the Sabula Railroad Bridge going at a speed of 04mph, it was lining up the set to go through, but the master misjudged the amount of set in the span. The master attempted to correct the alignment in time, but was unable to do so resulting in an allision. The tow struck the left descending protection pier with the BUNGE14067 causing it to break away from the tow and strike the sheer fencing that separated the right and left descending channels.
The BUNGE14067 sustained a dent on the stern and starboard side. No further damage, pollution, or injuries were reported. Drug/alcohol testing was conducted at the marine employer’s direction.

On May 05, 2017 a team from MSD Quad Cities responded to the scene to conduct a visual damage assessment. The bridge tender reported to the team that the sensor that monitors the integrity of the bridge was off by 1 degree. The bridge tender contacted surveyors to assess the totality of the damage.  

On May 06, 2017 surveyors conducted an acoustic imaging scan of the damage and repairs were commenced. Repairs to the bridge were made, however; they can't be directly related to this particular incident as the area of the bridge has been involved in dozens of marine casualties prior and has never been evaluated under water acoustically prior to this incident (so it would be impossible to figure out how much damage this incident actually caused or what would be necessary to return it to the unknown condition it was in prior to this casualty).

As a result of the investigation, the coast guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was due to pilot error.

At approximately 0500 CST on May 9, 2017, the UTV BOBBY JONES (O.N. 502672)was heading south bound on the Illinois River pushing two red flag barges at MM 239.5, when the port lead barge CF 103(O.N.503554) allided with the Ottawa Rail Road Bridge. The pilot stated that it was raining and the wind was blowing upon approach to the bridge. The wind pushed the tow against the bridge fender system. No damage was reported to the bridge fender system or the barge.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the wind gust of 20-22 mph, which pushed the tow against the Ottawa bridge. A Coast Guard Marine Inspector examined the barge and found no damage.

On May 02, 2017 at approximately 2232 LMT, the foreign flagged containership BUDAPEST BRIDGE (IMO 9494280) lost propulsion after it unmoored from Norfolk International Terminal, in Norfolk, VA enroute to sea.  

The loss of propulsion was caused by the failure of the main starting valve due to the malfunction of one of its subcomponents, the control 5-way pneumatic valve, which resulted in the propulsion system u to answer the requested bells.  The vessel re-moored and the crew corrected the issue.  The classification society boarded the vessel and concurred with the vessel's findings.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event was the material failure of the main starting valve, a subsequent event was a loss of propulsion.  Casual factors include: (1) Pre Condition:  The main start valve failed to actuate which in turn failed to turn over the main engine and provide propulsion.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to an enforcement activity.

On 05MAY17, the TRINITY BAY was underway on the San Bernard River heading south, bound for Bolivar. It was pushing one barge, the HTCO 3071, loaded with 17,000 bbl of hexane. Prior to approaching the FM 521 Bridge, the Pilot on watch directed the tankerman to lower the masthead; however, when he neared the bridge, the Pilot observed the masthead lights shining on the bridge and realized it was not lowered. He attempted to use the hydraulic controls to lower the masthead but could not lower it in time. The aluminum masthead struck a steel beam on the underside of the bridge at approximately 0525, causing damage to the masthead and its light. 

The vessel proceeded to Freeport, where it underwent repairs before continuing back on its transit to Bolivar. As a result of the allision, the vessel's company, Higman Marine instituted a policy and procedures for lowering masts on vessels prior to entering the San Bernard River and keeping them lowered until vessels leave the river.

On 17 MAY 2017, the towing vessel MISS LIS (O.N. 647237) was pushing ahead the chemical barge, KAYO (O.N. 1274395) when the barge's port rake allided with the Pensacola Bay Bridge fendering system. At the time of the event the vessel was transiting from Cantonment, FL to Port Arthur, TX, with an empty chemical barge. They were headed west and preparing to pass under the Pensacola Bay Bridge. The winds were out of the south at 20-25 mph, and began pushing and setting the stern of the vessel northward, which was turning the bow of the barge into the dolphin to the south of it. The operator tried to avoid the allision by turning the rudder to starboard and picking up the port engine from 900 rpms to 1200 rpms. When he realized he was not going to make the turn in time, he started backing the engine down, but could not avoid the allision. The port rake of the barge allided with the bridge dolphin, causing extensive damage to approximate 40 ft of dolphin timber and wiring, and causing scrapes along the hull of the barge. No further damage, pollution, or personnel injuries occurred.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the casualty was the allision with the Pensacola Bay Bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the strong winds from the south pushing the vessel, setting the stern, and turning it into the bridge, and (2) the operator's failure to take the wind into account when approaching the bridge to successfully pass through.

At approximately 0630 on May 14, 2017 the UTV COOPERATIVE MARINER was transiting northbound on the Illinois River at MM 151.2 with 14 dry cargo barges (4 loaded, 10 empty).  While attempting to pass through the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RAILROAD BRIDGE (AKA Lower Pekin Railroad) the tow got out of shape and the stern of the UTV allided with the upper protection cell of the bridge.  Master stated he intentionally laid up on the protection cell for a controlled landing but did not notify the bridge in advance.  There was no damage to the UTV or the bridge and the vessel continued its transit.

At 0516 LCL, on April 14, 2017, the M/V PAT VOSS (ON 1217929) allided with the Burlington RR Bridge. The M/V PAT VOSS was pushing 3 red flag barges loaded with slurry in 1x3 configuration heading southbound on the Mississippi River. The barge that the M/V PAT VOSS was faced up to (WEB218) made contact with a protection cell for the bridge on the Illinois side. The protection cell had some cracked timbers but was still operational. The barge (WEB218) incurred a 43.5' by 12' dent with a 9" inset. There were multiple broken welds on the structural members in the 2 affected void spaces. The barge was not taking on water. Damage was estimated to the barge to be $120,000.00. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the allision was a cross current that changed the vessel and tow's course.

On May 15, 2017, at approximately 1711 local time, the container ship BRUSSELS BRIDGE lost power and propulsion approximately 5NM west of the Golden Gate bridge while transiting towards the Port of Oakland, California.  After a few minutes, the vessel regained power/propulsion and was able to safely transit to anchorage within San Francisco Bay.  Upon investigation by the engineering crew members, it was determined the fuel oil filters for both the main diesel engine and generator were clogged.  The main fuel oil filter was replaced and the secondary fuel filters were cleaned/overhauled.  After the repairs, propulsion capabilities were satisfactorily tested.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this marine casualty was the unexpected failure of the diesel generator.  There were three subsequent events, the loss of power, the failure of the main diesel engine, and lastly the loss of propulsion.  The primary causal factor for the initiating event was the improper condition of the primary and secondary fuel oil filters.

On 29 January 2017, at approximately 0500 hours the towing vessel TANA I SETTOON was transiting south through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge while pushing the one empty barge, the SMI 351. When attempting adjust for current the Master steered the head barge away from the short wall on the East side, and in doing so allided the port bow corner of the SMI 351 with the North side of the short wall on the East span of the bridge. The damage to the SMI 351 was an approximate four foot by 1 foot hole in the port corner above the waterline. The damage to the bridge was four timbers on the fender system of the bridge. The initial damage was over estimated at approximately $34,200, but this initial damage estimate included cost not considered in property damage estimates as defined in 46 CFR 4.05-1(a)(7), the final damage estimate was actually $2500 for the fender timbers on the bridge and approximately $5000 for the vessel. There was no additional damage pollution, or injuries as a result of this allision.

At approximately 1130 on 28 MAY 17, the M/V DANA ALBRIGHT (Waterfront Services CO, 5559914, 1050HP) was u/w pusing 3 open hopper barges (empty) in a single string at MM 980 OHR with a steersman on the sticks u/i of the master of the vessel.  While transiting from one fleeting area to another, a gust of wind set the tow and the lead barge (MTC 0102) allided with the US 60 Cairo Highway Bridge (LLNR 28370).  The DANA ALBRIGHT continued to the fleeting area of Waterfront Services, MM 980 OHR, where the crew conducted a visual inspection and sounding of the barges with minimal damage reported.  No other injuries or pollution reported. SCC contacted KDOT who dispatched a bridge inspector with no reported damage.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the bridge allision.  Contributing factors were 1) Wind gusts that set the tow due to large sail area exposed. 2) Inexperienced steersman on the sticks at the time of the incident.

On May 19, 2017, MSD Quad Cities received a report of the BERNARD G alliding with the Sabula RR Bridge. The vessel was pushing 12 loaded dry cargo barges heading northbound to St Louis. The tow allided with the left descending protection cell after the currents were acting unusually and the captain overcorrected for them. Minor damage was reported on the barge. Damage was reported on the bridge protection cell by the bridge tender on watch and bridge foreman the next morning. After a follow-up the same day it was discovered that the bridge's protection cell that was struck had significant damage. The concrete had been cracked in a large area and the entire protection cell had expanded approximately 1 foot. Damages are estimated to be $1,000 to the bridge's retainer rings of it's protection cell. Damages on the barge are estimated at $5,000.00- which was significantly lower than what was originally estimated by over 100k. As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was a combination of river conditions and operator error.

On 26 May 2017, the Uninspected Towing Vessel BETTY D (O.N. 629525) allided with the BLACK IRON BRIDGE, causing approximately $15,000 in damage to the vessel's superstructure.  

The vessel was transiting southbound on the Hudson River between Champlain Canal Locks number 4 and 3 with a light hopper barge when it allided with the BLACK IRON BRIDGE, knocking the adjustable-height wheelhouse off its hydraulic ram and guide rails.  There was no damage to the bridge, no injuries and no environmental impact.  

This investigation  concluded that as the vessel was approaching the BLACK IRON Bridge, the vessel's mate on watch, at the helm was anticipating a 17.5 foot clearance based on the his experience and understanding that the dam-controlled water level was kept at the appropriate level for it's safe clearance.  At this time, the vessel's adjustable-height wheelhouse was in the down position, giving the vessel an approximately 17-foot air draft.  However, the clearance at this time was approximately 16.8 inches due to the heightened water level created by the dam height.  Because of this reduced vertical clearance, the top of the BETTY D's wheelhouse allided with the bottom of the BLACK IRON BRIDGE, The upon realizing that there was a potential for an allision, the vessel's mate put the vessel in full astern and exited the pilot house just before the allision.

After this incident, the vessel's management added to their safety management system that the vessel operator's will call the lock operators to determine vertical clearance every time before approaching bridges that pass over lock-controlled waters.

On June 1, 2017, at approximately 1100 LMT, the tug JENNIFER TURECAMO (O.N. 557188) was underway pushing the barge PORTLAND (O.N. 911886) in the notch with the tug SURRIE MORAN (1104101) secured bow to bow to the barge PORTLAND operating in astern propulsion. All three vessels were traveling southbound on the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River approaching the Gilmerton Bridge. While transiting under the Gilmerton Bridge, winds began to increase and beset the bow of the barge to the east, posing a risk of alliding with the east fendering system. The Master ordered the tug SURRIE MORAN to pull the bow of the barge to the west in an attempt to prevent the allision. The tug over compensated the corrective maneuver, which resulted in the starboard side of the barge alliding with the west side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system.

There was no monetary damage to the bridge or vessels involved in the allision. However, several man hours were dedicated to assess the potential for damages by bridge personnel. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge PORTLAND alliding with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge. Causal factors that contribute to this casualty include: (1) Over compensation of the SURRIE MORAN positioned on the bow  resulting in the movement to the west and allision. (2) the Masters limited exposure to the complex navigational challenges posed by the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River in the vicinity of the Gilmerton Bridge; (3) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement.

On May 17, 2017, the VIRGINIA INGRAM (O.N. 661437) was north bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282 pushing 15 empty dry cargo hopper barges. The vessel was transiting through the Louisiana R/R Bridge, when high winds forced the tow towards the right descending bank and the port stern barge near the towing vessel landed on the concrete swing span pier. The barge rubbed an 1 inch gash into the concrete pier.

On May 19, 2017 at approximately 0330 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel FORT PIKE was transiting northbound on the James River enroute to Hopewell, Virginia. The vessel was pushing ahead six empty hopper barges VMC 202 (O.N. 1127513), VMC 206 (O.N. 1127522), VMC 211 (O.N. 1123529), VMC 212 (O.N. 1127530), VMC 221 (O.N. 1127544), and VMC 223 (O.N. 1127546). The towing vessel JEANIE CLAY was also being towing alongside the FORT PIKE’s starboard side. While making the approach to the James River Bridge, the VMC 211 barge, starboard side allided with the northeast fender of the bridge.

There was no damage cost associated to the vessel. Damage to the bridge fender was inconclusive based on the pre-existing damage and the state's assessment. The Virginia Department of Transportation is estimated the cost of repair at approximately $50,000 for materials and labor.  
 
As a result of its investigation, The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the fender.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the weather conditions at the time which included gusts up to 20 MPH, and (2) the high sail area of the tow.

Recommend closing this investigation activity without a referral to an enforcement activity.
