On May 19, 2017, at approximately 0120 LMT, the towing vessel EVELYN DORIS (O.N. 274942) was pushing the loaded hopper barge SJ-400 (O.N. 647799) south bound on the Elizabeth River when the port stern of the SJ-400 allided with the east fender of the Gilmerton Bridge. Just prior to the allision the tow passed the towing vessel GOOSE CREEK in a port to port arrangement. After the passing situation the mate decided to proceed through the bridge in lieu of aligning the tow as he normally did. While proceeding through the bridge the mate attempted to steer the tow on the west fender, but the stern of the tow swung more than what was anticipated. As a result, the port stern of the barge allided with the bridge’s east fender. 

There was no monetary damage to the bridge or vessels involved in the allision. However, several man hours were dedicated to assess the potential for damages by bridge personnel. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the barge SJ-400 alliding with the fendering system of the Gilmerton Bridge. Causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) The mate’s failure to stop and align his tow and (2) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement

On 04 June, 2017 at approximately 1300, while transiting through the Bridge of Lions in St. Augustine, FL, the ISLAND EXPRESS allided with the bridge fendering system. The tug was pushing wide construction barges, leaving very little room to the port or starboard while passing through the bridge. The barge and tug were not damaged. The bridge fendering system received minor damage to the South fender system. FDOT conducted a survey of the bridge and its components and deemed it fully operational.

06 JUNE 17

At approximately 2038 on June 06, 2017, the UTV ARDYCE RANDALL allided it's barge ART45127, the lead barge on the port side of the tow, while transiting the Sabula R/R bridge at MM 535 on the Upper Mississippi River. The allision occured while the vessel was pushing it's tow through the span of the bridge, after calling ahead to request to conduct a controlled landing. After the landing, the stern of the vessel moved to the port side in order to pivot the tow into the span. As the tow moved forward, the wind pushed the bow back into the pier making contact with the walkway on the bridge. After the allision, the bridge tender noticed there was damage to the center pier. 3 out of 4 bolts securing an up right bracket supporting the walkway on the bridge, were dislodged, as well as chipping a small section of concrete approximately the size of a softball. No damage was noticed on the barges or UTV ARDYCE RANDALL. Due to the speed of the vessel being less than 1 mph, the impact sensor on the bridge did not even register an impact. No pollution or injuries occured from the incident. with the Sabula R/R bridge at MM 535 on the Upper Mississippi River. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determned that the wind caused the bow of the tow to be pushed back into the pier, making contact with the walkway, and pulling the bolts supporting the bracket out of the concrete.

On May 19, 2017, the JOHN R OPERLE (O.N. 630998) was downbound pushing 14 loaded dry cargo hopper barges and 1 empty red flag regulated barge. While transiting through the Louisiana HWY bridge span a weather cluster produced winds over 35 MPH, heavy rain and hail reducing visibility to zero. The Master allided with left descending bank bridge protection cell causing 5 barges to break away. Two assist towing vessel assisted in rounding up the barges.

Drug and alcohol testing was conducted IAW DOT regulations with negative results.  

Two barges (IN065411 & IN16447) continued to drift down river for approximately one mile and rested on the Louisiana Rail Road bridge. The other three barges were immediately recovered and placed in a local fleet. Salvage operations were conducted later that day and both barges were recovered and placed in local fleet.

Damage to all five dry cargo barges resulted in hull damage requiring dewatering and shingling. All barges had the cargo offloaded and were sent to local ship yards to complete permanent repairs.

On June 9th, 2017 the towing vessel MARGUERITE L. TERRAL (Official Number (O.N.) 1129737, operated by Terral River Service) was underway southbound on the Atchafalaya River pushing 6 (2 wide, by 3 long) open hopper barges loaded with aggregate. At approximately 1340 hours, the Captain of the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL contacted the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge via phone to request a 1420 hours bridge opening. The bridge operator stated that they might be having a crew change at that time, but that the bridge would be opened for their transit. The bridge tender began a visual inspection of the rail and bridge. While on the bridge, he was met by two Union Pacific supervisors who had arrived unannounced to conduct an observation and performance assessment of the bridge tender. The bridge tender informed the supervisors, both of whom were accompanying him during the visual inspection, of the request for a swingspan opening that he received from a downbound vessel.  

At approximately 1416 hours, as the pilot was maneuvering the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL around an area of the river known as the “39-mile bend,” he acquired a line of sight on both the Krotz Springs Highway Bridges and the still closed railroad bridge less than two miles downriver. At 1417, the pilot attempted to contact the bridge tender twice using the vessel’s VHF radio, but both radio callouts went unanswered. He then attempted to contact the bridge using the vessel’s cellular phone. While the phone was ringing, he received a response via VHF radio from the bridge tender hailing “southbound boat at the 39.” The bridge tender, who had still been performing the pre-opening examination of the bridge, had hailed the vessel after visually observing the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL and its tow rounding the bend.

As the pilot slowed the tow to allow the bridge to open, the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL was gradually set to west side of the river by the current on the stern. As a result, the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL was misaligned for a transit through the railroad bridge. 

When the swingspan was opened approximately three quarters of the way and rotating, the pilot put both main diesel engine throttles to full ahead in an attempt to pass through the opening and overcome the westerly set of the river current. This action, which resulted in some increase in the speed and greater control over the vessel, allowed him to clear the bow of the lead barge on the starboard side of the tow, RM 3367, between the swingspan pedestal and the easternmost pillar supporting the fixed portion of the bridge extending from the right descending bank. The pilot also lowered the retractable wheelhouse from its fully raised position to an undetermined distance, but not as far down to its lowest height, in an effort to protect its hydraulic pistons from potential damage. The lead barges cleared the turnstile but the middle barge in the starboard string (RM 3304B) made contact with the west piling. The vessel was making approximately 6-7 mph at the time of impact causing the coupling to break and setting the two lead barges (FR I640 and RM 3367) in the tow free. The pilot hailed the nearby towing vessel CHARLIE C rounded up the barges without further incident. 
	
The impact caused failure of the connecting wires for both the RM 3367 and the lead barge on the port side of the tow, FR 1640; subsequently, both barges began to drift downriver. Although some of the other wires connecting the remaining four barges either loosened or failed, the barges remained linked together and connected to the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL. Crewmembers on three nearby towing vessels—TONY LIPPMAN, RYAN, and CHARLIE C—overheard VHF-radio communications following the allision and responded by assisting with regaining control of the two drifting barges.

The force of the impact also caused the pillar supporting the western portion of the fixed-bridge structure to shift horizontally. Multiple large-diameter positioning pins and bolts attaching the northern and southern truss-mounting plates to the caisson were sheered. The fixed portion of the bridge truss on the western side shifted horizontally as well, causing a misalignment of the lift rail with the fixed and rider rails. The total damage resulting from the allision exceeded $4 million.

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the cause of the casualty to be the failure of the Krotz Springs Railroad Bridge to open promptly and fully upon being signaled by the MARGUERITE L. TERRAL as required by Title 33 USC § 499 (b).

At 0740LCL SUMR CC received a report from the Sabula RR Bridge MM 535 UMR.  The UTV SHOW ME STATE was north bound through the bridge when it struck a steel walkway with and empty dry cargo barge.  The walkway bent and pulled the lag bolts out of the wall.  No structural damage to the Sabula RR Bridge.  Sabula RR Bridge is operational and there is no impact to the waterway.  There is no reported damage on the UTV.  No DPI. As a result of the investigation, it was determined that the speed of the current was directly responsible for the casualty.

On June 7, 2017, 2005 LT, the M/V HONOLULU BRIDGE had a reduction in propulsion while maneuvering outbound at the Kings Island Turning Basin in the Port of Savannah. The pilot onboard the decision to moor the vessel back at Garden City Terminal to conduct an investigation as to the cause of the reduction in propulsion.  

Cause of reduction in propulsion: On June 6, 2017, while the vessel was moored alongside Garden City Terminal in the Port of Savannah, GA, the crew conducted an overhaul of the High Pressure hydraulic Exhaust Valve Actuator of the Main Engine Cylinder No. 9. During the assembly, the crew forgot to replace (install) the disc actuator to the exhaust valve. On June 7, 2017, 1932 Local time, the crew completed a test of the ME prior to departure and found no issues. The vessel departed the pier at 1950. At minute 2005, the ME had a high temperature and automatically reduced propulsion. The ME was not receiving any hydraulic fuel and the vessel was returned to the dock. Engineers completed an investigation, found the cause and installed the disc. ME was then tested and found all operational and vessel departed Garden City Terminal on 0001 on June 8, 2017 with no further issues.

On 21 June, 2017 at approximately 2145 the SIGNET INTRUDER collided with the barge CHICAGO BRIDGE while mooring the barge at Blount Island Terminal in Jacksonville, FL. The SIGNET INTRUDER was bringing the barge along its stbd side in a hip tow to push the barge towards the pier when the CHICAGO BRIDGE was pushed by the current into the SIGNET INTRUDER. The vessels made contact on the stbd bow of the barge and the stbd quarter of the tug. The SIGNET INTRUDER sustained damage to the second deck stbd handrails, stbd winch control station, and the john boat located on the second deck. No injuries were reported. Alcohol testing was conducted. 

The barge was reported to have an inset on the stbd rake at time of investigation. On 22 June, 2017 CG Inspectors attended the CHICAGO BRIDGE for damage survey (MISLE ACT #6182890); no damage found internally. No Sail CG-835 cleared at that time.

1508L:  The command center received a report from the Vicksburg Information Center that the UTV GRAESTONE EXPRESS (Doc. 279589, 3800HP, Graestone Logistics) allided with the Vicksburg Old Highway 80 / Railroad Bridge at MM 436 LMR in Vicksburg, MS.  The GRAESTONE EXPRESS was down bound pushing 14 loaded dry grain/coal barges.  Due to high water and the Master's error, the port stern barge in tow made contact with the bridge column resulting in 11 barges breaking away from the UTV and remaining 03 barges.  A block of 08 barges and a string of 03 barges were secured by the A/V SYNERGY and the A/V GENERAL.  Barge T-497 sank LDB near MM 432 LMR.

25JUN2017-The UTV CHIPPEWA was navigating south bound the Tombigbee River near mile marker 90 and north of the Jackson Railroad Bridge with barges JMC 182, C1245 and C1392.  C1245 and C1392 were loaded with coal and JMC 182, a deck barge, had miscellaneous deck equipment on board.  It was reported that the river at the Coffeeville locks was 50 feet above normal due to Tropical Storm Cindy heavy rainfall earlier in the week.  As the tug and tow were attempting to navigate through the open bridge, the tow got set to the west and allided with the north west side of the Jackson Railroad Draw bridge.  The allision caused minimal damage to the tow and the bridge.  The vessel aligned and continued through the open bridge and proceeded south down the Tombigbee River to Mobile, AL.

26JUN2017- Coast Guard Investigator boarded the CHIPPEWA and interviewed the master of the vessel.  The master of the vessel stated and offered for examination the electronic chartplotter demonstration the path that the CHIPPEWA took when it allided with the bridge.  The master demonstrated that he was attempting to align his tug and tow toward the eastern side of the bank as he approached the bridge from the north.  As he approached he stated that he noticed that his tug and tow were being set to the west (starboard) so he made an attempt to begine backing down.  With the extreme flood stage and swift current, the CHIPPEWA was not able to stop the tow and the vessel allided with the north western part of the bridge.  The allision caused minimal damage to the bridge (handrail) and the rails were inspected and aligned.   The barge sustained scrapes and small enset.  CG Investigator called the bridge supervisor for the Jackson Railroad bridge and he stated that there was minimal superficial damage.  The barge estimated about $1000 in damage for broken wires.

At approximately 1630 on 10 JUN 2017 the UTV ST JAMES (O.N. 1259643) was transiting outbound of the Gulfcoast Intracoastal Waterway pushing 06 empty barges ahead.  As it was transiting under the CSX railway bridge in Biloxi, MS, the Pilot noted that the current was pushing the vessel to the east.  The Pilot backed down on the throttles to avoid a hard allision and the two port side barges, FMTA-116 (O.N. 1230260) and SL-40 (O.N.1232310), grazed the CSX railway's east fendering system.  The allision freed two boards from the bridge's fendering system.

At approximately 1200 EST on June 29, 2017, the commercial fishing vessel SEA MINER (O.N. 632915) was underway on the Newport River transiting northbound from Beaufort Inlet when the vessel allided with the Morehead City High Rise Bridge, NC. The incident occurred as the SEA MINER approached the Morehead City High Rise Bridge with the main engine at idle speed (3 knot current pushing vessel towards the bridge) when the captain ordered the crewmembers to lower the outriggers in order to go underneath the bridge (approximately 65 feet clearance). The vessel's outriggers are deployed by an individual hydraulic winch for each outrigger. One of the crewmembers lowered the port outrigger without any problems, however the starboard outrigger did not lower because the cable jammed in the hydraulic winch system. When the crewmember realized that the starboard winch malfunctioned and was going to inform the captain, the starboard outrigger struck the center span of the bridge. The starboard outrigger was bent and the vessel continued through the Morehead City High Rise Bridge and proceeded to Oriental, NC in order to conduct an assessment. The vessel successfully moored at Garland Fulcher Seafood located in Oriental, NC. NC DOT was notified about the incident; no damages to the bridge. No injuries or pollution occurred as a result of the marine casualty.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the malfunction of the starboard winch system which prevented the deployment of the starboard outrigger causing the eventual allision between the SEA MINER and the Morehead City High Rise Bridge. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) outrigger cable jammed in the starboard hydraulic winch, (2) rising tide and current, and (3) restricted maneuverability.

On July 6, 2017, the Coast Guard received a report from an officer from the Hampton Police Department regarding damage to the J.P. Mugler Bridge. The bridge is located on Mellen Street in the city of Hampton, Virginia. The reporting officer also noted that the Commercial Fishing Vessel (CFV) FRANK & MARIA (O.N. 587137), which was moored at the Wanchese Fish Company dock, had sustained damage to the bow area indicative of a possible allision with the damaged bridge. A Coast Guard Investigating Officer responded to the scene and determined through interviews with Wanchese Fish Company personnel that the CFV FANK & MARIA had allided with the bridge on June 22, 2017. 

An assessment of damage to the J.P Mugler Bridge was conducted by Johnson, Miriman & Thompson Inc. The total damage assessment to the bridge as a result of the allision was $224,000. The vessel sustained non-structural damage to the bow.  No fiscal damage was reported by the marine employer of the FRANK & MARIA. However, the scheduled fishing trip that the vessel was preparing for was cancelled. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event was the failing of the linkage that connected the throttle control cable to the reduction gear clutch control. Subsequent events were the loss of propulsion and allision with the bridge.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the lack of regulatory oversight regarding mandatory inspections by the Coast Guard, (2) regulatory operation requirements of a safety management system and pre-underway checks, (3) an execution error in action that could have identified the latent unsafe condition, and (4) regulatory baseline training that would be required if mariners were to obtain a merchant mariner credential.  

In addition, three alleged violations of law or regulations were identified:  (1) the Marine employers failed to immediately report and (2) failure to submit a written report within the timelines required by federal regulations. (3) property damage assessment was in excess of $100K and this marine casualty was determined to be a Serious Marine Incident (SMI). In accordance with federal regulation mandatory chemical testing by the marine employer is required for all SMIs, which the marine employer failed to carry out.

 
Recommend closing this incident investigation activity with a referral to an enforcement activity.

On 28 JUNE 2017, the foreign vessel HHL RHINE departed K & K Integrated Logistics waterfront facility in Menominee, MI and was underway on the Menominee River outbound in lightship condition heading east to the bay of Green Bay a navigable waterway of Lake Michigan.  There were two lookouts on the bow of the vessel as it approached the Ogden Street bridge.  While the vessel was passing through the Ogden Street Bridge the vessel shifted north west resulting in the vessel striking the north west bridge protection cell and its associated fendering system.  The allision caused minor damage including cracked concrete and a damaged fender totaling $2,000 dollars in damage.  The vessel sustained only minor paint scuffing.  The bridge remained fully operational.  Repairs are being made.

This incident has been designated as a Data Collection level of investigative effort IAW MSM Vol. V.  No analysis or conclusions were required.

On July 22, 2017, at approximately 1420 LMT, the recreational vessel AZ4354DA collided with the inspected small passenger vessel LOOSEY LU (O.N. 1189035) in the vicinity of Blankenship Bend, Mohave County, AZ.  During the collision a passenger on board the AZ4354DA received injuries to her head when her body flew forward and her head made contact with the LOOSEY LU’s port side hull.  The passenger was in critical condition and was air lifted to University Medical Center Havasu.  The passenger was treated for a laceration to her head and later became stable. The San Bernardino County Sherriff’s Office and the Mohave County Sherriff’s Office took the lead in documenting the investigation. Alcohol testing was conducted on the operator of the AZ4354DA and the LOOSEY LU. The operator of the LOOSEY LU provided a post casualty drug test. Weather and fatigue were not causal factors during this marine casualty.

As a result of its investigation, The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the AZ4354DA not being able to maneuver appropriately when leaving the sand bar and causing the vessel to jerk to the left towards the LOOSEY LU.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) AZ4354DA failed to maintaining a Look-out, (2) AZ4354DA failed to operate at safe speed, (3) AZ4354DA failed to take action to avoid collision and (4) AZ4354DA failed to avoid a head on situation.   

This investigation activity does not recommend a referral to enforcement. The San Bernardino County Sherriff’s office found the operator of the AZ4354DA in violation of several nav rules and has forwarded a package to the District Attorney’s Office for further review and processing.

At 1700 CDT on 21JUL17, The M/V H B STEWART allided with the R J Corman Railroad Bridge (left descending pier) at mm 126.5 on the Cumberland River while down bound pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges.  During the approach approximately 500' above the bridge, the tow began to slide toward the left descending bank.  The master increased propulsion and twisted the stern attempting to avoid the pier.  The master failed to prevent the allision from occurring but cleared the bridge through the left descending fixed span of the bridge.  

Damage assessment of the bridge was conducted noting only cosmetic scraping.  Damage assessment of the barge was conducted by the crew revealing only cosmetic scraping.  No repairs were deemed necessary for the bridge or the barge.  USCG Aux and local FD verified report and provided photographic evidence.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the allision was due to the navigation of the master.  The master set up for passage through the LDB fixed span. After determining allision was imminent, he elected to increase speed and twist his stern around the pier unsuccessfully.  Weather and flow rates indicated normal operating conditions for navigation and were not deemed causal factors of the marine casualty.

During this investigation, discussion with industry representatives revealed that towing vessels often deviate the charted sail line toward the left descending fixed span of this particular bridge due to the wider span than the left and right center spans (118').  The IO intends to communicate this deviation from the normally anticipated vessel traffic scheme to the USACE-Nashville for planning purposes.

At approximately 0535 EST on July 22, 2017, the uninspected towing vessel EVELYN DORIS (O.N. 274942) allided with the William B. Umstead Bridge. The allision occurred as the EVELYN DORIS was pushing ahead a deck barge loaded with concrete bridge pilings southbound in the Croatan Sound. The William B. Umstead Bridge is a fixed bridge spanning the Croatan Sound, between Manns Harbor and Roanoke Island, in NC and has a horizontal clearance of 80 feet. Since the deck barge had a width of approximately 65 feet, the Mate utilized his deckhand to assist as a lookout during the transit. Neither the Mate nor the deckhand paid attention to the mast of the tug and the EVELYN DORIS struck the center span of the bridge with its mast which broke off at the point of impact approximately three feet from the top. In addition to the broken mast, the vessel's mast head light was damaged. The bridge sustained only minor damage, also losing a navigational light. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of the EVELYN DORIS with the William B. Umstead Bridge while passing under the structure. The weather conditions were not a contributing factor in this casualty. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the Mate's lack of familiarity with the vertical clearance of the William B. Umstead Bridge, and (2) Mate and lookout were only focused on the fendering system while passing through the bridge.

On 23 July 2017 at approximately 1500, the towing vessel BORN AGAIN (ON 562776) allided the lead port barge, the uninspected crane barge POULE D’EAU (ON 651232), with the center of the eastern side of the fendering system of the CSX Biloxi Railroad Bridge. At the time, the BORN AGAIN was pushing ahead 7 uninspected barges, 3 wide, which included 5 empty hopper barges and 2 crane barges. The master was steering the vessel and its tow southbound through the bridge at approximately 3.5 knots. The width of his tow was 108 feet and the span of the bridge was approximately 132 feet wide. He had 2 deckhands posted at the starboard and port bow of his tow to assist him in passing under the bridge safely. Winds were approximately 15 knots out of the northeast. Though the deckhand on the POULE D’EAU alerted the captain of the decreasing distance between the barge and the fendering system, the captain was not able to maneuver in time to avoid the allision due to the wind and minimal space on either side of his tow. 
No damage was sustained to the POULE D’EAU. The fendering system suffered rub marks and light scratching, which did not require repair. The bridge remained open after the allision to traffic.

At approximately 2315 CST, on July 24, 2017 the CAPT ELMER (O.N. 569698) was south bound on the Illinois River at MM 225.5 when the barge LTD 604 (O.N. 1122596) allided with the protection cell piling protecting the Illinois Central Rail Road Bridge. The pilot said the current pushed the tow onto the piling. The pilot had his crew check the barge and no damage was noted. The protection cell was undamaged.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the pilot's miscalculation of the river current's influence on the vessel, compounded with the vessel's speed while approaching the protection cell of the Illinois Central Rail Road Bridge, thus causing the allision.

On November 17, 2016, at approximately 8:00 p.m, the 64 foot U.S. towing vessel THOMAS R MORRISH departed Arcelor Mittal Facility in Cleveland, Ohio, pushing ahead barge CT 252, which was fully loaded with dredge spoils. The vessels began transiting down the Cuyahoga River, destined for the Confined Disposal Facility located inside the East Basin of Cleveland Inner Harbor.  At approximately 11:55 p.m. the captain on the THOMAS R MORRISH contacted the Columbus Road Bridge tender and requested an opening. After the bridge was opened, the captain began maneuvering through the bridge while following the bend of the river to starboard. As he attempted to turn under the bridge, the bow of the barge stopped swinging to starboard and struck the west fender of the Union Terminal Viaduct (immediately down river of the Columbus Road Bridge) and the vessels came to a stop. The captain was able to back the vessels out of the damaged fender and continued through the turn. However, as the towing vessel stern swung to port, the port quarter of the towing vessel struck the west fender of the Columbus Road Bridge but did not cause any damage. The captain continued down the river and did not notify the Coast Guard. Due to the length of time from date of the allision to the time this investigation was completed (16 months), enforcement action was not taken for failure to report a marine casualty.

The USCG was notified of the damage to the Union Terminal Viaduct fender by the Regional Transit Authority (bridge owner) at approximately 8:00 a.m. the same morning. Security camera footage from the Columbus Street Bridge, combined with the bridge tender log book, was used to identify the THOMAS R MORRISH and barge CT 252 as the vessels that struck and damaged the fender.

Although the initial estimate for fender repair was only $50,000.00, an updated cost estimate was submitted by the bridge owner a year after the incident that increased the cost to $447,000.00. Since the initial estimate was well under the Serious Marine Incident threshold of $100,000.00, alcohol and drug testing was not conducted on the captain of the towing vessel.
 
As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the barge and the Union Terminal Viaduct fender. After the captain backed the vessels out of the fender, the port quarter of the towing vessel allided with the Columbus Road Bridge fender. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) limited vessel maneuverability, (2) dynamic river current, (3) failure to anticipate effects of current, and (4) inexperience with maneuvering scenario.

HOU2017/0172: On July 31, 2018, the uninspected towing vessel DANIELLE GUIDRY’s  retractable anchor light allided with the I-10 bridge.  The vessel was under the control of the master and was inbound on the San Jacinto River Houston, Texas. Its destination was Lyondell Channelview, Texas where it intended to moor its barge, the Kirby K10035. The barge was loaded with Pygas.  

The captain reported that a crew member failed to lower the vessel’s anchor light while transiting under the bridge which caused the light to strike the bridge. Vessel repaired the damaged anchor light and received CG approval of the repairs. 

The initiating event for this casualty was the failure to follow procedures regarding the lowering of the anchor light.  

No damage was reported to the I-10 bridge. Case closed no further action to follow.

On June 30, 2017 at approximately 1015 (CST) the CHICAGO'S FAIR LADY (ON: 600933, 72FT, O/O Mercury Skyline Yacht Charters, Inspected under SubChapt T) was transiting on the South Branch of the Chicago River at MM 325 when the operator dropped his eye glasses on the deck. The operator leaned over to pick them up and when he regained his forward lookout, realized that the vessel was steering off-course. Before he could correct his heading the vessel allided with the northwest piling of the Van Buren Street Bridge. The vessel sustained some paint scrapes and minor damage to the fuel containment box. There was no damage to the bridge piling.

The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this incident was the vessel going off course because of the operator not maintaining a proper lookout. This was followed by the vessel alliding with the bridge piling.

MSD Quad Cities received notification from Sector Upper Mississippi River that UTV ARTHUR E SNIDER (272142) allided with the old Savanna Bridge. ARTHUR E SNIDER was transiting southbound at MM 537.8 pushing 09 loaded dry cargo barges. The ARTHUR E SNIDER approached the bridge at a reduced speed and with the guide of an assist boat due to construction in the area. The ARTHUR E SNIDER set was off and the tow lightly landed on the right descending pier. The crew conducted a round of the vessel and starboard barges. No damage of the vessel or barges were reported. No damage to the bridge was reported. The vessel continued southbound transit. The Illinois Department of Transportation sent engineer out to the bridge and did not report any damage.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot error in transiting through the bridge.

At approximately 0330 CST on July 30, 2017, the uninspected towing vessel CHARLES E MARTIN (O.N. 117727) allided with the Nickel Plate rail road bridge at MM 327.6 on the Calumet River. The pilot was maneuvering 2 red flag barges heading north bound on the Calumet River after his barges cleared the bridge (air gap), the pilot realized the top of the towing vessels bridge was not going to clear the bottom of the bridge and he attempted to lower it - but the bridge hit the mast and electrical equipment on top of the wheelhouse. The reporting party was the bridge tender on the bridge. The pilot on watch failed to report the allision. The bridge did not sustain damage as per a railroad representative.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the pilot misjudging the height of the CHARLES E MARTINS pilothouse.  This case has been referred for enforcement.

On 13 May, 2017 at approximately 1230 the SHERRY L was eastbound in the ICW, pushing 02 barges approaching the LI swing bridge. The vessel master was having trouble with a straight approach due to the 15 mph winds that were blowing out of the south.  As a precaution he posted tankerman on each side of the barges to alert him of pending issues on the approach.  As the vessel was approximately 350 ft from the bridge he was notified by a tankerman that he was approximately 15 feet "bad" on the port side.  The master proceeded to put the tug in full reverse in an attempt to correct the approach.  In doing so, the bow/barges swung to the starboard side of the channel. The master attempted to stop the swing by utilizing hard flanking rudders.  Vessel did not stop swinging and continued to the starboard side at which time it made contact with the dolphin on the starboard side of the channel.

After the allision, the vessel remained on scene until Coast Guard inspectors gathered information and ensured barge did not sustain any damage. No damage to the barges was noted. Damage noted on dolphin. 

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event to be the starboard barge swinging out of the channel due to ship handing by the master in an effort to straighten the tug and tow and alliding with the dolphin.  The casual factor leading to the initiating event was the captain's difficulty/inability to keep the tug and tow lined up properly to transit through the bridge due to the force of wind upon the tow.

On August 7, 2017, the tug JAY MICHAEL was inbound on the Fore River, pushing two empty barges in a tandem hip tow.  The starboard aft-most fendering tire on the starboard barge was turned sideways and protruding from the barge.  As the tug and tow passed through the Weymouth Bridge, the tow had approximately 2' of clearance between each barge and the bridge fenders.  Before clearing the bridge, the protruding tire snagged a beam on the bridge fendering system and detached from the barge, remaining on the bridge fender.  The bridge was inspected and no damage was found.  There was no damage to the tug or its barges.  The JAY MICHAEL delivered its barges and retrieved the tire from the bridge fender.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was contact between the barge fender tire and the bridge fender.

On 31 July 2017 at approx. 08:15 the towing vessel ARTHUR E SNIDER, downbound with 12 loaded grain barges was transiting the Burlington Northern Railroad Bridge at mile 328 UMR, when the tow allided with the protection cell of the bridge.  The barge SCF 2125 and the protection cell of the railroad bridge were damaged in this allision.  6 barges of the tow broke away due to the allision with the railroad bridge causing damage to the hopper barge BIG 9609.  One of the breakaway barges, (BIG 601) allided with the Quincy Memorial Highway Bridge at mile 327 UMR causing damage to the hopper barge.  The towing vessel PRAIRIE DAWN received damage to a tow knee while assisting in the capture of the breakaway barges.

On August 20, 2017, the Coast Guard Sector Hampton Roads Investigations Division investigated the tug ISLAND EXPRESS (O.N. 570877) and jumbo hopper barge SJ 199 (665820),which allided with the Great Bridge Lock fender system. This resulted in damage to the fender system and the temporary closure of the lock to repair essential lighting. The barge was loaded with scrap metal transiting south bound for Edenton, NC. No damage to the barge or pollution. Weather and fatigue were evaluated; however, it was determined that they were not a causal factor. 

The estimated damage assessment was approximately $75,000 according to the evaluation by the Army Corps of Engineers (ACOE). The electrical lighting was rewired and restored by the ACOE engineering division staff and the lock was returned to normal operation. The locks operation was interrupted for approximately three hours. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event was the allision with the Great Bridge Lock. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) poor planning by the mate on watch (2) failure to have the assistance of a crewman on watch as lookout, (3) the mates overconfidence bias that caused him to make bad judgment decisions regarding vessel maneuvering without assistance in a narrow channel, and (4) lack of individual training regarding navigation when pushing jumbo hopper barge.  

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity with a referral to an enforcement activity

On 20 July 2017 the tractor tug BRIDGETT MCALLISTER (O.N. 1193138) was operating in the Patapsco River in the vicinity of Anchorage #3 after assisting the vessel ATLANTIC SAIL moor at the Seagirt Marine Terminal. At approximately 1900 the vessel master was on the bridge with the mate on the helm and two maritime cadets who were observing operations. The master attempted to transit the interior bridge ladder to the galley when his foot lost contact with the top step. He fell approximately eight feet to the below. After he landed he noticed his right knee was twisted and laying flat at an unusual angle. He was lifted and repositioned on a bench in the galley until they returned to the dock where he was taken by ambulance to the local hospital.

On August 5, 2017, at approximately 2230, Towing Vessel W. P. SCOTT, pushing ahead barges MOBRO 203 and MOBRO 524, allided with the FEC Railway Bridge in Stuart, FL, while on a westbound course with a flooding current, leading to damage to the bridge’s fendering system. The overall size of the tow was 282 ft. x 48.5 ft. with a charted bridge horizontal clearance of 50 ft. As the vessel approached the bridge opening, it made contact, leading to damage of the wooden structures, concrete foundations and pilings with an estimated monetary damage of approximately $10,000 to $17,000.  

It was discovered that as the vessel approached the bridge opening, there was under 2 ft. of clearance. The master pushed up against the north (starboard fender) and made its way through the opening assuming no damage was incurred. Following the allision, the master made a report to Coast Guard Sector Miami via VHF, but due to miscommunication, the incorrect bridge was recorded (New River CSX Railway Bridge in Ft. Lauderdale, FL), and thereby Marine Safety Detachment Lake Worth was not notified of the casualty. The master reported no visible damage to none of the vessels or the bridge. 

The Coast Guard investigation has determined that the initiating event that led to the casualty was the vessel maneuvering with regards to the speed it was approaching the bridge, followed by the allision. The causal factors were 1) the current, 2) the bridge clearance, 3) the beam of the barges, 4) the vessel speed, and 5) the lack of control of the barges with regards to making a controlled approach. 

Initially as there was conflicting data between the monetary estimates regarding bridge damage due to pre-existing damage, it was relayed that damage could potentially be above $25,000, which is why the investigation was initially classified as an Informal Investigation, although based on the estimate, it meets the level of a Data Collection. Additionally, due to the deley in unit attaining notification and additionally due to lack of visual evidence, the vessel's speed and damage to the bridge was unverifiable as there was previous damage on the bridge's fendering system.

On 22 August, 2017 at approximately 0100, the tug CHAMPION, pushing two barges, allided with the Atlantic Beach Blvd Bridge while enroute to Green Cove Springs. As the vessel approached the bridge, the Master slowed the vessel to 3.5 knots. At approximately 200 feet from the bridge, the vessel began to set to the west. The starboard bow of the tow made contact with the east bridge fender system. The tug and barges then straightened out and continued on course. No damage was sustained by the barges or tug.

30 AUG 17, UTV LINDSAY ANN ERICKSON (Marquette Trans. CO., 647465, 6000HP) pushing 25 loaded barges (5 corn, 2 grain, 17 bean, 1 wheat) allided with the I-57 Bridge located at MM 7.3 UMR. The port stern barge CC 97116 (beans) sustained approx 20" inset over height of barge in the starboard bow and #1 void.  Pilot stated that he was observing the dewatering of a compartment in the starboard stern barge which had earlier sustained damage, when he got out of shape to properly navigate the channel span of the I-57 bridge.  The vessel was almost through th bridge span when the port stern barge struck the bridge pier. IL-DOT bridge inspector reported no damage was found to the I-57 bridge.

Coast Guard investigation determined the initiating event was the barge CC 97116 alliding with the left descending bank bridge pier of the I-57 bridge located at MM 7.3, Upper Mississippi River.  Contributing factors include 1) Pilot's attention being focused on a damaged barge in the tow; and 2) improperly navigating the brdige span because of the distraction.

At approximately 0240 CST on May 26, 2017, the UTV DORELLA BANTA pushing ahead two loaded red flagged barges had the port stern side of the tow's stern barge allide the Bayou Dularge Bridge Fender System.  Further, the UTV DORELLA BANTA's mast head light allided the underside of the Bayou Dularge Lift Bridge.  Both allisions occurred nearly simultaneously as the UTV DORELLA BANTA was underway west bound along the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway approaching MM 59.5 west of the Harvey Lock.  The tow initially got underway from Star Fleet, MM 90 along the Lower Mississippi River heading to Boones Fleet in Houston.  

The bridge fender system and the underside of the lift bridge were allided, but no damage reported and the bridge remained operational.  The mast head light of the UTV DORELLA BANTA was damaged and the port stern of red flag barge CCL 410 suffered a 14 foot long by 5 foot wide inset that began at the barge's deck.  All damage was above the waterline.  A Marine Surveyor and Coast Guard Inspector determined repairs to barge CCL 410 are deferred until next Internal Structural Examination due September 4, 2019.  A CG-835 was issued to that effect.  The UTV DORELLA BANTA was restricted to daylight transit only until the mast head light was repaired.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event was barge CCL 410 alliding the port side bridge fender system and the mast head light of the UTV DORELLA BANTA alliding the underside of the lift bridge nearly simultaneously.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: 1) Master neglected to request bridge be raised from 50 feet to accommodate for the vessel's 50 foot height; 2) Master's tow slid while lining up tow to go through the center of the 125 foot wide bridge opening causing port stern of barge CCL 410 to allide bridge fender.

At approximately 1830 EST on August 12, 2017, the towing vessel HEIDI (O.N. 500868) was underway on the Oregon Inlet while towing astern the crane barge WEEKS 522 (ON 1189038) with the trailing tow assistance from the towing vessel CAMIE when the WEEKS 522 allided with the Herbert C. Bonner bridge fender system. The incident occurred as the WEEKS 522 was being towed eastbound and during the transit through the bridge the current/wind took the crane barge's starboard side into the fender system. The master of the HEIDI immediately maneuvered the tug to starboard to prevent further damage to the fender system. 

The fender system was struck by WEEKS 522 starboard quarter. The fender system received damage to 6 vertical wooden reinforcements and the WEEKS 522 received only minimal damage to four tires installed alongside.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of barge WEEKS 522 into the bridge fender system. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty included: (1) master's lack of experience with the marine environment surrounding Oregon Inlet, and (2) weather and tidal conditions.

On October 25th, 2015 at approximately 2000 the towing vessel CHRISTI C (O.N. 1257680) was underway pushing the CAJUN COURAGE a crane barge up bound on the Atchafalaya River near mile marker 42. While transiting through the swing span of the Krotz Springs rail road bridge the CHRISTI C lost steering. The captain turned on the secondary steering pump to regain steering. In the time that the vessel did not have steering the current set the tow and laid the CAJUN COURAGE up against the swing span of the bridge. 

The CAJUN COURAGE had minor scratches. There was no damage to the bridge.

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the cause of the casualty to be the loss of steering on the CHRISTI C while transiting the bridge structure.

At approximately 0610 on September 22, 2017, the JACOB MICHAEL ECKSTEIN (ON: 668998) was transiting south bound on the Illinois River at MM 189 pushing 12 dry cargo barges when the vessel's port stern allided with the left descending piling of the highway 17 (Lacon) bridge. No report of damage, injury, or pollution was received.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the operators inadequate steering while passing the Lacon Bridge, resulting in the allision.

On 28SEP17, while transitting northbound along the ICW, the master of EL LORO struck a closed railroad drawbridge with the vessel's two masts. The masts were located forward on the focsle and aft on the poop deck, both were snapped clean off at the base. The masts fell aftward crashing onto a metallic canopy on the aft poop deck. The masts caused the canopy to collapse onto the passenger sitting area and the operator's station. The collapsed canopy severely restricts the master's ability to navigate the vessel by greatly limiting upward views above the vessel. No passengers suffered any injuries. Damage to the vessel resulted in an CG-835 being issued by the attending marine inspector.

UTV BRIDGET CAULLEY- KIRBY Inland Marine (ON 565797 2600 HP)north bound Ohio River at MM 950.2 with three red-flag barges strung out (Styrene cargo) grounded the lead barge.  The center bow corner of lead barge aground MM 950.2 OHR LDB while inside the channel. Tow is not blocking the channel. All voids have been checked and no damage observed.  The vessel was able to free the tow and resume its transit. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the grounding of the vessel and tow.  Contributing factors include 1) Low water on the Ohio River.

M/V ARDYCE RANDALL with 20 barges were down bound at MM 02 inside the channel when the port lead barge grounded.  The grounding causing barges to be set adrift. Assist tows from Cairo recovered 11 of the barges and with two barges grounded. The port lead barge RRS 8021 at MM .3 took on water in both the bow and stern tanks which were dewatered and the barge refloated. The ART 35001 grounded at MM 01. The ART 44147 grounded in channel at MM 02 and was refloated.

The M/V ELIZABETH CHASE was holding up at MM 1.4 UMR LDB with 30 barges in a 5x6 config. while waiting for down bound ARDYCE RANDALL.  The IN 95420 was in the tow of the ELIZABETH CHASE when it was struck in the center of the bow by two of the barges that were set adrift from the ARDYCE RANDAL, causing a facture 2ft x 1ft. above the water line in the center of the rake. The two barges then continued down the port side of the ELIZABETH CHASE tow before they were corraled by assist boats.

All grounded barges were refloated, and damaged barges taken to Cairo, IL for repairs.

Coast Guard investigation determined the intiating event to be the grounding of the lead barge in the tow of the ARDYCE RANDALL. Contributing factors include 1)suspected shoaling off the reds near Greenfield bend at approx MM 2.5 UMR; 2) Dropping water levels on the Mississippi River

On 23SEP17, the UTV BECKY SUE (587330) was navigating north bound on the Upper Mississippi River when the lead barge allided with the Belt Line Rail Road swing bridge at mile marker 835.5.  The UTV was pushing 03 empty dry cargo barges drafting 1' and preparing to transit through the Belt Line Railroad Swing Bridge when the lead barge, AEP 7347, allided with the left descending side pier. The barge caused damage to the outer layer of the bridge's concrete pier and a loss of a red navigation light tha was affixed to the bridge.  The lead barge sustained a dent to the bow approximately 2.5' wide by 2' tall.  The incident occured at approximately 0705 with the Master at the wheel, who misjudged the closing distance to the pier. The voyage continued with no other damage, pollution, or injuries (03 POB).

The owner of the barge stated the damage to the barge was minor and they have no plans to repair the vessel.

On 01 October 2017, at approximately 0930 hours, the DOUGLAS B (O.N. 1071022) and the SEA TIGER (O.N. 565697)were towing/pushing the COASTAL 20, which made contact and allided with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge. The vessel's were conducting the tow using a "piggy-back" method through the bridge. Piggy-back is a local term when both tugs face up to the object being towed, one in the front and one in the rear in order to maneuver in tight spaces. The COASTAL 20 is approximately 54 feet in width, and the opening of the bridge is approximately 56 feet in width. 

The allision with the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge fendering system caused slight damages. The wooden fendering system slightly splintered, causing small wooden pieces to litter the waterway. 

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the insufficient vessel approach angle.

At 0127 local, SECUMR rcvd a report of a bridge allison with Lacrosse R/R bridge at MM 699.8 UMR, near Lacrosse, MN, in MSD St Paul AOR. The V Sarah Hunter which is owned by Hunter Marine was transiting northbound from St Louis to St Paul. The Sarah Hunter was drafting 9.6 feet but the 08 barges she was pushing were empty dry cargo barges which provided sufficient surface area to be pushed about by an approximate wind of 17 knots while she was trying to pass under the bridge. The wind forced the tow into the sheer fence making contact with the port lead barge of the tow. The UTV reports no damage. The Bridge made initial call to CG confirming that bridge was hit. Bridge was inspected with no damage noted.  On scene weather was 77’ with South winds at 10-17 knots.

On June 4, 2017, at 10:23 a.m. Eastern Daylight Time, the 625 foot U.S. freight vessel GREAT REPUBLIC entered the main channel of the Cuyahoga River and began transiting up the river. The Cuyahoga River had an outbound current of approximately 1.4 mph during the transit. As the vessel commenced turning through the starboard bend at Jacobs Pavilion, the current slowed the turn rate of the vessel’s bow. At approximately 10:50 a.m., the port bow of the GREAT REPUBLIC allided with a concrete abutment/fender for the CSX RR Bridge located at mile marker 1.28 on the east bank of the Cuyahoga River.  After the allision, the vessel safely proceeded to Osborne Concrete and Stone Dock. While completing the transit, the forepeak bilge high level alarm sounded, caused by water ingress through a hull puncture below the waterline. Once safely docked, the captain notified the Coast Guard and the vessel was unloaded and ballasted to bring the damage out of water to stop the flooding. 

The vessel was authorized by Class (ABS) and the U.S. Coast Guard to complete a temporary patch to transit to Toledo, Ohio to complete permanent repairs. 

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the GREAT REPUBLIC and the CSX RR Bridge (1.28). After the allision, the steel hull failed below the waterline and the forepeak tank began to flood. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) strong river current, (2) failure to anticipate effects of current, (3) inadequate bridge fender, and (4) failure of hull below waterline.

On 17 October 2017, the deck barge AB 114 (O.N. 1266931) was anchored outside of Chesapeake Yachts in Chesapeake, Virginia. The crew of the tug MR CHESTER (O.N. 642927) made fast to starboard side of the barge in a hip tow configuration, and then proceeded to move the barge north towards the I-64 High Rise Bridge on the Elizabeth River. At the same time, a spud barge was stationed on the east side of the fendering system underneath the I-64 High Rise Bridge conducting annual maintenance to the bridge. A Coast Guard Safety Broadcast Notice to Mariners (BNM) and a Marine Safety Information Bulletin (MSIB) were in place from Sector Hampton Roads informing local mariners that the bridge was under construction and anyone passing through the center channel was required to contact the work barge at least 15 minutes prior to transiting under the bridge. The Master of the MR CHESTER had transited in that area several times while the bridge was under maintenance and was aware of the requirements established in the BNM and MSIB. When the MR CHESTER and AB 114 began to approach the I-64 High Rise Bridge, the Captain made no attempt to contact the work crew to inform them of his intentions. As the MR CHESTER and AB 114 passed underneath the bridge, the AB 114 allided with the west side of the bridge fendering system.

After alliding with the fendering system, the MR CHESTER and AB 114 continued northbound on the Elizabeth River and failed to report the allision. The crew on the work barge alerted Virginia Department of Transportation (VDOT), who notified Sector Hampton Roads of the allision. As a result of the allision with the fender system, four planks were knocked off the fender system and additional structural damage occurred to the support system. The damage amount to the fender system was estimated at $60,000.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event was the AB 114 allision with the west side of the I-64 High Rise Bridge fender system. The subsequent event was damage to the fendering system planks and structural supports. The causal factors contributing to the reportable marine casualty were: 1) overconfidence of the Captain created by multiple transits through the narrow channel without incident, 2) failure to notify the work barge before his transit as required by the BNM and MSIB, and 3) failure of VDOT to conduct repairs to the west side fender system prior to the allision.

Recommend closing this preliminary investigation with a referral to an enforcement activity.

MSD Quad Cities received a report of an allision between UTV PRAIRIE DAWN and the Clinton Railroad Bridge. The vessel was southbound pushing 6 barges (5 loaded grain, 1 empty). The set of approach was miscalculated and the barge ART 340 rubbed the bridge at MM 518. This caused damage to the barge in the #1 and #2 voids. Temporary repairs were made using shingling and tarps. Permanent repairs will be made in New Orleans.  The company is estimated approximately $1,000.00 in damage to the barge.

As a result of the investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the marine casualty was operator error and inexperience. There was a steersman that was working towards his license on watch behind the wheel with the master of the vessel. The set that was made to account for current while transiting under the bridge was the set that would normally work correctly for a tow of 15 barges. Due to the tow only having 6 barges, the set was not correct to prevent alliding with the bridge.

On October 14, 2017, MSD Quad Cities received a report of a bridge allision between JAMES F NEAL and the Dubuque Railroad Bridge. There was no damage reported on the vessel, barges, or the bridge. The vessel was southbound and had an assist tug on the jack staff barge. The barge that made contact lightly rubbed on one of the loaded dry cargo barges. The vessel was pushing 8 dry cargo barges and 1 unloaded red flag barge. The vessel continued its voyage southbound after no damage was reported to the Coast Guard.

As a result of the investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the marine casualty was operator error.

On 22 October 2017, at approximately 1130, a construction barge was unmanned and drifted down the ICW until it allided with the Bayou Bouef Railroad Bridge.  The bridge was able to open to let a tug come through and retrieve the barge but shut down until a bridge inspector arrived and deemed it safe for trains to pass.  The bridge was shut down for about two hours and then resumed operations.  The barge was secured back to its mooring location with no damage.  A damage survey was conducted on the barge on October 23, 2017, and showed the barge did not sustain any damage.  This event did not result in any injuries or pollution.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard had determined that the initiating event was caused by securing the spuds on the barge so they could not free fall. This was followed by a passing storm that provided high winds, rain, and a rise in the river which contributed to the barge drifting into the channel with no means on stopping until it allided with the Railroad Bridge.  As result of this incident, the company that owns the barge has a new policy that requires the spud safety cables have slack faked out on deck to allow the spuds to free fall while moored in case the water level rises again the spuds can drop to secure the barge in place.

On October 26 2017, the COOPERATIVE VENTURE (O.N. 577609) was southbound on the Upper Mississippi Mile Marker 835.7 pushing 12 loaded dry cargo barges. The Pilot was making the approach to the Pigs Eye Bridge and was advised to stay to the red buoy side of the channel. The Pilot was unable to execute the turn correctly which resulted in the stern of the towing vessel being too far to the right descending bank(RDB). The swift current in the bend on the RDB was faster moving than the head of the tow near the left descending bank. This caused the tow to become crossways in the channel and the Pilot added speed to increase the turn rate on the head of the tow. This maneuver was partially successful but the port lead barge contacted the east pier of the swing bridge causing extensive damage. The ITASCA and WHITE ROCK assisted with the recovery of the port string of barges. The lead barge ART 35157 (loaded with soybeans) sustained damage and was taking on water in the bow rake. ART 35157 was later moored at a nearby fleeting area. 

The bridge tender reported that the bridge pier was cracked along the length of the pier with significant damage. As a result of the allision, no railroad traffic was permitted to pass. The waterway remained open to river traffic, but only along the right descending bank span with one vessel and tow at a time. Initial property estimates placed this incident well over $500K making this a Major Marine Casualty necessitating notification to CG-INV and the NTSB. Additionally, Sector Upper Mississippi River has been in close coordination with the D8 bridge branch regarding the damage to the bridge and overseeing subsequent repairs. Investigating Officers drove to the bridge and walked out to the end of the bridge. The concrete pier supporting the end of the fixed part of the bridge on the east side of the river was displaced by approximately 4 to 5 feet to the down stream side. The fixed portion of the bridge is tilted at approximately 5 degrees with the higher portion on the up stream side. 

Investigating Officers reviewed the Operations Manual and found no inconsistencies between the actions taken and those required

Drug and Alcohol testing was completed.

On 24OCT17 MSD St Paul received notification of allision between the barge GM 5028 (pushed by T/V Kylie Brown) and the Lacrosse RR Bridge.  T/V KYLIE BROWN, transiting N/B pushing 2 empty red flag barges, rubbed the center protection cell of the bridge with stern of the port barge resulting in broken timbers. MSD St. Paul conducted an on scene investigation on 25OCT17.  Master stated a gust of wind and heavy current pushed the tow into the bridge before he could correct course to prevent impact with the bridge.  No other damage, pollution or injuries were observed.  The bridge was damaged but remains fully operational.

On Scene WX: CLEAR; Winds NW @ 20MPH/ G @ 28MPH; Air 47F; Water 52F; VIS 10NM

On October 21, 2017 at approximately 0700 local time, the uninspected towing vessel FRANK HOLLOMON pushing an empty barge allided with the Claiborne Avenue Bridge, located in the Industrial Canal, New Orleans, LA. 

While passing under the Claiborne Avenue Bridge with a clearance of 43 ft, the crew of the FRANK HOLLOMON failed to drop a mast light pole.  The mast light pole allided with the bridge breaking the support bolts holding the mast light pole upright.  No damage was reported by the bridge.  Damage to the vessel was estimated at $50.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that this incident met the criteria for a reportable marine casualty as this was an unintended allision with a bridge. Since the damages did not exceed $25K, the level of investigative effort met the requirements of a Data Collection.

The UTV JAKE WEST was northbound on the Arkansas River pushing 12 empty dry cargo barges.  The strbd stern barge in the tow, PB 9058, allided with the Broadway Bridge protector cell at MM 119. 

The pilot contacted the railroad bridge operator fifteen minutes prior to the vessel's arrival at the railroad bridge in order to obtain clearance to transit the bridge. The bridge operator notified the pilot that there was a train that would be crossing. The pilot made arrangements to allow train to pass prior to transiting the bridge. When the train exited the bridge, the pilot began transiting through the Broadway Bridge towards the Railway Bridge. As the pilot started transiting, a second train starting crossing the railroad bridge. The pilot got caught in between the two bridges and the wind pushed the tow down onto the protective cell of the Broadway Bridge. 

Arkansas DOT authorities inspected the bridge and no damage was reported.  The duty inspectors conducted a damage survey of the barge and noted no damage or water ingress in the voids.

The investigation revealed that there was miscommunication between the bridge operator and the pilot leading to the bridge allission. The pilot proceeded to the next bridge when he could have maintained the vessel position or pushed into the bank and held up while the second train passed over the railroad bridge.

On 03NOV2017 at approximately 2350 hrs the M/V VERNON M WEILAND (Borgess Towing, 643443, 2000HP). was down bound MM 937.1 with 15 hpper barges in a 3x5 configuration (1 red flag - refined soy oil, 11 soy bean, 1 corn & three empty hoppers) attempting to navigate the Irvin S. Cobb Bridge (LLNR 28205). While twisting stern out into channel to begin approach to lock, didn't work out far enough into channel before coming ahead and flipping head of tow out into river resulting in the stern in the saddle bag position on the right descending channel pier. After coming ahead to try to avoid pier realized stern was too far over. At that time reversed propulsion and began backing but was too late and resulted in contact with bridge pier.Kentucky DOT reported damage to the bridge. Damage to barge ART 35077 and 19 broken wires. 


Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the Allision with the bridge.  Contributing factors include 1) Loss situational awareness 2.) Insuffcent Vessel Horsepower to barge ratio(133 HP per barge.

On November 1, 2017, at approximately 0315, Central Standard Time, the towing vessel VIVIAN B allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge. The vessel was pushing 4 loaded coal barges (2X2) configuration down bound at mile marker 8.3 on the Green River in Reed, KY. After the vessel passed under the HWY 60 bridge the Master heard a noise and felt a vibration on the port engine. The Master put the port main into neutral, then reverse, and attempted to flush out what he thought was debris. The Master put the port main back into gear and realized it was inoperable due to the handling of the vessel. The port main lost maneuverability and propulsion. The starboard engine was online but the Master could not back down the head speed. The vessel allided the port lead barge with the CSX Railroad Bridge pillar.

The bridge and the barge were not damaged. The vessel lost their port shaft seal and took on approximately 30 inches of water. The crew was able to dewater the engine room and the vessel was inoperable due to the loss of the port engine.

The Coast Guard investigation determined that the initiating event was the loss of maneuverability due to a fouled prop shaft, subsequently the vessel lost of propulsion (partial) when the port propulsion shaft broke and the vessel's tow allided with the CSX Railroad Bridge (AKA Spottsville Railroad Bridge).

At approximately 2050 on 21 October 2017, Sector Miami was notified by the Master of UTV BRITTANY BEYEL, which was engaged in pushing an inspected barge (T Boat) named MIAMI SCIENCE BARGE that it had allided with the PALMETTO PARK BRIDGE. According to the Master, the UTV BRITTANY BEYEL had suffered an engine casualty causing the tug to lose propulsion and drift on to the east side of the bridge causing damage to the hanging light and fenders.  After conducting an initial assessment, the master reported that the MIAMI SCIENCE BARGE did not suffer any damage itself, only damage was to material found on deck. The bridge operator reported that they were having an inspector assess the situation and that only one span of the bridge was able to open due to mechanical issues, prior to this incident.

The attending marine inspector was able to conduct an operational inspection of the UTV BRITTANY BEYEL main engine along with the damage survey and they were found to be consistent with the initial report.  The Master described that the engine casualty was likely caused by sediment or water build up in the air line for the 2 and 1 valve that allows the vessel to go in and out of gear and to throttle up and down. This issue caused the valve to get stuck and was the initiating event in the allision. The engineer was able to respond soon after the machinery failure and manually recycled the valve, turned the engine back on and it worked satisfactorily. By the time the Master regained control it was too late to avoid the allision, specially accounting for the open space with the only one span opening.

The damages associated with this allision was limited to the solar panel and aluminum A-frame on the MIAMI SCIENCE BARGE, estimated at $2,500. Also, a damage assessment was conducted by the Boca Raton Police and bridge crew of the PALMETTO PARK BRIDGE.  Those damages were deemed minimal and estimated at $6,000.  

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the loss of air control to the port engine while under load.  This undoubtedly had an effect on the vessel's maneuverability while in tow of the MIAMI SCIENCE BARGE.  This was followed by the eventual allision with the PALMETTO PARK BRIDGE.  The casual factor that contributed to the casualty was the limitation for both spans to open on the PALMETTO PARK BRIDGE.

On October 28th, 2017, MSD Quad Cities recieved notification of an allision between the UTV STEVEN L COLBY and the Dubuque-Wisconsin Highway bridge. The UTV was pushing 12 dry cargo barges on the Mississippi River northbound at MM 583.4 while transiting under the bridge. The pilot's approach was favoring the red buoy line more than usual. The pilot had just made a turn prior to making his set to the bridge causing the set to be wider than usual. The pilot attempted to correct his course when he realized he was too close to the red buoy line. As a result of starting the set late the pilot was unable to avoid an allision with the bridge. This resulted in a barge break away splitting the barges into groups of 9, 2, and 1. The group of 9 laid over to the right descending bank and came to rest on the bridge. The 2 barges remained partially attached to the UTV. The 1 barge floated down the river and was recovered first. With the assistance of 2 assist vessels, the UTV managed to recover all 12 barges. It was later discovered that one of the 2 barges that remained partially attached to the UTV had struck the UTV puncturing 2 holes into the number 2 fuel tank and the number 3 gunnel. The 2 holes in the fuel tank and gunnel were located on the deck and the fuel level was well below the bottom of the hole. The vessel submitted a transit plan in order to proceed light ship to make permanent repairs.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the marine casualty was operator error. The pilot on watch was not positioned correctly to make the appropriate set for transiting under the bridge.

M/V MIDLAND allided with SABULA RR BRIDGE. Vessel is pushing 11 barges (5 loaded, 6 empty).  The second barge in the port string struck the bridge after getting caught in the cross current just below the bridge. No notifications were made to the bridge or CG prior to the unintentional incident.  No damage, pollution or injuries to report from the vessel.  SABULA RR BRIDGE is reporting broken concrete on a lower walkway however no significant damage was observed by CG responders.  Bridge is fully operational.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty were the misjudgment of the weather/water conditions.

Sector Long Island Sound received notification from the tug TIMOTHY L REINAUER pushing ahead (in the notch) the loaded fuel barge RTC 84 that they had been struck by the light coal barge BRIDGEPORT being towed astern by the tug JOAN MORAN while transiting in Long Island Sound off Stratford, CT. There were 7 crew members on the tug TIMOTHY L REINAUER and 8 crew members on the JOAN MORAN. No injuries were reported on either vessel. No pollution was reported. Post-casualty drug and alcohol tests were conducted for the TIMOTHY L REINAUER and JOAN MORAN on crew members determined to be directly involved in the incident.

The JOAN MORAN was towing the light coal barge BRIDGEPORT astern on a 915-foot cable, transiting Long Island Sound from Bridgeport, CT enroute to Providence RI. The TIMOTHY L REINAUER pushing (in the notch) the RTC 84 was transiting Long Island Sound from New York, enroute to New Haven, CT. The JOAN MORAN/BRIDGEPORT came upon the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84 near Stratford Shoal/Middle Ground, off Stratford, CT, approaching from behind, creating an overtaking situation. The Mate on the JOAN MORAN requested a "2 whistle pass", which the Mate on the TIMOTHY L REINAUER agreed to. That meant that the JOAN MORAN/BRIDGEPORT would pass the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84, keeping the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84 on her starboard side. In accordance with the Inland Navigation Rules, the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84 was to maintain her course and speed while the JOAN MORAN/BRIDGEPORT passed her on her port side. The JOAN MORAN/BRIDGEPORT was making 11.4 knots and altered course to port two times; at 1723 to 20 degrees and at 1724 to 15 degrees with a total of 35 degrees alteration to create room to overtake the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84. The TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84 was making 10.0 knots and maintained course and speed. At approximately 1726, TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC 84’s course had change 08 degrees to port, putting the BRIDGEPORT’s heading across the bow of the RTC 84. During the passing maneuver and before the BRIDEPORT had cleared the TIMOTHY L REINAUER/RTC, the Mate on the TIMOTHY L REINAUER notified the Mate on the JOAN MORAN on VHF Channel 13 of a pending collision. The Mate on the TIMOTHY L REINAUER had been putting a fix on a chart and changing charts when he looked over his shoulder and so the pending collision. The Mate on the JOAN MORAN turned hard to port and the Mate on the TIMOTHY L REINAUER went full astern but the collision could not be avoided. At 1735, the stern starboard quarter of the BRIDGEPORT made contact with the port bow of the RTC 84.  Both barges sustained damage. The RTC 84 suffered an inset on the port side bow in the way of the forepeak to frame #12 on the #1 port side ballast tank. All damage was above the waterline with no hull penetrations. The BRIDGEPORT suffered a 4-foot by 6-inch penetrating gash on the starboard aft quarter located 6 feet above the waterline. The collision occurred approximately 12 minutes from the agreed 2 whistle passing. 

The cause of this casualty was determined to be the loss of situational awareness by the Mates of the JOAN MORAN and TIMOTHY L REINAUER. The Mate on the JOAN MORAN did not observe the course change of the TIMOTHY L REINAUER and reduced distance to pass. The Mate on TIMOTHY L REINAUR was occupied with putting the fix on a chart and switching charts that he did not maintain awareness of JOAN MORAN/BRIDEPORT and the reduced passing distance.

At approximately 0450 CST on November 10, 2017, the bulk carrier OCEANA allided with the Corpus Christi Harbor Bridge in Corpus Christi, Texas.  The allision occurred as the OCEANA was transiting the Corpus Christi Ship Channel entering the Corpus Christi Inner Harbor to load cargo.  At the time of the allision, the vessel was empty, “in ballast” and had departed the Aransas Fairway Anchorage earlier that morning.

The OCEANA struck the bridge with its INMARSAT C antenna, sustaining damage only to the antenna and its mounting base.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the miscalculation of the vessel’s draft and “air draft” by the Chief Officer.  This was followed by the eventual allision with the bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) errors in the vessel’s computerized draft calculation software.

On 18 November 2017, the Fishing Vessel SENECA (O.N. 532569) was moored port side to the pier at Wanchese Fish Company in Hampton, Virginia, with the vessel bow approximately 10 yards from the J.P. Mugler Bridge. At approximately 1600 LMT the vessel’s master finished unloading his catch and was instructed to move the vessel to another pier at the same facility. He made a series of vessel maneuvers in order to conduct a clockwise turn away from the pier, and the vessel grounded next to the J.P. Mugler Bridge. The master then put a line around the bridge in an attempt to use it as a spring line once the vessel re-floated. The flood current caused the vessel to re-float and subsequently allide with a section of the J.P. Mugler Bridge. 

With assistance from another fishing vessel, the SENECA made it off the bridge and returned to the dock at Wanchese Fish Company. A post casualty inspection found that the starboard bow sustained minor damage to the hand rail and the upper hull plating, and six rudder collar bolts and a portion of the rudder collar itself had fractured. A dive survey found no underwater damage to the shaft, propeller, rudder, or hull.

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event to be the grounding of the SENECA. Without an ability to back off the bottom and move clear of the bridge, the vessel allided with the bridge as soon as the rising tide lifted the SENECA off the bottom. Causal factors contributing to this casualty were: 1) the failure of the master to provide an adequate margin of safety while shifting the SENECA to a different berth; and 2) the flooding tide that caused a substantial current towards the J.P. Mugler Bridge.

Recommended closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement.

At approximately 0450 CST on November 11th, 2014 the towing vessel TINY SANDERSON, official number (O/N) 572722 pushing two empty barges abreast 108 feet wide, when the starboard barge, KIRBY 28308, O/N 977262 allided with the Naheola Bridge in the Tombigbee River, AL. The KIRBY 28308 barely rubbed the north side pilling of the bridge causing no obvious damage to the bridge or the barge. The weather conditions at the time included smooth seas, less than 5mph winds, no current, and depth of water was approximately 18 feet. The pilot had been driving for approximately six hours at the time allission occurred and the Master was about to relieve the watch once they had ensured safe passage through the bridge. The pilot took all proper precautions to clear the bridge but did not anticipate the bridge width as he was turning the vessel to go pass through the bridge.

On November 26, 2017, at approximately 18:30, the HONG KONG BRIDGE lost propulsion while outbound from the Port of Long Beach. The vessel was brought safely to anchorage D5 by two assist tugs.  The servo oil pumps had become air-locked and unable to pump oil at the required pressure, resulting in a low pressure in the servo oil pumps.  The low pressure was the result of air being introduced into the servo oil system by an open vent valve, following replacement of filters while the vessel was in port. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the servo oil pump, which caused an automatic main engine shutdown.  The casual factor that contributed to this incident was the introduction of air into the servo oil system following the replacement of filters while the vessel was in port.

On 21 November 2017 at approx. 10:25 local time the towing vessel CODY BOYD (ACBL) experienced a complete loss of propulsion, steering, and power. The towing vessel and 14 barges (8 loaded (3 red flag)/6 empty (1 red flag)) drifted backwards downriver and the starboard rear barge in the tow allided with a protection cell of the Pearl R/R bridge causing 4 empty barges (1 empty red flag) to break away from the tow and become pinned between the protection cell and the right descending bank (RDB). The CODY BOYD continued to drift downbound with the remaining 10 barges attached. The towing vessel ERNA E HONEYCUTT arrived on-scene and assisted the CODY BOYD to the RDB.
