The towing vessel COOPERATIVE MARINER arrived on-scene and kept station in the vicinity of the Pearl R/R and monitored the 4 empty barges pinned against the bank. The  CODY BOYD was able to eventually restart her engines and restore full ship's power and propulsion systems.  The cause of the propulsion failure was determined to be water intrusion in the day tank due to a faulty hatch seal. 

The bridge was inspected with no damage to the protection cell. All barges were inspected with no damage found. The cause was determined to be water intrusion into a day tank due to a faulty gasket on a topside hatch covering. Repairs were affected on the gasket and the CODY BOYD's engines were restarted and run on-scene for several hours without further issues.

On 24 November 2017 at approx. 18:45, the towing vessel LAMONT TRADER (O.N. 5591046) was pushing a 4 barge tow down bound on the Illinois river at mile 151 with the towing vessel EDMUND L assisting  when two barges in the tow allided with the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RAILROAD BRIDGE (AKA Pekin Pacific Railroad bridge).  The CBC 390 and CBC 375, both loaded with Naphtha, were the barges that allided with the bridge’s left descending protection cell sheer fence. The M/V LAMONT TRADER's tow was able to continue with only minor damage not requiring immediate repair to the barge CBC 390. There was no damage to barge CBC 375. The bridge’s wooden sheer fence was damaged. There was no damage to the bridge track or lifting mechanism.  The Railroad’s Bridge Maintenance Manager stated that the damage to the sheer fence was estimated to exceed 100K. Post accident DOT drug testing was performed on the crew.

On 05DEC17 at approximately 1620 local time, The M/V AMERICAN DUCHESS (1030831, AMERICAN QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO.) allided with the R. J. Corman Railroad Bridge upper guide pier at MM126.5 on the Cumberland River.  The vessel was approaching the bridge in a northerly direction to transit the right descending span of the bridge with 200 passengers and crew at approximately 2.3 knots.  The bridge was notified by the vessel of the approach initiating the rotation of the bridge counter clockwise at approximately 1615 to allow the vessel to proceed.  As the vessel approached at approximately 1620 local time, the port stern quarter was set toward the pier by southerly winds affecting the large sail area of the vessel.  The vessel port stern quarter scraped along the pier causing cosmetic damage to the vessel and breaking off a red navigation light fixture and platform from the pier.  The vessel continued transit through the bridge without further incident en route to Dover, TN.  

The Coast Guard investigation identified bridge resource management gaps regarding delayed communications between navigation watchstanders and wind conditions on approach to the bridge, as causal factors to the allision.  Onscene witness described winds and gusts up to 15 mph and local weather reports indicate winds were up to 25 mph and gusting to 32 mph in a southerly direction.  Damage to the vessel was found to be cosmetic in nature and did not affect the seaworthiness of the vessel.  Damage to the bridge guide pier is estimated at $2500 for replacement of the light fixture and platform.

On December 6, 2017 at 0005, while moored and engaged in cargo operations at Conley Terminal, Boston Harbor, the Panamanian flagged containership HELSINKI BRIDGE broke away from the dock following failure of the single mooring bitt that was holding the vessel's bow lines. After the bitt failed, the remaining lines parted in sequence, from forward to aft, allowing the ship's bow to swing away from the pier. As the bow continued to swing, the bulbous bow allided with Black Falcon Cruise Ship Terminal, located across from Conley on the opposite side of the Reserved Channel. The vessel Master activated the bow thruster and dropped the port anchor in an attempt to stop the swing of the bow. Assist tug JUSTICE was alongside within 20 minutes of the break away to assist in holding the vessel stationary. A Harbor Pilot boarded the vessel and piloted it to Broad Sound anchorage without further incident. No injuries or pollution resulted from the casualty. Damage to Conley Terminal was limited to the broken bollard casting with replacement cost of $20,000.  Black Falcon Terminal sustained $550,000 in damage. A dive survey conducted on the HELSINKI BRIDGE found no structural damage to the vessel, however replacement cost for the parted lines amounted to $40,500.  

When the vessel arrived in Boston on December 5, 2017, the crew and docking pilot were aware that elevated wind conditions were forecast for that evening and the docking pilot advised the vessel Master to set five bow lines, five stern lines, two forward spring lines and two aft spring lines. Once the vessel was dockside, the Chief Mate took his position on the forecastle and directed line placement.  He directed the 5 head lines to be placed on 3 different mooring structures, but was told that the two forward bollards could not be used due to dock construction. The Chief Mate alerted the vessel Master of the issue and completed the mooring evolution with placement of all five headlines on one mooring structure.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the single mooring bitt on which the 5 headlines were placed. Once the single mooring bitt failed, the additional strain placed on the remaining lines exceeded their strength and they began to part in sequence from forward to aft as the vessel's bow swung away from the dock. As the vessel's bow continued to swing, the bulbous bow allided with the Black Falcon Terminal dock, damaging pilings and the dock's concrete deck. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) limited availability of mooring appurtenances for the vessel's assigned mooring location, (2) the vessel Captain's decision to place five mooring lines on one bitt, (3) the Docking Pilot did not verify the safety of the vessel's mooring arrangements prior to departure, (4) condition of the single mooring bitt prior to failure, and (5) Conley Terminal did not consider the vessel's mooring needs and available accommodations when directing the vessel's mooring location.

MSD Quad Cities received report of allision by UTV ANDREW CANNAVA with the Clinton R/R Bridge at Upper Mississippi River MM 517. The Vessel was transiting S/B, pushing 8 loaded dry cargo barges. While making its approach towards Clinton R/R Bridge the vessel came to a stop mid-channel to wait for a train to complete its crossing. There was a delay in the swing bridge opening while the UTV ANDREW CANNAVA maneuvered to set up its approach which caused the vessel to fall out of position. The Captain attempted to realign his set and the port lead barge carrying corn pushed against the protection cell. The impact caused several 1/4 inch small fractures within a 10 ft span approximately 6 ft down from the deck which resulted in the bow compartment to flood. The vessel pushed up into Beaver Slough out of the channel and utilized three 3" diesel pumps and a 2" diesel pump to dewater the space. The vessel had 2 extra 3" pumps and the UTV Trojan was in the vicinity to assist if needed. The UTV ANDREW CANNAVA dewatered the bow and utilized wood shingles to plug the fractures and secured the flooding to the compartment. UTV TROJAN was utilized to maneuver the damaged barge and repositioning it in the tow to the port stern with damage facing inboard to prevent shingles working loose. UTV ANDREW CANNAVA maintained 2" pump in the space as precautionary and proceeded en-route to their destination Cairo IL. No other damage, pollution or injury occurred and Clinton R/R Bridge remained operational and undamaged.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was due to operator error.

15 DEC 17 - SLMR received a report of the M/V BRIDGET CAULLEY (3,200 HP, twin screw, KIRBY INLAND MARINE LP) hitting a black buoy at MM 733 LMR, inside the channel. The buoy is stuck in the starboard wheel of the M/V. They have an assist tug on scene, M/V JIM BURTON, assisting them to McKellar Lake where they will have a diver meet them. There are no reports of damage, pollution, or injuries.

Investigation revealed vessel was hugging the RDB attemting to stay away from the area where the RICKY ROBINSON was sunk. Vessel ran over a buoy attempting to do so.

On 22 December 2017 at approximately 2315, the towing vessel ST PEREGRINE (ON 1112132) allided the forward, starboard barge in tow, the uninspected hopper barge MTC 0157 (ON 1232704), with the Pensacola Bay Bridge fendering system. At the time, the ST PEREGRINE was pushing ahead four empty, open hopper barges in a 2x2 configuration, transiting westbound at approximately 6.7 knots. Observed weather included winds at 15 knots out of the Southwest, gusting to 17-18 knots. When the Captain approached the bridge, he placed his tow within 5 or 6 feet of the port fendering system of the bridge. Despite his efforts, the wind gusted and pushed the tow towards the starboard fendering system, so that the starboard, quarter of the MTC 0157 rubbed against the northeast concrete cell of the fendering system. The MTC 0157 suffered paint scrapes along the starboard side. All voids were found dry. The concrete cell, which is surrounded by corrugated metal, suffered no damage from the barge. The operator of the ST PEREGRINE, Marquette Transportation, notified Pensacola DOT about the allision. No pollution or injuries resulted from this casualty.

On December 20, 2017 at approximately 0000 the UTV William C (O.N. 517882, 76ft) was pushing the empty tank barge, CBC 184 (O.N. 1027568, 200ft) southbound on the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal at MM 314.5 when the barge winch struck the Atchison Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Bridge. The allision caused damage to the winch frame. No report of any damage to the bridge, pollution or injury.

On 20 December, 2017, the towing vessel BIG JAKE was pushing a spudded construction barge through the Mill Basin Bridge in New York.  The towing vessel is a steel hull of a length of 86.5 feet. The towing vessel approached the bridge at .01 knots to ascertain the air draft and vertical clearance of the spudded construction barge however allided with the first beam of the bridge.

The master failed to follow navigation safety regulations found in 33 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 164 which requires the owner, master or operator of each vessel underway to ensure the following: that the person directing and controlling the movement of the vessel understands the limitations and constraints of their vessel(s) and tows, that they have knowledge of tides, currents, and dangers posed by visual or radar contacts, and that the vessel proceeds at a safe speed at all times. 

Also, the master failed to make a notification of a marine casualty in accordance with 46 CFR 4.05-1 after addressing all safety concerns. Furthermore, the master didn’t hold the proper merchant mariner credential (MMC) to be the person directing and controlling the towing vessel. Due to the size of the towing vessel (more than 26 feet in length) it requires a towing vessel master or a MMC endorsed as master of inspected, self-propelled vessel greater than 200 gross register tons holding either a completed Towing Officer’s Assessment Record (TAOR) or MMC endorsed for towing vessels.  

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the master’s unawareness of the air height of the bridge. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include; (1) Failure to recognize an accurate air draft data from its tow, (2) Failure to properly use resources regarding height of the bridge.

At approximately 0755 on 22DEC17 the M/V JAMES DALE ROBINS was down-bound with 12 loaded hopper barges approaching the I-155 bridge. Visibility was 2 miles with a 2.5 mph wind setting the vessel towards the RDB.  The vessel lined up on the green buoy line to make the main span.  The vessel then struck the RDB piling of the 900’ main span.  The tow arrangement made contact on the FMTA 9605 midship.

The FMTA 9605 suffered a 35’ inset on the starboard side compromising the #4, 5, and 6 voids.  The voids flooded to the waterline and the vessel remained stable.

Investigation revealed a strong current set the vessel to the RDB.  The vessel was lined up towards the RDB, which did not provide ample room to clear the bridge.  Piloting error resulted in the FMTA 9605 contacting the I-155 bridge.

On April 18th, 2017 the UTV DANNY TERRAL was heading southbound at MM 4 on the Atchafalaya River going through the east span on the Simmsport Railroad Bridge. The lead barge made contact with bridge causing all 6 rock barges to break free. A second barge also made contact. 

The first barge (RM3354) is taking on water, but still holding up. Damage is still unknown to the other barge and the bridge. 3 barges are rounded up. The assist vessel has one barge, and they are in the process of rounding up the other. After damage survey Bridge is undamaged and operational.

As per 46 CFR 4.05-1 (a)(1), this incident met the criteria of a reportable marine casualty, as it involved an unintended allision with a bridge.

UTV HOWARD CORSE was underway heading northbound at MM 0 on the Atchafalaya and the wind pushed them into the Simmsport Hwy bridge. Vessel was pushing 6 empty rock barges. Vessel lined up on the bridge expecting the to blow the vessel to the west, however wind was blowing east. Vessel starboard side landed on the bridge pier. 

No damage to bridge or barges reported.

On January 8, 2018 the tug ELK RIVER was pushing ahead the tank barge DS 202 on the Delaware River upbound, enroute to Croydon, PA when the barge's starboard bow allided with the bridge's fendering system causing damage to several pieces of timber. There was no damage to either vessel or any of the actual bridge structures.  The cause of the casualty was the heavy ice coverage in the river being funneled into the narrow passage at the Tacony Palmyra Bridge and the flood current pushing the unit into the bridge.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision of the starboard bow of the DS 202 into the Tacony palmyra Bridge fendering system.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the heavy ice coverage in the river that daycoupled with the flood current (2) lack of an assist tug/vessel.

At approxiamtely 2130 hrs on 15JAN18 the M/V AMERICAN HERITAGE (573798, American River Transportation Co, 10500HP) was pushing 30 loaded grain barges (5x6) down bound UMR MM 43 when the port string made contact with the left descending pier of the Thebes Railroad Bridge. After allision, the port string and head barges (10 total) were set adrift. UTV AMERICAN HERITAGE is currently in the middle of the channel attempting to recover the 10 barges. UTV LEGACY (1240165, Enterprise Marine Services, 2600HP), and UTV DALE ARTIGUE (1238778, Florida Marine Transporters, 4720HP) are on scene assisting in recovering barges. Thebes Railroad Bridge owner was contacted and Bridge Engineer responded to the scene. He found no noticeable damage to the bridge.

At approximately 2300 on 15JAN18, 6 of the adrift barges were caught by tug assisstance. The remaining 4 adrift barges grounded. 3 were retrieved and placed back in tow but the fourth barge was lightered.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the bridge allision. Contributing factors include 1) Slack water. 2) Less experienced pilot on the sticks at the time of the incident.

On 21JAN2018 at approximately 2140 hrs the M/V TOM BEHRINGER (584006, 5600HP, AMERICAN COMMERCIAL BARGE LINES)was pushing 15 barges (13 loaded & 2 empty) in a 5X3 configuration. The M/V was down bound at MM 941 and had just been through the navigation pass at Lock and Dam 52 when the Master was attempting to cross the river to line up for the High water span of the I24 bridge on the left descending bank. The Master did not properly align the vessel and tow properly causing the tow to allide with the left pier of the I 24 Bridge, no damage to the barge or to the bridge. Vessel was taken to Cairo, IL for further inspection.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be Allision with the I24 Highway Bridge.  Contributing factors include 1) pilot's loss situational awareness getting too deep in the turn towards the bridge span; and 2) Wind gusts up to 16-20 mph

At approximately 1330 on January 20, 2018, the uninspected towing vessel CAPT STEPHEN (O.N. 297251) was traveling northbound on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway heading to the LED dock in Amelia, LA pushing an uninspected deck barge with construction equipment. When approaching the BAYOU BOEUF RAILROAD BRIDGE the master had the lookout stand watch to ensure that the barge was not too close to the bridge. The master reported that there was a blind spot on the port side of the CAPT STEPHEN from the bridge. 

While pushing the deck barge through the BAYOU BOEUF RAILROAD BRIDGE the starboard side of CAPT STEPHEN’s barge rubbed the bridges fender system. The bridge tender reported there were three wooden stinger ends and metal brackets damaged during the allision. The master of the CAPT STEVEN reported no damage. 

No major damage, injuries or pollution to report.

As a result of its investigation the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the size of the bridge opening being very close in size to the barge not leaving much room to maneuver through and the blind spot on the masters port side.

On January 23, 2018, at approximately 0150, the barge KIRBY 28177 allided with the Caney Creek Swing Bridge fender system. The towboat MISS DARIAN was pushing barges KIRBY 29012 & KIRBY 28117 doubled up westbound towards the bridge opening when the marine casualty occurred. The starboard barge KIRBY 28177 suffered a 2” inset on its bottom plate approximately 3’ wide x 12’ long from striking the fender system. Three groupings of connected pilings on the north bank of the fender system that protect the swing bridge while in the open position were struck and leaned over in a westward position with many of the horizontal timbers that group the pilings together damaged or missing. The bridge navigational aids were extinguished. The Kast Away R/V Park dock had approximately 100' of dock damaged. The allision occurred when the starboard barge was misaligned with the bridge channel by the Captain and the barge struck the fender system approximately 10 feet north of the channel. The second allision occurred when the starboard barge was backed off the fender system.

As a result of its investigation, the United States Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this marine casualty was the allision of the barge KIRBY 28177 with the Caney Creek Swing Bridge fender system. This was followed by the allision of KIRBY 28177 with the Kast Away R/V Park Dock. The causal factors that contributed to this marine casualty include: 1) Captain misaligned barge during his approach of Caney Creek Swing Bridge. 2) Captain was notified by lookout about barge misalignment too late to avoid allision with bridge fender system. 2) Captain was too close to north bank of the channel to avoid secondary allision with dock.

On January 23, 2018, at approximately 1452, the container ship BAY BRIDGE lost power while transiting in bound to the Port of Oakland in the vicinity of buoys #1 and #2 in the San Francisco Main Ship Channel.  An alarm sounded on the navigation bridge which triggered a slow down of the main diesel engine followed by the loss of power, loss of propulsion, and loss of steering.  The pilot was able to eventually anchor the vessel in order to determine what caused the power loss.  After examination by the Chief Engineer, it was determined that the primary fuel oil transfer system filters were clogged which restricted the fuel going to main engine and generators.  The clogged filters were cleaned and reinstalled, enabling the vessel to transit to Anchorage 9 in San Francisco Bay without further incident.  

As a result of the investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the ship's diesel generators.  Subsequent events were the loss of power, failure of the steering gear systems, failure of the main diesel engine, and loss of propulsion.  The causal factor that contributed to this event was the improper condition of fuel oil transfer system primary fuel filters.

On February 4, 2018, at approximately 0847 local time, the uninspected commercial towing and emergency assist vessel TOWBOAT U.S. ANGEL ISLAND (S.N. CF8786SG) allided with the fender system protecting Piling #10 of the Benicia-Martinez Bridge while transiting eastbound on the Carquinez Strait in California (CA).  The high-speed allision resulted in the fatality of the sole operator and occupant aboard as well as the total constructive loss of the vessel.

The U.S. Coast Guard determined the initiating event for this casualty was the probability of the operator losing consciousness during the approach to the Benicia-Martinez Bridge.  The subsequent events were the high-speed allision with the bridge fender system at approximately 30 knots and the severe blunt force trauma experienced by the occupant.  The causal factor contributing to the initiating event was most likely the operator’s fatigued and/or pre-existing medical condition.  Factors contributing to the subsequent events were the lack of a deckhand and safety-restraining device.

On February 4, 2018, at approximately 05:15, the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE lost propulsion while departing the southeast turning basin when the main engine failed to respond to an ahead bell order.  The CAMPBELL FOSS was attached to the stern of the vessel with a head line and was off the port quarter of the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE.  The BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE was travelling approximately 4 knots astern when their port quarter collided with the port pilothouse of the CAMPBELL FOSS.  The BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE received only minor paint scraps, but the CAMPBELL FOSS sustained significant damage. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of the #2 cylinder start air control valve in the main engine of the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE.  This was followed by the loss of propulsion of the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE and subsequent collision with the CAMPBELL FOSS.  The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the main engine #2 cylinder start air control valve was leaking air, leading to the loss of propulsion by the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE, (2) the CAMPBELL FOSS’s operator in control of the vessel leading up to the collision had only 10 days of experience operating a towing vessel with a Z-drive, (3) the failure of the pilot to notify the CAMPBELL FOSS that the BEAR MOUNTAIN BRIDGE had lost propulsion, (4) the failure of the CAMPBELL FOSS's Master to take early and substantial action to avoid collision, (5) the master of the CAMPBELL FOSS tested positive for a dangerous drug in a post serious marine incident drug test.

On 22JAN2018, the UTV AVA CLAIRE ran aground at MM 57.5 on the Ouachita River while transiting upbound with 2 loaded red flag barges (gasoline and diesel). The forward barge (GMS952) grounded on a piece of debris from what is believed to have been left over from the demolition of the swing bridge previously located in the area. The trailing barge (BIG 950L) was not aground.

Budwine surveyors and divers located the obstruction and determined that the barge was not damaged significantly. The UTV AVA CLAIRE carefully maneuvered the barge off of the debris and continued operations as normal.

On 13 February 2018, at approximately 2100 hours the 80 foot towing vessel MAXX B (O.N. 641456) was underway with six empty barges when they rubbed against the Bayou Dularge Bridge. The vessel was coming in at a slight angle holding against the wind, and they slowed their approach as they were in the middle of the bridge opening to allow for adequate distance to the front vessel. The vessel rubbed against the north fender and scraped the third barge. The bridge tender saw dust fly; however, he did not see any major damage to the concrete fendering system. There were no reported damages to the vessel or barges.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the vessel's allision with the bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) master's helm control maneuver, and (2) unfavorable following distance.

21FEB2018 at approximately 2315 hrs. M/V SAMUEL J (Florida Marine Transporters Co., 575860, 4000hp) while pushing 15 rock barges (5x3) D/B at MM 941 OHR LDB (Brookport, IL) allided with the I-24 bridge, breaking away 03 barges, the UTV SAMUEL J recovered 02 of the barges and the UTV DOTTIE JOHNSON recovered the final barge. Due to high water the vessel was traveling through the navigational pass at Lock and Dam 52 on the RDB then had to transit across the river to the high water span of  the I-24 Highway bridge, the master on watch had very little experience with that area of the river during high water. KYDOT inspected the bridge and found no damage. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be Allision with the I-24 Highway Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Loss of situational awareness 2)Lack of experience on that vessel and in that area of the river during high water.

On February 22, 2018, the EL PASO was E/B pushing 2 red flag barges, each loaded with 27,000 bbls of Naptha.  Upon reaching the Bayou Dularge bridge at mile marker 59.9 on the ICW, the pilot overcorrected and made contact on the north pier on the west bank of the bridge with the port bow of barge EBL 2999.  Minimal damage to the fendering system and the bridge remaine fully operational.  EBL2999 received an inset on the port corner wrapper in way of the headlog (approximately 4 feet X 3.5 feet with an inset depth of 0-2 inches; damage costs estimated to be $15k.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty to be the pilot's overcorrection.  A causal factor of the overcorrection was the following current.

Received notification from SLM on the morning of 2/26/2018 that several unknown dry cargo barges were adrift approximately ten miles south of the Vicksburg bridges near MM 425.  Notification was made by several N bound tows at approx 0230, and requested CG broadcast notice to mariners to stay on the lookout.  MSD Vicksburg personnel ensured  notifications were made to the RR and I-20 bridge contacts for possible allisions and need for inspection as well as several unsuccessful attempts were made to contact several local barge operators/fleets to identify owner/operators.

At approximately 0830 (2/26/2018) MSD Vicksburg personnel received confirmation the breakaway barges, now aground between MM 425-420, belonged to Riverside Construction in Vicksburg, MS.  In addition, instrument readings installed on the RR bridge indicated barge(s) allied with the bridge when they passed through and inspectors were on the way to examine before additional trains were allowed to cross.  In addition, owner/operator of Riverside Construction was making arrangements to retrieve all barges, inspect for damage and return them to the mouth of the Yazoo River area.

At approximately 1415 CST on 3MAR18 the M/V CAPTAIN RICHARD SIDES was up-bound with 8 loaded UAN-32 unregulated barges approaching the I-155 bridge. Visibility was clear with a strong down bound current setting the vessel from LDB towards RDB.  The vessel lined up center channel to make the main span.  The vessel then struck the RDB piling of the 900’ main span.  The tow arrangement made contact on the STC 3016.

The STC 3016 suffered a 4’ long by 2’ wide inset on the port side with no compromised watertight integrity.

Investigation revealed a strong current set the vessel to the RDB.  The vessel did not adequately adjust for expected crosscurrents during the approach to the main span, which did not provide ample room to clear the bridge.  Piloting error resulted in the STC 3016 contacting the I-155 bridge.

At approximately 0430 on March 07, the UTV KEITH DARLING was southbound from Cairo, IL in transit to Convent, LA when the vessel allided with the I-155 bridge pier at mile marker 838. The vessel was pushing 30 loaded grain barges, 5 long by 6 wide, at the time of the incident. There was no damage caused to the bridge. The ACL 00111 was located in the port stern of the tow and allided with the bridge pier causing damage to the port corner of the bow rake. The port stern of the towing vessel subsequently struck the bridge pier causing damage to the port corner rub rail. There was no fracture to the hull of the towing vessel, just the rub rail.

The cause of the investigation revealed that the pilot misjudged the approach to transit the bridge and was not able to correct his position due to strong current.

On the morning of March 04, 2018, BILL STEGBAUER, pushing 14 barges departed McGinnis Fleeting Area located at Mile Marker (MM)481 on the Ohio River (OhR) on a northbound transit to Georgetown Fleeting Area in Georgetown,PA. AEP 3182 was the stern starboard barge in a 3 wide by 5 long tow configuration, measuring 1139 feet combined with the towboat. The 9 member crew of the BILL STEGBAUER was made up of two credential Merchant Mariners with endorsements as Master of Towing Vessels on Western Rivers, and seven non credential mariners. Marine traffic on the Ohio River was under a waterway advisoray as a result of high water and associated hazardous due to substandial rainfall throughtout the Ohio Valley Region. The Ohio River was recorded at 47.84 ft (22.44ft above pool stage),river current at 4.2 at the river gage located MM 470.5 OHR. COTP of Sector Ohio Valley (OHV) promulgated BNM 002-18 from Februaray 28th to March 6th.     

Prior to the BILL STEGBAUER departing McGinnis Fleeting Area on  March 4th, the towing vessel ROGER L. KNIGHT agreed to provide horespower assistance to the BILL STEGBAUER while navigating northbound pass the seven bridges located within a two mile stretch of the downtown Cincinnati area. At approximately 0545, Pilot maneuvered the vessel .5 mile below the Cincinnati Southern R/R Bridge in preparation of transiting the bridge. Once the head of the tow cleared the bridge the Captain requested to assumed the helm. Pilot relieved the watch to the Captain as the 2nd tier of barges began to pass underneath the bridge. 

Within 1 minute of being relieved of the watch the Pilot departed the wheelhouse, and the head of the tow took a sharp starboard turn toward the Kentucky riverbank. Aware of the swift moving current and the proximity of the bridge pier, the Captain attempted to maneuver the vessel port to return the tow to the river channel and away from the bridge pier. The starboard stern barge, AEP 3182, aft midship starboard side allided into the starboard bridge pier after the Captain was unsuccessfully at maneuering away from the bridge pier. AEP 3182 received no visble damage. The bridge was surveryed with no damaged reported by Southern Railroad(owner of the bridge)representatives.   

As a result of its investigation, Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the loss maneuverability when the vessel's tow was navigated into hazardous conditions associated with high water on the Ohio River. This was followed by the subsequent allision of the starboard side of AEP 3182 with the starboard pier of the Cincinnati Southern Railroad Bridge.

OCMI REQUESTED LEVEL OF INVESTIGATION TO BE ELEVATED AND CAUSAL ANALYSIS TO BE PERFORMED FOR ALL BRIDGE ALLISIONS. 

On 06MAR2018 at approximately 1810 hrs. the M/V D & R BONEY (Inland Marine CO, 575824, 6000HP) was transiting DB at MM 977 OHR pushing 24 barges (12 empty hoppers, 12 loaded dry cargo) while attempting to navigate the Illinois Central R/R (ICRR) Bridge the vessel became set by both wind and current when the portside lead barge (empty) allided with the left descending pier of the ICRR Bridge in Wycliffe, KY. The M/V reported that 06 barges were set adrift and 02 harbor tugs secured the 06 barges and put them back in tow. Investigation revealed that prior to this event the vessel had been holding up due to forecasted weather that was to continue until early 07MAR2018. The Master in charge of the navigational watch made the decision to get underway when he believed the weather had passed and the wind subsided. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be allision with the IC Railroad Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Loss of situational awareness 2) Judgement Error 3) Forecasted high winds and strong currents

On 08 March 2018 at approx. 23:55 the towing vessel DENNIS COLLINS(O.N.279030)was transiting southbound on the ILR MM 56, when the starboard barge in the two barge tow made contact with the protection cell on the RDB side of the Florence Highway Bridge.  The bridge tender reported no damage to the bridge or protection cell.  The DENNIS COLLINS was pushing 02 empty, (not gas freed),  anhydrous ammonia tank barges in a side by side configuration.  The starboard tank barge, STC 2502 struck the protection cell resulting in damage to the tank barge hull above the waterline on the starboard side.  The barge sustained damage in way of the #1 and #2 starboard voids. Several fractures were noted at the deck gunnel that started approximately 82 feet aft of the bow and extended 10 feet aft, affecting the #1 and #2 starboard voids, and approximately 11 feet above the waterline. Another crack just forward of the bulkhead between the #1 and #2 starboard void started at the deck and extended vertically approximately 3 feet. The tank barge was in an unloaded condition, cargo tanks were not affected and the barge did not take on water. A Permit to Proceed was issued to the barge to proceed in an unloaded condition to Mississippi Marine Shipyard in Greenville, MS to affect permanent repairs.

On March 13, 2018, at approximately 1430 Eastern Standard Time, the towing vessel HAILEY NICHOLE's tow allided with the I64 Sherman Minton Bridge. The vessel was pushing 14 empty barges, in a 3x5 configuration, down bound at mile marker 608 on the Ohio River, Louisville, KY. The Master was able to clear half of the barges in the tow when a gust of wind came across and pushed the fourth barge (AEP 139) in the port string into the bridge pillar. The bridge and the barge were not damaged. 

The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the loss of maneuverability and identified the contributing factors; high wind and vessel’s horsepower (3000HP) to barge (14 empties) ratio, approximately 214 hp per barge. The towing vessel struggled to effectively maneuver the tow in the prevailing conditions and subsequently allided with the I-64 Sherman Minton Bridge.

At approximatley 1715 on 14MAR18, the M/V PATRICK CENAC (CENAC Marine, 1233052, 2800HP) was pushing 3 loaded crude oil barges (1X3) down bound at MM 980.4 OHR. As the CENAC approached the Cairo Hwy Bridge, they reached out to the M/V CAPT. JOHN REYNOLDS, who was d/b ahead of them, to discuss the vessel's intentions and make passing arrangements. After discussing REYNOLDS intentions to top around and head up the UMR, the two masters agreed on a 2 whistle passing arrangement. Shortly afterward, the CENAC called the REYNOLDS again to ask if there was enough water on the KY span of the bridge, which he was aiming for. The REYNOLDS replied that there was plenty of water and the CENAC should have no problems transiting the KY span of the bridge. The REYNOLDS started his topping around maneuver at approximately 1722 as the CENAC made his approach to the KY span of the Cairo Hwy Bridge. At approximately 1725, the M/V PATRICK CENAC allided with the right descending channel pier of the KY span of the Cairo Highway Bridge (LLNR 2830). The center box barge (CTCO 356B) sustained a 12" x 18' inset along the port gunwhale. The stern barge (CTCO 323) sustained multiple insets ranging from 0-18" along the entire port side. The stern port side void and the port stern were taking on water and flooded to river level. The CTCO 356B and CTCO 357 were set adrift following the allision with the bridge and were corralled shortly thereafter. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the allision with the Cairo Hwy Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Failure of the master to assess a safe speed given the traffic conditions. 2) Failure of the master to properly plan his transit through the KY span of the Cairo Hwy Bridge given the previously agreed upon passing arrangements with the M/V CAPT JOHN REYNOLDS.

On March 18, 2018, at approximately 0920 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel MISS EMILY (ON: 1104495) was underway, making way at two knots pushing ahead the inspected dredge barge ATLANTIC (ON: 574373) when the ATLANTIC's port sideshell fenders (rubber tires) allided with the northeast side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system (galvanized rubber).

Prior to the allision, the MISS EMILY and ATLANCTIC were heading southbound on the Elizabeth River approaching the Gilmerton Bridge. The MISS EMILY was under command and control of a licensed Master. A lookout was on the forward end of the dredge.

There was no monetary damage to the bridge or vessels involved in the allision. However, several man hours were dedicated to assess the potential for damages by bridge personnel. A small boat was used with several employees of the Gilmerton Bridge to inspect the fendering system of the bridge to ensure the bridge and the fendering system were not structurally damaged. No drug and/or alcohol testing was conducted for the involved parties.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the inadequate vessel maneuvering of the MISS EMILY to transit between the bridge fendering system, the subsequent event was the ATLANTIC allision with the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) execution error/attention failure: docking pilot failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the bridge fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the current, width of bridge span, and dimensions of the barge to safely transit through without an allision, (2) environmental complexity: the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River has multiple bends when approaching from the north of the Gilmerton
Bridge. These angles and natural bends in the river make navigating this bridge and waterway complex, and (3) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

On February 19, 2018, at approximately 2150 LMT, the uninspected towing vessel EVELYN DORIS (ON: 274942) was underway, making way at 3-4 knots pushing ahead the uninspected hopper barge SJ 2620 (ON: 1264493) when the SJ 2620's starboard bow allided with the northeast side of the North Landing Bridge fendering system.

Prior to the allision, the EVELYN DORIS and SJ 2620 were heading northbound on the Atlantic Intercostal Waterway through fog approaching the North Landing Bridge. The EVELYN DORIS was under command and control of a licensed Master.  A lookout was on the forward end of the barge.  Once the vessels were aligned within the channel, the vessel transited through the Southside of the fendering system, the SJ 2620's starboard bow allided with the northeast side of the North Landing Bridge fendering system.

The Bridge is owned and managed by the Army Corps of Engineers (ACOE).  The ACOE surveyed the fendering system and provided a good faith estimate of less than $1000.  There was no monetary damage to the towing vessel or barge involved in the allision.  Alcohol testing was conducted for the involved parties.  No drug testing was conducted.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the inadequate vessel maneuvering of the EVELYN DORIS to transit between the bridge fendering system, the subsequent event was the SJ 2620 allision with the fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) Environment: The transit occurred at night and in fog that reduced visibility to less than one half of a mile, and (2) execution error/attention failure: The Master's maneuvering actions were not substantial enough to avoid allision with the bridge fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the night transit, fog, width of bridge span (70 feet), and dimensions of the barge (52 feet beam) to safely transit through without an allision.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement.

On February 26, 2018, at approximately 1800, the barge MISS RISING SUN, being pushed ahead by the tug boat EUDORA LEE (292719), allided with the Stuart FEC Railway Bridge, while on a westbound transit through the Okeechobee Waterway from Jacksonville, FL, to Mobile, AL. 

It was identified that the master began to make his approach westbound with a following current of approximately .08 knots. Due to the configuration of the waterway with three consecutive bridges within close proximity which are not aligned, after crossing the first bridge, the master turned slightly to port to line up with the Stuart FEC Railway Bridge. The tug and barge entered the bridge opening at approximately 2.5 knots, and began setting to the starboard side of the bridge, thereby rubbing the starboard side of the barge with the fendering system.  

The allision led to the barge tripping a wire which sent a signal to the FEC Jacksonville office alerting them of the allision. Additionally, it was reported that there was minor timber abrassion and pier concrete damage (18"x12") cracking without any monetary damage assigned.

On 18 Feb, 2018, the barge PTC 753, being pushed by the towing vessel TOM HUCKABEE (O.N. 512099) allided with a railroad bridge in the Tombigbee River at approximately mile 173. The incident occurred as the towing vessel was pushing 6 barges loaded with coal through the river. The barge brushed the west pillar, and suffered a 1.5 in spilt at the knuckle of the #3 wing tank. There was no damage observed to the bridge. No pollution or personnel injuries.

On 29 March 2018, the 105-foot towing vessel INDIAN DAWN (O.N. 570691) was operating on the Elizabeth River Eastern Branch as part of a long-term contract with Great Lakes Dredge & Dock Company to transport Great Lakes barges to and from various anchorages, job sites, and shipyards. During the morning of the 29th, the INDIAN DAWN transited approximately 800 yards from the Great Lakes facility to Colonna’s Shipyard in order to bring a barge from the shipyard to the Great Lakes facility. After successfully completing that barge transfer, the INDIAN DAWN made fast to the stern of the 277-foot dredge barge G.L. 63 (O.N. 922736) at the Great Lakes facility. The INDIAN DAWN and G.L. 63 then transited west along the Elizabeth River towards Colonna’s Shipyard. Just before Colonna’s Shipyard, the INDIAN DAWN and G.L. 63 passed underneath the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge #5 at a slow rate of speed due to the restricted waterway and the close proximity of the final destination. As the tug and barge passed underneath the railroad bridge, a gust of wind hit the port side of the barge and caused the barge to allide with the Railroad Bridge #5 north side fendering system. 

After the G.L. 63 allided with the fendering system, the tug and barge continued to Colonna’s Shipyard so the G.L. 63 could begin a scheduled maintenance period. Norfolk Southern personnel conducted a visual inspection of the fendering system and reported no damage to the structure, and a visual inspection of the G.L. 63 side shell identified no new damage to the barge. 

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event to be the allision of G.L. 63 with the Norfolk Southern Railroad Bridge #5 fendering system. Causal factors contributing to this casualty were: 1) lack of wind indicator on the front of the barge; and 2) failure of the tug master to provide an adequate margin of safety while transiting under the railroad bridge. 

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to enforcement.

On March 22, 2018, the 85 foot long UTV KAREN PAPE departed Houston, TX, pushing ahead the 297.6 foot long barges GM5020 (Leading) and GM5009, both carrying high sulfur vacuum gas oil, from Houston, TX to Valero St. Charles Refinery in Destrehan, LA. On March 26, 2018, at approximately 2145, while enroute to approach the Bayou Dularge Bridge, the master noticed the steering system was not responding appropriately, failing to follow direction from the bridge. While still operating at same speed and course, the master attempted to correct system by switching pumps, but steering system was still not responding. Subsequently, he directed the tankerman on watch to the steering system/pumps to verify condition of equipment and attempt to correct issue with steering. Simultaneously, the master reduced the speed of the UTV and attempted to put the vessel and barges in reverse to avoid an allusion with the bridge. Tankerman reported no visible issues with the steering system or pumps, and master speed reduction and change is course direction was not sufficient to avoid an allusion. At approximately 2200, the barge GM5020 allided with the Bayou Dularge Bridge. 

The allision resulted in damages to the bridge and the barge GM5020. Bridge had some concrete section affected, but traffic (road and maritime) was never stopped/affected, and no significant structural damages have been reported. GM5020 had an indent of 12 feet X 01 foot X 03 feet, on the stern section in the starboard side, in way of the bulwark, with water ingress observed by crew. A portable pump was placed on the barge to empty the affected space, and the pump was able to put out water at a faster rate than the water ingress rate. No discharge of oil was observed, and indent did not affect areas near cargo holding sections.  On March 26, 2018, at approximately 2330, USCG Sector New Orleans Command Center received notification of incident. MSU Houma Duty Marine Inspector and Duty Investigation Officers attended the vessel on March 27, 2018, at approximately 0115, to conduct post-casualty inspection. No injuries were reported. No damages were reported to have occurred to GM5009 or the KAREN PAPE as a result from the allision.  A technician from Rio Controls & Hydraulics INC (aka Rio Marine INC) attended the vessel while USCG MSU Houma personnel was onboard, to conduct a service inspection of the steering system. The technician tested the system, but did not find any operational abnormalities. Test conducted while UTV had no barges attached, and while moored in area of channel with low current. 

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the reduction of the KAREN PAPE’s steering. This event was followed by the allision of GM5020 with the Bayou Dularge Bridge, and by the progressive flooding of GM5020. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty included: (1) the operational failure of the KAREN PAPE’s steering system, (2) the delayed reaction from the master to avoid the allision, delaying the reduction of speed and change of course/direction of vessel and barges, (3) the inadequate preventative mechanisms installed to avoid or minimize depth of indents on barges.

On March 16, 2018, at approximately 15:08, the container vessel BANGKOK BRIDGE lost electrical power while mooring in the Port of Long Beach, CA.  The vessel’s #3 generator low lube oil pressure switch is normally set to shut down the generator down when the pressure falls below .35MPa. The switch was inadvertently set to .43MPa. The normal operating pressure for the generator is between .40 and .50MPa. When the bow thruster was brought online and powered by the #3 generator, the generator fell to .43MPa, causing the generator to shut down. The #4 generator automatically started and was being brought in parallel with the #1 and #2 generators. Before the #4 generator was brought fully online, the vessel’s crew brought the bow thruster online, causing an overload on the electrical system. All three generators tripped offline, resulting in a loss of power.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the #3 generator tripping offline due to the low lube oil pressure. This was followed by the #1, #2, and #4 generators tripping offline due to an electrical overload and a subsequent loss of power.  This was followed by the vessels loss of propulsion.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty were the low lube oil pressure being set improperly and the crew bringing the bow thruster online prior to the generators being in full operational status.

On March 22, 2018, at approximately 18:50 Hawaii Standard Time (HST), Sector Honolulu Command Center received a report from the managing owner of the UTV CHAMORRO that the CHAMORRO and freight barge S-2006 had ground at Wake Island.

The reporting source stated that, as the Tug CHAMORRO was arriving into Wake Island harbor with the freight barge S-2006 the barge drifted out of the channel and grounded during her inbound transit.

After the grounding, the master secured ahead propulsion which caused the tug to drift back and strike the barge, which caused the barge to refloat. Once free, the master maneuvered the tug and barge out of the channel and back into deeper water. The crew then conducted a preliminary damage assessment and found the freight barge S-2006 had sustained a 4-foot gash on her starboard side, numerous smaller gashes and dents along the side shell of the barge and a 12-inch diameter hole below the 3-foot draft mark as well. They also found the CHAMORRO’s starboard shaft had three wraps of the towline around it with no damage to the propeller or shaft. The master was able to remove the towline from the shaft.

Based on the initial damage assessment, the barge was moored off of Wake Island awaiting additional resources in assessing the condition of the barge and cargo. On 4/4/2018, the barge broke free of its mooring and regrounded on another section of reef. This caused additional damage to the hull plating which ultimately resulted in the determination that the barge was a total constructive loss.

The Owner arranged, through the Environmental Protection Agency and the Coast Guard, for a deep water disposal of the barge. Most of the cargo was off loaded to shore, the barge was then refloated, brought into deep water and sunk in approximately 3000 fathoms of water.

The investigation found the initiating event was vessel maneuvering which resulted in the grounding of the barge. Causal factors for the initiating event include a loss of situational awareness, failure to follow good marine practices for short tow while entering a restrictive channel.

On 05APR2018 at approximately 1245 hrs. The M/V CAPTAIN RICHARD SIDES (274333/Southern Towing Co/ 3800) was pushing 08 empty barges (2x4 config/previous cargo UAN solution) transiting down bound at MM 941 OHR. While going thru the navigational pass at L&D 52 the master had a radio conversation with the M/V LEE ANN INGRAM and made passing arrangements on the 1 whistle and that the M/V LEE ANN INGRAM would be past the bridge span by the time that the M/V CAPTAIN RICHARD SIDES was at the bridge span. As the M/V CAPTAIN RICHARD SIDES approached the bridge span it was evident that they would be meeting in the span potentially resulting in a collision. At that point the Master on the RICHARD SIDES turned to STBD and allided with the right descending pier on the I-24 Bridge. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be allision with the I-24 Highway Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) CAPT RICHARD SIDES pilot making passing arrangements close to a bridge span, 2) LEE ANN INGRAM pilot's failure to give way to the downbound CAPT RICHARD SIDES.

At approximately 2215 local on April 4, 2018, the M/V GLOBAL ROSE was transiting the Delaware River outbound.  While approaching the Tacony-Palmyra Bridge, the vessel became set to the NJ-side by strong gusting NW winds.  The vessel's port side contacted fendering system just forward of the wheelhouse on the NJ side bridge abutment.  The vessel's port bridge wing also made contact with a pedestrian handrail, bending the rail towards the bridge which prevented the bridge from closing.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the strong gusty winds setting the vessel into the bridge.

On March 22, 2018, the AEP LEADER (O.N. 1221907) was southbound on the Illinois River Mile Marker 56 pushing 15 loaded dry cargo hopper. The vessels starboard 3rd barge from the had of the tow, ACL 9726B rubbed the RDB protection cell on the Florence Highway Drawbridge MM 56.0 ILR. The bridge tender confirmed no damage to bridge.

On 22 February 2018 at approximately 2345 CST, the uninspected towing vessel HAZEL ANN, allied with the Huey P. Long Bridge while proceeding south bound enroute to the Harvey Locks, IVO MM 106.2 Lower Mississippi River. 

During the course of the investigation it was determined that the allision was caused when the HAZEL ANN’s master had slowed the vessel to allow for a northbound vessel to pass, however, the unseasonably strong current caused the vessel to swing out of alignment.  The tug was pushing one loaded dry cargo barge, AEP-1065.  When the tug swung, it caused a facing wire connected the barge to break, allowing the barge to swing out and rub on the fendering system protecting the bridge.  There was no damage to either the barge, or the bridge fenders.  A nearby Good Samaritan tug was able to arrive on scene momentarily and assisted the HAZEL ANN in re-establishing the tow. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that cause of the allision was due to the Master not taking into account the swift current associated with the early start of the High Water season. No damage was reported to either the tug, barge, or bridge. 

IAW 46 CFR 4.05-1, this incident was a reportable marine casualty as an unintended strike with a bridge occurred. The level of investigation effort meets the requirements of a Data Collection as the incident did not exceed $25k in damage.

On April 6, 2018, at approximately 2028 Eastern Standard Time, the vessel DEBI SHARP allided with the center pier of the US 41 Dual Highway Bridge (LLNR 27505). The vessel was pushing 15 empty open hoppers in a 3x5 configuration, down bound at MM 786.8 OHR. The Master was steering the barges in tow when winds came across and pushing the starboard lead barge onto the bridge pillar. The barge had a small inset and paint scuffed up in a small area, there were five facing wires that parted on the tow. The UTV ANGELA B assisted the DEBBIE SHARP to the bank where the towing vessel replaced the broken wiring. The master reports no other damage, pollution or injury.

The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was an error in navigation and the bridge allision due to high winds.

MSD Quad Cities received notification on March 26th, 2018, from Sector UMR that the UTV BRITTANY LEE was transiting northbound at the Sabula RR Bridge (MM 535) pushing 13 barges (1 dry UREA and 12 empties). While transiting under the bridge the vessel made contact with the wooden guide wall. Both the vessel and bridge reported no damage, pollution or injuries. The vessel continued its transit northbound. The bridge is fully operational. After further investigation, it was discovered that the vessel was planning to do a controlled landing; however, they did not call ahead. The vessel was also traveling at a fast rate to be doing a controlled landing.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for the casualty was operator error and a failure to call the bridge in advance to arrange a controlled landing.

On April 6, 2018 the towing vessel CAPTAIN BOUDREAUX was underway light boat (not pushing barges) transiting down bound on the Atchafalaya River near Melville, LA. At approximately 2130 the port stern quarter of the vessel made contact with the east span of the Union Pacific Railroad Bridge located near mile marker 30.
 
The bridge was inspected with no damage noted. The vessel suffered an 8” high, by 8” long, and 3” deep inset located near the port stern quarter of the vessel approximately 1.5’ above the water line along the gunwale.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the unexpected maneuvering of the CAPTAIN BOUDREAUX when it encountered the current. This was followed by the eventual allision with the bridge. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the Captain’s unfamiliarity with the route.

On March 26th, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received a report of an allision from Sector UMR. The UTV PROSPERITY (645129) was northbound on the Mississippi River at MM 535 pushing 15 barges (14 dry cargo and 1 empty). The master reported he was oversteering while making his approach to counteract the current. The master was unable to swing the tow to the correct position because he oversteered too much. The tow made contact on the barge ART 24129. There was no pollution or injuries and no damage to the barge or vessel. The bridge was reporting that the protection cell on the left descending down river side had some broken timbers, a damaged catwalk and the cell was shifted 6" - 18", making the channel wider than normal. The investigations team was unable to determine how much damage was from this incident and how much damage was from prior strikes.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was operator error.

On 30 MAR 2018 at approximately 1145 CST, the towing vessel TOMMIE'S TERMINAL (O.N. 553290) was underway southbound on the Tennessee - TomBigbee River pushing ahead 08 loaded hopper barges. The barges were aligned in an H- pattern with 3 barges on the port string, 2 in the middle, and 3 on the starboard string.  

While attempting to maneuver the bend at mile marker #293, the head barge on the port string grounded on the east bank of the river.  Subsequent to the grounding of the port head barge, the current pushed against the port string causing the barges in the port string to break free from their tow.  In an attempt to collect the barges in the port string which were adrift, the Master instructed the crew to un-face the vessel from the starboard string.  While adrift, the barge CPD 9701 (O.N. 1054360) struck two pylons on the south end of the Westervelt Renewable Energy dock and also struck the west pillar of the highway 17 bridge, causing damage to the barge.  No damage was caused to the bridge.  The towing vessel RHONDA S. arrived to the area and assisted the TOMMIE'S TERMINAL in gathering and lashing the tow.

The towing vessel UNCLE GEORGE was southbound on the Bayou Boeuf Canal in Amelia, LA, pushing one deck barge en route to Houston, TX.  While transiting through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge during high water,the current caught the bow and the barge allided with the protection cell of the center turn span.  The bridge remains fully operational.

On March 26, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received notification from Sector UMR that the UTV COOPERATIVE VENTURE (577609) allided with the Burlington RR Bridge at MM 403.1. The vessel was pushing 15 barges (8 corn, 3 bean, 2 ethanol and 2 corn oil). The vessel landed on the bridge's protection cell with two barges making contact (ART 9018 and ART 948). There was no damage, pollution or injuries on the bridge and no pollution or injuries on the vessel side. Damage on the vessel side was limited to broken wires. The vessel rebuilt their tow utilizes the assist tug UTV BURLINGTON. MSD Quad Cities conducted an on-scene investigation. After further investigation, it was discovered that there was reduced visibility down to 2 miles at the time of the incident. The master also took the bend proceeding the bridge too wide. This resulted in the master not being able to correct course prior to passing under the bridge. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the casualty was a combination of operator error and reduced visibility.

On 10 April 2018, vessel representatives conducted an inport inspection of the barge JAX-SAN JUAN BRIDGE. During this inspection, a significant amount of water was discovered in the #2 and #3 Starboard Tanks. The water was discharged from both tanks and an inset and hull breach were discovered in the side shell below the waterline. It was determined that during one of the 4 voyages between Jacksonville and Puerto Rico, the vessel sustained damage to the hull.

On April 15, 2018, at approximately 1800, the tug vessel FATCAT connected with the 254 ft barge CATERINE MARIE and proceeded to the Petaluma River channel, with 4 crewmembers on board.  At approximately 2250, while transiting upbound on the Petaluma River and attempting to align the tug and barge with the east channel of the swing bridge, the barge allided with the north side of the upriver fender system of the Black Point Railroad Bridge.  Approximately 60 ft of damage to the fender system was reported by Northwestern Pacific Railroad. The vessel Master reported the marine casualty to the Sector San Francisco Command Center at approximately 1110, on April 16, 2018.  No damage was reported to the barge or tug vessel.  

Westar Marine Services directed drug and alcohol testing to be conducted on all crewmembers involved in the marine casualty.  All drug and alcohol test results were negative.  

As a result of this investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the bridge.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the master’s inexperience transiting the waterway, (2) the master’s wrong plan to address an unfamiliar situation, (3) the improper placement of the spotlight, and (4) the inadequate use of lookouts.

Sector San Francisco Investigating Officer attempted to obtain a property damage estimate with the Sonoma-Marin Area Rail Transit (SMART), the Northwestern Pacific Railroad and Westar Marine Services on several occasions.  No property damage assessment could be provided due to pending litigation in this matter.

The investigation found substantial and probative evidence to support enforcmenet action against the mariner under 46 CFR Part 5.

On April 14, 2018, at approximately 1620 (CST) the AGGIE C (O.N. 585929) was transiting south bound on the Des Plaines River at MM 300.6 when the CBC 1314 (empty and clean with no product inside) bullet valve hood located on the stack allided with the Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad Bridge. The allision caused damage to the hood, requiring repair. There was no report of any damage to the bridge.

At approximately 0300 LMT on April 17, 2018, the KODIAK (ON 637055), an uninspected towing vessel, pushing ahead the barge M 3107 (ON 651477), was underway, making way northbound on the Elizabeth River when a towline parted the starboard quarter of the barge allided with the westside fender of Railroad Bridge #7.

The weather was 11 knot WNW winds with 17 knot gusts and north ebbing current. The KODIAK was underway, making way northbound on the southern branch of the Elizabeth River pushing ahead the barge M 3107. The tow and barge were approaching the Railroad Bridge #7 when the port face wire parted. Subsequently, the starboard quarter of the barge allided with the west side fender of Railroad Bridge #7.  The tow, dredge, and bridge were not damaged as a result of the allision. The Master notified the Coast Guard immediately following the marine casualty and although the incident did not reach the threshold for a Serious Marine Incident, he conducted post casualty alcohol testing on the Mate and Deckhand.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was material failure of the towline, the subsequent event was the allision with the Bridge fendering system.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include:  Material Condition:  The material condition of the towline was worn and inadequate to withstand the vessel's maneuvering.

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral for enforcement.

On 21 April 2018, at approximately 1255, the vessel INDEPENDENCE was departing its mooring from downtown Jacksonville, FL on the St. Johns River. After the vessel was walked sideways away from the pier, the Master turned the vessel about 45 degrees to port to head downriver. The vessel allided with the Main Street Bridge fendering system. The SE bridge fendering system was damaged and the vessel sustained two broken windows and three bent window frames on the starboard quarter. The Master continued downriver without notifying the Coast Guard of the Marine Casualty. A crewmember aboard the vessel made the initial report to the Coast Guard. A verbal Captain of the Port Order was issued to the vessel at approximately 1330 to restrict the vessel from departing Jacksonville prior to a Marine Inspector and Investigator attending the vessel for damage survey and preliminary investigation. The vessel continued towards the ICW for approximately 45 minutes before receiving another order to halt the vessel. 
Alcohol testing was conducted aboard the vessel in the presence of attending Coast Guard.

At approximately 0615 Eastern Standard Time (EST) on April 22, 2018, the towing vessel YVONNE CONWAY was pushing 15 empty barges in a 3x5 configuration down bound. As the vessel and tow approached the Matthew E. Welsh Bridge the third and fourth starboard barges in the towing string allided with the center bridge pier at mile marker 647.8 on the Ohio River.  No damage to the bridge was reported and minor damage to the 580, third barge and C1272, fourth barge. 


The Coast Guard's investigation found the initiating event was a navigation error.  The Master miscalculated the bridge's horizantal clearance on the starboard side and allided with the center bridge pier.

On 26 FEB 2018 at approximately 0230 CST, the towing vessel ASHLEIGH, was underway outbound on the Back Bay of Biloxi approaching the I-110 bridge in the Back Bay of Biloxi pushing 4 barges in a side by side, 2 by 2, configuration.  Weather conditions leading up to the event included 18 - 21mph winds with gusts up to 32mph. The wind direction was shifting from a WNW direction at 0219hrs to a N wind direction at 0231hrs.

While transiting between the I-110 bridge span, the Pilot attempted to compensate his steerage for the prevailing winds, tide, and current conditions.  Due to the shifting winds, the ASHLEIGH's tow began to push towards the south, causing the lead barge to allide with the southeast span of bridge cribbing. 

The barge did not sustain any damage from the allision.  Damage to the bridge cribbing was estimated by the company at approximately $156,000.  The crewmembers on watch at the time of the allision all provided drug and alcohol specimens with results on all.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this incident to be the allision between the ASHLEIGH and the I-110 Bridge which caused damage to the bridge cribbing. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) Inadequate Planning Before Pilot Shiphandling Maneuver and (2) Unknown Shift in Wind Direction.

On March 16, 2018, the BUCKEYE STATE (O.N. 1214534) was southbound on the Illinois River Mile Marker 56 pushing 15 loaded dry cargo hopper barges.  The Master was flanking down to the Florence HWY Bridge along the left descending bank (LDB) to stay off the right descending bank (RDB) draft of the river current. At approx. 500 feet above the bridge, the tow was setting towards the RDB and the Master throttled up to go through the bridge span, but set did not push the tow towards the center span quickly enough and the port lead barge ACL 00119 allided with the left descending bank protection cell. Later the grain from the ACL 00119 was off loaded to another hopper barge. By off loading the ACL00119 the damage was raised above the waterline and the barge was allowed to transit to Beardstown Mile Marker 88 ILR. Barge was later taken to shipyard in St Louis for repairs.

On April 23, 2018, the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) ALYDAR was underway on the Intra Coastal Waterway in the vicinity of mile marker 50, pushing six empty dry cargo barges. At approximately 1815, the UTV operator was making an approach to the Bayou Blue Bridge when the starboard lead barge, AEP 7485, allided with the guide wall of the bridge. A surveyor identified that the allision resulted in no damage to the barge, however it did result in the upper two timbers of the northwest guide wall having light scrapes and abrasions with multiple splinters. The bridge was operational after the incident. It was determined by both parties that the incident did not meet there thresholds to have repairs made to the barge or guide wall.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the barge AEP 7485 which was controlled by UTV ALYDAR and the northwest Bayou Blue Bridge guide wall. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: prevailing winds affecting the course of the barge.

On 25APR2018 the M/V CYNTHIA II (ON 1246833 5600HP) @ 2020 hrs was traveling SB at MM 980.5 Ohio River with 15 Empty dry cargo barges (No Red-flags) in a 3 x 5 config. While navigating the Kentucky span of the I24 Bridge the STRB string of the tow 2nd and 3rd barge back allied with the bridge causing 1 barge to be set adrift, breaking 8 wires and damaging a kevel. Master stated that while transiting the pass he had sustained winds of 12-14 MPH but as he made the approach to the bridge span winds gusted to 27 mph.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be allision with the I-24 Highway Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Loss of Situational Awareness 2) Pilot erred in determining set and speed of current and wind.

On 24APR2018 at approximately 0715 the UTV DONNA H FURLONG (HFL Barge Fleeting LLC, 1263519), while underway pushing 4 loaded sand barges in a 2 by 2 configuration, cleared the Martin Luther King Jr. Highway Bridge at mile marker 186 of the Cumberland River and proceeded downbound closely along the left descending bank.  As the vessel proceeded, it began to get closer to the bank, contacting vegetation until going aground at the port lead barge (HMT 402) on the bank near mile marker 185.5. After grounding, the stern of the towing vessel then began to move with the current down river alliding with a tank barge, HFL 3007, which was moored at the MPLX Marathon facility on the opposite bank of the Cumberland River.  The HFL 3007 was prepared for a product transfer of gasoline to the facility until personnel shut down the operation in anticipation of an allision as the vessel began to top around.  After alliding lightly with the HFL 3007, the stern continued to top around and allided with a dock piling at the Marathon MPLX facility.  After grounding on the bank, the pilot was intentionally pushing the tow head into the bank to slow the progression of his stern down river and in an attempt to maintain control which proved unsuccessful.  The current then caused couplings to break setting the tow adrift in two barge sections.  The aft string, ING 1658 and H 411B, floated down river and allided with the upper protection pier of the Walking Horse and Eastern RR bridge at MM 185.2 CBR, coming to rest parallel with the right descending bridge supports.  The lead barges, HMT 402 and HMT 314, were recovered by an assist vessel that approached from the down river side, fleeting them on the right descending bank a short distance down river.  SOHV USCG issued a SMIB notifying mariners that the channel was blocked IVO MM 185 CBR.  The Walking Horse & Eastern Railroad Bridge was also secured to rail traffic to allow the recovery of the barges.

The marine employer conducted drug and alcohol testing on the pilot and brought onboard a surveyor to conduct a third party damage assessment of the barges.  Additional personnel were also brought onboard to initiate a barge recovery operation from the bridge.  The barges were removed by lining up the M/V DONNA H FURLONG and another M/V bow to bow to increase horsepower and maneuverability in the high current flow adjacent to the bridge.  The barges ING 1658 and H 411B were recovered successfully from the bridge without further incident.  The surveyor identified damages to the H 411B and HMT 314.  Though no bridge damages were apparent at the time of the incident, damages were identified to the bridge protection pier after the water receded requiring repairs to a metal band that had come loose.  It cannot be determined if that damage is attributed to this incident.

The investigation revealed that the pilot brought his tow too close to the left descending bank upon clearing the MLK bridge.  The pilot could not bring the tow of the four loaded barges far enough off the bank to maintain headway and subsequently grounded the head of the tow and lost control of the vessel stern.  Further subsequent events include alliding with the HFL 3007 and Marathon MPLX facility piling, tow breakaway and bridge allision at the Walking Horse & Eastern R/R Bridge.  Damage estimate was provided by attending surveyor equaling $45621 to the two damaged barges.

AT 1646 local time, SUMR received report from UTV COOPERATIVE MARINER, transiting S/B on the UMR with 4 dry cargo barges carrying corn, that she allided with the Lacrosse Railroad Bridge at MM 699.7 in MSD St. Paul's AOR. UTV was drafting 9' when she allided her starboard barge into the bridge's RDB shore sheerfence caused by miss flanking operations. UTV reported no DPI and is currently transiting to St. Louis. Lacrosse Railroad Bridge confirmed allision and reported that it will not being filling paper work because no damage occurred. MSD Personnel confirmed reported information and verified that no damage, pollution, or injuries had occurred. MSD personnel also confirmed that the vessel had checked all void spaces within the barges and certified that they were free of flooding. 

On Scene WX: Winds W 17 MPH;  Air 28 F; Water 35 F; VIS 10 NM

On 30APR2018 at approximately 2300 hrs the M/V SAMUEL J (Florida Marine Transporters, 575860, 4000HP) was pushing 14 loaded rock barges (5X3 - 4 in the port string) down bound at MM 940.8 OHR navigating the high water span of the I-24 Highway Bridge when the tow was set by the current, causing the vessel to slide. The pilot was not able to stop the slide and the starboard string struck the right descending pier of the I-24 Bridge (LLNR 28220) mid-tow causing 12 barges to be set adrift. The MTC-213 (loaded rock barge) sank approximately 100 ft. from the right descending pier and the MTC-6413 (loaded rock barge) was pushed into the left descending bank where it partially sank. The other 10 barges were put back into tow and secured.  

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be allision with the I-24 Highway Bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Loss of Situational Awareness; and 2) Pilot misjudged the set and speed of the current.

On 26 April 2018 at 23:15 the towing vessel LYDIA MARIE(O.N.268970) was pushing 16 empty hopper barges northbound when the barge on the port hip, (SCF 24205) struck the protection cell of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge located at mile 282.1 UMR.  There was no damage to the bridge, bridge protection pier, or barge.

On 05APR2018 at approximately 1000 (CDT), the towing vessel BILL RODGERS was pushing 06 loaded sand barges (2 wide x 3 long) when it allided with the Pennington Bridge located at mile marker 199.9, Cumberland River. The BILL RODGERS tow was passing between the spans when the current set tow toward the left descending bank's span.  The second barge on the starboard string (HMT 309) landed against the bridges left descending bridge span.

During the investigation, it was found that at 08:00, on 05APR, the discharge from Old Hickory Lock and Dam was at 40 kcfs and was predicted to remain at 40 kcfs.  However, at 09:00, the discharge spiked to 56.1 kcfs.  This information was passed to the captain via email at 09:44.  The vessel was just beginning to pass between the Pennington bridge spans when swift current caused the vessel's speed to diminish from 3.1 kts to .8 kts.  The current set the tow approximately 30' into the left descending bank's bridge span.  The pilot maintained forward throttle and was able to safely slide the tow down river and push into the left descending bank until a second tow vessel could give assistance. 

Of the 6 barges involved in the allision, only one sustained minor damage, HMT 309.  The location of the HMT 309's damage was approximately from the port side number 1 void, starting at the 2nd kevel and extending into the port bow void at the first scuttle, a linear distance of about 7 feet.  The damage was from the gunwale extending down to the water line about 8 feet with various insets from 0"-2.75".   The Pennington's bridge left descending span's left corner sustained approximately 1'W x 4'L x 2" deep surface gouge.  The DOT surveyed and its assessment was the damage to the bridge span was superficial.  The total estimated cost of the vessel repairs was $6,000.00

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event was the allision with the Pennington Bridge.  A contributing factor to the allision was the sudden release of an additional 16.1 kcfs causing swift current unknown to the BILL RODGERS (mate) pilot.

At approx 0500 the UTV COOPERATIVE VENTURE barge ART 44156 loaded with grain (port barge in the third string) allided with the Pekin RR Bridge.  The barge contacted the bridge's protection cell while transiting S/B at MM 150 ILR. The bridge reported no damage to protection cell. The UTV reported that while transiting S/B, with the assist VSL EDMUND L, that they over compensated and pushed the UTVs port side of tow into the Lower Pekin R/R Bridge protection cell. There was no damage to the barge.

At approximately 0200 on May 10, 2018, the UTV LARRY TILLEY was northbound on the Arkansas River pushing four barges when the vessel allided with the I-30 Bridge.
