The four barges were empty liquid fertilizer barges. The stern of the starboard lead barge allided with the bridge. Three rigging wires were broken, but the barge sustained no damage. Arkansas Bridge authorities inspected the bridge and found no damage to the protection cells. The vessel was cleared to proceed to Catusa, OK. 

The investigation revealed that the pilot lost situational awareness.

On 11MAY18 at approximately 0230, the UTV DONNA H. FURLONG (1263519, Hines Furlong Lines, 2000HP) at MM 185.2 CMB allided with the right descending span pier of the Walking Horse and Eastern RR Bridge (Bordeaux Bridge). The vessel was pushing three loaded gasoline barges enroute to the Hines Furlong fleet at mile 176.  The pilot had come aboard as a trip pilot on 27APR18 and received orientation training on that day.  He had worked for the owner/operator over the past 3-4 years.  The pilot planned to flank the tow around the protection pier and through the bridge span.  The pilot positioned two lookouts port and starboard and received regular updates as the vessel approached the bridge.  The tow cleared the protection pier and came within 6" of the right pier and the pilot began to back down, but the momentum of the tow was enough to make contact with the bridge causing no apparent damage.

The investigation revealed that the pilot made a misjudgement of the affects of the current upon the DONNA H FURLONG with three loaded barges during the flank.  No damages were identified or associated costs.

On 29 April 2018 at approx. 04:15 the towing vessel CITY OF CASSVILLE(O.N.546984) was transiting northbound on the UMR MM 282.1 with 16 barges, 9 empty and 7 dry cargo hopper barges, when the barge on the port hip of the tow, (CC 97121) rubbed the RDB protection cell of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge located at mile 282.1 UMR.  There was no damage to the barge or bridge.

On May 17, 2018, the COOPERATIVE MARINER (O.N. 627829) was downbound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282 pushing 12 barges (9 dry cargo and 3-bulk liquid). The assist vessel PONDEROSA was at the head of the tow. The Master of the COOPERATIVE MARINER had a track line to pass through the LOUISANA Rail Road Bridge channel. The river current affected PONDEROSA and COOPERATIVE MARINER and the lead port barge ART 35959 (O.N 1242922) made a controlled landing on the north protection cell.

At 1725 LCL SECUMR RCVD notification of a bridge allision at the Soo Line RR Bridge at MM 699 UMR.  Bridge tender reported the UTV COOPERATIVE AMBASSADOR broke timbers on the RDB shear fence when they made contact while transiting under the bridge. UTV COOPERATIVE AMBASSADOR (ARTCO) reported that due to high water and current they made contact while transiting S/B pushing 12 dry cargo barges of corn. No D/P/I to vessel was reported. MSD IO conducted investigation and confirmed that the vessel was undamaged but a significant number of timbers (30-50 foot section) were damaged. The bridge tender refused to provide an initial estimate of damage, IO estimated the damage to be $50,000.

On scene weather: SW Winds 17MPH;  Air 74F; Water 53F; VIS 10NM

On 17MAY2018 at about 1410 LT, The M/V JEFFREY G, pushing 30 loaded grain barges, struck the Vicksburg Rail Bridge in Vicksburg, Mississippi as a result of pilot error when the Captain, Michael Ward, misjudged the current and took the wrong angle through the bridge. The allision led to a breakaway of five barges, four of which were recovered, and one of which was severely damaged. The damaged barge, LTD-6216, sank just outside of the channel past the bridge. The total cost of damages is estimated $746,000.00.

No injuries or pollution were reported or discovered during the investigation.

On 11MAY2018, at approximately 08:40 (CDT), the UTV BILL HILL was upbound pushihng 11 loaded barges (1 caustic soda, 7 sand, and 3 coal in a 3x4 configuration) attempting to pass under the O'neal Highway Bridge (U.S. HWY 72) near the right descending bank at mile 256 on the Tennessee River.  

The pilot misjudged the turn to enter the Wilson Lock and Dam and the starboard lead barge (PBM 2218) allided with the bridge span near the right descending bank.  The allision caused damage to the head log of the barge as well as crumpling of the deck over the bow void and was holed in several places in the hull and deck.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that this incident was not a result of any material failure of vessel components, but has been deemed it was caused by the pilot misjudging the turn.  The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for the marine casualty was the allision of the barge PBM 2218 and the O'Neal Highway Bridge.

At approximately 1315 the UTV POSEIDON with three barges westbound on the ICW laid against the fendering system of the West Port Arthur bridge. No damage, pollution, injuries were received by vessel or tow. It was discovered that the Captain on board the UTV POSEIDON miss judged the placement of his vessel around the bend in the river which led to the allision. TXDOT notified and confirmed that there was no damage done to the fendering system.

The cause of this casualty was an execution error by the Captain of the UTV POSEIDON.

On August 9, 2017, at approximately 1800, the ferry vessel SONOMA allided with Corte Madera Channel Light #5 (LLNR 5335) while navigating Larkspur Channel in Corte Madera, California causing the marker to submerge.  At the time of the allision, there was an ebb cross channel current that the Master was unable to successfully counter and the vessel was set onto the aid to navigation.  There was no damage sustained by the SONOMA, however, the estimated costs to repair the Corte Madera Channel Light #5 are $56,000.  This dollar amount exceeds the $25,000 threshold, thus making this allision a reportable marine casualty.  

As a result of this investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision itself.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty were the on-scene waterway conditions and the Master's inability to properly control the vessel.

At approximately 0015 29JUN18 the M/V CAPT BILL STEWART (575823, Inland Marine, 6000HP) was transiting D/B at MM 43.7 UMR pushing 25 loaded grain barges in a 5x5 configuration. After flanking the Grey's Point turn, the master noticed the lights on the bridge were extinguised and then set himself up to make his approach to the bridge. As he got closer, the master realized he had misjudged his slide and tried to come ahead to correct. However, before he could clear the bridge, the stbd stern barge allided with the RDP of the THEBES R/R Bridge. 

Coast Guard investivation revealed the initiating event to be the allision with the bridge. Contributing factors include 1) Human error 2) Loss of Situational Awarness 3) Failure of navigational lights.

On June 24, 2018, at approximately 1200hrs the Uninspected Towing Vessel AL WEAVER (Length 83ft, US Flag, O.N 551557, Managing Owner: American Commercial Barge Line, LLC) departed the Joliet dry dock located on the Des Plaines River at MM 288.4 with no barges in tow. The current set the vessel towards the Jackson Street Bridge. The AL WEAVER zodiac hoist boom made contact with the bridge, resulting in damage to the boom.  No damage was reported to the Jackson Street Bridge.

On May 16, 2018, the Cooperative Vanguard (O.N.648110) was on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 309.9 south bound pushing 12 loaded dry cargo hopper barges. The master slowed his vessel and tow down to allow the Hannibal Railroad Bridge to clear all rail traffic. The master then proceeded through the bridge span and current set to tow towards the left descending bank making contact with the bridge protection cell, breaking wires on lead starboard barge.

On 26 June 2018, at approximately 1542 hours, the towing vessel CHRISTY was south bound with six empty barges. The Master had an assist tug while transiting through the Morgan City VTS zone. A micro burst weather event occurred causing 27 to 30 knot winds from the east as the tow approached the Morgan City railroad bridge. The lead starboard barge allided with the dolphin (fender system) in front of the west piling of the bridge. There was no pollution or injuries associated with incident. The impact on the dolphin of the bridge caused the 6 face wires in the towing configuration to break, the tow held together as the Master backed off the dolphin and proceeded to the west bank to reconfigure the barges. Initial estimate to the barge that sustained damage was about $10,000. The bridge tender provided no estimate but the damage to the dolphin does not exceeded $100,000. Following the allision with the bridge dolphin the vessel had to back down and came close to hitting the Highway 90 bridge that was behind the towing vessel but there was no evidence of damage to the vessel or the Highway 90 bridge. Facilities on the west bank of the Atchafalaya came into close proximity to the barges, and possible contact as the barges were being reconfigured. There was no evidence on the barges or the towing vessel on their starboard side to show that they had made contact or allied with any structures along the bank. The likely cause of this allision was an unforeseeable micro burst weather event that had a strong impact on the sail area of the empty barges. The Master had already taken steps to mitigate the maneuverability hazards by having an assist towing vessel, exceeding minimum horsepower requirements for the tow.

At approximately 0422, Sector Upper Mississippi River received a report from the La Crosse R/R Bridge tender of damage to their sheer fence. The UTV Mary Scheel, drafting 9’, was pushing 05 dry cargo and 02 empty barges, transiting northbound on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 699.8 when the UTV's lead starboard bow allided into the sheer fence while attempting to pass through. The river was experiencing high water causing the vessel to have difficulty maneuvering within the bridge span and striking the left sheer pier. RR assessor assessed damage, which consisted of broken timbers.

Sector Upper Mississippi River (SUMR) received report from the UTV TOM BEHRINGER (ACBL) transiting S/B on the UMR MM 535 with 04 barges (corn/soy beans), drafting 9', under the SABULA R/R Drawbridge that 02 of the barges allided with the LDB protection cell wall. No damage to the bridge, the UTV suffered some broken wires. No other DPI.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined this marine casualty to be the result of strong currents in the area.

On June 20, 2018, at approximately 8:05 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time, the 690 foot U.S. freight vessel HERBERT C. JACKSON completed cargo unload at Arcelor Mittal and began transiting down the Cuyahoga River. As the vessel departed the dock it was in ballast and was drafting 19 feet 6 inches aft. The vessel was backed to the upper turning basin and turned around before continuing down the river. After the turn was complete, ballast was added to put the vessel into "Alpha ballast" with the aft draft of 20 feet 7 inches. At 12:05 a.m. on June 21, 2018, the captain on the HERBERT C. JACKSON contacted Norfolk & Southern Railroad Bridge #1 (NS1) to request an opening in 30 min, as required by regulation. At 12:40 a.m., the captain began navigating under NS1 after center span was fully open, as indicated by the illuminated green light. At 12:45 a.m. the mast headlight on the HERBERT C JACKSON allided with the center span of NS1, causing minor damage to the vessel's mast headlight. 

The bridge tender lowered the bridge, contacted the bridge supervisor, and suspended rail traffic until a structural inspection could be completed. At 2:09 a.m., the inspection was completed, revealing no damage to the bridge and rail traffic resumed.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard was not able to determine what caused the HERBERT C. JACKSON's mast headlight to strike the NS1 center span. All evidence indicated that the HERBERT C. JACKSON should have safely passed under the bridge with nearly 2 feet of clearance. However, this investigation will remain a data collection activity since this reportable marine casualty resulted in only minor damage.

Sector Upper Mississippi River (SUMR) received report from the UTV BILL STEGBAUER (Southern Towing) transiting N/B on the UMR MM 535 with 10 barges, dry cargo, drafting 8'6" that some barges allided with the sheer fence of the SABULA R/R DRAWBRIDGE. Bridge tender reported no damage, the UTV reports no DPI.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined this marine casualty to be the result of strong currents in the area.

On 28Feb2018 at 1645, UTV ALABAMA (O.N. 529650, O/O Amherst Madison, 2200hp) reported that while pushing 9 loaded coal barges (3x3) D/B at MM .5 KAN (Point Pleasant, WV) the UTVs lead starboard barge (AEP 9274) allided with the Baltimore & Ohio R&R bridge.

IO Findings:  Vessel operator was new to the vessel's maneuverability characteristics.  With high water, the vessel didn't handle as expected.

On July 20, 2018, at approximately 0100 hrs (local) the ITV GWYNETH ANNE (ON:1277658)(Length:65ft) was operating on the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal pushing 6 empty dry cargo barges when a gust of wind that was blowing across the channel at 18 mph caused the barge (IN116510) to allide with the South Cicero Avenue Bridge at MM317.2. The barge sustained minor damage to the coaming on the starboard/stern side, approx a 1'/.5' dent. No report of any injuries or damage to the bridge.

On 20JULY2018 at approximately 1300 local time, fishing vessel MASTER DEAN allided with the Highway 23 bridge in Empire, LA near MM 35 on the Mississippi River and Adams Bay MASTER DEAN intended to transit beneath the bridge, but the master misjudged the height of his mast in relation to the bridge. Once he realized he was going to strike the bridge, the master slowed the vessel to almost a stop, but the wind pushed the vessel into the bridge, causing $2500 worth of damage to the vessels booms. No damaged reported to the bridge. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that this incident met the criteria of a Data Collection as the fishing vessel made an unintended strike of a bridge.

On July 01, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received a notification that the DENNIS T DELANEY (536790) allided with the Sabula Railroad Bridge. DENNIS T DELANEY was transiting southbound pushing 12 barges loaded with dry cargo. As the vessel approached the Sabula Railroad Bridge, a strong eddy pulled the stern off the set. As the Captain attempted to correct the set, the third barge from the vessel in the port string made contact with the bridge protection pier. The bridge surveyor reported minor scrapes and few broken wood fencing around the protection pier. The Vessel reported no damage, pollution, or injuries.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was pilot error.

On 31 July 2018, at approximately 0045, the 65 foot Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) MISS MADELINE was transiting through the Bayou Blue swing bridge, located at mile marker 49.8 on the Intra Coastal Waterway in Houma LA. The UTV had 03 persons onboard pushing ahead one (01) unmanned empty construction barge. During the passage through the opening of the bridge span, the port bow of the barge allided with the south fender wall. After alliding with the south fender wall, the tow progressed through the span and then allided with the north fender wall. The bridge tender contacted the UTV and the UTV operator acknowledged that the barge allided with the bridge fender wall system twice. Due to the allision happening at approximately 0045, the damage was not able to be fully assessed until daylight. The UTV then continued its voyage to Morgan City, LA.

On 31 July 2018, by approximately 0800, the Bayou Blue swing bridge damage was assessed by the bridge tender and bridge supervisor. Damage to two timbers on the south fence wall, one timber on the north fence wall, and one red navigational light was reported. The bridge was operational at all times. No damage was reported to have occurred to the construction barge.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast has determined that the initiation event for this casualty was the UTV MISS MADELINE controlling a barge that allided with the Bayou Blue swing bridge. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) UTV operator unfamiliar with the line of site of the UTV, (2) limited visibility to due night time.

At approximately 1515 EST on July 30, 2018, the container vessel HABIB EXPRESS alided with the I-95 overpass bridge fendering system while being dead ship towed outbound on the Miami River, resulting in damage to both the bridge fendering system and the vessel. The investigation discovered that the tow operation conducted by the towing vessels CAPT BABUN and SARA from the MIAMI RIVER TOWING COMPANY, played a significant role in the allision. While navigating a narrow turn in the Miami River, the lead tug was overtaken by the HABIB EXPRESS and failed to recover the situation. The HABIB EXPRESS struck the bridge causing damage to the bridge fendering system, and also sustaining damage to her aft transom and aft bulwark plating on the port side resulted smashed, bended and holed (two perforations of 100 mm of diameter approximately) as well as inside of the fresh water tank (port side) two longitudinal elements (cant frame) were bended. There was no damage to either of the two tugs. No injuries were sustained during the incident.

On 05AUG2018 at approximately 1630 M/V SHELBY JEAN (270840, Greystone, 2800HP) was traveling down bound at MM 937 Ohio River pushing 15 loaded deck barges. While navigating the Irvin Cobb Bridge during a forecasted storm, the vessel's tow (Barge –HD125) allided with the bridge pier. After speaking with the master he stated that he did not check the weather during watch change. The master lost sight of the bridge and went outside of the navigational channel. 

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the Allision. Contributing Factors include 1): Loss of Situational Awareness 2) Master did not take into account predicted weather 3) reduced visibility from the storm.

On July 16, 2018, the CAPT. BILL STEWART (O.N. 575823) was up bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 288 pushing 15 empty dry cargo barges. The Master alter his course as he passed through the span of the Louisiana R/R Swing Bridge because of heavy river current and the port string third back AED 257 (O.N. 1097105)allied with the protection cell.

On August 2, 2018, ITV Albert C (O.N. 537179) departed MM 304.3 heading SW along the Chicago Ships Sanitary Canal (CSSC) enroute to Illinois Marine Towing Southslip at MM 299 on the CSSC, and pushing an empty covered dry cargo barge (IN085462 O.N. 1208522). At approx 1330, the top cover on the IN085462 allided with the Atchison Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Bridge at MM 300.7, resulting in damage to the barge top cover. There were no injuries, no pollution and no damage to the bridge.

On August 9, 2018, at approximately 0600 Eastern Standard Time (EST) the towing vessel M.K. MCNALLY was pushing 14 barges down bound when it allided with the US 41 Bridge. The vessel passed under the bridge and went to a fleeting area on the left descending bank to pick up another barge. The vessel was operating astern propulsion and attempted to line the front of the tow with the additional barge when the vessel’s starboard stern allided with the bridge. 

The stern of the M.K. MCNALLY sustained structural damage with a breech in the stern void tanks causing the compartment to flood. There was no damage to the barges or the bridge. 

The Coast Guard's investigation found the initiating event was a navigation error that was caused by the Master being distracted by a crew member that came to the bridge.  The Master and the crew member got into an argument and the Master lost his situational awareness and allided with the bridge.

The towing vessel SEA WOLF was pushing the COASTAL 20 drilling rig equipment barge with the assist vessel SEA OX northbound in Bayou Boeuf near Amelia, LA. While transiting through the Bayou Boeuf Railroad Bridge, the master of the SEA WOLF laid up the COASTAL 20 barge on the east side fender to assist in transiting through the bridge. The allision caused minor damage (a broken bolt) to the east approach fender of the bridge. While exact numbers could not be determined, initial damage estimates do not exceed $200,000. The barge and towing vessels were not damaged as a result of the allision.

SEC UMR CC received a report from ITV TITLETOWN USA that they made contact with the Upper Cell of the Clinton RR Bridge at MM 518 UMR. The starboard stern barge CC 1114 made contact with the Clinton RR Bridge, which caused the side shell plate to set in 0" to 5" full height of the barge. Bottom plate and Gunwale damaged which caused a small leak. Damages estimated at <$25,000. They were able to use pumps to maintain control of the leak and apply shingles as a temporary repair for the rest of their transit to St. Louis.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined this marine casualty to be the result of strong currents in the area.

On 31JUL18 the ITV JOHN LARANDEAU (O.N. 284238) was northbound on the Missouri River (MOR) mile marker (MM) 366.2 pushing 1 loaded coal barge. The Master was transiting through the left span (right descending bank (RDB) side) of the Hannibal Railroad Bridge (swing bridge) and lining up to pass under the Broadway Avenue Highway Bridge when the current set the tow towards the left descending bank (LDB) of the MOR. The head of the barge made contact with the one of the piers of the Broadway Bridge and began to top over to the starboard side. As the tow began to swing the stern of the JOHN LARANDEAU made contact with one of the piers of the Hannibal Bridge (bridges are less than 1/10th mile apart) and was wedges between the two piers. Tow laid along bridge piers until an assist vessel arrived on scene. Once tow was free, Master and crew inspected barge and ITV for damage and bridges were inspected by MODOT; no damage reported.

On August 12, 2018, at approximately 1800 LMT, uninspected towing vessel KAREN KOBY(ON: 1230122) was underway, making way at three knots pushing ahead the uninspected deck barge U 798 (ON:1068524) and uninspected deck barge U 800 (ON:1131544) when the U 798's (ON: 1131544) port sideshell allided with the northeast side of the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system (galvanized rubber).

Prior to the allision, the KAREN KOBY and U 798 barge were heading southbound on the Elizabeth River approaching the Gilmerton Bridge. The KAREN KOBY was under command and control of a licensed Master. A lookout was on the forward end of the barge.  There was no monetary damage to the bridge or vessels involved in the allision. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the inadequate vessel maneuvering of the KAREN KOBY to transit between the bridge fendering system, the subsequent event was the U 798 allision with the Gilmerton Bridge fendering system. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) execution error/attention failure: operator failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the bridge fendering system by incorrectly factoring in the width of bridge span and dimensions of the barge to safely transit through without an allision, (2) environmental complexity: the Southern Branch of the Elizabeth River has multiple bends when approaching from the north of the Gilmerton Bridge. These angles and natural bends in the river make navigating this bridge and waterway complex, and (3) the original construction of the bridge in 1938 did not consider the expansive commercial vessel traffic that would transit the waterway.

Recommend closing this Incident Investigation Activity without a referral to an Enforcement Activity.

At approximately 2020 local time on August 30, 2018 the towing vessel TAYLOR MARIE was transiting upbound at mile marker 146, Lower Mississippi River, pushing ahead the barge RANDY W which was carrying a crane as its cargo when the crane allided with the underside of the Gramercy Bridge in the alternate span. 

The crane sustained damage to the crane tower, tower sheaves, wire rope and various components. Estimated damage to the crane was $100,000. The Gramercy Bridge sustained damage to both lower chords of the main truss and two lower braces. Estimated damage to the bridge was $15,000. Total estimated damage is $115,000. 

Through its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event of this marine casualty was the allision of the bridge by the crane. Causal factors contributing to this marine casualty were: 1) no company procedure to measure air draft of tall cargo, 2) failure of the master of the TAYLOR MARIE to measure the air draft of the crane on the RANDY W, 3) unverified height of the Gramercy Bridge, crane, and Reserve Gage, 4) imprudent decision of the TAYLOR MARIE to use the alternate span of the Gramercy Bridge, and 5) no published height of Gramercy Bridge alternate span in the Mississippi River map book. The level of investigative effort was an informal investigation.

On August 31, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received a report of a bridge allision. ITV BRAD BENNINK (576108) was southbound on the Mississippi River, pushing 12 loaded dry grain barges at UMR MM 579.3. The ITV BRAD BENNINK had just completed its transit through the Dubuque railroad swing bridge and was approaching HWY 20 Bridge. The vessel attempted to transit through the alternate span to save time on transit, when the vessel made contact with the bridge. The contact resulted in a broken timber off the protection pier. No further damage, pollution, or injuries were reported. 

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating cause of the incident was due to pilot error.

On 26 August 2018 at approximately 1410, while transiting through the industrial locks in the vicinity of mile marker 6.4 on the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway East, the master of the inspected towing vessel (ITV) RED RIVER reported an unintended allision with the Claiborne Bridge. 

The master stated his main mast, which contained his 02 amber towing lights, struck the bridge. No damage to the bridge was reported. The mast repair expense was minimal.

As a result of its investigation the Coast Guard determined this incident is a reportable Marine Casualty in accordance with 46 CFR Part 4.01-5. The level of investigative effort was a data collection.

04SEPT19 2235 - Sector Upper Mississippi River (SECUMR) received a report from the ITV JAMES F. NEAL (Ingram Barge Co) transiting S/B on the UMR MM 481.2 with 15 barges, dry cargo (corn, soybeans), drafting 9', that they allided with the Crescent R/R Drawbridge, causing a puncture in one barge which is taking on water. The ITV has placed a pump, which kept up with the water intake while enroute to a fleeting area at UMR MM 474 where the barge was to moored off for damage repairs.  No damage to bridge or further DPI was reported.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined this marine casualty to be the result of improper ship handling by the Master.

On September 04, 2018 at approx. 2315, the AMERICAN QUEEN (O.N. 1030765) was southbound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) mile marker (MM) 283.2 with 391 passengers onboard when the vsl allided with the Champ Clark Bridge (formerly Louisiana Hwy Bridge) pier. Scheduled construction was being conducted on the bridge and was to be completed at 1800 that day. Due to the scheduled bridge maintenance, departure from Hannibal, MO (MM 309.0) was set to align with the timeframe of the scheduled bridge maintenance and minimize potential delays when the vsl reached the Champ Clark Bridge. Once the vsl reached the Champ Clark Bridge (at approx. 2100), contractors informed the Master of the AMERICAN QUEEN that there will be a 2 hour delay. The AMERICAN QUEEN held up just north of the bridge for approx. 2 hrs. At approx. 2300 the Master once again contacted the bridge contractor about passage through the bridge and were once again told of another 2 hr delay. Approx. 15 mins later the bridge contractor contacted the AMERICAN QUEEN and informed them that the “MO side” of the bridge span would be made available for transit (normal transit is done through the center span). Despite the Master having never traversed this span previously and high water warnings in the area, he proceeded to transit the MO side span. Once the nose of the vsl was under the bridge extreme current was setting the vsl to the portside. The Master put the rudders and two installed Z-drives hard over to starboard. The vsl was not able to overcome the current and allided with the bridge pier portside amidships. Damage on the vsl included a damaged rub rail, slight buckling of the deck, shifted internal staircase, and a cracked keel cooler line for the port generator. MODOT dispatched a bridge inspector and reported back that the bridge did not suffer any damage. No notification to the CG (Bridge Branch or Sector UMR) was made to advise of the construction delay that went beyond the scheduled 1800 timeframe.

At Approximately 0715 on September 9, 2018, BARGE T13957, loaded with corn, while DB under the control of the ITV ERNA E HONEYCUTT allided with the protection cell on the left descending bank of the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RAILROAD BRIDGE (AKA Lower Pekin Railroad),on the Illinois River, Mile Marker 151.2. ITV ERNA E HONEYCUTT was pushing a 15 barge tow and BARGE T13957 was third barge in port string.  ITV ARTCO MAIDEN was assisting tow through the bridge. Master stated the tow was about halfway through the bridge when the current set the tow onto the bridge piling. Master reported one broken wire and no damage to either the barge or the bridge.  MSD Peoria conducted a phone investigation with both the master of ITV ERNA E HONEYCUTT and the bridge tender for the Lower Pekin RR Bridge.  Confirmed no damage to the bridge or barges.  Vessel continued transiting south.

HOU 2018/0193: On July 23, 2018, at approximately 0300, The towing vessel MR. EARL allided with the Interstate 10 Bridge that crosses the San Jacinto River Houston, Texas.  There was no damage to the bridge and the damage to the MR. EARL was limited to a bent railing, ladder, & pole.  No injuries, pollution, or waterway obstructions were reported.
The MR. EARL was able to make repairs and return to normal operating status the following day.  The Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the master of the MR. EARL falling asleep at the helm prior to the allision.  A Letter of Warning will be issued to the master of the MR. EARL.

On August 28th, 2018 the towing vessel MISS DOROTHY(O.N. 271680) was pushing 15 loaded grain barges headed southbound, including barge MMA 2215B (O.N. 1131047), which struck the Louisiana Railroad Bridge at MM 282 UMR. The bridge reports no damage. The barge MMA 2215B suffered a puncture in the bow tank, and the pumps were keeping up with the flooding. The crew conducted temporary repairs, applying a patch to stop the leak. No other damage, pollution, or injuries are reported.

On 28AUG18 the JILL CAROLYN (O.N. 625953) departed the Lange-Stegmann waterfront facility and headed  northbound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) mile marker (MM) 183.0 pushing 2 empty fertilizer barges. The Master transited through the center span of the Merchant’s Railroad Bridge with the intent to top around and head south to ARTCO’s fleeting area at approx. MM 175 UMR. Once clear of the Merchant’s Bridge the Capt began his turn to starboard. About halfway through the turn (with the tow facing east) the tow began to encounter heavy winds out of the south preventing him from coming full around to head south. The river’s current carried the tow down towards the Merchant’s Bridge, with the tow still facing east. As the tow began to pass under the Missouri side span of the bridge, the lead barge, ART 35341, allided with the bridge pier, broke free from the tow and floated down the UMR. An assist boat recovered the ART 35341 and brought it back to the JILL CAROLYN. The tow was made up and brought to the ARTCO fleet. No damage was reported on the barge or the bridge pier.

At Approximately 1640 on September 9, 2018, BARGE FMT 3050, loaded with ethanol, while DB under the control of the ITV HARVEY SBISA allided with the protection cell on the left descending bank of the CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN RAILROAD BRIDGE (AKA Lower Pekin Railroad),on the Illinois River, Mile Marker 151.2. ITV HARVEY SBISA was pushing a 03 barge tow and FMT 3050 was Second barge in port string.  ITV ARTCO MAIDEN was assisting tow through the bridge. Master stated the tow was about halfway through the bridge when the current set the tow onto the bridge piling. Master reported broken couplings and no damage to the barge.  Master and Bridge Tender reported damage to the sheer fence on the protection cell of the bridge.  MSD Peoria conducted an on scene investigation and confirmed no damage to the barge and an unknown amount of damage to the sheer fence on the bridge. Vessel continued transiting south.

On September 8, 2018, at approximately 1200 local time, the Golden Gate Bridge, Highway and Transportation District small passenger vessel SONOMA, attempted to inflate a 50 man inflatable buoyant apparatus (IBA) during the VMAP-Urban shield drill.  However, the IBA failed to inflate.  

As a result of the investigation, the U.S. Coast Guard determined the cause of the IBA deployment failure was due to the painter line becoming fouled during the packing process.  During the repacking of the IBA in May, the painter line became pinched between the two canister halves and the gasket. This prevented the painter line from being pulled to fire the gas cylinders to inflate the IBA.

On September 18, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received a report of a bridge allision. ITV STEPHEN L COLBY (506770) was southbound pushing 6 dry cargo barges on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 383.9. ITV STEPHEN L COLBY was transiting through the FT. Madison Drawbridge when strong currents carried stern towards the turntable protection cell. The master attempted to regain control but was unsuccessful before alliding with the FT Madison Bridge. The allision resulted in superficial damages of scrapes to the port stern barge and protection pier. No other damage, pollution, or injuries were reported.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determine that the initiating event for this casualty was due to high water and strong currents.

On September 14, 20108, J. N. PHILLIPS (O.N.520414) was down bound on the Upper Mississippi River Mile Marker 282 pushing 12 dry cargo barges. The Master experienced an out draft that caused the J.N. PHILLIPS tow to become out of shape by the high current flows. The lead barges passed through the Louisiana Rail Road Bride spans and the port string second and third back barges IN 075073 (O.N 1198194) and IN 77503 (O.N. 1194838) allided with east pier of the Louisiana Rail Road Bride. The damaged barges were left at a fleeting area in Louisiana MO to be off loaded.

On September 19, 2018 at approximately 0859, the ITV W. STANLEY JAMES towing the HBM 4045, pushing ahead, allided with the Purple People Bridge while down bound on the Ohio River mile mark 469.7.  The HBM 4045 allided with the channel span towards the left descending bank.  Damage was limited to superficial scrapes to the barge and bridge was undamaged.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event was the Master's failure to appropriately judge the distance between the channel span and the lead barge. This was followed by the HBM 4045 alliding with the concrete span. Level of investigation elevated to identify causal factors per OCMI's allision reduction efforts.

On 17-Feb-2018 at about 0515 CST, the UTV CAPT PETE was traveling west bound near MM 60 of the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway when the vessel’s mast pole allided the underside of the Bayou DuLarge Bridge.  This resulted in no damage to the bridge; but, the vessel’s mast was bend back about 15 to 20 degrees.  The cost to repair the damaged bent mast was about $2,500.00.  

During the time of the incident, the vessel was operating under previous owners, Higman Barge Lines’ Safety Management System (SMS).  Since then, the vessel is now under the SMS of Kirby Inland Marine which states that any navigational bridge watch shall not commit to transiting any bridge while it is in the down or closed position without first receiving confirmation from the bridge tender that the air gap is safe.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined the initiating event was the vessel's mast pole alliding the underside of the Bayou Dularge Bridge.  The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: 1) The vessel’s master neglected to request to the bridge tender that the bridge be opened; 2) Also, the master did not confirm with the bridge tender the vessel had sufficient overhead clearance; 3) Depending of tide, the bridge’s air gap is about 50 feet in the down position.  Thus, had the master lowered the vessel's mast pole before going under the bridge, the vessel would have cleared the underside of the bridge by about 3 feet.

On 04SEP18 at approx. 0120 the JAMES FARIS (O.N. 249088) was northbound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) mile marker (MM) 309.9 with four spudded construction barges when it allided with the Hannibal Railroad Drawbridge. While the drawbridge was in the “full open” position, a crane on the deck of the lead barge made contact with the lower expanse truss of the drawbridge bending it inward and knocking the drawbridge off of the guides. Estimates of available air draft below the bridge were approx. 54 ft 8 in (54.7 ft) given current river levels in the area. The height of the top of the crane to the waterline was measured to be approx. 55 ft 11 in (55.9 ft); approx. 1 ft 3 in (1.3 ft) higher than the bridge expanse.

On 04 October 2018, at approximately 2015, the Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) MARY KAY was transiting through the Bayou Blue swing bridge, located at mile marker 49.8 on the Intracoastal Waterway in Houma LA. The UTV was pushing ahead 06 empty hopper barges. During the passage through the opening of the bridge span, the Master noticed the tow was not lined up to clear the bridge and he attempted to make corrections by swinging the lead barges to the starboard. The port bow of the barge allided with the south fender wall. The bridge tender contacted the UTV and the UTV operator acknowledged that the barge allided with the bridge fender wall system. Due to the allision happening at approximately 2015, the damage was not able to be fully assessed until daylight. The UTV then continued its voyage to Morgan City, LA.

On 05 October 2018, the Bayou Blue swing bridge damage was assessed by the bridge tender and bridge supervisor. No damage was observed on the south fence wall of the bridge fender system. The bridge remained operational at all times. No damage was reported to have occurred to the barges.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast has determined that the initiation event for this casualty was the UTV MARY KAY controlling the barge that allided with the Bayou Blue swing bridge. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) UTV operator improperly aligned tow for safe passage through bridge opening,(2)limited visibility to due night time.

On 19OCT2018 at approximately 0555 hrs. ITV CAPT R.P. GETTLEFINGER (7800HP, American Commercial Barge Lines, 568139) was up-bound transiting through the I-57 Highway bridge when the vessel and its tow were set by current and the barge RF 927 on the starboard side of the tow rubbed pier on the left descending bank side of the channel. No damage to the bridge or to the vessel and tow. The vessel was traveling at 1.5 knots up-bound while transiting the bridge. The current was 6.5 KNTS and the the Thebes gauge was at 35.80 ft. and the Cairo gauge was at 38 ft.

Coast Guard investigation revealed the initiating event to be the Allision. Contributing Factors include 1): Loss of Situational Awareness 2) Master did not take into account river current and conditions.

On October 20, 2018 , the CHRIS REEVES (ON 1266623) was transiting up bound on the UMR MM 184 with 15 loaded dry cargo barges. The Master of the CHRIS REEVES miscalculated the ships air draft and the mast allided with the Merchants R/R Bridge. This damaged both radars and mast lights.

On October 26, 2018, at approximately 1705, the towing vessel ROBERT ANTHONY (ON: 1256311) was heading northbound while pushing three empty tank barges on the Illinois Waterway and attempting to transit under the Ottawa Railroad Bridge on the Illinois River at MM 239.5 when the vessel's mast allided with the bridge. The allision knocked off the anchor light and wind indicator. There was no other damage to the vessel, its tow or the bridge. The employer determined alcohol was not a factor in the allision. Initial damage estimate provided by the employer was $2500. The actual cost of repairs to the mast and affected navigation equipment was approximately $1655.00, as stated by the vessel's Port Captain during a phone interview.

During a phone interview the pilot related that when the vessel is operating on the Illinois Waterway, he usually lowers the upper section of the vessel's retractable mast because there are no lights on that section of the mast that the vessel needs while transiting up the waterway. The pilot stated that he had lowered the upper mast section about a day prior to the bridge allision, and that another crewmember had put the mast back up and did not pass the information on to him. Pilot took responsibility for the allision, stating that he should have verified the position of the mast when he assumed the watch but made the mistake of assuming that the mast was still lowered.

Based upon the evidence collected during this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the cause of the casualty was the pilot not verifying the position of the upper retractable section of the vessel's mast when he assumed the watch. When the pilot took the watch he assumed that the mast was still lowered when it wasn't, and that ultimately led the upper section of the mast alliding with the Ottawa Railroad bridge as he attempted to navigate the vessel under the bridge.

On 29OCT18 at approx. 2350 the ITV CAPT BILL STEWART (O.N. 575823) was transiting northbound through the right span (left descending bank (LDB) side) of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge (swing bridge) on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) at mile marker (MM) 282.1 when the tow allided with the turntable cell (center pier of the swing bridge). At the time of the incident the ITV was pushing 14 dry cargo barges and 1 loaded "red flag" tank barge (15 total barges). The allision occurred along the outboard side of the port string on the 3rd (CHEM 801) and 4th (BOI 1241) barges back from the head of the tow.  The Capt. reported a stronger than expected current (due to high water) caused the tow to set over on the turntable cell approx. halfway down the port string. No broken wires or damage were reported on the barges or the turntable cell (bridge).

On November 1, 2018, at approximately 2215 Eastern Standard Time (EST) the towing vessel DOUG TURNER  was pushing four loaded barges down bound when it allided with the Spottsville Rail Road Drawbridge. The vessel locked through Lock & Dam 1 on the Green River and was headed down bound. As the vessel was going through the right descending side of the bridge it allided with the center span and damaged the port stern barge. 

Three of the barges broke free and the port stern barge stayed in the tow and started to list because it was taking on water. The damaged barge was pushed into the right descending bank and the vessel collected the 3 adrift barges and also push them into the right descending bank approximately one mile down river. There was no damage to the two starboard barges and a 6" gouge in radius of gunwale over a length of 13' in the port lead barge. 

The port stern barge's starboard stern compartment was flooded to the river level due to a hole below the water line. The barge was lightered and moved to mile marker 4 for all the cargo to be off loaded. The barge was taken to Paducah, KY for permanent repairs.

The Coast Guard's investigation found the initiating event was a navigation error that was caused by the Master not compensating for the high water & currents to make a safe passage under the bridge.

Investigation Level raised to Informal with Causal Analysis, per OCMI Bridge Allision reduction initiative.

On 03 November 2018, at approximately 0642, the 44 foot Uninspected Towing Vessel (UTV) CAPT. JIM pushing ahead barge MISS COLLETTE II departed Hot Energy dock in Houma, LA with two crewmembers onboard, the master and a secondary master. During the south transit to Cocodrie, LA, the master of the UTV CAPT. JIM hailed the Houma Navigational Canal Swing Bridge one half mile away to request the bridge to open so the master could transit through. Due to other vessel traffic in the area, the Master of CAPT. JIM made passing arrangements with the north bound Motor Vessel CHRIS W and the Towing Vessel SVI for vessel traffic sequence through the Houma Navigational Canal Swing Bridge passage. Once the two vessels completed the passage through the bridge opening, the master of the UTV CAPT. JIM began to maneuver his UTV with the barge MISS COLLETTE II through the bridge opening. While in the bridge passage, the bridge operator closed the Houma Navigational Canal Swing Bridge. The bridge struck the starboard side of the barge MISS COLLETTE II and pushed the barge into the east retaining wall. The bottom of the bridge became wedged onto the starboard cleat of the barge MISS COLLETTE II.

The bridge impact onto the barge detached the south east hydraulic roller wedge ram rendering the bridge shutdown to vehicle traffic. When the impact and consequential detachment of the bridge hydraulic roller wedge ram occurred, it created a hydraulic fluid leak onto the barge and navigable waterway. The bridge sustained approximately $45,000 in damages. The MISS COLLETTE sustained damage consisting of a two inch by four inch inset to its forward starboard spud, three feet of the forward oil containment coaming and three stanchions to its starboard side hand rail. The damage totaled approximately $10,000.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the bridge closing on the barge MISS COLLETTE II. This was followed by the bridge striking the barge until the barge was pinned against the bridges' east retaining wall. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) lack of clear communication between passing vessels and the bridge operator, (2) bridge operator keeping insufficient tracking record of transiting vessels, (3) not broadcasting via VHF that the bridge will close so vessels in the area knew not to transit.

On 17OCT2018, Sector Ohio Valley command center received notification from the Inspected Towing Vessel (ITV) ENID DIBERT (ON 1044131) of an allision that occurred between a barge (uninspected and loaded coal barge) in the ENID DIBERT 's tow and the Try Street Railroad Bridge.  The ENID DIBERT was upbound near mile marker 1 on the Monongahela River pushing 15 loaded coal barges.  The Master of the ENID DIBERT reported the head of the tow was initially passing through the bridge span as planned, but unexpectedly the head of the tow was set to starboard by river current.  When the master noticed the tow being set to starboard he realized that he could not completely overcome the effects of the current, so he backed down and stopped the forward movement of the tow.  With no forward movement, the forces of the current pushed the barge into the Try Street Railroad Bridge.  Once along side the bridge, the master of the vessel was able to swing the head of the tow back to port, align the tow for safe passage through the bridge span and continue under bridge without further contact.  During the allision with the bridge several wires were broken ($1,200) on the port side of the tow, however there was no damage to the barge that contacted the bridge.  The bridge owners reported there were no damages sustained to the bridge.  The vessel's Master was tested for alcohol as required by company policy and test was found to be.  There were no injuries or pollution as a result of this marine casualty.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the barge and the bridge.  The master had made this trip several times before during similar river and weather conditions.  Despite the similar river stage/weather conditions to previous trips, this trip's river currents were reported (by the master) to be stronger than anticipated.  In addition, the master reported that the prevailing winds at the time of the incident were blowing from starboard to port in the vessel's direction of travel.  The master further reported that he counted on the winds to counter the set and drift of the expected current, though this did not occur as anticipated.    

Recommend this incident investigation activity be closed with no further referrals.

At approximately 0845 Eastern Standard Time (EST) on November 06, 2018, the Inspected Towing Vessel (ITV) CRYSTAL D TAYLOR (Ingram Barge Company, 503329, 6400HP, COI) was pushing 15 loaded coal barges down bound when the port lead barge (ING 2318) allided with the left descending pier of the Southern Railroad Bridge at MM 472.5 OHR (Cincinnati, OH). The damaged barge was inset 5ft at port bow with two fractures below the water line. The vessel pushed in to the right descending bank at MM 479 OHR. 

The Coast Guard's investigation found the towing vessel was out of position on the approach to the bridge, causing the port lead barge to allide with the center span of the railroad bridge. Level of investigation elevated to identify causal factors per OCMI's allision reduction efforts.

On 06NOV2018 at approximately 1600, while pushing 12 empty hopper barges down bound through the R. J. CORMAN R/R Bridge at mm 126.5 CMB, the M/V MAR MIYASAKI’s tow allided with bridge pier/support nearest to the left descending bank side of the river. The barge ING 5717 in the starboard string, came in contact with the pier/support on its starboard side, resulting in no visible damage to the bridge or barge. The bridge tender/owner confirmed no damage.

The CG investigation identified the allision as the initiating event and causal factor(s): navigation in response to the river current setting the tow toward right descending bank; (1) the master backed down to reduce speed and; (2) master used the bridge pier to stop the starboard momentum and slide of the tow. Enforcement referral made based on moving vessel striking a charted fixed object, outside the recommended sail line.

M/V CAPT GREGORY SMITH 9000 HP (ACBL) with 35 barges in tow allided with the Vicksburg R/R & I20 bridges at MM 435.8 LMR. The captain of the vessel stated that 20 dry cargo barges (17 loads/03 empties) of the 35 barges broke away and were adrift. 02 barges were damaged by the bridge pier, and 01 sank at the bridge pier. SECLMR CC issued waterway restriction for no vessels to transit between MM 437-420 LMR. SECLMR CC contacted Vicksburg Bridge Commission and bridge inspectors are enroute. State police were notified, inspected the roadway of the I-20 bridge and found no damage. The cause of the allision was determined to be a planning failure by the captain, when he was expecting a hard set to push his tow through, but never got the push.

At approximately 0330 on November 11th, 2018 the UTV SCOUT, pushing 2 double up empty barges struck both the north and south fenders of the West Port Arthur Bridge due to high winds. No damage, pollution or injuries reported to the vessel or barges and 60,000 dollars to the bridge fendering systme in way of broke pilings. Vessel was able to get right back underway and continue through the bridge without further incident.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that Captain on board the UTV SCOUT underestimated the wind effect on the barges being pushed ahead causing the Captain of the UTV SCOUT to misjudge the placement of the vessel and barges while transiting under the West Port Arthur Bridge which led to the allision.

On November 7, 2018, at approximately 0734, the container ship VENICE BRIDGE lost propulsion while departing the Port of Los Angeles. The vessel pushed off the docks via tug assist and upon the Pilot ordering the engine "slow astern", the engine did not respond and "M/E start fail" alarm resulted. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the failure of #1 and #6 fuel pump puncture valves. The failure of the puncture valves caused inadequate fuel injection required to start the main engine.  The lack of injection caused the main engine, the vessel's sole source of propulsion, to not respond. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) sludge build-up on the puncture valves, and (2) inadequate maintenance periods.

At approximately 2350 local time on 12NOV18, the ITV BOBBY JOHNSON (Hines Furlong, 1262984, 1200HP) allided with the Jefferson Street bridge at MM 190 CMB.  The vessel had the empty red flag barge, the T/V AI 513, in tow and was transiting in reverse down bound to the Hines Furlong fleet at mm 176, when the barge went wide and laid up against the left descending pier allegedly due to being set by wind and current.

The master intentionally backed towing vessel (flank manuever) in effort to stay close to the bank to transit the bridge for better control.  The vessel was estimated to be making 2 mph with a current of 4 mph.  Winds were present at 15 mph from the SW.  The river's estimated flow was over 30,000 cfs according to Nashville, TN flow meter.  As the barge began to set wide toward the bridge structure, the master took evasive action by reducing speed before alliding with the bridge structure.  No post-casualty damage to the bridge or barge was identified or observed.

The investigation revealed that the tow did allide with the Jefferson Street Bridge after being set by current and wind while transiting with astern (reverse) propulsion (flanking).  The crew was aware of waterway and weather conditions before transiting.  The allision with the bridge raises the presumption of negligence, when a moving vessel strikes a fixed/charted object, as described in 46 USCG 7703(1)(B).

On October 28, 2018, at approximately 1600 LMT, the 71-foot twin screw towing vessel ELLIE J (O.N. 517804) was pushing the 260-foot empty scrap steel hopper barge SJ 160 (O.N. 651507) north on the Southern Branch Elizabeth River and was approaching the Gilmerton Bridge on the Gilmerton Bridge Reach. At the same time, the 54-foot recreation vessel CAFÉ PETRON (O.N. 1240010) was transiting south on the Southern Branch Elizabeth River at approximately 14 knots and was approaching the Gilmerton Bridge from the north. The Gilmerton Bridge operator began raising the bridge for the ELLIE J and SJ 160 to pass underneath, but he saw the CAFÉ PETRON approaching the restricted visibility turn at the bridge and attempted to contact the CAFÉ PETRON on channel 13 without success. Due to CAFÉ PETRON's rapid approach to the restricted visibility turn and narrow channel underneath the bridge, the ELLIE J began sounding the danger signal and backing down as the tug and barge passed underneath the Gilmerton Bridge. The bridge operator was able to hail the CAFÉ PETRON on channel 16 and the CAFÉ PETRON stopped short of the Gilmerton Bridge. However, the ELLIE J lost maneuverability due to backing down at the bridge, and at 1615 LMT the starboard bow of the barge allided with the east side fender system.

After the starboard bow of the SJ 160 allided with the Gilmerton Bridge fender system, the ELLIE J and SJ 160 continued north to the Norfolk Tug Company facility in Norfolk, Virginia. The CAFÉ PETRON waited until the ELLIE J and SJ 160 were clear of the Gilmerton Bridge and then continued south on the Elizabeth River. The crew of the ELLIE J determined there was no detectable damage to the barge from the allision, and the Gilmerton Bridge employees determined there was no detectable damage to the bridge fender system from the allision. 

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event was the allision of the SJ 160 with the Gilmerton Bridge fender system. The causal factors that contribute to the casualty include: (1) restricted maneuverability through the Gilmerton Bridge fender system, (2) restricted visibility as vessels approach a tight turn in the channel, and (3) failure to establish radio communications with vessels in a meeting situation.  

Recommend closing this incident investigation activity without a referral to an enforcement activity.

On 13NOV18 the ITV MIKE BIRD, pushing 4 empty fertalizer barges, was tranisting the Sabula Railroad Bridge headed Southbound on the UMR at MM 535. The Vessel allided with the center pier protection cell of the bridge when the Captain was unable to steer clear due to high current and winds.  The vessel reported that the Port head of the tow had made contact, but sustained no damage. The bridge reported some concrete had been chipped away on the bullnose but was still fully operational. The ITV MIKE BIRD continued on route to Peoria.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard determined that that the Allision was caused by high wind and current which hindered the captian's ability to manuever and set the vessel toward the bridge's protection cell.

On 23 November 2018, at approximately 1340 local time, the 152-foot small passenger vessel SAN FRANCISCO (O.N. 586350) departed Larkspur ferry terminal en route the San Francisco Ferry Terminal, with fifty-three passengers onboard. The vessel proceeded as planned and approached the San Francisco Ferry Terminal. The Master slowed the vessel and waited for the vessel traffic in the area to clear. The Master then began maneuvering to bring the vessel into its slip at the San Francisco Ferry Terminal. 

At approximately 1430, while the vessel was approaching the outer berth mooring location, the Master realized he did not have throttle control on the port bridge wing. The vessel struck the San Francisco Ferry Terminal in three locations prior to the Master being able to declutch the vessel’s port engine. The port engine's revolutions per minute (RPMs) remained at approximately 1140 during all three of the allision events.

The vessel sustained visible damage to the bow/port bow section of the vessel (all above the waterline).  A three-foot fracture was visible on the bow approximately five feet above waterline.  Another inset was observed approximately 10-feet after of the stem approximately nine-feet above the waterline. A crewmember sustained minor injuries.

All five crewmembers (Master, Relief Master, three deckhands) were directed to undergo post-casualty drug and alcohol testing.

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard determined that the initiating event (first unwanted outcome) was the Master's inadvertent and unknown activation of the Port Main Engine's RPM Backup Mode. The initiating event caused the subsequent loss of vessel maneuverability while the vessel was alongside the pier. The Master did not realize that control of the port engine's RPMs was locked at the navigation bridge's center control console location. The primary causal factors that led to the accidental Backup Mode activation and loss of vessel control were:  
1) The lack of a physical cover to prevent accidental touching or bumping of the rocker-style switch that moves the RPM controls from Auto to Backup Mode; 
2) The lack of an audible or visual alarm that would alert the vessel operator that the main engine's RPM control modes were switched from Auto to Backup; 
3) The Master's failure to adhere to company policy and guidance regarding transferring control stations onboard the SAN FRANCISCO and;
4) The inaccurate information contained within the automated propulsion controls operating manual pertaining to the transferring of control stations onboard the SAN FRANCISCO.

The next subsequent events occurred when the vessel allided with the outer berth, inner berth, and finally a pedestrian walkway located at the San Francisco Ferry Terminal. There were no failed or inadequate defense factors or latent unsafe conditions that could have reasonably prevented these allisions from occurring following the initiating event because the master did not have ample enough time to respond to the loss of vessel propulsion control. Similiarly, there were no failed or inadequate defense factors or latent unsafe conditions that directly led to the vessel and facility damage or the minor injuries sustained by the crewmember located on the bow of the vessel, once the allisions occurred.

While not a direct causal factor, the investigation concluded that the U.S. Coast Guard failed to provide proper project management oversight during the automated propulsion control system's installation in December of 2015.  The investigation did not find conclusive proof that such oversight, with associated testing procedures, would have necessarily identified the inconsistencies between the automated control manufacturer's manual and actual control system operations. However, it is reasonable to believe that these flaws may have been discovered by proper Coast Guard inspection oversight during design verification and periodic testing procedures.

On November 23, 2018, at approximately 1210 hrs CST, the towing vessel KIOWA (O.N. 501784) was underway with 07 crewmembers on board and pushing an undocumented/uninspected dredge barge (ID'd locally by owner as the Twinkle barge) along the Illinois River and attempting to pass under the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad bridge near mile marker 290, when a spud on the dredge barge made contact with the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern railroad bridge. The impact of the allision pushed the dredge barge back into the KIOWA, puncturing the keel cooler for the KIOWA's port main engine. No other damage was noted on the KIOWA, the dredge barge, or the bridge. Alcohol testing was completed per the vessel operator's company policy and the results were.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the dredge barge alliding with the Elgin, Joliet, & Eastern Railroad bridge. This was followed by the collision between the dredge barge and the ITV KIOWA, and the puncturing of the KIOWA's PORT main engine keel cooler. The casual factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1)Vessel's completed safety checklist did not include an assessment of the air draft of the vessel and it's tow, (2) Company's pre-underway safety checklist provided to the vessel, did not include air draft assessments required by 46 CFR 140.635, (3) Crew was not trained/aware of the Navigation assessment requirements under 46 CFR 140.635 which include assessing air draft relative to vertical clearance of bridges along the vessel's route, (4) The air draft of the dredge barge with its spuds, exceeded the vertical clearance under the Elgin, Joliet and Eastern Railroad bridge at mile marker 290 on the Illinois waterway.

On November 24, 2018 at approximately 1435 LMT, the towing vessel COASTAL TRADER (O.N. 1208724) was underway pushing ahead the loaded scrap steel barge SJ 400 (O.N. 647799), when the SJ 400 allided with the Pungo Ferry Bridge wood pile fender. The allision occurred as the COASTAL TRADER was navigating on the North Landing River. The Mate, who was in charge of the navigational watch, attempted to line up the barge to complete the transit through the Pungo Ferry Bridge, when the port bow of the SJ 400 made contact with the northeast portion of the wood pile fender.  

A bridge surveyor with the City of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works conducted a survey of the bridge and confirmed that there was no structural damage to the bridge, only to the timber pile fender system. Sector Hampton Roads Marine Investigators were provided with an initial damage estimate of $300,000.00, which was used to determine the level of investigation. It was later determined the total damage cost was $530,264.40. There was no damage to the tug or barge.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event was the improper vessel maneuver by the Mate. The subsequent event was the bridge allision. The causal factors that contributed to the incident are: (1) execution error-attention failure: the Mate failed to take early and substantial action to avoid allision with the wood pile fender system by incorrectly factoring width of bridge span, and dimensions of the barge to safely transit through.

Recommend closing the incident investigation activity with a referral to enforcement.

On November 11, 2018, the BRANDON G BUCHANAN (O.N. 567698) was up bound with 15 empty dry cargo barges at MM 282 UMR. The Master BRANDON G BUCHANAN misaligned passing through the Louisiana R/R Bridge span and Barge ACBL 00516 (O.N. 1099657) located in the port string third back rubbed the center span north protection cell.

On 18NOV2018 at approximately 0620, the P/V AMERICAN DUCHESS (277.6') carrying 228 passengers, allided with the RJ CORMAN RAILROAD BRIDGE while up bound at mile 125.6 on the Cumberland River.  The vessel approached the swing bridge in its fully opened position and transited through the right descending span of the bridge.  

Navigating from the starboard side bridge wing, the master made use of z-drives, paddlewheel and two bow thrusters at an estimated vessel speed of 1 mph. Lookouts were posted on the main deck and port bridge wing.  The breadth of the vessel is measured at 99' and the span of the bridge is 118' wide.  The river flow was documented at 52,000 cubic feet per second below Cheatham lock according to USGS/ACOE waterway data and decreasing.  The master states that an unanticipated current shift set the vessel toward the bridge causing the starboard decorative exhaust stack to allide with the open swing bridge structure. 

The investigation determined that the initiating event was the P/V AMERICAN DUCHESS allision with the RJ CORMAN RAILROAD BRIDGE.  Causal factors include; the master's anticipation of being set toward the right descending riverbank and away from the bridge’s swing structure, based on a previous down bound transit.  The vessel was set toward the left descending riverbank/swing bridge structure and did not have sufficient maneuvering allowance/space for course correction to avoid the allision.  Post incident, the bridge remained fully operational with superficial damages identified by engineering survey.  Damage to the vessel was cosmetic in nature.

On 30OCT2018, the Inspected Towing Vessel (ITV) CINCINNATI (Marathon Petroleum, 1126162, 2600HP) was pushing 3 empty red flag barges (previous cargos were asphalt) south bound at MM 8.6 of the Monongahela River passing beneath the CSX TRANS. (HOT METAL) RAILROAD BRIDGE (LLNR 22635) when the tow was set by high wind and the lead barge struck the right descending pier. The barge sustained a 6" indent 200' back from the head, above the waterline. The ITV reports no other damage (besides ~$30k to barge), pollution or injury. The ITV's final destination is Catlettsburg, KY.  There was no reported damage to the bridge.

Investigator and Marine Inspector from MSU Pittsburgh attended vessel for investigation and barge inspection.  Mariner stated wind set the barge onto the bridge and there were no mechanical issues with the vessel prior to the allision.  Reviewed all electronic means of communication (vessel and pilot phones/email/text) and determined no distractions contributed to this allision.  

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined the initiating event for this casualty was the allision between the empty tank barge MAP 725 and the bridge.  The mariner claimed weather (high winds) to be a contributing factor for this casualty; however, there was no evidence of inclement weather discovered or provided to support this claim.

Recommend this incident investigation activity be closed after a referral for enforcement.

02 DEC 18 - M/V MARIE HENDERICK 8000 HP (Marquette) with 35 loaded dry cargo barges in tow SB enroute NOLA reports grounding the STBD lead barge on the RDB of the channel at MM 612.9 LMR causing 02 barges to breakaway. M/V MARIE HENDERICK is pushed in on the RDB at MM 612 LMR approximately 100 ft north of the 05 barges. M/V BRIDGET CAULLEY 3200 HP (Kirby Inland Marine) secured the 01 remaining adrift barge and will assist in putting it back into the tow of M/V MARIE HENDERICK. M/V BRIDGET CAULLEY caused damage above the waterline to the adrift barge when catching it. The extent of the damage to any of the barges is UNK ATT. Marine surveyors will be conducting an inspection of the barges with UNK ETA. Drug and alcohol testing is being conducted per company policy regardless of the SMI threshold requiring it. SECLMR CC issued SMIB advising mariners of the location of the barges, vessel and to transit the area with caution. OU briefed SECLMR DMI on case details. 

Investigation revealed master swung too wide in the bend and grounded outside of the channel.

ITV MIKE BIRD (Kirby Inland Marine, 561721, 3000HP) was pushing 2 loaded red flag barges (Vacuum Gas Oil) lining up for the right descending span of the CSX R/R Bridge at MM 0.8 BSR, when the pilot changed his mind and tried to line up for the left descending span. The ITV struck the center pier with the lead barge (Kirby 27782) causing a 7' indent in the bow rake. The barges were taken to Marathon Crude Dock at MM 3.1 BSR. The barge has been inspected and found to be serviceable. No damage was done to the RR bridge.

Master misjudged the current which lead to the allision and subsequent damage to the barge.

On 26 NOV 18 at approx. 0630 the ITV LEONARD WHITTINGTON (O.N. 575826) was northbound transiting below the Martin Luther King Bridge (MLK) on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) mile marker (MM) 180.2 pushing 20 dry cargo barges when the MEM 5001 allided with the bridge. Excessive winds out of the west/northwest (20+ mph with 30+ mph gusts) set the tow off to the starboard side of the channel during the transit. The Capt attempted to correct but the wind conditions were too much to overcome and the starboard aft most barge (MEM 5001) came into contact with the Illinois-side pier of the main channel span of the MLK Bridge. Once tow was clear of the bridge, the Master pushed the tow in along IL bank and crew inspected barge and ITV for damage; none noted. Contacted ILDOT for bridge to be inspected; no damage reported.

The ITV ROBERT E. MURRAY II (1273130, Murray Transportation, 2600HP) was transiting down bound, was set by the wind and currents and made contact with the B&O RR Bridge, MM184.3 OHR. The ITV was pushing 15 empty barges to Reedsville, OH, MM 205 OHR. Visual inspection by the ITV crew showed no damage to their tow, and no visible damage to the bridge. MSU HUNT received a 2692 and the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad representative of the incident indicated that there was no damage to the Rail Road Bridge.

The investigation revealed the captain used the fending system as designed to fender off the bridge and was part of his navigation assessment and not an unintentional strike of a bridge as originally reported.

On 03 Dec 2018, at approximately 1920, the CROSBY RAM was under way with the LB ROBERT in tow on the Houma Navigation Channel at Mile Marker 23. The MISS CROSBY and the CROSBY HUNTERT were acting as tethers for the LB ROBERT, both the vessels were positioned behind the LB ROBERT to assist the CROSBY RAM control the movement of the LB ROBERT. While approaching the Dulac Pontoon Bridge the master of the CROSBY RAM relayed the plan to the crews of the two other vessels and the crew of the LB ROBERT. While making its way through the Dulac Pontoon Bridge the CROSBY RAM noticed the LB ROBERT was drifting too far to the starboard side and the master gave verbal directions to the vessels in the rear to correct the movement. The vessels were unable to make the corrections necessary and the master of the LB ROBERT engaged the thrusters on the vessel, which lessened the impact on the bridge. After the LB ROBERT made contact on the bridge the master of the LB ROBERT continued to use the thrusters to move the LB ROBERT away from the bridge. 

The CROSBY RAM and the two other vessel were able to gain positive control of the LB ROBERT and continued their transit to the CROSBY shipyard in Houma LA. The bridge supervisor stated there was minimal damage to the Dulac Pontoon Bridge. The fairlead and the pulley were knocked out of place making the bridge stuck in the open position until the repairs were made the following day. 

As a result of this investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the bridge being struck by the LB ROBERT. The causal factors that contributed to this casualty include: (1) the slack in the tethering lines, (2) miscommunication between the master of the CROSBY RAM and the LB ROBERT.

At approximately 1430 on December 03, 2018, MSD Quad Cities received a report of an allision between KATIE ANN (ON# 288474) and the Sabula Railroad Bridge. The KATIE ANN was southbound on the Upper Mississippi River at MM 535 pushing 03 deck barges configured with the #1 and #2 in line and #3 on the port side. The #3 hit the protection pier breaking away from the tow. The breakaway swung the other two barges and vessel off course and the #1 hit the turntable, damaging the walkway plank and handrail and breaking up the concrete. The cables of the walkway were caught in the gears of the turntable preventing the bridge from swinging open or close. When the #3 (NMS14) hit the turntable protection pier, the spudwell punched a two foot by two foot hole on the its port side approximately four feet above the waterline.

As a result of the investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the allision with the turntable protection pier. The subsequent event was another allision with the actual turntable.

On Novemeber 30, 2018, the MARY ELIZABETH (O.N. 284066) was down bound on the ILLINOIS River Mile Marker 56 pushing 4 loaded unregulated tank barges. The Master of the MARY ELIZABETH had to make a course correct while transiting through the bridge span and made a controlled unintended landing with the port lead barge STC 3014 (O.N. 982559)on the upper protection cell of the Florence HWY Drawbridge.

On 16 December, 2018, the Passenger Vessel CIRCLE LINE QUEENS (O.N. 1218805) allided with the BROADWAY BRIDGE.  There was only superficial damage to the vessel and  no damage to the bridge.
The vessel was traveling west in the Spuyten Duyvil Creek, underneath the BROADWAY Bridge, at less than 1 knot with 121 persons onboard when the overhead of its bridge made contact with a bolt head fastened to the BROADWAY BRIDGE.  The contact caused an approximately 2-inch wide and 1-inch deep inset into the metal of the overhead, causing a small crack in the metal.  
The Coast Guard's investigation concluded that the water level was higher than normal.  The predicted bridge clearance at the time of the incident was expected to be 24 feet while the vessel's air draft was 23 feet, 8 inches.  Expecting to have approximately four inches of clearance, the vessel's master proceed under the bridge at less than one knot.  Upon realizing that there was not enough clearance, the vessel's master placed the vessel in astern propulsion and backed out of the bridge.  
There was no damage to the bridge and no injuries.  The attending Marine Inspector determined that there was no need for immediate repairs and did not issue any requirements.

On November 17, 2018, the ITV THOMAS E ERICKSON (O.N. 581142) was transiting north bound on the Upper Mississippi River (UMR) at mile marker 282.1, pushing 16 empty dry cargo barges, when the port  stern barge, the MTC 7359 (O.N. 1220386), allided with the southern protection cell of the Louisiana Railroad Bridge.  The cause of the allision was attributed to strong winds in the area. The vessel operator reported no damage to the barge or bridge. Bridge representatives confirmed no damage to the bridge. No further damage, pollution, or injuries.

On 21NOV2018 at approximately 1245 local time, the Inspected Towing Vessel (ITV) MV O. NELSON JONES (ON 294844) was transiting upriver in the vicinity of mile 6 of the Monongahela River pushing 3 loaded (uninspected) coal barges.  During the transit, and while in the channel, the vessel's Master reported the ITV grounded on an uncharted object.  As a result, wires broke on the barges in tow and the two lead barges broke free of the tow and continued forward motion towards the CSX TRANS. RAILROAD BRIDGE.  The two barges that broke free were headed up river and lost the majority of their headway before alliding with the CSX TRANS. RAILROAD BRIDGE.  The ITV was able to free itself from its grounded position and recover both of the barges that broke free.  The tow of 3 barges was reassembled and the vessels continued on their intended voyage.  There were no reported injuries, pollution or damage to the barges or bridge.  The damage reported in the incident was limited to 4 broken wires and a ratchet.

This grounding occurred in waters that were reported by the USGS to have a depth greater than the 8.5ft the ITV was drafting.  The United States Army Corps of Engineers (USACOE) conducted a survey of the area and could find no obstructions.  The USACOE also charted the ITVs trackline from the incident and determined the vessel never left the navigation channel during the transit that led to the grounding.

As a result of its investigation, the Coast Guard has determined that the initiating event for this casualty was the grounding of the MV O. NELSON JONES.   Subsequent events include the breakaway of two barges and their eventual allision with a railroad bridge.  The casual factor that contributed to this casualty was a water depth that was less than expected by the Master and less than reported by the USACOE.

Recommend this incident investigation sctivity be closed with no further referrals.

On December 16, 2018 at approximately 1515, the 75 foot uncertificated Inspected Towing Vessel (ITV) was transiting on the Intracoastal Waterway in Houma pushing ahead six loaded uninspected barges that were loaded with limestone.
